English workmen completely lose their balance.

sn.def: An equality between the sums total of the two sides of an account; as, to bring one's accounts to a balance ; -- also, the excess on either side; as, the balance of an account.
sn.q: Abalanceat the banker's.
I still think the balance of probabilities leans towards the account given in the text.

sn.def: A balance wheel, as of a watch, or clock. See Balance wheelin the Vocabulary).

sd.def: The constellation Libra.
The seventh sign in the Zodiac, called Libra, which the sun enters at the equinox in September.

sn.def: A movement in dancing. See Balance v. t., 8.

entry.cs: Balanced valve. See Balance valve, under Balance n.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Balanced băl"�nst; p. pr. & vb. n. Balancing băl"�n*sĭng
entry.ety: From Balance n.: cf. F. balancer

sn.def: To bring to an equipoise, as the scales of a balance by adjusting the weights; to weigh in a balance.
To support on a narrow base, so as to keep from falling; as, to balance a plate on the end of a cane; to balance one's self on a tight rope.
To equal in number, weight, force, or proportion; to counterpoise, counterbalance, counteract, or neutralize.
sn.q: One expression . . . must check and balance another.

sn.def: To compare in relative force, importance, value, etc.; to estimate.
sn.q: Balance the good and evil of things.

sn.def: To settle and adjust, as an account; to make two accounts equal by paying the difference between them.
sn.q: I am very well satisfied that it is not in my power to balance accounts with my Maker.

sn.def: To make the sums of the debits and credits of an account equal; -- said of an item; as, this payment, or credit, balances the account.
To arrange accounts in such a way that the sum total of the debits is equal to the sum total of the credits; as, to balance a set of books.
To move toward, and then back from, reciprocally; as, to balance partners.
To contract, as a sail, into a narrower compass; as, to balance the boom mainsail.
sn.syn: To poise; weigh; adjust; counteract; neutralize; equalize.

sn.def: To have equal weight on each side; to be in equipoise; as, the scales balance .
To fluctuate between motives which appear of equal force; to waver; to hesitate.
sn.q: He would not balance or err in the determination of his choice.

sn.def: To move toward a person or couple, and then back.

entry.def: Such as can be balanced.

entries.entry: bal"anced adj. being in a state of proper balance or equilibrium; -- opposite of unbalanced. the carefully balanced seesaw a properly balanced symphony orchestra a balanced assessment of intellectual and cultural history a balanced blend of whiskeys the educated man shows a balanced development of all his powersNarrower terms: counterbalanced, counter-balanced, counterpoised; well-balanced; poised] [Related terms: stable --- (maintaining equilibrium)

entry.def: The act or result of balancing or adjusting; equipoise; even adjustment of forces.

sn.def: One who balances, or uses a balance.
In Diptera, the rudimentary posterior wing.

entry.def: The last reef in a fore-and-aft sail, taken to steady the ship.

entries.entry:
Bal"ance wheel`. Horology
A wheel which regulates the beats or pulses of a watch or chronometer, answering to the pendulum of a clock; -- often called simply a balance.
A ratchet-shaped scape wheel, which in some watches is acted upon by the axis of the balance wheel proper (in those watches called a balance).
Mach A wheel which imparts regularity to the movements of any engine or machine; a fly wheel.

entry.ety: L. balanus acorn + -ferous
entry.def: Bearing or producing acorns.

entry.ety: L. balanus acorn: cf. F. balanite
entry.def: A fossil balanoid shell.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ba`lanos acorn + glw^ssa tongue
entry.def: A peculiar marine worm. See Enteropneusta, and Tornaria.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`lanos acorn + -oid
entry.def: Resembling an acorn; -- applied to a group of barnacles having shells shaped like acorns. See Acornshell, and Barnacle.

entries.entry: Bal"as ru`by. OE. bales balais, F. balais, LL. balascus, fr. Ar. balakhsh, so called from Badakhshan Balashan, or Balaxiam, a place in the neighborhood of Samarkand, where this ruby is found Min A variety of spinel ruby, of a pale rose red, or inclining to orange. See Spinel.

entry.ety: Sp., prob. fr. native name

sn.def: A West Indian sapotaceous tree (Bumelia retusa).

entry.ety: L. balaustium, Gr. balay`stion
entry.def: The pomegranate tree (Punica granatum). The bark of the root, the rind of the fruit, and the flowers are used medicinally.

entry.ety: F., lit., a female sweeper
entry.def: A protecting ruffle or frill, as of silk or lace, sewed close to the lower edge of a skirt on the inside.

entry.ety: L. balbutire, fr. balbus stammering: cf. F. balbutier
entry.def: To stammer.
The defect of stammering; also, a kind of incomplete pronunciation.
A balcony.
Having balconies.

entries.entry:
Bal"co*ny ☞ “The accent has shifted from the second to the first syllable within these twenty years.” băl"k�*n�; 277 n.; pl.Balconies băl"k�*nĭz. It. balcone; cf. It. balco palco, scaffold, fr. OHG. balcho palcho, beam, G. balken. See Balk beam
Arch A platform projecting from the wall of a building, usually resting on brackets or consoles, and inclosed by a parapet; as, a balcony in front of a window. Also, a projecting gallery in places of amusement; as, the balcony in a theater.
A projecting gallery once common at the stern of large ships.

cs.cd: the fishhawk or osprey.
a name of the European coot (Fulica atra), alluding to the bare patch on the front of the head.

entry.ety: OE. balled ballid, perh. the p. p. of ball to reduce to the roundness or smoothness of a ball, by removing hair. √85. But cf. W. bali whiteness in a horse's forehead

sn.def: Destitute of the natural or common covering on the head or top, as of hair, feathers, foliage, trees, etc.; as, a bald head; a bald oak.
sn.q: On the bald top of an eminence.

sn.def: Destitute of ornament; unadorned; bare; literal.
sn.q: In the preface to his own bald translation.

sn.def: Undisguised.
sn.q: Baldegotism.

sn.def: Destitute of dignity or value; paltry; mean.
Destitute of a beard or awn; as, bald wheat.

sd.def: Destitute of the natural covering.
Marked with a white spot on the head; bald-faced.

entry.ety: LL. baldachinus baldechinus, a canopy of rich silk carried over the host; fr. Bagdad, It. Baldacco, a city in Turkish Asia from whence these rich silks came: cf. It. baldacchino. Cf. Baudekin

sn.def: A rich brocade; baudekin.
A structure in form of a canopy, sometimes supported by columns, and sometimes suspended from the roof or projecting from the wall; generally placed over an altar; as, the baldachin in St. Peter's.
A portable canopy borne over shrines, etc., in procession.

entries.entry: Bald" ea"gle ☞ The bald eagle is represented in the coat of arms, and on the coins, of the United States.. Zoöl The white-headed eagle (Haliæetus leucocephalus) of America. The young, until several years old, lack the white feathers on the head.

entry.ety: Icel. Baldr, akin to E. bold
entry.def: The most beautiful and beloved of the gods; the god of peace; the son of Odin and Freya.

entry.ety: Of uncertain origin: cf. Dan. balder noise, clatter, and E. dash; hence, perhaps, unmeaning noise, then hodgepodge, mixture; or W. baldorduss a prattling, baldordd baldorddi, to prattle

sn.def: A worthless mixture, especially of liquors.
sn.q: Indeed beer, by a mixture of wine, hath lost both name and nature, and is called balderdash.

sn.def: Senseless jargon; ribaldry; nonsense; trash.

entry.def: To mix or adulterate, as liquors.
entry.q: The wine merchants of Nice brew and balderdash, and even mix it with pigeon's dung and quicklime.

entry.def: Having a white face or a white mark on the face, as a stag.

sn.def: A person whose head is bald.
A white-headed variety of pigeon.

entry.def: Having a bald head; lacking hair on all or most of the scalp; -- alsp called bald and bald-pated; as, a bald-headed gentleman.
Nakedly; without reserve; inelegantly.
The state or condition of being bald; as, baldness of the head; baldness of style.
entry.q: This gives to their syntax a peculiar character of simplicity and baldness.

sn.def: A baldheaded person.
The American widgeon (Anas Americana).

entry.def: Destitute of hair on the head; baldheaded.
A piece of pork cut lower down than the sparerib, and destitute of fat.

entry.ety: OE. baudric bawdrik, through OF. (cf. F. baudrier and LL. baldringus baldrellus), from OHG. balderich, cf. balz palz, akin to E. belt. See Belt n.
entry.def: A broad belt, sometimes richly ornamented, worn over one shoulder, across the breast, and under the opposite arm; it is used to support a sword or bugle by the left hip; less properly, any belt.
entry.q: A radiant baldric o'er his shoulder tied Sustained the sword that glittered at his side.

entry.def: A kind of reddish, moderately acid, winter apple.
a person who has a bald head; -- a deprecatory term.

cs.cd: a pair of dice.

entry.ety: OE. bale, OF. bale, F. balle, LL. bala, fr. OHG. balla palla pallo, G. ball balle ballen, ball, round pack; cf. D. baal. Cf. Ball a round body
entry.def: A bundle or package of goods in a cloth cover, and corded for storage or transportation; also, a bundle of straw, hay, etc., put up compactly for transportation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Baled bāld; p. pr. & vb. n. Baling
entry.def: To make up in a bale.
See Bail v. t., to lade.

entry.ety: AS. bealo bealu balu; akin to OS. balu, OHG. balo, Icel. böl, Goth. balweins

sn.def: Misery; calamity; misfortune; sorrow.
sn.q: Let now your bliss be turned into bale.

sn.def: Evil; an evil, pernicious influence; something causing great injury.

entry.cs: Balearic crane. Zoöl See Crane.
entry.ety: L. Balearicus, fr. Gr. baliarei^s the Balearic Islands
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the isles of Majorca, Minorca, Ivica, etc., in the Mediterranean Sea, off the coast of Valencia.

entry.ety: F. baleine whale and whalebone, L. balaena a whale; cf. Gr. fa`laina.
entry.def: Plates or blades of “whalebone,” from two to twelve feet long, and sometimes a foot wide, which in certain whales (Balænoidea) are attached side by side along the upper jaw, and form a fringelike sieve by which the food is retained in the mouth.

entry.ety: AS. bǣlfȳr the fire of the funeral pile; bǣl fire, flame (akin to Icel. bāl, OSlav. bēlŭ, white, Gr. falo`s bright, white, Skr. bhāla brightness) + fȳr, E. fire
entry.def: A signal fire; an alarm fire.
entry.q: Sweet Teviot! on thy silver tide The glaring balefires blaze no more.

entry.ety: AS. bealoful. See Bale misery

sn.def: Full of deadly or pernicious influence; destructive.
sn.q: Balefulenemies.
Four infernal rivers that disgorge Into the burning lake their baleful streams.

sn.def: Full of grief or sorrow; woeful; sad.

entry.def: In a baleful manner; perniciously.
The quality or state of being baleful.

entry.ety: Hind
entry.def: A badgerlike animal of India (Arctonyx collaris).

entry.ety: OF. balestre. See Ballista
entry.def: A crossbow.

sn.def: a natural family comprising the triggerfishes.

entry.def: Like a fish of the genus Balistes; of the family Balistidæ. See Filefish.

entry.ety: LL
entry.def: A narrow opening, often cruciform, through which arrows might be discharged.

entry.ety: F. balise; cf. Sp. balisa
entry.def: A pole or a frame raised as a sea beacon or a landmark.

cs.cd: a line across a billiard table near one end, marking a limit within which the cue balls are placed in beginning a game; also, a line around the table, parallel to the sides, used in playing a particular game, called the balk line game.

entry.ety: AS. balca beam, ridge; akin to Icel. bālkr partition, bjālki beam, OS. balko, G. balken; cf. Gael. balc ridge of earth between two furrows. Cf. Balcony Balk v. t., 3d Bulk

sn.def: A ridge of land left unplowed between furrows, or at the end of a field; a piece missed by the plow slipping aside.
sn.q: Bad plowmen made balks of such ground.

sn.def: A great beam, rafter, or timber; esp., the tie-beam of a house. The loft above was called “the balks.”
sn.q: Tubs hanging in the balks.

sn.def: One of the beams connecting the successive supports of a trestle bridge or bateau bridge.
A hindrance or disappointment; a check.
sn.q: A balk to the confidence of the bold undertaker.

sn.def: A sudden and obstinate stop; a failure.
A deceptive gesture of the pitcher, as if to deliver the ball. It is illegal and is penalized by allowing the runners on base to advance one base.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Balked b�kt; p. pr. & vb. n. Balking
entry.ety: From Balk a beam; orig. to put a balk or beam in one's way, in order to stop or hinder. Cf., for sense 2, AS. on balcan legan to lay in heaps

sn.def: To leave or make balks in.
To leave heaped up; to heap up in piles.
sn.q: Ten thousand bold Scots, two and twenty knights,Balk'd in their own blood did Sir Walter see.

sn.def: To omit, miss, or overlook by chance.
To miss intentionally; to avoid; to shun; to refuse; to let go by; to shirk.
sn.q: By reason of the contagion then in London, we balked the inns.
Sick he is, and keeps his bed, and balks his meat.
Nor doth he any creature balk, But lays on all he meeteth.

sn.def: To disappoint; to frustrate; to foil; to baffle; to thwart; as, to balk expectation.
sn.q: They shall not balk my entrance.

entry.note: ☞ This has been regarded as an Americanism, but it occurs in Spenser's “Faërie Queene,” Book IV., 10, xxv.

sn.def: To engage in contradiction; to be in opposition.
sn.q: In strifeful terms with him to balk.

sn.def: To stop abruptly and stand still obstinately; to jib; to stop short; to swerve; as, the horse balks .
sn.q: Ne ever ought but of their true loves talkt, Ne ever for rebuke or blame of any balkt.

sn.def: to commit a balk{6}; -- of a pitcher.

entry.ety: Prob. from D. balken to bray, bawl
entry.def: To indicate to fishermen, by shouts or signals from shore, the direction taken by the shoals of herring.

sn.def: to divide a territory into small, hostile states.
The countries occupying the Balkan Peninsula.
sn.syn: Balkan countries, Balkan nations, Balkan states.

sn.def: The Balkan mountains.
Same as baffled.

entry.ety: See 2d Balk
entry.def: One who, or that which, balks.

entry.ety: See last Balk
entry.def: A person who stands on a rock or eminence to espy the shoals of herring, etc., and to give notice to the men in boats which way they pass; a conder; a huer.

sn.def: likely to stop abruptly and unexpectedly.
line across a billiard table behind which the cue balls are placed at the start of a game.

entry.def: In a manner to balk or frustrate.
Uneven; ridgy.
Apt to balk; as, a balky horse.

cs.cd: a joint in which a ball moves within a socket, so as to admit of motion in every direction within certain limits.
a mechanical device for lessening the friction of axle bearings by means of small loose metal balls.
a cartridge containing a ball, as distinguished from a blank cartridge, containing only powder.
a faucet or valve which is opened or closed by the fall or rise of a ball floating in water at the end of a lever.
a pivot of a spherical form, which permits lateral deflection of the arbor or shaft, while retaining the pivot in its socket.
the lever used in a ball cock.
the eye itself, as distinguished from its lids and socket; -- formerly, the pupil of the eye.
a contrivance by which a ball, placed in a circular cup with a hole in its bottom, operates as a valve.
a sort of iron ore, found in loose masses of a globular form, containing sparkling particles.
cs.mcol: Three balls, or Three golden balls
cs.cd: a pawnbroker's sign or shop.
alert; competent and knowledgeable.
to carry on the task; to assume the responsibility.
to fail to perform as expected; to fail to live up to a responsibility.

entry.ety: OE. bal balle; akin to OHG. balla palla, G. ball, Icel. böllr, ball; cf. F. balle. Cf. 1st Bale n. Pallmall

sn.def: Any round or roundish body or mass; a sphere or globe; as, a ball of twine; a ball of snow.
A spherical body of any substance or size used to play with, as by throwing, knocking, kicking, etc.
A general name for games in which a ball is thrown, kicked, or knocked. See Baseball, and Football.

Any solid spherical, cylindrical, or conical projectile of lead or iron, to be discharged from a firearm; as, a cannon ball; a rifle ball ; -- often used collectively; as, powder and ball . Spherical balls for the smaller firearms are commonly called bullets.
A flaming, roundish body shot into the air; a case filled with combustibles intended to burst and give light or set fire, or to produce smoke or stench; as, a fire ball; a stink ball .
A leather-covered cushion, fastened to a handle called a ballstock; -- formerly used by printers for inking the form, but now superseded by the roller.
A roundish protuberant portion of some part of the body; as, the ball of the thumb; the ball of the foot.
A large pill, a form in which medicine is commonly given to horses; a bolus.
The globe or earth.
sn.q: Move round the dark terrestrial ball.

sn.def: A pitched ball, not struck at by the batter, which fails to pass over the home plate at a height not greater than the batter's shoulder nor less than his knee (i.e. it is outside the strike zone). If the pitcher pitches four balls before three strikes are called, the batter advances to first base, and the action of pitching four balls is called a walk.
a testicle; usually used in the plural.
courage; nerve.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Balled b�ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Balling
entry.def: To gather balls which cling to the feet, as of damp snow or clay; to gather into balls; as, the horse balls; the snow balls .

sn.def: To heat in a furnace and form into balls for rolling.
To form or wind into a ball; as, to ball cotton.

entry.ety: F. bal, fr. OF. baler to dance, fr. LL. ballare. Of uncertain origin; cf. Gr. ba`llein to toss or throw, or pa`llein pa`llesqai, to leap, bound, balli`zein to dance, jump about; or cf. 1st Ball n.

sn.def: A social assembly for the purpose of dancing; -- usually applied to an occasion lavish or formal.
A very enjoyable time; as, we had a ball at the wedding.

entry.ety: OE. balade, OF. balade, F. ballade, fr. Pr. ballada a dancing song, fr. ballare to dance; cf. It. ballata. See 2d Ball n., and Ballet
entry.def: A popular kind of narrative poem, adapted for recitation or singing; as, the ballad of Chevy Chase; esp., a sentimental or romantic poem in short stanzas.
To make or sing ballads.
To make mention of in ballads.

entry.ety: See Ballad n.
entry.def: A form of French versification, sometimes imitated in English, in which three or four rhymes recur through three stanzas of eight or ten lines each, the stanzas concluding with a refrain, and the whole poem with an envoy.
A writer of ballads.

entries.entry:
Bal"lad mon`ger. See Monger
A seller or maker of ballads; a poetaster.

entry.ety: From Ballad n.
entry.def: Ballad poems; the subject or style of ballads.
entry.q: Baseballadryis so beloved.

entry.def: A fast-sailing schooner, used in the Bermudas and West Indies.

entry.ety: Corrupted fr. bullirag
entry.def: To bully; to threaten.

cs.cd: a steam engine used in excavating and for digging and raising stones and gravel for ballast.
a ship carrying only ballast.

entry.ety: D. ballast; akin to Dan. baglast ballast, OSw. barlast, Sw. ballast. The first part is perh. the same word as E. bare, adj.; the second is last a burden, and hence the meaning a bare, or mere load. See Bare a., and Last load

sn.def: Any heavy substance, as stone, iron, etc., put into the hold to sink a vessel in the water to such a depth as to prevent capsizing.
Any heavy matter put into the car of a balloon to give it steadiness.
Gravel, broken stone, etc., laid in the bed of a railroad to make it firm and solid.
The larger solids, as broken stone or gravel, used in making concrete.
Fig.: That which gives, or helps to maintain, uprightness, steadiness, and security.
sn.q: It [piety] is the right ballast of prosperity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ballasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Ballasting

sn.def: To steady, as a vessel, by putting heavy substances in the hold.
To fill in, as the bed of a railroad, with gravel, stone, etc., in order to make it firm and solid.
To keep steady; to steady, morally.
sn.q: 'T is charity must ballast the heart.

entry.def: A toll paid for the privilege of taking up ballast in a port or harbor.
That which is used for steadying anything; ballast.
See Balladry.
formed or gathered into a ball.
A female ballet dancer.

entry.ety: F., a dim. of bal dance. See 2d Ball n.

sn.def: An artistic dance performed as a theatrical entertainment, or an interlude, by a number of persons, usually women. Sometimes, a scene accompanied by pantomime and dancing.
The company of persons who perform the ballet.
A light part song, or madrigal, with a fa la burden or chorus, -- most common with the Elizabethan madrigal composers; -- also spelled ballett.
A bearing in coats of arms, representing one or more balls, which are denominated bezants, plates, etc., according to color.

entry.def: of or pertaining to ballet{1}.
a man who trains ballet dancers.
a woman who trains ballet dancers.
a ballet enthusiast.
a heelless slipper specifically designed to be worn by ballet dancers while dancing.
An ornament resembling a ball placed in a circular flower, the petals of which form a cup round it, -- usually inserted in a hollow molding.
skilled in stealing the ball or robbing a batter of a hit; -- used of a Baseball or basketball or football player.

entries.entry: Bal*lis"ta Bal*lis"ta n.; pl.Ballistæ. L. ballista balista, fr. Gr. ba`llein to throw An ancient military engine, in the form of a crossbow, used for hurling large missiles.

entry.ety: L. ballista. Cf. Balister
entry.def: A crossbow.

cs.cd: an instrument consisting of a mass of wood or other material suspended as a pendulum, for measuring the force and velocity of projectiles by means of the arc through which their impact impels it.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the ballista, or to the art of hurling stones or missile weapons by means of an engine.
Pertaining to ballistics{2}, or to a projectile in a gravitational field.
frenzied; very angry; -- used mostly in the phrase go ballistic.

entry.note:
Ballistic missiles are sometimes referred to by their range, such as an intercontinental ballistic missile
ICBM) or an intermediate range ballistic missile
IRBM).
entry.def: A rocket-propelled missile of long range which is guided only during the powered portion of its flight, which usually takes only a small part of the total flight time; -- contrasted with guided missile.

entry.ety: Cf. F. balistique. See Ballista
entry.def: The science or art of hurling missile weapons by the use of an engine.

sn.def: The science treating the motion of projectiles in flight, especially when they are in free fall within the earth's gravitational field.
The study of the characteristics of a cartridge fired from a firearm, and of the processes occurring during the discharge of a firearm.

The division within a police department which studies the characteristics of cartridges fired from a firearm; the ballistics department. The characteristics of the weapons and bullets fired may be used as evidence in criminal investigations.

entry.ety: See Ballista
entry.def: A smokeless powder containing equal parts of soluble nitrocellulose and nitroglycerin.

entry.ety: LL
entry.def: See Bailey.

cs.cd: a balloon for aërial navigation.
a house frame constructed altogether of small timber.
a variety of woven lace in which the weft threads are twisted in a peculiar manner around the warp.

entry.ety: F. ballon, aug. of balle ball: cf. It. ballone. See 1st Ball n., and cf. Pallone

sn.def: A bag made of silk or other light material, and filled with hydrogen gas or heated air, so as to rise and float in the atmosphere; especially, one with a car attached for aërial navigation.
A ball or globe on the top of a pillar, church, etc., as at St. Paul's, in London.
A round vessel, usually with a short neck, to hold or receive whatever is distilled; a glass vessel of a spherical form.
A bomb or shell.
A game played with a large inflated ball.
The outline inclosing words represented as coming from the mouth of a pictured figure.

entry.def: To take up in, or as if in, a balloon.

sn.def: To go up or voyage in a balloon.
To expand, or puff out, like a balloon.

entry.def: Swelled out like a balloon.
One who goes up in a balloon; an aëronaut.

entries.entry: bal*loon"fish` bal*loon" fish` . Zoöl A fish of the genus Diodonsuch as Diodon holocanthus) or the genus Tetraodon, having the power of distending its body by taking air or water into its dilatable esophagus. It is similar to but smaller than the porcupinefish. See Globefish, and Bur fish.

sn.def: The art or practice of managing balloons or voyaging in them; the sport of riding in balloons.
The process of temporarily raising the value of a stock, as by fictitious sales.

entries.entry: Bal*loon"ing spi"der. Zoöl A spider which has the habit of rising into the air. Many kinds (esp. species of Lycosa) do this while young by ejecting threads of silk until the force of the wind upon them carries the spider aloft.

entry.def: An aëronaut.
The art or practice of ascending in a balloon; an older term for ballooning.

entry.cs: Ballot box a box for receiving ballots. the act, process or system of voting secretly; same as ballot2}. “The question will be resolved by the ballot box.”
entry.ety: F. ballotte, fr. It. ballotta. See Ball round body

sn.def: Originally, a ball used for secret voting. Hence: Any printed or written ticket used in voting.
The act of secret voting, whether by balls, written or printed ballots or tickets, or by use of a voting machine; the system of voting secretly.
sn.q: The insufficiency of the ballot.

sn.def: The whole number of votes cast at an election, or in a given territory or electoral district.
the official list of candidates competing in an election.
sn.illu: There are no women on the ballot.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Balloted; p. pr. & vb. n. Balloting
entry.ety: F. ballotter to toss, to ballot, or It. ballottare. See Ballot n.
entry.def: To vote or decide by ballot; as, to ballot for a candidate.
To vote for or in opposition to.
entry.q: None of the competitors arriving to a sufficient number of balls, they fell to ballot some others.

entry.ety: F. ballottade, fr. ballotter to toss. See Ballot v. i.
entry.def: A leap of a horse, as between two pillars, or upon a straight line, so that when his four feet are in the air, he shows only the shoes of his hind feet, without jerking out.

entry.ety: F. ballottage
entry.def: In France, a second ballot taken after an indecisive first ballot to decide between two or several candidates; a runoff election.
Voting by ballot.
One who votes by ballot.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: An officer who has charge of a ballot box.
A cudgel.

sn.def: an athlete who plays baseball.

entry.def: a pen which has a small metal ball as point of transfer of ink to paper, at the tip of a cylandrical and non-refillable reservoir of ink; -- short for ballpoint pen.
Incapable of being penetrated by balls from firearms; bulletproof.
A room for balls or dancing.
nonsense.
shaped like a sphere.
entry.syn: global, globose, globular, orbicular, spheric, spherical.

entry.def: something badly botched or muddled; a foul-up.
same as balls-up.
an informal intensifier.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. ballyhooed; p. pr. & vb. n. ballyhooing

a small evergreen African and Asiatic tree of the terebinthine family (Balsamodendron Gileadense). Its leaves yield, when bruised, a strong aromatic scent; and from this tree is obtained the balm of Gilead of the shops, or balsam of Mecca. This has a yellowish or greenish color, a warm, bitterish, aromatic taste, and a fragrant smell. It is valued as an unguent and cosmetic by the Turks. The fragrant herb Dracocephalum Canariense is familiarly called balm of Gilead, and so are the American trees, Populus balsamifera, variety candicansbalsam poplar), and Abies balsameabalsam fir).

entry.ety: OE. baume, OF. bausme basme, F. baume, L. balsamum balsam, from Gr. ba`lsamon; perhaps of Semitic origin; cf. Heb. bāsām. Cf. Balsam

entry.note: ☞ The balsams are aromatic resinous substances, flowing spontaneously or by incision from certain plants. A great variety of substances pass under this name, but the term is now usually restricted to resins which, in addition to a volatile oil, contain benzoic and cinnamic acid. Among the true balsams are the balm of Gilead, and the balsams of copaiba, Peru, and Tolu. There are also many pharmaceutical preparations and resinous substances, possessed of a balsamic smell, to which the name balsam has been given.
entry.cs:
Balsam apple Bot an East Indian plant (Momordica balsamina), of the gourd family, with red or orange-yellow cucumber-shaped fruit of the size of a walnut, used as a vulnerary, and in liniments and poultices. Balsam fir Bot the American coniferous tree, Abies balsamea, from which the useful Canada balsam is derived. Balsam of copaiba. See Copaiba. Balsam of Mecca balm of Gilead. Balsam of Peru a reddish brown, syrupy balsam, obtained from a Central American tree (Myroxylon Pereiræ and used as a stomachic and expectorant, and in the treatment of ulcers, etc. It was long supposed to be a product of Peru. Balsam of Tolu a reddish or yellowish brown semisolid or solid balsam, obtained from a South American tree (Myroxylon toluiferum). It is highly fragrant, and is used as a stomachic and expectorant. Balsam tree any tree from which balsam is obtained, esp. the Abies balsamea.
Canada balsam Balsam of fir
Canada turpentine, a yellowish, viscid liquid, which, by time and exposure, becomes a transparent solid mass. It is obtained from the balm of Gilead (or balsam) fir (Abies balsamea) by breaking the vesicles upon the trunk and branches. See Balm.
entry.ety: L. balsamum the balsam tree or its resin, Gr. ba`lsamon. See Balm n.

sn.def: A resin containing more or less of an essential or volatile oil.

sd.def: A species of tree (Abies balsamea).
An annual garden plant (Impatiens balsamina) with beautiful flowers; balsamine.

A common bird (Icterus galbula) of eastern and central America and Canada, named after Lord Baltimore , because its colors (black and orange red) are like those of his coat of arms; -- called also golden robin. It winters in the American tropics.

entry.note: ☞ The most useful species is Bambusa arundinacea, which has a woody, hollow, round, straight, jointed stem, and grows to the height of forty feet and upward. The flowers grow in large panicles, from the joints of the stalk, placed three in a parcel, close to their receptacles. Old stalks grow to five or six inches in diameter, and are so hard and durable as to be used for building, and for all sorts of furniture, for water pipes, and for poles to support palanquins. The smaller stalks are used for walking sticks, flutes, etc.
entry.ety: Malay bambu mambu
entry.def: A plant of the family of grasses, and genus Bambusa, growing in tropical countries.

Something commonplace, hackneyed, or trivial; the commonplace, in speech. The highest things were thus brought down to the banalities of discourse.

entry.note: ☞ The banana has a soft, herbaceous stalk, with leaves of great length and breadth. The flowers grow in bunches, covered with a sheath of a green or purple color; the fruit is five or six inches long, and over an inch in diameter; the pulp is soft, and of a luscious taste, and is eaten either raw or cooked. This plant is a native of tropical countries, and furnishes an important article of food.

cs.cd: a small American bird (Icterus leucopteryx), which feeds on the banana.
a small bird of tropical America, of the genus Certhiola, allied to the creepers.

entries.entry: Ba*na"na so*lu"tion. A solution used as a vehicle in applying bronze pigments. In addition to acetote, benzine, and a little pyroxylin, it contains amyl acetate, which gives it the odor of bananas.

a band that is the size of an orchestra, usually playing mostly jazz or swing music. The big band typically features both ensemble and solo playing, sometimes has a lead singer, and is often located in a night club where the patrons may dance to its music. The big bands were popular from the late 1920's to the 1940's. Contrasted with combo, which has fewer players.

entry.ety: OE. band bond, Icel. band; akin to G., Sw., & D. band, OHG. bant, Goth. bandi, Skr. bandha a binding, bandh to bind, for bhanda bhandh, also to E. bend bind. In sense 7, at least, it is fr. F. bande, from OHG. bant. √90. See Bind v. t., and cf. Bend Bond, 1st Bandy

entry.note: The term has been used metaphorically to mean an ineffective cosmetic solution, when used on a serious problem.
entry.ety: from a Trademark
entry.def: An adhesive bandage, composed of a short ribbon of cloth or plastic with an adhesive coating on one side, and having a patch of gauze at the center. It is used to cover small cuts, abrasions, or blisters on the skin, and may be easily applied to and removed from the skin with no additional material. Originally a trademark, the term has been popularly used generically.

sn.def: A hurried repair; a temporary fix for a minor problem.

entry.ety: Hind. bāndhnū a mode of dyeing in which the cloth is tied in different places so as to prevent the parts tied from receiving the dye. Cf. Band n.

sn.def: A species of silk or cotton handkerchief, having a uniformly dyed ground, usually of red or blue, with white or yellow figures of a circular, lozenge, or other simple form; -- it is often used as a neckerchief. The term is also used for any large and brightly colored handkerchief.
Any scarf worn on the neck or head, usually of large size.

A style of calico printing, in which white or bright spots are produced upon cloth previously dyed of a uniform red or dark color, by discharging portions of the color by chemical means, while the rest of the cloth is under pressure.

entry.def: A light box of pasteboard or thin wood, usually cylindrical, for holding ruffs (the bands of the 17th century), collars, caps, bonnets, etc.

entries.entry: Ban*deau" Ban*deau" băn*dō"; băn"dō n.; pl.Bandeaux băn*dōz" . F A narrow band or fillet, as for the hair, part of a headdress, etc. Around the edge of this cap was a stiff bandeau of leather.

entries.entry: Band" fish`. Zoöl A small red fish of the genus Cepola; the ribbon fish.

entries.entry: Band"ing plane`. A plane used for cutting out grooves and inlaying strings and bands in straight and circular work.

Ban"dit ☞ The plural banditti was formerly used as a collective noun. băn"dĭt n.; pl.Bandits băn"dĭtsorBanditti băn*dĭt"tĭ. It. bandito outlaw, p. p. of bandire to proclaim, to banish, to proscribe, LL. bandire bannire. See Ban an edict, and cf. Banish
An outlaw; a brigand. No savage fierce, bandit, or mountaineer. Deerstealers are ever a desperate banditti.

entry.q: The keeper entered leading his bandog, a large bloodhound, tied in a leam, or band, from which he takes his name.

entry.ety: F. bandoulièrecf. It. bandoliera, Sp. bandolera), fr. F. bande band, Sp. & It. banda. See Band n.

sn.def: A broad leather belt formerly worn by soldiers over the right shoulder and across the breast under the left arm. Originally it was used for supporting the musket and twelve cases for charges, but later only as a cartridge belt.
One of the leather or wooden cases in which the charges of powder were carried.

entry.ety: Perh. allied to band
entry.def: A glutinous pomatum for the hair.

entry.ety: OF. bandon. See Abandon
entry.def: Disposal; control; license.

entry.def: A musical stringed instrument, similar in form to a guitar; a pandore. It is now obsolete, but see bandura.
Same as Banderole.

entry.def: A traditional Ukrainian stringed musical instrument shaped like a lute, having many strings.

sn.def: A popular trend that attracts growing support.

entries.entry:
Ban"dy n.; pl.Bandies -dĭz. Cf. F. bandé, p. p. of bander to bind, to bend (a bow), to bandy, fr. bande. See Band n.
A club bent at the lower part for striking a ball at play; a hockey stick.
The game played with such a club; hockey; shinney; bandy ball.

entry.ety: OE. bane destruction, AS. bana murderer; akin to Icel. bani death, murderer, OHG. bana murder, bano murderer, Goth. banja stroke, wound, Gr. foney`s murderer, fo`nos murder, OIr. bath death, benim I strike. √31

sn.def: That which destroys life, esp. poison of a deadly quality.
sn.mark: Obs. except in combination, as in ratsbane, henbane, etc

sn.def: Destruction; death.
sn.q: The cup of deception spiced and tempered to their bane.

sn.def: Any cause of ruin, or lasting injury; harm; woe.
sn.q: Money, thou bane of bliss, and source of woe.

sn.def: A disease in sheep, commonly termed the rot.

entry.def: To be the bane of; to ruin.
A genus Actæa of plants, of the order Ranunculaceæ, native in the north temperate zone. The red or white berries are poisonous.
Having poisonous qualities; deadly; destructive; injurious; noxious; pernicious.
entry.q: Banefulhemlock.
Banefulwrath.

entry.def: Deadly nightshade.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Banged; p. pr. & vb. n. Banging
entry.ety: Icel. banga to hammer; akin to Dan. banke to beat, Sw. bångas to be impetuous, G. bengel club, clapper of a bell

sn.def: To beat, as with a club or cudgel; to treat with violence; to handle roughly.
sn.q: The desperate tempest hath so banged the Turks.

sn.def: To beat or thump, or to cause (something) to hit or strike against another object, in such a way as to make a loud noise; as, to bang a drum or a piano; to bang a door (against the doorpost or casing) in shutting it.
To have sexual intercourse with; to fuck; -- usually used with the male as a subject. Considered vulgar or obscene.
To make a loud noise, as if with a blow or succession of blows; as, the window blind banged and waked me; he was banging on the piano.
To have sexual intercourse; to fuck. Considered vulgar and obscene.
A blow as with a club; a heavy blow.
sn.q: Many a stiff thwack, many a bang.

sn.def: The loud sound produced by a sudden concussion or explosion.
A surge of pleasure; a thrill; -- usually used in the phrase get a bang out of; as, I always get a bang out of watching an ice skater do a quadruple jump.
An exclamation point; -- used in verbal descriptions of text, in printing and in computer technology; as, his email address is tom bang stanford dot edu (i.e. tom!stanford.edu.
An instance of sexual intercourse; a fuck. Considered vulgar and obscene.

entry.def: To cut squarely across, as the tail of a horse, or the forelock of human beings; to cut (the hair).
entry.q: His hair banged even with his eyebrows.

entry.def: The short, front hair combed down over the forehead, esp. when cut squarely across; a false front of hair similarly worn; -- usually used in the plural; as, her bangs came down almost to her eyes.
entry.q: His hair cut in front like a young lady's bang.

entry.def: See Bhang.
Huge; great in size.
An independent Asian country on teh Bay of Bengal that was once part of India and then part of Pakistan (called East Pakistan).

Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Bangladesh.

entry.ety: From 1st Bang
entry.def: To waste by little and little; to fritter away.

cs.cd: a loose hanging ear of a horse, like that of a spaniel.

entry.ety: Hind. bangrī bracelet, bangle
entry.def: An ornamental circlet, of glass, gold, silver, or other material, worn mostly by women, upon the wrist or ankle; a ring bracelet. It differs from other bracelets in being rigid and not articulated, in contrast to bracelets made of links.

sn.def: a horse bred for racing.

cs.cd: days in which the sailors have no flesh meat served out to them. This use seems to be borrowed from the Banians or Banya race, who eat no flesh.

entry.ety: Skr. banij merchant. The tree was so named by the English, because used as a market place by the merchants

sn.def: A Hindu trader, merchant, cashier, or money changer.
A man's loose gown, like that worn by the Banians.
The Indian fig. See Banyan.

entry.usage: The idea of a coercive removal from a place is common to these terms. A man is banished when he is forced by the government of a country (be he a foreigner or a native) to leave its borders. A man is exiled when he is driven into banishment from his native country and home. Thus to exile is to banish, but to banish is not always to exile. To expel is to eject or banish summarily or authoritatively, and usually under circumstances of disgrace; as, to expel from a college; expelled from decent society.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Banished băn"ĭsht; p. pr. & vb. n. Banishing
entry.ety: OF. banir, F. bannir, LL. bannire, fr. OHG. bannan to summon, fr. ban ban. See Ban an edict, and Finish v. t.

sn.def: To condemn to exile, or compel to leave one's country, by authority of the ruling power.
sn.q: Webanishyou our territories.

sn.def: To drive out, as from a home or familiar place; -- used with from and out of.
sn.q: How the ancient Celtic tongue came to be banished from the Low Countries in Scotland.

sn.def: To drive away; to compel to depart; to dispel.
sn.q: Banishall offense.

entry.def: One who banishes.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bannissement
entry.def: The act of banishing, or the state of being banished.
entry.q: He secured himself by the banishment of his enemies.
Round the wide world in banishment we roam.
entry.syn: Expatriation; ostracism; expulsion; proscription; exile; outlawry.

entry.ety: A corruption of baluster

sn.def: A baluster.

entry.sn:
sing. or pl. The balustrade of a staircase. Formerly used in this sense mostly in the plural, now mostly in the singular.
bannister
He struggled to ascend the pulpit stairs, holding hard on the banisters.Sir W. Scott.

entry.ety: Formerly also banjore and banjer; corrupted from bandore, through negro slave pronunciation
entry.def: A stringed musical instrument having a head and neck like the guitar, and a circular body like a tambourine. It has five strings, and is played with the fingers and hands.

cs.cd: the otter.
a small American and European swallow (Clivicola riparia) that nests in a hole which it excavates in a bank.

entry.ety: OE. banke; akin to E. bench, and prob. of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. bakki. See Bench

sn.def: A mound, pile, or ridge of earth, raised above the surrounding level; hence, anything shaped like a mound or ridge of earth; as, a bank of clouds; a bank of snow.
sn.q: They cast up a bank against the city.

sn.def: A steep acclivity, as the slope of a hill, or the side of a ravine.
The margin of a watercourse; the rising ground bordering a lake, river, or sea, or forming the edge of a cutting, or other hollow.
sn.q: Tiber trembled underneath her banks.

sn.def: An elevation, or rising ground, under the sea; a shoal, shelf, or shallow; as, the banks of Newfoundland.

sd.def: The face of the coal at which miners are working.
A deposit of ore or coal, worked by excavations above water level.
The ground at the top of a shaft; as, ores are brought to bank .

sn.def: The lateral inclination of an aëroplane as it rounds a curve; as, a bank of 45° is easy; a bank of 90° is dangerous.
A group or series of objects arranged near together; as, a bank of electric lamps, etc.

The tilt of a roadway or railroad, at a curve in the road, designed to counteract centrifugal forces acting on vehicles moving rapiudly around the curve, thus reducing the danger of overturning during a turn.

cs.cd: to cover the coals or embers with ashes or cinders, thus keeping the fire low but alive.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bankedbăṉkt); p. pr. & vb. n. Banking

sn.def: To raise a mound or dike about; to inclose, defend, or fortify with a bank; to embank.
sn.q: Bankedwell with earth.

sn.def: To heap or pile up; as, to bank sand.
To pass by the banks of.

To build (a roadway or railroad) with an inclination at a curve in the road, so as to counteract centrifugal forces acting on vehicles moving rapiudly around the curve, thus reducing the danger of vehicles overturning at a curve; as, the raceway was steeply banked at the curves.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. F. banc. Of German origin, and akin to E. bench. See Bench

sn.def: A bench, as for rowers in a galley; also, a tier of oars.
sn.q: Placed on their banks, the lusty Trojan sweep Neptune's smooth face, and cleave the yielding deep.

sd.def: The bench or seat upon which the judges sit.
The regular term of a court of law, or the full court sitting to hear arguments upon questions of law, as distinguished from a sitting at Nisi Prius, or a court held for jury trials. See Banc.

sn.def: A sort of table used by printers.
A bench, or row of keys belonging to a keyboard, as in an organ.

cs.cd: a credit by which a person who has given the required security to a bank has liberty to draw to a certain extent agreed upon.
a bank which receives money for safe keeping.
a bank which issues its own notes payable to bearer.

entry.ety: F. banque, It. banca, orig. bench, table, counter, of German origin, and akin to E. bench; cf. G. bank bench, OHG. banch. See Bench, and cf. Banco Beach

sn.def: An establishment for the custody, loan, exchange, or issue, of money, and for facilitating the transmission of funds by drafts or bills of exchange; an institution incorporated for performing one or more of such functions, or the stockholders (or their representatives, the directors), acting in their corporate capacity.
The building or office used for banking purposes.
A fund to be used in transacting business, especially a joint stock or capital.
sn.q: Let it be no bank or common stock, but every man be master of his own money.

sn.def: The sum of money or the checks which the dealer or banker has as a fund, from which to draw his stakes and pay his losses.
In certain games, as dominos, a fund of pieces from which the players are allowed to draw; in Monopoly, the fund of money used to pay bonuses due to the players, or to which they pay fines.
a place where something is stored and held available for future use;
an organization that stores biological products for medical needs; as, a blood bank, an organ bank, a sperm bank .

entry.def: To deposit in a bank.

sn.def: To keep a bank; to carry on the business of a banker.
To deposit money in a bank; to have an account with a banker.

entry.def: To tilt sidewise in rounding a curve; -- said of a flying machine, an aërocurve, or the like.
Receivable at a bank.

entries.entry:
Bank" bill` băṉk" bĭl`. In America (and formerly in England), a promissory note of a bank payable to the bearer on demand, and used as currency; a bank note.
In England, a note, or a bill of exchange, of a bank, payable to order, and usually at some future specified time. Such bills are negotiable, but form, in the strict sense of the term, no part of the currency.
Bank" book` băṉk" b�k`. A book kept by a depositor, in which an officer of a bank enters the debits and credits of the depositor's account with the bank.
Bank discount. A sum equal to the interest at a given rate on the principal (face) of a bill or note from the time of discounting until it becomes due.

entry.ety: See the nouns Bank and the verbs derived from them

sn.def: One who conducts the business of banking; one who, individually, or as a member of a company, keeps an establishment for the deposit or loan of money, or for traffic in money, bills of exchange, etc.
A money changer.
The dealer, or one who keeps the bank in a gambling house.
A vessel employed in the cod fishery on the banks of Newfoundland.
A ditcher; a drain digger.
The stone bench on which masons cut or square their work.

entry.def: A female banker.
a genus consisting of giant shipworms.

cs.cd: an establishment or office in which, or a firm by whom, banking is done.

entry.def: The business of a bank or of a banker.

entries.entry:
bank"note` bank" note`
☞ In the United States popularly called a bank bill. băṉk"nōt`. A promissory note issued by a bank or banking company, payable to the bearer on demand. See also sense 4.
Formerly, a promissory note made by a banker, or banking company, payable to a specified person at a fixed date; a bank bill. See Bank bill, 2. Obs
A promissory note payable at a bank.
A promissory note issued by an authorized bank, payable to the bearer on demand and intended to circulate as government-authorized money; in the United States such notes may only be issued by a Federal Reserve Bank; as, he peeled off five one-thousand-zloty banknotes. bill, note, government note, bank bill, banker's bill, bank note, Federal Reserve note, greenback.

entry.def: Depend on; be confident of.

entry.sn: the money carried on one's person. ”He shot his bankroll on a bob-tailed nag.” roll, wad.

sn.def: one's total supply of money; funds.

entry.def: To pay the costs of; as, Who will bankroll the restoration of the former East German economy?.

entry.note: ☞ In England, until the year 1861 none but a “trader” could be made a bankrupt; a non-trader failing to meet his liabilities being an “insolvent”. But this distinction was abolished by the Bankruptcy Act of 1861. The laws of 1841 and 1867 of the United States relating to bankruptcy applied this designation bankrupt to others besides those engaged in trade.
entry.ety: F. banqueroute, fr. It. bancarotta bankruptcy; banca bank (fr. OHG. banch, G. bank, bench) + rotta broken, fr. L. ruptus, p. p. of rumpere to break. At Florence, it is said, the bankrupt had his bench (i.e., money table) broken. See 1st Bank, and Rupture n.

sn.def: A trader who secretes himself, or does certain other acts tending to defraud his creditors.
A trader who becomes unable to pay his debts; an insolvent trader; popularly, any person who is unable to pay his debts; an insolvent person.
A person who, in accordance with the terms of a law relating to bankruptcy, has been judicially declared to be unable to meet his liabilities.

cs.cd: a law by which the property of a person who is unable or unwilling to pay his debts may be taken and distributed to his creditors, and by which a person who has made a full surrender of his property, and is free from fraud, may be discharged from the legal obligation of his debts. See Insolvent a.

sn.def: Being a bankrupt or in a condition of bankruptcy; unable to pay, or legally discharged from paying, one's debts; as, a bankrupt merchant.
Depleted of money; not having the means of meeting pecuniary liabilities; as, a bankrupt treasury.
Relating to bankrupts and bankruptcy.
Destitute of, or wholly wanting (something once possessed, or something one should possess).
sn.q: Bankruptin gratitude.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bankrupted; p. pr. & vb. n. Bankrupting
entry.def: To make bankrupt; to bring financial ruin upon; to impoverish.

entries.entry:
Bank"rupt*cy n.; pl.Bankruptcies.
The state of being actually or legally bankrupt.
The act or process of becoming a bankrupt.
Complete loss; -- followed by of.

entry.def: The slope of a bank, especially of the bank of a stream.
Having sides inclining inwards, as a ship; -- opposed to wall-sided.

entries.entry: Bank" swal"low. See under 1st Bank n.

entry.ety: F., fr. LL. bannum leucae banleuca; bannum jurisdiction + leuca league
entry.def: The territory without the walls, but within the legal limits, of a town or city.

cs.cd: a large fish of the genus Histiophorus, of the Swordfish family, having a broad bannerlike dorsal fin; the sailfish. One species (Histiophorus Americanus) inhabits the North Atlantic.

entry.ety: OE. banere, OF. baniere, F. bannière bandière, fr. LL. baneria banderia, fr. bandum banner, fr. OHG. bant band, strip of cloth; cf. bindan to bind, Goth. bandwa bandwo, a sign. See Band n.

sn.def: A kind of flag attached to a spear or pike by a crosspiece, and used by a chief as his standard in battle.
sn.q: Hang out our banners on the outward walls.

sn.def: A large piece of silk or other cloth, with a device or motto, extended on a crosspiece, and borne in a procession, or suspended in some conspicuous place.
Any flag or standard; as, the star-spangled banner .

entry.def: Furnished with, or bearing, banners.
entry.q: Abanneredhost.

entry.note: ☞ The usual mode of conferring the rank on the field of battle was by cutting or tearing off the point of the pennon or pointed flag on the spear of the candidate, thereby making it a banner.
entry.ety: OE. baneret, OF. baneret, F. banneret; properly a dim. of OF. baniere. See Banner

sn.def: Originally, a knight who led his vassals into the field under his own banner; -- commonly used as a title of rank.
A title of rank, conferred for heroic deeds, and hence, an order of knighthood; also, the person bearing such title or rank.
A civil officer in some Swiss cantons.
A small banner.

entry.def: A banderole; esp. a banner displayed at a funeral procession and set over the tomb. See Banderole.
an order that bans something.
same as banister.

entry.ety: LL. bannitio. See Banish
entry.def: The act of expulsion.

cs.cd: the turbot.

entry.ety: Gael. bonnach
entry.def: A kind of cake or bread, in shape flat and roundish, commonly made of oatmeal or barley meal and baked on an iron plate, or griddle; -- used in Scotland and the northern counties of England.
A battle in which the Scots under Robert the Bruce defeated the English and assured the independence of Scotland.

entry.ety: See Ban
entry.def: Notice of a proposed marriage, proclaimed in a church, or other place prescribed by law, in order that any person may object, if he knows of just cause why the marriage should not take place.

entry.ety: F., a feast, prop. a dim. of banc bench; cf. It. banchetto, dim. of banco a bench, counter. See Bank a bench, and cf. Banquette

sn.def: A feast; a sumptuous entertainment of eating and drinking; often, a complimentary or ceremonious feast, followed by speeches.
A dessert; a course of sweetmeats; a sweetmeat or sweetmeats.
sn.q: We'll dine in the great room, but let the music And banquet be prepared here.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Banqueted; p. pr. & vb. n. Banqueting
entry.def: To treat with a banquet or sumptuous entertainment of food; to feast.
entry.q: Just in time to banquet The illustrious company assembled there.

sn.def: To regale one's self with good eating and drinking; to feast.
sn.q: Were it a draught for Juno when she banquets, I would not taste thy treasonous offer.

sn.def: To partake of a dessert after a feast.
sn.q: Where they did both sup and banquet.

entry.def: Eating an elaborate meal (often accompanied by entertainment).
A bench or seat for passengers on the top of a diligence or other public vehicle.
entry.q: My brother-in-law . . . took refuge in the banquette.

entry.def: One who banquets; one who feasts or makes feasts.

entry.ety: F. See Banquet n.

sn.def: A raised way or foot bank, running along the inside of a parapet, on which musketeers stand to fire upon the enemy.
A narrow window seat; a raised shelf at the back or the top of a buffet or dresser.

entry.ety: Gael. bean-shith fairy; Gael. & Ir. bean woman + Gael. sith fairy
entry.def: A supernatural being supposed to warn a family of the approaching death of one of its members, by wailing or singing in a mournful voice, as under the windows of the house.

entry.ety: OE. ban bon, bone + stickle prickle, sting. See Bone n. Stickleback
entry.def: A small fish, the three-spined stickleback.
A variety of small barnyard fowl, with feathered legs, probably brought from Bantam, a district of Java.

entries.entry: Ban"tam work`. Carved and painted work in imitation of Japan ware.

entry.def: The wild ox of Java (Bibos Banteng).

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bantered băn"tẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Bantering
entry.ety: Prob. corrupted fr. F. badiner to joke, or perh. fr. E. bandy to beat to and fro. See Badinage, and cf. Barter fr. OF. barater

sn.def: To address playful good-natured ridicule to, -- the person addressed, or something pertaining to him, being the subject of the jesting; to rally; as, he bantered me about my credulity.
sn.q: Hag-ridden by my own fancy all night, and then bantered on my haggard looks the next day.

sn.def: To jest about; to ridicule in speaking of, as some trait, habit, characteristic, and the like.
sn.q: If they banter your regularity, order, and love of study, banter in return their neglect of them.

sn.def: To delude or trick, -- esp. by way of jest.
sn.q: We diverted ourselves with bantering several poor scholars with hopes of being at least his lordship's chaplain.

sn.def: To challenge or defy to a match.
sn.mark: Colloq. Southern and Western U. S

entry.def: The act of bantering; joking or jesting; humorous or good-humored raillery; pleasantry.
entry.q: Part banter, part affection.

entry.def: One who banters or rallies.
A method of reducing corpulence by avoiding food containing much farinaceous, saccharine, or oily matter; -- so called from William Banting of London.

entry.ety: Prob. for bandling, from band, and meaning a child wrapped in swaddling bands; or cf. G. bäntling a bastard, fr. bank bench. Cf. Bastard n.
entry.def: A young or small child; an infant.
entry.q: In what out of the way corners genius produces her bantlings.

entry.def: A member of one of the great family of Negroid tribes occupying equatorial and southern Africa. These tribes include, as important divisions, the Kafirs, Damaras, Bechuanas, and many tribes whose names begin with Aba- Ama- Ba- Ma- Wa-, variants of the Bantu plural personal prefix Aba-, as in Ba-ntu, or Aba-ntu, itself a combination of this prefix with the syllable -ntu, a person; or as in Watusi.

sn.def: the family of languages spoken by the Bantu people (definition 1).
Of or pertaining to the Bantu language group Bantu (definition 2); as, Bantu languages.
of or pertaining to the Bantu people (definition 1).
sn.illu: The Bantu population of Sierra Leone

entry.def: An East Indian insectivorous mammal of the genus Tupaia.

entry.ety: See Banian
entry.def: A tree of the same genus as the common fig, and called the Indian fig (Ficus Indica), whose branches send shoots to the ground, which take root and become additional trunks, until it may be the tree covers some acres of ground and is able to shelter thousands of men.

entry.ety: Jap. banzai banzei, ten thousand years, forever
entry.def: Lit., May you live ten thousand years; -- used in salutation of the emperor and as a battle cry.

entry.ety: The native name
entry.def: A gigantic African tree (Adansonia digitata), also naturalized in India. See Adansonia.

entry.ety: A corruption of Mahomet or Mohammed, the Arabian prophet: cf. Pr. Bafomet, OSp. Mafomat, OPg. Mafameda
entry.def: An idol or symbolical figure which the Templars were accused of using in their mysterious rites.
same as baptize.
A genus of North American plants with showy pealike flowers and an inflated pod.

entry.ety: OE. baptim baptem, OF. baptesme batisme, F. baptême, L. baptisma, fr. Gr. ba`ptisma, fr. bapti`zein to baptize, fr. ba`ptein to dip in water, akin to baqy`s deep, Skr. gāh to dip, bathe, v. i.
entry.def: The act of baptizing; the application of water to a person, as a sacrament or religious ceremony, by which he is initiated into the visible church of Christ. This is performed by immersion, sprinkling, or pouring.

cs.cd: the Christian name, which is given at baptism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. baptismal
entry.def: Pertaining to baptism; as, baptismal vows.
In a baptismal manner.

entry.note: In doctrine the Baptists of this country [the United States] are Calvinistic, but with much freedom and moderation.

cs.cd: a sect of Baptists who are Arminian in doctrine, and practice open communion.
a sect of Baptists who keep the seventh day of the week, or Saturday, as the Sabbath. See Sabbatarian. The Dunkers and Campbellites are also Baptists.

entry.ety: L. baptista, Gr. baptisth`s

sn.def: One who administers baptism; -- specifically applied to John, the forerunner of Christ.

One of a denomination of Christians who deny the validity of infant baptism and of sprinkling, and maintain that baptism should be administered to believers alone, and should be by immersion. See Anabaptist.

entries.entry:
Bap"tis*ter*y,Bap"tis*try
n.; pl.Baptisteries Baptistries. L. baptisterium, Gr. baptisth`rion: cf. F. baptistère
Arch In early times, a separate building, usually polygonal, used for baptismal services. Small churches were often changed into baptisteries when larger churches were built near. A part of a church containing a font and used for baptismal services.

entry.ety: Gr. baptistiko`s
entry.def: Of or for baptism; baptismal.
Baptistic.
Capable of being baptized; fit to be baptized.
Baptism.
entry.q: Their baptizations were null.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Baptized; p. pr. & vb. n. Baptizing
entry.ety: F. baptiser, L. baptizare, fr. Gr. bapti`zein. See Baptism

sn.def: To administer the sacrament of baptism to.
To christen (because a name is given to infants at their baptism); to give a name to; to name.
sn.q: I'll be new baptized; Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

sn.def: To sanctify; to consecrate.

entry.def: The act of baptizing.
One who baptizes.

entry.note: ☞ A double bar marks the end of a strain or main division of a movement, or of a whole piece of music; in psalmody, it marks the end of a line of poetry. The term bar is very often loosely used for measure, i.e., for such length of music, or of silence, as is included between one bar and the next; as, a passage of eight bars; two bars' rest.
entry.cs:
Bar shoe Far a kind of horseshoe having a bar across the usual opening at the heel, to protect a tender frog from injury. Bar shot a double headed shot, consisting of a bar, with a ball or half ball at each end; -- formerly used for destroying the masts or rigging in naval combat. Bar sinister Her a term popularly but erroneously used for baton, a mark of illegitimacy. See Baton. Bar tracery Arch ornamental stonework resembling bars of iron twisted into the forms required. Blank bar Law. See Blank. Case at bar Law a case presently before the court; a case under argument. In bar of as a sufficient reason against; to prevent.
Matter in bar, or Defence in bar
any matter which is a final defense in an action. Plea in bar a plea which goes to bar or defeat the plaintiff's action absolutely and entirely. Trial at bar Eng. Law a trial before all the judges of one the superior courts of Westminster, or before a quorum representing the full court.
entry.ety: OE. barre, F. barre, fr. LL. barra, W. bar the branch of a tree, bar, baren branch, Gael. & Ir. barra bar. √91

sn.def: A piece of wood, metal, or other material, long in proportion to its breadth or thickness, used as a lever and for various other purposes, but especially for a hindrance, obstruction, or fastening; as, the bars of a fence or gate; the bar of a door.
sn.q: Thou shalt make bars of shittim wood.

sn.def: An indefinite quantity of some substance, so shaped as to be long in proportion to its breadth and thickness; as, a bar of gold or of lead; a bar of soap.
Anything which obstructs, hinders, or prevents; an obstruction; a barrier.
sn.q: Must I new bars to my own joy create?

sn.def: A bank of sand, gravel, or other matter, esp. at the mouth of a river or harbor, obstructing navigation.
Any railing that divides a room, or office, or hall of assembly, in order to reserve a space for those having special privileges; as, the bar of the House of Commons.

sd.def: The railing that incloses the place which counsel occupy in courts of justice. Hence, the phrase at the bar of the court signifies in open court.
The place in court where prisoners are stationed for arraignment, trial, or sentence.
The whole body of lawyers licensed in a court or district; the legal profession.
A special plea constituting a sufficient answer to plaintiff's action.

sn.def: Any tribunal; as, the bar of public opinion; the bar of God.
A barrier or counter, over which liquors and food are passed to customers; hence, the portion of the room behind the counter where liquors for sale are kept.
An ordinary, like a fess but narrower, occupying only one fifth part of the field.
A broad shaft, or band, or stripe; as, a bar of light; a bar of color.
A vertical line across the staff. Bars divide the staff into spaces which represent measures, and are themselves called measures.

sd.def: The space between the tusks and grinders in the upper jaw of a horse, in which the bit is placed.
The part of the crust of a horse's hoof which is bent inwards towards the frog at the heel on each side, and extends into the center of the sole.
A drilling or tamping rod.
A vein or dike crossing a lode.
A gatehouse of a castle or fortified town.
A slender strip of wood which divides and supports the glass of a window; a sash bar.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Barredbärd); p. pr. & vb. n. Barring
entry.ety: F. barrer. See Bar n.

sn.def: To fasten with a bar; as, to bar a door or gate.

To restrict or confine, as if by a bar; to hinder; to obstruct; to prevent; to prohibit; as, to bar the entrance of evil; distance bars our intercourse; the statute bars my right; the right is barred by time; a release bars the plaintiff's recovery; -- sometimes with up.
sn.q: He barely looked the idea in the face, and hastened to bar it in its dungeon.

sn.def: To except; to exclude by exception.
sn.q: Nay, but I bar to-night: you shall not gauge me By what we do to-night.

sn.def: To cross with one or more stripes or lines.
sn.q: For the sake of distinguishing the feet more clearly, I have barred them singly.

entry.def: An international, interdenominational organization of Bible classes of young men; -- so named in allusion to the Hebrew word BerachahMeaning blessing) occurring in 2 Chron. xx. 26 and 1 Chron. xii.

entry.ety: Gr. � weight
entry.def: The pressure of one dyne per square centimeter; -- used as a unit of pressure.

entry.ety: Gr. � weight + æsthesiometer
entry.def: An instrument for determining the delicacy of the sense of pressure.
A soft fabric with a kind of basket weave and a diapered pattern.

entry.ety: F. barbe, fr. L. barba beard. See Beard n.

sn.def: Beard, or that which resembles it, or grows in the place of it.
sn.q: The barbel, so called by reason of his barbs, or wattles in his mouth.

sn.def: A muffler, worn by nuns and mourners.

Paps, or little projections, of the mucous membrane, which mark the opening of the submaxillary glands under the tongue in horses and cattle. The name is mostly applied when the barbs are inflamed and swollen.
The point that stands backward in an arrow, fishhook, etc., to prevent it from being easily extracted. Hence: Anything which stands out with a sharp point obliquely or crosswise to something else.
sn.q: Having twobarbsor points.

sn.def: A bit for a horse.
One of the side branches of a feather, which collectively constitute the vane. See Feather.
A southern name for the kingfishes of the eastern and southeastern coasts of the United States; -- also improperly called whiting.
A hair or bristle ending in a double hook.

entry.def: The terrestrial Siberian squirrel (Eutamius sibiricus).
the inability to estimate the weight of an object.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Barbed bärbd; p. pr. & vb. n. Barbing

sn.def: To shave or dress the beard of.
To clip; to mow.
To furnish with barbs, or with that which will hold or hurt like barbs, as an arrow, fishhook, spear, etc.
sn.q: But rattling storm of arrows barbed with fire.

entry.ety: F. barbe, fr. Barbarie

sn.def: The Barbary horse, a superior breed introduced from Barbary into Spain by the Moors.
A blackish or dun variety of the pigeon, originally brought from Barbary.

entry.ety: Corrupted fr. bard
entry.def: Armor for a horse. Same as 2d Bard n., 1.
See Barbican.
See Barbicanage.

a species of elephantiasis incident to hot climates.

entry.def: A West Indian island, giving its name to a disease, to a cherry, etc.

entry.ety: Coined by logicians

a genus of biennial or perennial herbs of north temperate regions: winter cress.

sn.def: A foreigner.

sn.def: A man in a rude, savage, or uncivilized state.
A person destitute of culture.
A cruel, savage, brutal man; one destitute of pity or humanity.

entry.def: Of, or pertaining to, or resembling, barbarians; rude; uncivilized; barbarous; as, barbarian governments or nations.

entry.def: the act or process of barbarizing; an act that makes people primitive and uncivilized.
same as barbarize.

entry.ety: L. barbarismus, Gr. barbarismo`s; cf. F. barbarisme

sn.def: An uncivilized state or condition; rudeness of manners; ignorance of arts, learning, and literature; barbarousness.
A barbarous, cruel, or brutal action; an outrage.
sn.q: A heinous barbarism . . . against the honor of marriage.

sn.def: An offense against purity of style or language; any form of speech contrary to the pure idioms of a particular language. See Solecism.
sn.q: The Greeks were the first that branded a foreign term in any of their writers with the odious name of barbarism.

entries.entry:
Bar*bar"i*ty n.; pl.Barbarities. From Barbarous
The state or manner of a barbarian; lack of civilization.
Cruelty; ferociousness; inhumanity. Treating Christians with a barbarity which would have shocked the very Moslem.
A barbarous or cruel act.
Barbarism; impurity of speech. Obs

sn.def: the act or process of barbarizing; an act that makes people primitive and uncivilized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Barbarized; p. pr. & vb. n. Barbarizing

sn.def: To become barbarous.
sn.q: The Roman empire was barbarizing rapidly from the time of Trajan.

sn.def: To adopt a foreign or barbarous mode of speech.
sn.q: The ill habit . . . of wretched barbarizing against the Latin and Greek idiom, with their untutored Anglicisms.

entry.ety: Cf. F. barbariser, LL. barbarizare

entry.q: The hideous changes which have barbarized France.

entry.ety: L. barbarus, Gr. ba`rbaros, strange, foreign; later, slavish, rude, ignorant; akin to L. balbus stammering, Skr. barbara stammering, outlandish. Cf. Brave a.

sn.def: Being in the state of a barbarian; uncivilized; rude; peopled with barbarians; as, a barbarous people; a barbarous country.
Foreign; adapted to a barbaric taste.
sn.q: Barbarous gold.

sn.def: Cruel; ferocious; inhuman; merciless.
sn.q: By their barbarous usage he died within a few days, to the grief of all that knew him.

sn.def: Contrary to the pure idioms of a language.

sn.syn: Uncivilized; unlettered; uncultivated; untutored; ignorant; merciless; brutal. See Ferocious.

entry.def: In a barbarous manner.

cs.cd: an ape (Macacus innuus) of north Africa and Gibraltar Rock, being the only monkey inhabiting Europe. It is very commonly trained by showmen.

entry.ety: Fr. Ar. Barbar the people of Barbary

a kind of pigeon.
a West Indian shrub or small tree (Jacquinia keyensis) having leathery saponaceous leaves and extremely hard wood.

entry.def: A European bat (Barbastellus communis), with hairy lips.

entry.ety: L. barbatus, fr. barba beard. See Barb beard

sn.def: a framework of metal or brick, usually with a grill on top, in which a fire is lighted and on which food is cooked, usually outdoors; -- also called a barbecue grill.

Barbs or paps under the tongues of horses and cattle. See 1st Barb, 3.

entry.def: A bar to which heavy discs are attached at each end; -- it is used for weightlifting exercises.

entry.cs: Barber's itch. See under Itch.

entry.ety: OE. barbour, OF. barbeor, F. barbier, as if fr. an assumed L. barbator, fr. barba beard. See 1st Barb
entry.def: One whose occupation it is to shave or trim the beard, and to cut and dress the hair of his patrons.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Barbered bär"bẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Barbering
entry.def: To shave and dress the beard or hair of.
A storm accompanied by driving ice spicules formed from sea water, esp. one occurring on the Gulf of St. Lawrence; -- so named from the cutting ice spicules.

entries.entry: Bar"ber fish. Zoöl See Surgeon fish.

entry.def: A fop.

entry.note: It is often electrically powered, so as to be turning when the barbershop is open for business and stationary when the shop is closed. It symbolizes the practise of surgery, some aspects of which which used to be performed by barbers.
entry.def: a pole with red and white spiral stripes; -- usually found outside a barbershop.

entry.ety: OE. barbarin barbere, OF. berbere
entry.def: A shrub of the genus Berberis, common along roadsides and in neglected fields. Berberis vulgaris is the species best known; its oblong red berries are made into a preserve or sauce, and have been deemed efficacious in fluxes and fevers. The bark dyes a fine yellow, esp. the bark of the root.
a shop where a barber works, especially one where men can get their hair cut.

entry.ety: F. barbet, fr. barbe beard, long hair of certain animals. See Barb beard
entry.def: A variety of small dog, having long curly hair.

A bird of the family Bucconidæ, allied to the Cuckoos, having a large, conical beak swollen at the base, and bearded with five bunches of stiff bristles; the puff bird. It inhabits tropical America and Africa.
A larva that feeds on aphids.

cs.cd: said of guns when they are elevated so as to fire over the top of a parapet, and not through embrasures.
a single gun, or a number of guns, mounted in barbette, or partially protected by a parapet or turret.
a gun carriage which elevates guns sufficiently to be in barbette. [See Illust. of Casemate

entry.ety: F. Cf. Barbet
entry.def: A mound of earth or a platform in a fortification, on which guns are mounted to fire over the parapet.

entry.ety: OE. barbican barbecan, F. barbacane, LL. barbacana barbicana, of uncertain origin: cf. Ar. barbakh aqueduct, sewer. F. barbacane also means, an opening to let out water, loophole

sn.def: A tower or advanced work defending the entrance to a castle or city, as at a gate or bridge. It was often large and strong, having a ditch and drawbridge of its own.
An opening in the wall of a fortress, through which missiles were discharged upon an enemy.

entry.ety: NL. barbicella, dim. of L. barba. See 1st Barb

A variety of paralysis, peculiar to India and the Malabar coast; -- considered by many to be the same as beriberi in a chronic form.

entry.ety: L. barba a beard + -gerous
entry.def: Having a beard; bearded; hairy.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. ba`rbiton
entry.def: An ancient Greek instrument resembling a lyre.

entries.entry: Bar`bi*tu"ric ac"id. Chem A white, crystalline substance, CH2(CO.NH)2.CO, derived from alloxantin, also from malonic acid and urea, and regarded as a substituted urea.

Bar`bi`zon" schoolorBar`bi`son" school . Painting A French school of the middle of the 19th century centering in the village of Barbizon near the forest of Fontainebleau. Its members went straight to nature in disregard of academic tradition, treating their subjects faithfully and with poetic feeling for color, light, and atmosphere. It is exemplified, esp. in landscapes, by Corot, Rousseau, Daubigny, Jules Dupré, and Diaz. Associated with them are certain painters of animals, as Troyon and Jaque, and of peasant life, as Millet and Jules Breton.

entry.def: See Barbel.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A paste of clay used in decorating coarse pottery in relief.
Barbarian.

entry.ety: L. barbula, fr. barba beard

sn.def: A very minute barb or beard.

entry.ety: It. barcone, fr. barca a bark

sn.def: Plain; simple; unadorned; without polish; bald; meager.

bare-breasted bâr"brĕst`ĕd adj. wearing no covering for the breasts or featuring such nudity.
bare-breasted beauties parading along the beach" braless, topless.

entry.cs: Bargain and sale Law a species of conveyance, by which the bargainor contracts to convey the lands to the bargainee, and becomes by such contract a trustee for and seized to the use of the bargainee. The statute then completes the purchase; i. e., the bargain vests the use, and the statute vests the possession. Blackstone. Into the bargain over and above what is stipulated; besides. To sell bargains to make saucy (usually indelicate) repartees. Obs Swift. To strike a bargain to reach or ratify an agreement. “A bargain was struck.” Macaulay.
entry.ety: OE. bargayn bargany, OF. bargaigne bargagne, prob. from a supposed LL. barcaneum, fr. barca a boat which carries merchandise to the shore; hence, to traffic to and fro, to carry on commerce in general. See Bark a vessel.

sn.def: An agreement between parties concerning the sale of property; or a contract by which one party binds himself to transfer the right to some property for a consideration, and the other party binds himself to receive the property and pay the consideration.
sn.q: A contract is a bargain that is legally binding.

sn.def: An agreement or stipulation; mutual pledge.
sn.q: And whon your honors mean to solemnize The bargain of your faith.

sn.def: A purchase; also ( when not qualified), a gainful transaction; an advantageous purchase; as, to buy a thing at a bargain .
The thing stipulated or purchased; also, anything bought cheap.
sn.q: She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.

entry.ety: OE. barganien, OF. bargaigner, F. barguigner, to hesitate, fr. LL. barcaniare. See Bargain n.
entry.def: To make a bargain; to make a contract for the exchange of property or services; -- followed by with and for; as, to bargain with a farmer for a cow.
entry.q: So worthless peasants bargain for their wives.

entry.cs: To bargain away to dispose of in a bargain; -- usually with a sense of loss or disadvantage; as, to bargain away one's birthright. “The heir . . . had somehow bargained away the estate.” G. Eliot.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bargained�); p. pr. & vb. n. Bargaining
entry.def: To transfer for a consideration; to barter; to trade; as, to bargain one horse for another.

entry.ety: OF. bargaigné, p. p. See Bargain v. i.

entry.ety: OF. barge, F. berge, fr. LL. barca, for baricanot found), prob. fr. L. baris an Egyptian rowboat, fr. Gr. �, prob. fr. Egyptian: cf. Coptic bari a boat. Cf. Bark a vessel

entries.entry: Bar" i`ron. See under Iron.

entry.def: Native sulphate of barium, a mineral occurring in transparent, colorless, white to yellow crystals (generally tabular), also in granular form, and in compact massive forms resembling marble. It has a high specific gravity, and hence is often called heavy spar. It is a common mineral in metallic veins.
See Barytone.

entry.note: ☞ Some of the compounds of this element are remarkable for their high specific gravity, as the sulphate, called heavy spar, and the like. The oxide was called barote, by Guyton de Morveau, which name was changed by Lavoisier to baryta, whence the name of the metal.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. bary`s heavy
entry.def: One of the elements, belonging to the alkaline earth group; a metal having a silver-white color, and melting at a very high temperature. It is difficult to obtain the pure metal, from the facility with which it becomes oxidized in the air. Atomic weight, 137. Symbol, Ba. Its oxide called baryta.

entry.cs: Bark bed. See Bark stovebelow). Bark pit a pit filled with bark and water, in which hides are steeped in tanning. Bark stove Hort a glazed structure for keeping tropical plants, having a bed of tanner's bark (called a bark bed) or other fermentable matter which produces a moist heat.
entry.ety: Akin to Dan. & Sw. bark, Icel. börkr, LG. & HG. borke

To make a clamor; to make importunate outcries.
