entries.entry: Bark"er's mill`. From Dr. Barker, the inventor A machine, invented in the 17th century, worked by a form of reaction wheel. The water flows into a vertical tube and gushes from apertures in hollow horizontal arms, causing the machine to revolve on its axis.

Full of barm or froth; in a ferment.
entry.q: Barmybeer.

cs.cd: an owl of Europe and America (Aluco flammeus, or Strix flammea), which frequents barns and other buildings.
the common American swallow (Hirundo horreorum), which attaches its nest of mud to the beams and rafters of barns.

entry.ety: OE. bern, AS. berern bern; bere barley + ern ærn, a close place. √92. See Barley
entry.def: A covered building used chiefly for storing grain, hay, and other productions of a farm. In the United States a part of the barn is often used for stables.
To lay up in a barn.
entry.q: Men . . . often barn up the chaff, and burn up the grain.

entry.def: A child. See Bairn.
A member of a religious order, named from St. Barnabas .

cs.cd: the orange filefish.
a bark louse (Ceroplastes cirripediformis) of the orange and quince trees in Florida. The female scale curiously resembles a sessile barnacle in form.

entry.ety: Prob. from E. barnacle a kind of goose, which was popularly supposed to grow from this shellfish; but perh. from LL. bernacula for pernacula, dim. of perna ham, sea mussel; cf. Gr. pe`rna ham. Cf. F. bernacle barnacle, E. barnacle a goose; and Ir. bairneach barneach, limpet
entry.def: Any cirriped crustacean adhering to rocks, floating timber, ships, etc., esp. the sessile species (genus Balanus and allies), and the stalked or goose barnacles (genus Lepas and allies). See Cirripedia, and Goose barnacle.

entry.ety: See Bernicle
entry.def: A bernicle goose.

entry.note: Formerly used in the sing.
entry.ety: OE. bernak bernacle; cf. OF. bernac, and Prov. F. (Berriberniques, spectacles

sn.def: An instrument for pinching a horse's nose, and thus restraining him.
sn.q: The barnacles . . . give pain almost equal to that of the switch.

sn.def: Spectacles; -- so called from their resemblance to the barnacles used by farriers.
covered with barnacles.
sn.illu: the barnacled hull of a wrecked ship

entry.ety: So called in allusion to the fable of the man who burned his barn in order to rid it of rats

sn.def: A member of the radical section of the Democratic party in New York, about the middle of the 19th century, which was hostile to extension of slavery, public debts, corporate privileges, etc., and supported Van Buren against Cass for president in 1848; -- opposed to Hunker.

entry.sn: an impressively successful or unusually good event. informal ”The rock concert was a real barnburner.”

entry.def: An opaque adjustable flap on a lamp fixture; used in photography to cut off light from particular areas.

sn.def: The quantity that a barn will hold.

entry.ety: Barn + storm, v

sn.def: To travel from place to place, making brief stops.
To fly an airplane from place to place, usually at small airports, doing flying stunts or flying passengers for sightseeing, for the purpose of earning money.
to tour the country to solicit votes.

entry.ety: Barn + storm, v

sn.def: An itinerant theatrical player who plays in barns when a theatre is lacking; hence, an inferior actor, or one who plays in the country away from the larger cities.

an aviator who flies an airplane from place to place, usually at small airports, doing flying stunts or flying passengers for sightseeing, for the purpose of earning money. It was a practise common in the early days of aviation, but by late 20th century was seldom encountered.

entry.def: A yard belonging to a barn.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: See Baroque.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`ros weight + cyclone + -meter
entry.def: An aneroid barometer for use with accompanying graphic diagrams and printed directions designed to aid mariners to interpret the indications of the barometer so as to determine the existence of a violent storm at a distance of several hundred miles.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`ros weight + -gram
entry.def: A tracing, usually made by the barograph, showing graphically the variations of atmospheric pressure for a given time.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`ros weight + -graph
entry.def: An instrument for recording automatically the variations of atmospheric pressure.

entry.ety: A mnemonic word
entry.def: A form or mode of syllogism of which the first proposition is a universal affirmative, and the other two are particular negatives.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`ros weight + -logy
entry.def: The science of weight or gravity.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`ros weight + makro`s long + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for ascertaining the weight and length of a newborn infant.

entry.note: ☞ The barometer was invented by Torricelli at Florence about 1643. It is made in its simplest form by filling a graduated glass tube about 34 inches long with mercury and inverting it in a cup containing mercury. The column of mercury in the tube descends until balanced by the weight of the atmosphere, and its rise or fall under varying conditions is a measure of the change in the atmospheric pressure. At the sea level its ordinary height is about 30 inches (760 millimeters). See Sympiesometer.
entry.cs: Aneroid barometer. See Aneroid barometer, under Aneroid. Marine barometer a barometer with tube contracted at bottom to prevent rapid oscillations of the mercury, and suspended in gimbals from an arm or support on shipboard. Mountain barometer a portable mercurial barometer with tripod support, and long scale, for measuring heights. Siphon barometer a barometer having a tube bent like a hook with the longer leg closed at the top. The height of the mercury in the longer leg shows the pressure of the atmosphere. Wheel barometer a barometer with recurved tube, and a float, from which a cord passes over a pulley and moves an index.
entry.ety: Gr. ba`ros weight + -meter: cf. F. baromètre
entry.def: An instrument for determining the weight or pressure of the atmosphere, and hence for judging of the probable changes of weather, or for ascertaining the height of any ascent.
Pertaining to the barometer; made or indicated by a barometer; as, barometric changes; barometrical observations.
By means of a barometer, or according to barometric observations.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`ros weight + me`tron measure + -graph
entry.def: A form of barometer so constructed as to inscribe of itself upon paper a record of the variations of atmospheric pressure.
The art or process of making barometrical measurements.

entry.ety: Cf. Russ. baranets' clubmoss
entry.def: The woolly-skinned rhizoma or rootstock of a fern (Dicksonia barometz), which, when specially prepared and inverted, somewhat resembles a lamb; -- called also Scythian lamb.

entry.note: ☞ “The tenants in chief from the Crown, who held lands of the annual value of four hundred pounds, were styled Barons; and it is to them, and not to the members of the lowest grade of the nobility (to whom the title at the present time belongs), that reference is made when we read of the Barons of the early days of England's history. . . . Barons are addressed as ‘My Lord,' and are styled ‘Right Honorable.' All their sons and daughters are ‘Honorable.'”

cs.cd: two sirloins not cut asunder at the backbone.
formerly members of the House of Commons, elected by the seven Cinque Ports, two for each port.
the judges of the Court of Exchequer, one of the three ancient courts of England, now abolished.

entry.ety: OE. baron barun, OF. baron, accus. of ber, F. baron, prob. fr. OHG. baronot found) bearer, akin to E. bear to support; cf. O. Frisian bere, LL. baro, It. barone, Sp. varon. From the meaning bearerof burdens) seem to have come the senses strong man manin distinction from woman), which is the oldest meaning in French, and lastly, nobleman. Cf. L. baro, simpleton. See Bear to support

sn.def: A title or degree of nobility; originally, the possessor of a fief, who had feudal tenants under him; in modern times, in France and Germany, a nobleman next in rank below a count; in England, a nobleman of the lowest grade in the House of Lords, being next below a viscount.
A husband; as, baron and feme, husband and wife.

entry.ety: OE. barnage baronage, OF. barnage, F. baronnage; cf. LL. baronagium

sn.def: The whole body of barons or peers.
sn.q: The baronage of the kingdom.

sn.def: The dignity or rank of a baron.
The land which gives title to a baron.

entry.def: same as baranduki; the terrestrial Siberian squirrel.
entry.syn: baranduki, barunduki, burunduki, Eutamius asiaticus, Eutamius sibiricus.

entry.def: A baron's wife; also, a lady who holds the baronial title in her own right; as, the Baroness Burdett-Coutts.

entry.note: ☞ The order was founded by James I. in 1611, and is given by patent. The word, however, in the sense of a lesser baron, was in use long before. “Baronets have the title of 'Sir' prefixed to their Christian names; their surnames being followed by their dignity, usually abbreviated Bart. Their wives are addressed as 'Lady' or 'Madam'. Their sons are possessed of no title beyond 'Esquire.'”
entry.ety: Baron + -et
entry.def: A dignity or degree of honor next below a baron and above a knight, having precedency of all orders of knights except those of the Garter. It is the lowest degree of honor that is hereditary. The baronets are commoners.

sn.def: State or rank of a baronet.
The collective body of baronets.

entry.def: The rank or patent of a baronet.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A kind of cutting weapon similar to a cleaver, with a thick back and thin razorlike edge, used by the Moros of the Philippine Islands.
Pertaining to a baron or a barony.
entry.q: Baronialtenure.

entries.entry:
Bar"o*ny n.; pl.Baronies. OF. baronie, F. baronnie, LL. baronia. See Baron
The fee or domain of a baron; the lordship, dignity, or rank of a baron.
In Ireland, a territorial division, corresponding nearly to the English hundred, and supposed to have been originally the district of a native chief. There are 252 of these baronies. In Scotland, an extensive freehold. It may be held by a commoner.

entry.ety: F.; cf. It. barocco

sn.def: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of, an artistic style common in the 17th century, characterized by the use of complex and elaborate ornamentation, curved rather than straight lines, and, in music a high degree of embellishment.
Hence, overly complicated, or ornamented to excess; in bad taste; grotesque; odd.
Irregular in form; -- said esp. of a pearl.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`ros weight + -scope: cf. F. baroscope
entry.def: Any instrument showing the changes in the weight of the atmosphere; also, less appropriately, any instrument that indicates or foreshadows changes of the weather, as a deep vial of liquid holding in suspension some substance which rises and falls with atmospheric changes.
Pertaining to, or determined by, the baroscope.

entry.ety: Gr. � weight + thermograph
entry.def: An instrument for recording both pressure and temperature, as of the atmosphere.

entry.ety: G. barutsche, It. baroccio biroccio, LL. barrotium, fr. L. birotus two-wheeled; bi- = bis twice + rota wheel
entry.def: A four-wheeled carriage, with a falling top, a seat on the outside for the driver, and two double seats on the inside arranged so that the sitters on the front seat face those on the back seat.
A kind of light barouche.
A post sunk in the ground to receive the bars closing a passage into a field.
Same as 3d Bark n.

entry.ety: F. baracan bouracancf. Pr. barracan, It. baracane, Sp. barragan, Pg. barregana, LL. barracanus), fr. Ar. barrakān a kind of black gown, perh. fr. Per. barak a garment made of camel's hair
entry.def: A thick, strong stuff, somewhat like camlet; -- still used for outer garments in the Levant.

entry.ety: F. baraque, fr. It. baraccacf. Sp. barraca), from LL. barra bar. See Bar n.

sn.def: A building for soldiers, especially when in garrison. Commonly in the pl., originally meaning temporary huts, but now usually applied to a permanent structure or set of buildings.
sn.q: He lodged in a miserable hut or barrack, composed of dry branches and thatched with straw.

sn.def: A movable roof sliding on four posts, to cover hay, straw, etc.

entry.def: To supply with barracks; to establish in barracks; as, to barrack troops.
To live or lodge in barracks.

entry.ety: D. baar, OD. baer, naked, bare + kleed garment, i. e., cloth undressed or without nap
entry.def: A home-made woolen blanket without nap.

entry.ety: Sp. or Pg. barraca. See Barrack
entry.def: A slave warehouse, or an inclosure where slaves are quartered temporarily.

entry.note: ☞ That of Europe and our Atlantic coast is Sphyræna spetor Sphyræna vulgaris); a southern species is Sphyræna picuda; the Californian is Sphyræna argentea.
entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: Any of several voracious pikelike marine fishes allied to the gray mullets, constituting the genus Sphyræna and family Sphyrænidæ. The great barracuda (Sphyræna barracuda) of the West Indies, Florida, etc., is often six feet or more long, and as dangerous as a shark. In Cuba its flesh is reputed to be poisonous. Sphyræna Argentea of the Pacific coast and Sphyræna sphyræna of Europe are smaller species, and are used as food.

sn.def: A large edible fresh-water fish of Australia and New Zealand (Thyrsites atun).

entry.ety: F., fr. barrer to bar, from barre bar
entry.def: An artificial bar or obstruction placed in a river or watercourse to increase the depth of water; as, the barrages of the Nile.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A remarkable Australian fresh-water ganoid fish of the genus Ceratodus.
An Australian river fish (Osteoglossum Leichhardtii).

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: A ravine caused by heavy rains or a watercourse.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A resin, called also galipot.

entry.ety: OE. baratour, OF. barateor deceiver, fr. OF. barater bareter, to deceive, cheat, barter. See Barter v. i.
entry.def: One guilty of barratry.
Tainted with, or constituting, barratry.

entry.ety: Cf. F. baraterie, LL. barataria. See Barrator, and cf. Bartery

sn.def: The practice of exciting and encouraging lawsuits and quarrels.

A fraudulent breach of duty or willful act of known illegality on the part of a master of a ship, in his character of master, or of the mariners, to the injury of the owner of the ship or cargo, and without his consent. It includes every breach of trust committed with dishonest purpose, as by running away with the ship, sinking or deserting her, etc., or by embezzling the cargo.
The crime of a judge who is influenced by bribery in pronouncing judgment.

entries.entry: Barred" owl". Zoöl A large American owl (Syrnium nebulosum); -- so called from the transverse bars of a dark brown color on the breast.

entry.cs: Barrel bulk Com a measure equal to five cubic feet, used in estimating capacity, as of a vessel for freight. Barrel drain Arch a drain in the form of a cylindrical tube. Barrel of a boiler the cylindrical part of a boiler, containing the flues. Barrel of the ear Anat the tympanum, or tympanic cavity. Barrel organ an instrument for producing music by the action of a revolving cylinder. Barrel vault. See under Vault.
entry.ety: OE. barel, F. baril, prob. fr. barre bar. Cf. Barricade

sn.def: A round vessel or cask, of greater length than breadth, and bulging in the middle, made of staves bound with hoops, and having flat ends or heads; as, a cracker barrel . Sometimes applied to a similar cylindrical container made of metal, usually called a drum.

The quantity which constitutes a full barrel. This varies for different articles and also in different places for the same article, being regulated by custom or by law. A barrel of wine is 311/2 gallons; a barrel of flour is 196 pounds.
A solid drum, or a hollow cylinder or case; as, the barrel of a windlass; the barrel of a watch, within which the spring is coiled.
A metallic tube, as of a gun, from which a projectile is discharged.
A jar.
The hollow basal part of a feather.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Barreled -rĕld, or Barrelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Barreling, or Barrelling
entry.def: To put or to pack in a barrel or barrels.

entries.entry: bar"rel cac"tus băr"rĕl kăk"tŭs n.; pl. barrel cacti băr"rĕl kăk"tī . any of several large cacti native to the southwestern U. S. and Mexico, having a short cylindrical form with deep vertical ribs and bearing sharp spines. They are classed in the genera Ferocactus and Echinocactus.

sn.def: Having a barrel; -- used in composition; as, a double-barreled gun.
put in or stored in a barrel; ; as, barreled beer; -- opposite of unbarreled.
tapered toward both ends; -- of an arrow.

entry.def: A blackish fish (Hyperglyphe perciformis) of New England waters.
The quantity that a barrel (of any size) will hold.
A cheap drinking and dancing establishment.

entries.entry: Bar"rel proc"ess. Metal A process of extracting gold or silver by treating the ore in a revolving barrel, or drum, with mercury, chlorine, cyanide solution, or other reagent.

cs.cd: a flower which has only stamens without a pistil, or which has neither stamens nor pistils.
a vast tract in British America northward of the forest regions.
a peculiar bear, inhabiting the Barren Grounds, now believed to be a variety of the brown bear of Europe.
a small reindeer (Rangifer Grœnlandicus) peculiar to the Barren Grounds and Greenland.

entry.ety: OE. barein, OF. brehaing, fem. brehaigne baraigne, F. bréhaigne; of uncertain origin; cf. Arm. brékhañ markhañ, sterile; LL. brana a sterile mare, principally in Aquitanian and Spanish documents; Bisc. barau baru, fasting

sn.def: Incapable of producing offspring; producing no young; sterile; -- said of women and female animals.
sn.q: She was barren of children.

sn.def: Not producing vegetation, or useful vegetation; sterile.
sn.q: Barrenmountain tracts.

sn.def: Unproductive; fruitless; unprofitable; empty.
sn.q: Brilliant but barren reveries.
Some schemes will appear barren of hints and matter.

sn.def: Mentally dull; stupid.
A tract of barren land.
Elevated lands or plains on which grow small trees, but not timber; as, pine barrens; oak barrens . They are not necessarily sterile, and are often fertile.

entry.def: Unfruitfully; unproductively.
The condition of being barren; sterility; unproductiveness.
entry.q: A total barrenness of invention.

entry.def: An herbaceous plant of the Barberry family (Epimedium alpinum), having leaves that are bitter and said to be sudorific.

entry.ety: F. barrette, LL. barretum a cap. See Berretta, and cf. Biretta
entry.def: A kind of cap formerly worn by soldiers; -- called also barret cap. Also, the flat cap worn by Roman Catholic ecclesiastics.

entry.note: ☞ The original form consisted of an extremely fine platinum wire loop attached to terminals and inclosed in a small glass or silver bulb. It operates by increased resistance when subjected to the influence of an electric current. In a later variety, called the liquid barretter, wire is replace by a column of liquid in a very fine capillary tube. A recent version has a resistor composed of an iron wire in a glass bulb containing hydrogen, with the temperature variation of resistance such that the current passing through it remains constant over a wide range of applied voltages.
entry.ety: OF. bareter to exchange. Cf. Barter

sn.def: a resistor inserted into a circuit to compensate for changes (such as those arising from temperature fluctuations); a thermal cymoscope.

entry.ety: F. barricade, fr. Sp. barricada, orig. a barring up with casks; fr. barrica cask, perh. fr. LL. barra bar. See Bar n., and cf. Barrel n.

sn.def: A fortification, made in haste, of trees, earth, palisades, wagons, or anything that will obstruct the progress or attack of an enemy. It is usually an obstruction formed in streets to block an enemy's access.
Any bar, obstruction, or means of defense.
sn.q: Such a barricade as would greatly annoy, or absolutely stop, the currents of the atmosphere.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Barricaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Barricading
entry.ety: Cf. F. barricader. See Barricade n.
entry.def: To fortify or close with a barricade or with barricades; to stop up, as a passage; to obstruct; as, the workmen barricaded the streets of Paris.
entry.q: The further end whereof [a bridge] was barricaded with barrels.

entry.def: One who constructs barricades.
See Barricade.

cs.cd: a heavy gate to close the opening through a barrier.
a form of coral reef which runs in the general direction of the shore, and incloses a lagoon channel more or less extensive.
to fight with a barrier between, as a martial exercise.

entry.ety: OE. barrere barere, F. barrière, fr. barre bar. See Bar n.

sn.def: A carpentry obstruction, stockade, or other obstacle made in a passage in order to stop an enemy.
A fortress or fortified town, on the frontier of a country, commanding an avenue of approach.
A fence or railing to mark the limits of a place, or to keep back a crowd.
sn.q: No sooner were the barriers opened, than he paced into the lists.

sn.def: Any obstruction; anything which hinders approach or attack.
sn.q: Constitutionalbarriers.

sn.def: Any limit or boundary; a line of separation.
sn.q: 'Twixt that [instinct] and reason, what a nice barrier!

entry.ety: Native name, fr. Sp. barrigudo big-bellied
entry.def: A large, dark-colored, South American monkey, of the genus Lagothrix, having a long prehensile tail.
the act of excluding someone by a negative vote or veto.
The act of closing the doors of a schoolroom against a schoolmaster; -- a boyish mode of rebellion in schools.

entries.entry: Bar"ri*o Bar"ri*o n.; pl. Barrios # . Sp In Spain and countries colonized by Spain, a village, ward, or district outside a town or city to whose jurisdiction it belongs; in Spanish-speaking areas of cities in the United States, it is a neighborhood, ward, or quarter inside a town.

entry.ety: From Bar n.
entry.def: Counselor at law; a counsel admitted to plead at the bar, and undertake the public trial of causes, as distinguished from an attorney or solicitor. See Attorney.

sn.def: A room containing a bar or counter at which liquors are sold.
a commercial establishment where alcoholic drinks are served over a counter.

entry.ety: OE. barow, fr. AS. beran to bear. See Bear to support, and cf. Bier

sn.def: A support having handles, and with or without a wheel, on which heavy or bulky things can be transported by hand. See Handbarrow, and Wheelbarrow.
A wicker case, in which salt is put to drain.

entry.ety: OE. barow bargh, AS. bearg bearh; akin to Icel. börgr, OHG. barh barug, G. barch. √95
entry.def: A hog, esp. a male hog castrated.

entry.ety: OE. bergh, AS. beorg beorh, hill, sepulchral mound; akin to G. berg mountain, Goth. bairgahei hill, hilly country, and perh. to Skr. bṛhant high, OIr. brigh mountain. Cf. Berg Berry a mound, and Borough an incorporated town

sn.def: A large mound of earth or stones over the remains of the dead; a tumulus.
A heap of rubbish, attle, etc.

entry.def: A follower of Henry Barrowe , one of the founders of Independency or Congregationalism in England. Barrowe was executed for nonconformity in 1593.

entry.ety: Dim. of bar, n
entry.def: A diminutive of the bar, having one fourth its width.
Traversed by barrulets or small bars; -- said of the field.
Divided into bars; -- said of the field.

entry.ety: AS. bears bærs, akin to D. baars, G. bars barsch. Cf. 1st Bass n.
entry.def: The common perch. See 1st Bass.
an abbreviation of baronet.
entry.q: Since he was a baronet he had to be addressed asSir Henry Jones, Bart.

entry.def: A barkeeper.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Barteredbär"tẽrd); p. pr. & vb. n. Bartering
entry.ety: OE. bartren, OF. barater bareter, to cheat, exchange, perh. fr. Gr. pra`ttein to do, deal (well or ill), use practices or tricks, or perh. fr. Celtic; cf. Ir. brath treachery, W. brad. Cf. Barrator
entry.def: To traffic or trade, by exchanging one commodity for another, in distinction from a sale and purchase, in which money is paid for the commodities transferred; to truck.
To trade or exchange in the way of barter; to exchange (frequently for an unworthy consideration); to traffic; to truck; -- sometimes followed by away; as, to barter away goods or honor.

sn.def: The act or practice of trafficking by exchange of commodities; an exchange of goods.
sn.q: The spirit of huckstering and barter.

sn.def: The thing given in exchange.

entry.def: One who barters.
Barter.

entry.ety: Etymol. unknown
entry.def: A place of shelter for cattle.

entries.entry: Bar*thol"o*mew tide`. Time of the festival of St. Bartholomew, August 24th.

entry.ety: Cf. Brettice
entry.def: A small, overhanging structure for lookout or defense, usually projecting at an angle of a building or near an entrance gateway.

A Bartlett pear, a favorite kind of pear, which originated in England about 1770, and was called Williams' Bonchrétien. It was brought to America, and distributed by Mr. Enoch Bartlett, of Dorchester, Massachusetts.

entry.ety: AS. beretūn courtyard, grange; bere barley + tūn an inclosure

sn.def: The demesne lands of a manor; also, the manor itself.
A farmyard.

entry.def: See Bertram.
A passage into a field or yard, closed by bars made to take out of the posts.
Horizontally.
A red wood of a leguminous tree (Baphia nitida), from Angola and the Gabon in Africa. It is used as a dyewood, and also for ramrods, violin bows and turner's work.
the point representing the mean position of the matter in a body.

entry.ety: Gr. bary`s heavy + ke`ntron center
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the center of gravity. See Barycentric calculus, under Calculus.

sn.def: any of the elementary particles having a mass equal to or greater than that of a proton and that participate in strong interactions; a hadron with a baryon number of +1.

entry.ety: Gr. bary`s heavy + fwnh` a sound, voice
entry.def: Difficulty of speech.

entry.ety: Gr. bary`s heavy + sphere
entry.def: The heavy interior portion of the earth, within the lithosphere.

entry.ety: Gr. bary`s heavy. Cf. Baria
entry.def: An oxide of barium (or barytum); a heavy earth with a specific gravity above 4.

entry.ety: Gr. bary`s heavy: cf. Gr. bary`ths heaviness, F. baryte
entry.def: Barium sulphate, generally called heavy spar or barite. See Barite.
Of or pertaining to baryta.

entry.ety: Baryta + calcite
entry.def: A mineral of a white or gray color, occurring massive or crystallized. It is a compound of the carbonates of barium and calcium.

entry.ety: Gr. bary`tonos; bary`s heavy + to`nos tone

sn.def: Grave and deep, as a kind of male voice.
Not marked with an accent on the last syllable, the grave accent being understood.

entry.ety: F. baryton: cf. It. baritono

sd.def: A male voice, the compass of which partakes of the common bass and the tenor, but which does not descend as low as the one, nor rise as high as the other.
A person having a voice of such range.
The viola di gamba, now entirely disused.

sn.def: A word which has no accent marked on the last syllable, the grave accent being understood.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: The metal barium. See Barium.

entry.cs: Basal cleavage. See under Cleavage. Basal plane Crystallog a plane parallel to the lateral or horizontal axis.
entry.def: Relating to, or forming, the base.
Having the nerves radiating from the base; -- said of leaves.

entry.note: ☞ It is usually of a greenish black color, or of some dull brown shade, or black. It constitutes immense beds in some regions, and also occurs in veins or dikes cutting through other rocks. It has often a prismatic structure as at the Giant's Causeway, in Ireland, where the columns are as regular as if the work of art. It is a very tough and heavy rock, and is one of the best materials for macadamizing roads.
entry.ety: L. basaltesan African word), a dark and hard species of marble found in Ethiopia: cf. F. basalte

sn.def: A rock of igneous origin, consisting of augite and triclinic feldspar, with grains of magnetic or titanic iron, and also bottle-green particles of olivine frequently disseminated.
An imitation, in pottery, of natural basalt; a kind of black porcelain.

entry.ety: Cf. F. basaltique
entry.def: Pertaining to basalt; formed of, or containing, basalt; as basaltic lava.

entry.ety: Basalt + -form
entry.def: In the form of basalt; columnar.

entry.ety: Basalt + -oid
entry.def: Formed like basalt; basaltiform.
Same as Basil, a sheepskin.

entry.ety: L. basanites lapis, Gr. ba`sanos the touchstone: cf. F. basanite
entry.def: Lydian stone, or black jasper, a variety of siliceous or flinty slate, of a grayish or bluish black color. It is employed to test the purity of gold, the amount of alloy being indicated by the color left on the stone when rubbed by the metal.

entry.ety: F., fr. bas stocking + bleu blue
entry.def: A bluestocking; a literary woman.

entry.ety: OE. bacinet basnet, OF. bassinet bacinet, F. bassinet, dim. of OF. bacin, F. bassin, a helmet in the form of a basin
entry.def: A light helmet, at first open, but later made with a visor.

cs.cd: a counterpoise or balanced drawbridge, which is opened by sinking the counterpoise and thus lifting the footway into the air.

entry.ety: F., a seesaw
entry.def: In mechanics, an apparatus on the principle of the seesaw, in which one end rises as the other falls.

entry.cs: Base fee formerly, an estate held at the will of the lord; now, a qualified fee. See note under Fee n., 4. Base metal. See under Metal.
entry.usage: Base Vile Mean. These words, as expressing moral qualities, are here arranged in the order of their strength, the strongest being placed first. Base marks a high degree of moral turpitude; vile and mean denote, in different degrees, the lack of what is valuable or worthy of esteem. What is base excites our abhorrence; what is vile provokes our disgust or indignation; what is mean awakens contempt. Base is opposed to high-minded; vile, to noble; mean, to liberal or generous. Ingratitude is base; sycophancy is vile; undue compliances are mean.
entry.ety: OE. bass, F. bas, low, fr. LL. bassus thick, fat, short, humble; cf. L. Bassus, a proper name, and W. bas shallow. Cf. Bass a part in music

sn.def: Of little, or less than the usual, height; of low growth; as, base shrubs.
Low in place or position.
Of humble birth; or low degree; lowly; mean.
sn.q: A peasant andbaseswain.

sn.def: Illegitimate by birth; bastard.
sn.q: Why bastard? wherefore base?

sn.def: Of little comparative value, as metal inferior to gold and silver, the precious metals.
Alloyed with inferior metal; debased; as, base coin; base bullion.
Morally low. Hence: Low-minded; unworthy; without dignity of sentiment; ignoble; mean; illiberal; menial; as, a base fellow; base motives; base occupations.
sn.q: A cruel act of abaseand a cowardish mind.
Baseingratitude.

sn.def: Not classical or correct.
sn.q: BaseLatin.

sn.def: Deep or grave in sound; as, the base tone of a violin.
Not held by honorable service; as, a base estate, one held by services not honorable; held by villenage. Such a tenure is called base, or low, and the tenant, a base tenant.
sn.syn: Dishonorable; worthless; ignoble; low-minded; infamous; sordid; degraded.

entry.cs: Altern base. See under Altern. Attic base. Arch See under Attic. Base course. Arch The first or lower course of a foundation wall, made of large stones or a mass of concrete; -- called also foundation course. The architectural member forming the transition between the basement and the wall above. Base hit Baseball a hit, by which the batsman, without any error on the part of his opponents, is able to reach the first base without being put out. Base line. A main line taken as a base, as in surveying or in military operations. A line traced round a cannon at the rear of the vent. Base plate the foundation plate of heavy machinery, as of the steam engine; the bed plate. Base ring Ordnance a projecting band of metal around the breech, connected with the body of the gun by a concave molding. H. L. Scott.
entry.ety: F. base, L. basis, fr. Gr. ba`sis a stepping, step, a base, pedestal, fr. bai`nein to go, step, akin to E. come. Cf. Basis, and see Come

sn.def: The bottom of anything, considered as its support, or that on which something rests for support; the foundation; as, the base of a statue.
sn.q: Thebaseof mighty mountains.

sn.def: Fig.: The fundamental or essential part of a thing; the essential principle; a groundwork.

sd.def: The lower part of a wall, pier, or column, when treated as a separate feature, usually in projection, or especially ornamented.
The lower part of a complete architectural design, as of a monument; also, the lower part of any elaborate piece of furniture or decoration.

sn.def: That extremity of a leaf, fruit, etc., at which it is attached to its support.

The positive, or non-acid component of a salt; a substance which, combined with an acid, neutralizes the latter and forms a salt; -- applied also to the hydroxides of the positive elements or radicals, and to certain organic bodies resembling them in their property of forming salts with acids.
The chief ingredient in a compound.
A substance used as a mordant.
The exterior side of the polygon, or that imaginary line which connects the salient angles of two adjacent bastions.
The line or surface constituting that part of a figure on which it is supposed to stand.
The number from which a mathematical table is constructed; as, the base of a system of logarithms.
A low, or deep, sound. Mus The lowest part; the deepest male voice. One who sings, or the instrument which plays, base.
sn.q: The trebles squeak for fear, the bases roar.

sn.def: A place or tract of country, protected by fortifications, or by natural advantages, from which the operations of an army proceed, forward movements are made, supplies are furnished, etc.
The smallest kind of cannon.
That part of an organ by which it is attached to another more central organ.
The basal plane of a crystal.
The ground mass of a rock, especially if not distinctly crystalline.
The lower part of the field. See Escutcheon.
The housing of a horse.
A kind of skirt (often of velvet or brocade, but sometimes of mailed armor) which hung from the middle to about the knees, or lower.
The lower part of a robe or petticoat.
An apron.
sn.q: Bakers in their linenbases.

sn.def: The point or line from which a start is made; a starting place or a goal in various games.
sn.q: To their appointed base they went.

sn.def: A line in a survey which, being accurately determined in length and position, serves as the origin from which to compute the distances and positions of any points or objects connected with it by a system of triangles.
A rustic play; -- called also prisoner's base prison base, or bars.
sn.q: To run the countrybase.

sn.def: Any one of the four bounds which mark the circuit of the infield.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Based bāsd; p. pr. & vb. n. Basing
entry.ety: From Base n.
entry.def: To put on a base or basis; to lay the foundation of; to found, as an argument or conclusion; -- used with on or upon.

entry.ety: See Base a., and cf. Abase

sn.def: To abase; to let, or cast, down; to lower.
sn.q: If any . . . based his pike.

sn.def: To reduce the value of; to debase.
sn.q: Metals which we can not base.

sn.def: A game of ball, so called from the bases or bounds (four in number) which designate the circuit which each player must endeavor to make after striking the ball.
The ball used in this game.

entry.def: A board, or other woodwork, carried round the walls of a room and touching the floor, to form a base and protect the plastering; -- also called washboardin England), mopboard, and scrubboard.

sn.def: Born out of wedlock.
Born of low parentage.
Vile; mean.
sn.q: Thybasebornheart.

entry.def: A furnace or stove in which the fuel is contained in a hopper or chamber, and is fed to the fire as the lower stratum is consumed.

entry.ety: F. basse-cour. See Base a., and Court n.

sn.def: The secondary, inferior, or rear courtyard of a large house; the outer court of a castle.
An inferior court of law, not of record.

entries.entry:
Based bāsd p. p. & a.
Having a base, or having as a base; supported; as, broad-based .
See Base n., 18-21 Wearing, or protected by, bases. Obs
Basedin lawny velvet.

Ba"se*dow's dis*ease". Named for Dr. Basedow , a German physician Med A disease characterized by enlargement of the thyroid gland, prominence of the eyeballs, and inordinate action of the heart; -- called also exophthalmic goiter.

sn.def: causing formation of an alkali.

entry.ety: OF. baselarde, LL. basillardus
entry.def: A short sword or dagger, worn in the fifteenth century.
Without a base; having no foundation or support.
entry.q: Thebaselessfabric of this vision.

sn.def: an imaginary line or standard by which things are measured or compared; as, they established a baseline for the budget.
the back line at each end of a tennis court.
the lines between bases on a baseball field along which a baseball player must run while running the bases.

a measurement that represents the value of a physical quantity (such as a voltage, or a level of radioactivity) in the absence of effects from other variables in a measurement, test or experiment; a control value.
any horizontal line in a plot, graph, or diagram, or on a visual display in an electronic device, used as a reference point to which other values are referred.
In a base manner; with despicable meanness; dishonorably; shamefully.
Illegitimately; in bastardy.

cs.cd: a delicate membrane composed of a single layer of flat cells, forming the substratum upon which, in many organs, the epithelioid cells are disposed.

entry.ety: F. soubassement. Of uncertain origin. Cf. Base a. Bastion
entry.def: The outer wall of the ground story of a building, or of a part of that story, when treated as a distinct substructure. (See Base n., 3 .) Hence: The rooms of a ground floor, collectively.
The quality or condition of being base; degradation; vileness.
entry.q: I once did hold it a baseness to write fair.

entry.def: See Bascinet.

a unit of double-stranded DNA or RNA consisting of two complementary bases on opposing strands of the double-stranded polynucleotide, bound together by hydrogen bonds and other non-covalent chemical forces. The bases comprising the base pairs are adenine, thymine, cytidine, and guanine. In normal DNA, the base adenine on one strand of DNA pairs with thymine on the opposite strand, and cytosine on one strand pairs with guanine on the opposite strand. The term base pair usually includes the sugar (ribose or deoxyribose) and the phosphate bound to each base to form a nucleotide unit. One base pair is sometimes used as a unit of length or size for DNA, and in this usage is abbreviated bp; as, a 100-bp fragment of DNA. A length of 1000 base pairs is a kilobase pair or kbp.
the initial price of something (goods or services) without the additional charges that may be added, such as handling or shipping charges, sales tax, optional equipment charges, etc.

entries.entry: Base" vi`ol. See Bass viol.

entry.ety: OE. baschen baissen. See Abash
entry.def: To abash; to disconcert or be disconcerted or put out of countenance.
entry.q: His countenance was bold and bashed not.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bashed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bashing
entry.ety: Perh. of imitative origin; or cf. Dan. baske to strike, bask a blow, Sw. basa to beat, bas a beating
entry.def: To strike heavily; to beat; to crush.
entry.q: Bash her open with a rock.

sn.def: a forceful blow, especially one that does damage to its target.
a elaborate or lively social gathering or party.

entry.ety: See Pasha

sn.def: A Turkish title of honor, now written pasha. See Pasha.
Fig.: A magnate or grandee.
A very large siluroid fish (Leptops olivaris) of the Mississippi valley; -- also called goujon mud cat, and yellow cat.

entry.ety: See Bash

sn.def: Abashed; daunted; dismayed.
Very modest, or modest to excess; constitutionally disposed to shrink from public notice; indicating extreme or excessive modesty; shy; as, a bashful person, action, expression.

entry.def: In a bashful manner.

entry.usage: Modesty arises from a low estimate of ourselves; bashfulness is an abashment or agitation of the spirits at coming into contact with others; diffidence is produced by an undue degree of self-distrust; shyness usually arises from an excessive self-consciousness, and a painful impression that every one is looking at us. Modesty of deportment is becoming in all; bashfulness often gives rise to mistakes and blundering; diffidence in society frequently makes a man a burden to himself; shyness usually produces a reserve or distance which is often mistaken for haughtiness.
entry.def: The quality of being bashful.

entry.ety: Turkish, light-headed, a foolish fellow
entry.def: A soldier belonging to the irregular troops of the Turkish army.
Shameless; unblushing.
See Basyle.

entries.entry: Ba"si-. A combining form, especially in anatomical and botanical words, to indicate the base or position at or near a base; forming a base; as basibranchials, the most ventral of the cartilages or bones of the branchial arches; basicranial, situated at the base of the cranium; basifacial, basitemporal, etc.

cs.cd: a salt formed from a base or hydroxide by the partial replacement of its hydrogen by a negative or acid element or radical.

sd.def: Relating to a base; performing the office of a base in a salt.
Having the base in excess, or the amount of the base atomically greater than that of the acid, or exceeding in proportion that of the related neutral salt.
Apparently alkaline, as certain normal salts which exhibit alkaline reactions with test paper.

sn.def: Said of crystalline rocks which contain a relatively low percentage of silica, as basalt.

entry.note: Writing a program in BASIC or other higher computer languages is simpler than writing in assembly language. See also programming language FORTRAN.

sn.def: an artificial computer language with a relatively simplified instruction set.

entry.ety: Basi- + Gr. ke`ras horn, antenna
entry.def: The second joint of the antennæ of crustaceans.
The quality or state of being a base.
The power of an acid to unite with one or more atoms or equivalents of a base, as indicated by the number of replaceable hydrogen atoms contained in the acid.

entries.entry: Ba"sic proc"ess. Iron Metal A Bessemer or open-hearth steel-making process in which a lining that is basic, or not siliceous, is used, and additions of basic material are made to the molten charge during treatment. Opposed to acid process , above. Called also Thomas process.

sn.def: a statement of fundamental facts or principles.
principles from which other truths can be derived; as, let's get down to basics .
sn.syn: fundamentals, fundamental principle, basic principle, bedrock.

entries.entry: Basic slag. A by-product from the manufacture of steel by the basic process, used as a fertilizer. It is rich in lime and contains 14 to 20 per cent of phosphoric acid. Called also Thomas slag phosphatic slag, and odorless phosphate.
Basic steel. Steel produced by the basic process.

entry.def: of or pertaining to a basidium.
a lichen in which the fungus component is a basidiomycete.

sn.def: any of various fungi of the subdivision Basidiomycota.

entry.def: a phylum of fungi with the Basidiomycota
of or pertaining to basidiomycetes.

entry.note: In the 1913 Webster, the Basidiomycetes were defined as "coördinate with the Ascomycetes", and other fungal phyla (the Zygomycota and Deuteromycota) were not mentioned.
entry.ety: NL., fr. NL. & E. basidium + Gr. �, �, fungus
entry.def: A large subdivision of the kingdom Fungi coextensive with the phylum Basidiomycetes, characterized by having the spores borne on a basidium. It embraces those fungi best known to the public, such as mushrooms, toadstools, etc. Among the classes of the Basidiomycota are: Gasteromycetes puffballs); Tiliomycetes comprising the orders Ustilaginalessmuts) and Uredinalesrusts)); and Hymenomycetes mushrooms; toadstools; agarics; bracket fungi).
same as Basidiomycota.

entry.ety: Basidium + spore
entry.def: A spore borne by a basidium.
of or pertaining to a basidiospore.

entry.ety: NL., dim. of Gr. ba`sis base
entry.def: A special oblong or pyriform cell, with slender branches, which bears the spores in that division of fungi called Basidiomycetes, of which the common mushroom is an example.
That which converts into a salifiable base.

entry.ety: Base,n.+ L. fugere to flee
entry.def: Tending or proceeding away from the base; as, a basifugal growth.

entry.ety: Base + -fy
entry.def: To convert into a salifiable base.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ba`sis base + gynh` woman
entry.def: The pedicel on which the ovary of certain flowers, as the passion flower, is seated; a carpophore or thecaphore.

entry.ety: Basi- + Gr. υ (the letter “upsilon”); from the shape
entry.def: Noting two small bones, forming the body of the inverted hyoid arch.

entry.ety: Basi- + hyoid
entry.def: The central tongue bone.

entry.ety: Cf. F. basile and E. Bezel
entry.def: The slope or angle to which the cutting edge of a tool, as a plane, is ground.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Basiled�); p. pr. & vb. n. Basiling
entry.def: To grind or form the edge of to an angle.

cs.cd: a name given to the fragrant herbs Calamintha Acinos and Calamintha Nepeta.
a plant (Calamintha clinopodium) of the Mint family.

entry.ety: F. basilic, fr. L. basilicus royal, Gr. basiliko`s fr. basiley`s king
entry.def: The name given to several aromatic herbs of the Mint family, but chiefly to the common or sweet basil (Ocymum basilicum), and the bush basil, or lesser basil (Ocymum minimum), the leaves of which are used in cookery. The name is also given to several kinds of mountain mint (Pycnanthemum).

entry.ety: Corrupt. from E. basan, F. basane, LL. basanium bazana, fr. Ar. bithāna, prop., lining
entry.def: The skin of a sheep tanned with bark.

entry.ety: F. basilaire, fr. L. basis. See Base n.

sn.def: Relating to, or situated at, the base.
Lower; inferior; applied to impulses or springs of action.
sn.q: Basilarinstincts.

entry.def: a ruler of the eastern Roman Empire.

entry.ety: F. basilique
entry.def: Basilica.

entry.ety: See Basilica

sn.def: Royal; kingly; also, basilican.
Pertaining to certain parts, anciently supposed to have a specially important function in the animal economy, as the middle vein of the right arm.

entries.entry:
Ba*sil"i*ca n.; pl.Basilicas; sometimes Basilicæ -sē. L. basilica, Gr. basilikh`sc. o'iki`a or stoa` fr. basiliko`s royal, fr. basiley`s king
Originally, the palace of a king; but afterward, an apartment provided in the houses of persons of importance, where assemblies were held for dispensing justice; and hence, any large hall used for this purpose.
Arch
A building used by the Romans as a place of public meeting, with court rooms, etc., attached.
A church building of the earlier centuries of Christianity, the plan of which was taken from the basilica of the Romans. The name is still applied to some churches by way of honorary distinction.

entry.def: A digest of the laws of Justinian, translated from the original Latin into Greek, by order of Basil I., in the ninth century.
Of, relating to, or resembling, a basilica; basilical.
entry.q: There can be no doubt that the first churches in Constantinople were in the basilican form.

entry.ety: OF. basilicoc
entry.def: The basilisk.

entry.ety: L. basilicon, Gr. basiliko`n neut. of basiliko`s: cf. F. basilicon. See Basilica
entry.def: An ointment composed of wax, pitch, resin, and olive oil, lard, or other fatty substance.

entry.note: ☞ This genus is remarkable for a membranous bag rising above the occiput, which can be filled with air at pleasure; also for an elevated crest along the back, that can be raised or depressed at will.
entry.ety: L. basiliscus, Gr. basili`skos little king, kind of serpent, dim. of basiley`s king; -- so named from some prominences on the head resembling a crown.]

sn.def: A fabulous serpent, or dragon. The ancients alleged that its hissing would drive away all other serpents, and that its breath, and even its look, was fatal. See Cockatrice.
sn.q: Make me not sighted like the basilisk.

sn.def: A lizard of the genus Basiliscus, belonging to the family Iguanidæ.
A large piece of ordnance, so called from its supposed resemblance to the serpent of that name, or from its size.

entry.ety: OF. bacin, F. bassin, LL. bacchinus, fr. bacca a water vessel, fr. L. bacca berry, in allusion to the round shape; or perh. fr. Celtic. Cf. Bac

sn.def: A hollow vessel or dish, to hold water for washing, and for various other uses.
The quantity contained in a basin.
A hollow vessel, of various forms and materials, used in the arts or manufactures, as that used by glass grinders for forming concave glasses, by hatters for molding a hat into shape, etc.
A hollow place containing water, as a pond, a dock for ships, a little bay.

sd.def: A circular or oval valley, or depression of the surface of the ground, the lowest part of which is generally occupied by a lake, or traversed by a river.
The entire tract of country drained by a river, or sloping towards a sea or lake.

sn.def: An isolated or circumscribed formation, particularly where the strata dip inward, on all sides, toward a center; -- especially applied to the coal formations, called coal basins or coal fields.

entry.def: of or pertaining to a basin.
Inclosed in a basin.
entry.q: Basinedrivers.

entry.def: Same as Bascinet.

entry.ety: Basi- + occipital
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the bone in the base of the cranium, frequently forming a part of the occipital in the adult, but usually distinct in the young.

def2.def: The basioccipital bone.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`sis a base
entry.def: The middle of the anterior margin of the great foramen of the skull.

entry.ety: Basi- + poy`s podo`s, foot
entry.def: The basal joint of the legs of Crustacea.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ba`sis a base + ptery`gion a fin
entry.def: A bar of cartilage at the base of the embryonic fins of some fishes. It develops into the metapterygium.

entry.ety: Basi- + pterygoid
entry.def: Applied to a protuberance of the base of the sphenoid bone.

entries.entry:
Ba"sis bā"sĭs n.; pl.Bases bā"sēz. L. basis, Gr. ba`sis. See Base n.
The foundation of anything; that on which a thing rests.
The pedestal of a column, pillar, or statue. Obs If no basis bear my rising name.
The groundwork; the first or fundamental principle; that which supports. The basis of public credit is good faith.
The principal component part of a thing.

entry.ety: Basi- + solute, a
entry.def: Prolonged at the base, as certain leaves.

entry.ety: Basi- + sphenoid
entry.def: Of or pertaining to that part of the base of the cranium between the basioccipital and the presphenoid, which usually ossifies separately in the embryo or in the young, and becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult.
The basisphenoid bone.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Basked bȧskt; p. pr. & vb. n. Basking
entry.ety: OScand. baðask to bathe one's self, or perh. bakask to bake one's self, sk being reflexive. See Bath n. Bake v. t.
entry.def: To lie in warmth; to be exposed to genial heat.
entry.q: Basks in the glare, and stems the tepid wave.

entry.def: To warm by continued exposure to heat; to warm with genial heat.
entry.q: Basks at the fire his hairy strength.

entry.note: The earliest balloons designed to carry people often had small vessels of woven flexible vegetable materials to hold the passengers, which resembled large baskets{1}, from which the name was derived.

cs.cd: an ophiuran of the genus Astrophyton, having the arms much branched. See Astrophyton.
a hilt with a covering wrought like basketwork to protect the hand.
work consisting of plaited osiers or twigs.

a lepidopterous insect of the genus Thyridopteryx and allied genera, esp. Thyridopteryx ephemeræformis. The larva makes and carries about a bag or basket-like case of silk and twigs, which it afterwards hangs up to shelter the pupa and wingless adult females.

a small basket{1} mounted on the end of a pole, used in churches to collect donations from those attending a church service; -- the long pole allows the collector to hold the basket in front of those at the end of the pew, while the collector remains in the aisle.

a basket{4} used to hold waste matter, such as discarded paper, commonly shaped like a truncated cone, with the wide end open and at the top. Vessels of other shapes, such as oblong containers, are also called waste baskets.

entry.ety: Of unknown origin. The modern Celtic words seem to be from the English

sn.def: A vessel made of osiers or other twigs, cane, rushes, splints, or other flexible material, interwoven.
sn.q: Rudebaskets. . . woven of the flexile willow.

sn.def: The contents of a basket; as much as a basket contains; as, a basket of peaches.
The bell or vase of the Corinthian capital.
The two back seats facing one another on the outside of a stagecoach.
A container shaped like a basket{1}, even if made of solid material rather than woven; -- the top is often, but not always, open and without a lid.
a vessel suspended below a balloon, designed to carry people or measuring instruments for scientific research.

A goal{3} consisting of a short cylindrical net suspended from a circular rim, which itself is attached at about ten feet above floor level to a backboard, placed at the end of a basketball court. In professional basketball, two such baskets are used, one at each end of the court, and each team may score only by passing the ball though its own basket. In informal games, only one such basket is often used.

An instance of scoring points by throwing the basketball through the basket; as, he threw four baskets in the first quarter; -- the ball must pass through the basket from above in order to score points.

entry.def: To put into a basket.

sn.def: A ball game, usually played indoors in an area called the basketball court, in which two opposing teams of five players each contest with each other to toss a large inflated ball (the basketball) into opposite goals (baskets) resembling baskets, each typically a cylindrical mesh suspended from a circular rim which is held ten feet above the court. A goal scored by passing the basketball through the basket may count from one to three points, depending on the situation in which it was thrown.
The inflatable ball used in the game of basketball.

entries.entry: Bas"ket*ful n.; pl.Basketfuls. As much as a basket will contain.

entry.def: The art of making baskets; also, baskets, taken collectively.

entries.entry: Bask"ing shark`. Zoöl One of the largest species of sharks (Cetorhinus maximus), so called from its habit of basking in the sun; the liver shark, or bone shark. It inhabits the northern seas of Europe and America, and grows to a length of more than forty feet. It is a harmless species.

entry.def: Same as Bascinet.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ba`sis base + 'o`mma eye + fe`rein to bear
entry.def: A group of Pulmonifera having the eyes at the base of the tentacles, including the common pond snails.
A basin.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Pertaining to Biscay, its people, or their language.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: One of a race, of unknown origin, inhabiting a region on the Bay of Biscay in Spain and France.
The language spoken by the Basque people.
A part of a lady's dress, resembling a jacket with a short skirt; -- probably so called because this fashion of dress came from the Basques.

entry.ety: F. Basque Biscayan: cf. G. Baskisch
entry.def: Pertaining to the country, people, or language of Biscay; Basque

entry.ety: F. bas-relief; bas low + relief raised work, relever to raise: cf. It. bassorilievo
entry.def: Low relief; sculpture, the figures of which project less than half of their true proportions; -- called also bass-relief and basso-rilievo. See Alto-rilievo.

entries.entry:
Bass ☞ The common European bass is Labrax lupus. American species are: the striped bass (Roccus lineatus); white or silver bass of the lakes (Roccus chrysops); brass or yellow bass (Roccus interruptus). ☞ The name is also applied to many other fishes. See Calico bass, under Calico. bȧs n.; pl.Bass, and sometimes Basses bȧs"ĕz. A corruption of barse
Zoöl
An edible, spiny-finned fish, esp. of the genera Roccus Labrax, and related genera. There are many species.
The two American fresh-water species of black bass (genus Micropterus). See Black bass.
Species of Serranus, the sea bass and rock bass. See Sea bass.
The southern, red, or channel bass (Sciæna ocellata). See Redfish.

entry.ety: A corruption of bast

sn.def: The linden or lime tree, sometimes wrongly called whitewood; also, its bark, which is used for making mats. See Bast.
A hassock or thick mat.

entry.cs: Thorough bass. See Thorough bass.
entry.ety: F. basse, fr. bas low. See Base a.

sn.def: A bass, or deep, sound or tone.

sd.def: The lowest part in a musical composition.
One who sings, or the instrument which plays, bass.

entry.cs: Bass clef Mus the character placed at the beginning of the staff containing the bass part of a musical composition.See Illust. under Clef.]Bass voice a deep-sounding voice; a voice fitted for singing bass.
entry.def: Deep or grave in tone.
To sound in a deep tone.
See Bashaw.
a division of mammals, in some classifications considered a separate family.
a genus comprising the cacomistles. See bassarisk.
A raccoonlike omnivorous mammal (Bassariscus astutus) of Mexico and southwestern U. S. having a long bushy tail with black and white rings.
entry.syn: cacomistle, cacomixle, coon cat, raccoon fox, ringtail, ring-tailed cat, civet cat, miner's cat.

entries.entry: Bass` drum". Mus The largest of the different kinds of drums, having two heads, and emitting a deep, grave sound. See Bass a.

entry.ety: F. bassette, fr. It. bassetta. Cf. Basso
entry.def: A game at cards, resembling the modern faro, said to have been invented at Venice.
entry.q: Some dress, some dance, some play, not to forget Your piquet parties, and your dear basset.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. basset somewhat low, dim. of bas low
entry.def: Inclined upward; as, the basset edge of strata.
The edge of a geological stratum at the surface of the ground; the outcrop.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Basseted; p. pr. & vb. n. Basseting
entry.def: To incline upward so as to appear at the surface; to crop out; as, a vein of coal bassets .

entries.entry:
Bas"set horn` băs"sĕt hôrn`. See Basset a.
Mus An instrument blown with a reed, and resembling a clarinet, but of much greater compass, embracing nearly four octaves; The corno di bassetto.

Bas"set hound`. F. basset
Zoöl A small kind of hound with a long body and short legs, used as an earth dog.

entry.def: The upward direction of a vein in a mine; the emergence of a stratum at the surface.

entry.ety: It., adj., somewhat low; n., counter tenor. See Basso
entry.def: A tenor or small bass viol.

entries.entry: Bass" horn". Mus A modification of the bassoon, much deeper in tone.

sn.def: Coarse leaf fiber from palmyra palms used in making brushes and brooms.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bassinet, dim. of bassin. See Basin, and cf. Bascinet

sn.def: A wicker basket, with a covering or hood over one end, in which young children are placed as in a cradle.
See Bascinet.

entry.cs: ‖Basso continuo. It., bass continued Mus A bass part written out continuously, while the other parts of the harmony are indicated by figures attached to the bass; continued bass.
entry.ety: It., fr. LL. bassus. See Base a.
entry.def: The bass or lowest part; as, to sing basso .
One who sings the lowest part.
The double bass, or contrabasso.
A hassock. See 2d Bass, 2.

entry.note: ☞ Its compass comprehends three octaves. For convenience of carriage it is divided into two parts; whence it is also called a fagot.
entry.ety: F. basson, fr. basse bass; or perh. fr. bas son low sound. See Bass a part in music.
entry.def: A wind instrument of the double reed kind, furnished with holes, which are stopped by the fingers, and by keys, as in flutes. It forms the natural bass to the oboe, clarinet, etc.
A performer on the bassoon.

entry.ety: It. basso-rilievo
entry.def: Same as Bas-relief.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bassorine
entry.def: A constituent part of a species of gum from Bassora, as also of gum tragacanth and some gum resins. It is one of the amyloses.
Same as Bas-relief.

entries.entry: Bass" vi`ol. Mus A stringed instrument of the viol family, used for playing bass. See 3d Bass n., and Violoncello.

entry.def: The bass (Tilia) or its wood; especially, Tilia Americana. See Bass, the lime tree.
entry.q: All the bowls were made of basswood, White and polished very smoothly.

entry.ety: AS. bæst; akin to Icel., Sw., Dan., D., & G. bast, of unknown origin. Cf. Bass the tree

sn.def: The inner fibrous bark of various plants; esp. of the lime tree; hence, matting, cordage, etc., made therefrom.
A thick mat or hassock. See 2d Bass, 2.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Enough; stop.

entry.note: ☞ By the civil and canon laws, and by the laws of many of the United States, a bastard becomes a legitimate child by the intermarriage of the parents at any subsequent time. But by those of England, and of some states of the United States, a child, to be legitimate, must at least be born after the lawful marriage.
entry.ety: OF. bastard bastart, F. b�tard, prob. fr. OF. bast, F. b�t, a packsaddle used as a bed by the muleteers (fr. LL. bastum) + -ard. OF. fils de bast son of the packsaddle; as the muleteers were accustomed to use their saddles for beds in the inns. See Cervantes, “Don Quixote,” chap. 16; and cf. G. bankert, fr. bank bench

sn.def: A “natural” child; a child begotten and born out of wedlock; an illegitimate child; one born of an illicit union.

sd.def: An inferior quality of soft brown sugar, obtained from the sirups that have already had several boilings.
A large size of mold, in which sugar is drained.

sn.def: A sweet Spanish wine like muscatel in flavor.
sn.q: Brown bastard is your only drink.

sn.def: A writing paper of a particular size. See Paper.

cs.cd: stones for ashlar work, roughly squared at the quarry.
a file intermediate between the coarsest and the second cut.
type having the face of a larger or a smaller size than the body; e. g., a nonpareil face on a brevier body.
three to five quill feathers on a small joint corresponding to the thumb in some mammalia; the alula.

sn.def: Begotten and born out of lawful matrimony; illegitimate. See Bastard n., note.
Lacking in genuineness; spurious; false; adulterate; -- applied to things which resemble those which are genuine, but are really not so.
sn.q: That bastard self-love which is so vicious in itself, and productive of so many vices.

sn.def: Of an unusual or irregular make or proportion; as, a bastard musket; a bastard culverin.
Abbreviated, as the half title in a page preceding the full title page of a book.

entry.def: To bastardize.
An act that debases or corrupts.
Same as bastardize.
The state of being a bastard; bastardy.
An act that debases or corrupts.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bastardized�); p. pr. & vb. n. Bastardizing

sn.def: To make or prove to be a bastard; to stigmatize as a bastard; to declare or decide legally to be illegitimate.
sn.q: The law is so indulgent as not to bastardize the child, if born, though not begotten, in lawful wedlock.

sn.def: To beget out of wedlock.
to change something (for example, art forms) so that its value declines; to debase.

entry.def: deriving from more than one source or style.
Bastardlike; baseborn; spurious; corrupt.

def2.def: In the manner of a bastard; spuriously.

sn.def: The state of being a bastard; illegitimacy.
The procreation of a bastard child.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Basted; p. pr. & vb. n. Basting
entry.ety: Cf. Icel. beysta to strike, powder; Sw. basa to beat with a rod: perh. akin to E. beat

sn.def: To beat with a stick; to cudgel.
sn.q: One man was basted by the keeper for carrying some people over on his back through the waters.

sn.def: To sprinkle flour and salt and drip butter or fat on, as on meat in roasting.
To mark with tar, as sheep.

entry.ety: OE. basten, OF. bastir, F. b�tir, prob. fr. OHG. bestan to sew, MHG. besten to bind, fr. OHG. bast bast. See Bast
entry.def: To sew loosely, or with long stitches; -- usually, that the work may be held in position until sewed more firmly.

entry.ety: F. bastille fortress, OF. bastir to build, F. bâtir

sn.def: A tower or an elevated work, used for the defense, or in the siege, of a fortified place.
sn.q: The high bastiles . . . which overtopped the walls.

sn.def: “The Bastille”, formerly a castle or fortress in Paris, used as a prison, especially for political offenders; hence, a rhetorical name for a prison.

entry.def: See Bastinado n.
To bastinado.

entries.entry:
Bas`ti*na"do n.; pl.Bastinadoes. Sp. bastonadacf. F. bastonnade), fr. bastoncf. F. bâton) a stick or staff. See Baston
A blow with a stick or cudgel.
A sound beating with a stick or cudgel. Specifically: A form of punishment among the Turks, Chinese, and others, consisting in beating an offender on the soles of his feet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bastinadoed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bastinadoing
entry.def: To beat with a stick or cudgel, especially on the soles of the feet.

sn.def: Loose temporary stitches.
The act or process of moistening a roast as it is cooking.

entry.ety: F. bastioncf. It. bastione), fr. LL. bastire to build (cf. F. bâtir, It. bastire), perh. from the idea of support for a weight, and akin to Gr. basta`zein to lift, carry, and to E. baston baton
entry.def: A work projecting outward from the main inclosure of a fortification, consisting of two faces and two flanks, and so constructed that it is able to defend by a flanking fire the adjacent curtain, or wall which extends from one bastion to another. Two adjacent bastions are connected by the curtain, which joins the flank of one with the adjacent flank of the other. The distance between the flanks of a bastion is called the gorge. A lunette is a detached bastion. See Ravelin.
Furnished with a bastion; having bastions.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: The ace of clubs in quadrille and omber.

entry.ety: OF. baston, F. bâton, LL. basto. See Bastion, and cf. Baton, and 3d Batten

sn.def: A staff or cudgel.
sn.q: To fight with bluntbastons.

sn.def: See Baton.
An officer bearing a painted staff, who formerly was in attendance upon the king's court to take into custody persons committed by the court.

entries.entry: Ba*su"tos n. pl.; sing.Basuto. Ethnol A warlike South African people of the Bantu stock, divided into many tribes, at one time subjected by the English. They formerly practiced cannibalism, but have now adopted many European customs.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`sis base + "y`lh wood. See -yl
entry.def: A positive or nonacid constituent of compound, either elementary, or, if compound, performing the functions of an element.
Pertaining to, or having the nature of, a basyle; electro-positive; basic; -- opposed to chlorous.

cs.cd: a bolt barbed or jagged at its butt or tang to make it hold the more firmly.

entry.ety: OE. batte botte, AS. batt; perhaps fr. the Celtic; cf. Ir. bat bata, stick, staff; but cf. also F. batte a beater (thing), wooden sword, battre to beat

sn.def: A large stick; a club; specifically, a piece of wood with one end thicker or broader than the other, used in playing baseball, cricket, etc.
In badminton, tennis, and similar games, a racket.
A sheet of cotton used for filling quilts or comfortables; batting.
A part of a brick with one whole end; a brickbat.
Shale or bituminous shale.
A stroke; a sharp blow.
A stroke of work.
Rate of motion; speed.
sn.q: A vast host of fowl . . . making at fullbatfor the North Sea.

sn.def: A spree; a jollification.
Manner; rate; condition; state of health.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Batted băt"tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Batting
entry.def: To strike or hit with a bat or a pole; to cudgel; to beat.

To use a bat, as in a game of baseball; when used with a numerical postmodifier it indicates a baseball player's performance (as a decimal) at bat; as, he batted .270 in 1993 (i.e. he got safe hits in 27 percent of his official turns at bat.

sn.def: To bate or flutter, as a hawk.
To wink.

cs.cd: a wingless, dipterous insect of the genus Nycteribia, parasitic on bats.

entry.ety: Corrupt. from OE. back backe balke; cf. Dan. aften-bakke aften evening), Sw. natt-backa natt night), Icel. leðr-blaka leðr leather), Icel. blaka to flutter
entry.def: One of the Chiroptera, an order of flying mammals, in which the wings are formed by a membrane stretched between the elongated fingers, legs, and tail. The common bats are small and insectivorous. See Chiroptera and Vampire.
entry.q: Silent bats in drowsy clusters cling.

entry.ety: Siamese
entry.def: Same as Tical n., 1.

entry.note: ☞ The border land between England and Scotland, being formerly a subject of contention, was called batable or debatable ground.
entry.ety: Abbrev. from debatable
entry.def: Disputable.
Embattled.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: A cofferdam.
A wall built across the ditch of a fortification, with a sluice gate to regulate the height of water in the ditch on both sides of the wall.

entry.def: An aboriginal American name for the sweet potato (Ipomæa batatas).

cs.cd: the name given to Holland by the French after its conquest in 1795.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the Batavi, an ancient Germanic tribe.
Of or pertaining to Batavia or Holland; as, a Batavian legion.

entry.def: A native or inhabitant of Batavia or Holland.
A boy who holds the bats and presents the bat to a batter when the batter is going to the batter's box to bat. The batboy sometimes also keeps other team equipment.

entry.ety: OE. bache bacche, fr. AS. bacan to bake; cf. G. gebäck and D. baksel. See Bake v. t.

sn.def: The quantity of bread baked at one time.
A quantity of anything produced at one operation; a group or collection of persons or things of the same kind; as, a batch of letters; the next batch of business.
sn.q: A newbatchof Lords.

entry.ety: Prob. abbrev. from debate
entry.def: Strife; contention.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bated; p. pr. & vb. n. Bating
entry.ety: From abate

sn.def: To lessen by retrenching, deducting, or reducing; to abate; to beat down; to lower.
sn.q: He must either bate the laborer's wages, or not employ or not pay him.

sn.def: To allow by way of abatement or deduction.
sn.q: To whom he bates nothing of what he stood upon with the parliament.

sn.def: To leave out; to except.
sn.q: Bate me the king, and, be he flesh and blood, He lies that says it.

sn.def: To remove.
sn.q: About autumn bate the earth from about the roots of olives, and lay them bare.

sn.def: To deprive of.
sn.q: When baseness is exalted, do not bate The place its honor for the person's sake.

sn.def: To remit or retrench a part; -- with of.
sn.q: Abate thy speed, and I will bate of mine.

sn.def: To waste away.

entry.def: To attack; to bait.
imp. of Bite.

entry.ety: F. battre des ailes to flutter. Cf. Bait to flutter
entry.def: To flutter as a hawk; to bait.
See 2d Bath.

entry.ety: Cf. Sw. beta maceration, soaking, G. beize, and E. bite
entry.def: An alkaline solution consisting of the dung of certain animals; -- employed in the preparation of hides; grainer.
To steep in bate, as hides, in the manufacture of leather.

entries.entry:
Ba*teau" Ba*teau"
Bateau bridge a floating bridge supported by bateaux.
n.; pl.Bateaux. F. bateau, LL. batellus, fr. battus batus, boat, which agrees with AS. bāt boat: cf. W. bad boat. See Boat n.
A boat; esp. a flat-bottomed, clumsy boat used on the Canadian lakes and rivers.
batteau

entry.def: Reduced; lowered; restrained; as, to speak with bated breath.
Exciting contention; contentious.
entry.q: It didbatefulquestion frame.

entry.def: Not to be abated.

cs.cd: a window or one division of a window having vertical sides, but with the sill not horizontal, as where it follows the rake of a staircase.

entry.ety: For Abatement. See 2d Bate
entry.def: Abatement; diminution.
A name given to several species of fishes:
The Malthe vespertilio of the Atlantic coast.
The flying gurnard of the Atlantic (Cephalacanthus spinarella).
The California batfish or sting ray (Myliobatis Californicus
One who practices or finds sport in batfowling.

entry.ety: From Bat a stick
entry.def: A mode of catching birds at night, by holding a torch or other light, and beating the bush or perch where they roost. The birds, flying to the light, are caught with nets or otherwise.

entry.ety: Icel. bati amelioration, batna to grow better; akin to AS. bet better. Goth. ga-batnan to profit. √255. Cf. Batten v. i. Better
entry.def: Rich; fertile.
entry.q: Batfulvalleys.

entries.entry:
Bath ☞ Bath is used adjectively or in combination, in an obvious sense of or for baths or bathing; as, bathroom, bath tub, bath keeper.
Douche bath. See Douche. Order of the Bath a high order of British knighthood, composed of three classes, viz., knights grand cross, knights commanders, and knights companions, abbreviated thus: G. C. B., K. C. B., K. B. Russian bath a kind of vapor bath which consists in a prolonged exposure of the body to the influence of the steam of water, followed by washings and shampooings. Turkish bath a kind of bath in which a profuse perspiration is produced by hot air, after which the body is washed and shampooed. Bath house a house used for the purpose of bathing; -- also a small house, near a bathing place, where a bather undresses and dresses.
bȧth; 61 n.; pl.Baths bȧ�z. AS. bæð; akin to OS. & Icel. bað, Sw., Dan., D., & G. bad, and perh. to G. bähen to foment
The act of exposing the body, or part of the body, for purposes of cleanliness, comfort, health, etc., to water, vapor, hot air, or the like; as, a cold or a hot bath; a medicated bath; a steam bath; a hip bath .
Water or other liquid for bathing.
A receptacle or place where persons may immerse or wash their bodies in water.
A building containing an apartment or a series of apartments arranged for bathing. Among the ancients, the public baths were of amazing extent and magnificence.
Chem A medium, as heated sand, ashes, steam, hot air, through which heat is applied to a body.
Photog A solution in which plates or prints are immersed; also, the receptacle holding the solution.

entry.ety: Heb
entry.def: A Hebrew measure containing the tenth of a homer, or five gallons and three pints, as a measure for liquids; and two pecks and five quarts, as a dry measure.

entry.cs: Bath brick a preparation of calcareous earth, in the form of a brick, used for cleaning knives, polished metal, etc. Bath chair a kind of chair on wheels, as used by invalids at Bath. “People walked out, or drove out, or were pushed out in their Bath chairs.” Dickens. Bath metal an alloy consisting of four and a half ounces of zinc and one pound of copper. Bath note a folded writing paper, 8 1/2 by 14 inches. Bath stone a species of limestone (oölite) found near Bath, used for building.
entry.def: A city in the west of England, resorted to for its hot springs, which has given its name to various objects.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bathed bā�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Bathing
entry.ety: OE. baðien, AS. baðian, fr. bæð bath. See 1st Bath, and cf. Bay to bathe

sn.def: To wash by immersion, as in a bath; to subject to a bath.
sn.q: Chancing to bathe himself in the River Cydnus.

sn.def: To lave; to wet.
sn.q: The lake whichbathedthe foot of the Alban mountain.

sn.def: To moisten or suffuse with a liquid.
sn.q: And let us bathe our hands in Cæsar's blood.

sn.def: To apply water or some liquid medicament to; as, to bathe the eye with warm water or with sea water; to bathe one's forehead with camphor.
To surround, or envelop, as water surrounds a person immersed.
sn.q: The rosy shadowsbatheme.
The bright sunshinebathingall the world.

sn.def: To bathe one's self; to take a bath or baths.
sn.q: Theybathein summer.

sn.def: To immerse or cover one's self, as in a bath.
sn.q: Tobathein fiery floods.
Bathein the dimples of her cheek.

sn.def: To bask in the sun.

entry.def: The immersion of the body in water; as, to take one's usual bathe .
One who bathes.
Having the character of bathos.

sn.def: a building containing dressing rooms for bathers.
a building containing public baths.

cs.cd: a small room on wheels, to be driven into the water, for the convenience of bathers, who undress and dress therein.

entry.def: Act of taking a bath or baths.
See Vital force.
A large mass of intrusive igneous rock believed to have solidified deep within the earth.

entry.ety: Gr. baqo`s depth + -lith
entry.def: A large mass of intrusive igneous rock believed to have solidified deep within the earth.
Of or pertaining to a batholith.

entry.ety: Gr. baqo`s depth + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring depths, esp. one for taking soundings without a sounding line.

entry.ety: F. bât packsaddle (cheval de bât packhorse) + E. horse. See Bastard
entry.def: A horse which carries an officer's baggage during a campaign.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`qos depth, fr. baqy`s deep
entry.def: A ludicrous descent from the elevated to the low, in writing or speech; anticlimax.
a large towel used to dry oneself after a bath.

A relatively large tub used to take a bath, usually a permanent fixture in a bathroom; it is an open container that is filled with water, in which a person immerses himself for the purpose of washing the body.
of or pertaining to bathymetry.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. baqy`s deep + bi`os life
entry.def: A name given by Prof. Huxley to a gelatinous substance found in mud dredged from the Atlantic and preserved in alcohol. He supposed that it was free living protoplasm, covering a large part of the ocean bed. It is now known that the substance is of chemical, not of organic, origin.
a natural family inclusing the mole rats and sand rats.
a genus consisting of the mole rats.

entry.ety: Gr. baqy`s deep + graphic
entry.def: Descriptive of the ocean depth; as, a bathygraphic chart.
Pertaining to bathymetry; relating to the measurement of depths, especially of depths in the sea.

entry.ety: Gr. ba`qos depth + -metry
entry.def: The art or science of sounding, or measuring depths in the sea.
navigable deep diving vessel for underwater exploration.
a spherical deep diving apparatus (lowered by a cable) for underwater exploration; it is constructed with a strong steel shell to withstand high pressures at the ocean bottom.
a natural family coextensive with genus Batis; the saltworts.

sn.def: A dyed fabric with designs drawn on by applying a removable wax where the dye is not wanted.
The method used to create a batik{1}; using wax to allow drawing or printing of designs on a fabric.

entry.ety: Strictly p. pr. of Bate to abate
entry.def: With the exception of; excepting.
entry.q: We have little reason to think that they bring many ideas with them, bating some faint ideas of hunger and thirst.

entry.def: A small genus of plants constituting the family Batidaceae: low straggling dioecious shrubs.

entry.ety: F. batiste, from the name of the alleged first maker, Baptiste of Cambrai. Littré.
entry.def: Originally, cambric or lawn of fine linen; now applied also to cloth of similar texture made of cotton.

entry.ety: Bat stick + -let
entry.def: A short bat for beating clothes in washing them; -- called also batler batling staff batting staff.

entry.ety: Turk. baṭman
entry.def: A weight used in the East, varying according to the locality; in Turkey, the greater batman is about 157 pounds, the lesser only a fourth of this; at Aleppo and Smyrna, the batman is 17 pounds.

entries.entry:
