sn.q: The second was to Triamond behight.

sn.def: To mean, or intend.
sn.q: More than heart behighteth.

sn.def: To consider or esteem to be; to declare to be.
sn.q: All the lookers-on him dead behight.

sn.def: To call; to name; to address.
sn.q: Whom . . . he knew and thus behight.

sn.def: To command; to order.
sn.q: He behight those gates to be unbarred.

entry.def: A vow; a promise.

entry.ety: AS. behindan; pref. be- + hindan. See Hind a.

sn.def: On the side opposite the front or nearest part; on the back side of; at the back of; on the other side of; as, behind a door; behind a hill.
sn.q: A tall Brabanter, behind whom I stood.

sn.def: Left after the departure of, whether this be by removing to a distance or by death.
sn.q: A small part of what he left behind him.

sn.def: Left a distance by, in progress of improvement Hence: Inferior to in dignity, rank, knowledge, or excellence, or in any achievement.
sn.q: I was not a whit behind the very chiefest apostles.

sn.def: At the back part; in the rear.
sn.q: I shall not lagbehind.

sn.def: Toward the back part or rear; backward; as, to look behind .
Not yet brought forward, produced, or exhibited to view; out of sight; remaining.
sn.q: We can not be sure that there is no evidence behind.

sn.def: Backward in time or order of succession; past.
sn.q: Forgetting those things which are behind.

sn.def: After the departure of another; as, to stay behind .
sn.q: Leave not a rack behind.

entry.def: The backside; the rump.

entry.ety: Behind + hand

sn.def: In arrears financially; in a state where expenditures have exceeded the receipt of funds.

In a state of backwardness, in respect to what is seasonable or appropriate, or as to what should have been accomplished; not equally forward with some other person or thing; dilatory; backward; late; tardy; as, behindhand in studies or in work.
sn.q: In this also [dress] the country are very much behindhand.

entry.def: On this side of.
entry.q: Two miles behither Clifden.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Beheld p. p. formerly Beholden, now used only as a p. a.); p. pr. & vb. n. Beholding
entry.ety: OE. bihalden biholden, AS. behealdan to hold, have in sight; pref. be- + healdan to hold, keep; akin to G. behalten to hold, keep. See Hold
entry.def: To have in sight; to see clearly; to look at; to regard with the eyes.
entry.q: When he beheld the serpent of brass, he lived.
Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world.
entry.syn: To scan; gaze; regard; descry; view; discern.

entry.def: To direct the eyes to, or fix them upon, an object; to look; to see.
entry.q: And I beheld, and, lo, in the midst of the throne, . . . a lamb as it had been slain.

entry.ety: Old p. p. of behold, used in the primitive sense of the simple verb hold
entry.def: Obliged; bound in gratitude; indebted.
entry.q: But being so beholden to the Prince.

entry.def: One who beholds; a spectator.
Obliged; beholden.
entry.q: I was much bound and beholding to the right reverend father.
So much hath Oxford been beholding to her nephews, or sister's children.

entry.def: The act of seeing; sight; also, that which is beheld.
The state of being obliged or beholden.

entry.ety: OE. to bihove for the use of, AS. beh�f advantage, a word implied in beh�flīc necessary; akin to Sw. behof, Dan. behov, G. behuf, and E. heave, the root meaning to seize, hence the meanings “to hold, make use of.” See Heave v. t.
entry.def: Advantage; profit; benefit; interest; use.
entry.q: No mean recompense it brings To your behoof.

entry.def: Supplying need; profitable; advantageous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Behooved; p. pr. & vb. n. Behooving
entry.ety: OE. bihoven behoven, AS. beh�fian to have need of, fr. beh�f. See Behoof
entry.def: To be necessary for; to be fit for; to be meet for, with respect to necessity, duty, or convenience; -- mostly used impersonally.
entry.q: And thus it behooved Christ to suffer.

entry.def: To be necessary, fit, or suitable; to befit; to belong as due.
Advantage; behoof.
entry.q: It shall not be to his behoove.

entry.def: Advantageous; useful; profitable.
and derivatives. See Behoove, &c.
Useful, or usefully.
To howl at.
entry.q: The wolf behowls the moon.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Debeige.

entry.ety: Prob. from the same root as build, v. t
entry.def: A place of shelter; protection; refuge.
entry.q: The random beild o' clod or stane.

entries.entry:
Be"ing ☞ Being was formerly used where we now use having. “Being to go to a ball in a few days.” Miss Edgeworth.
☞ In modern usage, is are was or were being, with a past participle following (as built made, etc.) indicates the process toward the completed result expressed by the participle. The form is or was building, in this passive signification, is idiomatic, and, if free from ambiguity, is commonly preferable to the modern is or was being built. The last form of speech is, however, sufficiently authorized by approved writers. The older expression was is, or was a-building or in building. p. pr. from Be. Existing. A man who is being strangled. While the article on Burns was being written. Fresh experience is always being gained.

sn.def: Existence, as opposed to nonexistence; state or sphere of existence.
sn.q: In Him we live, and move, and have our being.

sn.def: That which exists in any form, whether it be material or spiritual, actual or ideal; living existence, as distinguished from a thing without life; as, a human being; spiritual beings .
sn.q: What a sweet being is an honest mind !
A Being of infinite benevolence and power.

sn.def: Lifetime; mortal existence.
sn.q: Claudius, thou Wast follower of his fortunes in his being.

sn.def: An abode; a cottage.
sn.q: It was a relief to dismiss them [Sir Roger's servants] into little beings within my manor.

entry.def: Since; inasmuch as.
entry.q: And being you have Declined his means, you have increased his malice.

entry.def: To jade or tire.
To jape; to laugh at; to deceive.
To infect with jaundice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bejeweled or Bejewelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Bejeweling or Bejewelling
entry.def: To ornament with a jewel or with jewels; to spangle.
entry.q: Bejeweledhands.

entry.ety: Sp., a reed or woody vine
entry.def: Any climbing woody vine of the tropics with the habit of a liane; in the Philippines, esp. any of various species of Calamus, the cane or rattan palm.
To jumble together.

entry.ety: Heb
entry.def: Half a shekel.
To call knave.
To confess; to acknowledge.
The Babylonian name of the god known among the Hebrews as Baal. See Baal.

entry.ety: Hind., fr. Skr. bilva
entry.def: A thorny rutaceous tree (Ægle marmelos) of India, and its aromatic, orange-like fruit; -- called also Bengal quince golden apple wood apple. The fruit is used medicinally, and the rind yields a perfume and a yellow dye.

entry.ety: from Alexander Graham Bell
entry.def: a unit of sound intensity equal to ten decibels.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belabored; p. pr. & vb. n. Belaboring

sn.def: To ply diligently; to work carefully upon.
sn.q: If the earth isbelaboredwith culture, it yieldeth corn.

sn.def: To beat soundly; to cudgel.
sn.q: Ajax belabors there a harmless ox.

entry.ety: F. bel beautiful + accueil reception
entry.def: A kind or favorable reception or salutation.

sn.def: To fasten, as with a lace or cord.
To cover or adorn with lace.
To beat with a strap. See Lace.

entry.ety: See Lam
entry.def: To beat or bang.

entry.ety: F. bel amour fair love

sn.def: A lover.
A flower, but of what kind is unknown.
sn.q: Her snowy brows, like budded belamours.

entry.ety: F. bel ami fair friend
entry.def: Good friend; dear friend.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belated; p. pr. & vb. n. Belating
entry.def: To retard or make too late.
Delayed beyond the usual time; too late; overtaken by night; benighted.
entry.q: Somebelatedpeasant.

entry.def: To laud or praise greatly.

cs.cd: Stop.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belaid Belayed; p. pr. & vb. n. Belaying
entry.ety: For senses 1 & 2, D. beleggen to cover, belay; akin to E. pref. be-, and lay to place: for sense 3, OE. beleggen, AS. belecgan. See pref. Be-, and Lay to place

sn.def: To lay on or cover; to adorn.
sn.q: Jacket . . . belayed with silver lace.

sn.def: To make fast, as a rope, by taking several turns with it round a pin, cleat, or kevel.
To lie in wait for with a view to assault. Hence: to block up or obstruct.

entries.entry: Be*lay"ing pin` b�*lā"ĭng pĭn`. Naut A strong pin in the side of a vessel, or by the mast, round which ropes are wound when they are fastened or belayed.

entry.ety: It., beautiful singing
entry.def: a cantabile style of operatic singing characterized by purity and evenness of tone, and a precise but brilliant vocal technique displaying ease and agility.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belched bĕlch; p. pr. & vb. n. Belching
entry.ety: OE. belken, AS. bealcan, akin to E. bellow. See Bellow v. i.

sn.def: To eject or throw up from the stomach with violence; to eruct.
sn.q: I belched a hurricane of wind.

sn.def: To eject violently from within; to cast forth; to emit; to give vent to; to vent.
sn.q: Within the gates that now Stood open wide, belching outrageous flame.

sn.def: To eject wind from the stomach through the mouth; to eructate.
To issue with spasmodic force or noise.
The act of belching; also, that which is belched; an eructation.
Malt liquor; -- vulgarly so called as causing eructation.

entry.def: One who, or that which, belches.

entry.ety: Pref. bel-, denoting relationship + dame mother: cf. F. belledame fair lady, It. belladonna. See Belle, and Dame

sn.def: Grandmother; -- corresponding to belsire.
sn.q: To show the beldam daughters of her daughter.

sn.def: An old woman in general; especially, an ugly old woman; a hag.
sn.q: Around the beldam all erect they hang.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Beleaguered; p. pr. & vb. n. Beleaguering
entry.ety: D. belegerenakin to G. belagern, Sw. belägra, Dan. beleire); pref. be- = E. be- + leger bed, camp, army, akin to E. lair. See Lair
entry.def: To surround with an army so as to preclude escape; to besiege; to blockade.
entry.q: The wail of famine in beleaguered towns.
entry.syn: To block up; environ; invest; encompass.

entry.def: One who beleaguers.
To leave or to be left.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belectured; p. pr. & vb. n. Belecturing
entry.def: To vex with lectures; to lecture frequently.
To place under the lee, or unfavorably to the wind.

entry.ety: Gr. � dart, fr. � dart, fr. � to throw: cf. F. bélemnite
entry.def: A conical calcareous fossil, tapering to a point at the lower extremity, with a conical cavity at the other end, where it is ordinarily broken; but when perfect it contains a small chambered cone, called the phragmocone, prolonged, on one side, into a delicate concave blade; the thunderstone. It is the internal shell of a cephalopod related to the sepia, and belonging to an extinct family. The belemnites are found in rocks of the Jurassic and Cretaceous ages.
an order of extinct dibranchiate cephalopods related to the surviving spirulas.
To infect with leprosy.

entries.entry: Bel"-es*prit" Bel"-es*prit" n.; pl.Beaux-esprits. F., fine wit A fine genius, or man of wit. A man of letters and abel esprit.

entry.def: the capital of Northern Ireland; -- the center of Irish Protestantism.

entry.ety: OE. berfray movable tower used in sieges, OF. berfreit berfroit, F. beffroi, fr. MHG. bervrit bercvrit, G. bergfriede, fr. MHG. bergen to protect (G. bergen to conceal) + vride peace, protection, G. friede peace; in compounds often taken in the sense of security, or place of security; orig. therefore a place affording security. G. friede is akin to E. free. See Burg, and Free

sn.def: A movable tower erected by besiegers for purposes of attack and defense.
A bell tower, usually attached to a church or other building, but sometimes separate; a campanile.
A room in a tower in which a bell is or may be hung; or a cupola or turret for the same purpose.
The framing on which a bell is suspended.

entry.ety: It. bel guardo
entry.def: A sweet or loving look.
Of or pertaining to Belgium.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Belgium.

entries.entry: Belgian block. A nearly cubical block of some tough stone, esp. granite, used as a material for street pavements. Its usual diameter is 5 to 7 inches.

entry.ety: L. Belgicus, fr. Belgae the Belgians

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the Belgæ, a German tribe who anciently possessed the country between the Rhine, the Seine, and the ocean.
sn.q: How unlike their Belgic sires of old.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the Netherlands or to Belgium.

entry.def: Belonging to Belgravia (a fashionable quarter of London, around Pimlico), or to fashionable life; aristocratic.

cs.cd: a worthless, wicked, or thoroughly depraved person.

entry.ety: Heb. beli ya'al; beli without + ya'al profit
entry.def: An evil spirit; a wicked and unprincipled person; the personification of evil.
entry.q: What concord hath Christ with Belia ?

entry.ety: See Libel v. t.
entry.def: To libel or traduce; to calumniate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belied; p. pr. & vb. n. Belying
entry.ety: OE. bilien bili�en, AS. beleógan; pref. be- + leógan to lie. See Lie n.

sn.def: To show to be false; to convict of, or charge with, falsehood.
sn.q: Their trembling hearts belie their boastful tongues.

sn.def: To give a false representation or account of.
sn.q: Should I do so, I should belie my thoughts.

sn.def: To tell lie about; to calumniate; to slander.
sn.q: Thou dost belie him, Percy, thou dost belie him.

sn.def: To mimic; to counterfeit.
To fill with lies.
sn.q: The breath of slander dothbelieall corners of the world.

cs.cd: a first principle incapable of proof; an intuitive truth; an intuition.

entry.ety: OE. bileafe bileve; cf. AS. geleáfa. See Believe

sn.def: Assent to a proposition or affirmation, or the acceptance of a fact, opinion, or assertion as real or true, without immediate personal knowledge; reliance upon word or testimony; partial or full assurance without positive knowledge or absolute certainty; persuasion; conviction; confidence; as, belief of a witness; the belief of our senses.
sn.q: Belief admits of all degrees, from the slightest suspicion to the fullest assurance.

sn.def: A persuasion of the truths of religion; faith.
sn.q: No man can attain [tobelief by the bare contemplation of heaven and earth.

sn.def: The thing believed; the object of belief.
sn.q: Superstitious prophecies are not only the belief of fools, but the talk sometimes of wise men.

sn.def: A tenet, or the body of tenets, held by the advocates of any class of views; doctrine; creed.
sn.q: In the heat of persecution to which Christian belief was subject upon its first promulgation.

entry.def: Having belief or faith.
Capable of being believed; credible.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Believed; p. pr. & vb. n. Believing
entry.ety: OE. bilevenwith pref. be- for AS. ge-), fr. AS. gel�fan gel�fan; akin to D. gelooven, OHG. gilouban, G. glauben, OS. gil�bian, Goth. galaubjan, and Goth. liubs dear. See Lief a. Leave n.
entry.def: To exercise belief in; to credit upon the authority or testimony of another; to be persuaded of the truth of, upon evidence furnished by reasons, arguments, and deductions of the mind, or by circumstances other than personal knowledge; to regard or accept as true; to place confidence in; to think; to consider; as, to believe a person, a statement, or a doctrine.
entry.q: Our conqueror (whom I now Of force believe almighty).
King Agrippa, believest thou the prophets ?
Often followed by a dependent clause. I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.

entry.cs: To believe in. To believe that the subject of the thought (if a person or thing) exists, or (if an event) that it has occurred, or will occur; -- as, to believe in the resurrection of the dead. “She does not believe in Jupiter.” J. H. Newman. To believe that the character, abilities, and purposes of a person are worthy of entire confidence; -- especially that his promises are wholly trustworthy. “Let not your heart be troubled: ye believe in God, believe also in me.” John xiv. 1. To believe that the qualities or effects of an action or state are beneficial: as, to believe in sea bathing, or in abstinence from alcoholic beverages. To believe on to accept implicitly as an object of religious trust or obedience; to have faith in.

sn.def: To have a firm persuasion, esp. of the truths of religion; to have a persuasion approaching to certainty; to exercise belief or faith.
sn.q: Lord, I believe; help thou mine unbelief.
With the heart man believeth unto righteousness.

sn.def: To think; to suppose.
sn.q: I will not believe so meanly of you.

sn.def: One who believes; one who is persuaded of the truth or reality of some doctrine, person, or thing.

One who gives credit to the truth of the Scriptures, as a revelation from God; a Christian; -- in a more restricted sense, one who receives Christ as his Savior, and accepts the way of salvation unfolded in the gospel.
sn.q: Thou didst open the Kingdom of Heaven to all believers.

sn.def: One who was admitted to all the rights of divine worship and instructed in all the mysteries of the Christian religion, in distinction from a catechumen, or one yet under instruction.

entry.def: That believes; having belief.
To illuminate.

entry.ety: Pref. be-for by) + like
entry.def: It is likely or probably; perhaps.
entry.q: Belike, boy, then you are in love.

entry.def: To besmear or insnare with birdlime.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belittled; p. pr. & vb. n. Belittling
entry.def: To make little or less in a moral sense; to speak of in a depreciatory or contemptuous way.

entry.ety: Cf. Live a.
entry.def: Forthwith; speedily; quickly.

entry.ety: See Belch
entry.def: To vomit.

entry.note: ☞ Bells have been made of various metals, but the best have always been, as now, of an alloy of copper and tin.

cs.cd: the famous bell of the Philadelphia State House, which rang when the Continental Congress declared the Independence of the United States, in 1776. It had been cast in 1753, and upon it were the words “Proclaim liberty throughout all the land, to all the inhabitants thereof.”

entry.note: ☞ On shipboard, time is marked by a bell, which is struck eight times at 4, 8, and 12 o'clock. Half an hour after it has struck “eight bells” it is struck once, and at every succeeding half hour the number of strokes is increased by one, till at the end of the four hours, which constitute a watch, it is struck eight times.
entry.cs:
To bear away the bell to win the prize at a race where the prize was a bell; hence, to be superior in something. Fuller. To bear the bell to be the first or leader; -- in allusion to the bellwether or a flock, or the leading animal of a team or drove, when wearing a bell.
To curse by bell book and candle
a solemn form of excommunication used in the Roman Catholic church, the bell being tolled, the book of offices for the purpose being used, and three candles being extinguished with certain ceremonies. Nares. To lose the bell to be worsted in a contest. “In single fight he lost the bell.” Fairfax. To shake the bells to move, give notice, or alarm. Shak.
entry.note: ☞ Bell is much used adjectively or in combinations; as, bell clapper; bell foundry; bell hanger; bell-mouthed; bell tower, etc., which, for the most part, are self-explaining.
entry.cs:
Bell arch Arch an arch of unusual form, following the curve of an ogee.
Bell cage, or Bell carriage
Arch a timber frame constructed to carry one or more large bells. Bell cot Arch a small or subsidiary construction, frequently corbeled out from the walls of a structure, and used to contain and support one or more bells. Bell deck Arch the floor of a belfry made to serve as a roof to the rooms below. Bell founder one whose occupation it is to found or cast bells.
Bell foundry, or Bell foundery
a place where bells are founded or cast. Bell gable Arch a small gable-shaped construction, pierced with one or more openings, and used to contain bells. Bell glass. See Bell jar. Bell hanger a man who hangs or puts up bells. Bell pull a cord, handle, or knob, connecting with a bell or bell wire, and which will ring the bell when pulled. Aytoun. Bell punch a kind of conductor's punch which rings a bell when used. Bell ringer one who rings a bell or bells, esp. one whose business it is to ring a church bell or chime, or a set of musical bells for public entertainment. Bell roof Arch a roof shaped according to the general lines of a bell. Bell rope a rope by which a church or other bell is rung. Bell tent a circular conical-topped tent. Bell trap a kind of bell shaped stench trap.
entry.ety: AS. belle, fr. bellan to bellow. See Bellow

sn.def: A hollow metallic vessel, usually shaped somewhat like a cup with a flaring mouth, containing a clapper or tongue, and giving forth a ringing sound on being struck.
A hollow perforated sphere of metal containing a loose ball which causes it to sound when moved.
Anything in the form of a bell, as the cup or corol of a flower.
sn.q: In a cowslip'sbellI lie.

sn.def: That part of the capital of a column included between the abacus and neck molding; also used for the naked core of nearly cylindrical shape, assumed to exist within the leafage of a capital.
The strikes of the bell which mark the time; or the time so designated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belled; p. pr. & vb. n. Belling
entry.def: To put a bell upon; as, to bell the cat.

sn.def: To make bell-mouthed; as, to bell a tube.

entry.def: To develop bells or corollas; to take the form of a bell; to blossom; as, hops bell .

entry.ety: AS. bellan. See Bellow
entry.def: To utter by bellowing.
To call or bellow, as the deer in rutting time; to make a bellowing sound; to roar.
entry.q: As loud as belleth wind in hell.
The wild buck bells from ferny brake.

entry.ety: It., literally fine lady; bella beautiful + donna lady
entry.def: An herbaceous European plant (Atropa belladonna) with reddish bell-shaped flowers and shining black berries. The whole plant and its fruit are very poisonous, and the root and leaves are used as powerful medicinal agents. Its properties are largely due to the alkaloid atropine which it contains. Called also deadly nightshade.
A species of Amaryllis Amaryllis belladonna); the belladonna lily.

entries.entry: Bell" an`i*mal"cule. Zoöl An infusorian of the family Vorticellidæ, common in fresh-water ponds.

entry.def: A stoneware jug of a pattern originated in the neighborhood of Cologne, Germany, in the 16th century. It has a bearded face or mask supposed to represent Cardinal Bellarmine, a leader in the Roman Catholic Counter Reformation, following the Reformation; -- called also graybeard longbeard.

entries.entry: Bell" bear`er. Zoöl A Brazilian leaf hopper (Bocydium tintinnabuliferum), remarkable for the four bell-shaped appendages of its thorax.

entry.ety: So called from their notes
entry.def: A South and Central American bird of the genus Casmarhincos, and family Cotingidæ, of several species; the campanero.
The Myzantha melanophrys of Australia.
having legs that flare at the bottom; -- of trousers.
trousers with legs that flare; commonly worn as part of a sailor's uniform; -- such absurdly wide hems were also fashionable in the 1960s.
someone employed as an errand boy and luggage carrier around hotels.

entries.entry: Bell" crank`. A lever whose two arms form a right angle, or nearly a right angle, having its fulcrum at the apex of the angle. It is used in bell pulls and in changing the direction of bell wires at angles of rooms, etc., and also in machinery.

entry.ety: F. belle, fem. of bel beau, beautiful, fine. See Beau
entry.def: A young lady of superior beauty and attractions; a handsome lady, or one who attracts notice in society; a fair lady.
Hung with a bell or bells.

entries.entry: Bel*leek" ware. A porcelainlike kind of decorative pottery with a high gloss, which is sometimes iridescent. A very fine kind is made at Belleek in Ireland.

entry.def: One versed in belles-lettres.
A genus of fossil univalve shells, believed to belong to the Heteropoda, peculiar to the Paleozoic age.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Polite or elegant literature; the humanities; -- used somewhat vaguely for literary works in which imagination and taste are predominant.
Occupied with, or pertaining to, belles-lettres.
entry.q: An unlearned,belletristictrifler.

entry.def: Having the striking surface convex; -- said of hammers.
A plant of the genus Campanula; -- so named from its bell-shaped flowers.

entry.ety: F. bellefleur, lit., beautiful flower
entry.def: A kind of apple. The yellow bellflower is a large, yellow winter apple.

entry.ety: F. belle et bonne, beautiful and good
entry.def: A woman excelling both in beauty and goodness; a fair maid.

entry.ety: L. bellicus. See Bellicose
entry.def: Of or pertaining to war; warlike; martial.
entry.q: BellicCæsar.

entry.ety: L. bellicosus, fr. bellicus of war, fr. bellum war. See Duel
entry.def: Inclined to war or contention; warlike; pugnacious.
entry.q: Arnold was, in fact, in a bellicose vein.

entry.def: In a bellicose manner.
Bellicose.
Having (such) a belly; puffed out; -- used in composition; as, pot-bellied; shad-bellied .
The quality of being belligerent.

sn.def: the act or state of being engaged in war or a warlike conflict; warfare.
an aggressively hostile or warlike attitude or nature; a readiness to fight or offend, with little or no provocation.

entry.ety: L. bellum war + gerens -entis, waging, p. pr. of gerere to wage: cf. F. belligérant. See Bellicose Jest

sn.def: Waging war; carrying on war.
sn.q: Belligerentpowers.

sn.def: Pertaining, or tending, to war; of or relating to belligerents; as, a belligerent tone; belligerent rights.

entry.def: A nation or state recognized as carrying on war; a person engaged in warfare.
In a belligerent manner; hostilely.

entry.ety: From Bell to bellow
entry.def: A bellowing, as of a deer in rutting time.

entry.ety: L. bellipotens; bellum war + potens powerful, p. pr. of posse to be able
entry.def: Mighty in war; armipotent.

entries.entry: Bell" jar`. Phys A glass vessel, varying in size, open at the bottom and closed at the top like a bell, and having a knob or handle at the top for lifting it. It is used for a great variety of purposes; as, with the air pump, and for holding gases, also for keeping the dust from articles exposed to view.

entry.def: A man who rings a bell, especially to give notice of anything in the streets. Formerly, also, a night watchman who called the hours.

entries.entry:
Bell" met`al
Bell metal ore a sulphide of tin, copper, and iron; the mineral stannite. . A hard alloy or bronze, consisting usually of about three parts of copper to one of tin; -- used for making bells.

entry.def: Expanding at the mouth; as, a bell-mouthed gun.
Lead colic.

entry.ety: L., from bellum war
entry.def: The goddess of war.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bellowed ; p. pr. & vb. n. Bellowing
entry.ety: OE. belwen belowen, AS. bylgean, fr. bellan; akin to G. bellen, and perh. to L. flere to weep, OSlav. bleja to bleat, Lith. balsas voice. Cf. Bell n. & v. Bawl Bull

sn.def: To make a hollow, loud noise, as an enraged bull.
To bowl; to vociferate; to clamor.
To roar; as the sea in a tempest, or as the wind when violent; to make a loud, hollow, continued sound.
sn.q: The bellowing voice of boiling seas.

entry.def: To emit with a loud voice; to shout; -- used with out.
entry.q: Wouldbellowout a laugh.

entry.def: A loud resounding outcry or noise, as of an enraged bull; a roar.
One who, or that which, bellows.

entry.cs: Bellows camera in photography, a form of camera, which can be drawn out like an accordion or bellows. Hydrostatic bellows. See Hydrostatic. A pair of bellows the ordinary household instrument for blowing fires, consisting of two nearly heart-shaped boards with handles, connected by leather, and having a valve and tube.
entry.ety: OE. bely below, belly, bellows, AS. bælg bælig, bag, bellows, belly. Bellows is prop. a pl. and the orig. sense is bag. See Belly
entry.def: An instrument, utensil, or machine, which, by alternate expansion and contraction, or by rise and fall of the top, draws in air through a valve and expels it through a tube for various purposes, as blowing fires, ventilating mines, or filling the pipes of an organ with wind.

entries.entry: Bel"lows fish`. Zoöl A European fish (Centriscus scolopax), distinguished by a long tubular snout, like the pipe of a bellows; -- called also trumpet fish, and snipe fish.
Bell" pep`per. Bot A species of Capsicum, or Guinea pepper (Capsicum annuum). It is the red pepper of the gardens.
Bell process. Iron Metal The process of washing molten pig iron by adding iron oxide, proposed by I. Lowthian Bell of England about 1875.

sn.def: a person who rings church bells (as for summoning the congregation).
someone who plays musical handbells.

entry.def: playing a set of bells that are (usually) hung in a tower.
Having the shape of a wide-mouthed bell; campanulate.

entries.entry: Bell's palsy. Paralysis of the facial nerve, producing distortion of one side of the face.
Bell system of control. Aëronautics See Cloche.

entry.ety: L. belluinus, fr. bellua beast
entry.def: Pertaining to, or like, a beast; brutal.
entry.q: Animal and belluine life.

sn.def: A wether, or sheep, which leads the flock, with a bell on his neck.
Hence: A leader.

entry.def: A genus of plants (Uvularia) with yellowish bell-shaped flowers.

entries.entry:
Bel"ly ☞ Formerly all the splanchnic or visceral cavities were called bellies; -- the lower belly being the abdomen; the middle belly, the thorax; and the upper belly, the head.
Belly doublet a doublet of the 16th century, hanging down so as to cover the belly. Shak. Belly fretting the chafing of a horse's belly with a girth. Johnson. Belly timber food. Ludicrous Prior. Belly worm a worm that breeds or lives in the belly (stomach or intestines). Johnson.
bĕl"l� n.; pl.Bellies -lĭz. OE. bali bely, AS. belg bælg bælig, bag, bellows, belly; akin to Icel. belgr bag, bellows, Sw. bälg, Dan. bælg, D. & G. balg, cf. W. bol the paunch or belly, dim. boly, Ir. bolg. Cf. Bellows Follicle Fool Bilge
That part of the human body which extends downward from the breast to the thighs, and contains the bowels, or intestines; the abdomen.
The under part of the body of animals, corresponding to the human belly. Underneath the belly of their steeds.
The womb. Obs Before I formed thee in the belly I knew thee.
The part of anything which resembles the human belly in protuberance or in cavity; the innermost part; as, the belly of a flask, muscle, sail, ship. Out of the belly of hell cried I.
Arch The hollow part of a curved or bent timber, the convex part of which is the back.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bellied; p. pr. & vb. n. Bellying
entry.def: To cause to swell out; to fill.
entry.q: Your breath of full consent bellied his sails.

entry.def: To swell and become protuberant, like the belly; to bulge.
entry.q: The bellying canvas strutted with the gale.

entry.def: Pain in the bowels; colic.
to complain, especially in a whining or grumbling manner; to gripe.
entry.syn: gripe, whine, complain, moan, snivel, grumble, squawk.

entry.def: a person who complains habitually, usually about everyday minor problems.
entry.syn: whiner, complainer, moaner, sniveler, crybaby, grumbler, squawker.

sn.def: A band that passes under the belly of a horse and holds the saddle or harness in place; a girth.
A band of flannel or other cloth about the belly.
A band of canvas, to strengthen a sail.

entry.def: Costive; constipated.
The depression in the middle of the abdomen in humans left as a residue of the umbilical cord; the umbilicus; the navel{1}.
An apron or covering for the front of the person.

entry.ety: Perh. from F. belle chère
entry.def: Good cheer; viands.
entry.q: Bellycheerand banquets.
Loaves andbellycheer.

entry.def: To revel; to feast.
entry.q: A pack of clergymen [assembled] by themselves to bellycheer in their presumptuous Sion.

entry.def: As much as satisfies the appetite. Hence: A great abundance; more than enough.
entry.q: King James told his son that he would have his bellyful of parliamentary impeachments.

entry.def: One whose great pleasure it is to gratify his appetite; a glutton; an epicure.
to land on the underside without the landing gear; -- of airplanes.
to laugh a deep, hearty laugh.
a vigorous, loud laugh, expressing a strong amusement.
Pinched with hunger; starved.
entry.q: Thebelly-pinchedwolf.

entry.def: to approach (a counter) and stand in front of it; -- used mostly in the phrase belly up to the bari.e. to a counter in a saloon).

entry.ety: from analogy to the position of a floating dead fish
entry.def: defunct; bankrupt; -- used mostly of commercial organizations; often used in the phrase go belly-up, i. e. to go bankrupt.

sn.def: Babylonian) the chief Babylonian god; his consort was Sarpanitu.

entry.ety: Pref. be- + lock: cf. AS. belūcan
entry.def: To lock, or fasten as with a lock.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � arrow + � a diviner: cf. F. bélomancie
entry.def: A kind of divination anciently practiced by means of marked arrows drawn at random from a bag or quiver, the marks on the arrows drawn being supposed to foreshow the future.

entry.note: Usually construed with to
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belonged; p. pr. & vb. n. Belonging
entry.ety: OE. belongenakin to D. belangen to concern, G. belangen to attain to, to concern); pref. be- + longen to desire. See Long v. i.

sn.def: To be the property of; as, Jamaica belongs to Great Britain.
To be a part of, or connected with; to be appendant or related; to owe allegiance or service.
sn.q: A desert place belonging to . . . Bethsaids.
The mighty men which belonged to David.

sn.def: To be the concern or proper business or function of; to appertain to.
sn.q: Do not interpretationsbelongto God ?

sn.def: To be suitable for; to be due to.
sn.q: Strong meat belongeth to them that are of full age.
No blame belongs to thee.

sn.def: To be native to, or an inhabitant of; esp. to have a legal residence, settlement, or inhabitancy, whether by birth or operation of law, so as to be entitled to maintenance by the parish or town.
sn.q: Bastards also are settled in the parishes to which the mothers belong.

entry.def: To be deserved by.
entry.q: More evils belong us than happen to us.

entry.ety: Commonly in the pl

sn.def: That which belongs to one; that which pertains to one; hence, goods or effects.
sn.q: Thyself and thybelongings.

sn.def: That which is connected with a principal or greater thing; an appendage; an appurtenance.
Family; relations; household.
sn.q: Few persons of her ladyship's belongings stopped, before they did her bidding, to ask her reasons.

entry.ety: Gr. � a needle
entry.def: Minute acicular or dendritic crystalline forms sometimes observed in glassy volcanic rocks.
Of or pertaining to Beloochistan, or to its inhabitants.

def2.def: A native or an inhabitant of Beloochistan.

sn.def: To act the lord over.
To address by the title of “lord”.

entry.ety: OE. bilufien. See pref. Be-, and Love v. t.
entry.def: To love.
Greatly loved; dear to the heart.
entry.q: Antony, so well beloved of Cæsar.
This is my beloved Son.

entry.def: One greatly loved.
entry.q: My beloved is mine, and I am his.

entry.ety: Pref. be- by + low

sn.def: Under, or lower in place; beneath not so high; as, below the moon; below the knee.
Inferior to in rank, excellence, dignity, value, amount, price, etc.; lower in quality.
sn.q: One degreebelowkings.

sn.def: Unworthy of; unbefitting; beneath.
sn.q: They beheld, with a just loathing and disdain, . . . how below all history the persons and their actions were.
Who thinks no fact below his regard.

sn.def: In a lower place, with respect to any object; in a lower room; beneath.
sn.q: Lord Marmion waits below.

sn.def: On the earth, as opposed to the heavens.
sn.q: The fairest child of Jove below.

sn.def: In hell, or the regions of the dead.
sn.q: What business brought him to the realms below.

sn.def: In court or tribunal of inferior jurisdiction; as, at the trial below .
In some part or page following.

entry.def: To treat as a lout; to talk abusively to.

entry.ety: Pref. bel- + sire. Cf. Beldam
entry.def: A grandfather, or ancestor.
entry.q: His greatbelsire Brute.

entry.ety: Contr. from bellyswagger
entry.def: A lewd man; also, a bully.

entry.note: See Illust. of Pulley

cs.cd: thongs used for lacing together the ends of machine belting.

entry.ety: AS. belt; akin to Icel. belti, Sw. bälte, Dan. bælte, OHG. balz, L. balteus, Ir. & Gael. balt border, belt

sn.def: That which engirdles a person or thing; a band or girdle; as, a lady's belt; a sword belt .
sn.q: The shining belt with gold inlaid.

sn.def: That which restrains or confines as a girdle.
sn.q: He cannot buckle his distempered cause Within the belt of rule.

sn.def: Anything that resembles a belt, or that encircles or crosses like a belt; a strip or stripe; as, a belt of trees; a belt of sand.
Same as Band n., 2. A very broad band is more properly termed a belt.
One of certain girdles or zones on the surface of the planets Jupiter and Saturn, supposed to be of the nature of clouds.
A narrow passage or strait; as, the Great Belt and the Lesser Belt, leading to the Baltic Sea.
A token or badge of knightly rank.
A band of leather, or other flexible substance, passing around two wheels, and communicating motion from one to the other.
A band or stripe, as of color, round any organ; or any circular ridge or series of ridges.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Belted; p. pr. & vb. n. Belting
entry.def: To encircle with, or as with, a belt; to encompass; to surround.
entry.q: A coarse black robe belted round the waist.
They belt him round with hearts undaunted.

sn.def: To shear, as the buttocks and tails of sheep.

entry.ety: Gael. bealltainn bealltuinn

sn.def: The first day of May (Old Style).
sn.q: The quarter-days anciently in Scotland were Hallowmas, Candlemas, Beltane, and Lammas.

sn.def: A festival of the heathen Celts on the first day of May, in the observance of which great bonfires were kindled. It still exists in a modified form in some parts of Scotland and Ireland.

cs.cd: cattle originally from Dutch stock, having a broad band of white round the middle, while the rest of the body is black; -- called also blanketed cattle.

sn.def: Encircled by, or secured with, a belt; as, a belted plaid; girt with a belt, as an honorary distinction; as, a belted knight; a belted earl.
Marked with a band or circle; as, a belted stalk.
Worn in, or suspended from, the belt.
sn.q: Three men with belted brands.

entry.def: See Beltane.
The material of which belts for machinery are made; also, belts, taken collectively.
lacking a belt.
entry.illu: beltless jackets are in this season

entry.note: ☞ The northern beluga Delphinapterus catodon) is the white whale and white fish of the whalers. It grows to be from twelve to eighteen feet long.
entry.ety: Russ. bieluga a sort of large sturgeon, prop. white fish, fr. bieluii white. The whale is now commonly called bieluka in Russian

sn.def: A cetacean allied to the dolphins.
the sturgeon (Huso huso) native to the Black Sea and Caspian Sea; -- also called hausen. It is valued for its roe, sold as caviar, and is also used for production of isinglass. See also sturgeon.

the caviar obtained from the beluga{2}; -- also called beluga caviar. The caviar of the beluga is considered the finest sort, larger and of a taste superior to that obtained from other sturgeon. See also sturgeon and caviar.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Beluted; p. pr. & vb. n. Beluting
entry.ety: Pref. be- + L. lutum mud
entry.def: To bespatter, as with mud.

entry.ety: It., fr. bello bel, beautiful + vedere to see
entry.def: A small building, or a part of a building, more or less open, constructed in a place commanding a fine prospect.

entry.ety: From Beelzebub
entry.def: A spider monkey (Ateles belzebuth) of Brazil.

entry.ety: Gr. � step, platform

sn.def: A platform from which speakers addressed an assembly.

sd.def: That part of an early Christian church which was reserved for the higher clergy; the inner or eastern part of the chancel.
Erroneously: A pulpit.

entry.def: To make mad.
To mangle; to tear asunder.
To mask; to conceal.
To master thoroughly.
To maul or beat severely; to bruise.
entry.q: In order tobemaulYorick.

entry.ety: OE. bimasen; pref. be- + masen to maze
entry.def: To bewilder.
entry.q: Intellects bemazed in endless doubt.

entry.def: To make mean; to lower.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bemet; p. pr. & vb. n. Bemeeting
entry.def: To meet.
entry.q: Our very loving sister, well bemet.

entry.def: To mete.
To mingle; to mix.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bemired; p. pr. & vb. n. Bemiring
entry.def: To drag through, encumber with, or fix in, the mire; to soil by passing through mud or dirt.
entry.q: Bemired and benighted in the dog.

entry.def: To envelop in mist.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bemoaned; p. pr. & vb. n. Bemoaning
entry.ety: OE. bimenen, AS. bem�nan; pref. be- + m�nan to moan. See Moan
entry.def: To express deep grief for by moaning; to express sorrow for; to lament; to bewail; to pity or sympathize with.
entry.q: Implores their pity, and his pain bemoans.

entry.def: One who bemoans.
To mock; to ridicule.
entry.q: Bemock the modest moon.

entry.ety: Pref. be- + moil, fr. F. mouiller to wet; but cf. also OE. bimolen to soil, fr. AS. māl spot: cf. E. mole
entry.def: To soil or encumber with mire and dirt.

entry.ety: F. bémol, fr. bé ♭ + mol soft
entry.def: The sign ♭; the same as B flat.
To make monstrous or like a monster.
To mourn over.
To muddle; to stupefy or bewilder; to confuse.
To cover as with a muffler; to wrap up.
entry.q: Bemuffled with the externals of religion.

entry.def: To muddle, daze, or partially stupefy, as with liquor.
entry.q: A parson much bemused in beer.

entries.entry: Ben Ben" nut` . Ar. bān, name of the tree Bot The seed of one or more species of moringa; as, oil of ben . See Moringa.

entry.ety: AS. binnan; pref. be- by + innan within, in in
entry.def: Within; in; in or into the interior; toward the inner apartment.

entry.ety: See Ben adv.
entry.def: The inner or principal room in a hut or house of two rooms; -- opposed to but, the outer apartment.

entries.entry: Ben. An old form of the pl. indic. pr. of Be. Obs

entry.def: To promise; to name.

entries.entry:
Bench
Bench mark Leveling one of a number of marks along a line of survey, affixed to permanent objects, to show where leveling staffs were placed. See bench mark in the vocabulary. Bench of bishops the whole body of English prelates assembled in council. Bench plane any plane used by carpenters and joiners for working a flat surface, as jack planes, long planes. Bench show an exhibition of dogs. Bench table Arch a projecting course at the base of a building, or round a pillar, sufficient to form a seat.
n.; pl.Benches. OE. bench benk, AS. benc; akin to Sw. bänk, Dan bænk, Icel. bekkr, OS., D., & G. bank. Cf. Bank Beach
A long seat, differing from a stool in its greater length. Mossy benches supplied the place of chairs.
A long table at which mechanics and other work; as, a carpenter's bench .
The seat where judges sit in court. To pluck down justice from your awful bench.
The persons who sit as judges; the court; as, the opinion of the full bench . See King's Bench.
A collection or group of dogs exhibited to the public; -- so named because the animals are usually placed on benches or raised platforms.
A conformation like a bench; a long stretch of flat ground, or a kind of natural terrace, near a lake or river.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Benched; p. pr. & vb. n. Benching

sn.def: To furnish with benches.
sn.q: 'T was benched with turf.
Stately theaters benched crescentwise.

sn.def: To place on a bench or seat of honor.
sn.q: Whom I . . . have benched and reared to worship.

entry.def: To sit on a seat of justice.

sn.def: One of the senior and governing members of an Inn of Court.
An alderman of a corporation.
A member of a court or council.
One who frequents the benches of a tavern; an idler.

entries.entry:
benchmark bench mark . Surveying
Any permanent mark to which other levels may be referred. such as: A horizontal mark at the water's edge with reference to which the height of tides and floods may be measured.
a surveyer's mark on a permanent object of predetermined position and elevation used as a reference point.
something serving as a standard by which related items may be judged; as, his painting sets the benchmark of quality.
a test or series of tests designed to compare the qualities or performance of different devices of the same type. Certain sets of computer programs are much used as benchmarks for comparing the performance of different computers, especially by comparing the time it takes to complete a test.
Bench" war`rant. Law A process issued by a presiding judge or by a court against a person guilty of some contempt, or indicted for some crime; -- so called in distinction from a justice's warrant.

cs.cd: to knit the brow, as in deep thought or in anger; to scowl; to frown.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bended or Bent; p. pr. & vb. n. Bending
entry.ety: AS. bendan to bend, fr. bend a band, bond, fr. bindan to bind. See Bind v. t., and cf. 3d & 4th Bend

sn.def: To strain or move out of a straight line; to crook by straining; to make crooked; to curve; to make ready for use by drawing into a curve; as, to bend a bow; to bend the knee.
To turn toward some certain point; to direct; to incline.
sn.q: Bendthine ear to supplication.
Towards Coventry bend we our course.
Bending her eyes . . . upon her parent.

sn.def: To apply closely or with interest; to direct.
sn.q: To bend his mind to any public business.
But when to mischief mortals bend their will.

sn.def: To cause to yield; to render submissive; to subdue.
sn.q: Except shebendher humor.

sn.def: To fasten, as one rope to another, or as a sail to its yard or stay; or as a cable to the ring of an anchor.
sn.syn: To lean; stoop; deflect; bow; yield.

sn.def: To be moved or strained out of a straight line; to crook or be curving; to bow.
sn.q: The green earth's end Where the bowed welkin slow doth bend.

sn.def: To jut over; to overhang.
sn.q: There is a cliff, whose high and bending head Looks fearfully in the confined deep.

sn.def: To be inclined; to be directed.
sn.q: To whom our vows and wished bend.

sn.def: To bow in prayer, or in token of submission.
sn.q: While each to his great Father bends.

cs.cd: the thickest and strongest planks in her sides, more generally called wales. They have the beams, knees, and foothooks bolted to them. Also, the frames or ribs that form the ship's body from the keel to the top of the sides; as, the midship bend.

entry.ety: See Bend v. t., and cf. Bent n.

sn.def: A turn or deflection from a straight line or from the proper direction or normal position; a curve; a crook; as, a slight bend of the body; a bend in a road.
Turn; purpose; inclination; ends.
sn.q: Farewell, poor swain; thou art not for my bend.

sn.def: A knot by which one rope is fastened to another or to an anchor, spar, or post.
The best quality of sole leather; a butt. See Butt.
Hard, indurated clay; bind.
same as caisson disease. Usually referred to as the bends.

cs.cd: an honorable ordinary drawn from the sinister chief to the dexter base.

entry.ety: AS. bend. See Band, and cf. the preceding noun

sn.def: A band.

sn.ety: OF. bende bande, F. bande. See Band
sn.def: One of the honorable ordinaries, containing a third or a fifth part of the field. It crosses the field diagonally from the dexter chief to the sinister base.

entry.def: Capable of being bent.
to reproduce by the Benday method.

sn.def: One who, or that which, bends.
An instrument used for bending.
A drunken spree.
A sixpence.

entry.def: The marking of the clothes with stripes or horizontal bands.

entry.ety: Bend + -let: cf. E. bandlet
entry.def: A narrow bend, esp. one half the width of the bend.
Diagonally.

entry.ety: From Bend a band
entry.def: Divided into an even number of bends; -- said of a shield or its charge.
See Benne.

entry.ety: AS. bēn
entry.def: A prayer; boon.
entry.q: What is good for a bootless bene ?

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A hoglike mammal of New Guinea (Porcula papuensis).
See Neaped.

entry.ety: OE. benethe bineoðen, AS. beneoðan benyðan; pref. be- + neoðan nyðan, downward, beneath, akin to E. nether. See Nether

sn.def: Lower in place, with something directly over or on; under; underneath; hence, at the foot of.
sn.q: Beneaththe mount.
Beneath a rude and nameless stone he lies.

sn.def: Under, in relation to something that is superior, or that oppresses or burdens.
sn.q: Our country sinks beneath the yoke.

sn.def: Lower in rank, dignity, or excellence than; as, brutes are beneath man; man is beneath angels in the scale of beings. Hence: Unworthy of; unbecoming.
sn.q: He will do nothing that is beneath his high station.

sn.def: In a lower place; underneath.
sn.q: The earth you take from beneath will be barren.

sn.def: Below, as opposed to heaven, or to any superior region or position; as, in earth beneath .

entry.ety: L., (imperative pl.,) bless ye, praise ye
entry.def: A canticle (the Latin version of which begins with this word) which may be used in the order for morning prayer in the Church of England. It is taken from an apocryphal addition to the third chapter of Daniel.

entry.ety: See Benedicite n.
entry.def: An exclamation corresponding to Bless you !.

entry.ety: From Benedick, one of the characters in Shakespeare's play of “Much Ado about Nothing.”
entry.def: A married man, or a man newly married.

entry.ety: L. benedictus, p. p. of benedicere to bless. See Benison, and cf. Bennet
entry.def: Having mild and salubrious qualities.
Pertaining to the monks of St. Benedict, or St. Benet.

entry.note: ☞ The Benedictines wear black clothing, and are sometimes called Black Monks. The name Black Fr����rs which belongs to the Dominicans, is also sometimes applied to the Benedictines.
entry.def: One of a famous order of monks, established by St. Benedict of Nursia in the sixth century. This order was introduced into the United States in 1846.

entry.ety: L. benedictio: cf. F. bénédiction. See Benison

sn.def: The act of blessing.
A blessing; an expression of blessing, prayer, or kind wishes in favor of any person or thing; a solemn or affectionate invocation of happiness.
sn.q: So saying, he arose; whom Adam thus Followed with benediction.
Homeward serenely she walked with God's benediction upon her.
sn.def: The short prayer which closes public worship; as, to give the benediction .
The short prayer which closes public worship; as, to give the benediction .
The form of instituting an abbot, answering to the consecration of a bishop.
A solemn rite by which bells, banners, candles, etc., are blessed with holy water, and formally dedicated to God.

entry.def: A book of benedictions.
A collected series of benedictions.
entry.q: The benedictionary of Bishop Athelwold.

entry.def: Tending to bless.
Expressing wishes for good; as, a benedictory prayer.

entry.ety: L., blessed. See Benedict a.
entry.def: The song of Zacharias at the birth of John the Baptist (Luke i. 68); -- so named from the first word of the Latin version.
Blessed.

entry.ety: L. benefactio, fr. benefacere to do good to one; bene well + facere to do. See Benefit

sn.def: The act of conferring a benefit.
A benefit conferred; esp. a charitable donation.

entries.entry: Ben`e*fac"tor,n. L One who confers a benefit or benefits.

entry.def: A woman who confers a benefit.
entry.q: His benefactress blushes at the deed.

entry.ety: L. beneficus. See Benefice
entry.def: Favorable; beneficent.

entry.note: ☞ Such an estate was granted at first for life only, and held on the mere good pleasure of the donor; but afterward, becoming hereditary, it received the appellation of fief, and the term benefice became appropriated to church livings.

☞ All church preferments are called benefices, except bishoprics, which are called dignities. But, ordinarily, the term dignity is applied to bishoprics, deaneries, archdeaconries, and prebendaryships; benefice to parsonages, vicarages, and donatives.
entry.ety: F. bénéfice, L. beneficium, a kindness , in LL. a grant of an estate, fr. L. beneficus beneficent; bene well + facere to do. See Benefit

sn.def: A favor or benefit.
An estate in lands; a fief.
An ecclesiastical living and church preferment, as in the Church of England; a church endowed with a revenue for the maintenance of divine service. See Advowson.

entry.note: Commonly in the past participle
entry.def: To endow with a benefice.
Possessed of a benefice or church preferment.
entry.q: Beneficedclergymen.

entry.def: Having no benefice.
entry.q: Beneficelessprecisians.

entry.ety: L. beneficentia, fr. beneficus: cf. F. bénéficence. See Benefice
entry.def: The practice of doing good; active goodness, kindness, or charity; bounty springing from purity and goodness.

entry.usage: Benevolence marks a disposition made up of a choice and desire for the happiness of others. Beneficence marks the working of this disposition in dispensing good on a somewhat broad scale. Munificence shows the same disposition, but acting on a still broader scale, in conferring gifts and favors. These are not necessarily confined to objects of immediate utility. One may show his munificence in presents of pictures or jewelry, but this would not be beneficence. Benevolence of heart; beneficence of life; munificence in the encouragement of letters.
entry.ety: OF. benevolence, L. benevolentia. See Benevolent

sn.def: The disposition to do good; good will; charitableness; love of mankind, accompanied with a desire to promote their happiness.
sn.q: The wakeful benevolence of the gospel.

sn.def: An act of kindness; good done; charity given.
A species of compulsory contribution or tax, which has sometimes been illegally exacted by arbitrary kings of England, and falsely represented as a gratuity.

entry.usage: Etymologically considered, benevolent implies wishing well to others, and beneficent doing well. But by degrees the word benevolent has been widened to include not only feelings, but actions; thus, we speak of benevolent operations, benevolent labors for the public good, benevolent societies. In like manner, beneficent is now often applied to feelings; thus, we speak of the beneficent intentions of a donor. This extension of the terms enables us to mark nicer shades of meaning. Thus, the phrase “benevolent labors” turns attention to the source of these labors, viz., benevolent feeling; while beneficent would simply mark them as productive of good. So, “beneficent intentions” point to the feelings of the donor as bent upon some specific good act; while “benevolent intentions” would only denote a general wish and design to do good.
entry.ety: L. benevolens -entis; bene well (adv. of bonus good) + volens, p. pr. of volo I will, I wish. See Bounty, and Voluntary
entry.def: Having a disposition to do good; possessing or manifesting love to mankind, and a desire to promote their prosperity and happiness; disposed to give to good objects; kind; charitable.

entry.ety: L. benevolus

sn.def: Changed by pressure so as to be no longer straight; crooked; as, a bent pin; a bent lever.

Strongly inclined toward something, so as to be resolved, determined, set, etc.; -- said of the mind, character, disposition, desires, etc., and used with on; as, to be bent on going to college; he is bent on mischief.

entry.usage: Bent Bias Inclination Prepossession. These words agree in describing a permanent influence upon the mind which tends to decide its actions. Bent denotes a fixed tendency of the mind in a given direction. It is the widest of these terms, and applies to the will, the intellect, and the affections, taken conjointly; as, the whole bent of his character was toward evil practices. Bias is literally a weight fixed on one side of a ball used in bowling, and causing it to swerve from a straight course. Used figuratively, bias applies particularly to the judgment, and denotes something which acts with a permanent force on the character through that faculty; as, the bias of early education, early habits, etc. Inclination is an excited state of desire or appetency; as, a strong inclination to the study of the law. Prepossession is a mingled state of feeling and opinion in respect to some person or subject, which has laid hold of and occupied the mind previous to inquiry. The word is commonly used in a good sense, an unfavorable impression of this kind being denominated a prejudice. “Strong minds will be strongly bent, and usually labor under a strong bias; but there is no mind so weak and powerless as not to have its inclinations, and none so guarded as to be without its prepossessions.”
entry.ety: See Bend n. & v.

entry.usage: Both these words denote the giving or disposing of property by will. Devise, in legal usage, is property used to denote a gift by will of real property, and he to whom it is given is called the devisee. Bequeath is properly applied to a gift by will or legacy; i. e., of personal property; the gift is called a legacy, and he who receives it is called a legatee. In popular usage the word bequeath is sometimes enlarged so as to embrace devise; and it is sometimes so construed by courts.

entries.entry: Be"ring Sea Controversy. A controversy (1886 -- 93) between Great Britain and the United States as to the right of Canadians not licensed by the United States to carry on seal fishing in the Bering Sea, over which the United States claimed jurisdiction as a mare clausum. A court of arbitration, meeting in Paris in 1893, decided against the claim of the United States, but established regulations for the preservation of the fur seal.

The isotope with atomic weight 249 has a half-life of 314 days, and was isolated in weighable quantities.

The emerald is another variety highly prized in jewelry, and distinguished by its deep color, which is probably due to the presence of a little oxide of chromium.

entry.usage: To Beseech Entreat Solicit Implore Supplicate. These words agree in marking that sense of want which leads men to beg some favor. To solicit is to make a request, with some degree of earnestness and repetition, of one whom we address as a superior. To entreat implies greater urgency, usually enforced by adducing reasons or arguments. To beseech is still stronger, and belongs rather to the language of poetry and imagination. To implore denotes increased fervor of entreaty, as addressed either to equals or superiors. To supplicate expresses the extreme of entreaty, and usually implies a state of deep humiliation. Thus, a captive supplicates a conqueror to spare his life. Men solicit by virtue of their interest with another; they entreat in the use of reasoning and strong representations; they beseech with importunate earnestness; they implore from a sense of overwhelming distress; they supplicate with a feeling of the most absolute inferiority and dependence.

entry.usage:
These words, whether used as prepositions or adverbs, have been considered strictly synonymous, from an early period of our literature, and have been freely interchanged by our best writers. There is, however, a tendency, in present usage, to make the following distinction between them: 1. That beside be used only and always as a preposition, with the original meaning “by the side of; ” as, to sit beside a fountain; or with the closely allied meaning “aside from”, “apart from”, or “out of”; as, this is beside our present purpose; to be beside one's self with joy. The adverbial sense to be wholly transferred to the cognate word. 2. That besides, as a preposition, take the remaining sense “in addition to”, as, besides all this; besides the considerations here offered. “There was a famine in the land besides the first famine.” Gen. xxvi. 1. And that it also take the adverbial sense of “moreover”, “beyond”, etc., which had been divided between the words; as, besides, there are other considerations which belong to this case. The following passages may serve to illustrate this use of the words:Lovely Thais sits beside thee. Dryden. Only be patient till we have appeased The multitude, beside themselves with fear. Shak. It is beside my present business to enlarge on this speculation. Locke.
Besides this, there are persons in certain situations who are expected to be charitable. Bp. Porteus. And, besides, the Moor May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril. Shak. That man that does not know those things which are of necessity for him to know is but an ignorant man, whatever he may know besides. Tillotson.
entry.note: See Moreover.

entries.entry:
Best
Best man the only or principal groomsman at a wedding ceremony.
bĕst a.; superl. of Good. AS. besta best, contr. from betest betst betsta; akin to Goth. batists, OHG. pezzisto, G. best beste, D. best, Icel. beztr, Dan. best, Sw. bäst. This word has no connection in origin with good. See Better
Having good qualities in the highest degree; most good, kind, desirable, suitable, etc.; most excellent; as, the best man; the best road; the best cloth; the best abilities. When he is best, he is a little worse than a man. Heaven's last, best gift, my ever new delight.
Most advanced; most correct or complete; as, the best scholar; the best view of a subject.
Most; largest; as, the best part of a week.

entry.cs: At best in the utmost degree or extent applicable to the case; under the most favorable circumstances; as, life is at best very short. For best finally. Obs “Those constitutions . . . are now established for best, and not to be mended.” Milton. To get the best of to gain an advantage over, whether fairly or unfairly. To make the best of. To improve to the utmost; to use or dispose of to the greatest advantage. “Let there be freedom to carry their commodities where they can make the best of them.” Bacon. To reduce to the least possible inconvenience; as, to make the best of ill fortune or a bad bargain.
entry.def: Utmost; highest endeavor or state; most nearly perfect thing, or being, or action; as, to do one's best; to the best of our ability.

entries.entry:
Best adv.; superl. of Well. In the highest degree; beyond all others. Thou serpent! That namebestbefits thee. He prayeth best, who loveth best All things both great and small.
To the most advantage; with the most success, case, profit, benefit, or propriety. Had we best retire? I see a storm. Had I not best go to her?
Most intimately; most thoroughly or correctly; as, what is expedient is best known to himself.

entry.def: To get the better of.
