entry.def: In a bestial manner.

entry.ety: LL. bestiarium, fr. L. bestiarius pert. to beasts, fr. bestia beast: cf. F. bestiaire
entry.def: A treatise on beasts; esp., one of the moralizing or allegorical beast tales written in the Middle Ages.
entry.q: A bestiary . . . in itself one of the numerous mediæval renderings of the fantastic mystical zoölogy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bestuck; p. pr. & vb. n. Besticking
entry.def: To stick over, as with sharp points pressed in; to mark by infixing points or spots here and there; to pierce.
entry.q: Truth shall retireBestuck with slanderous darts.

entry.def: To make still.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bestirred; p. pr. & vb. n. Bestirring
entry.def: To put into brisk or vigorous action; to move with life and vigor; -- usually with the reciprocal pronoun.
entry.q: You have so bestirred your valor.
Rouse and bestir themselves ere well awake.

entry.def: To storm.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bestowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bestowing
entry.ety: OE. bestowen; pref. be- + stow a place. See Stow

sn.def: To lay up in store; to deposit for safe keeping; to stow; to place; to put.
sn.q: Hebestowedit in a pouch.
See that the women are bestowed in safety.

sn.def: To use; to apply; to devote, as time or strength in some occupation.
To expend, as money.
To give or confer; to impart; -- with on or upon.
sn.q: Empire is on us bestowed.
Though I bestow all my goods to feed the poor.

sn.def: To give in marriage.
sn.q: I could have bestowed her upon a fine gentleman.

sn.def: To demean; to conduct; to behave; -- followed by a reflexive pronoun.
sn.q: How might we see Falstaff bestow himself to-night in his true colors, and not ourselves be seen ?
sn.syn: To give; grant; present; confer; accord.

entry.def: The act of bestowing; disposal.
One that bestows.

sn.def: The act of giving or bestowing; a conferring or bestowal.
sn.q: If we consider this bestowment of gifts in this view.

sn.def: That which is given or bestowed.
sn.q: They almost refuse to give due praise and credit to God's own bestowments.

entry.def: To bestride.

entry.ety: Pref. be- + straught; prob. here used for distraught
entry.def: Out of one's senses; distracted; mad.
To streak.

entry.vmorph: imp. Bestrewed; p. p. Bestrewed Bestrown�); p. pr. & vb. n. Bestrewing
entry.def: To strew or scatter over; to besprinkle.

entry.vmorph: imp. Bestrode Obs. or R Bestrid; p. p. Bestridden Bestrid Bestrode; p. pr. & vb. n. Bestriding
entry.ety: AS. bestrīdan; pref. be- + strīdan to stride

sn.def: To stand or sit with anything between the legs, or with the legs astride; to stand over
sn.q: That horse that thou so often hast bestrid.
Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world Like a Colossus.

sn.def: To step over; to stride over or across; as, to bestride a threshold.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Bestride.
p. p. of Bestrew.
imp. & p. p. Bestick.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bestudded; p. pr. & vb. n. Bestudding
entry.def: To set or adorn, as with studs or bosses; to set thickly; to stud; as, to bestud with stars.

entry.ety: AS. beswīcan; be- + swīcan to deceive, entice; akin to OS. swīkan, OHG. swīhhan, Icel. svīkja
entry.def: To lure; to cheat.

entry.ety: Prob. from OE. abet abetting, OF. abet, fr. abeter to excite, incite. See Abet
entry.def: That which is laid, staked, or pledged, as between two parties, upon the event of a contest or any contingent issue; the act of giving such a pledge; a wager.
entry.q: Having made hisbets.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bet Betted; p. pr. & vb. n. Betting
entry.def: To stake or pledge upon the event of a contingent issue; to wager.
entry.q: John a Gaunt loved him well, and betted much money on his head.
I'll bet you two to one I'll make him do it.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Beat.

cs.cd: to go fast; to hurry.

entry.def: An early form of Better.

entry.note: BetaB, β) is used variously for classifying, as: Astron To designate some bright star, usually the second brightest, of a constellation, as, β Aurigæ. Chem To distinguish one of two or more isomers; also, to indicate the position of substituting atoms or groups in certain compounds; as, β-naphthol. With acids, it commonly indicates that the substituent is in union with the carbon atom next to that to which the carboxyl group is attached.
entry.ety: Gr. bh^ta
entry.def: The second letter of the Greek alphabet, B, β. See B, and cf. etymology of Alphabet.
Excessive or extended use of the b sound in speech, due to conversion of other sounds into it, as through inability to distinguish them from b, or because of difficulty in pronouncing them.

entry.ety: From beta, generic name of the beet
entry.def: A nitrogenous base, C5H11NO2, produced artificially, and also occurring naturally in beet-root molasses and its residues, from which it is extracted as a white crystalline substance; -- called also lycine and oxyneurine. It has a sweetish taste.

entry.vmorph: imp. Betook; p. p. Betaken; p. pr. & vb. n. Betaking
entry.ety: Pref. be- + take

sn.def: To take or seize.
To have recourse to; to apply; to resort; to go; -- with a reflexive pronoun.
sn.q: They betook themselves to treaty and submission.
The rest, in imitation, to like armsBetook them.
Whither shall I betake me, where subsist?

sn.def: To commend or intrust to; to commit to.

entries.entry: Be"ta rays. Physics a form of ionizing radiation emitted by radioactive substances (such as radium), more penetrating than alpha rays, and consisting of negatively charged electrons. The electrons are the same kind of particle as those of cathode rays, but have much higher velocities (about 35,000 to 180,000 miles per second). They are readily deflected by a magnetic or electric field.

entry.def: a type of particle accelerator which accelerates a continuous beam of electrons to high speeds by means of the electric field produced by changing magnetic flux.

entries.entry:
Be*taught" b�*t�t",a. p. p. of OE. bitechen, AS. betǣcan, to assign, deliver. See Teach
Delivered; committed in trust. Obs

entry.def: To better; to mend. See Beete.

entry.ety: Pg. beatilha
entry.def: An East India muslin, formerly used for cravats, veils, etc.

entry.ety: Pref. be- + an old verb teem to be fitting; cf. D. betamen to beseem, G. ziemen, Goth. gatiman, and E. tame. See Tame a.

sn.def: To give ; to bestow; to grant; to accord; to consent.
To allow; to permit; to suffer.
sn.q: So loving to my mother, That he might not beteem the winds of heaven Visit her face too roughly.

entry.ety: Pg., fr. Tamil veṭṭilei, prop. meaning, a mere leaf
entry.def: A species of pepper (Piper betle), the leaves of which are chewed, with the areca or betel nut and a little shell lime, by the inhabitants of the East Indies. It is a woody climber with ovate many-nerved leaves.

entry.ety: F. Bételgeuse, of Arabic origin
entry.def: A bright star of the first magnitude, near one shoulder of Orion.

entries.entry: Be"tel nut`. The nutlike seed of the areca palm, chewed in the East with betel leaves (whence its name) and shell lime.
Bête" noire" Bête" noire". Fr., lit. black beast Something especially hated or dreaded; a bugbear.

entry.def: the 2nd letter of the Hebrew alphabet.

entries.entry: Beth*ab"a*ra wood`. Bot A highly elastic wood, used for fishing rods, etc. The tree is unknown, but it is thought to be East Indian.

entry.ety: Heb. bēth-el house of God

sn.def: A place of worship; a hallowed spot.
A chapel for dissenters.
A house of worship for seamen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bethought; p. pr. & vb. n. Bethinking
entry.ety: AS. beþencan; pref. be- + þencan to think. See Think
entry.def: To call to mind; to recall or bring to recollection, reflection, or consideration; to think; to consider; -- generally followed by a reflexive pronoun, often with of or that before the subject of thought.
entry.q: I have bethought me of another fault.
The rest . . . may . . . bethink themselves, and recover.
We bethink a means to break it off.

entry.def: To think; to recollect; to consider.
entry.q: Bethinkere thou dismiss us.

entry.ety: Heb. bēth-lekhem house of food; bēth house + lekhem food, lākham to eat. Formerly the name of a hospital for the insane, in London, which had been the priory of St. Mary of Bethlehem. Cf. Bedlam

sn.def: A hospital for lunatics; -- corrupted into bedlam.
In the Ethiopic church, a small building attached to a church edifice, in which the bread for the eucharist is made.
An inhabitant of Bethlehem in Judea.
An insane person; a madman; a bedlamite.
One of an extinct English order of monks.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Bethink.
To reduce to thralldom; to inthrall.
To handle; to wear or soil by handling; as books.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bethumped, or Bethumpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Bethumping
entry.def: To beat or thump soundly.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Betided Obs. Betid; p. pr. & vb. n. Betiding
entry.ety: OE. bitiden; pref. bi- be- + tiden, fr. AS. tīdan, to happen, fr. tīd time. See Tide
entry.def: To happen to; to befall; to come to ; as, woe betide the wanderer.
entry.q: What will betide the few ?

entry.note: ☞ Shakespeare has used it with of. “What would betide of me ?”
entry.def: To come to pass; to happen; to occur.
entry.q: A salve for any sore that may betide.

entry.ety: Pref. be-for by) + time; that is, by the proper time. The -s is an adverbial ending

sn.def: In good season or time; before it is late; seasonably; early.
sn.q: To measure life learn thou betimes.
To rise betimes is often harder than to do all the day's work.

sn.def: In a short time; soon; speedily; forth with.
sn.q: He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes.

entry.def: To furnish with a title or titles; to entitle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Betokened; p. pr. & vb. n. Betokening

sn.def: To signify by some visible object; to show by signs or tokens.
sn.q: A dewy cloud, and in the cloud a bow . . . Betokening peace from God, and covenant new.

sn.def: To foreshow by present signs; to indicate something future by that which is seen or known; as, a dark cloud often betokens a storm.
sn.syn: To presage; portend; indicate; mark; note.

entry.ety: F. béton, fr. L. bitumen bitumen
entry.def: The French name for concrete; hence, concrete made after the French fashion.
To attack with the tongue; to abuse; to insult.

entries.entry:
Bet"o*ny ☞ The purple or wood betony (Betonica officinalis, Linn.) is common in Europe, being formerly used in medicine, and (according to Loudon) in dyeing wool a yellow color. n.; pl.Betonies. OE. betony betany, F. betoine, fr. L. betonica vettonica
Bot A plant of the genus BetonicaLinn.).

entry.def: imp. of Betake.
Torn in pieces; tattered.
To put in violent motion; to agitate; to disturb; to toss.
entry.q: Mybetossedsoul.

sn.def: To draw into, or catch in, a trap; to insnare; to circumvent.
To put trappings on; to clothe; to deck.
sn.q: After them followed two other chariots covered with red satin, and the horses betrapped with the same.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Betrayed -trād"; p. pr. & vb. n. Betraying
entry.ety: OE. betraien bitraien; pref. be- + OF. traïr to betray, F. trahir, fr. L. tradere. See Traitor

sn.def: To deliver into the hands of an enemy by treachery or fraud, in violation of trust; to give up treacherously or faithlessly; as, an officer betrayed the city.
sn.q: Jesus said unto them, The Son of man shall be betrayed into the hands of men.

sn.def: To prove faithless or treacherous to, as to a trust or one who trusts; to be false to; to deceive; as, to betray a person or a cause.
sn.q: But when I rise, I shall find my legs betraying me.

sn.def: To violate the confidence of, by disclosing a secret, or that which one is bound in honor not to make known.
sn.q: Willing to serve or betray any government for hire.

sn.def: To disclose or discover, as something which prudence would conceal; to reveal unintentionally.
sn.q: Be swift to hear, but cautious of your tongue, lest you betray your ignorance.

sn.def: To mislead; to expose to inconvenience not foreseen to lead into error or sin.
sn.q: Genius . . . often betrays itself into great errors.

sn.def: To lead astray, as a maiden; to seduce (as under promise of marriage) and then abandon.
To show or to indicate; -- said of what is not obvious at first, or would otherwise be concealed.
sn.q: All the names in the country betray great antiquity.

entry.def: The act or the result of betraying.
One who, or that which, betrays.
Betrayal.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Betrimmed; p. pr. & vb. n. Betrimming
entry.def: To set in order; to adorn; to deck, to embellish; to trim.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Betrothed; p. pr. & vb. n. Betrothing
entry.ety: Pref. be- + troth, i. e., truth. See Truth

sn.def: To contract to any one for a marriage; to engage or promise in order to marriage; to affiance; -- used esp. of a woman.
sn.q: He, in the first flower of my freshest age,Betrothed me unto the only heir.
Ay, and we are betrothed.

sn.def: To promise to take (as a future spouse); to plight one's troth to.
sn.q: What man is there that hath betrothed a wife, and hath not taken her?

sn.def: To nominate to a bishopric, in order to consecration.

entry.def: The act of betrothing, or the fact of being betrothed; a mutual promise, engagement, or contract for a future marriage between the persons betrothed; betrothment; affiance.
entry.q: The feast ofbetrothal.

entry.def: The act of betrothing, or the state of being betrothed; betrothal.
To trust or intrust.
The act of intrusting, or the thing intrusted.

entry.ety: It. bezzo
entry.def: A small brass Venetian coin.

entries.entry:
Bet"ter
All the better. See under All adv.
Better half an expression used to designate one's wife. My dear, my better half (said he), I find I must now leave thee. Sir P. Sidney. To be better off to be in a better condition. Had better. See under Had). The phrase had better, followed by an infinitive without to, is idiomatic. The earliest form of construction was “were better” with a dative; as, “Him were better go beside.” (Gower.i. e., It would be better for him, etc. At length the nominative (I, he, they, etc.) supplanted the dative and had took the place of were. Thus we have the construction now used. By all that's holy, he had better starve Than but once think this place becomes thee not. Shak.
a.; compar. of Good. OE. betere bettre, and as adv. bet, AS. betera, adj., and bet, adv.; akin to Icel. betri, adj., betr, adv., Goth. batiza, adj., OHG. bezziro, adj., baz, adv., G. besser, adj. and adv., bass, adv., E. boot, and prob. to Skr. bhadra excellent. See Boot advantage, and cf. Best Batful
Having good qualities in a greater degree than another; as, a better man; a better physician; a better house; a better air. Could make the worse appear The better reason.
Preferable in regard to rank, value, use, fitness, acceptableness, safety, or in any other respect. To obey is better than sacrifice. It is better to trust in the Lord than to put confidence in princes.
Greater in amount; larger; more.
Improved in health; less affected with disease; as, the patient is better .
More advanced; more perfect; as, upon better acquaintance; a better knowledge of the subject.

entry.cs: For the better in the way of improvement; so as to produce improvement. “If I have altered him anywhere for the better.” Dryden.

sn.def: Advantage, superiority, or victory; -- usually with of; as, to get the better of an enemy.
One who has a claim to precedence; a superior, as in merit, social standing, etc.; -- usually in the plural.
sn.q: Their betters would hardly be found.

entries.entry:
Bet"ter
To think better ofany one), to have a more favorable opinion of any one. To think better ofan opinion, resolution, etc.), to reconsider and alter one's decision.
adv.; compar. of Well. In a superior or more excellent manner; with more skill and wisdom, courage, virtue, advantage, or success; as, Henry writes better than John; veterans fight better than recruits. I could have better spared a better man.
More correctly or thoroughly. The better to understand the extent of our knowledge.
In a higher or greater degree; more; as, to love one better than another. Never was monarch better feared, and loved.
More, in reference to value, distance, time, etc.; as, ten miles and better . Colloq

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bettered; p. pr. & vb. n. Bettering
entry.ety: AS. beterian betrian, fr. betera better. See Better a.

sn.def: To improve or ameliorate; to increase the good qualities of.
sn.q: Love betters what is best.
He thought to better his circumstances.

sn.def: To improve the condition of, morally, physically, financially, socially, or otherwise.
sn.q: The constant effort of every man to better himself.

sn.def: To surpass in excellence; to exceed; to excel.
sn.q: The works of nature do always aim at that which can not be bettered.

sn.def: To give advantage to; to support; to advance the interest of.
sn.q: Weapons more violent, when next we meet, May serve to better us and worse our foes.
sn.syn: To improve; meliorate; ameliorate; mend; amend; correct; emend; reform; advance; promote.

entry.def: To become better; to improve.
One who bets or lays a wager.

entries.entry: bettering adj. changing for the better; -- antonym of worsening.Narrower terms: ameliorating(prenominal), ameliorative, amelioratory, meliorative

entry.def: more familiar or renowned than the other of two. Antonym of lesser-known.
entry.illu: the better known book of the two

entry.def: more pleasing in appearance especially by reason of conformity to ideals of form and proportion.

sn.def: A making better; amendment; improvement.
An improvement of an estate which renders it better than mere repairing would do; -- generally used in the plural.

entry.def: Best.
entry.q: Thebettermostclasses.

sn.def: The quality of being better or superior; superiority.
The difference by which fine gold or silver exceeds in fineness the standard.
in a more fortunate condition.
sn.illu: she would have been better off if she had stuck to her Bible

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A small, leaping Australian marsupial of the genus Bettongia; the jerboa kangaroo.
a genus of marsupials including the jerboa kangaroo, the bettong.
One who bets; a better.

sn.ety: Supposed to be a cant word, from Betty, for Elizabeth, as such an instrument is also called Bessi. e., Elizabeth) in the Canting Dictionary of 1725, and Jennyi. e., Jane)
sn.def: A short bar used by thieves to wrench doors open.
sn.q: The powerful betty, or the artful picklock.

sn.def: A name of contempt given to a man who interferes with the duties of women in a household, or who occupies himself with womanish matters.
A pear-shaped bottle covered round with straw, in which olive oil is sometimes brought from Italy; -- called by chemists a Florence flask.
a natural family of monoecious trees and shrubs, including the genera Betula; Alnus; Carpinus; Corylus; Ostrya; and Ostryopsis.

entry.ety: L. betula birch tree
entry.def: a term originally applied to a substance obtained as a resin or tar by extraction from the outer bark of the common European white birch (Betula alba); now referring to the chemical compound (C30H50O2) having a cyclopentanophenanthrene ring system, which is the main constituent of that extract, and which may be obtained crystalline; -- called also birch camphor.
To throw into disorder; to tumble.
entry.q: From her betumbled couch she starteth.

entry.def: To tutor; to instruct.

cs.cd: the space, or in the space, between the decks of a vessel.
in confidence; with the understanding that the matter is not to be communicated to others.

entry.usage: Between etymologically indicates only two; as, a quarrel between two men or two nations; to be between two fires, etc. It is however extended to more than two in expressing a certain relation.I . . . hope that between public business, improving studies, and domestic pleasures, neither melancholy nor caprice will find any place for entrance. Johnson. Among implies a mass or collection of things or persons, and always supposes more than two; as, the prize money was equally divided among the ship's crew.
entry.ety: OE. bytwene bitweonen, AS. betweónan betweónum; prefix be- by + a form fr. AS. twā two, akin to Goth. tweihnai two apiece. See Twain, and cf. Atween Betwixt

sn.def: In the space which separates; betwixt; as, New York is between Boston and Philadelphia.
Used in expressing motion from one body or place to another; from one to another of two.
sn.q: If things should go so between them.

sn.def: Belonging in common to two; shared by both.
sn.q: Castor and Pollux with only one soul between them.

sn.def: Belonging to, or participated in by, two, and involving reciprocal action or affecting their mutual relation; as, opposition between science and religion.
sn.q: An intestine struggle, open or secret, between authority and liberty.

sn.def: With relation to two, as involved in an act or attribute of which another is the agent or subject; as, to judge between or to choose between courses; to distinguish between you and me; to mediate between nations.
In intermediate relation to, in respect to time, quantity, or degree; as, between nine and ten o'clock.

entry.def: Intermediate time or space; interval.

cs.cd: in a midway position; so-so; neither one thing nor the other.

entry.ety: OE. betwix bitwix, rarely bitwixt, AS. betweox betweohs betweoh betwīh; pref. be- by + a form fr. AS. twā two. See Between

sn.def: In the space which separates; between.
sn.q: From betwixt two aged oaks.

sn.def: From one to another of; mutually affecting.
sn.q: There was some speech of marriageBetwixt myself and her.

entry.ety: F., fr. beurre butter
entry.def: A beurré (or buttery) pear, one with the meat soft and melting; -- used with a distinguishing word; as, Beurré d'Anjou; Beurré Clairgeau.
a particle accelerator which is capable of accelerating protons up to 6 gigaeletron volts.

entry.ety: C. F. biveau, earlier buveau, Sp. baivel; of unknown origin. Cf. Bevile

sn.def: Any angle other than a right angle; the angle which one surface makes with another when they are not at right angles; the slant or inclination of such surface; as, to give a bevel to the edge of a table or a stone slab; the bevel of a piece of timber.

An instrument consisting of two rules or arms, jointed together at one end, and opening to any angle, for adjusting the surfaces of work to the same or a given inclination; -- called also a bevel square.

cs.cd: any angle other than one of 90°.
a cogwheel whose working face is oblique to the axis.

sn.def: Having the slant of a bevel; slanting.
Hence: Morally distorted; not upright.
sn.q: I may be straight, though they themselves be bevel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Beveled�) or Bevelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Beveling or Bevelling
entry.def: To cut to a bevel angle; to slope the edge or surface of.
To deviate or incline from an angle of 90°, as a surface; to slant.
entry.q: Their houses are very ill built, the walls bevel.

sn.def: Formed to a bevel angle; sloping; as, the beveled edge of a table.
Replaced by two planes inclining equally upon the adjacent planes, as an edge; having its edges replaced by sloping planes, as a cube or other solid.

entries.entry: Bev"el gear`. Mech A kind of gear in which the two wheels working together lie in different planes, and have their teeth cut at right angles to the surfaces of two cones whose apices coincide with the point where the axes of the wheels would meet.

entry.def: The replacement of an edge by two similar planes, equally inclined to the including faces or adjacent planes.

entry.ety: OE. bever a drink, drinking time, OF. beivre boivre, to drink, fr. L. bibere
entry.def: A light repast between meals; a lunch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bevered�)
entry.def: To take a light repast between meals.

entry.ety: OF. bevrage, F. breuvage, fr. beivre to drink, fr. L. bibere. Cf. Bib v. t. Poison Potable

sn.def: Liquid for drinking; drink; -- usually applied to drink artificially prepared and of an agreeable flavor; as, an intoxicating beverage .
sn.q: He knew no beverage but the flowing stream.

sn.def: Specifically, a name applied to various kinds of drink.
A treat, or drink money.

entry.ety: See Bevel
entry.def: A chief broken or opening like a carpenter's bevel.
Notched with an angle like that inclosed by a carpenter's bevel; -- said of a partition line of a shield.

entries.entry:
Bev"y n.; pl.Bevies. Perhaps orig. a drinking company, fr. OF. bevéecf. It. beva) a drink, beverage; then, perh., a company in general, esp. of ladies; and last applied by sportsmen to larks, quails, etc. See Beverage
A company; an assembly or collection of persons, especially of ladies. What a bevy of beaten slaves have we here !
A flock of birds, especially quails or larks; also, a herd of roes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bewailed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bewailing
entry.def: To express deep sorrow for, as by wailing; to lament; to wail over.
entry.q: Hath widowed and unchilded many a one, Which to this hour bewail the injury.

entry.def: To express grief; to lament.
Such as may, or ought to, be bewailed; lamentable.
One who bewails or laments.
Wailing over; lamenting.
The act of bewailing.
To keep watch over; to keep awake.

entry.note: ☞ This word is a compound from be and the Old English ware, now wary, which is an adjective. “Be ye war of false prophetis.” Wyclif, Matt. vii. 15. It is used commonly in the imperative and infinitive modes, and with such auxiliaries (shall should must, etc.) as go with the infinitive.
entry.ety: Be, imperative of verb to be + ware. See Ware Wary

sn.def: To be on one's guard; to be cautious; to take care; -- commonly followed by of or lest before the thing that is to be avoided.
sn.q: Beware of all, but most beware of man !
Beware the awful avalanche.

sn.def: To have a special regard; to heed.
sn.q: Behold, I send an Angel before thee. . . . Beware of him, and obey his voice.

entry.def: To avoid; to take care of; to have a care for.
entry.q: Priest,bewareyour beard.
To wish them beware the son.

entry.def: To drench or souse with water.
entry.q: Let the maidsbewashthe men.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bewept; p. pr. & vb. n. Beweeping
entry.ety: AS. bew�pan; pref. be- + weep
entry.def: To weep over; to deplore; to bedew with tears.
entry.q: His timeless deathbeweeping.

entry.def: To weep.
To wet or moisten.

sn.def: To corrupt with regard to chastity; to make a whore of.
To pronounce or characterize as a whore.

entry.def: To cover (the head) with a wig.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bewildered; p. pr. & vb. n. Bewildering
entry.ety: Pref. be- + wilder
entry.def: To lead into perplexity or confusion, as for lack of a plain path; to perplex with mazes; or in general, to perplex or confuse greatly.
entry.q: Lost and bewildered in the fruitless search.
entry.syn: To perplex; puzzle; entangle; confuse; confound; mystify; embarrass; lead astray.

entry.def: Greatly perplexed; as, a bewildered mind.
The state of being bewildered; bewilderment.
Causing bewilderment or great perplexity; as, bewildering difficulties.

sn.def: The state of being bewildered.
A bewildering tangle or confusion.
sn.q: He . . . soon lost all traces of it amid bewilderment of tree trunks and underbrush.

entry.def: To make wintry.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. buie bond, chain, fr. L. boja neck collar, fetter. Cf. Buoy
entry.def: A double slip of leather by which bells are fastened to a hawk's legs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bewitched; p. pr. & vb. n. Bewitching

sn.def: To gain an ascendency over by charms or incantations; to affect (esp. to injure) by witchcraft or sorcery.
sn.q: See how I am bewitched; behold, mine arm Is like a blasted sapling withered up.

sn.def: To charm; to fascinate; to please to such a degree as to take away the power of resistance; to enchant.
sn.q: The charms of poetry our souls bewitch.

entry.def: The state of being bewitched.
One who bewitches.
The power of bewitching or fascinating; bewitchment; charm; fascination.
entry.q: There is a certain bewitchery or fascination in words.

entry.def: Having power to bewitch or fascinate; enchanting; captivating; charming.

sn.def: The act of bewitching, or the state of being bewitched.
The power of bewitching or charming.
To fill with wonder.
To wonder at; to admire.

entry.def: To wrap up; to cover.
To soil. See Beray.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bewrayed -rād"; p. pr. & vb. n. Bewraying
entry.ety: OE. bewraien biwreyen; pref. be- + AS. wrēgan to accuse, betray; akin to OS. wrōgian, OHG. ruogēn, G. rügen, Icel. rægja, Goth. wrōhjan to accuse
entry.def: To expose; to reveal; to disclose; to betray.
entry.q: The murder being once done, he is in less fear, and in more hope that the deed shall not be bewrayed or known.
Thy speech bewrayeth thee.

entry.def: One who, or that which, bewrays; a revealer.
Betrayal.
To wreck.

entry.ety: Pref. be- + wreak
entry.def: To wreak; to avenge.

entry.ety: Pref. be- + wrought, p. p. of work, v. t.
entry.def: Embroidered.

entry.ety: See Beg a bey
entry.def: A governor of a province or district in the Turkish dominions; also, in some places, a prince or nobleman; a beg; as, the bey of Tunis.

entry.ety: Turk
entry.def: The territory ruled by a bey.

entry.cs: Beyond sea. Law See under Sea. To go beyond to exceed in ingenuity, in research, or in anything else; hence, in a bed sense, to deceive or circumvent.
entry.ety: OE. biyonde biȝeonde, AS. begeondan, prep. and adv.; pref. be- + geond yond, yonder. See Yon Yonder

sn.def: On the further side of; in the same direction as, and further on or away than.
sn.q: Beyond that flaming hill.

sn.def: At a place or time not yet reached; before.
sn.q: A thing beyond us, even before our death.

sn.def: Past, out of the reach or sphere of; further than; greater than; as, the patient was beyond medical aid; beyond one's strength.
In a degree or amount exceeding or surpassing; proceeding to a greater degree than; above, as in dignity, excellence, or quality of any kind.
sn.q: Beyondexpectation.
Beyond any of the great men of my country.
That no man go beyond and defraud his brother in any matter.

entry.def: Further away; at a distance; yonder.
entry.q: Lo, where beyond he lyeth languishing.

entry.ety: See Byzant

sn.def: A gold coin of Byzantium or Constantinople, varying in weight and value, usually (those current in England) between a sovereign and a half sovereign. There were also white or silver bezants.
A circle in or, i. e., gold, representing the gold coin called bezant.
A decoration of a flat surface, as of a band or belt, representing circular disks lapping one upon another.

entry.ety: L. bis twice (OF. bes) + E. antler
entry.def: The second branch of a stag's horn.

entry.ety: From an old form of F. biseau sloping edge, prob. fr. L. bis double. See Bi-
entry.def: The rim which encompasses and fastens a jewel or other object, as the crystal of a watch, in the cavity in which it is set.

entry.ety: F. bésigue
entry.def: A game at cards in which various combinations of cards in the hand, when declared, score points.

entry.note: ☞ Two kinds were particularly esteemed, the Bezoar orientale of India, and the Bezoar occidentale of Peru.
entry.cs: Bezoar antelope. See Antelope. Bezoar goat Zoöl the wild goat (Capra ægagrus). Bezoar mineral an old preparation of oxide of antimony. Ure.
entry.ety: F. bézoard, fr. Ar. bāzahr bādizahr, fr. Per. pād-zahr bezoar; pād protecting + zahr poison; cf. Pg. & Sp. bezoar
entry.def: A calculous concretion found in the intestines of certain ruminant animals (as the wild goat, the gazelle, and the Peruvian llama) formerly regarded as an unfailing antidote for poison, and a certain remedy for eruptive, pestilential, or putrid diseases. Hence: Any antidote or panacea.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bézoardique bézoartique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or compounded with, bezoar.

def2.def: A medicine containing bezoar.

entry.ety: See Bezoardic
entry.def: Having the qualities of an antidote, or of bezoar; healing.

entry.ety: Cf. F. besoin need, want, It bisogno
entry.def: A low fellow or scoundrel; a beggar.
entry.q: Great men oft die by vile bezonians.

entry.ety: Russ.; bez without + popovtsy, a derivative of pop priest
entry.def: A Russian sect. See Raskolnik.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bezzled; p. pr. & vb. n. Bezzling
entry.ety: OF. besillier besiler, to maltreat, pillage; or shortened fr. embezzle. Cf. Embezzle
entry.def: To plunder; to waste in riot.
To drink to excess; to revel.

sn.def: a woman employed by a bar to act as a companion to men customers.

entry.ety: Per. bang; cf. Skr. bhangā hemp
entry.def: An astringent and narcotic drug made from the dried leaves and seed capsules of wild hemp (Cannabis Indica), and chewed or smoked in the East as a means of intoxication. See Hasheesh.

entry.ety: Per. bihishtī lit., heavenly
entry.def: A water carrier, as to a household or a regiment.
Same as Bheesty.
that layer of soil in a well-developed soil lying immediately below the A-horizon, and which contains deposits of organic matter leached from surface soils.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: An Indian monkey (Macacus Rhesus), protected by the Hindus as sacred. See Rhesus.
a principality in the Himalayas northeast of India.
a native or inhabitant of Bhutan.
of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Bhutan.

sn.def: of or pertaining to the Bhutani language or people.
of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Bhutan.

entry.def: a native or inhabitant of Bhutan.

entries.entry:
Bi-. L. bis twice, which in composition drops the -s, akin to E. two. See Bis- Two, and cf. Di- Dis-
In most branches of science bi- in composition denotes two, twice, or doubly; as, bidentate, two-toothed; biternate, doubly ternate, etc.
Chem In the composition of chemical names bi- denotes two atoms, parts, or equivalents of that constituent to the name of which it is prefixed, to one of the other component, or that such constituent is present in double the ordinary proportion; as, bichromate, bisulphide. Be- and di- are often used interchangeably.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + acid
entry.def: Having two hydrogen atoms which can be replaced by negative atoms or radicals to form salts; -- said of bases. See Diacid.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + acuminate
entry.def: Having points in two directions.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + angular
entry.def: Having two angles or corners.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + angulate angulated
entry.def: Biangular.

entries.entry:
Bi*an"gu*lous,a. Pref. bi- + angulous
Biangular. R

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + annual
entry.def: Occurring twice a year; half-yearly; semiannual.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + antherigerous
entry.def: Having two anthers.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + articulate
entry.def: Having, or consisting of, tow joints.

entries.entry:
Bi"as bī"�s n.; pl.Biases -ĕz. F. biasis, perh. fr. LL. bifax two-faced; L. bis + facies face. See Bi-, and cf. Face
A weight on the side of the ball used in the game of bowls, or a tendency imparted to the ball, which turns it from a straight line. Being ignorant that there is a concealed bias within the spheroid, which will . . . swerve away.
A leaning of the mind; propensity or prepossession toward an object or view, not leaving the mind indifferent; bent; inclination. Strong love is a bias upon the thoughts. Morality influences men's lives, and gives a bias to all their actions.
A wedge-shaped piece of cloth taken out of a garment (as the waist of a dress) to diminish its circumference.
A slant; a diagonal; as, to cut cloth on the bias . Prepossession; prejudice; partiality; inclination. See Bent.

sn.def: Inclined to one side; swelled on one side.
Cut slanting or diagonally, as cloth.

entry.def: In a slanting manner; crosswise; obliquely; diagonally; as, to cut cloth bias .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Biased bī"�st; p. pr. & vb. n. Biasing
entry.def: To incline to one side; to give a particular direction to; to influence; to prejudice; to prepossess.
entry.q: Me it had not biased in the one direction, nor should it have biased any just critic in the counter direction.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + auriculate

sn.def: Having two auricles, as the heart of mammals, birds, and reptiles.
Having two earlike projections at its base, as a leaf.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + axal axial
entry.def: Having two axes; as, biaxial polarization; biaxial crystals.

entry.ety: From Bib, v., because the bib receives the drink that the child slavers from the mouth

sn.def: A small piece of cloth worn by children over the breast, to protect the clothes.
An arctic fish (Gadus luscus), allied to the cod; -- called also pout and whiting pout.
A bibcock.

entry.ety: L. bibere. See Beverage, and cf. Imbibe
entry.def: To drink; to tipple.
entry.q: This miller hath . . . bibbed ale.

entry.def: To drink; to sip; to tipple.
entry.q: He was constantly bibbing.

entry.ety: L. bibax bibacis, fr. bibere. See Bib
entry.def: Addicted to drinking.
The practice or habit of drinking too much; tippling.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + basic
entry.def: Having to hydrogen atoms which can be replaced by positive or basic atoms or radicals to form salts; -- said of acids. See Dibasic.
A bibcock. See Bib n., 3.
One given to drinking alcoholic beverages too freely; a tippler; -- chiefly used in composition; as, winebibber .

entry.ety: A reduplication of babble
entry.def: Idle talk; babble.
Pieces of timber bolted to certain parts of a mast to support the trestletrees.
A cock or faucet having a bent down nozzle.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A small decorative object without practical utility.
entry.q: Her pictures, her furniture, and her bibelots.

entry.def: See Bebeerine.
Of or pertaining to drinking or tippling.

entry.cs: Bible Society an association for securing the multiplication and wide distribution of the Bible. Douay Bible. See Douay Bible. Geneva Bible. See under Geneva.
entry.ety: F. bible, L. biblia, pl., fr. Gr. bibli`a, pl. of bibli`on, dim. of bi`blos by`blos, book, prop. Egyptian papyrus

sn.def: A book.

The Book by way of eminence, -- that is, the book which is made up of the writings accepted by Christians as of divine origin and authority, whether such writings be in the original language, or translated; the Scriptures of the Old and New Testaments; -- sometimes in a restricted sense, the Old Testament; as, King James's Bible; Douay Bible; Luther's Bible . Also, the book which is made up of writings similarly accepted by the Jews; as, a rabbinical Bible .
A book containing the sacred writings belonging to any religion; as, the Koran is often called the Mohammedan Bible .
a book with an authoritative exposition of some topic, respected by many who are experts in the field.

entry.ety: See Bib v. t.
entry.def: A great drinker; a tippler.
lacking a bib.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the Bible; as, biblical learning; biblical authority.
The quality of being biblical; a biblical subject.
According to the Bible.

entry.ety: Cf. F. biblicisme
entry.def: Learning or literature relating to the Bible.
One skilled in the knowledge of the Bible; a demonstrator of religious truth by the Scriptures.
Bibliographer.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � book + � to write : cf. F. bibliographe
entry.def: One who writes, or is versed in, bibliography.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bibliographique
entry.def: Pertaining to bibliography, or the history of books.

entries.entry:
Bib`li*og"ra*phy bĭb`lĭ*ŏg"rȧ*f� n.; pl.Bibliographies. Gr. bibliografi`a: cf. F. bibliographie
a history or description of books and manuscripts, with notices of the different editions, the times when they were printed, etc.
a list of books or other printed works having some common theme, such as topic, period, author, or publisher.
a list of the published (and sometimes unpublished) sources of information referred to in a scholarly discourse or other text, or used as reference materials for its preparation.
the branch of library science dealing with the history and classification of books and other published materials.

entry.ety: See. Bibliolatry
entry.def: A worshiper of books; especially, a worshiper of the Bible; a believer in its verbal inspiration.

entry.ety: Gr. bibli`on book + latrei`a service, worship, latrey`ein to serve
entry.def: Book worship, esp. of the Bible; -- applied by Roman Catholic divines to the exaltation of the authority of the Bible over that of the pope or the church, and by Protestants to an excessive regard to the letter of the Scriptures.
Relating to bibliology.

entry.ety: Gr. � book + -logy

sn.def: An account of books; book lore; bibliography.
The literature or doctrine of the Bible.

entry.ety: Gr. � book + -mancy: cf. F. bibliomancie
entry.def: A kind of divination, performed by selecting passages of Scripture at hazard, and drawing from them indications concerning future events.

entry.ety: Gr. � book + � madness: cf. F. bibliomanie
entry.def: A mania for acquiring books.
One who has a mania for books.

def2.def: Relating to a bibliomaniac.

entry.def: Pertaining to a passion for books; relating to a bibliomaniac.

entry.ety: Gr. bibli`on book + phgny`naito make fast
entry.def: Relating to the binding of books.
A bookbinder.
Pertaining to the art of binding books.

entry.ety: See Bibliopegic
entry.def: The art of binding books.

entry.ety: Gr. � book + � to love: cf. F. bibliophile
entry.def: A lover of books.
Love of books.
A lover of books.

entry.ety: Gr. � book + � to fear
entry.def: A dread of books.

entry.ety: L. bibliopola, Gr. �; � book + � to sell: cf. F. bibliopole
entry.def: One who sells books.

entry.ety: See Bibliopole
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the sale of books.
entry.q: Bibliopolicdifficulties.

entry.def: The trade or business of selling books.
Same as Bibliopole.
Of or pertaining to bibliopolism.

entry.ety: Gr. � book + � a burial
entry.def: One who hides away books, as in a tomb.
A librarian.

entry.ety: L. See Bibliotheke
entry.def: A library.

entry.ety: L. bibliothecalis. See Bibliotheke
entry.def: Belonging to a library.

entry.ety: L. bibliothecarius: cf. F. bibliothécaire
entry.def: A librarian.

entry.ety: L. bibliotheca, Gr. �; � book + � a case, box, fr. � to place: cf. F. bibliothèque
entry.def: A library.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bibliste. See Bible

sn.def: One who makes the Bible the sole rule of faith.
A biblical scholar; a biblicist.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + bracteate
entry.def: Furnished with, or having, two bracts.

entry.ety: L. bibulus, fr. bibere to drink. See Bib v. t.

sn.def: Readily imbibing fluids or moisture; spongy; as, bibulous blotting paper.
Inclined to drink; addicted to tippling.

entry.def: In a bibulous manner; with profuse imbibition or absorption.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + calcarate
entry.def: Having two spurs, as the wing or leg of a bird.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + callose callous
entry.def: Having two callosities or hard spots.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + camera
entry.def: Consisting of, or including, two chambers, or legislative branches.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + capsular: cf. F. bicapsulaire
entry.def: Having two capsules; as, a bicapsular pericarp.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + carbonate
entry.def: A carbonate in which but half the hydrogen of the acid is replaced by a positive element or radical, thus making the proportion of the acid to the positive or basic portion twice what it is in the normal carbonates; an acid carbonate; -- sometimes called supercarbonate.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + carbureted
entry.def: Containing two atoms or equivalents of carbon in the molecule.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + carinate
entry.def: Having two keel-like projections, as the upper palea of grasses.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + caudal
entry.def: Having, or terminating in, two tails.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + caudate
entry.def: Two-tailed; bicaudal.

cs.cd: pecked, or notched, bones; dice.

entry.ety: Of unknown origin
entry.def: Pecked; pitted; notched.

cs.cd: is prepared from the blue, by adding yellow orpiment, or by grinding down the green carbonate of copper.

entry.ety: F. bis, akin to It. bigio light gray, tawny
entry.def: A pale blue pigment, prepared from the native blue carbonate of copper, or from smalt; -- called also blue bice.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + centenary
entry.def: Of or pertaining to two hundred, esp. to two hundred years; as, a bicentenary celebration.

def2.def: The two hundredth anniversary, or its celebration.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + centennial

sn.def: Consisting of two hundred years.
Occurring every two hundred years.

entry.def: The two hundredth year or anniversary, or its celebration.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + cephalous: cf. F. bicéphale
entry.def: Having two heads.

entry.ety: L., two-headed; bis twice + caput head. See Capital
entry.def: A muscle having two heads or origins; -- applied particularly to a flexor in the arm, and to another in the thigh.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A remarkable ganoid fish (Polypterus bichir) found in the Nile and other African rivers. See Brachioganoidei.

cs.cd: mercuric chloride; -- sometimes called corrosive sublimate.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + chloride
entry.def: A compound consisting of two atoms of chlorine with one or more atoms of another element; -- called also dichloride.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: See Jigger.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + chromate
entry.def: A salt containing two parts of chromic acid to one of the other ingredients; as, potassium bichromate ; -- called also dichromate.
To combine or treat with a bichromate, esp. with bichromate of potassium; as, bichromatized gelatine.

sn.def: having two colors.

entry.ety: L. biceps bicipitis: cf. F. bicipital. See Biceps

sd.def: Having two heads or origins, as a muscle.
Pertaining to a biceps muscle; as, bicipital furrows, the depressions on either side of the biceps of the arm.

sn.def: Dividing into two parts at one extremity; having two heads or two supports; as, a bicipital tree.

entry.def: Having two heads; bicipital.
entry.q: Bicipitousserpents.

entry.ety: See Beaker
entry.def: A small wooden vessel made of staves and hoops, like a tub.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bickered; p. pr. & vb. n. Bickering
entry.ety: OE. bikeren, perh. fr. Celtic; cf. W. bicra to fight, bicker, bicre conflict, skirmish; perh. akin to E. beak

sn.def: To skirmish; to exchange blows; to fight.
sn.q: Two eagles had a conflict, and bickered together.

sn.def: To contend in petulant altercation; to wrangle.
sn.q: Petty things about which men cark and bicker.

sn.def: To move quickly and unsteadily, or with a pattering noise; to quiver; to be tremulous, like flame.
sn.q: They [streamletsbickered through the sunny shade.

sn.def: A skirmish; an encounter.
A fight with stones between two parties of boys.
A wrangle; also, a noise,, as in angry contention.

entry.def: One who bickers.

sn.def: A skirmishing.
sn.q: Frays andbickerings.

sn.def: Altercation; wrangling.

entry.def: Contention.

entry.ety: F. bigorne. See Bicorn
entry.def: An anvil ending in a beak or point (orig. in two beaks); also, the beak or horn itself.

entries.entry: Bick"ford fuseorBick"ford fuzeorBickford match . A fuse used in blasting, consisting of a long cylinder of explosive material inclosed in a varnished wrapping of rope or hose. It burns from 2 to 4 feet a minute.

entry.ety: L. bis twice + colligatus, p. p. See Colligate v. t.
entry.def: Having the anterior toes connected by a basal web.

entry.ety: L. bicolor; bis twice + color color
entry.def: Of two colors.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + concave
entry.def: Concave on both sides; as, biconcave vertebræ.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + conjugate, a
entry.def: Twice paired, as when a petiole forks twice.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + convex
entry.def: Convex on both sides; as, a biconvex lens.

entry.ety: L. bicornis; bis twice + cornu horn: cf. F. bicorne. Cf. Bickern
entry.def: Having two horns; two-horned; crescentlike.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + corporal
entry.def: Having two bodies.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + corporate
entry.def: Double-bodied, as a lion having one head and two bodies.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + costate
entry.def: Having two principal ribs running longitudinally, as a leaf.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + crenate
entry.def: Twice crenated, as in the case of leaves whose crenatures are themselves crenate.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + crescent
entry.def: Having the form of a double crescent.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + crural
entry.def: Having two legs.

entry.ety: See pref. Bi-, and Cuspidate
entry.def: Having two points or prominences; ending in two points; -- said of teeth, leaves, fruit, etc.
One of the two double-pointed teeth which intervene between the canines (cuspids) and the molars, on each side of each jaw. See Tooth n.
See Dicyanide.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + cycle
entry.def: A light vehicle having two wheels one behind the other. It has a saddle seat and is propelled by the rider's feet acting on cranks or levers.
One who rides a bicycle.
Relating to bicycles.
The use of a bicycle; the act or practice of riding a bicycle.
The art of riding a bicycle.
A bicycler.
Relating to bicycling.

entry.cs: To bid beads to pray with beads, as the Roman Catholics; to distinguish each bead by a prayer. Obs To bid defiance to , to defy openly; to brave. To bid fair to offer a good prospect; to make fair promise; to seem likely.
entry.vmorph: imp. Bade băd Bid Obs Bad; p. p. Bidden Bid; p. pr. & vb. n. Bidding
entry.ety: OE. bidden, prop to ask, beg, AS. biddan; akin to OS. biddian, Icel. biðja, OHG. bittan, G. bitten, to pray, ask, request, and E. bead, also perh. to Gr. teiqein to persuade, L. fidere to trust, E. faith, and bide. But this word was early confused with OE. beden beoden, AS. beódan, to offer, command; akin to Icel. bjōða, Goth. biudanin comp.), OHG. biotan to command, bid, G. bieten, D. bieden, to offer, also to Gr. pynqa`nesqai to learn by inquiry, Skr. budh to be awake, to heed, present OSlav. budēti to be awake, E. bode, v. The word now has the form of OE. bidden to ask, but the meaning of OE. beden to command, except in “to bid beads.” √30

sn.def: To make an offer of; to propose. Specifically : To offer to pay ( a certain price, as for a thing put up at auction), or to take (a certain price, as for work to be done under a contract).
To offer in words; to declare, as a wish, a greeting, a threat, or defiance, etc.; as, to bid one welcome; to bid good morning, farewell, etc.
sn.q: Neither bid him God speed.
He bids defiance to the gaping crowd.

sn.def: To proclaim; to declare publicly; to make known.
sn.q: Our banns thricebid!

sn.def: To order; to direct; to enjoin; to command.
sn.q: That Power who bids the ocean ebb and flow.
Lord, if it be thou, bid me come unto thee.
I was bid to pick up shells.

sn.def: To invite; to call in; to request to come.
sn.q: As many as ye shall find, bid to the marriage.
sn.syn: To offer; proffer; tender; propose; order; command; direct; charge; enjoin.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Bid.
An offer of a price, especially at auctions; a statement of a sum which one will give for something to be received, or will take for something to be done or furnished; that which is offered.

entry.ety: See Bid v. t.

sn.def: To pray.
To make a bid; to state what one will pay or take.

entry.ety: Bid + ale
entry.def: An invitation of friends to drink ale at some poor man's house, and there to contribute in charity for his relief.

entry.ety: Russ. baidarka, dim. Cf. Baidar
entry.def: A portable boat made of skins stretched on a frame.
Obedient; docile.
p. p. of Bid.

entry.ety: AS. biddere.
entry.def: One who bids or offers a price.

entries.entry:
Bid"der*y ware`. From Beder or Bidar a town in India A kind of metallic ware made in India. The material is a composition of zinc, tin, and lead, in which ornaments of gold and silver are inlaid or damascened.
bidree bedery beder

sn.def: Command; order; a proclamation or notifying.
sn.q: Do thou thy master'sbidding.

sn.def: The act or process of making bids; an offer; a proposal of a price, as at an auction.

entries.entry:

entries.entry: Bie"la's com"et. Astron A periodic coment, discovered by Biela in 1826, which revolves around the sun in 6.6 years. The November meteors (Andromedes or Bielids) move in its orbit, and may be fragments of the comet.

I talked big to them at first.

entry.ety: Cf. Digamist
entry.def: One who is guilty of bigamy.
Guilty of bigamy; involving bigamy; as, a bigamous marriage.

entry.note: ☞ It is not strictly correct to call this offense bigamy: it more properly denominated polygamy, i. e., having a plurality of wives or husbands at once, and in several statutes in the United States the offense is classed under the head of polygamy. In the canon law bigamy was the marrying of two virgins successively, or one after the death of the other, or once marrying a widow. This disqualified a man for orders, and for holding ecclesiastical offices. Shakespeare uses the word in the latter sense.
entry.ety: OE. bigamie, fr. L. bigamus twice married; bis twice + Gr. � marriage; prob. akin to Skt. jāmis related, and L. gemini twins, the root meaning to bind join: cf. F. bigamie. Cf. Digamy
entry.def: The offense of marrying one person when already legally married to another.
entry.q: Base declension and loathed bigamy.

entry.def: New York City; -- a nickname, usually written The Big Apple.

entry.ety: F. bigarreau, fr. bigarré variegated

A band that is the size of an orchestra, usually playing mostly jazz or swing music. The big band typically features both ensemble and solo playing, sometimes has a lead singer, and is often located in a night club where the patrons may dance to its music. The big bands were popular from the late 1920's to the 1940's. Contrasted with combo, which has fewer players.

entry.note: The big bang is likened to a massive explosion from a point containing all of the matter and energy of the beginning universe, which started the expansion and evolution of the universe which continues today. The evidence for such an event includes the apparently expanding size of the present universe, and a background microwave radiation of about 3° Kelvin, equal to that predicted from mathematical models of such an explosive event.
entry.def: The explosive event marking the beginning of the known universe, according to big bang theory; the beginning of time.

The theory that the known universe originated in an explosive event (the big bang) in which all of the matter and energy of the universe was contained in a single point and began to rapidly expand and evolve, starting as high-energy particles and radiation, and, as it cooled over time, evolving into ordinary subatomic particles, atoms, and then stars and galaxies. According to this theory, the four-dimensional space-time continuum which we perceive as our universe continues to expand to the present time, but it is unknown whether the expansion will continue indefinitely or eventually stop or even reverse, possibly leading to a contraction to a single point sometimes referred to as the “big crunch”. The competing “Steady-state Theory” gradually lost favor in the 1980's and 1990's. See also big bang.
Having a great belly; as, a big-bellied man or flagon; advanced in pregnancy.

In an extended sense, a person who is intolerant of opinions which conflict with his own, as in politics or morals; one obstinately and blindly devoted to his own church, party, belief, or opinion.

entry.note: ☞ In the United States, it is usually called a note, a note of hand, or a promissory note.
entry.cs:
Bill of adventure. See under Adventure. Bill of costs a statement of the items which form the total amount of the costs of a party to a suit or action. Bill of credit. Within the constitution of the United States, a paper issued by a State, on the mere faith and credit of the State, and designed to circulate as money. No State shall “emit bills of credit.”
U. S. Const. Peters. Wharton. Bouvier Among merchants, a letter sent by an agent or other person to a merchant, desiring him to give credit to the bearer for goods or money. Bill of divorce in the Jewish law, a writing given by the husband to the wife, by which the marriage relation was dissolved. Jer. iii. 8. Bill of entry a written account of goods entered at the customhouse, whether imported or intended for exportation. Bill of exceptions. See under Exception. Bill of exchange Com a written order or request from one person or house to another, desiring the latter to pay to some person designated a certain sum of money therein generally is, and, to be negotiable, must be, made payable to order or to bearer. So also the order generally expresses a specified time of payment, and that it is drawn for value. The person who draws the bill is called the drawer, the person on whom it is drawn is, before acceptance, called the drawee, -- after acceptance, the acceptor; the person to whom the money is directed to be paid is called the payee. The person making the order may himself be the payee. The bill itself is frequently called a draft. See Exchange. Chitty. Bill of fare a written or printed enumeration of the dishes served at a public table, or of the dishes (with prices annexed) which may be ordered at a restaurant, etc. Bill of health a certificate from the proper authorities as to the state of health of a ship's company at the time of her leaving port. Bill of indictment a written accusation lawfully presented to a grand jury. If the jury consider the evidence sufficient to support the accusation, they indorse it “A true bill,” otherwise they write upon it “Not a true bill,” or “Not found,” or “Ignoramus”, or “Ignored.” Bill of lading a written account of goods shipped by any person, signed by the agent of the owner of the vessel, or by its master, acknowledging the receipt of the goods, and promising to deliver them safe at the place directed, dangers of the sea excepted. It is usual for the master to sign two, three, or four copies of the bill; one of which he keeps in possession, one is kept by the shipper, and one is sent to the consignee of the goods. Bill of mortality an official statement of the number of deaths in a place or district within a given time; also, a district required to be covered by such statement; as, a place within the bills of mortality of London. Bill of pains and penalties a special act of a legislature which inflicts a punishment less than death upon persons supposed to be guilty of treason or felony, without any conviction in the ordinary course of judicial proceedings. Bouvier. Wharton. Bill of parcels an account given by the seller to the buyer of the several articles purchased, with the price of each. Bill of particulars Law a detailed statement of the items of a plaintiff's demand in an action, or of the defendant's set-off. Bill of rights a summary of rights and privileges claimed by a people. Such was the declaration presented by the Lords and Commons of England to the Prince and Princess of Orange in 1688, and enacted in Parliament after they became king and queen. In America, a bill or declaration of rights is prefixed to most of the constitutions of the several States. Bill of sale a formal instrument for the conveyance or transfer of goods and chattels. Bill of sight a form of entry at the customhouse, by which goods, respecting which the importer is not possessed of full information, may be provisionally landed for examination. Bill of store a license granted at the customhouse to merchants, to carry such stores and provisions as are necessary for a voyage, custom free. Wharton. Bills payable pl.), the outstanding unpaid notes or acceptances made and issued by an individual or firm. Bills receivable pl.), the unpaid promissory notes or acceptances held by an individual or firm. McElrath. A true bill a bill of indictment sanctioned by a grand jury.
entry.ety: OE. bill bille, fr. LL. billaor OF. bille), for L. bulla anything rounded, LL., seal, stamp, letter, edict, roll; cf. F. bille a ball, prob. fr. Ger.; cf. MHG. bickel, D. bikkel, dice. Cf. Bull papal edict, Billet a paper

sn.def: A declaration made in writing, stating some wrong the complainant has suffered from the defendant, or a fault committed by some person against a law.
A writing binding the signer or signers to pay a certain sum at a future day or on demand, with or without interest, as may be stated in the document.
A form or draft of a law, presented to a legislature for enactment; a proposed or projected law.
A paper, written or printed, and posted up or given away, to advertise something, as a lecture, a play, or the sale of goods; a placard; a poster; a handbill.
sn.q: She put up the bill in her parlor window.

sn.def: An account of goods sold, services rendered, or work done, with the price or charge; a statement of a creditor's claim, in gross or by items; as, a grocer's bill .
Any paper, containing a statement of particulars; as, a bill of charges or expenditures; a weekly bill of mortality; a bill of fare, etc.
To advertise by a bill or public notice.
To charge or enter in a bill; as, to bill goods.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: In Australia, a blind channel leading out from a river; -- sometimes called an anabranch. This is the sense of the word as used in the Public Works Department; but the term has also been locally applied to mere back-waters forming stagnant pools and to certain water channels arising from a source.
Same as Bilge.
An English fish, allied to the cod; the coalfish.
A weevil or curculio of various species, as the corn weevil. See Curculio.

sn.def: A piece of thick plank, armed with iron plates, and fixed on the bow or fore channels of a vessel, for the bill or fluke of the anchor to rest on.
A flat surface, as of a panel or of a fence, on which bills are posted; a bulletin board.
A large board out of doors and visible to passers-by, on which the space is rented for advertising purposes; also, the advertising displayed on such a board.

entries.entry: Bill" book`. Com A book in which a person keeps an account of his notes, bills, bills of exchange, etc., thus showing all that he issues and receives.
Bill" bro`ker. One who negotiates the discount of bills.

entry.def: Furnished with, or having, a bill, as a bird; -- used in composition; as, broad-billed .

entry.ety: F. billet, dim. of an OF. bille bill. See Bill a writing

sn.def: A small paper; a note; a short letter.
sn.q: I got your melancholybillet.

sn.def: A ticket from a public officer directing soldiers at what house to lodge; as, a billet of residence.
Quarters or place to which one is assigned, as by a billet or ticket; berth; position. Also used fig.
sn.q: The men who cling to easy billets ashore.
His shafts of satire fly straight to their billet, and there they rankle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Billeted; p. pr. & vb. n. Billeting
entry.ety: From Billet a ticket
entry.def: To direct, by a ticket or note, where to lodge. Hence: To quarter, or place in lodgings, as soldiers in private houses.
entry.q: Billeted in so antiquated a mansion.

entry.ety: F. billette bille, log; of unknown origin; a different word from bille ball. Cf. Billiards Billot

sn.def: A small stick of wood, as for firewood.
sn.q: They shall beat out my brains with billets.

sn.def: A short bar of metal, as of gold or iron.
An ornament in Norman work, resembling a billet of wood either square or round.

sd.def: A strap which enters a buckle.
A loop which receives the end of a buckled strap.

sn.def: A bearing in the form of an oblong rectangle.

entries.entry:
Bil`let-doux" Bil`let-doux" bĭl`l�*d�" n.; pl.Billets-doux bĭl`l�*d�z". F. billet note + doux sweet, L. dulcis
A love letter or note. A lover chanting out a billet-doux.

entry.def: A round piece of timber at the bow or stern of a whaleboat, around which the harpoon line is run out when the whale darts off.

entries.entry: Bill"fish` bĭl"fĭsh` n. Zoöl A name applied to several distinct fishes: The garfish (Tylosurus longirostrisorBelone longirostris) and allied species. The saury, a slender fish of the Atlantic coast (Scomberesox saurus). The Tetrapturus albidus, a large oceanic species related to the swordfish; the spearfish. The American fresh-water garpike (Lepidosteus osseus).

entry.def: A small, thin, flat container, usually made of leather or imitation leather, having a pocket of a size just large enough to hold paper currency and folded over once to fit in the pocket of one's clothing; it is a type of wallet, but having fewer compartments than the typical wallet.
A printed form, used by merchants in making out bills or rendering accounts.

entries.entry:
Bill" hold`er bĭl" hōl`dẽr. A person who holds a bill or acceptance.
A device by means of which bills, etc., are held.

entry.ety: Bill + hook
entry.def: A thick, heavy knife with a hooked point, used in pruning hedges, etc. When it has a short handle, it is sometimes called a hand bill; when the handle is long, a hedge bill or scimiter.
Of or pertaining to the game of billiards.
entry.q: Smooth as is abilliardball.

entry.ety: F. billiard billiards, OF. billart staff, cue form playing, fr. bille log. See Billet a stick
entry.def: A game played with ivory balls o a cloth-covered, rectangular table, bounded by elastic cushions. The player seeks to impel his ball with his cue so that it shall either strike (carom upon) two other balls, or drive another ball into one of the pockets with which the table sometimes is furnished.
Caressing; kissing.

sn.def: A market near the Billings gate in London, celebrated for fish and foul language.
Coarsely abusive, foul, or profane language; vituperation; ribaldry.

entry.ety: F. billion, arbitrarily formed fr. L. bis twice, in imitation of million a million. See Million
entry.def: According to the French and American method of numeration, a thousand millions, or 1,000,000,000; according to the English method, a million millions, or 1,000,000,000,000. See Numeration.

entries.entry: Bill"man n.; pl.Billmen. One who uses, or is armed with, a bill or hooked ax. Abillmanof the guard.

entry.ety: F. Cf. Billet a stick
entry.def: An alloy of gold and silver with a large proportion of copper or other base metal, used in coinage.

entry.ety: F. billot, dim. of bille. See Billet a stick
entry.def: Bullion in the bar or mass.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. bylgja billow, Dan. bölge, Sw. bölja; akin to MHG. bulge billow, bag, and to E. bulge. See Bulge

sn.def: A great wave or surge of the sea or other water, caused usually by violent wind.
sn.q: Whom the winds waft where'er the billows roll.

sn.def: A great wave or flood of anything.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Billowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Billowing

entry.ety: p. pr. & vb. n. of billow, verb

stormy; affected by storms; -- of weather, used prenominally.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to billows; swelling or swollen into large waves; full of billows or surges; resembling billows.
entry.q: And whitening down the many-tinctured stream, Descends the billowy foam.

entry.def: One whose occupation is to post handbills or posters in public places.

sn.def: A club; esp., a policeman's club. Also called billy club
A slubbing or roving machine.

entry.def: see billy n. 1.

entries.entry: Bil"ly*cock n.orBil"ly*cock hat` . Perh. from bully + cock; that is, cocked like the hats of the bullies A round, low-crowned felt hat; a wideawake. The undignifiedbillycocksand pantaloons of the West. Little acquiesced, and Ransome disguised him in a beard, and a loose set of clothes, and a billicock hat.

entry.def: A flat-bottomed river barge or coasting vessel.
a policeman's club; a nightstick.

entries.entry: Bil"ly goat`. A male goat. Colloq

a policeman's club.

having two lobes; as, a bilobate leaf.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + locular: cf. F. biloculaire

divided into or containing two cells or chambers; as, having a biloculate capsule.

entry.ety: S. African
entry.def: Lean meat cut into strips and sun-dried.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + maculate, a
entry.def: Having, or marked with, two spots.

entry.ety: NL. See Bimanous
entry.def: Animals having two hands; -- a term applied by Cuvier to man as a special order of Mammalia.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + marginate
entry.def: Having a double margin, as certain shells.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + Gr. � breast

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + medial
entry.def: Applied to a line which is the sum of two lines commensurable only in power (as the side and diagonal of a square).

entry.ety: L. bis twice + membrum member

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + mensal
entry.def: See Bimonthly a.

entry.ety: L. bimestris; bis twice + mensis month
entry.def: Continuing two months.
a material made by bonding together sheets of two different metals.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + metallic: cf. F. bimétallique

sn.def: Of or relating to, or using, a double metallic standard (as gold and silver) for a system of coins or currency.
Composed of two different metals; formed of two parts, each of a different metal; as, bimetallic wire; bimetallic thermometer, etc.

entry.note: ☞ The words bimétallisme and monométallisme are due to M. Cernuschi [1869].
entry.ety: F. bimétalisme
entry.def: The legalized use of two metals (as gold and silver) in the currency of a country, at a fixed relative value; -- in opposition to monometallism.

of or pertaining to bimetallism.
a span of 2000 years.
of or pertaining to the bimillennium.

the year 2000 a. d.

def2.def: A bimonthly publication.

having two motors.

entry.def: Having two adductor muscles, as a bivalve mollusk.

entry.ety: OE. binne, AS. binn manager, crib; perh. akin to D. ben benne, basket, and to L. benna a kind of carriage ( a Gallic word), W. benn men, wain, cart
entry.def: A box, frame, crib, or inclosed place, used as a receptacle for any commodity; as, a corn bin; a wine bin; a coal bin .

entry.def: To put into a bin; as, to bin wine.

entries.entry: Bin. An old form of Be and Been. Obs
Bin-. A euphonic form of the prefix Bi-.

entry.ety: See Binary
entry.def: Twofold; double.
entry.q: Binalrevenge, all this.

entry.ety: Pref. bin- + arseniate
entry.def: A salt having two equivalents of arsenic acid to one of the base.

cs.cd: that in which numbers are expressed according to the binary scale, or in which two figures only, 0 and 1, are used, in lieu of ten; the cipher multiplying everything by two, as in common arithmetic by ten. Thus, 1 is one; 10 is two; 11 is three; 100 is four, etc.
a compound of two elements, or of an element and a compound performing the function of an element, or of two compounds performing the function of elements.

a system of logarithms devised by Euler for facilitating musical calculations, in which 1 is the logarithm of 2, instead of 10, as in the common logarithms, and the modulus 1.442695 instead of .43429448.
measure divisible by two or four; common time.
nomenclature in which the names designate both genus and species.
a uniform scale of notation whose ratio is two.
a double star whose members have a revolution round their common center of gravity.
the theory that all chemical compounds consist of two constituents of opposite and unlike qualities.

entry.ety: L. binarius, fr. bini two by two, two at a time, fr. root of bis twice; akin to E. two: cf. F. binaire
entry.def: Compounded or consisting of two things or parts; characterized by two (things).
That which is constituted of two figures, things, or parts; two; duality.

entry.ety: L. bini two and two
entry.def: Double; growing in pairs or couples.

entry.ety: Pref. bin- + aural
entry.def: Of or pertaining to, or used by, both ears.

entry.ety: Turk., prop., chief of a thousand; bin thousand + bash head
entry.def: A major in the Turkish army.

cs.cd: to put under bonds to do something, as to appear at court, to keep the peace, etc.
to contract; as, to bind one's self to a wife.
to cause to be wholly engrossed with; to absorb in.

entry.vmorph: imp. Bound; p. p. Bound, formerly Bounden; p. pr. & vb. n. Binding
entry.ety: AS. bindan, perfect tense band bundon, p. p. bunden; akin to D. & G. binden, Dan. binde, Sw. & Icel. binda, Goth. bindan, Skr. bandhfor bhandh) to bind, cf. Gr. �for �) cable, and L. offendix. √90

sn.def: To tie, or confine with a cord, band, ligature, chain, etc.; to fetter; to make fast; as, to bind grain in bundles; to bind a prisoner.
To confine, restrain, or hold by physical force or influence of any kind; as, attraction binds the planets to the sun; frost binds the earth, or the streams.
sn.q: He bindeth the floods from overflowing.
Whom Satan hath bound, lo, these eighteen years.

sn.def: To cover, as with a bandage; to bandage or dress; -- sometimes with up; as, to bind up a wound.
To make fast ( a thingabout or upon something, as by tying; to encircle with something; as, to bind a belt about one; to bind a compress upon a part.
To prevent or restrain from customary or natural action; as, certain drugs bind the bowels.
To protect or strengthen by a band or binding, as the edge of a carpet or garment.
To sew or fasten together, and inclose in a cover; as, to bind a book.

Fig.: To oblige, restrain, or hold, by authority, law, duty, promise, vow, affection, or other moral tie; as, to bind the conscience; to bind by kindness; bound by affection; commerce binds nations to each other.
sn.q: Who made our laws to bind us, not himself.

sd.def: To bring (any one) under definite legal obligations; esp. under the obligation of a bond or covenant.
To place under legal obligation to serve; to indenture; as, to bind an apprentice; -- sometimes with out; as, bound out to service.
sd.syn: To fetter; tie; fasten; restrain; restrict; oblige.

sn.def: To tie; to confine by any ligature.
sn.q: They that reap must sheaf and bind.

sn.def: To contract; to grow hard or stiff; to cohere or stick together in a mass; as, clay binds by heat.
To be restrained from motion, or from customary or natural action, as by friction.
To exert a binding or restraining influence.
That which binds or ties.
Any twining or climbing plant or stem, esp. a hop vine; a bine.
Indurated clay, when much mixed with the oxide of iron.
A ligature or tie for grouping notes.
One who binds; as, a binder of sheaves; one whose trade is to bind; as, a binder of books.
Anything that binds, as a fillet, cord, rope, or band; a bandage; -- esp. the principal piece of timber intended to bind together any building.
a pair of stiff oblong covers, sometimes detachable, designed for insertion of paper pages to create a book-like document, such as in a loose-leaf binder.

entry.def: A place where books, or other articles, are bound; a bookbinder's establishment.

entry.ety: From Bindheim, a German who analyzed it
entry.def: An amorphous antimonate of lead, produced from the alteration of other ores, as from jamesonite.

cs.cd: the main timber in double flooring.
the secondary timber in double-framed flooring.

entry.def: That binds; obligatory.
entry.syn: Obligatory; restraining; restrictive; stringent; astringent; costive; styptic.

sn.def: The act or process of one who, or that which, binds.
Anything that binds; a bandage; the cover of a book, or the cover with the sewing, etc.; something that secures the edge of cloth from raveling.
The transoms, knees, beams, keelson, and other chief timbers used for connecting and strengthening the parts of a vessel.

entry.def: So as to bind.
The condition or property of being binding; obligatory quality.

entries.entry: Bind"ing post`. Elec A metallic post attached to electrical apparatus for convenience in making connections.
Bind"ing screw`. A set screw used to bind parts together, esp. one for making a connection in an electrical circuit.

entry.def: A plant of the genus Convolvulus; as, greater bindweed Convolvulus Sepium); lesser bindweed Convolvulus arvensis); the white bindweed, the blue bindweed, the Syrian bindweed . The black bryony, or Tamus, is called black bindweed, and the Smilax aspera rough bindweed.
entry.q: The fragile bindweed bells and bryony rings.

entry.ety: Bind, cf. Woodbine
entry.def: The winding or twining stem of a hop vine or other climbing plant.

entry.ety: L. bis twice + nervus sinew, nerve

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. bingr, Sw. binge, G. beige beuge. Cf. Prov. E. bink bench, and bench coal the uppermost stratum of coal

Abingof corn.

entry.note: Variants of the game may require that all peripheral numbers are covered, to form a box, or other figure. The numbers usually have one letter from the group “B”, “I”, “N”, “G”, and “O”, plus two digits. The “cards” may be disposable sheets of paper on which the numbers are printed.
entry.def: a game commonly used for low-stakes gambling, in which numbered balls or slips are drawn at random and players cover the correponding numbers on their cards, called Bingo cards, which have square arrangement of such numbers. Each card has a different arrangement of the numbers, and the first player to cover all numbers in one row (horizontal, vertical, or diagonal) is the winner, usually announcing that fact by a cry of “Bingo!”
Same as Diiodide.
A bench.

entry.ety: For bittacle, corrupted (perh. by influence of bin) fr. Pg. bitacola binnacle, fr. L. habitaculum dwelling place, fr. habitare to dwell. See Habit, and cf. Bittacle
entry.def: A case or box placed near the helmsman, containing the compass of a ship, and a light to show it at night.
A large species of barbel (Barbus bynni), found in the Nile, and much esteemed for food.

entry.ety: F. binocle; L. bini two at a time + oculus eye
entry.def: A dioptric telescope, fitted with two tubes joining, so as to enable a person to view an object with both eyes at once; a double-barreled field glass or an opera glass.

entry.ety: Cf. F. binoculaire. See Binocle

sn.def: Having two eyes.
sn.q: Most animals arebinocular.

sn.def: Pertaining to both eyes; employing both eyes at once; as, binocular vision.
Adapted to the use of both eyes; as, a binocular microscope or telescope.

entry.def: A binocular glass, whether opera glass, telescope, or microscope.
In a binocular manner.
Having two eyes.

entry.ety: L. bis twice + nomen name: cf. F. binome, LL. binomiusor fr. bi- + Gr. � distribution ?). Cf. Monomial
entry.def: An expression consisting of two terms connected by the sign plus (+) or minus (-); as, a + b, or 7 - 3.

cs.cd: the theorem which expresses the law of formation of any power of a binomial.

sn.def: Consisting of two terms; pertaining to binomials; as, a binomial root.
Having two names; -- used of the system by which every animal and plant receives two names, the one indicating the genus, the other the species, to which it belongs.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to two names; binomial.
Binominal.

entry.ety: L. bini two at a time + tonus, fr. Gr. �, tone

Same as Binate.

a prefix meaning of or pertaining to life produced by living things, etc.
acting upon or influencing bodily functions; -- of chemical substances.
appraisal of the biological activity of a substance by testing its effect on an organism.
to subject to a bio-assay.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + -blast

a biochemical catalyst such as an enzyme.
