sn.def: caused by a biocatalyst.

entry.ety: L. bis twice + ocellatus. See Ocellated
entry.def: Having two ocelli (eyelike spots); -- said of a wing, etc.
of or pertaining to biochemistry.
a chemical substance produced by a living organism, or such a substance produced synthetically.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + E. chemistry
entry.def: The chemistry of living organisms; the chemistry of the processes incidental to, and characteristic of, life.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to biodynamics, or the doctrine of vital forces or energy.
of or pertaining to a method of farming that uses only organic fertilizers (rather than chemical fertilizers) and organic materials for improving the soil characteristics.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + E. dynamics

sn.def: The doctrine of vital forces or energy.
The branch of biology which treats of the active vital phenomena of organisms; -- opposed to biostatics.

entry.def: electric phenomena in animals or plants.

sn.def: biological science applied to the study the relation between workers and their environments.
the application of engineeering principles to solve problems in medicine, such as the design of artificial limbs or organs; -- called also biomedical engineering.

the branch of engineering dealing with the application of biological processes to the solution of practical problems, such as the manufacture of products by fermentation, the production and use of enzymes for various purposes, the use of microorganisms in environmental cleanup, etc.; -- called also biotechnology.

entry.def: a training program in which a person is given information about physiological processes (heart rate or blood pressure) that is not normally available with the goal of gaining conscious control of them.
a vitamin that maintains the resistance of cell and capillary walls to permeation; -- called also vitamin P and citrin.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + -gen

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + � �, birth
entry.def: A doctrine that the genesis or production of living organisms can take place only through the agency of living germs or parents; -- called also biogeny; -- opposed to abiogenesis.
Life development generally.

sn.def: the production of a chemical compound by a living organism.

entry.def: Pertaining to biogenesis.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + -gen + -ic
entry.def: produced by living organisms; as, biogenic methane.
A believer in the theory of biogenesis.
the production of living organisms from other living organisms; same as biogenesis{1.
of or pertaining to biogeography.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + E. geography
entry.def: The branch of biology which deals with the geographical distribution of animals and plants. It includes both zoögeography and phytogeography.

entry.ety: Gr. � life + � investigation

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + -graph

entry.def: One who writes an account or history of the life of a particular person; a writer of lives, as Plutarch.

To write a history of the life of.

entries.entry:
Bi*og"ra*phy n.; pl.Biographies. Gr. �; bi`os life + � to write: cf. F. biographie. See Graphic
The written history of a person's life.
Biographical writings in general.

sn.def: Of or relating to biology.
related by blood; -- of parents and children; -- contrasted with adoptive adopted, or foster; as, Mary was adopted directly from the maternity hospital and never met her biological mother.

entry.def: use of biological principles in explaining human behavior, especially social behavior.
of or pertaining to biologism.
A student of biology; one versed in the science of biology.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + -logy: cf. F. biologie
entry.def: The science of life; that branch of knowledge which treats of living matter as distinct from matter which is not living; the study of living tissue. It has to do with the origin, structure, development, function, and distribution of animals and plants.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + � a dissolving
entry.def: The destruction of life.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + luminescence
entry.def: a type of luminescence produced by biological or biochemical processes, such as a glowworm glow or the action of luciferase on luciferin. A well-known example is that of firefly luminescence . See also luciferin.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + � to destroy
entry.def: Relating to the destruction of life.
Relating to biomagnetism.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + E. magnetism

sn.def: Animal magnetism.
magnetic phenomena in living organisms.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + -metry
entry.def: Measurement of life; calculation of the probable duration of human life.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life

sn.def: a specific type of complex ecological community characterized by specific environmental conditions and a distinctive group of plants and animals, maintained in a relatively stable equilibrium, such as a rain forest biome or prairie biome.
a particular region which is a biome{1}.

entry.def: Pertaining to the biological and physiological aspects of medicine.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to biomedicine.

entry.def: The application of engineeering principles to solve problems in medicine, such as the design of artificial limbs or organs; -- called also bioengineering.

sn.def: The application of the principles and techniques of the natural sciences, especially biology, to investigate and solve problems in clinical medicine.
The investigation of the effects of external environmental factors such as weightlessness on the human body.

entry.ety: Gr. biw^n living, p. pr. of bioy^n to live
entry.def: The physiological individual, characterized by definiteness and independence of function, in distinction from the morphological individual or morphon.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + no`mos law
entry.def: Physiology.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + fo`ros bearing, fr. fe`rein to bear
entry.def: One of the smaller vital units of a cell, the bearer of vitality and heredity. See Pangen, in Supplement.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + photo + fwnh` sound, voice
entry.def: An instrument combining a cinematograph and a phonograph so that the moving figures on the screen are accompanied by the appropriate sounds; -- an archaic term replaced by movie projector.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + pla`sma form, mold, fr. pla`ssein to mold
entry.def: A name suggested by Dr. Beale for the germinal matter supposed to be essential to the functions of all living beings; the material through which every form of life manifests itself; unaltered protoplasm.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, bioplasm.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + pla`ssein to form
entry.def: A tiny mass of bioplasm, in itself a living unit and having formative power, as a living white blood corpuscle; bioblast.
Bioplasmic.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + psychic -cal
entry.def: Pertaining to psychical phenomena in their relation to the living organism or to the general phenomena of life.

an apparatus in which a suspension of microorganisms in a liquid are used to perform chemical reactions, as in synthesis of pharmaceutical agents or the conversion of harmful waste to less harmful substances. The reactor consists of a vessel to contain the suspension of microorganisms, plus a variety of attached devices used to control the reaction.
the branch of biotechnology that uses biological processes to overcome environmental problems.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + E. organ
entry.def: A physiological organ; a living organ; an organ endowed with function; -- distinguished from idorgan.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + -scope

sn.def: A view of life; that which gives such a view.
sn.q: Bagman's Bioscope: Various Views of Men and Manners. Book Title

sn.def: An animated picture machine for screen projection; a cinematograph (which see); an archaic term replaced by movie projector.
a South African movie theater.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + �. See Statics
entry.def: The physical phenomena of organized bodies, in opposition to their organic or vital phenomena.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + E. statistics
entry.def: Vital statistics.

sn.def: production of a chemical compound by a living organism.
the production of chemical substances by use of reagents or enzymes derived from living organisms, in reactions modeled on those observed in living organisms.

entry.def: of or pertaining to biosynthesis.
of or pertaining to biosystematics.
use of data (e. g. cytogenetic or biochemical) to assess taxonomic relations esp within an evolutionary framework.
use of data (e. g. cytogenetic or biochemical) to assess taxonomic relations especially within an evolutionary framework.
all the plant and animal life of a particular region.

entry.ety: Gr. bi`os life + � arrangement
entry.def: The classification of living organisms according to their structural character; taxonomy.
same as bioengineering.

entry.ety: Gr. biwtiko`s pert. to life

sn.def: Relating to life; as, the biotic principle.
produced by or caused by living things.

entry.note: Biotin binds tightly to the substance avidin, found in raw egg-whites. Rats or chick on a diet high in raw egg-white may develop skin lesions and retarded growth, which can be prevented by adding biotin to the diet.
entry.def: a B vitamin (C10H16N2O3S) that aids in body growth; -- called also vitamin H and coenzyme R. It functions as a coenzyme in many carboxylation reactions.

entry.ety: From Biot, a French naturalist
entry.def: Mica containing iron and magnesia, generally of a black or dark green color; -- a common constituent of crystalline rocks. See Mica.
a region uniform in its environmental conditions and in the types of plants and animals living in it.

sn.def: a group of organisms sharing the same genotype.
the genotype shared by a biotype{1.

entry.def: of or pertaining to a biotype.
derived from two separate ferilized ova; -- of twins; as, fraternal twins are biovular . Antonym of identical.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + palmate
entry.def: Palmately branched, with the branches again palmated.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + parietal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the diameter of the cranium, from one parietal fossa to the other.

entry.ety: L. bis twice + parere to bring forth
entry.def: Bringing forth two at a birth.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bipartible. See Bipartite
entry.def: Capable of being divided into two parts.

entry.ety: L. bis twice + partiens p. pr. of partire to divide
entry.def: Dividing into two parts.

def2.def: A number that divides another into two equal parts without a remainder.

entry.def: Divisible into two parts.

entry.ety: L. bipartitus, p. p. of bipartire; bis twice + partire. See Partite

sn.def: Being in two parts; having two correspondent parts, as a legal contract or writing, one for each party; shared by two; as, a bipartite treaty.
Divided into two parts almost to the base, as a leaf; consisting of two parts or subdivisions.

entry.def: The act of dividing into two parts, or of making two correspondent parts, or the state of being so divided.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + pectinate
entry.def: Having two margins toothed like a comb.

entry.ety: L. bipes; bis twice + pes pedis, �oot: cf. F. bipède
entry.def: A two-footed animal, as man.
Having two feet; two-footed.
entry.q: By which the man, when heavenly life was ceased, Became a helpless, naked, biped beast.

entry.ety: L. bipedalis: cf. F. bipédal. See Biped n.

sn.def: Having two feet; biped.
Pertaining to a biped.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + peltate
entry.def: Having a shell or covering like a double shield.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + pennate: cf. L. bipennis. Cf. Bipinnate
entry.def: Having two wings.
entry.q: Bipennatedinsects.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: An ax with an edge or blade on each side of the handle.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + petalous
entry.def: Having two petals.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. bis twice + pinna feather
entry.def: The larva of certain starfishes as developed in the free-swimming stage.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + pinnate; cf. F. bipinné. Cf. Bipennate
entry.def: Twice pinnate.

entry.note: A bipinnatifid leaf is a pinnatifid leaf having its segments or divisions also pinnatifid. The primary divisions are pinnæ and the secondary pinnules.
entry.ety: Pref. bi- + pinnatifid
entry.def: Doubly pinnatifid.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + plane
entry.def: An aëroplane with two main supporting surfaces one above the other.
Having, or consisting of, two superposed planes, aërocurves, or the like; of or pertaining to a biplane; as, a biplane rudder.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + plicate
entry.def: Twice folded together.
The state of being twice folded; reduplication.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + polar. Cf. Dipolar
entry.def: Doubly polar; having two poles; as, a bipolar cell or corpuscle.
Bipolar quality.
Relating to books printed at Deuxponts, or Bipontium (Zweibrücken), in Bavaria.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + prism

sn.def: A prism whose refracting angle is very nearly 180 degrees.
A combination of two short rectangular glass prisms cemented together at their diagonal faces so as to form a cube; -- called also optical cube. It is used in one form of photometer.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + punctate
entry.def: Having two punctures, or spots.
Having two points.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + pupilof the eye)
entry.def: Having an eyelike spot on the wing, with two dots within it of a different color, as in some butterflies.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + pyramidal
entry.def: Consisting of two pyramids placed base to base; having a pyramid at each of the extremities of a prism, as in quartz crystals.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + quadrate
entry.def: The fourth power, or the square of the square. Thus 4x4=16, the square of 4, and 16x16=256, the biquadrate of 4.

cs.cd: an equation of the fourth degree, or an equation in some term of which the unknown quantity is raised to the fourth power.
the square root of the square root of that number. Thus the square root of 81 is 9, and the square root of 9 is 3, which is the biquadratic root of 81. Hutton.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + quadratic: cf. F. biquadratique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the biquadrate, or fourth power.
A biquadrate.
A biquadratic equation.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + quintile: cf. F. biquintile
entry.def: An aspect of the planets when they are distant from each other by twice the fifth part of a great circle -- that is, twice 72 degrees.
consisting of, combining two races.
showing both bilateral and radial symmetry.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + radiate
entry.def: Having two rays; as, a biradiate fin.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + ramous
entry.def: Having, or consisting of, two branches.

entries.entry:
Birch ☞ The twigs of the common European birch (B. alba), being tough and slender, were formerly much used for rods in schools. They were also made into brooms.
Birch of Jamaica a species (Bursera gummifera) of turpentine tree. Birch partridge. Zoöl See Ruffed grouse. Birch wine wine made of the spring sap of the birch. Oil of birch. An oil obtained from the bark of the common European birch (Betula alba), and used in the preparation of genuine (and sometimes of the imitation) Russia leather, to which it gives its peculiar odor. An oil prepared from the black birch (Betula lenta), said to be identical with the oil of wintergreen, for which it is largely sold.
bẽrch n.; pl.Birches -ĕz. OE. birche birk, AS. birce beorc; akin to Icel. björk, Sw. björk, Dan. birk, D. berk, OHG. piricha, MHG. birche birke, G. birke, Russ. bereza, Pol. brzoza, Serv. breza, Skr. bhūrja. √254. Cf. 1st Birk
A tree of several species, constituting the genus Betula; as, the white or common birch (Betula alba) (also called silver birch and lady birch); the dwarf birch (Betula glandulosa); the paper or canoe birch (Betula papyracea); the yellow birch (Betula lutea); the black or cherry birch (Betula lenta).
The wood or timber of the birch.
A birch twig or birch twigs, used for flogging. The threatening twigs of birch.
A birch-bark canoe.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the birch; birchen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Birched bẽrcht; p. pr. & vb. n. Birching
entry.def: To whip with a birch rod or twig; to flog.
a canoe made with the bark of a birch tree.
Of or relating to birch.
entry.q: He passed where Newark's stately tower Looks out from Yarrow's birchen bower.

cs.cd: the phenix.
the eagle.
the peacock.

a wingless insect of the group Mallophaga, of which the genera and species are very numerous and mostly parasitic upon birds. -- Bird mite Zoöl, a small mite (genera Dermanyssus Dermaleichus and allies) parasitic upon birds. The species are numerous.
a migratory bird.
a very large South American spider (Mygale avicularia). It is said sometimes to capture and kill small birds.
a dipterous insect parasitic upon birds (genus Ornithomyia, and allies), usually winged.

entry.ety: OE. brid bred bird, young bird, bird, AS. bridd young bird. √92

sn.def: Orig., a chicken; the young of a fowl; a young eaglet; a nestling; and hence, a feathered flying animal (see 2).
sn.q: That ungentle gull, the cuckoo's bird.
The bryddsbirds] of the aier have nestes.

sn.def: A warm-blooded, feathered vertebrate provided with wings. See Aves.
Specifically, among sportsmen, a game bird.
Fig.: A girl; a maiden.
sn.q: And by my word! the bonny bird In danger shall not tarry.

sn.def: To catch or shoot birds.
Hence: To seek for game or plunder; to thieve.
to watch birds, especially in their natural habitats, for enjoyment; to birdwatch.

entry.def: an ornamental basin (usually in a garden) for birds to bathe in.
A short blunt arrow for killing birds without piercing them.
Anything which smites without penetrating.

sn.def: a person with confused ideas; incapable of serious thought.

entry.def: A cage for confining birds.

sn.def: A sound made in imitation of the note or cry of a bird for the purpose of decoying the bird or its mate.
An instrument of any kind, as a whistle, used in making the sound of a birdcall.

entry.def: One whose employment it is to catch birds; a fowler.
The art, act, or occupation or catching birds or wild fowls.

entries.entry: Bird" cher`ry. Bot A shrub (Prunus Padus ) found in Northern and Central Europe. It bears small black cherries.

sn.def: A birdcatcher.
a birdwatcher.

entry.def: Quick-sighted; catching a glance as one goes.

entries.entry:
Bird" fan`ci*er. One who takes pleasure in rearing or collecting rare or curious birds.
One who has for sale the various kinds of birds which are kept in cages.

entry.def: A pretty or dear little bird; -- a pet name.
A young bird.

cs.cd: a fowling piece.

entry.def: Birdcatching or fowling.
A little bird; a nestling.
Resembling a bird.

entry.note: ☞ Birdlime is also made from mistletoe, elder, etc.
entry.ety: Bird + lime viscous substance
entry.def: An extremely adhesive viscid substance, usually made of the middle bark of the holly, by boiling, fermenting, and cleansing it. When a twig is smeared with this substance it will hold small birds which may light upon it. Hence: Anything which insnares.
entry.q: Not birdlime or Idean pitch produce A more tenacious mass of clammy juice.

entry.def: To smear with birdlime; to catch with birdlime; to insnare.
entry.q: When the heart is thus birdlimed, then it cleaves to everything it meets with.

entry.def: A little bird; a nestling.
A fowler or birdcatcher.

entries.entry: Bird" of par"a*dise ☞ The Great emerald Paradisea apoda) and the Lesser emerald Paradisea minor) furnish many of the plumes used as ornaments by ladies; the Red bird of paradise is Paradisea rubraorParadisea sanguinea; the Golden bird of paradise is Parotia aureaorParotia sexsetacea; the King bird of paradise is Cincinnurus regius. The name is also applied to the longer-billed birds of another related group (Epimachinæ) from the same region. The Twelve-wired bird of paradise Seleucides alba) is one of these. See Paradise bird, and Note under Apod.. Zoöl The name of several very beautiful birds of the genus Paradisea and allied genera, inhabiting New Guinea and the adjacent islands. The males have brilliant colors, elegant plumes, and often remarkable tail feathers.

entry.def: a common trailing perennial milkwort of eastern North America (Polygala paucifolia), having leaves like wintergreen and usually rosy-purple flowers with winged sepals.
entry.syn: flowering wintergreen, gaywings, gay-wings, fringed polygala.

entries.entry: Bird" pep`per. A species of capsicum (Capsicum baccatum), whose small, conical, coral-red fruit is among the most piquant of all red peppers.

entry.def: An aviator; airman.
A molding whose section is thought to resemble a beak.
Canary seed, hemp, millet or other small seeds used for feeding caged birds.

sn.def: Seen from above, as if by a flying bird; embraced at a glance; hence, general; not minute, or entering into details; as, a bird's-eye view.
Marked with spots resembling bird's eyes; as, bird's-eye diaper; bird's-eye maple.

entry.def: A plant with a small bright flower, as the Adonis or pheasant's eye, the mealy primrose (Primula farinosa), and species of Veronica, Geranium, etc.

entries.entry: Bird's"-eye` ma"ple. See under Maple.

entry.cs: Bird's-foot trefoil. Bot A genus of plants (Lotus) with clawlike pods. Lotus corniculatas, with yellow flowers, is very common in Great Britain. the related plant, Trigonella ornithopodioides, is also European.
entry.def: A papilionaceous plant, the Ornithopus, having a curved, cylindrical pod tipped with a short, clawlike point.
An interior angle or notch cut across a piece of timber, for the reception of the edge of another, as that in a rafter to be laid on a plate; -- commonly called crow's-foot in the United States.

entry.note: ☞ The nests are found in caverns and fissures of cliffs on rocky coasts, and are composed in part of algæ. They are of the size of a goose egg, and in substance resemble isinglass. See Illust. under Edible.

cs.cd: a pudding containing apples whose cores have been replaced by sugar.
a plant, the Monotropa hypopitys.

sn.def: The nest in which a bird lays eggs and hatches her young.
The nest of a small swallow (Collocalia nidifica and several allied species), of China and the neighboring countries, which is mixed with soups.
An orchideous plant with matted roots, of the genus Neottia Neottia nidus-avis).

entry.def: Hunting for, or taking, birds' nests or their contents.
The knotgrass (Polygonum aviculare).
to watch birds, especially in their natural habitats, for enjoyment or as a hobby; to bird{3.
one who enjoys watching birds, especially to find and identify a variety of birds in their natural habitats; a birder{2}.
Flighty; passing rapidly from one subject to another; not having the faculty of attention.
An airwoman; an aviatress.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + rectangular
entry.def: Containing or having two right angles; as, a birectangular spherical triangle.

entry.ety: L. biremis; bis twice + remus oar: cf. F. birème
entry.def: An ancient galley or vessel with two banks or tiers of oars.
Same as Berretta.
See Bergander.

entry.ety: See Birch n.
entry.def: A birch tree.
entry.q: The silverbirk.

entry.def: A small European minnow (Leuciscus phoxinus).

entry.ety: From 1st Birk
entry.def: To whip with a birch or rod.
Birchen; as, birken groves.
A lively or mettlesome fellow.
To revolve or cause to revolve; to spin.

entry.ety: AS. byrlian. √92
entry.def: To pour (beer or wine); to ply with drink; to drink; to carouse.

entry.ety: See By -law
entry.def: A law made by husbandmen respecting rural affairs; a rustic or local law or by-law.

sn.def: a city in Alabama.
a city in England.

entry.ety: from the name of the inventor
entry.def: a pen with small metal ball as point of transfer of ink to paper; same as ballpoint pen.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + rostrate
entry.def: Having a double beak, or two processes resembling beaks.
entry.q: The capsule is bilocular and birostrated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Birred; p. pr. & vb. n. Birring
entry.ety: Cf. OE. bur bir, wind, storm wind, fr. Icel. byrr wind. Perh. imitative
entry.def: To make, or move with, a whirring noise, as of wheels in motion.

sn.def: A whirring sound, as of a spinning wheel.
A rush or impetus; force.

entry.ety: LL., fr. L. birrus a kind of cloak. See Berretta
entry.def: A coarse kind of thick woolen cloth, worn by the poor in the Middle Ages; also, a woolen cap or hood worn over the shoulders or over the head.
A bristle or bristles.

entry.ety: OE. byrte; cf. F. bertonneau. Cf. Bret Burt
entry.def: A fish of the turbot kind; the brill.

cs.cd: regeneration, or the commencement of a religious life.

entry.ety: OE. burth birth, AS. beorð gebyrd, fr. beran to bear, bring forth; akin to D. geboorte, OHG. burt giburt, G. geburt, Icel. burðr, Skr. bhrti bearing, supporting; cf. Ir. & Gael. beirthe born, brought forth. √92. See 1st Bear, and cf. Berth

sn.def: The act or fact of coming into life, or of being born; -- generally applied to human beings; as, the birth of a son.
Lineage; extraction; descent; sometimes, high birth; noble extraction.
sn.q: Elected without reference to birth, but solely for qualifications.

sn.def: The condition to which a person is born; natural state or position; inherited disposition or tendency.
sn.q: A foe by birth to Troy's unhappy name.

sn.def: The act of bringing forth; as, she had two children at a birth .
sn.q: At her nextbirth.

sn.def: That which is born; that which is produced, whether animal or vegetable.
sn.q: Poets are far rarer births than kings.
Others hatch their eggs and tend the birth till it is able to shift for itself.

sn.def: Origin; beginning; as, the birth of an empire.

entry.def: See Berth.

entry.note: Conception may be prevented by ingesting medicines, using barriers such as condoms or spermicides during copulation, or by ligating or removing the reproductive organs.
entry.def: the act or process of deliberately limiting the number of one's children born, especially by preventing conception.

sn.def: The day in which any person is born; day of origin or commencement.
sn.q: Those barbarous ages past, succeeded next The birthday of invention.

sn.def: The day of the month in which a person was born, in whatever succeeding year it may recur; the anniversary of one's birth.
sn.q: This is my birthday; as this very day Was Cassius born.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the day of birth, or its anniversary; as, birthday gifts or festivities.

entry.ety: Birth + -dom
entry.def: The land of one's birth; one's inheritance.
to give birth to.
entry.syn: give birth, deliver, bear, birth, have.

sn.def: Anything added to raise the sides of a ship.
the act or process of giving birth.

entry.def: Of mean extraction.
Some peculiar mark or blemish on the body at birth.
entry.q: Most part of this noble lineage carried upon their body for a natural birthmark, . . . a snake.

entry.def: The night in which a person is born; the anniversary of that night in succeeding years.
entry.q: The angelic song in Bethlehem field, On thy birthnight, that sung thee Savior born.

entry.def: The town, city, or country, where a person is born; place of origin or birth, in its more general sense.
entry.q: Thebirthplaceof valor.

entry.def: the ratio of live births in an area to the population of that area; usually expressed as birthes per 1000 population per year.

Any right, privilege, or possession to which a person is entitled by birth, such as an estate descendible by law to an heir, or civil liberty under a free constitution; esp. the rights or inheritance of the first born.
entry.q: Lest there be any . . . profane person, as Esau, who for one morsel of meat sold his birthright.

entry.def: An herbaceous plant (Trillium erectum), and its astringent rootstock, which is said to have medicinal properties.
A genus of herbs and shrubs (Aristolochia), reputed to have medicinal properties.

entry.ety: L. bis twice, for duis, fr. root of duo two. See Two, and cf. Bi-
entry.def: Twice; -- a word showing that something is, or is to be, repeated; as a passage of music, or an item in accounts.
A form of Bi-, sometimes used before sc, or a vowel.

entries.entry: Bi"sa an"te*lope. Zoöl See Oryx.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + saccate
entry.def: Having two little bags, sacs, or pouches.
Of or pertaining to Biscay in Spain.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Biscay.

entry.ety: F. biscotin. See Biscuit
entry.def: A confection made of flour, sugar, marmalade, and eggs; a sweet biscuit.

cs.cd: an alimentary preparation consisting of matters extracted from meat by boiling, or of meat ground fine and combined with flour, so as to form biscuits.

entry.ety: F. biscuitcf. It. biscotto, Sp. bizcocho, Pg. biscouto), fr. L. bis twice + coctus, p. p. of coquere to cook, bake. See Cook, and cf. Bisque a kind of porcelain

sn.def: A kind of unraised bread, of many varieties, plain, sweet, or fancy, formed into flat cakes, and bakes hard; as, ship biscuit .
sn.q: According to military practice, the bread or biscuit of the Romans was twice prepared in the oven.

sn.def: A small loaf or cake of bread, raised and shortened, or made light with soda or baking powder. Usually a number are baked in the same pan, forming a sheet or card.
Earthen ware or porcelain which has undergone the first baking, before it is subjected to the glazing.
A species of white, unglazed porcelain, in which vases, figures, and groups are formed in miniature.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + scutate
entry.def: Resembling two bucklers placed side by side.
a genus off Eurasian herbs and small shrubs: buckler mustard.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A cold north wind which prevails on the northern coasts of the Mediterranean and in Switzerland, etc.; -- nearly the same as the mistral.
See Bice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bisected; p. pr. & vb. n. Bisecting
entry.ety: L. bis twice + secare sectum, to cut

sn.def: To cut or divide into two parts.
To divide into two equal parts.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bissection
entry.def: Division into two parts, esp. two equal parts.
One who, or that which, bisects; esp. Geom a straight line which bisects an angle.
The line bisecting the angle between the optic axes of a biaxial crystal.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + segment
entry.def: One of tow equal parts of a line, or other magnitude.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + septate
entry.def: With two partitions or septa.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + serial seriate
entry.def: In two rows or series.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + serrate

sn.def: Doubly serrate, or having the serratures serrate, as in some leaves.
Serrate on both sides, as some antennæ.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + setose setous
entry.def: Having two bristles.

entry.ety: L. bis twice + sexus sex: cf. F. bissexe
entry.def: Bisexual.

entry.ety: Pref. bi- + sexual
entry.def: Of both sexes; hermaphrodite; as a flower with stamens and pistil, or an animal having ovaries and testes.
Bisexual.

cs.cd: ill looking.

entry.def: p. p. of Besee.
Same as Bikh.

entry.cs: Bishop in partibus [infidelium R. C. Ch a bishop of a see which does not actually exist; one who has the office of bishop, without especial jurisdiction. Shipley. Titular bishop R. C. Ch a term officially substituted in 1882 for bishop in partibus. Bench of Bishops. See under Bench.
entry.ety: OE. bischop biscop bisceop, AS. bisceop biscop, L. episcopus overseer, superintendent, bishop, fr. Gr. � � over + � inspector, fr. root of � �, to look to, perh. akin to L. specere to look at. See Spy, and cf. Episcopal

sn.def: A spiritual overseer, superintendent, or director.
sn.q: Ye were as sheep going astray; but are now returned unto the Shepherd and Bishop of your souls.

It is a fact now generally recognized by theologians of all shades of opinion, that in the language of the New Testament the same officer in the church is called indifferently “bishop” ( � ) and “elder” or “presbyter.”

sn.def: In the Roman Catholic, Greek, and Anglican or Protestant Episcopal churches, one ordained to the highest order of the ministry, superior to the priesthood, and generally claiming to be a successor of the Apostles. The bishop is usually the spiritual head or ruler of a diocese, bishopric, or see.
In the Methodist Episcopal and some other churches, one of the highest church officers or superintendents.
A piece used in the game of chess, bearing a representation of a bishop's miter; -- formerly called archer.
A beverage, being a mixture of wine, oranges or lemons, and sugar.
An old name for a woman's bustle.
sn.q: If, by her bishop, or her “grace” alone, A genuine lady, or a church, is known.

entry.note: The plan adopted is to cut off all the nippers with a saw to the proper length, and then with a cutting instrument the operator scoops out an oval cavity in the corner nippers, which is afterwards burnt with a hot iron until it is black. J. H. Walsh.

Wood betony (Stachys betonica); also, the plant called fennel flower (Nigella Damascena), or devil-in-a-bush.

A salt of metasilicic acid; -- so called because the ratio of the oxygen of the silica to the oxygen of the base is as two to one. The bisilicates include many of the most common and important minerals.

entry.note: ☞ Chemically, bismuth (with arsenic and antimony is intermediate between the metals and nonmetals; it is used in thermo-electric piles, and as an alloy with lead and tin in the fusible alloy or metal. Bismuth is the most diamagnetic substance known.

cs.cd: bismuth sulphide; bismuthinite.
a native bismuth oxide; bismite.

entry.ety: Ger. bismuth wismuth: cf. F. bismuth
entry.def: One of the elements; a metal of a reddish white color, crystallizing in rhombohedrons. It is somewhat harder than lead, and rather brittle; masses show broad cleavage surfaces when broken across. It melts at 507° Fahr., being easily fused in the flame of a candle. It is found in a native state, and as a constituent of some minerals. Specific gravity 9.8. Atomic weight 207.5. Symbol Bi.
Containing bismuth.
Of or pertaining to bismuth; containing bismuth, when this element has its higher valence; as, bismuthic oxide.

entry.ety: Bismuth + -ferous
entry.def: Containing bismuth.
Native bismuth sulphide; -- sometimes called bismuthite.
Of, or containing, bismuth, when this element has its lower valence.
Hydrous carbonate of bismuth, an earthy mineral of a dull white or yellowish color.

entry.note: Efforts at conservation of the American bison resulted in setting aside several reserves, and by 1990 a few stable herds were established, numbering from hundreds to thousands, roaming certain public areas, such as Yellowstone Park, some reserves in Canada, and some private reserves. Some bison are kept as range animals for food, and the American bison has been bred with domestic cattle to form a cross called the beefalo. The American bison is commonly (though improperly) called a buffalo; an image of the bison appeared on the inverse of the U. S. five-cent coin (nickel) from 1913 to 1937, and that coin was referred to as the buffalo nickel.
entry.ety: L. bison, Gr. bi`swn, a wild ox; akin to OHG. wisunt wisant, G. wisent, AS. wesend, Icel. vīsundr: cf. F. bison
entry.def: The aurochs or European bison.

The American bison buffalo (Bison Americanus), a large, gregarious bovine quadruped with shaggy mane and short black horns, which formerly roamed in herds over most of the temperate portion of North America, but by 1900 was restricted to very limited districts in the region of the Rocky Mountains, and was almost hunted to extinction.
of, relating to, or characteristic of bison.

entry.ety: F

entries.entry: Bis"sell truck. A truck for railroad rolling stock, consisting of two ordinary axle boxes sliding in guides attached to a triangular frame; -- called also pony truck.

entry.ety: L. bissextilis annus, fr. bissextus bis + sextus sixth, fr. sex six) the sixth of the calends of March, or twenty-fourth day of February, which was reckoned twice every fourth year, by the intercalation of a day
entry.def: Leap year; every fourth year, in which a day is added to the month of February on account of the excess of the tropical year (365 d. 5 h. 48 m. 46 s.) above 365 days. But one day added every four years is equivalent to six hours each year, which is 11 m. 14 s. more than the excess of the real year. Hence, it is necessary to suppress the bissextile day at the end of every century which is not divisible by 400, while it is retained at the end of those which are divisible by 400.
Pertaining to leap year.

entry.ety: OE. bisen bisne, AS. bisen, prob. for bīs�ne; bi by + s�ne clear, akin to seón to see; clear when near, hence short-sighted. See See

Bis"tou*ry n.; pl.Bistouries. F. bistouri

entry.def: A sulphide having two atoms of sulphur in the molecule; a disulphide, as in iron pyrites, FeS2; -- less frequently called bisulphuret.
A salt of sulphurous acid in which the base replaces but half the hydrogen of the acid; an acid sulphite.

entry.ety: OE. bitt bite, AS. bite, bite, fr. bītan to bite. See Bite n. & v., and cf. Bit a morsel

sn.def: The part of a bridle, usually of iron, which is inserted in the mouth of a horse, and having appendages to which the reins are fastened.
sn.q: The foamy bridle with the bit of gold.

sn.def: Fig.: Anything which curbs or restrains.

entry.def: In the British West Indies, a fourpenny piece, or groat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Bitting
entry.def: To put a bridle upon; to put the bit in the mouth of.
imp. & p. p. of Bite.

entry.note: ☞ This word is used, also, like jot and whit, to express the smallest degree; as, he is not a bit wiser.
entry.ety: OE. bite, AS. bita, fr. bītan to bite; akin to D. beet, G. bissen bit, morsel, Icel. biti. See Bite v., and cf. Bit part of a bridle

sn.def: A part of anything, such as may be bitten off or taken into the mouth; a morsel; a bite. Hence: A small piece of anything; a little; a mite.
Somewhat; something, but not very great.
sn.q: My young companion was a bit of a poet.

sn.def: A tool for boring, of various forms and sizes, usually turned by means of a brace or bitstock. See Bitstock.
The part of a key which enters the lock and acts upon the bolt and tumblers.
The cutting iron of a plane.
In the Southern and Southwestern States, a small silver coin (as the real) formerly current; commonly, one worth about 12 1/2 cents; also, the sum of 12 1/2 cents.

cs.cd: piecemeal.

entry.ety: binary digit

sn.def: the smallest unit of information, equivalent to a choice between two alternatives, as yes or no; on or off.

the physical representation of a bit of information in a computer memory or a data storage medium. Within a computer circuit a bit may be represented by the state of a current or an electrical charge; in a magnetic storage medium it may be represented by the direction of magnetization; on a punched card or on paper tape it may be represented by the presence or absence of a hole at a particular point on the card or tape.

entry.def: 3d sing. pr. of Bid, for biddeth.

entry.def: Possessing the property of touching at two points.

def2.def: A line that touches a curve in two points.

entry.ety: OE. biche bicche, AS. bicce; cf. Icel. bikkja, G. betze peize

sn.def: The female of the canine kind, as of the dog, wolf, and fox.

an unpleasant, malicious, or offensive person.

complaining; griping.

To bite the dust To bite the ground
to fall in the agonies of death; as, he made his enemy bite the dust. To bite in Etching to corrode or eat into metallic plates by means of an acid. To bite the thumb atany one), formerly a mark of contempt, designed to provoke a quarrel; to defy. “Do you bite your thumb at us?” Shak. To bite the tongue to keep silence. Shak.
entry.vmorph: imp. Bit bĭt; p. p. Bitten bĭt"t'n Bit; p. pr. & vb. n. Biting
entry.ety: OE. biten, AS. bītan; akin to D. bijten, OS. bītan, OHG. bīzan, G. beissen, Goth. beitan, Icel. bīta, Sw. bita, Dan. bide, L. findere to cleave, Skr. bhid to cleave. √87. Cf. Fissure

sn.def: To seize with the teeth, so that they enter or nip the thing seized; to lacerate, crush, or wound with the teeth; as, to bite an apple; to bite a crust; the dog bit a man.
sn.q: Such smiling rogues as these, Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain.

sn.def: To puncture, abrade, or sting with an organ (of some insects) used in taking food.
To cause sharp pain, or smarting, to; to hurt or injure, in a literal or a figurative sense; as, pepper bites the mouth.
sn.q: Frosts dobitethe meads.

sn.def: To cheat; to trick; to take in.
To take hold of; to hold fast; to adhere to; as, the anchor bites the ground.
sn.q: The last screw of the rack having been turned so often that its purchase crumbled, . . . it turned and turned with nothing to bite.

sn.def: To seize something forcibly with the teeth; to wound with the teeth; to have the habit of so doing; as, does the dog bite?
To cause a smarting sensation; to have a property which causes such a sensation; to be pungent; as, it bites like pepper or mustard.
To cause sharp pain; to produce anguish; to hurt or injure; to have the property of so doing.
sn.q: At the last it [winebiteth like serpent, and stingeth like an adder.

To take or keep a firm hold; as, the anchor bites .

sn.q: I have known a very good fisher angle diligently four or six hours for a river carp, and not have a bite.

sn.def: The act of puncturing or abrading with an organ for taking food, as is done by some insects.
The wound made by biting; as, the pain of a dog's or snake's bite; the bite of a mosquito.
A morsel; as much as is taken at once by biting.
The hold which the short end of a lever has upon the thing to be lifted, or the hold which one part of a machine has upon another.
A cheat; a trick; a fraud.
sn.q: The baser methods of getting money by fraud and bite, by deceiving and overreaching.

sn.def: A sharper; one who cheats.
A blank on the edge or corner of a page, owing to a portion of the frisket, or something else, intervening between the type and paper.
One who, or that which, bites; that which bites often, or is inclined to bite, as a dog or fish.

entries.entry:
Bi"to n. Bi"to tree`
☞ The hard yellowish white wood is made into plows in Abyssinia; the bark is used in Farther India to stupefy fish; the ripe fruit is edible, when green it is an anthelmintic; the fermented juice is used as a beverage; the seeds yield a medicinal oil called zachun. The African name of the tree is hajilij.. Etym. uncertain Bot A small scrubby tree (Balanites Ægyptiaca) growing in dry regions of tropical Africa and Asia.

entry.cs: Bitter apple Bitter cucumber Bitter gourd . Bot See Colocynth. Bitter cress Bot a plant of the genus Cardamine, esp. Cardamine amara. Bitter earth Min tale earth; calcined magnesia. Bitter principles Chem a class of substances, extracted from vegetable products, having strong bitter taste but with no sharply defined chemical characteristics. Bitter salt Epsom salts; magnesium sulphate. Bitter vetch Bot a name given to two European leguminous herbs, Vicia Orobus and Ervum Ervilia. To the bitter end to the last extremity, however calamitous.
entry.ety: AS. biter; akin to Goth. baitrs, Icel. bitr, Dan., Sw., D., & G. bitter, OS. bittar, fr. root of E. bite. See Bite v. t.

sn.def: Having a peculiar, acrid, biting taste, like that of wormwood or an infusion of hops; as, a bitter medicine; bitter as aloes.
Causing pain or smart; piercing; painful; sharp; severe; as, a bitter cold day.
Causing, or fitted to cause, pain or distress to the mind; calamitous; poignant.
sn.q: It is an evil thing and bitter, that thou hast forsaken the Lord thy God.

sn.def: Characterized by sharpness, severity, or cruelty; harsh; stern; virulent; as, bitter reproach.
sn.q: Husbands, love your wives, and be not bitter against them.

sn.def: Mournful; sad; distressing; painful; pitiable.
sn.q: The Egyptians . . . made their lives bitter with hard bondage.
sn.syn: Acrid; sharp; harsh; pungent; stinging; cutting; severe; acrimonious.

entry.def: Any substance that is bitter. See Bitters.
To make bitter.
the butterbump or bittern.
any of various herbs of the genus Cardamine, having usually pinnate leaves and racemes of white, pink or purple flowers; cosmopolitan except in the Antarctic.
Full of bitterness.
A bitter compound used in adulterating beer; bittern.
Somewhat bitter.

entry.ety: G
entry.def: A roachlike European fish (Rhodima amarus).
In a bitter manner.

entry.note: ☞ The common European bittern is Botaurus stellaris. It makes, during the brooding season, a noise called by Dryden bumping, and by Goldsmith booming. The American bittern is Botaurus lentiginosus, and is also called stake-driver and meadow hen. See Stake-driver.
The name is applied to other related birds, as the least bittern Ardetta exilis), and the sun bittern.
entry.ety: OE. bitoure betore bitter, fr. F. butor; of unknown origin
entry.def: A wading bird of the genus Botaurus, allied to the herons, of various species.

entry.ety: From Bitter a.

sn.def: The brine which remains in salt works after the salt is concreted, having a bitter taste from the chloride of magnesium which it contains.
A very bitter compound of quassia, cocculus Indicus, etc., used by fraudulent brewers in adulterating beer.

entry.ety: AS. biternys; biter better + -nys = -ness

sn.def: The quality or state of being bitter, sharp, or acrid, in either a literal or figurative sense; implacableness; resentfulness; severity; keenness of reproach or sarcasm; deep distress, grief, or vexation of mind.
sn.q: The lip that curls with bitterness.
I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.

sn.def: A state of extreme impiety or enmity to God.
sn.q: Thou art in the gall of bitterness, and in the bond of iniquity.

sn.def: Dangerous error, or schism, tending to draw persons to apostasy.
sn.q: Looking diligently, . . . lest any root of bitterness springing up trouble you.

entry.def: The swamp hickory (Carya amara). Its thin-shelled nuts are bitter.

A plant (Lewisia rediviva) allied to the purslane, but with fleshy, farinaceous roots, growing in the mountains of Idaho, Montana, etc. It gives the name to the Bitter Root mountains and river. The Indians call both the plant and the river Spæt'lum.
A liquor, generally spirituous in which a bitter herb, leaf, or root is steeped.

entries.entry: Bit"ter spar". A common name of dolomite; -- so called because it contains magnesia, the soluble salts of which are bitter. See Dolomite.

entry.def: Sweet and then bitter or bitter and then sweet; esp. sweet with a bitter after taste; hence (Fig.), pleasant but painful.

sn.def: Anything which is bittersweet.
A kind of apple so called.

sd.def: A climbing shrub, with oval coral-red berries (Solanum dulcamara); woody nightshade. The whole plant is poisonous, and has a taste at first sweetish and then bitter. The branches are the officinal dulcamara.
An American woody climber (Celastrus scandens), whose yellow capsules open late in autumn, and disclose the red aril which covers the seeds; -- also called Roxbury waxwork.

entry.def: A species of Ambrosia Ambrosia artemisiæfolia); Roman worm wood.
A West Indian tree (Picræna excelsa) from the wood of which the bitter drug Jamaica quassia is obtained.
The yellow gentian (Gentiana lutea), which has a very bitter taste.

entry.ety: See Bit a morsel
entry.def: A small bit of anything, of indefinite size or quantity; a short distance.

entry.ety: See Bittern
entry.def: The bittern.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bitte, Icel. biti, a beam. �87
entry.def: A frame of two strong timbers fixed perpendicularly in the fore part of a ship, on which to fasten the cables as the ship rides at anchor, or in warping. Other bitts are used for belaying (belaying bitts), for sustaining the windlass (carrick bitts winch bitts, or windlass bitts), to hold the pawls of the windlass (pawl bitts) etc.

entry.ety: F. See Bitumen

Smeared with bitumen.
entry.q: The hatches caulked andbitumed.

entry.ety: L. bitumen: cf. F. bitume. Cf. Béton

sn.def: Mineral pitch; a black, tarry substance, burning with a bright flame; Jew's pitch. It occurs as an abundant natural product in many places, as on the shores of the Dead and Caspian Seas. It is used in cements, in the construction of pavements, etc. See Asphalt.

By extension, any one of the natural hydrocarbons, including the hard, solid, brittle varieties called asphalt, the semisolid maltha and mineral tars, the oily petroleums, and even the light, volatile naphthas.

entries.entry: Bi*tu"men proc"ess. Photog Any process in which advantage is taken of the fact that prepared bitumen is rendered insoluble by exposure to light, as in photolithography.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bituminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Bituminating

entry.ety: Cf. F. bituminisation
entry.def: The process of bituminizing.

of or pertaining to bitumen.

a mineral of a brown or black color, emitting an unpleasant smell when rubbed. That of Dalmatia is so charged with bitumen that it may be cut like soap.
an argillaceous shale impregnated with bitumen, often accompanying coal.

entry.ety: L. bituminosus: cf. F. bitumineux
entry.def: Having the qualities of bitumen; compounded with bitumen; containing bitumen.

entry.ety: F. bivalve; bi-L. bis) + valve valve

sn.def: A mollusk having a shell consisting of two lateral plates or valves joined together by an elastic ligament at the hinge, which is usually strengthened by prominences called teeth. The shell is closed by the contraction of two transverse muscles attached to the inner surface, as in the clam, -- or by one, as in the oyster. See Mollusca.
A pericarp in which the seed case opens or splits into two parts or valves.

entry.def: Having two shells or valves which open and shut, as the oyster and certain seed vessels.
Having two valves, as the oyster and some seed pods; bivalve.
Bivalvular.
Having two valves.

entry.def: Having two vaults or arches.

entry.ety: L. bivius; bis twice + via way

entry.def: To bewray; to reveal.

entry.ety: F. bizarre odd, fr. Sp. bizarro gallant, brave, liberal, prob. of Basque origin; cf. Basque bizarra beard, whence the meaning manly brave

relating to or concerned with the combined affairs of two administrative zones.
entry.illu: Bizonal currency was used in occupied Germany after World War II

entry.def: the chemical symbol for berkelium.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blabbedblăbd); p. pr. & vb. n. Blabbing
entry.ety: Cf. OE. blaberen, or Dan. blabbre, G. plappern, Gael. blabaran a stammerer; prob. of imitative origin. Cf. also Blubber v.
entry.def: To utter or tell unnecessarily, or in a thoughtless manner; to publish (secrets or trifles) without reserve or discretion; -- sometimes used with out.
entry.q: And yonder a vile physician blabbing The case of his patient.

entry.def: To talk thoughtlessly or without discretion; to tattle; to tell tales.
entry.q: She must burst or blab.

entry.ety: OE. blabbe
entry.def: One who blabs; a babbler; a telltale.
entry.q: Avoided as ablab.
For who will open himself to a blab or a babbler.

entry.def: one who blabr; a tattler; a telltale.
someone who gossips indiscreetly.

sn.def: tending to talk excessively.
prone to revealing secrets; -- of people.

entry.def: same as blabbermouthed 1.
a genus of insects consisting of giant cockroaches.

entry.note: ☞ Black is often used in self-explaining compound words; as, black-eyed, black-faced, black-haired, black-visaged.
entry.cs:
Black act the English statute 9 George I, which makes it a felony to appear armed in any park or warren, etc., or to hunt or steal deer, etc., with the face blackened or disguised. Subsequent acts inflicting heavy penalties for malicious injuries to cattle and machinery have been called black acts. Black angel Zoöl a fish of the West Indies and Florida (Holacanthus tricolor), with the head and tail yellow, and the middle of the body black. Black antimony Chem the black sulphide of antimony, Sb2S3, used in pyrotechnics, etc. Black bear Zoöl the common American bear (Ursus Americanus). Black beast. See Bête noire. Black beetle Zoöl the common large cockroach (Blatta orientalis). Black bonnet Zoöl the black-headed bunting (Embriza Schœniclus) of Europe. Black canker a disease in turnips and other crops, produced by a species of caterpillar. Black cat Zoöl the fisher, a quadruped of North America allied to the sable, but larger. See Fisher. Black cattle any bovine cattle reared for slaughter, in distinction from dairy cattle. Eng Black cherry. See under Cherry. Black cockatoo Zoöl the palm cockatoo. See Cockatoo. Black copper. Same as Melaconite. Black currant. Bot See Currant. Black diamond. Min See Carbonado. Black draught Med a cathartic medicine, composed of senna and magnesia. Black drop Med vinegar of opium; a narcotic preparation consisting essentially of a solution of opium in vinegar. Black earth mold; earth of a dark color. Woodward. Black flag the flag of a pirate, often bearing in white a skull and crossbones; a signal of defiance. Black flea Zoöl a flea beetle (Haltica nemorum) injurious to turnips. Black flux a mixture of carbonate of potash and charcoal, obtained by deflagrating tartar with half its weight of niter. Brande & C. Black Forest a translation of G. Schwarzwald
a forest in Baden and Würtemburg, in Germany; a part of the ancient Hercynian forest.
Black game, or Black grouse . Zoöl See Blackcock Grouse, and Heath grouse. Black grass Bot a grasslike rush of the species Juncus Gerardi, growing on salt marshes, and making good hay. Black gum Bot an American tree, the tupelo or pepperidge. See Tupelo. Black Hamburg (grape Bot a sweet and juicy variety of dark purple or “black” grape. Black horse Zoöl a fish of the Mississippi valley (Cycleptus elongatus), of the sucker family; the Missouri sucker. Black lemur Zoöl the Lemurniger of Madagascar; the acoumbo of the natives. Black list a list of persons who are for some reason thought deserving of censure or punishment; -- esp. a list of persons stigmatized as insolvent or untrustworthy, made for the protection of tradesmen or employers. See Blacklist v. t.
Black manganese Chem the black oxide of manganese, MnO2. Black Maria the close wagon in which prisoners are carried to or from jail. Black martin Zoöl the chimney swift. See Swift. Black moss Bot the common so-called long moss of the southern United States. See Tillandsia. Black oak. See under Oak. Black ocher. See Wad. Black pigment a very fine, light carbonaceous substance, or lampblack, prepared chiefly for the manufacture of printers' ink. It is obtained by burning common coal tar. Black plate sheet iron before it is tinned. Knight. Black quarter malignant anthrax with engorgement of a shoulder or quarter, etc., as of an ox. Black rat Zoöl one of the species of rats (Mus rattus), commonly infesting houses. Black rent. See Blackmail n., 3. Black rust a disease of wheat, in which a black, moist matter is deposited in the fissures of the grain. Black sheep one in a family or company who is unlike the rest, and makes trouble. Black silver. Min See under Silver. Black and tan black mixed or spotted with tan color or reddish brown; -- used in describing certain breeds of dogs. Black tea. See under Tea. Black tin Mining tin ore (cassiterite), when dressed, stamped and washed, ready for smelting. It is in the form of a black powder, like fine sand. Knight. Black walnut. See under Walnut. Black warrior Zoöl an American hawk (Buteo Harlani).
entry.ety: OE. blak, AS. blæc; akin to Icel. blakkr dark, swarthy, Sw. bläck ink, Dan. blæk, OHG. blach, LG. & D. blaken to burn with a black smoke. Not akin to AS. blāc, E. bleak pallid. √98

sn.def: Destitute of light, or incapable of reflecting it; of the color of soot or coal; of the darkest or a very dark color, the opposite of white; characterized by such a color; as, black cloth; black hair or eyes.
sn.q: O night, with hue so black!

sn.def: In a less literal sense: Enveloped or shrouded in darkness; very dark or gloomy; as, a black night; the heavens black with clouds.
sn.q: I spy a black, suspicious, threatening cloud.

sn.def: Fig.: Dismal, gloomy, or forbidding, like darkness; destitute of moral light or goodness; atrociously wicked; cruel; mournful; calamitous; horrible.
sn.q: This day'sblack Blackvillainy.
Arise,blackvengeance.
Black day.
Blackdespair.

sn.def: Expressing menace, or discontent; threatening; sullen; foreboding; as, to regard one with black looks.
sn.syn: Dark; murky; pitchy; inky; somber; dusky; gloomy; swart; Cimmerian; ebon; atrocious.

entry.def: Sullenly; threateningly; maliciously; so as to produce blackness.

entry.cs: Black and white writing or print; as, I must have that statement in black and white . Blue black a pigment of a blue black color. Ivory black a fine kind of animal charcoal prepared by calcining ivory or bones. When ground it is the chief ingredient of the ink used in copperplate printing. Berlin black. See under Berlin.

sn.def: That which is destitute of light or whiteness; the darkest color, or rather a destitution of all color; as, a cloth has a good black .
sn.q: Black is the badge of hell, The hue of dungeons, and the suit of night.

sn.def: A black pigment or dye.
A negro; a person whose skin is of a black color, or shaded with black; esp. a member or descendant of certain African races.

entry.sn:
A black garment or dress; as, she wears black
; pl. Obs Mourning garments of a black color; funereal drapery. Friends weeping, and blacks, and obsequies, and the like show death terrible. That was the full time they used to wear blacks for the death of their fathers.

sn.def: The part of a thing which is distinguished from the rest by being black.
sn.q: The black or sight of the eye.

sn.def: A stain; a spot; a smooch.
sn.q: Defiling her white lawn of chastity with ugly blacks of lust.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blacked; p. pr. & vb. n. Blacking
entry.ety: See Black a., and cf. Blacken

sn.def: To make black; to blacken; to soil; to sully.
sn.q: They have their teeth blacked, both men and women, for they say a dog hath his teeth white, therefore they will black theirs.
Sins which black thy soul.

sn.def: To make black and shining, as boots or a stove, by applying blacking and then polishing with a brush.

entry.ety: Black + Moor
entry.def: A negro or negress.
discolored by or as if by bruising; -- of skin.
the dark color of a bruise in the flesh, which is accompanied with a mixture of blue.
entry.q: To pinch the slatternsblack and blue.

entry.def: print or writing, especially the result of the printing process.

depicted only in black and white colors, or in shades of gray; also called monochromatic and monochrome; -- of images. Opposite of color or in color, and contrasting with polychrome technicolor three-color; as, a black-and-white TV; black-and-white film; the movie “Schindler's List” was shot in black and white .

entries.entry: Black" art` ☞ This name was given in the Middle Ages to necromancy, under the idea that the latter term was derived from niger black, instead of nekro`s, a dead person, and mantei`a, divination. Wright. . The art practiced by conjurers and witches; necromancy; conjuration; magic.

entry.def: Dark-visaged; swart.

sn.def: A composition for blacking shoes, boots, etc.; also, one for taking impressions of engraved work.
A ball of black color, esp. one used as a negative in voting; -- in this sense usually two words.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blackballed; p. pr. & vb. n. Blackballing

sn.def: To vote against, by putting a black ball into a ballot box; to reject or exclude, as by voting against with black balls; to ostracize.
sn.q: He was blackballed at two clubs in succession.

sn.def: To blacken (leather, shoes, etc.) with blacking.

entry.def: An earthy carbonate of iron containing considerable carbonaceous matter; -- valuable as an iron ore.

entries.entry:
Black" bass`. Zoöl
An edible, fresh-water fish of the United States, of the genus Micropterus. The small-mouthed kind is Micropterus dolomieī; the large-mouthed is Micropterus salmoides.
The sea bass. See Blackfish, 3.

entry.def: a comedy that treats of morbid, tragic, gloomy, or grotesque situations as a major element of the plot.

entry.ety: OE. blakberye, AS. blæcberie; blæc black + berie berry
entry.def: The fruit of several species of bramble (Rubus); also, the plant itself. Rubus fruticosus is the blackberry of England; Rubus villosus and Rubus Canadensis are the high blackberry and low blackberry of the United States. There are also other kinds.
garden plant whose capsule discloses when ripe a mass of seeds resembling a blackberry.

In England, a species of thrush (Turdus merula), a singing bird with a fin note; the merle. In America the name is given to several birds, as the Quiscalus versicolor, or crow blackbird; the Agelæus phœniceus, or red-winged blackbird; the cowbird; the rusty grackle, etc. See Redwing.

sn.def: Among slavers and pirates, a negro or Polynesian.
A native of any of the islands near Queensland; -- called also Kanaka.

entry.def: to engage in the slave trade.
A slave ship; a slaver.

sn.def: The kidnaping of negroes or Polynesians to be sold as slaves.
The act or practice of collecting natives of the islands near Queensland for service on the Queensland sugar plantations.

entry.def: A broad board painted black, or any black surface on which writing, drawing, or the working of mathematical problems can be done with chalk or crayons. It is much used in schools. In late 20th century similar boards of a green slate as well as some colored white became common; wrioting on the slate bioards may be done with chalk, but writing on the white boards is done with colored pens, such as grease pens, which leaves a trace that can be easily erased. The newer boards, usualy called chalkboards are nevertheless still sometimes referred to as blackboards.

entries.entry:
Black" book` blăk" b�k`. One of several books of a political character, published at different times and for different purposes; -- so called either from the color of the binding, or from the character of the contents.
A book compiled in the twelfth century, containing a description of the court of exchequer of England, an official statement of the revenues of the crown, etc.
A book containing details of the enormities practiced in the English monasteries and religious houses, compiled by order of their visitors under Henry VIII., to hasten their dissolution.
A book of admiralty law, of the highest authority, compiled in the reign of Edw. III.
A book kept for the purpose of registering the names of persons liable to censure or punishment, as in the English universities, or the English armies.
Any book which treats of necromancy.
A book containing a black list.
A book kept by a single man, containing a list of women whom he calls occasionally for a social date; -- usually used in the phrase little black book. jocose

entry.note: They are often brightly colored to assist recovery, not actually black.

sn.def: any electronic instrument or part of an instrument whose function is defined, but which is treated as a unit without consideration of the internal mechanisms; broadly, any device whose internal workings are considered as incomprehensible or mysterious by the user; as, to treat the meter as a black box and take its readings on faith.

a device which maintains a record of cockpit conversations and the readings of many of the instruments on board an aircraft, continuously or at frequent time intervals during a flight. It is of rugged design to withstand a violent crash, and is used to determine the causes of aircraft accidents.

entry.def: Having black eyebrows. Hence: Gloomy; dismal; threatening; forbidding.

entries.entry: Black*bur"ni*an war"bler. Named from Mrs. Blackburn, an English lady Zoöl A beautiful warbler of the United States (Dendroica Blackburniæ). The male is strongly marked with orange, yellow, and black on the head and neck, and has an orange-yellow breast.

sd.def: A small European song bird (Sylvia atricapilla), with a black crown; the mock nightingale.
An American titmouse (Parus atricapillus); the chickadee. Also called the black-cap chickadee.

sn.def: An apple roasted till black, to be served in a dish of boiled custard.
The black raspberry.

entry.def: Same as black cap1b}.
A clergyman; -- familiarly so called, as a soldier is sometimes called a redcoat or a bluecoat.
The male of the European black grouse (Tetrao tetrix, Linn.); -- so called by sportsmen. The female is called gray hen. See Heath grouse.
a comedy that treats of morbid, tragic, gloomy, or grotesque situations as a major element of the plot.

entries.entry: Black" death`. A pestilence which ravaged Europe and Asia in the fourteenth century.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blackened; p. pr. & vb. n. Blackening
entry.ety: See Black a., and cf. Black v. t.

sn.def: To make or render black.
sn.q: While the long funerals blacken all the way.

sn.def: To make dark; to darken; to cloud.
sn.q: Blackenedthe whole heavens.

sn.def: To defame; to sully, as reputation; to make infamous; as, vice blackens the character.
sn.syn: To denigrate; defame; vilify; slander; calumniate; traduce; malign; asperse.

entry.def: To grow black or dark.
One who blackens.
Having black eyes.

entries.entry: Black"-eyed` Su"san. Bot The coneflower, or yellow daisy (Rudbeckia hirta). The bladder ketmie.

entry.def: Having a black, dark, or gloomy face or aspect.
A tribe of North American Indians formerly inhabiting the country from the upper Missouri River to the Saskatchewan, but now much reduced in numbers.
See Bluefin.

entry.note: ☞ The name is locally applied to other fishes.

sn.def: A small kind of whale, of the genus Globicephalus, of several species. The most common is Globicephalus melas. Also sometimes applied to other whales of larger size.
The tautog of New England (Tautoga).
The black sea bass (Centropristis atrarius) of the Atlantic coast. It is excellent food fish; -- locally called also black Harry.
A fish of southern Europe (Centrolophus pompilus) of the Mackerel family.
The female salmon in the spawning season.

entries.entry: Black Flags. An organization composed originally of Chinese rebels that had been driven into Tonkin by the suppression of the Taiping rebellion, but later increased by bands of pirates and adventurers. It took a prominent part in fighting the French during their hostilities with Anam, 1873-85.

sn.def: In the United States, a small, venomous, two-winged fly of the genus Simulium of several species, exceedingly abundant and troublesome in the northern forests; -- called also buffalo gnat. The larvæ are aquatic. It sucks the blood of birds as well as humans and other mammals.
A black plant louse, as the bean aphis (Aphis fabæ), which infests e. g. beans and sugar beets; -- called also bean aphid.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Blackfeet; as, a Blackfoot Indian.

def2.def: A Blackfoot Indian.

entry.def: a weasellike mammal (Mustela nigripes) inhabiting the western North American prairie, having dark feet, a dark-tipped tail, and a dark face on a yellowish-brown coat. It is an endangered species.

entries.entry: Blackfriar Black" fri`ar . Eccl A friar of the Dominican order, so named becaise wearing wearing the black mantle of the Dominicans; -- called also predicant and preaching friar; in France, Jacobin. Also, sometimes, a Benedictine. Dominican.

Black Friday. Any Friday on which a public disaster has occurred, as: In England, December 6, 1745, when the news of the landing of the Pretender reached London, or May 11, 1866, when a financial panic commenced. In the United States, September 24, 1869, and September 18, 1873, on which financial panics began.

entry.ety: Black + guard

sn.def: The scullions and lower menials of a court, or of a nobleman's household, who, in a removal from one residence to another, had charge of the kitchen utensils, and being smutted by them, were jocularly called the “black guard”; also, the servants and hangers-on of an army.
sn.q: A lousy slave, that . . . rode with the black guard in the duke's carriage, 'mongst spits and dripping pans.

sn.def: The criminals and vagrants or vagabonds of a town or community, collectively.
A person of stained or low character, esp. one who uses scurrilous language, or treats others with foul abuse; a scoundrel; a rough.
sn.q: A man whose manners and sentiments are decidedly below those of his class deserves to be called a blackguard.

sn.def: A vagrant; a bootblack; a gamin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blackguarded; p. pr. & vb. n. Blackguarding
entry.def: To revile or abuse in scurrilous language.
Scurrilous; abusive; low; worthless; vicious; as, blackguard language.
The conduct or language of a blackguard; ruffianism.
In the manner of or resembling a blackguard; abusive; scurrilous; ruffianly.
having black head hair; -- of people.

entries.entry: Black Ham"burg. A sweet and juicy variety of European grape, of a dark purplish black color, much grown under glass in northern latitudes.

Black Hand. A trans. of Sp. mano negra
A Spanish anarchistic society, many of the members of which were imprisoned in 1883.
A lawless or blackmailing secret society, esp. among Italians. U. S

entry.def: The scaup duck.
A heart-shaped cherry with a very dark-colored skin.
Having a wicked, malignant disposition; morally bad.

entries.entry:
black" hole`. A dungeon or dark cell in a prison; a military lock-up or guardroom; -- now commonly with allusion to the cell (the Black Hole) in a fort at Calcutta (called the Black Hole of Calcutta), into which 146 English prisoners were thrust by the nabob Suraja Dowla on the night of June 20, 1765, and in which 123 of the prisoners died before morning from lack of air. A discipline of unlimited autocracy, upheld by rods, and ferules, and the black hole.
Physics, Astron An astronomical object whose mass is so condensed that the gravitational force does not allow anything, even light, to escape from its outer limit (the event horizon). The existence of such objects was first proposed from theoretical considerations. Because light cannot escape from such objects, they have not yet been detected with certainty (1998), but several "candidates" have been observed whose properties strongly suggest that they are black holes. Some theorists suggest that the centers of many galaxies may have large black holes at their cores. See also escape velocity.
from the astronomical black hole
a place into which things may enter, but can never emerge. Fig., Jocose "He was so disorganized his office was a black hole."

sn.def: Any preparation for making things black; esp. one for giving a black luster to boots and shoes, or to stoves.
The act or process of making black.

entry.def: Somewhat black.

sn.def: A name given by English miners to sphalerite, or zinc blende; -- called also false galena. See Blende.
Caramel or burnt sugar, used to color wines, spirits, ground coffee, etc.
A large leather vessel for beer, etc.
The Quercus nigra, or barren oak.
The ensign of a pirate.

entries.entry: Black` lead". Plumbago; graphite. It leaves a blackish mark somewhat like lead. See Graphite.

entry.def: To coat or to polish with black lead (graphite).

sn.def: A notorious gambler.
A disease among calves and sheep, characterized by a settling of gelatinous matter in the legs, and sometimes in the neck.

entries.entry: Black" let`ter. The old English or Gothic letter, in which the Early English manuscripts were written, and the first English books were printed. It was conspicuous for its blackness. See Type.

sn.def: Written or printed in black letter; as, a black-letter manuscript or book.
Given to the study of books in black letter; that is, of old books; out of date.
sn.q: Kemble, a black-letter man!

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the days in the calendar not marked with red letters as saints' days; -- compare red-letter.
Unlucky; inauspicious.

entry.def: To put in a black list as deserving of suspicion, censure, or punishment; esp. to put in a list of persons stigmatized as insolvent or untrustworthy, -- as tradesmen and employers do for mutual protection; as, to blacklist a workman who has been discharged. See Black list, under Black a.
entry.q: If you blacklist us, we will boycott you.

entry.def: the popular name for a form of the chronic lung disease pneumoconiosis which is observed among coal miners, and is caused by the inhalation of coal dust. It is thus named because of the black appearance of the lungs (pneumomelanosis) of those affected with the disease. See also the related condition anthracosis.
In a black manner; darkly, in color; gloomily; threateningly; atrociously.
entry.q: Deeds soblacklygrim and horrid.

cs.cd: to extort money by threats, as of injury to one's reputation.

entry.ety: Black + mail a piece of money

sn.def: A certain rate of money, corn, cattle, or other thing, anciently paid, in the north of England and south of Scotland, to certain men who were allied to robbers, or moss troopers, to be by them protected from pillage.
Payment of money exacted by means of intimidation; also, extortion of money from a person by threats of public accusation, exposure, or censure.
Black rent, or rent paid in corn, flesh, or the lowest coin, a opposed to “white rent”, which paid in silver.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blackmailed; p. pr. & vb. n. Blackmailing
entry.def: To extort money from by exciting fears of injury other than bodily harm, as injury to reputation, distress of mind, etc.; as, to blackmail a merchant by threatening to expose an alleged fraud.
One who extorts, or endeavors to extort, money, by black mailing.
The act or practice of extorting money by exciting fears of injury other than bodily harm, as injury to reputation.

entries.entry: Black" Ma*ri"a. a paddy wagon.

sn.def: the illicit buying and selling of goods, in violation of price controls, rationing, tax laws, prohibition of sale, etc.
a place where such illegal commerce is conducted, or the entire system of such illicit commerce considered as a whole; as, the black market accounts for twenty percent of the Ukrainian economy.

entry.def: distributed or sold illicitly.

entries.entry:
Black" Mon`day. Easter Monday, so called from the severity of that day in 1360, which was so unusual that many of Edward III.'s soldiers, then before Paris, died from the cold. Then it was not for nothing that my nose fell a bleeding on Black Monday last.
The first Monday after the holidays; -- so called by English schoolboys.
Black" monk`. A Benedictine monk.

entry.def: See Blackamoor.
Using foul or scurrilous language; slanderous.
The quality or state of being black; black color; atrociousness or enormity in wickedness.
entry.q: They're darker now than blackness.

sn.def: a suspension of radio or tv broadcasting.
any darkness resulting from the extinction of lights.
the failure of electric power for a general region sufficient to extinguish all normal lighting.
a momentary loss of consciousness.
partial or total loss of memory.
sn.illu: he has a total blackout for events of the evening

sn.def: a period during which artificial lighting is forbidden, as in a city as a precaution against an air raid.
the darkening of all stage lights, as at then end of a performance or between acts.
suppression of information distribution; as, there was a blackout on news from the military for the first day of the Gulf War.

the prohibition of the broadcasting of a sports event, such as a boxing match or football game, sometimes confined to one particular area. It is usually done to encourage sales of tickets to the event.

entry.def: to experience a temporary loss of consciousness, memory, or vision.

sn.def: to cause to become black, such as a stage, a computer screen, or a city.
to impose a blackout on (news or a sports event).
to make (a written text) illegible by applying a black ink over it; to blot out.
to suppress (a memory).

entry.ety: Black + poll head
entry.def: A warbler of the United States (Dendroica striata).

entries.entry: Black" pud"ding. A kind of sausage made of blood, suet, etc., thickened with meal. And fat black puddings, -- proper food, For warriors that delight in blood.

Black" Rod`. the usher to the Chapter of the Garter, so called from the black rod which he carries. He is of the king's chamber, and also usher to the House of Lords. Eng An usher in the legislature of British colonies. Committed to the custody of the Black Rod.

entry.def: See Colicroot.

sn.def: The name of a kind of in used in copperplate printing, prepared from the charred husks of the grape, and residue of the wine press.
Soot flying in the air.
Black garments, etc. See Black n., 4.

entry.def: One who makes crude potash, or black salts.

entries.entry: Black" salts`. Crude potash.

entry.ety: Blackin allusion to the color of the metal) + smith. Cf. Whitesmith

sn.def: A smith who works in iron with a forge, and makes iron utensils, horseshoes, etc.
sn.q: The blacksmith may forge what he pleases.

sn.def: A fish of the Pacific coast (Chromis punctipinnisorHeliastes punctipinnis), of a blackish color.

entry.note: ☞ The name is also applied to various other black serpents, as Natrix atra of Jamaica.
entry.def: A snake of a black color, of which two species are common in the United States, the Bascanium constrictor, or racer, sometimes six feet long, and the Scotophis Alleghaniensis, seven or eight feet long.

entries.entry: Black Spanish. One of an old and well-known Mediterranean breed of domestic fowls with glossy black plumage, blue legs and feet, bright red comb and wattles, and white face. They are remarkable as egg layers.

sn.def: A mixture of spirituous liquor (usually rum) and molasses.
sn.q: No blackstrap to-night; switchel, or ginger pop.

sn.def: Bad port wine; any common wine of the Mediterranean; -- so called by sailors.

entry.ety: Black + tail

sn.def: A fish; the ruff or pope.
The black-tailed deer (Cervus ColumbianusorCariacus Columbianus) of California and Oregon; also, the mule deer of the Rocky Mountains. See Mule deer.

entry.def: A spreading thorny shrub or small tree (Prunus spinosa), with blackish bark, and bearing little black plums, which are called sloes; the sloe.
A species of Cratægus or hawthorn (Cratægus tomentosa). Both are used for hedges.

requiring semiformal evening clothes, e. g. a black bowtie and a tuxedo or dinner jacket for men, and a formal dress for women; contrasted with white-tie, for a fully formal occasion, and with informal, and casual.

sn.def: a bituminous material used for providing a smooth paving to a road.
the surface of a road paved with blacktop{1}.

entry.def: paved with a bituminous material; -- of roads or paths; as, a blacktopped driveway.

entries.entry: Black" vom"it. Med A copious vomiting of dark-colored matter; or the substance so discharged; -- one of the most fatal symptoms in yellow fever.

sn.def: A lotion made by mixing calomel and lime water.
A wash that blackens, as opposed to whitewash; hence, figuratively, calumny.
sn.q: To remove as far as he can the modern layers of black wash, and let the man himself, fair or foul, be seen.

sn.def: same as defame.
to color with blackwash.

entries.entry: Black"wa`ter State. Nebraska; -- a nickname alluding to the dark color of the water of its rivers, due to the presence of a black vegetable mold in the soil.

entry.def: any of several human or animal diseases characterized by dark urine resulting from rapid breakdown of red blood cells; -- used especially of blackwater fever , a severe form of malaria caused by the blood parasite Plasmodium falciparum.
A name given to several dark-colored timbers. The East Indian black wood is from the tree Dalbergia latifolia.
Work wrought by blacksmiths; -- so called in distinction from that wrought by whitesmiths.

cs.cd: a genus of plants (Staphylea) with bladderlike seed pods.
a genus of low herbs (Vesicaria) with inflated seed pods.
a genus of shrubs (Colutea), with membranaceous, inflated pods.
