the larva of any species of tapeworm (Tænia), found in the flesh or other parts of animals. See Measle Cysticercus.
the common black rock weed of the seacoast (Fucus nodosus and Fucus vesiculosus) -- called also bladder tangle. See Wrack.

entry.ety: OE. bladder bleddre, AS. blǣdre blǣddre; akin to Icel. blaðra, SW. bläddra, Dan. blære, D. blaar, OHG. blātara the bladder in the body of animals, G. blatter blister, bustule; all fr. the same root as AS. blāwan, E. blow, to puff. See Blow to puff

sn.def: A bag or sac in animals, which serves as the receptacle of some fluid; as, the urinary bladder; the gall bladder ; -- applied especially to the urinary bladder, either within the animal, or when taken out and inflated with air.
Any vesicle or blister, especially if filled with air, or a thin, watery fluid.
A distended, membranaceous pericarp.
Anything inflated, empty, or unsound.
sn.q: To swim withbladdersof philosophy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bladdered; p. pr. & vb. n. Bladdering

sn.def: To swell out like a bladder with air; to inflate.
To put up in bladders; as, bladdered lard.

entry.def: similar to a bladder.
a medium-sized blackish-gray seal (Cystophora cristata) with a large inflatable sac on the head; of Arctic-Atlantic waters.

sn.def: a North American wild lobelia (Lobelia inflata) having small blue flowers and inflated capsules formerly used as an antispasmodic.
any of a number of annual or perennial herbs with inflated seed pods; some are placed in the genus Lesquerella.
any of several plants of the genus Physaria having racemose yellow flowers and inflated pods.
any of several hairy North American herbs having yellow racemose flowers and inflated pods.

entry.def: A genus (Utricularia) of aquatic or marshy plants, which usually bear numerous vesicles in the divisions of the leaves. These serve as traps for minute animals. See Ascidium.

sn.def: similar to and found with black rockweed.
common black rockweed used in preparing kelp and as manure.
sn.syn: black rockweed, bladder fucus, tang, Fucus vesiculosus.

entry.def: Having bladders; also, resembling a bladder.

entry.ety: OE. blade blad, AS. blæd leaf; akin to OS., D., Dan., & Sw. blad, Icel. blað, OHG. blat, G. blatt, and perh. to L. folium, Gr. fy`llon. The root is prob. the same as that of AS. blōwan, E. blow, to blossom. See Blow to blossom, and cf. Foil leaf of metal

sn.def: Properly, the leaf, or flat part of the leaf, of any plant, especially of gramineous plants. The term is sometimes applied to the spire of grasses.
sn.q: The crimson dulse . . . with its waving blade.
First the blade, then ear, after that the full corn in the ear.

sn.def: The cutting part of an instrument; as, the blade of a knife or a sword.
The broad part of an oar; also, one of the projecting arms of a screw propeller.
The scapula or shoulder blade.
The principal rafters of a roof.
The four large shell plates on the sides, and the five large ones of the middle, of the carapace of the sea turtle, which yield the best tortoise shell.
A sharp-witted, dashing, wild, or reckless, fellow; -- a word of somewhat indefinite meaning.
sn.q: He saw a turnkey in a trice Fetter a troublesome blade.

sn.def: The flat part of the tongue immediately behind the tip, or point.
sn.q: “Lower blade” implies, of course, the lower instead of the upper surface of the tongue.

entry.def: To furnish with a blade.
To put forth or have a blade.
entry.q: As sweet a plant, as fair a flower, is faded As ever in the Muses' garden bladed.

entry.def: The scapula. See Blade, 4.

sn.def: Having a blade or blades; as, a two-bladed knife.
sn.q: Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass.

sn.def: Divested of blades; as, bladed corn.
Composed of long and narrow plates, shaped like the blade of a knife.

entry.def: A long, thin, marine fish of Europe (Trichiurus lepturus); the ribbon fish.
A sword cutler.
Consisting of blades.
entry.q: Bladygrass.

entry.ety: See Blue
entry.def: Dark blue or bluish gray; lead-colored.

entry.ety: Blæ + berry; akin to Icel blāber, Sw. bl�bär, D. blaabær. Cf. Blueberry
entry.def: The bilberry.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Mendacious boasting; falsehood; humbug.

entry.ety: OE. blein bleyn, AS. blēgen; akin to Dan. blegn, D. blein; perh. fr. the same root as E. bladder. See Bladder

sn.def: An inflammatory swelling or sore; a bulla, pustule, or blister.
sn.q: Blotches and blains must all his flesh emboss.

sn.def: A bladder growing on the root of the tongue of a horse, against the windpipe, and stopping the breath.

entry.ety: Cf. F. blâmable
entry.def: Deserving of censure; faulty; culpable; reprehensible; censurable; blameworthy.

cs.cd: to be blamed, or deserving blame; in fault; as, the conductor was to blame for the accident.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blamed blāmd; p. pr. & vb. n. Blaming
entry.ety: OE. blamen, F. blâmer, OF. blasmer, fr. L. blasphemare to blaspheme, LL. also to blame, fr. Gr. blasfhmei^n to speak ill, to slander, to blaspheme, fr. bla`sfhmos evil speaking, perh, for blapsi`fhmos; bla`psis injury (fr. bla`ptein to injure) + fh`mh a saying, fr. fa`nai to say. Cf. Blaspheme, and see Fame

sn.def: To censure; to express disapprobation of; to find fault with; to reproach.
sn.q: We have none to blame but ourselves.

sn.def: To bring reproach upon; to blemish.
sn.q: She . . . blamed her noble blood.
You were to blame, I must be plain with you.

entry.ety: OE. blame, fr. F. blâme, OF. blasme, fr. blâmer, OF. blasmer, to blame. See Blame v.

sn.def: An expression of disapprobation fir something deemed to be wrong; imputation of fault; censure.
sn.q: Let me bear the blame forever.

sn.def: That which is deserving of censure or disapprobation; culpability; fault; crime; sin.
sn.q: Holy and without blame before him in love.

sn.def: Hurt; injury.
sn.syn: Censure; reprehension; condemnation; reproach; fault; sin; crime; wrongdoing.

entry.def: same as blameworthy.

sn.def: Faulty; meriting blame.
Attributing blame or fault; implying or conveying censure; faultfinding; censorious.

entry.usage: Blameless Spotless Faultless Stainless. We speak of a thing as blameless when it is free from blame, or the just imputation of fault; as, a blameless life or character. The others are stronger. We speak of a thing as faultless stainless, or spotless, only when we mean that it is absolutely without fault or blemish; as, a spotless or stainless reputation; a faultless course of conduct. The last three words apply only to the general character, while blameless may be used in reverence to particular points; as, in this transaction he was wholly blameless. We also apply faultless to personal appearance; as, a faultless figure; which can not be done in respect to any of the other words.
entry.def: Free from blame; without fault; innocent; guiltless; -- sometimes followed by of.
entry.q: A bishop then must be blameless.
Blameless still of arts that polish to deprave.
We will be blameless of this thine oath.

entry.def: In a blameless manner.
The quality or state of being blameless; innocence.
One who blames.
Deserving blame; culpable; reprehensible.

entry.ety: F., white

sn.def: A white cosmetic.
A white sauce of fat, broth, and vegetables, used esp. for braised meat.

entry.ety: F., fr. blanc white
entry.def: A kind of linen cloth made in Normandy, the thread of which is partly blanches before it is woven.

entry.usage: To whiten is the generic term, denoting, to render white; as, to whiten the walls of a room. Usually (though not of necessity) this is supposed to be done by placing some white coloring matter in or upon the surface of the object in question. To blanch is to whiten by the removal of coloring matter; as, to blanch linen. So the cheek is blanched by fear, i. e., by the withdrawal of the blood, which leaves it white.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blanched; p. pr. & vb. n. Blanching
entry.ety: OE. blanchen blaunchen, F. blanchir, fr. blanc white. See Blank a.

sn.def: To take the color out of, and make white; to bleach; as, to blanch linen; age has blanched his hair.
To bleach by excluding the light, as the stalks or leaves of plants, by earthing them up or tying them together.

sd.def: To make white by removing the skin of, as by scalding; as, to blanch almonds.
To whiten, as the surface of meat, by plunging into boiling water and afterwards into cold, so as to harden the surface and retain the juices.

sn.def: To give a white luster to (silver, before stamping, in the process of coining.).
To cover (sheet iron) with a coating of tin.
Fig.: To whiten; to give a favorable appearance to; to whitewash; to palliate.
sn.q: Blanch over the blackest and most absurd things.

entry.def: To grow or become white; as, his cheek blanched with fear; the rose blanches in the sun.
entry.q: Bonesblanching on the grass.

entry.ety: See Blench

sn.def: To avoid, as from fear; to evade; to leave unnoticed.
sn.q: Ifs and ands to qualify the words of treason, whereby every man might express his malice and blanch his danger.
I suppose you will not blanch Paris in your way.

sn.def: To cause to turn aside or back; as, to blanch a deer.

entry.def: To use evasion.
entry.q: Books will speak plain, when counselors blanch.

entry.def: Ore, not in masses, but mixed with other minerals.

entries.entry: Blan"chard lathe. After Thomas Blanchard, American inventor Mach A kind of wood-turning lathe for making noncircular and irregular forms, as felloes, gun stocks, lasts, spokes, etc., after a given pattern. The pattern and work rotate on parallel spindles in the same direction with the same speed, and the work is shaped by a rapidly rotating cutter whose position is varied by the pattern acting as a cam upon a follower wheel traversing slowly along the pattern.

entry.def: One who, or that which, blanches or whitens; esp., one who anneals and cleanses money; also, a chemical preparation for this purpose.
One who, or that which, frightens away or turns aside.
entry.q: And Gynecia, a blancher, which kept the dearest deer from her.
And so even now hath he divers blanchers belonging to the market, to let and stop the light of the gospel.

entries.entry: Blanch" hold`ing. Scots Law A mode of tenure by the payment of a small duty in white rent (silver) or otherwise.

entry.ety: 1st blanch + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the bleaching power of chloride of lime and potash; a chlorometer.

entry.ety: F. blancmanger, lit. white food; blanc white + manger to eat
entry.def: A preparation for desserts, etc., made from isinglass, sea moss, cornstarch, or other gelatinous or starchy substance, with mild, usually sweetened and flavored, and shaped in a mold.

entry.ety: F. See Blancmange
entry.def: A sort of fricassee with white sauce, variously made of capon, fish, etc.

entry.ety: L. blandus, of unknown origin

sn.def: Mild; soft; gentle; smooth and soothing in manner; suave; as, a bland temper; bland persuasion; a bland sycophant.
sn.q: Exhilarating vaporbland.

sn.def: Having soft and soothing qualities; not drastic or irritating; not stimulating; as, a bland oil; a bland diet.

entry.ety: Cf. L. blanditia blandities, fr. blandus. See Bland
entry.def: Flattery.

entry.ety: L. blandiloquentia; blandus mild + loqui to speak
entry.def: Mild, flattering speech.
Fair-spoken; flattering.

entry.ety: Same word as Blandish
entry.def: To blandish any one.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blandished; p. pr. & vb. n. Blandishing
entry.ety: OE. blaundisen, F. blandir, fr. L. blandiri, fr. blandus mild, flattering

sn.def: To flatter with kind words or affectionate actions; to caress; to cajole.
To make agreeable and enticing.
sn.q: Mustering all her wiles, With blandished parleys.

entry.def: One who uses blandishments.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. blandissement
entry.def: The act of blandishing; a word or act expressive of affection or kindness, and tending to win the heart; soft words and artful caresses; cajolery; allurement.
entry.q: Cowering low with blandishment.
Attacked by royal smiles, by female blandishments.

entry.def: In a bland manner; mildly; suavely.
The state or quality of being bland.

entry.cs:
Blank bar Law a plea put in to oblige the plaintiff in an action of trespass to assign the certain place where the trespass was committed; -- called also common bar. Blank cartridge a cartridge containing no ball. Blank deed. See Deed.
Blank doororBlank window
Arch a depression in a wall of the size of a door or window, either for symmetrical effect, or for the more convenient insertion of a door or window at a future time, should it be needed. Blank indorsement Law an indorsement which omits the name of the person in whose favor it is made; it is usually made by simply writing the name of the indorser on the back of the bill. Blank line Print a vacant space of the breadth of a line, on a printed page; a line of quadrats. Blank tire Mech a tire without a flange. Blank tooling. See Blind tooling, under Blind. Blank verse. See under Verse. Blank wall a wall in which there is no opening; a dead wall.
entry.ety: OE. blank blonc blaunc blaunche, fr. F. blanc, fem. blanche, fr. OHG. blanch shining, bright, white, G. blank; akin to E. blink, cf. also AS. blanc white. �98. See Blink, and cf. 1st Blanch

sn.def: Of a white or pale color; without color.
sn.q: To the blank moon Her office they prescribed.

sn.def: Free from writing, printing, or marks; having an empty space to be filled in with some special writing; -- said of checks, official documents, etc.; as, blank paper; a blank check; a blank ballot.
Utterly confounded or discomfited.
sn.q: Adam . . . astonied stood, and blank.

sn.def: Empty; void; without result; fruitless; as, a blank space; a blank day.

Lacking characteristics which give variety; as, a blank desert; a blank wall; destitute of interests, affections, hopes, etc.; as, to live a blank existence; destitute of sensations; as, blank unconsciousness.
Lacking animation and intelligence, or their associated characteristics, as expression of face, look, etc.; expressionless; vacant.
sn.q: Blankand horror-stricken faces.
The blank . . . glance of a half returned consciousness.

sn.def: Absolute; downright; unmixed; as, blank terror.

cs.cd: with an essential portion to be supplied by another; as, to make out a check in blank.

sn.def: Any void space; a void space on paper, or in any written instrument; an interval void of consciousness, action, result, etc; a void.
sn.q: I can not write a paper full, I used to do; and yet I will not forgive a blank of half an inch from you.
From this time there ensues a long blank in the history of French legislation.
I was ill. I can't tell how long -- it was a blank.

sn.def: A lot by which nothing is gained; a ticket in a lottery on which no prize is indicated.
sn.q: In Fortune's lottery lies A heap of blanks, like this, for one small prize.

sn.def: A paper unwritten; a paper without marks or characters a blank ballot; -- especially, a paper on which are to be inserted designated items of information, for which spaces are left vacant; a bland form.
sn.q: The freemen signified their approbation by an inscribed vote, and their dissent by a blank.

sn.def: A paper containing the substance of a legal instrument, as a deed, release, writ, or execution, with spaces left to be filled with names, date, descriptions, etc.
The point aimed at in a target, marked with a white spot; hence, the object to which anything is directed.
sn.q: Let me still remain The true blank of thine eye.

sn.def: Aim; shot; range.
sn.q: I have stood . . . within the blank of his displeasure For my free speech.

sn.def: A kind of base silver money, first coined in England by Henry V., and worth about 8 pence; also, a French coin of the seventeenth century, worth about 4 pence.
A piece of metal prepared to be made into something by a further operation, as a coin, screw, nuts.
A piece or division of a piece, without spots; as, the “double blank”; the “six blank.”

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blanked; p. pr. & vb. n. Blanking
entry.ety: Cf. 3d Blanch

sn.def: To make void; to annul.
To blanch; to make blank; to damp the spirits of; to dispirit or confuse.
sn.q: Each opposite that blanks the face of joy.

entry.note: ☞ The use of blankets formerly as curtains in theaters explains the following figure of Shakespeare.

cs.cd: a newspaper of folio size.
anything which damps, chills, dispirits, or discour�ges.

entry.ety: F. blanchet, OF. also blanket, a woolen waistcoat or shirt, the blanket of a printing press; prop. white woolen stuff, dim. of blanc white; blanquette a kind of white pear, fr. blanc white. See Blank a.

sn.def: A heavy, loosely woven fabric, usually of wool, and having a nap, used in bed clothing; also, a similar fabric used as a robe; or any fabric used as a cover for a horse.
A piece of rubber, felt, or woolen cloth, used in the tympan to make it soft and elastic.
A streak or layer of blubber in whales.
sn.q: Nor heaven peep through the blanket of the dark To cry, “Hold, hold!”

entry.cs: Blanket cattle. See Belted cattle, under Belted.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blanketed; p. pr. & vb. n. Blanketing

sn.def: To cover with a blanket.
sn.q: I'll . . . blanket my loins.

sn.def: To toss in a blanket by way of punishment.
sn.q: We'll have our men blanket 'em i' the hall.

sn.def: To take the wind out of the sails of (another vessel) by sailing to windward of her.

entries.entry: Blan"ket clause`. Law A clause, as in a blanket mortgage or policy, that includes a group or class of things, rather than a number mentioned individually and having the burden, loss, or the like, apportioned among them.

sn.def: Cloth for blankets.
The act or punishment of tossing in a blanket.
sn.q: That affair of the blanketing happened to thee for the fault thou wast guilty of.

entries.entry: Blanket mortgageorBlanket policy . One that covers a group or class of things or properties instead of one or more things mentioned individually, as where a mortgage secures various debts as a group, or subjects a group or class of different pieces of property to one general lien.
Blanket stitch. A buttonhole stitch worked wide apart on the edge of material, as blankets, too thick to hem.

sn.def: In a blank manner; without expression; vacuously; as, to stare blankly .
Directly; flatly; point blank.

entry.def: The state of being blank.

entry.ety: F. blanquette, from blanc white
entry.def: A white fricassee.

entry.ety: Sp. blanquillo whitish
entry.def: A large fish of Florida and the W. Indies (Caulolatilus chrysops). It is red, marked with yellow.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blared; p. pr. & vb. n. Blaring
entry.ety: OE. blaren bloren, to cry, woop; cf. G. plärren to bleat, D. blaren to bleat, cry, weep. Prob. an imitative word, but cf. also E. blast. Cf. Blore
entry.def: To sound loudly and somewhat harshly.
entry.q: The trumpetblared.

entry.def: To cause to sound like the blare of a trumpet; to proclaim loudly.
entry.q: To blare its own interpretation.

entry.def: The harsh noise of a trumpet; a loud and somewhat harsh noise, like the blast of a trumpet; a roar or bellowing.
entry.q: With blare of bugle, clamor of men.
His ears are stunned with the thunder's blare.

entry.def: a genus of mammals consisting of the shrews.
harshly or unpleasantly loud (in sound intensity); -- used mostly of electronic entertainment devices, such as TV, radio, or phonograph.

cs.cd: a stone in Blarney castle, Ireland (built in 1446), said to make those who kiss it proficient in the use of blarney.
cs.note: The origin of the stone is uncertain. In order to kiss the Blarney stone, which is located in the side of the castle, one must be held upside-down by the feet and lowered into the proper position from an opening in an overhang in the parapet. It is an experience eschewed by some tourists.

entry.ety: Blarney, a village and castle near Cork in Ireland
entry.def: Smooth, wheedling talk; flattery.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blarneyed -nĭd; p. pr. & vb. n. Blarneying
entry.def: To influence by blarney; to wheedle with smooth talk; to make or accomplish by blarney.
entry.q: Blarneyedthe landlord.
Had blarneyed his way from Long Island.

entry.ety: F., p. p. of blaser

sn.def: Having the sensibilities deadened by excess or frequency of enjoyment; sated or surfeited with pleasure; uninterested because of frequent exposure or indulgence; used up.
very sophisticated; versed in the ways of the world.
sn.illu: the blase traveler refers to the ocean he has crossed as `the pond'

sn.def: uninterested and attaching little importance; -- of attitudes toward duties.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blasphemed -fēmf"; p. pr. & vb. n. Blaspheming
entry.ety: OE. blasfemēn, L. blasphemare, fr. Gr. blasfhmei^n: cf. F. blasphémer. See Blame v.

sn.def: To speak of, or address, with impious irreverence; to revile impiously (anything sacred); as, to blaspheme the Holy Spirit.
sn.q: So Dagon shall be magnified, and God, Besides whom is no god, compared with idols, Disglorified, blasphemed, and had in scorn.
How long, O Lord, holy and true, dost thou not judge and avenge thyself on all those who thus continually blaspheme thy great and all-glorious name?

sn.def: Figuratively, of persons and things not religiously sacred, but held in high honor: To calumniate; to revile; to abuse.
sn.q: You do blaspheme the good in mocking me.
Those who from our labors heap their board,Blaspheme their feeder and forget their lord.

entry.def: To utter blasphemy.
entry.q: He that shall blaspheme against the Holy Ghost hath never forgiveness.

entry.def: One who blasphemes.
entry.q: And each blasphemer quite escape the rod, Because the insult's not on man, but God ?

entry.note: ☞ Formerly this word was accented on the second syllable, as in the above example.
entry.ety: L. blasphemus, Gr. �
entry.def: Speaking or writing blasphemy; uttering or exhibiting anything impiously irreverent; profane; as, a blasphemous person; containing blasphemy; as, a blasphemous book; a blasphemous caricature.
entry.q: Blasphemouspublications.
Nor from the Holy One of Heaven Refrained his tongue blasphemous.

entry.def: In a blasphemous manner.

entry.note: ☞ When used generally in statutes or at common law, blasphemy is the use of irreverent words or signs in reference to the Supreme Being in such a way as to produce scandal or provoke violence.
entry.ety: L. blasphemia, Gr. �: cf. OF. blasphemie

sn.def: An indignity offered to God in words, writing, or signs; impiously irreverent words or signs addressed to, or used in reference to, God; speaking evil of God; also, the act of claiming the attributes or prerogatives of deity.
Figuratively, of things held in high honor: Calumny; abuse; vilification.
sn.q: Punished for his blasphemy against learning.

entries.entry: -blast. Gr. blasto`s sprout, shoot A suffix or terminal formative, used principally in biological terms, and signifying growth formation; as, bioblast, epiblast, mesoblast, etc.

entry.note: ☞ The terms hot blast and cold blast are employed to designate whether the current is heated or not heated before entering the furnace. A blast furnace is said to be in blast while it is in operation, and out of blast when not in use.

cs.cd: a furnace, usually a shaft furnace for smelting ores, into which air is forced by pressure.
a hole in the bottom of a pump stock through which water enters.
a fixed or variable orifice in the delivery end of a blast pipe; -- called also blast orifice.
in complete operation; in a state of great activity. See Blast n., 2.

entry.ety: AS. blǣst a puff of wind, a blowing; akin to Icel. blāstr, OHG. blāst, and fr. a verb akin to Icel. blāsa to blow, OHG. blâsan, Goth. blēsanin comp.); all prob. from the same root as E. blow. See Blow to eject air

sn.def: A violent gust of wind.

A forcible stream of air from an orifice, as from a bellows, the mouth, etc. Hence: The continuous blowing to which one charge of ore or metal is subjected in a furnace; as, to melt so many tons of iron at a blast .
The exhaust steam from and engine, driving a column of air out of a boiler chimney, and thus creating an intense draught through the fire; also, any draught produced by the blast.
The sound made by blowing a wind instrument; strictly, the sound produces at one breath.
sn.q: One blast upon his bugle horn Were worth a thousand men.
The blast of triumph o'er thy grave.

sn.def: A sudden, pernicious effect, as if by a noxious wind, especially on animals and plants; a blight.
sn.q: By the blast of God they perish.
Virtue preserved from fell destruction's blast.

sn.def: The act of rending, or attempting to rend, heavy masses of rock, earth, etc., by the explosion of gunpowder, dynamite, etc.; also, the charge used for this purpose.
sn.q: Largeblastsare often used.

sn.def: A flatulent disease of sheep.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Blasting

sn.def: To injure, as by a noxious wind; to cause to wither; to stop or check the growth of, and prevent from fruit-bearing, by some pernicious influence; to blight; to shrivel.
sn.q: Seven thin ears, and blasted with the east wind.

sn.def: Hence, to affect with some sudden violence, plague, calamity, or blighting influence, which destroys or causes to fail; to visit with a curse; to curse; to ruin; as, to blast pride, hopes, or character.
sn.q: I'll cross it, though it blast me.
Blasted with excess of light.

sn.def: To confound by a loud blast or din.
sn.q: Trumpeters, With brazen din blast you the city's ear.

sn.def: To rend open by any explosive agent, as gunpowder, dynamite, etc.; to shatter; as, to blast rocks.
To be blighted or withered; as, the bud blasted in the blossom.
To blow; to blow on a trumpet.
sn.q: Toke his blake trumpe faste And gan to puffen and to blaste.

sn.def: Blighted; withered.
sn.q: Upon this blasted heath.

sn.def: Confounded; accursed; detestable.
sn.q: Some of her own blasted gypsies.

sn.def: Rent open by an explosive.
sn.q: The blasted quarry thunders, heard remote.

entries.entry: Blas*te"ma Blas*te"ma n.; pl.Blastemata. Gr. bla`sthma bud, sprout Biol The structureless, protoplasmic tissue of the embryo; the primitive basis of an organ yet unformed, from which it grows.

entry.def: Relating to the blastema; rudimentary.
Connected with, or proceeding from, the blastema; blastemal.
One who, or that which, blasts or destroys.

entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout, fr. � to grow
entry.def: A small, clear space in the segments of the ovum, the precursor of the nucleus.

sn.def: A blast; destruction by a blast, or by some pernicious cause.
sn.q: I have smitten you with blasting and mildew.

sn.def: The act or process of one who, or that which, blasts; the business of one who blasts.

entries.entry: Blast lamp. A lamp provided with some arrangement for intensifying combustion by means of a blast.

entry.def: A sudden stroke or injury produced by some destructive cause.

entry.ety: Gr. � sprout, germ + � fruit
entry.def: Germinating inside the pericarp, as the mangrove.

entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout + koi^los hollow
entry.def: The cavity inside a blastula; -- also called segmentation cavity.
of or pertaining to a blastocoel.

entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout + E. cyst
entry.def: The germinal vesicle.
an undifferentiated embryonic cell.

entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout + E. derm
entry.def: the early stage of an embryo after the first cleavages of the ovum; also, the layer of cells of which the early embryo is composed;
the early embryo developing from a blastodisc, after the blastocoel has formed.
in an insect embryo, the layer of cells that surrounds the internal mass of the yolk.
Of or pertaining to the blastoderm.
a disc-shaped layer of cells on the surface of the yolk mass of an egg (such as that of a bird) which develops to form the embryo.
the launching of a rocket, especially of a spacecraft, under its own power.
to begin ascending from the ground under rocket power; -- of a rocket.

entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout + E. genesis
entry.def: Multiplication or increase by gemmation or budding.
One of the Blastoidea.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. blasto`s sprout + -oid
entry.def: One of the divisions of Crinoidea found fossil in paleozoic rocks; pentremites. They are so named on account of their budlike form.

entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout + -mere
entry.def: One of the segments first formed by the division of the ovum.
any of various yeastlike budding fungi of the genus Blastomyces; -- they may cause disease in humans and other animals.
any of several fungal infections caused by blastomycetes; they are characterized by inflammatory lesions of skin and mucous membranes or internal organs.
of or pertaining to blastomycosis.
Relating to the blastophore.

entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout + � to bear
entry.def: That portion of the spermatospore which is not converted into spermatoblasts, but carries them.
of or pertaining to a blastopore.

entry.note: See Illust. of Invagination
entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout + E. pore
entry.def: The pore or opening leading into the cavity of invagination, or archenteron.

entry.note: See Illust. of Invagination
entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout + E. sphere
entry.def: The hollow globe or sphere formed by the arrangement of the blastomeres on the periphery of an impregnated ovum.

entry.ety: Gr. blasto`s sprout, bud + � a pillar
entry.def: In certain hydroids, an imperfect zooid, whose special function is to produce medusoid buds. See Hydroidea, and Athecata.

entries.entry: Blast" pipe`. The exhaust pipe of a steam engine, or any pipe delivering steam or air, when so constructed as to cause a blast.

entry.ety: NL., dim. of Gr. blasto`s a sprout
entry.def: That stage in the development of the ovum in which the outer cells of the morula become more defined and form the blastoderm.
Same as Blastula.

sn.def: Affected by blasts; gusty.
Causing blast or injury.

entry.def: To cry, as a calf or sheep; to bleat; to make a senseless noise; to talk inconsiderately.
To utter inconsiderately.
entry.q: If I have anything on my mind, I have to blat it right out.

entry.def: Blatant quality.

entry.ety: Cf. Bleat
entry.def: Bellowing, as a calf; bawling; brawling; clamoring; disagreeably clamorous; sounding loudly and harshly.
entry.q: Harsh andblatanttone.
A monster, which the blatant beast men call.
Glory, that blatant word, which haunts some military minds like the bray of the trumpet.

entry.def: In a blatant manner.
to of sheep, goats, or calves.
bashful; timid; sheepish; -- chiefly Scottish.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blathered; p. pr. & vb. n. Blathering
entry.ety: Icel. blaðra. Cf. Blatherskite
entry.def: To talk foolishly, or nonsensically, or concerning matters of no consequence.
Voluble, foolish, or nonsensical talk; -- often in the pl.
A blustering, talkative fellow.

entry.ety: L. blaterare to babble: cf. F. blatérer to bleat
entry.def: To prate; to babble; to rail; to make a senseless noise; to patter.
entry.q: The rainblattered.
They procured . . . preachers to blatter against me, . . . so that they had place and time to belie me shamefully.

entry.ety: L. blateratio a babbling
entry.def: Blattering.
One who blatters; a babbler; a noisy, blustering boaster.
Senseless babble or boasting.

entry.ety: L. blatero -onis
entry.def: A senseless babbler or boaster.
entry.q: I hate suchblatteroons.

entry.ety: D. blauwbok
entry.def: The blue buck. See Blue buck, under Blue.

entry.ety: AS. bl�ge, fr. bl�c, bleak, white; akin to Icel. bleikja, OHG. bleicha, G. bleihe. See Bleak n. & a.
entry.def: A fish. See Bleak n.

entry.cs: In a blaze on fire; burning with a flame; filled with, giving, or reflecting light; excited or exasperated. Like blazes furiously; rapidly. Low “The horses did along like blazes tear.” Poem in Essex dialect.
entry.note: ☞ In low language in the U. S., blazes is frequently used of something extreme or excessive, especially of something very bad; as, blue as blazes. Neal.
entry.usage: A blaze and a flame are both produced by burning gas. In blaze the idea of light rapidly evolved is prominent, with or without heat; as, the blaze of the sun or of a meteor. Flame includes a stronger notion of heat; as, he perished in the flames.
entry.ety: OE. blase, AS. blæse blase; akin to OHG. blass whitish, G. blass pale, MHG. blas torch, Icel. blys torch; perh. fr. the same root as E. blast. Cf. Blast Blush Blink

sn.def: A stream of gas or vapor emitting light and heat in the process of combustion; a bright flame.
sn.q: To heaven theblazeuprolled.

sn.def: Intense, direct light accompanied with heat; as, to seek shelter from the blaze of the sun.
sn.q: O dark, dark, dark, amid the blaze of noon!

sn.def: A bursting out, or active display of any quality; an outburst; a brilliant display.
sn.q: Fierceblazeof riot.
Hisblazeof wrath.
For what is glory but the blaze of fame?

sn.ety: Cf. D. bles; akin to E. blaze light
sn.def: A white spot on the forehead of a horse.
A spot made on trees by chipping off a piece of the bark, usually as a surveyor's mark.
sn.q: Three blazes in a perpendicular line on the same tree indicating a legislative road, the single blaze a settlement or neighborhood road.

cs.cd: to discharge a firearm, or to continue firing; -- said esp. of a number of persons, as a line of soldiers. Also used (fig.) of speech or action.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blazed; p. pr. & vb. n. Blazing

sn.def: To shine with flame; to glow with flame; as, the fire blazes .
To send forth or reflect glowing or brilliant light; to show a blaze.
sn.q: And far and wide the icy summit blazed.

sn.def: To be resplendent.
To mark (a tree) by chipping off a piece of the bark.
sn.q: I found my way by the blazed trees.

sn.def: To designate by blazing; to mark out, as by blazed trees; as, to blaze a line or path.
sn.q: Champollion died in 1832, having done little more than blaze out the road to be traveled by others.

entry.ety: OE. blasen to blow; perh. confused with blast and blaze a flame, OE. blase. Cf. Blaze v. i., and see Blast

sn.def: To make public far and wide; to make known; to render conspicuous.
sn.q: On charitable lists he blazed his name.
To blaze those virtues which the good would hide.

sn.def: To blazon.

entry.def: One who spreads reports or blazes matters abroad.
entry.q: Blazersof crime.

sn.def: Anything that blazes or glows, as with heat or flame.
A light jacket, usually of wool or silk and of a bright color, for wear at tennis, cricket, or other sport.
The dish used when cooking directly over the flame of a chafing-dish lamp, or the coals of a brasier.

entry.cs: Blazing star. A comet. Obs A brilliant center of attraction. Bot A name given to several plants; as, to Chamælirium luteum of the Lily family; Liatris squarrosa; and Aletris farinosa, called also colicroot and star grass.
entry.def: Burning with a blaze; as, a blazing fire; blazing torches.

sn.def: any of various North American plants of the genus Liatris having racemes or panicles of small discoid flower heads.
sn.syn: blazing star, button snakeroot, gayfeather, snakeroot.

entry.ety: OE. blason blasoun, shield, fr. F. blason coat of arms, OF. shield, from the root of AS. blæse blaze, i. e., luster, splendor, MHG. blas torch See Blaze n.

sn.def: A shield.
An heraldic shield; a coat of arms, or a bearing on a coat of arms; armorial bearings.
sn.q: Their blazon o'er his towers displayed.

sn.def: The art or act of describing or depicting heraldic bearings in the proper language or manner.
Ostentatious display, either by words or other means; publication; show; description; record.
sn.q: Obtrude the blazon of their exploits upon the company.
Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions, and spirit, Do give thee fivefold blazon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blazoned; p. pr. & vb. n. Blazoning
entry.ety: From blazon, n.; confused with 4th blaze: cf. F. blasonner

sn.def: To depict in colors; to display; to exhibit conspicuously; to publish or make public far and wide.
sn.q: Thyself thou blazon'st.
There pride sits blazoned on th' unmeaning brow.
To blazon his own worthless name.

sn.def: To deck; to embellish; to adorn.
sn.q: She blazons in dread smiles her hideous form.

sn.def: To describe in proper terms (the figures of heraldic devices); also, to delineate (armorial bearings); to emblazon.
sn.q: The coat of , arms, which I am not herald enough to blazon into English.

entry.def: To shine; to be conspicuous.
One who gives publicity, proclaims, or blazons; esp., one who blazons coats of arms; a herald.
The act of blazoning; blazoning; emblazonment.

sn.def: Same as Blazon, 3.
sn.q: The principles of blazonry.

sn.def: A coat of arms; an armorial bearing or bearings.
sn.q: The blazonry of Argyle.

sn.def: Artistic representation or display.

entry.def: The part of a tree which lies immediately under the bark; the alburnum or sapwood.
See Blaeberry.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bleached; p. pr. & vb. n. Bleaching
entry.ety: OE. blakien blechen, v. t. & v. i., AS. blācian bl�can, to grow pale; akin to Icel. bleikja, Sw. bleka, Dan. blege, D. bleeken, G. bleichen, AS. blāc pale. See Bleak a.
entry.def: To make white, or whiter; to remove the color, or stains, from; to blanch; to whiten.
entry.q: The destruction of the coloring matters attached to the bodies to be bleached is effected either by the action of the air and light, of chlorine, or of sulphurous acid.
Immortal liberty, whose look sublime Hath bleached the tyrant's cheek in every varying clime.

entry.def: To grow white or lose color; to whiten.
Whitened; make white.
entry.q: Let their bleached bones, and blood's unbleaching stain, Long mark the battlefield with hideous awe.

entry.def: One who whitens, or whose occupation is to whiten, by bleaching.

entries.entry: Bleach"er*y n.; pl.Bleacheries. A place or an establishment where bleaching is done.

cs.cd: a powder for bleaching, consisting of chloride of lime, or some other chemical or chemicals.

entry.def: The act or process of whitening, by removing color or stains; esp. the process of whitening fabrics by chemical agents.

entry.ety: OE. blac bleyke bleche, AS. blāc blǣc, pale, wan; akin to Icel. bleikr, Sw. blek, Dan. bleg, OS. blēk, D. bleek, OHG. pleih, G. bleich; all from the root of AS. blīcan to shine; akin to OHG. blīchen to shine; cf. L. flagrare to burn, Gr. fle`gein to burn, shine, Skr. bhrāj to shine, and E. flame. √98. Cf. Bleach Blink Flame

sn.def: Without color; pale; pallid.
sn.q: When she came out she looked as pale and as bleak as one that were laid out dead.

sn.def: Desolate and exposed; swept by cold winds.
sn.q: Wastes too bleak to rear The common growth of earth, the foodful ear.
At daybreak, on the bleak sea beach.

sn.def: Cold and cutting; cheerless; as, a bleak blast.

entry.note: ☞ The silvery pigment lining the scales of the bleak is used in the manufacture of artificial pearls.
entry.ety: From Bleak a., cf. Blay
entry.def: A small European river fish (Leuciscus alburnus), of the family Cyprinidæ; the blay.
Bleak.

entry.ety: See Blear v.

sn.def: Dim or sore with water or rheum; -- said of the eyes.
sn.q: His blear eyes ran in gutters to his chin.

sn.def: Causing or caused by dimness of sight; dim.
sn.q: Power to cheat the eye with blear illusion.

cs.cd: to deceive; to impose upon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bleared; p. pr. & vb. n. Blearing
entry.ety: OE. bleren; cf. Dan. plire to blink, Sw. plira to twinkle, wink, LG. plieren; perh. from the same root as E. blink. See Blink, and cf. Blur
entry.def: To make somewhat sore or watery, as the eyes; to dim, or blur, as the sight. Figuratively: To obscure (mental or moral perception); to blind; to hoodwink.
entry.q: That tickling rheums Should ever tease the lungs and blear the sight.

entry.def: Dimmed, as by a watery humor; affected with rheum.
entry.q: Dardanian wives, With bleared visages, come forth to view The issue of the exploit.

entry.def: A disease of the eyelids, consisting in chronic inflammation of the margins, with a gummy secretion of sebaceous matter.

sn.def: Having sore eyes; having the eyes dim with rheum; dim-sighted.
sn.q: The blear-eyed Crispin.

sn.def: Lacking in perception or penetration; short-sighted; as, a blear-eyed bigot.

entry.def: The state of being blear-eyed.
Somewhat blear.
having eyes sore or unfocused, due to weariness or excessive drinking; same as blear-eyed{1.

sn.def: same as teary.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bleated; p. pr. & vb. n. Bleating
entry.ety: OE. bleten, AS. bl�tan; akin to D. blaten bleeten, OHG. blāzan plāzan; prob. of imitative origin
entry.def: To make the noise of, or one like that of, a sheep; to cry like a sheep or calf.
entry.q: Then suddenly was heard along the main, To low the ox, to bleat the woolly train.
The ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baas, will never answer a calf when he bleats.

entry.def: A plaintive cry of, or like that of, a sheep.
entry.q: The bleat of fleecy sheep.

entry.def: One who bleats; a sheep.
entry.q: In cold, stiff soils the bleaters oft complain Of gouty ails.

entry.def: Crying as a sheep does.
entry.q: Then came the shepherd back with his bleating flocks from the seaside.

entry.def: The cry of, or as of, a sheep.

entry.ety: Prov. E. bleb bleib blob, bubble, blister. This word belongs to the root of blub blubber blabber, and perh. blow to puff
entry.def: A large vesicle or bulla, usually containing a serous fluid; a blister; a bubble, as in water, glass, etc.
entry.q: Arsenic abounds with air blebs.

entry.def: marred by small bubbles or small particles of foreign material; -- of glass or quartzite.
Containing blebs, or characterized by blebs; as, blebby glass.
To blacken; also, to defile.
imp. & p. p. of Bleed.

entry.ety: AS. bleó bleóh
entry.def: Complexion; color; hue; likeness; form.
entry.q: For him which is so bright of blee.
That boy has a strong blee of his father.

cs.cd: to cause extreme pain, as from sympathy or pity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bled; p. pr. & vb. n. Bleeding
entry.ety: OE. bleden, AS. bl�dan, fr. bl�d blood; akin to Sw. blöda, Dan. blöde, D. bloeden, G. bluten. See Blood

sn.def: To emit blood; to lose blood; to run with blood, by whatever means; as, the arm bleeds; the wound bled freely; to bleed at the nose.
To withdraw blood from the body; to let blood; as, Dr. A. bleeds in fevers.
To lose or shed one's blood, as in case of a violent death or severe wounds; to die by violence.
sn.q: Cæsar mustbleed.
The lamb thy riot dooms to bleed to-day.

sn.def: To issue forth, or drop, as blood from an incision.
sn.q: For me the balm shall bleed.

sn.def: To lose sap, gum, or juice; as, a tree or a vine bleeds when tapped or wounded.
To pay or lose money; to have money drawn or extorted; as, to bleed freely for a cause.
To let blood from; to take or draw blood from, as by opening a vein.
To lose, as blood; to emit or let drop, as sap.
sn.q: A decaying pine of stately size, bleeding amber.

sn.def: To draw money from (one); to induce to pay; as, they bled him freely for this fund.

entry.def: One who, or that which, draws blood.
One in whom slight wounds give rise to profuse or uncontrollable bleeding.
Emitting, or appearing to emit, blood or sap, etc.; also, expressing anguish or compassion.
A running or issuing of blood, as from the nose or a wound; a hemorrhage; the operation of letting blood, as in surgery; a drawing or running of sap from a tree or plant.
a short high-pitched tone produced as a signal or warning.
to to obscure or replace (an offensive word or phrase) by substituting a beeping sound while broadcasting.

entry.note: Used as a euphemistic emphatic adjective to express displeasure, in place of damned goddammed or stronger (more offensive) words.
entry.def: damned.
same as bleep v. t..

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blemished; p. pr. & vb. n. Blemishing
entry.ety: OE. blemissen blemishen, OF. blemir blesmir, to strike, injure, soil, F. blêmir to grow pale, fr. OF. bleme blesme, pale, wan, F. blême, prob. fr. Icel blāman the livid color of a wound, fr. blār blue; akin to E. blue. OF. blemir properly signifies to beat one (black and) blue, and to render blue or dirty. See Blue

sn.def: To mark with deformity; to injure or impair, as anything which is well formed, or excellent; to mar, or make defective, either the body or mind.
sn.q: Sin is a soil which blemisheth the beauty of thy soul.

sn.def: To tarnish, as reputation or character; to defame.
sn.q: There had nothing passed between us that might blemish reputation.

entries.entry: Blem"ish n.; pl.Blemishes. Any mark of deformity or injury, whether physical or moral; anything that diminishes beauty, or renders imperfect that which is otherwise well formed; that which impairs reputation. He shall take two he lambs without blemish, and one ewe lamb of the first year without blemish. The reliefs of an envious man are those little blemishes and imperfections that discover themselves in an illustrious character. Spot; speck; flaw; deformity; stain; defect; fault; taint; reproach; dishonor; imputation; disgrace.

entry.def: Without blemish; spotless.
entry.q: A life in all so blemishless.

entry.def: The state of being blemished; blemish; disgrace; damage; impairment.
entry.q: For dread of blame and honor's blemishment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blenched; p. pr. & vb. n. Blenching
entry.ety: OE. blenchen to blench, elude, deceive, AS. blencan to deceive; akin to Icel. blekkja to impose upon. Prop. a causative of blink to make to wink, to deceive. See Blink, and cf. 3d Blanch

sn.def: To shrink; to start back; to draw back, from lack of courage or resolution; to flinch; to quail.
sn.q: Blench not at thy chosen lot.
This painful, heroic task he undertook, and never blenched from its fulfillment.

sn.def: To fly off; to turn aside.
sn.q: Though sometimes you do blench from this to that.

sn.def: To baffle; to disconcert; to turn away; -- also, to obstruct; to hinder.
sn.q: Ye should have somewhat blenched him therewith, yet he might and would of likelihood have gone further.

sn.def: To draw back from; to deny from fear.
sn.q: He now blenched what before he affirmed.

entry.def: A looking aside or askance.
entry.q: These blenches gave my heart another youth.

entry.ety: See 1st Blanch
entry.def: To grow or make pale.

sn.def: One who, or that which, scares another; specifically, a person stationed to prevent the escape of the deer, at a hunt. See Blancher.
One who blenches, flinches, or shrinks back.

entries.entry: Blench" hold`ing. Law See Blanch holding.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blended or Blent blĕnt; p. pr. & vb. n. Blending
entry.ety: OE. blenden blanden, AS. blandan to blend, mix; akin to Goth. blandan to mix, Icel. blanda, Sw. blanda, Dan. blande, OHG. blantan to mis; to unknown origin

sn.def: To mix or mingle together; esp. to mingle, combine, or associate so that the separate things mixed, or the line of demarcation, can not be distinguished. Hence: To confuse; to confound.
sn.q: Blending the grand, the beautiful, the gay.

sn.def: To pollute by mixture or association; to spoil or corrupt; to blot; to stain.
sn.syn: To commingle; combine; fuse; merge; amalgamate; harmonize.

entry.def: To mingle; to mix; to unite intimately; to pass or shade insensibly into each other, as colors.
entry.q: There is a tone of solemn and sacred feeling that blends with our conviviality.

entry.def: A thorough mixture of one thing with another, as color, tint, etc., into another, so that it cannot be known where one ends or the other begins.

entry.ety: AS. blendan, from blind blind. See Blind a.
entry.def: To make blind, literally or figuratively; to dazzle; to deceive.

entry.ety: G., fr. blenden to blind, dazzle, deceive, fr. blind blind. So called either in allusion to its dazzling luster; or (Dana) because, though often resembling galena, it yields no lead. Cf. Sphalerite
entry.def: A mineral, called also sphalerite, and by miners mock lead false galena, and black-jack. It is a zinc sulphide, but often contains some iron. Its color is usually yellow, brown, or black, and its luster resinous.
A general term for some minerals, chiefly metallic sulphides which have a somewhat brilliant but nonmetallic luster.

entry.sn: combined or mixed together so that the constituent parts are indistinguishable. Antonym of unblended.Narrower terms: alloyed; emulsified; homogenized mingled, commingled.

entries.entry: Blend"er n. One who, or that which, blends; an instrument, as a brush, used in blending. Specifically, an electrical device with a rapidly rotating spindle to which a specially designed container can be attached, so that the contents of the container are agitated by rotating blades at adjustable speeds, permitting various degrees of homogenization of the contents. container are

sn.def: The act of mingling.
The method of laying on different tints so that they may mingle together while wet, and shade into each other insensibly.

entry.def: Pertaining to, consisting of, or containing, blende.
A distemper incident to cattle, in which their livers are affected.

entries.entry: Blen"heim span"iel. So called from Blenheim House, the seat of the duke of Marlborough, in England A small variety of spaniel, kept as a pet.

entry.def: To blink; to shine; to look.

entry.ety: Blenny + -oid
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the blennies.

entry.ety: Gr. � mucus + -genous
entry.def: Generating mucus.

entry.ety: Gr. � mucus + � to flow
entry.def: An inordinate secretion and discharge of mucus.
Gonorrhea.

entries.entry: Blen"ny n.; pl.Blennies. L. blennius blendius blendea, Gr. �, fr. � slime, mucus Zoöl A marine fish of the genus Blennius or family Blenniidæ; -- so called from its coating of mucus. The species are numerous.
Blent imp. & p. p. of Blend to mingle. Mingled; mixed; blended; also, polluted; stained. Rider and horse, friend, foe, in one red burial blent.
Blent imp. & p. p. of Blend to blind. Blinded. Also (Chaucer), 3d sing. pres. Blindeth. Obs

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � eyelid + -ilis
entry.def: Inflammation of the eyelids.

entry.ety: D., fr. bles a white spot on the forehead + bok buck
entry.def: A South African antelope (Alcelaphus albifrons), having a large white spot on the forehead.

entry.note: ☞ This is an old sense of the word, supposed by Johnson, Nares, and others, to have been derived from the old rite of blessing a field by directing the hands to all parts of it. “In drawing [their bow] some fetch such a compass as though they would turn about and bless all the field.”
entry.cs:
Bless me! Bless us!
an exclamation of surprise. Milton. To bless from to secure, defend, or preserve from. “Bless me from marrying a usurer.” Shak. To bless the doors from nightly harm. Milton.
To bless with To be blessed with
to favor or endow with; to be favored or endowed with; as, God blesses us with health; we are blessed with happiness.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blessed or Blest; p. pr. & vb. n. Blessing
entry.ety: OE. blessien bletsen, AS. bletsian bledsian bloedsian, fr. bl�d blood; prob. originally to consecrate by sprinkling with blood. See Blood

sn.def: To make or pronounce holy; to consecrate
sn.q: And God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it.

sn.def: To make happy, blithesome, or joyous; to confer prosperity or happiness upon; to grant divine favor to.
sn.q: The quality of mercy is . . . twice blest; It blesseth him that gives and him that takes.
It hath pleased thee to bless the house of thy servant, that it may continue forever before thee.

sn.def: To express a wish or prayer for the happiness of; to invoke a blessing upon; -- applied to persons.
sn.q: Bless them which persecute you.

sn.def: To invoke or confer beneficial attributes or qualities upon; to invoke or confer a blessing on, -- as on food.
sn.q: Then he took the five loaves and the two fishes, and looking up to heaven, he blessed them.

sn.def: To make the sign of the cross upon; to cross (one's self).
To guard; to keep; to protect.
To praise, or glorify; to extol for excellences.
sn.q: Bless the Lord, O my soul: and all that is within me, bless his holy name.

sn.def: To esteem or account happy; to felicitate.
sn.q: The nations shall bless themselves in him.

sn.def: To wave; to brandish.
sn.q: And burning blades about their heads do bless.
Round his armed head his trenchant blade he blest.

sn.def: Hallowed; consecrated; worthy of blessing or adoration; heavenly; holy.
sn.q: O, run; prevent them with thy humble ode, And lay it lowly at his blessed feet.

sn.def: Enjoying happiness or bliss; favored with blessings; happy; highly favored.
sn.q: All generations shall call me blessed.
Towards England's blessed shore.

sn.def: Imparting happiness or bliss; fraught with happiness; blissful; joyful.
sn.q: Then was ablessed blesseda disposition.

sn.def: Enjoying, or pertaining to, spiritual happiness, or heavenly felicity; as, the blessed in heaven.
sn.q: Reverenced like a blessed saint.
Cast out from God and blessed vision.

sn.def: Beatified.
Used euphemistically, ironically, or intensively.
sn.q: Not a blessed man came to set her [a boat] free.

entry.def: Happily; fortunately; joyfully.
entry.q: We shall blessedly meet again never to depart.

entry.cs: Single blessedness the unmarried state. “Grows, lives, and dies in single blessedness.” Shak.
entry.def: The state of being blessed; happiness; felicity; bliss; heavenly joys; the favor of God.
entry.q: The assurance of a future blessedness.

entries.entry: Bless"ed this"tle. See under Thistle.

entry.def: One who blesses; one who bestows or invokes a blessing.

entry.ety: AS. bletsung. See Bless v. t.

sn.def: The act of one who blesses.
A declaration of divine favor, or an invocation imploring divine favor on some or something; a benediction; a wish of happiness pronounces.
sn.q: This is the blessing, where with Moses the man of God blessed the children of Israel.

sn.def: A means of happiness; that which promotes prosperity and welfare; a beneficent gift.
sn.q: Nature's full blessings would be well dispensed.

sn.def: A gift.
Grateful praise or worship.

entry.def: Blessed.
entry.q: This patriarchblest.
White these blest sounds my ravished ear assail.

entry.ety: F. blet blette, a., soft from over ripeness
entry.def: A form of decay in fruit which is overripe.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bletted; p. pr. & vb. n. Bletting
entry.def: To decay internally when overripe; -- said of fruit.
The supposed faculty of perceiving subterraneous springs and currents by sensation; -- so called from one Bleton, of France.
A form of decay seen in fleshy, overripe fruit.
imp. of Blow.

sn.def: an edible agaric (Tricholoma personatum) that is pale lilac when young.
same as blewit.

entry.ety: F. bleime
entry.def: An inflammation in the foot of a horse, between the sole and the bone.
imp. of Blench.

entry.ety: D. blik tin
entry.def: A tin dinner pail.
small genus of West African evergreen trees and shrubs bearing fleshy capsular three-seeded fruits edible when neither unripe nor overripe.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blighted; p. pr. & vb. n. Blighting
entry.ety: Perh. contr. from AS. blīcettan to glitter, fr. the same root as E. bleak. The meaning “to blight” comes in that case from to glitter, hence, to be white or pale, grow pale, make pale, bleach. Cf. Bleach Bleak

sn.def: To affect with blight; to blast; to prevent the growth and fertility of.
sn.q: This vapor] blasts vegetables, blights corn and fruit, and is sometimes injurious even to man.

sn.def: Hence: To destroy the happiness of; to ruin; to mar essentially; to frustrate; as, to blight one's prospects.
sn.q: Seared in heart and lone and blighted.

entry.def: To be affected by blight; to blast; as, this vine never blights .

sn.def: Mildew; decay; anything nipping or blasting; -- applied as a general name to various injuries or diseases of plants, causing the whole or a part to wither, whether occasioned by insects, fungi, or atmospheric influences.
The act of blighting, or the state of being blighted; a withering or mildewing, or a stoppage of growth in the whole or a part of a plant, etc.
That which frustrates one's plans or withers one's hopes; that which impairs or destroys.
sn.q: A blight seemed to have fallen over our fortunes.

sn.def: A downy species of aphis, or plant louse, destructive to fruit trees, infesting both the roots and branches; -- also applied to several other injurious insects.
A rashlike eruption on the human skin.

entry.def: Causing blight.
So as to cause blight.
See Bilimbi, etc.

entry.ety: from Colonel Blimp, a fictional character
entry.def: any elderly pompous reactionary.

sn.def: a small nonrigid airship used for observation or as a barrage balloon.

entry.ety: from Colonel Blimp, a fictional character
entry.def: pompously ultraconservative and nationalistic.

entry.ety: OE. blinnen, AS. blinnan; pref. be- + linnan to cease
entry.def: To stop; to cease; to desist.

entry.ety: AS. blinn
entry.def: Cessation; end.

entries.entry: blin n.; pl.blini bliny or blinis. Russian a thin buckwheat pancake made with yeast and usually filled with sour cream and folded over. See also blini.

cs.cd: an alley closed at one end; a cul-de-sac.
an axle which turns but does not communicate motion.
one of the insects apt to fly against people, esp. at night.
a species of catfish (Gronias nigrolabris), nearly destitute of eyes, living in caverns in Pennsylvania.
coal that burns without flame; anthracite coal.
an imitation of a door or window, without an opening for passage or light. See Blank doororBlank window, under Blank a.
a level or drainage gallery which has a vertical shaft at each end, and acts as an inverted siphon.
dead nettle. See Dead nettle, under Dead.
a shell containing no charge, or one that does not explode.
the side which is most easily assailed; a weak or unguarded side; the side on which one is least able or disposed to see danger.
a small, harmless, burrowing snake, of the family Typhlopidæ, with rudimentary eyes.
the point in the retina of the eye where the optic nerve enters, and which is insensible to light.
in bookbinding and leather work, the indented impression of heated tools, without gilding; -- called also blank tooling, and blind blocking.
a wall without an opening; a blank wall.

entry.ety: AS.; akin to D., G., OS., Sw., & Dan. blind, Icel. blindr, Goth. blinds; of uncertain origin

sn.def: Destitute of the sense of seeing, either by natural defect or by deprivation; without sight.
sn.q: He that is strucken blind can not forget The precious treasure of his eyesight lost.

sn.def: Not having the faculty of discernment; destitute of intellectual light; unable or unwilling to understand or judge; as, authors are blind to their own defects.
sn.q: But hard be hardened, blind be blinded more, That they may stumble on, and deeper fall.

sn.def: Undiscerning; undiscriminating; inconsiderate.
sn.q: This plan is recommended neither to blind approbation nor to blind reprobation.

sn.def: Having such a state or condition as a thing would have to a person who is blind; not well marked or easily discernible; hidden; unseen; concealed; as, a blind path; a blind ditch.
Involved; intricate; not easily followed or traced.
sn.q: The blind mazes of this tangled wood.

sn.def: Having no openings for light or passage; as, a blind wall; open only at one end; as, a blind alley; a blind gut.
Unintelligible, or not easily intelligible; as, a blind passage in a book; illegible; as, blind writing.
Abortive; failing to produce flowers or fruit; as, blind buds; blind flowers.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blinded; p. pr. & vb. n. Blinding

sn.def: To make blind; to deprive of sight or discernment.
sn.q: Toblindthe truth and me.
A blind guide is certainly a great mischief; but a guide that blinds those whom he should lead is . . . a much greater.

sn.def: To deprive partially of vision; to make vision difficult for and painful to; to dazzle.
sn.q: Her beauty all the rest did blind.

sn.def: To darken; to obscure to the eye or understanding; to conceal; to deceive.
sn.q: Such darkness blinds the sky.
The state of the controversy between us he endeavored, with all his art, to blind and confound.

sn.def: To cover with a thin coating of sand and fine gravel; as a road newly paved, in order that the joints between the stones may be filled.
Something to hinder sight or keep out light; a screen; a cover; esp. a hinged screen or shutter for a window; a blinder for a horse.
Something to mislead the eye or the understanding, or to conceal some covert deed or design; a subterfuge.

sn.ety: Cf. F. blindes, p�., fr. G. blende, fr. blenden to blind, fr. blind blind
sn.def: A blindage. See Blindage.
A halting place.

entry.def: See Blende.

entry.ety: Cf. F. blindage
entry.def: A cover or protection for an advanced trench or approach, formed of fascines and earth supported by a framework.
deprived of one's sight; rendered blind.

sn.def: One who, or that which, blinds.
One of the leather screens on a bridle, to hinder a horse from seeing objects at the side; a blinker.

entry.def: A small fish (Amblyopsis spelæus) destitute of eyes, found in the waters of the Mammoth Cave, in Kentucky. Related fishes from other caves take the same name.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blindfolded; p. pr. & vb. n. Blindfolding
entry.ety: OE. blindfolden blindfelden blindfellen; AS. blind blind + prob. fellan fyllan, to fell, strike down
entry.def: To cover the eyes of, as with a bandage; to hinder from seeing.
entry.q: And when they had blindfolded him, they struck him on the face.

entry.def: Having the eyes covered; blinded; having the mental eye darkened. Hence: Heedless; reckless; as, blindfold zeal; blindfold fury.
entry.q: Fate's blindfold reign the atheist loudly owns.

entry.def: a flexible object placed over the eyes to prevent seeing; usually a strip of cloth wrapped around the head so as to cover the eyes.
having a blindfold placed over the eyes; -- done to prevent the wearer from seeing.
Making blind or as if blind; depriving of sight or of understanding; obscuring; as, blinding tears; blinding snow.
A thin coating of sand and fine gravel over a newly paved road. See Blind v. t., 4.
Without sight, discernment, or understanding; without thought, investigation, knowledge, or purpose of one's own.
entry.q: By his imperious mistress blindly led.

entries.entry: Blind"man's buff" Blind" man's buff" . See Buff a buffet A game in which one person is blindfolded, and tries to catch some one of the other players, and tell who it is. Surely he fancies I play at blindman's buff with him, for he thinks I never have my eyes open.
Blind`man's hol"i*day. The time between daylight and candle light. Humorous

cs.cd: inability to distinguish certain color. See Daltonism.

entry.def: State or condition of being blind, literally or figuratively.

entries.entry: Blind reader. A post-office clerk whose duty is to decipher obscure addresses.

entry.def: to attack a person from his blind side; metaphorically, to give a person an unpleasant suprise.
entry.illu: He had completed his plan to develop a new office building, but was blindsided by the sudden drop in real estate values.

entry.def: The triforium as opposed to the clearstory.
A small, burrowing, snakelike, limbless lizard (Anguis fragilis), with minute eyes, popularly believed to be blind; the slowworm; -- formerly a name for the adder.
entry.q: Newts and blindworms do no wrong.

entries.entry: bli"ni blē"nē; blĭ"nē n. pl.; sing.blin. Russian Russian pancakes of buckwheat flour and yeast, sometimes made from white flour; they are usually served folded over, with caviar and sour cream on the inside; -- properly, it is a plural word (from the Russian plural of blin) but in America, often used as singular; thus the common plural blinis. bliny, blinis.

entry.def: a typ of small Indian lettuce (Montia lamprosperma) of northern regions.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blinked blĭṉkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Blinking
entry.ety: OE. blenken; akin to dan. blinke, Sw. blinka, G. blinken to shine, glance, wink, twinkle, D. blinken to shine; and prob. to D. blikken to glance, twinkle, G. blicken to look, glance, AS. blīcan to shine, E. bleak. √98. See Bleak; cf. 1st Blench

sn.def: To wink; to twinkle with, or as with, the eye.
sn.q: One eye was blinking, and one leg was lame.

sn.def: To see with the eyes half shut, or indistinctly and with frequent winking, as a person with weak eyes.
sn.q: Show me thy chink, to blink through with mine eyne.

sn.def: To shine, esp. with intermittent light; to twinkle; to flicker; to glimmer, as a lamp.
sn.q: The dew was falling fast, the stars began to blink.
The sun blinked fair on pool and stream .

sn.def: To turn slightly sour, as beer, mild, etc.
To shut out of sight; to avoid, or purposely evade; to shirk; as, to blink the question.
To trick; to deceive.

entry.ety: OE. blink. See Blink v. i.

sn.def: A glimpse or glance.
sn.q: This is the first blink that ever I had of him.

sn.def: Gleam; glimmer; sparkle.
sn.q: Not a blink of light was there.

sn.def: The dazzling whiteness about the horizon caused by the reflection of light from fields of ice at sea; ice blink.
Boughs cast where deer are to pass, to turn or check them.

entry.ety: Blind + -ard

sn.def: One who blinks with, or as with, weak eyes.
sn.q: Among the blind the one-eyed blinkard reigns.

sn.def: That which twinkles or glances, as a dim star, which appears and disappears.

entry.def: Beer kept unbroached until it is sharp.

sn.def: One who, or that which, blinks.
A blinder for horses; a flap of leather on a horse's bridle to prevent him from seeing objects as his side hence, whatever obstructs sight or discernment.
sn.q: Nor bigots who but one way see, through blinkers of authority.

sn.def: A kind of goggles, used to protect the eyes form glare, etc.

entry.def: Habitually winking.

entries.entry:
blintz blintze
n.; pl.blintzes. Yiddish blintze, fr. Byelorussian blinets, dimin. of Russ. blin. See also blin and blini
Jewish Cookery a thin wheat pancake folded around a filling (such as cheese or fruit) and sauteed, fried, or baked.

entry.def: same as blini.

entry.note: this sense is also used metaphorically to mean a barely perceptible object; , Kennedy's candidacy was a mere blip on Humphrey's radar screen until he won the West Virginia primary. This is the probably origin of sense 3.

sn.def: a spot of light on a radar screen, showing the position of a reflecting surface, such as an airplane or ship.
a short upward or downward deviation from a trend line on a graph, especially in a plot of some variable, such as an economic variable, against time; as, a brief blip upward in the unemployment rate.
something small or insignificant.
a brief interruption in the continuity of a recorded or transmitted signal; as, there is a blip on my CD of Beethoven's ninth.

entry.def: A gust of wind and rain.

entries.entry:
Bliss blĭs n.; pl.Blisses blĭs"ĕz. OE. blis blisse, AS. blis blīðs, fr. blīðe blithe. See Blithe
Orig., blithesomeness; gladness; now, the highest degree of happiness; blessedness; exalted felicity; heavenly joy. An then at last our bliss Full and perfect is. Blessedness; felicity; beatitude; happiness; joy; enjoyment. See Happiness.

entry.def: Full of, characterized by, or causing, joy and felicity; happy in the highest degree.
entry.q: Blissfulsolitude.

entry.def: Destitute of bliss.

entry.ety: For blithesome: but cf. also Icel. bl�sma of a goat at heat
entry.def: To be lustful; to be lascivious.
Lascivious; also, in heat; -- said of ewes.
a genus comprising the chinch bugs. See chinch, 2.

entry.cs: Blister beetle a beetle used to raise blisters, esp. the Lytta vesicatoriaorCantharis vesicatoria), called Cantharis or Spanish fly by druggists. See Cantharis. Blister fly a blister beetle. Blister plaster a plaster designed to raise a blister; -- usually made of Spanish flies. Blister steel crude steel formed from wrought iron by cementation; -- so called because of its blistered surface. Called also blistered steel. Blood blister. See under Blood.
entry.ety: OE.; akin to OD. bluyster, fr. the same root as blast bladder blow. See Blow to eject wind

sn.def: A vesicle of the skin, containing watery matter or serum, whether occasioned by a burn or other injury, or by a vesicatory; a collection of serous fluid causing a bladderlike elevation of the cuticle.
sn.q: And painful blisters swelled my tender hands.

sn.def: Any elevation made by the separation of the film or skin, as on plants; or by the swelling of the substance at the surface, as on steel.
A vesicatory; a plaster of Spanish flies, or other matter, applied to raise a blister.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blistered; p. pr. & vb. n. Blistering
entry.def: To be affected with a blister or blisters; to have a blister form on.
entry.q: Let my tongue blister.

sn.def: To raise a blister or blisters upon.
sn.q: My hands were blistered.

sn.def: To give pain to, or to injure, as if by a blister.
sn.q: This tyrant, whose sole name blisters our tongue.

sn.def: harshly or corrosively critical in tone; -- of comments about people or their actions.
sn.syn: acerb, acerbic, acid, bitter, caustic, scathing, venomous, virulent, vitriolic.

sn.def: intensely hot.
very fast; as, a blistering pace.

entry.def: Full of blisters.

entry.ety: L. blitum, Gr. bli`ton
entry.def: A genus of herbs (Blitum) with a fleshy calyx. Blitum capitatum is the strawberry blite.

entry.ety: AS. blīðe blithe, kind; akin to Goth. bleiþs kind, Icel. blīðr mild, gentle, Dan. & Sw. blid gentle, D. blijd blithe, OHG. blīdi kind, blithe
entry.def: Gay; merry; sprightly; joyous; glad; cheerful; as, a blithe spirit.
entry.q: The blithe sounds of festal music.
A daughter fair, So buxom, blithe, and debonair.

entry.def: Gay; full of gayety; joyous.
In a blithe manner.
The state of being blithe.
same as blather.
talking incoherently; as, a blithering idiot.
Cheery; gay; merry.
entry.q: The blithesome sounds of wassail gay.

sn.def: a quick move by defensive players toward the passer on the offensive team, as soon as the ball is snapped; -- it is used when the defensive teams assumes that a pass will be attempted, and risks allowing substantial gains by the offensive team if other plays are in fact planned.
a rapid and violent military attack with intensive aerial bombardment. Same as blitzkrieg
any vigorous and intensive attack, bombardment, or assault, literally or figuratively; as, they used a blitz of television commercials to launch their new product; the German blitz on London.
same as blitz chess.

entry.ety: German, blitz lightning + krieg war
entry.def: an overwhelming all-out attack with infantry, armor, and air forces, especially by surprise against an unprepared enemy.
to fight a quick and surprising war.

entry.ety: A contraction of Belive
entry.def: Quickly; forthwith.

entry.ety: Cf. Blaze to flash. Formerly, in local use, a rattling volley; cf. “to blaze away” to fire away
entry.def: A gale of piercingly cold wind, usually accompanied with fine and blinding snow; a furious blast.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bloated; p. pr. & vb. n. Bloating
entry.ety: Cf. Icel. blotna to become soft, blautr soft, wet, Sw. blöt soft, blöta to soak; akin to G. bloss bare, and AS. bleát wretched; or perh. fr. root of Eng. 5th blow. Cf. Blote

sn.def: To make turgid, as with water or air; to cause a swelling of the surface of, from effusion of serum in the cellular tissue, producing a morbid enlargement, often accompanied with softness.
To inflate; to puff up; to make vain.

entry.def: To grow turgid as by effusion of liquid in the cellular tissue; to puff out; to swell.
Bloated.
A term of contempt for a worthless, dissipated fellow.
To dry (herrings) in smoke. See Blote.
Distended beyond the natural or usual size, as by the presence of water, serum, etc.; turgid; swollen; as, a bloated face. Also, puffed up with pride; pompous.
The state of being bloated.

entry.ety: See Bloat Blote
entry.def: The common herring, esp. when of large size, smoked, and half dried; -- called also bloat herring.

entry.ety: See Bleb

sn.def: Something blunt and round; a small drop or lump of something viscid or thick; a drop; a bubble; a blister.
A small fresh-water fish (Uranidea Richardsoni); the miller's thumb.

cs.cd: a thick, protruding lip.

entry.ety: See Blubber Blub
entry.def: A bubble; blubber.
entry.q: His blobber lips and beetle brows commend.

entry.def: Having thick lips.
entry.q: Ablobber-lippedshell.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The roughest and cheapest sort of rubblework, in masonry.

entry.cs: A block of shares Stock Exchange a large number of shares in a stock company, sold in a lump. Bartlett. Block printing. A mode of printing (common in China and Japan) from engraved boards by means of a sheet of paper laid on the linked surface and rubbed with a brush. S. W. Williams. A method of printing cotton cloth and paper hangings with colors, by pressing them upon an engraved surface coated with coloring matter. Block system on railways, a system by which the track is divided into sections of three or four miles, and trains are so run by the guidance of electric signals that no train enters a section or block before the preceding train has left it. Back blocks Australian pastoral country which is remote from the seacoast or from a river.
entry.ety: OE. blok; cf. F. blocfr. OHG.), D. & Dan. blok, Sw. & G. block, OHG. bloch. There is also an OHG. bloch biloh; bi by + the same root as that of E. lock. Cf. Block v. t. Blockade, and see Lock

sn.def: A piece of wood more or less bulky; a solid mass of wood, stone, etc., usually with one or more plane, or approximately plane, faces; as, a block on which a butcher chops his meat; a block by which to mount a horse; children's playing blocks, etc.
sn.q: Now all our neighbors' chimneys smoke, And Christmas blocks are burning.
All her labor was but as a block Left in the quarry.

sn.def: The solid piece of wood on which condemned persons lay their necks when they are beheaded.
sn.q: Noble heads which have been brought to the block.

sn.def: The wooden mold on which hats, bonnets, etc., are shaped.
The pattern or shape of a hat.
sn.q: He wears his faith but as the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with the next block.

sn.def: A large or long building divided into separate houses or shops, or a number of houses or shops built in contact with each other so as to form one building; a row of houses or shops.
A square, or portion of a city inclosed by streets, whether occupied by buildings or not.
sn.q: The new city was laid out in rectangular blocks, each block containing thirty building lots. Such an average block, comprising 282 houses and covering nine acres of ground, exists in Oxford Street.

sn.def: A grooved pulley or sheave incased in a frame or shell which is provided with a hook, eye, or strap, by which it may be attached to an object. It is used to change the direction of motion, as in raising a heavy object that can not be conveniently reached, and also, when two or more such sheaves are compounded, to change the rate of motion, or to exert increased force; -- used especially in the rigging of ships, and in tackles.
The perch on which a bird of prey is kept.

Any obstruction, or cause of obstruction; a stop; a hindrance; an obstacle; -- also called blockage; as, a block in the way; a block in an artery; a block in a nerve; a block in a biochemical pathway.
A piece of box or other wood for engravers' work.
A piece of hard wood (as mahogany or cherry) on which a stereotype or electrotype plate is mounted to make it type high.
A blockhead; a stupid fellow; a dolt.
sn.q: What a block art thou !

sn.def: A section of a railroad where the block system is used. See Block system, below.
In Australia, one of the large lots into which public land, when opened to settlers, is divided by the government surveyors.

sd.def: The position of a player or bat when guarding the wicket.
A block hole.
The popping crease.

sn.def: a number of individual items sold as a unit; as, a block of airline ticketes; a block of hotel rooms; a block of stock.
the length of one side of a city block{5}, traversed along any side; as, to walk three blocks ahead and turn left at the corner.
a halt in a mental process, especially one due to stress, memory lapse, confusion, etc.; as, a writer's block; to have a block in remembering a name.
a quantity of binary-encoded information transferred, or stored, as a unit to, from, or on a data storage device; as, to divide a disk into 512-byte blocks .
a number of locations in a random-access memory allocated to storage of specific data; as, to allocate a block of 1024 bytes for the stack.

cs.cd: to begin to reduce to shape; to mark out roughly; to lay out; to outline; as, to block out a plan.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blocked blŏkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Blocking
entry.ety: Cf. F. bloquer, fr. bloc block. See Block n.

sn.def: To obstruct so as to prevent passage or progress; to prevent passage from, through, or into, by obstructing the way; -- used both of persons and things; -- often followed by up; as, to block up a road or harbor; to block an entrance.
sn.q: With moles . . . would block the port.
A city . . . besieged and blocked about.

sn.def: To secure or support by means of blocks; to secure, as two boards at their angles of intersection, by pieces of wood glued to each.
To shape on, or stamp with, a block; as, to block a hat.
to cause (any activity) to halt by creating an obstruction; as, to block a nerve impulse; to block a biochemical reaction with a drug.

entry.note: ☞ Blockade is now usually applied to an investment with ships or vessels, while siege is used of an investment by land forces. To constitute a blockade, the investing power must be able to apply its force to every point of practicable access, so as to render it dangerous to attempt to enter; and there is no blockade of that port where its force can not be brought to bear.
entry.cs: To raise a blockade. See under Raise.
entry.ety: Cf. It. bloccata. See Block v. t.

sn.def: The shutting up of a place by troops or ships, with the purpose of preventing ingress or egress, or the reception of supplies; as, the blockade of the ports of an enemy.
An obstruction to passage.
interference with transmission of a physiological signal, or a physiological reaction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blockaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Blockading

sn.def: To shut up, as a town or fortress, by investing it with troops or vessels or war for the purpose of preventing ingress or egress, or the introduction of supplies. See note under Blockade n.
sn.q: Blockadedthe place by sea.

sn.def: Hence, to shut in so as to prevent egress.
sn.q: Till storm and driving ice blockade him there.

sn.def: To obstruct entrance to or egress from.
sn.q: Huge bales of British cloth blockade the door.

entry.def: having access obstructed by emplacement of a barrier, or by threat of force.

sn.def: One who blockades.
A vessel employed in blockading.

entry.def: The act of blocking up; the state of being blocked up.

entries.entry: Block" book`. A book printed from engraved wooden blocks instead of movable types.
Block chain. Mach A chain in which the alternate links are broad blocks connected by thin side links pivoted to the ends of the blocks, used with sprocket wheels to transmit power, as in a bicycle.

sn.def: closed to traffic.
sn.illu: Traffic was blocked by an overturned tractor-trailor

sn.def: at a complete standstill because of opposition of two unrelenting forces or factions.
unusable because of some obstruction.

entry.ety: Block + head
entry.def: A stupid fellow; a dolt; a person deficient in understanding.
entry.q: The bookful blockhead, ignorantly read, With loads of learned lumber in his head.

entry.def: Stupid; dull.
That which characterizes a blockhead; stupidity.
