entry.ety: Block + house: cf. G. blockhaus

sn.def: An edifice or structure of heavy timbers or logs for military defense, having its sides loopholed for musketry, and often an upper story projecting over the lower, or so placed upon it as to have its sides make an angle wit the sides of the lower story, thus enabling the defenders to fire downward, and in all directions; -- formerly much used in America and Germany.
A house of squared logs.
The act of obstructing, supporting, shaping, or stamping with a block or blocks.
Blocks used to support (a building, etc.) temporarily.

entries.entry: Block"ing course`. Arch The finishing course of a wall showing above a cornice.

entry.def: Like a block; deficient in understanding; stupid; dull.
entry.q: BlockishAjax.

entry.def: Like a block; stupid.

entries.entry: Block signal. Railroads One of the danger signals or safety signals which guide the movement of trains in a block system. The signal is often so coupled with a switch that act of opening or closing the switch operates the signal also.

Block system. Railroads A system by which the track is divided into short sections, as of three or four miles, and trains are so run by the guidance of electric, or combined electric and pneumatic, signals that no train enters a section or block until the preceding train has left it, as in absolute blocking, or that a train may be allowed to follow another into a block as long as it proceeds with excessive caution, as in permissive blocking.
Block" tin`. See under Tin.

entry.ety: From the chemist Blöde
entry.def: A hydrous sulphate of magnesium and sodium.
A shrub or small tree of southern Florida and the West Indies (Pisonia obtusata) with smooth oval leaves and a hard, 10-ribbed fruit.
The rubiaceous shrub Chicocca racemosa, of the same region.
See Bloomery.

entry.ety: OF. blanquet whitish, dim. of blanc white. Cf. Blanket
entry.def: Gray; bluish gray.
entry.q: Our bloncket liveries been all too sad.

entry.ety: F., fair, light, of uncertain origin; cf. AS. blonden-feax gray-haired, old, prop. blended-haired, as a mixture of white and brown or black. See Blend v. t.
entry.def: Of a fair color; light-colored; as, blond hair; a blond complexion.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: A person of very fair complexion, with light hair and light blue eyes.
A kind of silk lace originally of the color of raw silk, now sometimes dyed; -- called also blond lace.

entries.entry: Blond" met`al. A variety of clay ironstone, in Staffordshire, England, used for making tools.

entry.def: The state of being blond.

entry.note: ☞ The blood consists of a liquid, the plasma, containing minute particles, the blood corpuscles. In the invertebrate animals it is usually nearly colorless, and contains only one kind of corpuscles; but in all vertebrates, except Amphioxus, it contains some colorless corpuscles, with many more which are red and give the blood its uniformly red color. See Corpuscle Plasma.

cs.cd: relationship through only one parent.
relationship through both father and mother. In American Law, blood includes both half blood, and whole blood.

entry.note: ☞ In stock breeding half blood is descent showing one half only of pure breed. Blue blood full blood, or warm blood, is the same as blood.

☞ Often, in this sense, accompanied with bad cold warm, or other qualifying word. Thus, to commit an act in cold blood, is to do it deliberately, and without sudden passion; to do it in bad blood, is to do it in anger. Warm blood denotes a temper inflamed or irritated. To warm or heat the blood is to excite the passions. Qualified by up, excited feeling or passion is signified; as, my blood was up.

☞ Blood is often used as an adjective, and as the first part of self-explaining compound words; as, blood-bespotted, blood-bought, blood-curdling, blood-dyed, blood-red, blood-spilling, blood-stained, blood-warm, blood-won.
entry.cs: Blood baptism Eccl. Hist the martyrdom of those who had not been baptized. They were considered as baptized in blood, and this was regarded as a full substitute for literal baptism. Blood blister a blister or bleb containing blood or bloody serum, usually caused by an injury. Blood brother brother by blood or birth. Blood clam Zoöl a bivalve mollusk of the genus Arca and allied genera, esp. Argina pexata of the American coast. So named from the color of its flesh. Blood corpuscle. See Corpuscle. Blood crystal Physiol one of the crystals formed by the separation in a crystalline form of the hæmoglobin of the red blood corpuscles; hæmatocrystallin. All blood does not yield blood crystals. Blood heat heat equal to the temperature of human blood, or about 981/2 ° Fahr. Blood horse a horse whose blood or lineage is derived from the purest and most highly prized origin or stock. Blood money. See in the Vocabulary. Blood orange an orange with dark red pulp. Blood poisoning Med a morbid state of the blood caused by the introduction of poisonous or infective matters from without, or the absorption or retention of such as are produced in the body itself; toxæmia. Blood pudding a pudding made of blood and other materials. Blood relation one connected by blood or descent. Blood spavin. See under Spavin. Blood vessel. See in the Vocabulary. Blue blood the blood of noble or aristocratic families, which, according to a Spanish prover , has in it a tinge of blue; -- hence, a member of an old and aristocratic family. Flesh and blood. A blood relation, esp. a child. Human nature. In blood Hunting in a state of perfect health and vigor. Shak. To let blood. See under Let. Prince of the blood the son of a sovereign, or the issue of a royal family. The sons, brothers, and uncles of the sovereign are styled princes of the blood royal; and the daughters, sisters, and aunts are princesses of the blood royal.
entry.ety: OE. blod blood, AS. blōd; akin to D. bloed, OHG. bluot, G. blut, Goth. blōþ, Icel. blōð, Sw. & Dan. blod; prob. fr. the same root as E. blow to bloom. See Blow to bloom

sn.def: The fluid which circulates in the principal vascular system of animals, carrying nourishment to all parts of the body, and bringing away waste products to be excreted. See under Arterial.
Relationship by descent from a common ancestor; consanguinity; kinship.
sn.q: To share the blood of Saxon royalty.
A friend of our own blood.

sn.def: Descent; lineage; especially, honorable birth; the highest royal lineage.
sn.q: Give us a prince of blood, a son of Priam.
I am a gentleman of blood and breeding.

sn.def: Descent from parents of recognized breed; excellence or purity of breed.
The fleshy nature of man.
sn.q: Nor gives it satisfaction to our blood.

sn.def: The shedding of blood; the taking of life, murder; manslaughter; destruction.
sn.q: So wills the fierce, avenging sprite, Till blood for blood atones.

sn.def: A bloodthirsty or murderous disposition.
sn.q: He was a thing of blood, whose every motion Was timed with dying cries.

sn.def: Temper of mind; disposition; state of the passions; -- as if the blood were the seat of emotions.
sn.q: When you perceive his blood inclined to mirth.

sn.def: A man of fire or spirit; a fiery spark; a gay, showy man; a rake.
sn.q: Seest thou not . . . how giddily 'a turns about all the hot bloods between fourteen and five and thirty?
It was the morning costume of a dandy or blood.

sn.def: The juice of anything, especially if red.
sn.q: He washed . . . his clothes in the blood of grapes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blooded; p. pr. & vb. n. Blooding

sn.def: To bleed.
To stain, smear or wet, with blood.
sn.q: Reach out their spears afar, And blood their points.

sn.def: To give (hounds or soldiers) a first taste or sight of blood, as in hunting or war.
sn.q: It was most important too that his troops should be blooded.

sn.def: To heat the blood of; to exasperate.
sn.q: The auxiliary forces of the French and English were much blooded one against another.

sn.def: Indiscriminate slaughter; the killing of multiple persons.
Substantial losses by many people, as in a mass termination of employment or widespread financial loss; as, the sudden market drop created a bloodbath among overoptimistic investors.

entry.def: A bushy houseplant (Rivina humilis) having white to pale pink flowers followed by racemes of scarlet berries; it is native to the tropical Americas.
An Australian honeysucker (Myzomela sanguineolata); -- so called from the bright red color of the male bird.

entry.ety: Blood + Prov. E. bolter to mat in tufts. Cf. Balter
entry.def: Having the hair matted with clotted blood.
entry.q: The blood-boltered Banquo smiles upon me.

entry.def: causing sudden intense fear due to an apprehension of imminent bodily harm, to oneself or others.
entry.illu: Awakened by a bloodcurdling scream from right outside her window

entry.note: ☞ Used also in composition in phrases indicating a particular condition or quality of blood; as, cold-blooded; warm-blooded.
entry.def: Having pure blood, or a large admixture or pure blood; of approved breed; of the best stock.

entry.ety: From the color of the flower
entry.def: A genus of bulbous plants, natives of Southern Africa, named Hæmanthus, of the Amaryllis family. The juice of Hæmanthus toxicarius is used by the Hottentots to poison their arrows.
Guilty of murder or bloodshed.
entry.q: Abloodguiltylife.

entry.def: A breed of large and powerful dogs, with long, smooth, and pendulous ears, and remarkable for acuteness of smell. It is employed to recover game or prey which has escaped wounded from a hunter, and for tracking criminals. Formerly it was used for pursuing runaway slaves. Other varieties of dog are often used for the same purpose and go by the same name. The Cuban bloodhound is said to be a variety of the mastiff.
Covered with blood.
In a bloody manner; cruelly; with a disposition to shed blood.

sn.def: The state of being bloody.
Disposition to shed blood; bloodthirstiness.
sn.q: All that bloodiness and savage cruelty which was in our nature.

entry.ety: AS. blōdleás

sn.def: Destitute of blood, or apparently so; as, bloodless cheeks; lifeless; dead.
sn.q: The bloodless carcass of my Hector sold.

sn.def: Not attended with shedding of blood, or slaughter; as, a bloodless victory.
Without spirit or activity.
sn.q: Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood !

entry.ety: AS. blōdlǣtan; blōd blood + lǣatan to let
entry.def: bleed; to let blood.
One who, or that which, lets blood; a phlebotomist.
The act or process of letting blood or bleeding, as by opening a vein or artery, or by cupping or leeches; -- esp. applied to venesection.
a desire for bloodshed.
a motor vehicle equipped to collect blood donations.

entries.entry:
Blood" mon`ey. Money paid to the next of kin of a person who has been killed by another.
Money obtained as the price, or at the cost, of another's life; -- said of a reward for supporting a capital charge, of money obtained for betraying a fugitive or for committing murder, or of money obtained from the sale of that which will destroy the purchaser.

entry.def: having any of numerous bright or strong colors reminiscent of the color of cherries or tomatoes or rubies or blood.
entry.syn: red, carmine, cerise, cherry, cherry-red, crimson, ruby, ruby-red, scarlet.

sn.def: related by blood, i.e. by a common genetic heritage.

entry.note: ☞ In England the name is given to the tormentil, once used as a remedy for dysentery.
entry.def: A plant (Sanguinaria Canadensis), with a red root and red sap, and bearing a pretty, white flower in early spring; -- called also puccoon redroot bloodwort tetterwort turmeric, and Indian paint. It has acrid emetic properties, and the rootstock is used as a stimulant expectorant. See Sanguinaria.

entry.ety: Blood + shed
entry.def: The shedding or spilling of blood; slaughter; the act of shedding human blood, or taking life, as in war, riot, or murder.
One who sheds blood; a manslayer; a murderer.
Bloodshed.

entry.ety: Blood + shot, p. p. of shoot to variegate
entry.def: Red and inflamed; suffused with blood, or having the vessels turgid with blood, as when the conjunctiva is inflamed or irritated.
entry.q: His eyes were bloodshot, . . . and his hair disheveled.

entry.def: Bloodshot.
stained with blood; as, a bloodstained shirt; a bloodstained carpet; a bloodstained sidewalk.
A piece of hard wood loaded at one end with lead, and used to strike the fleam into the vein.
thoroughbred horses (collectively).
A green siliceous stone sprinkled with red jasper, as if with blood; hence the name; -- called also heliotrope.
Hematite, an ore of iron yielding a blood red powder or “streak.”

entry.ety: Cf. F. coup de sang
entry.def: Loss of sensation and motion from hemorrhage or congestion in the brain.

sn.def: Any animal that sucks blood; esp., the leech (Hirudo medicinalis), and related species.
One who sheds blood; a cruel, bloodthirsty man; one guilty of bloodshed; a murderer.
A hard and exacting master, landlord, or money lender; an extortioner.
drawing blood from the body of another; as, a plague of bloodsucking insects.
having the nature or habits of a parasite or leech; living off another; -- of plants or persons; as, a bloodsucking blackmailer; bloodsucking lawyers.

entry.def: Eager to shed blood; cruel; sanguinary; murderous; having a bloodlust.

sn.def: a European deciduous shrub (Cornus sanguinea) turning red in autumn having dull white flowers.
sn.syn: common European dogwood, red dogwood, pedwood.

entry.def: The European bullfinch.

entries.entry: Blood" ves`sel. Anat Any vessel or canal in which blood circulates in an animal, as an artery or vein.

entry.ety: AS. blōwīte; blōd blood, + wīte wite, fine
entry.def: A fine or amercement paid as part of a settlement for the shedding of blood; also, a riot wherein blood was spilled.

entry.note: Norfolk Island bloodwood is a euphorbiaceous tree (Baloghia lucida), from which the sap is collected for use as a plant. Various other trees have the name, chiefly on account of the color of the wood, as Gordonia Hæmatoxylon of Jamaica, and several species of Australian Eucalyptus; also the true logwood ( Hæmatoxylon campechianum).
entry.def: A tree having the wood or the sap of the color of blood.

A plant, Rumex sanguineus, or bloody-veined dock. The name is applied also to bloodroot (Sanguinaria Canadensis), and to an extensive order of plants (Hæmodoraceæ), the roots of many species of which contain a red coloring matter useful in dyeing.

entry.ety: AS. blōdig

sn.def: Containing or resembling blood; of the nature of blood; as, bloody excretions; bloody sweat.
Smeared or stained with blood; as, bloody hands; a bloody handkerchief.
Given, or tending, to the shedding of blood; having a cruel, savage disposition; murderous; cruel.
sn.q: Some bloody passion shakes your very frame.

sn.def: Attended with, or involving, bloodshed; sanguinary; esp., marked by great slaughter or cruelty; as, a bloody battle.
Infamous; contemptible; -- variously used for mere emphasis or as a low epithet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bloodied; p. pr. & vb. n. Bloodying
entry.def: To stain with blood.
A terrible bugbear.

entries.entry: Blood"y flux`. The dysentery, a disease in which the flux or discharge from the bowels has a mixture of blood.

Blood"y hand`. A hand stained with the blood of a deer, which, in the old forest laws of England, was sufficient evidence of a man's trespass in the forest against venison.
Her A red hand, as in the arms of Ulster, which is now the distinguishing mark of a baronet of the United Kingdom.

entry.def: Having a cruel, ferocious disposition; bloodthirsty.

entries.entry: Blood"y sweat`. A sweat accompanied by a discharge of blood; a disease, called sweating sickness, formerly prevalent in England and other countries.

entry.ety: OE. blome, fr. Icel. bl�m bl�mi; akin to Sw. blom, Goth. bl�ma, OS. bl�mo, D. bloem, OHG. bluomo bluoma, G. blume; fr. the same root as AS. bl�wan to blow, blossom. See Blow to bloom, and cf. Blossom

sn.def: A blossom; the flower of a plant; an expanded bud; flowers, collectively.
sn.q: The rich blooms of the tropics.

sn.def: The opening of flowers in general; the state of blossoming or of having the flowers open; as, the cherry trees are in bloom .
sn.q: Sight of vernalbloom.

sn.def: A state or time of beauty, freshness, and vigor; an opening to higher perfection, analogous to that of buds into blossoms; as, the bloom of youth.
sn.q: Every successive mother has transmitted a fainter bloom, a more delicate and briefer beauty.

sn.def: The delicate, powdery coating upon certain growing or newly-gathered fruits or leaves, as on grapes, plums, etc. Hence: Anything giving an appearance of attractive freshness; a flush; a glow.
sn.q: A new, fresh, brilliant world, with all the bloom upon it.

sn.def: The clouded appearance which varnish sometimes takes upon the surface of a picture.
A yellowish deposit or powdery coating which appears on well-tanned leather.
A popular term for a bright-hued variety of some minerals; as, the rose-red cobalt bloom .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bloomed; p. pr. & vb. n. Blooming

sn.def: To produce or yield blossoms; to blossom; to flower or be in flower.
sn.q: A flower which once In Paradise, fast by the tree of life, Began to bloom.

sn.def: To be in a state of healthful, growing youth and vigor; to show beauty and freshness, as of flowers; to give promise, as by or with flowers.
sn.q: A better country blooms to view,
Beneath a brighter sky.

sn.def: To cause to blossom; to make flourish.
sn.q: Charitable affection bloomed them.

sn.def: To bestow a bloom upon; to make blooming or radiant.
sn.q: While barred clouds bloom the soft-dying day.

entry.ety: AS. bl�ma a mass or lump, īsenes bl�ma a lump or wedge of iron
entry.def: A mass of wrought iron from the Catalan forge or from the puddling furnace, deprived of its dross, and shaped usually in the form of an oblong block by shingling.
A large bar of steel formed directly from an ingot by hammering or rolling, being a preliminary shape for further working.
See Bloomery.

entry.ety: From Mrs. Bloomer, an American, who sought to introduce this style of dress

sn.def: A costume for women, consisting of a short dress, with loose trousers gathered round ankles, and (commonly) a broad-brimmed hat.
A woman who wears a Bloomer costume.

entry.def: A furnace and forge in which wrought iron in the form of blooms is made directly from the ore, or (more rarely) from cast iron.
The process of making blooms from the ore or from cast iron.

sn.def: Opening in blossoms; flowering.
Thriving in health, beauty, and vigor; indicating the freshness and beauties of youth or health.

entry.def: In a blooming manner.
A blooming condition.
Without bloom or flowers.

sn.def: Full of bloom; flowery; flourishing with the vigor of youth; as, a bloomy spray.
sn.q: But all the bloomy flush of life is fled.

sn.def: Covered with bloom, as fruit.

entry.def: Bloom; a blossoming.
entry.q: All that blooth means heavy autumn work for him and his hands.

entry.ety: Perh. a variant of blare, v. i.; or cf. Gael. & Ir. blor a loud noise
entry.def: The act of blowing; a roaring wind; a blast.
entry.q: A most tempestuous blore.

entry.def: Blossomy.

entry.note: ☞ The term has been applied by some botanists, and is also applied in common usage, to the corolla. It is more commonly used than flower or bloom, when we have reference to the fruit which is to succeed. Thus we use flowers when we speak of plants cultivated for ornament, and bloom in a more general sense, as of flowers in general, or in reference to the beauty of flowers.

cs.cd: having the blossoms open; in bloom.

entry.ety: OE. blosme blostme, AS. blōsma blōstma, blossom; akin to D. bloesem, L. fios, and E. flower; from the root of E. blow to blossom. See Blow to blossom, and cf. Bloom a blossom

sn.def: The flower of a plant, or the essential organs of reproduction, with their appendages; florescence; bloom; the flowers of a plant, collectively; as, the blossoms and fruit of a tree; an apple tree in blossom .
sn.q: Blossoms flaunting in the eye of day.

sn.def: A blooming period or stage of development; something lovely that gives rich promise.
sn.q: In the blossom of my youth.

sn.def: The color of a horse that has white hairs intermixed with sorrel and bay hairs; -- otherwise called peach color.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blossomed; p. pr. & vb. n. Blossoming
entry.ety: AS. bl�stmian. See Blossom n.

sn.def: To put forth blossoms or flowers; to bloom; to blow; to flower.
sn.q: The moving whisper of huge trees that branched And blossomed.

sn.def: To flourish and prosper; to develop into a superior type.
sn.q: Israel shall blossom and bud, and full the face of the world with fruit.

sn.def: to appear or grow as if by blossoming; to spread out rapidly.

entry.def: the process of budding and unfolding of blossoms.
Without blossoms.
Full of blossoms; flowery.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blotted; p. pr. & vb. n. Blotting
entry.ety: Cf. Dan. plette. See 3d Blot

sn.def: To spot, stain, or bespatter, as with ink.
sn.q: The brief was writ and blotted all with gore.

sn.def: To impair; to damage; to mar; to soil.
sn.q: It blots thy beauty, as frosts do bite the meads.

sn.def: To stain with infamy; to disgrace.
sn.q: Blot not thy innocence with guiltless blood.

sn.def: To obliterate, as writing with ink; to cancel; to efface; -- generally with out; as, to blot out a word or a sentence. Often figuratively; as, to blot out offenses.
sn.q: One act like this blots out a thousand crimes.

sn.def: To obscure; to eclipse; to shadow.
sn.q: He sung how earth blots the moon's gilded wane.

sn.def: To dry, as writing, with blotting paper.
sn.syn: To obliterate; expunge; erase; efface; cancel; tarnish; disgrace; blur; sully; smear; smutch.

entry.def: To take a blot; as, this paper blots easily.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. blettr, Dan. plet

sn.def: A spot or stain, as of ink on paper; a blur.
sn.q: Inkyblotsand rotten parchment bonds.

sn.def: An obliteration of something written or printed; an erasure.
A spot on reputation; a stain; a disgrace; a reproach; a blemish.
sn.q: This deadly blot in thy digressing son.

entry.ety: Cf. Dan. blot bare, naked, Sw. blott, d. bloot, G. bloss, and perh. E. bloat

sd.def: An exposure of a single man to be taken up.
A single man left on a point, exposed to be taken up.
sd.q: He is too great a master of his art to make a blot which may be so easily hit.

sn.def: A weak point; a failing; an exposed point or mark.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. blacche in blacchepot blacking pot, akin to black, as bleach is akin to bleak. See Black a., or cf. Blot a spot

sn.def: A blot or spot, as of color or of ink; especially a large or irregular spot. Also Fig.; as, a moral blotch .
sn.q: Spots and blotches . . . some red, others yellow.

sn.def: A large pustule, or a coarse eruption.
sn.q: Foul scurf and blotches him defile.

entry.def: Marked or covered with blotches.
entry.q: To give their blotched and blistered bodies ease.

entry.def: Having blotches.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bloted; p. pr. & vb. n. Bloting
entry.ety: Cf. Sw. blöt-fisk soaked fish, fr. blöta to soak. See 1st Bloat
entry.def: To cure, as herrings, by salting and smoking them; to bloat.
Without blot.

sn.def: One who, or that which, blots; esp. a device for absorbing superfluous ink.
A wastebook, in which entries of transactions are made as they take place.

entry.def: Characterized by blots or heavy touches; coarsely depicted; wanting in delineation.

entries.entry: Blot"ting pa`per pā`pẽr. A kind of thick, bibulous, unsized paper, used to absorb superfluous ink from a freshly written manuscript, and thus prevent blots.

entry.def: drunk{1}.

entry.ety: F. blouse. Of unknown origin
entry.def: A light, loose over-garment, like a smock frock, worn especially by workingmen in France; also, a loose coat of any material, as the undress uniform coat of the United States army.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. bloviated blō"vĭ*ā*tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. bloviating blō"vĭ*ā*tĭng
entry.def: To orate pompously; -- used especially of politicians and news commentators.
entry.au: Frank Rich (N. Y. Times Jan. 6, 1999, p. A23

q.au: Quoted by Eric Schmitt in The New York Times, Jan 22, 1999, p. A15.

entry.q: “We've had almost three weeks of lawyers bloviating about what the facts in the case are,” Mr. Rogan said. “Wouldn't it be easier to bring the witnesses?”

entry.vmorph: imp. Blew blū; p. p. Blown blōn; p. pr. & vb. n. Blowing
entry.ety: OE. blowen, AS. blōwan to blossom; akin to OS. blōjan, D. bloeijen, OHG. pluojan, MHG. blüejen, G. blühen, L. florere to flourish, OIr. blath blossom. Cf. Blow to puff, Flourish
entry.def: To flower; to blossom; to bloom.
entry.q: How blows the citron grove.

entry.def: To cause to blossom; to put forth (blossoms or flowers).
entry.q: The odorous banks, that blow Flowers of more mingled hue.

entry.def: A blossom; a flower; also, a state of blossoming; a mass of blossoms.
entry.q: Such ablowof tulips.

entry.cs: At a blow suddenly; at one effort; by a single vigorous act. “They lose a province at a blow.” Dryden. To come to blows to engage in combat; to fight; -- said of individuals, armies, and nations.
entry.ety: OE. blaw blowe; cf. OHG. bliuwan pliuwan, to beat, G. bläuen, Goth. bliggwan

sn.def: A forcible stroke with the hand, fist, or some instrument, as a rod, a club, an ax, or a sword.
sn.q: Well struck ! there was blow for blow.

sn.def: A sudden or forcible act or effort; an assault.
sn.q: A vigorous blow might win [Hanno's camp].

sn.def: The infliction of evil; a sudden calamity; something which produces mental, physical, or financial suffering or loss (esp. when sudden); a buffet.
sn.q: A most poor man, made tame to fortune's blows.

entry.cs: To blow hot and cold a saying derived from a fable of Æsop's to favor a thing at one time and treat it coldly at another; or to appear both to favor and to oppose. To blow off to let steam escape through a passage provided for the purpose; as, the engine or steamer is blowing off. To blow out. To be driven out by the expansive force of a gas or vapor; as, a steam cock or valve sometimes blows out . To talk violently or abusively. Low To blow over to pass away without effect; to cease, or be dissipated; as, the storm and the clouds have blown over . To blow up to be torn to pieces and thrown into the air as by an explosion of powder or gas or the expansive force of steam; to burst; to explode; as, a powder mill or steam boiler blows up. “The enemy's magazines blew up.” Tatler.
entry.vmorph: imp. Blew blū; p. p. Blown blōn; p. pr. & vb. n. Blowing
entry.ety: OE. blawen blowen, AS. blāwan to blow, as wind; akin to OHG. plājan, G. blähen, to blow up, swell, L. flare to blow, Gr. 'ekflai`nein to spout out, and to E. bladder blast inflate, etc., and perh. blow to bloom

sn.def: To produce a current of air; to move, as air, esp. to move rapidly or with power; as, the wind blows .
sn.q: Hark how it rains and blows !

sn.def: To send forth a forcible current of air, as from the mouth or from a pair of bellows.
To breathe hard or quick; to pant; to puff.
sn.q: Here is Mistress Page at the door, sweating and blowing.

sn.def: To sound on being blown into, as a trumpet.
sn.q: There let the pealing organ blow.

sn.def: To spout water, etc., from the blowholes, as a whale.
To be carried or moved by the wind; as, the dust blows in from the street.
sn.q: The grass blows from their graves to thy own.

sn.def: To talk loudly; to boast; to storm.
sn.q: You blow behind my back, but dare not say anything to my face.

sn.def: To stop functioning due to a failure in an electrical circuit, especially on which breaks the circuit; sometimes used with out; -- used of light bulbs, electronic components, fuses; as, the dome light in the car blew out.
To deflate by sudden loss of air; usually used with out; -- of inflatable tires.

entry.cs: To blow great guns to blow furiously and with roaring blasts; -- said of the wind at sea or along the coast. To blow off to empty (a boiler) of water through the blow-off pipe, while under steam pressure; also, to eject (steam, water, sediment, etc.) from a boiler. To blow one's own trumpet to vaunt one's own exploits, or sound one's own praises. To blow out to extinguish by a current of air, as a candle. To blow up. To fill with air; to swell; as, to blow up a bladder or bubble. To inflate, as with pride, self-conceit, etc.; to puff up; as, to blow one up with flattery. “Blown up with high conceits engendering pride.” Milton. To excite; as, to blow up a contention. To burst, to raise into the air, or to scatter, by an explosion; as, to blow up a fort. To scold violently; as, to blow up a person for some offense. Colloq I have blown him up well -- nobody can say I wink at what he does. G. Eliot. To blow upon. To blast; to taint; to bring into discredit; to render stale, unsavory, or worthless. To inform against. Colloq How far the very custom of hearing anything spouted withers and blows upon a fine passage, may be seen in those speeches from [Shakespeare's] Henry V. which are current in the mouths of schoolboys. C. Lamb. A lady's maid whose character had been blown upon. Macaulay.

sn.def: To force a current of air upon with the mouth, or by other means; as, to blow the fire.
To drive by a current air; to impel; as, the tempest blew the ship ashore.
sn.q: Off at sea northeast winds blow Sabean odors from the spicy shore.

sn.def: To cause air to pass through by the action of the mouth, or otherwise; to cause to sound, as a wind instrument; as, to blow a trumpet; to blow an organ; to blow a horn.
sn.q: Hath she no husband That will take pains to blow a horn before her?
Boy, blow the pipe until the bubble rise, Then cast it off to float upon the skies.

sn.def: To clear of contents by forcing air through; as, to blow an egg; to blow one's nose.
To burst, shatter, or destroy by an explosion; -- usually with up down open, or similar adverb; as, to blow up a building.
To spread by report; to publish; to disclose; to reveal, intentionally or inadvertently; as, to blow an agent's cover.
sn.q: Through the court his courtesy was blown.
His language does his knowledge blow.

sn.def: To form by inflation; to swell by injecting air; as, to blow bubbles; to blow glass.
To inflate, as with pride; to puff up.
sn.q: Look how imagination blows him.

sn.def: To put out of breath; to cause to blow from fatigue; as, to blow a horse.
To deposit eggs or larvæ upon, or in (meat, etc.).
sn.q: To suffer The flesh fly blow my mouth.

sn.def: To perform an act of fellatio on; to stimulate another's penis with one's mouth; -- usually considered vulgar.
to smoke (e. g. marijuana); to blow pot.
to botch; to bungle; as, he blew his chance at a good job by showing up late for the interview.
to leave; to depart from; as, to blow town.
to squander; as, he blew his inheritance gambling.
A blowing, esp., a violent blowing of the wind; a gale; as, a heavy blow came on, and the ship put back to port.
The act of forcing air from the mouth, or through or from some instrument; as, to give a hard blow on a whistle or horn; to give the fire a blow with the bellows.
The spouting of a whale.
A single heat or operation of the Bessemer converter.
An egg, or a larva, deposited by a fly on or in flesh, or the act of depositing it.
the backward escape of unburned gunpowder after a shot.

entry.def: The downy seed head of a dandelion, which children delight to blow away.
the leakage of gases from the combustion cylinder of an internal combustion engine between the piston and cylinder wall into the crankcase.
A prostitute; a courtesan; a strumpet.

sn.def: One who, or that which, blows.

A device for producing a current of air; as: A metal plate temporarily placed before the upper part of a grate or open fire. A machine for producing an artificial blast or current of air by pressure, as for increasing the draft of a furnace, ventilating a building or shaft, cleansing gram, etc.
A blowing out or excessive discharge of gas from a hole or fissure in a mine.
The whale; -- so called by seamen, from the circumstance of its spouting up a column of water.
A small fish of the Atlantic coast (Tetrodon turgidus); the puffer.
A braggart, or loud talker.

entry.note: In Japan it is called fugu. Deaths due to ingestion of the meat of this fish occur almost every year.

sn.def: a fish eaten as a delicacy, especially in Japan. It is highly dangerous because of a potent nerve poison (tetrodotoxin) in its ovaries and liver. Chefs require special training to learn how to remove the poisonous parts, and in Japan they must be licensed.

any of numerous marine fishes of the family Tetraodontidae whose elongated spiny body can inflate itself with water or air to form a globe; several species contain tetrodotoxin, a potent nerve poison; they are closely related to spiny puffers.

entry.def: Any species of fly of the genus Musca that deposits its eggs or young larvæ (called flyblows and maggots) upon meat or other animal products.

A tube, as of cane or reed, sometimes twelve feet long, through which an arrow (sometimes poisoned) or other projectile may be impelled by the force of the breath. It is a weapon much used by certain Indians of America and the West Indies; -- called also blowpipe, and blowtube. See Sumpitan.
a very boastful and talkative person.

entry.note: ☞ There are two spiracles or blowholes in the common whales, but only one in sperm whales, porpoises, etc.

sn.def: A cavern in a cliff, at the water level, opening to the air at its farther extremity, so that the waters rush in with each surge and rise in a lofty jet from the extremity.
A nostril or spiracle in the top of the head of a whale or other cetacean.
A hole in the ice to which whales, seals, etc., come to breathe.
An air hole in a casting.
processing that involves blowing a gas.
windy.

entry.def: An act of fellatio, a form of oral sex; -- a slang term. See blow11}, v. i.
A burner that produces a hot flame.

sn.def: Swollen; inflated; distended; puffed up, as cattle when gorged with green food which develops gas.
Stale; worthless.
Out of breath; tired; exhausted.
Covered with the eggs and larvæ of flies; fly blown.

entry.def: Opened; in blossom or having blossomed, as a flower.

entry.sn:
A blowing off steam, water, etc.;Also, adj.
as, a blow-off cock or pipe.

sn.def: An outburst of temper or excitement.

entry.def: The cleaning of the flues of a boiler from scale, etc., by a blast of steam.

sn.def: a gay or lavish festivity.
the sudden deflation of an inflatable tire due to a puncture or rupture, often accompanied by a bang.
the sudden escape of gas or liquid confined under pressure, such as in a gas or oil well, or in a system containing pressurized air or steam.

entry.note: ☞ It is called a mouth blowpipe when used with the mouth; but for both chemical and industrial purposes, it is often worked by a bellows or other contrivance. The common mouth blowpipe is a tapering tube with a very small orifice at the end to be inserted in the flame. The oxyhydrogen blowpipe, invented by Dr. Hare in 1801, is an instrument in which oxygen and hydrogen, taken from separate reservoirs, in the proportions of two volumes of hydrogen to one of oxygen, are burned in a jet, under pressure. It gives a heat that will consume the diamond, fuse platinum, and dissipate in vapor, or in gaseous forms, most known substances.

cs.cd: analysis by means of the blowpipe.
the characteristic behavior of a substance subjected to a test by means of the blowpipe.

sn.def: A tube for directing a jet of air into a fire or into the flame of a lamp or candle, so as to concentrate the heat on some object.
A blowgun; a blowtube.

entry.def: A child's game.
See Blowze.

entry.ety: From Blow to blossom: cf. Growth
entry.def: A blossoming; a bloom.
entry.q: In theblowthand bud.

sn.def: A blowgun.
A similar instrument, commonly of tin, used by boys for discharging paper wads and other light missiles.
A long wrought iron tube, on the end of which the workman gathers a quantity of “metal” (melted glass), and through which he blows to expand or shape it; -- called also blowing tube, and blowpipe.

entries.entry: Blow" valve`. Mach See Snifting valve.

entry.def: Windy; as, blowy weather; a blowy upland.

entry.ety: Prob. from the same root as blush
entry.def: A ruddy, fat-faced woman; a wench.
Having high color from exposure to the weather; ruddy-faced; blowzy; disordered.
entry.q: Huge women blowzed with health and wind.

entry.def: Coarse and ruddy-faced; fat and ruddy; high colored; frowzy.

entry.ety: Cf. Bleb Blob
entry.def: To swell; to puff out, as with weeping.

entry.ety: See Blobber Blob Bleb

sn.def: A bubble.
sn.q: At his mouth a blubber stood of foam.

sn.def: The fat of whales and other large sea animals from which oil is obtained. It lies immediately under the skin and over the muscular flesh.
A large sea nettle or medusa.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blubbered; p. pr. & vb. n. Blubbering
entry.def: To weep noisily, or so as to disfigure the face; to cry in a childish manner.
entry.q: She wept, she blubbered, and she tore her hair.

sn.def: To swell or disfigure (the face) with weeping; to wet with tears.
sn.q: Dear Cloe, how blubbered is that pretty face!

sn.def: To give vent to (tears) or utter (broken words or cries); -- with forth or out.

entry.def: Swollen; turgid; as, a blubbered lip.
The act of weeping noisily.
entry.q: He spake well save that his blubbering interrupted him.

sn.def: Swollen; protuberant.
Like blubber; gelatinous and quivering; as, a blubbery mass.

entry.def: A kind of half boot, or high shoe, with laces over the tongue; -- named from the Prussian general Blücher.

entry.ety: Cf. Ir. blocan a little block, Gael. plocan a mallet, W. plocyn, dim. of ploc block; or perh. connected with E. blow a stroke. Cf. Block Blow a stroke
entry.def: A short stick, with one end loaded, or thicker and heavier that the other, used as an offensive weapon.

entry.cs:
Blue asbestus. See Crocidolite. Blue black of, or having, a very dark blue color, almost black. Blue blood. See under Blood. Blue buck Zoöl a small South African antelope (Cephalophus pygmæus); also applied to a larger species (Ægoceras leucophæus); the blaubok. Blue cod Zoöl the buffalo cod. Blue crab Zoöl the common edible crab of the Atlantic coast of the United States (Callinectes hastatus). Blue curls Bot a common plant (Trichostema dichotomum), resembling pennyroyal, and hence called also bastard pennyroyal. Blue devils apparitions supposed to be seen by persons suffering with delirium tremens; hence, very low spirits. “Can Gumbo shut the hall door upon blue devils, or lay them all in a red sea of claret?” Thackeray. Blue gage. See under Gage, a plum. Blue gum an Australian myrtaceous tree (Eucalyptus globulus), of the loftiest proportions, now cultivated in tropical and warm temperate regions for its timber, and as a protection against malaria. The essential oil is beginning to be used in medicine. The timber is very useful. See Eucalyptus.
Blue jack Blue stone
blue vitriol; sulphate of copper. Blue jacket a man-of war's man; a sailor wearing a naval uniform. Blue jaundice. See under Jaundice. Blue laws a name first used in the eighteenth century to describe certain supposititious laws of extreme rigor reported to have been enacted in New Haven; hence, any puritanical laws. U. S Blue light a composition which burns with a brilliant blue flame; -- used in pyrotechnics and as a night signal at sea, and in military operations. Blue mantle Her one of the four pursuivants of the English college of arms; -- so called from the color of his official robes. Blue mass a preparation of mercury from which is formed the blue pill. McElrath.
Blue moldorBlue mould
the blue fungus (Aspergillus glaucus) which grows on cheese. Brande & C. Blue Monday a Monday following a Sunday of dissipation, or itself given to dissipation (as the Monday before Lent). a Monday considered as depressing because it is a workday in contrast to the relaxation of the weekend. Blue ointment Med mercurial ointment. Blue Peter British Marine a blue flag with a white square in the center, used as a signal for sailing, to recall boats, etc. It is a corruption of blue repeater, one of the British signal flags. Blue pill. Med A pill of prepared mercury, used as an aperient, etc. Blue mass. Blue ribbon. The ribbon worn by members of the order of the Garter; -- hence, a member of that order. Anything the attainment of which is an object of great ambition; a distinction; a prize. “These [scholarships] were the blue ribbon of the college.” Farrar. The distinctive badge of certain temperance or total abstinence organizations, as of the Blue ribbon Army. Blue ruin utter ruin; also, gin. Eng. Slang Carlyle. Blue spar Min azure spar; lazulite. See Lazulite. Blue thrush Zoöl a European and Asiatic thrush (Petrocossyphus cyaneas). Blue verditer. See Verditer. Blue vitriol Chem sulphate of copper, a violet blue crystallized salt, used in electric batteries, calico printing, etc. Blue water the open ocean. Big Blue the International Business Machines corporation. Wall Street slang To look blue to look disheartened or dejected. True blue genuine and thorough; not modified, nor mixed; not spurious; specifically, of uncompromising Presbyterianism, blue being the color adopted by the Covenanters.
entry.ety: OE. bla blo blew, blue, livid, black, fr. Icel.blār livid; akin to Dan. blaa blue, Sw. blå, D. blauw, OHG. blāo, G. blau; but influenced in form by F. bleu, from OHG. blāo

sn.def: Having the color of the clear sky, or a hue resembling it, whether lighter or darker; as, the deep, blue sea; as blue as a sapphire; blue violets.
sn.q: Thebluefirmament.

sn.def: Pale, without redness or glare, -- said of a flame; hence, of the color of burning brimstone, betokening the presence of ghosts or devils; as, the candle burns blue; the air was blue with oaths.
Low in spirits; melancholy; as, to feel blue .
Suited to produce low spirits; gloomy in prospect; as, thongs looked blue .
Severe or over strict in morals; gloom; as, blue and sour religionists; suiting one who is over strict in morals; inculcating an impracticable, severe, or gloomy mortality; as, blue laws.
Literary; -- applied to women; -- an abbreviation of bluestocking.
sn.q: The ladies were very blue and well informed.
For his religion . . . 'T was Presbyterian, true blue.

entry.cs: Berlin blue Prussian blue. Mineral blue. See under Mineral. Prussian blue. See under Prussian.

sn.def: One of the seven colors into which the rays of light divide themselves, when refracted through a glass prism; the color of the clear sky, or a color resembling that, whether lighter or darker; a pigment having such color.
the sky; as, to fly off into the blue .
A pedantic woman; a bluestocking.
Low spirits; a fit of despondency; melancholy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blued; p. pr. & vb. n. Bluing
entry.def: To make blue; to dye of a blue color; to make blue by heating, as metals, etc.
A trout (Salmo oquassa) inhabiting some of the lakes of Maine.
A salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka) of the Columbia River and northward.
An American river herring (Clupea æstivalis), closely allied to the alewife.

The hero of a mediæval French nursery legend, who, leaving home, enjoined his young wife not to open a certain room in his castle. She entered it, and found the murdered bodies of his former wives. -- Also used adjectively of a subject which it is forbidden to investigate.
entry.q: The Bluebeard chamber of his mind, into which no eye but his own must look.

entry.def: A plant of the genus Campanula, especially the Campanula rotundifolia, which bears blue bell-shaped flowers; the harebell.
A plant of the genus Scilla Scilla nutans).

entry.ety: Cf. Blaeberry
entry.def: The berry of several species of Vaccinium, an ericaceous genus, differing from the American huckleberries in containing numerous minute seeds instead of ten nutlets. The commonest species are Vaccinium Pennsylvanicum and Vaccinium vacillans. Vaccinium corymbosum is the tall blueberry.
A duck of the genus Fuligula. Two American species (Fuligula marila and Fuligula affinis) are common. See Scaup duck.

cs.cd: a brilliant Indian or East Indian bird of the genus Irena, of several species.

entry.def: A small song bird (Sialia sialis), very common in the United States, and, in the north, one of the earliest to arrive in spring. The male is blue, with the breast reddish. It is related to the European robin.
unable to see the color blue or to distinguish the colors blue and yellow.
inability to distinguish blue and yellow.

sn.def: a member of the nobility or aristocracy, or a person of high social status.
the quality of status that qualifies one as a blue blood; -- used metaphorically, as “They have blue blood in their veins.”.

entry.def: of aristocratic birth and refined upbringing.
entry.syn: aristocratic, coroneted, gentle, highborn, patrician, titled, wellborn, upper-class.

sn.def: A broad, flat Scottish cap of blue woolen, or one wearing such cap; a Scotchman.
A plant. Same as Bluebottle.
The European blue titmouse (Parus cœruleus); the bluecap.

entries.entry:
Blue" book`. A parliamentary publication, so called from its blue paper covers. Eng
The United States official “Biennial Register.”

sn.def: an annual Eurasian plant (Centaurea cyanus) which grows in grain fields; -- called also bachelor's button. It receives its name from its blue bottle-shaped flowers. Varieties cultivated in North America have showy heads of blue or purple or pink or white flowers
A large and troublesome species of blowfly (Musca vomitoria). Its body is steel blue.

entry.def: A small European bird; the blue-throated warbler.

sd.def: The bluepoll.
The blue bonnet or blue titmouse.

sn.def: A Scot; a Scotchman; -- so named from wearing a blue bonnet.

entry.def: One dressed in blue, as a soldier, a sailor, a beadle, etc.

entry.sn: of or designating work or workers in industry not requiring well-groomed appearance.Narrower terms: industrial white-collar
of those who work for wages especially manual or industrial laborers.Narrower terms: lower-class, low-class propertyless, wage-earning, working-class.

entry.def: The blue-cheeked honeysucker of Australia.

sn.def: Having blue eyes.
favorite.

entry.def: a grasslike plant (Sisyrinchium anceps), with small flowers of a delicate blue color.
A species of whitefish (Coregonus nigripinnis) found in Lake Michigan.

entry.note: ☞ The name is applied locally to other species of fishes; as the cunner, sea bass, squeteague, etc.

sn.def: A large voracious fish (Pomatomus saitatrix), of the family Carangidæ, valued as a food fish, and widely distributed on the American coast. On the New Jersey and Rhode Island coast it is called the horse mackerel, in Virginia saltwater tailor, or skipjack.
A West Indian fish (Platyglossus radiatus), of the family Labridæ.

entry.def: One of a class of paupers or pensioners, or licensed beggars, in Scotland, to whim annually on the king's birthday were distributed certain alms, including a blue gown; a beadsman.

entries.entry:
Blue" grass`
Kentucky blue grass a species of grass (Poa pratensis) which has running rootstocks and spreads rapidly. It is valuable as a pasture grass, as it endures both winter and drought better than other kinds, and is very nutritious. . Bot A species of grass (Poa compressa) with bluish green stems, valuable in thin gravelly soils; wire grass.
Blue-grass State. The Sate of Kentucky; -- a nickname alluding to the blue-grass region, where fine horses are bred.

blue"-green al"ga. pl.blue"-green al"gae
from the color and resemblance to algae any of a group of photosynthetic microorganisms possessing characteristics of both bacteria and plants. When classed as bacteria, they are assigned to the Cyanobacteria; when classed as plants, they are assigned to the Cyanophyta. They are now known to be prokaryotic, and are usually called cyanobacteria in technical contexts. See cyanobacterium.

Blue Hen State. The State of Delaware; -- a popular sobriquet. It is said, though the story lacks proof, to have taken its origin from the insistence of a Delaware Revolutionary captain, named Caldwell, that no cock could be truly game unless the mother was a blue hen, whence Blue Hen's Chickens came to be a nickname for the people of Delaware.

entry.def: Same as bluing.
a serviceman in the navy.

entries.entry: Blue" jay`. Zoöl The common jay of the United States (Cyanocitta, or Cyanura, cristata). The predominant color is bright blue.

entry.def: a tight-fitting trousers made of blue denim or a similar fabric, designed originally to serve as inexpensive durable workclothes, and often having metal rivets for reinforcement. They have become very popular as casual wear for all age groups, and more expensive and more carefully styled and tailored versions called designer jeanshave also become popular among girls and women.
A name given to fluor spar in Derbyshire, where it is used for ornamental purposes.
With a blue color.

cs.cd: very rarely; -- from the observation that the moon rarely has a bluish tint.
cs.note: In 1980, the phrase blue moon was applied to the second full moon of any month, because this phenomenon is unusual. This new meaning for the old phrase blue moon has become widely accepted.

entry.def: The second full moon occurring in the same month; -- derived from the expression once in a blue moon; as, we had a blue moon on January 31, 1999, and another in March.
The quality of being blue; a blue color.
A nickname for a Nova Scotian; also, a Nova Scotian ship (called also Blue"nos`er); a Nova Scotian potato, etc.
to change, delete, or abridge (a portion of a text) with a blue pencil (or as if with a blue pencil), as in the editing process; -- of books, etc.

entry.ety: Blue + poll head
entry.def: A kind of salmon (Salmo Cambricus) found in Wales.

entries.entry: Blue"print. See under Print.

entry.def: selected or chosen for special qualifications; as, a blue-ribbon grand jury.
a type of folk song that originated among Black Americans at the beginning of the 20th century; has a melancholoy sound from repeated used of blue notes.

sn.def: a state of depression; as, he had a bad case of the blues .

entries.entry: Blue"-sky"law`. A law enacted to provide for the regulation and supervision of investment companies in order to protect the public against companies that do not intend to do a fair and honest business and that offer investments that do not promise a fair return; -- so called because the promises made by some investment companies are as boundless or alluring as the blue sky, or, perhaps, because designed to clear away the clouds and fogs from the simple investor's horizon. Colloq

entry.def: tall grass with smooth bluish leaf sheaths grown for hay in Western U.S.
entry.syn: blue stem, Andropogon furcatus, Andropogon gerardii.

entry.note: ☞ As explained in Boswell's “Life of Dr. Johnson”, this term is derived from the name given to certain meetings held by ladies, in Johnson's time, for conversation with distinguished literary men. An eminent attendant of these assemblies was a Mr. Stillingfleet, who always wore blue stockings. He was so much distinguished for his conversational powers that his absence at any time was felt to be a great loss, so that the remark became common, “We can do nothing without the blue stockings.” Hence these meetings were sportively called bluestocking clubs, and the ladies who attended them, bluestockings.

sn.def: A literary lady; a female pedant.
The American avocet (Recurvirostra Americana).

entry.def: The character or manner of a bluestocking; female pedantry.

sn.def: Blue vitriol.
A grayish blue building stone, as that commonly used in the eastern United States.

entry.def: A singing bird of northern Europe and Asia (Cyanecula Suecica), related to the nightingales; -- called also blue-throated robin and blue-throated warbler.

entry.ety: F. bluet bleuet, dim. of bleu blue. See Blue a.
entry.def: A name given to several different species of plants having blue flowers, as the Houstonia cœrulea, the Centaurea cyanus or bluebottle, and the Vaccinium angustifolium.
Having blue veins or blue streaks.
a coarse prickly European weed (Echium vulgare) with spikes of blue flowers; naturalized in the U. S.
entry.syn: blue devil, blue thistle, viper's bugloss.

entry.def: The blue-winged teal. See Teal.

entries.entry: Blue"y,a. Bluish.

entry.ety: From Blue a.

sn.def: A bushman's blanket; -- named from its color.
sn.q: We had to wring our blueys.

sn.def: A bushman's bundle; a swag; -- so called because a blanket is sometimes used as the outside covering.

entry.ety: Cf. OD. blaf flat, broad, blaffaert one with a broad face, also, a boaster; or G. verblüffen to confuse, LG. bluffen to frighten; to unknown origin

sn.def: Having a broad, flattened front; as, the bluff bows of a ship.
sn.q: Bluffvisages.

sn.def: Rising steeply with a flat or rounded front.
sn.q: Abluffor bold shore.
Its banks, if not really steep, had a bluff and precipitous aspect.

sn.def: Surly; churlish; gruff; rough.
Abrupt; roughly frank; unceremonious; blunt; brusque; as, a bluff answer; a bluff manner of talking; a bluff sea captain.
sn.q: BluffKing Hal.
There is indeed a bluff pertinacity which is a proper defense in a moment of surprise.

sn.def: A high, steep bank, as by a river or the sea, or beside a ravine or plain; a cliff with a broad face.
sn.q: Beach, bluff, and wave, adieu.

sn.def: An act of bluffing; an expression of self-confidence for the purpose of intimidation; braggadocio; as, that is only bluff, or a bluff .
A game at cards; poker.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bluffed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bluffing

sn.def: To deter (an opponent) from taking the risk of betting on his hand of cards, as the bluffer does by betting heavily on his own hand although it may be of less value.
To frighten or deter from accomplishing a purpose by making a show of confidence in one's strength or resources; as, he bluffed me off.

entry.def: To act as in the game of bluff.
Built with the stem nearly straight up and down.
One who bluffs.
Built with the stem nearly straight up and down.
The quality or state of being bluff.

sn.def: Having bluffs, or bold, steep banks.
Inclined to bo bluff; brusque.
The act of rendering blue; as, the bluing of steel.
Something, as indigo or other preparations, used to give a bluish tint, especially to white clothing when being washed.

entry.def: Somewhat blue; as, bluish veins.
entry.q: Bluishmists.

entry.cs: To blunder on. To continue blundering. To find or reach as if by an accident involving more or less stupidity, -- applied to something desirable; as, to blunder on a useful discovery.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blundered; p. pr. & vb. n. Blundering
entry.ety: OE. blunderen blondren, to stir, confuse, blunder; perh. allied to blend to mix, to confound by mixture

sn.def: To make a gross error or mistake; as, to blunder in writing or preparing a medical prescription.
To move in an awkward, clumsy manner; to flounder and stumble.
sn.q: I was never distinguished for address, and have often even blundered in making my bow.
Yet knows not how to find the uncertain place, And blunders on, and staggers every pace.

sn.def: To cause to blunder.
sn.q: Toblunderan adversary.

sn.def: To do or treat in a blundering manner; to confuse.
sn.q: He blunders and confounds all these together.

entry.usage: An error is a departure or deviation from that which is right or correct; as, an error of the press; an error of judgment. A mistake is the interchange or taking of one thing for another, through haste, inadvertence, etc.; as, a careless mistake. A blunder is a mistake or error of a gross kind. It supposes a person to flounder on in his course, from carelessness, ignorance, or stupidity. A bull is a verbal blunder containing a laughable incongruity of ideas.

sn.def: Confusion; disturbance.
A gross error or mistake, resulting from carelessness, stupidity, or culpable ignorance.

entry.ety: Either fr. blunder + D. bus tube, box, akin to G. büchse box, gun, E. box; or corrupted fr. D. donderbusliterally) thunder box, gun, musket

sn.def: A short gun or firearm, with a large bore, capable of holding a number of balls, and intended to do execution without exact aim.
A stupid, blundering fellow.

entry.def: One who is apt to blunder.
A stupid, blundering fellow.
Characterized by blunders.
In a blundering manner.
To amalgamate and blend; to beat up or mix in water, as clay.

entry.ety: Corrupted from plunger
entry.def: A wooden blade with a cross handle, used for mi�ing the clay in potteries; a plunger.
The process of mixing clay in potteries with a blunger.

entry.note: ☞ Blunt is much used in composition, as blunt-edged, blunt-sighted, blunt-spoken.
entry.ety: Cf. Prov. G. bludde a dull or blunt knife, Dan. blunde to sleep, Sw. & Icel. blunda; or perh. akin to E. blind

sn.def: Having a thick edge or point, as an instrument; dull; not sharp.
sn.q: The murderous knife was dull and blunt.

sn.def: Dull in understanding; slow of discernment; stupid; -- opposed to acute.
sn.q: His wits are not so blunt.

sn.def: Abrupt in address; plain; unceremonious; wanting the forms of civility; rough in manners or speech.
sn.q: Hiding his bitter jests inbluntbehavior.
A plain,bluntman.

sn.def: Hard to impress or penetrate.
sn.q: I find my heart hardened and blunt to new impressions.
sn.syn: Obtuse; dull; pointless; curt; short; coarse; rude; brusque; impolite; uncivil.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blunted; p. pr. & vb. n. Blunting

sn.def: To dull the edge or point of, by making it thicker; to make blunt.
To repress or weaken, as any appetite, desire, or power of the mind; to impair the force, keenness, or susceptibility, of; as, to blunt the feelings.
A fencer's foil.
A short needle with a strong point. See Needle.
Money.
made dull or blunt.
reduced in force or effectiveness.

entry.def: Somewhat blunt.
In a blunt manner; coarsely; plainly; abruptly; without delicacy, or the usual forms of civility.
entry.q: Sometimes after bluntly giving his opinions, he would quietly lay himself asleep until the end of their deliberations.

sn.def: Want of edge or point; dullness; obtuseness; lack of sharpness.
sn.q: The multitude of elements and bluntness of angles.

sn.def: Abruptness of address; rude plainness.
sn.q: Bluntnessof speech.

entry.def: Dull; stupid.
entry.q: Blunt-witted lord, ignoble in demeanor!

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blurred blûrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Blurring
entry.ety: Prob. of same origin as blear. See Blear

sn.def: To render obscure by making the form or outline of confused and uncertain, as by soiling; to smear; to make indistinct and confused; as, to blur manuscript by handling it while damp; to blur the impression of a woodcut by an excess of ink.
sn.q: But time hath nothing blurred those lines of favor Which then he wore.

sn.def: To cause imperfection of vision in; to dim; to darken.
sn.q: Her eyes are blurred with the lightning's glare.

sn.def: To sully; to stain; to blemish, as reputation.
sn.q: Sarcasms may eclipse thine own, But can not blur my lost renown.
sn.syn: To spot; blot; disfigure; stain; sully.

sn.def: That which obscures without effacing; a stain; a blot, as upon paper or other substance.
sn.q: As for those who cleanse blurs with blotted fingers, they make it worse.

sn.def: A dim, confused appearance; indistinctness of vision; as, to see things with a blur; it was all blur .
A moral stain or blot.
sn.q: Lest she . . . will with her railing set a great blur on mine honesty and good name.

entry.def: out of focus; not sharply defined.
Full of blurs; blurred.

cs.cd: to speak contemptuously of.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blurted; p. pr. & vb. n. Blurting
entry.ety: Cf. Blare
entry.def: To utter suddenly and unadvisedly; to divulge inconsiderately; to ejaculate; -- commonly with out.
entry.q: Others . . . can not hold, but blurt out, those words which afterward they are forced to eat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blushed blŭsht; p. pr. & vb. n. Blushing
entry.ety: OE. bluschen to shine, look, turn red, AS. blyscan to glow; akin to blysa a torch, āblȳsian to blush, D. blozen, Dan. blusse to blaze, blush

sn.def: To become suffused with red in the cheeks, as from a sense of shame, modesty, or confusion; to become red from such cause, as the cheeks or face.
sn.q: To the nuptial bower I led her blushing like the morn.
In the presence of the shameless and unblushing, the young offender is ashamed to blush.
He would stroke The head of modest and ingenuous worth, That blushed at its own praise.

sn.def: To grow red; to have a red or rosy color.
sn.q: The sun of heaven, methought, was loth to set, But stayed, and made the western welkin blush.

sn.def: To have a warm and delicate color, as some roses and other flowers.
sn.q: Full many a flower is born to blush unseen.

sn.def: To suffuse with a blush; to redden; to make roseate.
sn.q: To blush and beautify the cheek again.

sn.def: To express or make known by blushing.
sn.q: I'll blush you thanks.

entry.cs:
At first blush, or At the first blush
at the first appearance or view. “At the first blush, we thought they had been ships come from France.” Hakluyt. This phrase is used now more of ideas, opinions, etc., than of material things. “All purely identical propositions, obviously, and at first blush, appear,” etc. Locke.
To put to the blush to cause to blush with shame; to put to shame.

sn.def: A suffusion of the cheeks or face with red, as from a sense of shame, confusion, or modesty.
sn.q: The rosy blush of love.

sn.def: A red or reddish color; a rosy tint.
sn.q: Light's last blushes tinged the distant hills.

entry.def: rose-colored.
One that blushes.
A modest girl.
Full of blushes.
entry.q: While from his ardent look the turning Spring Averts her blushful face.

entry.def: Showing blushes; rosy red; having a warm and delicate color like some roses and other flowers; blooming; ruddy; roseate.
entry.q: The dappled pink and blushing rose.

entry.def: The act of turning red; the appearance of a reddish color or flush upon the cheeks.
In a blushing manner; with a blush or blushes; as, to answer or confess blushingly .
Free from blushes; incapable of blushing; shameless; impudent.
entry.q: Vice now, secure, her blushless front shall raise.

entry.def: Like a blush; having the color of a blush; rosy.
entry.q: Ablushycolor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Blustered; p. pr. & vb. n. Blustering
entry.ety: Allied to blast

sn.def: To blow fitfully with violence and noise, as wind; to be windy and boisterous, as the weather.
sn.q: And ever-threatening storms Of Chaos blustering round.

sn.def: To talk with noisy violence; to swagger, as a turbulent or boasting person; to act in a noisy, tumultuous way; to play the bully; to storm; to rage.
sn.q: Your ministerial directors blustered like tragic tyrants.

entry.def: To utter, or do, with noisy violence; to force by blustering; to bully.
entry.q: He bloweth and blustereth out . . . his abominable blasphemy.
As if therewith he meant to bluster all princes into a perfect obedience to his commands.

sn.def: Fitful noise and violence, as of a storm; violent winds; boisterousness.
sn.q: To the winds they set Their corners, when with bluster to confound Sea, air, and shore.

sn.def: Noisy and violent or threatening talk; noisy and boastful language.
sn.syn: Noise; boisterousness; tumult; turbulence; confusion; boasting; swaggering; bullying.

entry.def: One who, or that which, blusters; a noisy swaggerer.

sn.def: Exhibiting noisy violence, as the wind; stormy; tumultuous.
sn.q: A tempest and a blustering day.

sn.def: Uttering noisy threats; noisy and swaggering; boisterous.
sn.q: Ablusteringfellow.

entry.def: In a blustering manner.
Inclined to bluster; given to blustering; blustering.
Blusterous.
an abbreviation for bowel movement; -- used as an informal euphemism, especially in hospitals.

sn.def: an exceedingly short-lived meson.

entry.def: any automobile manufactured by the German firm BMW AGfrom the German Bayerische MotorWerke); -- sometimes referred to colloquially as a beemer.

entry.ety: Cf. W. bw, an interj. of threatening or frightening; n., terror, fear, dread
entry.def: An exclamation used to startle or frighten.

entries.entry:
Bo"a ☞ The name is also applied to related genera; as, the dog-headed boa Xiphosoma caninum). bō"ȧ n.; pl.Boas. L. boa a kind of water serpent. Perh. fr. bos an ox
Zoöl A genus of large American serpents, including the boa constrictor, the emperor boa of Mexico (Boa imperator), and the chevalier boa of Peru (Boa eques).
A long, round fur tippet; -- so called from its resemblance in shape to the boa constrictor.

Bo"a con*strict"or ☞ It has a succession of spots, alternately black and yellow, extending along the back. It kills its prey by constriction. The name is also loosely applied to other large serpents which crush their prey, particularly to those of the genus Python, found in Asia and Africa.. NL. See Boa, and Constrictor
Zoöl A large and powerful serpent of tropical America, sometimes twenty or thirty feet long. See Illustration in Appendix.

Bo`a*ner"ges Bo`a*ner"ges. Gr. �, fr. Heb. bnē hargem sons of thunder. -- an appellation given by Christ to two of his disciples (James and John). See Mark iii. 17 Any declamatory and vociferous preacher or orator.

entry.ety: OE. bar bor bore, AS. bār; akin to OHG. pēr, MHG. bēr, G. bär, boar (but not bär bear), and perh. Russ. borov' boar
entry.def: The uncastrated male of swine; specifically, the wild hog.

entry.note: ☞ When sawed thick, as over one and a half or two inches, it is usually called a plank.
☞ The term board answers to the modern table, but it was often movable, and placed on trestles.

☞ Board is much used adjectively or as the last part of a compound; as, fir board, clapboard, floor board, shipboard, sideboard, ironing board, chessboard, cardboard, pasteboard, seaboard; board measure.
entry.cs: The American Board a shortened form of “The American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions” (the foreign missionary society of the American Congregational churches). Bed and board. See under Bed. Board and board Naut side by side. Board of control six privy councilors formerly appointed to superintend the affairs of the British East Indies. Stormonth. Board rule a figured scale for finding without calculation the number of square feet in a board. Haldeman. Board of trade in England, a committee of the privy council appointed to superintend matters relating to trade. In the United States, a body of men appointed for the advancement and protection of their business interests; a chamber of commerce. Board wages. Food and lodging supplied as compensation for services; as, to work hard, and get only board wages. Money wages which are barely sufficient to buy food and lodging. A separate or special allowance of wages for the procurement of food, or food and lodging. Dryden. By the board over the board, or side. “The mast went by the board.” Totten. Hence (Fig.), To go by the board to suffer complete destruction or overthrow. To enter on the boards to have one's name inscribed on a board or tablet in a college as a student. Cambridge, England “Having been entered on the boards of Trinity college.” Hallam. To make a good board Naut to sail in a straight line when close-hauled; to lose little to leeward. To make short boards to tack frequently. On board. On shipboard; in a ship or a boat; on board of; as, I came on board early; to be on board ship. In or into a railway car or train. Colloq. U. S Returning board a board empowered to canvass and make an official statement of the votes cast at an election. U.S
entry.ety: OE. bord, AS. bord board, shipboard; akin to bred plank, Icel. borð board, side of a ship, Goth. fōtu-baurd footstool, D. bord board, G. brett bort. See def. 8. √92

sn.def: A piece of timber sawed thin, and of considerable length and breadth as compared with the thickness, -- used for building, etc.
A table to put food upon.
sn.q: Fruit of all kinds . . . She gathers, tribute large, and on the board Heaps with unsparing hand.

sn.def: Hence: What is served on a table as food; stated meals; provision; entertainment; -- usually as furnished for pay; as, to work for one's board; the price of board .
A table at which a council or court is held.

A council, convened for business, or any authorized assembly or meeting, public or private; a number of persons appointed or elected to sit in council for the management or direction of some public or private business or trust; as, the Board of Admiralty; a board of trade; a board of directors, trustees, commissioners, etc.
sn.q: Both better acquainted with affairs than any other who sat then at that board.
We may judge from their letters to the board.

sn.def: A square or oblong piece of thin wood or other material used for some special purpose, as, a molding board ; a board or surface painted or arranged for a game; as, a chessboard; a backgammon board .
Paper made thick and stiff like a board, for book covers, etc.; pasteboard; as, to bind a book in boards .
The stage in a theater; as, to go upon the boards, to enter upon the theatrical profession.

sn.ety: In this use originally perh. a different word meaning border margin; cf. D. boord, G. bord, shipboard, and G. borte trimming; also F. bordfr. G.) the side of a ship. Cf. Border
sn.def: The border or side of anything.

sd.def: The side of a ship.
sd.q: Nowboard to boardthe rival vessels row.

sd.def: The stretch which a ship makes in one tack.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Boarded; p. pr. & vb. n. Boarding

sn.def: To cover with boards or boarding; as, to board a house.
sn.q: Theboardedhovel.

sn.ety: Cf. Board to accost, and see Board n.
sn.def: To go on board of, or enter, as a ship, whether in a hostile or a friendly way.
sn.q: You board an enemy to capture her, and a stranger to receive news or make a communication.

sn.def: To enter, as a railway car.
To furnish with regular meals, or with meals and lodgings, for compensation; to supply with daily meals.
To place at board, for compensation; as, to board one's horse at a livery stable.

entry.def: To obtain meals, or meals and lodgings, statedly for compensation; as, he boards at the hotel.
entry.q: We are several of us, gentlemen and ladies, who board in the same house.

entry.ety: F. aborder. See Abord v. t.
entry.def: To approach; to accost; to address; hence, to woo.
entry.q: I will board her, though she chide as loud As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.

entry.def: That can be boarded, as a ship.

sn.def: One who has food statedly at another's table, or meals and lodgings in his house, for pay, or compensation of any kind.
One who boards a ship; one selected to board an enemy's ship.

cs.cd: a house in which boarders are kept.
a strong network of cords or ropes erected at the side of a ship to prevent an enemy from boarding it.
a pike used by sailors in boarding a vessel, or in repelling an attempt to board it.
a school in which pupils receive board and lodging as well as instruction.

sn.def: The act of entering a ship, whether with a hostile or a friendly purpose.
sn.q: Both slain at one time, as they attempted the boarding of a frigate.

sn.def: The act of covering with boards; also, boards, collectively; or a covering made of boards.
The act of supplying, or the state of being supplied, with regular or specified meals, or with meals and lodgings, for pay.

entry.def: a private house that provides accommodations and meals for paying guests.
a room where a committee meets (such as the board of directors of a company).

sn.def: the boarding that surrounds an ice hockey rink.
the stage; as, to walk the boards, i.e. to act on stage.
board examinations (in a profession, as in medicine); -- an informal contraction; as, to take the boards; he flunked the boards .

entry.def: a walkway made of wooden boards; usually at a seaside. The more elaborate boardwalks at shore resorts are lined with many commercial retail establishments, on the side of the walk opposite the ocean.
A Mediterranean fish (Capros aper), of the family Caproidæ; -- so called from the resemblance of the extended lips to a hog's snout.
An Australian percoid fish (Histiopterus recurvirostris), valued as a food fish.
Swinish; brutal; cruel.
entry.q: In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Boasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Boasting
entry.ety: OE. bosten boosten, v., bost boost, n., noise, boasting; cf. G. bausen bauschen, to swell, pusten, Dan. puste, Sw. pusta, to blow, Sw. pösa to swell; or W. bostio to boast, bost boast, Gael. bosd. But these last may be from English

sn.def: To vaunt one's self; to brag; to say or tell things which are intended to give others a high opinion of one's self or of things belonging to one's self; as, to boast of one's exploits courage, descent, wealth.
sn.q: By grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: . . not of works, lest any man should boast.

sn.def: To speak in exulting language of another; to glory; to exult.
sn.q: In God we boast all the day long.
sn.syn: To brag; bluster; vapor; crow; talk big.

cs.cd: to speak with unbecoming confidence in, and approval of, one's self; -- followed by of and the thing to which the boasting relates.

sn.def: To display in ostentatious language; to speak of with pride, vanity, or exultation, with a view to self-commendation; to extol.
sn.q: Lest bad men should boast Their specious deeds.

sn.def: To display vaingloriously.
To possess or have; as, to boast a name.
sn.q: Boast not thyself of to-morrow.

entry.ety: Of uncertain etymology

sn.def: To dress, as a stone, with a broad chisel.
To shape roughly as a preparation for the finer work to follow; to cut to the general form required.
Act of boasting; vaunting or bragging.
sn.q: Reason and morals? and where live they most, In Christian comfort, or in Stoic boast!

sn.def: The cause of boasting; occasion of pride or exultation, -- sometimes of laudable pride or exultation.
sn.q: The boast of historians.

entry.def: Boasting.
One who boasts; a braggart.
A stone mason's broad-faced chisel.
Given to, or full of, boasting; inclined to boast; vaunting; vainglorious; self-praising.
The act of glorying or vaunting; vainglorious speaking; ostentatious display.
entry.q: When boasting ends, then dignity begins.

entry.def: Boastfully; with boasting.
entry.q: Heboastinglytells you.

entry.def: Presumptuous.
Without boasting or ostentation.

entry.note: ☞ Different kinds of boats have different names; as, canoe yawl wherry pinnace punt, etc.

☞ Boat is much used either adjectively or in combination; as, boat builder or boatbuilder; boat building or boatbuilding; boat hook or boathook; boathouse; boat keeper or boatkeeper; boat load; boat race; boat racing; boat rowing; boat song; boatlike; boat-shaped.
entry.cs: Advice boat. See under Advice. Boat hook Naut an iron hook with a point on the back, fixed to a long pole, to pull or push a boat, raft, log, etc. Totten. Boat rope a rope for fastening a boat; -- usually called a painter. In the same boat in the same situation or predicament. Colloq F. W. Newman.
entry.ety: OE. boot bat, AS. bāt; akin to Icel. bātr, Sw. båt, Dan. baad, D. & G. boot. Cf. Bateau

sn.def: A small open vessel, or water craft, usually moved by cars or paddles, but often by a sail.

Hence, any vessel; usually with some epithet descriptive of its use or mode of propulsion; as, pilot boat, packet boat, passage boat, advice boat, etc. The term is sometimes applied to steam vessels, even of the largest class; as, the Cunard boats .
A vehicle, utensil, or dish, somewhat resembling a boat in shape; as, a stone boat; a gravy boat .

entry.cs: To boat the oars. See under Oar.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Boated; p. pr. & vb. n. Boating

sn.def: To transport in a boat; as, to boat goods.
To place in a boat; as, to boat oars.

entry.def: To go or row in a boat.
entry.q: I boated over, ran my craft aground.

sn.def: Such as can be transported in a boat.
Navigable for boats, or small river craft.
sn.q: The boatable waters of the Alleghany.

entry.def: Conveyance by boat; also, a charge for such conveyance.

sn.def: A wading bird (Cancroma cochlearia) of the tropical parts of South America. Its bill is somewhat like a boat with the keel uppermost.
A perching bird of India, of the genus Eurylaimus.

entries.entry: Boat" bug`. Zoöl An aquatic hemipterous insect of the genus Notonecta; -- so called from swimming on its back, which gives it the appearance of a little boat. Called also boat fly boat insect boatman, and water boatman.
Boat"ful n.; pl.Boatfuls. The quantity or amount that fills a boat.

entry.def: A house for sheltering boats.
entry.q: Half the latticed boathouse hides.

sn.def: The act or practice of rowing or sailing, esp. as an amusement; carriage in boats.
In Persia, a punishment of capital offenders, by laying them on the back in a covered boat, where they are left to perish.

entry.ety: L. boatus, fr. boare to roar
entry.def: A crying out; a roaring; a bellowing; reverberation.
entry.q: The guns were heard . . . about a hundred Italian miles, in long boations.

entries.entry:
Boat"man n.; pl.Boatmen.
A man who manages a boat; a rower of a boat. As late the boatman hies him home.
Zoöl A boat bug. See Boat bug.

entry.def: The art of managing a boat.
See Cymbiform.

entries.entry: Boat" shell`. Zoöl A marine gastropod of the genus Crepidula. The species are numerous. It is so named from its form and interior deck. A marine univalve shell of the genus Cymba.

entry.def: A boatman.

cs.cd: an assistant of the boatswain.

entry.ety: Boat + swain

sn.def: An officer who has charge of the boats, sails, rigging, colors, anchors, cables, cordage, etc., of a ship, and who also summons the crew, and performs other duties.

sd.def: The jager gull.
The tropic bird.

entry.def: A large grackle or blackbird (Quiscalus major), found in the Southern United States.

entries.entry: Boat"wom`an n.; pl.Boatwomen. A woman who manages a boat.

entry.ety: An onomatopoetic word, expressing quick, jerky motion; OE. bob bunch, bobben to strike, mock, deceive. Cf. Prov. Eng. bob, n., a ball, an engine beam, bunch, blast, trick, taunt, scoff; as, a v., to dance, to courtesy, to disappoint, OF. bober to mock

sn.def: Anything that hangs so as to play loosely, or with a short abrupt motion, as at the end of a string; a pendant; as, the bob at the end of a kite's tail.
sn.q: In jewels dressed and at each ear a bob.

sn.def: A knot of worms, or of rags, on a string, used in angling, as for eels; formerly, a worm suitable for bait.
sn.q: Or yellow bobs, turned up before the plow, Are chiefest baits, with cork and lead enow.

sn.def: A small piece of cork or light wood attached to a fishing line to show when a fish is biting; a float.
The ball or heavy part of a pendulum; also, the ball or weight at the end of a plumb line.
A small wheel, made of leather, with rounded edges, used in polishing spoons, etc.
A short, jerking motion; act of bobbing; as, a bob of the head.
A working beam.
A knot or short curl of hair; also, a bob wig.
sn.q: A plain brown bob he wore.

sn.def: A peculiar mode of ringing changes on bells.
The refrain of a song.
sn.q: To bed, to bed, will be the bob of the song.

sn.def: A blow; a shake or jog; a rap, as with the fist.
A jeer or flout; a sharp jest or taunt; a trick.
sn.q: He that a fool doth very wisely hit, Doth very foolishly, although he smart, Not to seem senseless of the bob.

sn.def: A shilling.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bobbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bobbing
