entry.q: But O, thou bounteous Giver of all good.

entry.def: rewarded or rewardable by a bounty; as, a bountied animal pelt.

sn.def: Free in giving; liberal in bestowing gifts and favors.
sn.q: God, the bountiful Author of our being.

sn.def: Plentiful; abundant; as, a bountiful supply of food.

entry.def: Goodness; generosity.

entries.entry:
Boun"ty
Bounty jumper one who, during the latter part of the Civil War, enlisted in the United States service, and deserted as soon as possible after receiving the bounty. Collog Queen Anne's bounty Eng. Hist a provision made in Queen Anne's reign for augmenting poor clerical livings.
n.; pl.Bounties. OE. bounte goodness, kindness, F. bonté, fr. L. bonitas, fr. bonus good, for older duonus; cf. Skr. duvas honor, respect
Goodness, kindness; virtue; worth. Obs Nature set in her at once beauty with bounty.
Liberality in bestowing gifts or favors; gracious or liberal giving; generosity; munificence. My bounty is as boundless as the sea.
That which is given generously or liberally. Thy morningbounties.
A premium offered or given to induce men to enlist into the public service; or to encourage any branch of industry, as husbandry or manufactures. Munificence; generosity; beneficence.

entry.ety: F. bouquet bunch, bunch of flowers, trees, feathers, for bousquet bosquet, thicket, a little wood, dim. of LL. boscus. See Bush thicket, and cf. Bosket Busket

A kind of organ stop.

entry.note: ☞ This line is printed in bourgeois type.
entry.ety: From a French type founder named Bourgeois, or fr. F. bourgeois of the middle class; hence applied to an intermediate size of type between brevier and long primer: cf. G. bourgeois borgis. Cf. Burgess
entry.def: A size of type between long primer and brevier. See Type.

entry.ety: F., fr. bourg town; of German origin. See Burgess
entry.def: A man of middle rank in society; one of the shopkeeping class.

def2.def: Characteristic of the middle class, as in France.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The French middle class, particularly such as are concerned in, or dependent on, trade.

entry.ety: OE. burjoun a bud, burjounen to bud, F. bourgeon a bud, bourgeonner to bud; cf. OHG. burjan to raise
entry.def: To sprout; to put forth buds; to shoot forth, as a branch.
entry.q: Gayly to bourgeon and broadly to grow.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A mullet (Mugil capito) found in the rivers of Southern Europe and in Africa.

entry.ety: OE. burne borne, AS. burna; akin to OS. brunno spring, G. born brunnen, OHG. prunno, Goth. brunna, Icel. brunnr, and perh. to Gr. �. The root is prob. that of burn, v., because the source of a stream seems to issue forth bubbling and boiling from the earth. Cf. Torrent, and see Burn v.
entry.def: A stream or rivulet; a burn.
entry.q: My little boat can safely pass this perilous bourn.

entry.ety: F. borne. See Bound a limit
entry.def: A bound; a boundary; a limit. Hence: Point aimed at; goal.
entry.q: Where the land slopes to its watery bourn.
The undiscovered country, from whose bourn No traveler returns.
Sole bourn, sole wish, sole object of my song.
To make the doctrine . . . their intellectual bourne.

entry.def: Without a bourn or limit.

entry.ety: Named after Count Bournon, a mineralogist
entry.def: A mineral of a steel-gray to black color and metallic luster, occurring crystallized, often in twin crystals shaped like cogwheels (wheel ore), also massive. It is a sulphide of antimony, lead, and copper.
See Burnoose.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: An old French dance tune in common time.

entry.ety: F. bourse purse, exchange, LL. bursa, fr. Gr.� skin, hide, of which a purse was usually made. Cf. Purse Burse
entry.def: An exchange, or place where merchants, bankers, etc., meet for business at certain hours; esp., the Stock Exchange of Paris.
common black-fruited shrub or small tree (Sambucus nigra) of Europe and Asia; -- the fruit is used for wines and jellies.
entry.syn: black elder, common elder, elderberry, European elder.

entry.def: To drink immoderately; to carouse; to booze. See Booze.
Drink, esp. alcoholic drink; also, a carouse; a booze.
entry.q: A goodbouseof liquor.

entry.def: A toper; a boozer.

entry.ety: Gr. � turning like oxen in plowing; � to turn
entry.def: An ancient mode of writing, in alternate directions, one line from left to right, and the next from right to left (as fields are plowed), as in early Greek and Hittite.
Relating to the boustrophedon made of writing.

entry.ety: Gr. � �ox-guiding
entry.def: Boustrophedonic.
Drunken; sotted; boozy.
entry.q: In his cups the bousy poet songs.

entry.ety: A different spelling and application of bought bend

sn.def: As much of an action as is performed at one time; a going and returning, as of workmen in reaping, mowing, etc.; a turn; a round.
sn.q: In notes with many a winding bout Of linked sweetness long drawn out.
The prince . . . has taken me in his train, so that I am in no danger of starving for this bout.

sn.def: A conflict; contest; attempt; trial; a set-to at anything; as, a fencing bout; a drinking bout .
sn.q: The gentleman will, for his honor's sake, have one bout with you; he can not by the duello avoid it.

entry.ety: F., fr. bouter to thrust. See Butt
entry.def: An outbreak; a caprice; a whim.

entry.ety: F.; bouter to thrust, put + feu fire
entry.def: An incendiary; an inciter of quarrels.
entry.q: Animated by . . . John à Chamber, a very boutefeu, . . . they entered into open rebellion.

entry.ety: F., buttonhole
entry.def: A bouquet worn in a buttonhole.

entry.ety: F. bout end + rimé rhymed
entry.def: Words that rhyme, proposed as the ends of verses, to be filled out by the ingenuity of the person to whom they are offered.
the location where in 1214 the French under King Philip Augustus defeated a coalition formed against him in one of the greatest battles of the middle ages.

entry.ety: LL. bovata, fr. bos bovis, ox
entry.def: An oxgang, or as much land as an ox can plow in a year; an ancient measure of land, of indefinite quantity, but usually estimated at fifteen acres.

entries.entry: Bo"vey coal`. Min A kind of mineral coal, or brown lignite, burning with a weak flame, and generally a disagreeable odor; -- found at Bovey Tracey, Devonshire, England. It is of geological age of the oölite, and not of the true coal era.

entry.ety: L. bos bovis, ox, cow
entry.def: Relating to that tribe of ruminant mammals of which the genus Bos is the type.

entry.ety: L. bos bovis, ox + -form
entry.def: Resembling an ox in form; ox-shaped.
a term essentially coextensive with the genus Bos, including cattle, buffalo, and sometimes kudu; -- it is not used technically.
a term essentially coextensive with the genus Bos; -- it is not used technically.

entry.ety: LL. bovinus, fr. L. bos bovis, ox, cow: cf. F. bovine. See Cow

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the genus Bos; relating to, or resembling, the ox or cow; oxlike; as, the bovine genus; a bovine antelope.
Having qualities characteristic of oxen or cows; sluggish and patient; dull; as, a bovine temperament.
sn.q: The bovine gaze of gaping rustics.

entry.def: an extract of beef (given to people who are ill).

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bowing
entry.ety: OE. bowen bogen bugen, AS. būgangenerally v. i.); akin to D. buigen, OHG. biogan, G. biegen beugen, Icel. boginn bent, beygja to bend, Sw. böja, Dan. böie bugne, Coth. biugan; also to L. fugere to flee, Gr. �, and Skr. bhuj to bend. √88. Cf. Fugitive

sn.def: To cause to deviate from straightness; to bend; to inflect; to make crooked or curved.
sn.q: We bow things the contrary way, to make them come to their natural straightness.
The whole nation bowed their necks to the worst kind of tyranny.

sn.def: To exercise powerful or controlling influence over; to bend, figuratively; to turn; to incline.
sn.q: Adversities do more bow men's minds to religion.
Not to bow and bias their opinions.

sn.def: To bend or incline, as the head or body, in token of respect, gratitude, assent, homage, or condescension.
sn.q: They came to meet him, and bowed themselves to the ground before him.

sn.def: To cause to bend down; to prostrate; to depress,;� to crush; to subdue.
sn.q: Whose heavy hand hath bowed you to the grave.

sn.def: To express by bowing; as, to bow one's thanks.
To bend; to curve.
To stop.
sn.q: They stoop, they bow down together.

sn.def: To bend the head, knee, or body, in token of reverence or submission; -- often with down.
sn.q: O come, let us worship and bow down: let us kneel before the Lord our maker.

sn.def: To incline the head in token of salutation, civility, or assent; to make bow.
sn.q: Admired, adored by all circling crowd, For wheresoe'er she turned her face, they bowed.

entry.def: An inclination of the head, or a bending of the body, in token of reverence, respect, civility, or submission; an obeisance; as, a bow of deep humility.

cs.cd: an under officer of the forest who looked after trespassers.
a drill worked by a bow and string.
any stringed instrument from which the tones are produced by the bow.
See Bay window.
to lie; to exaggerate.

entry.ety: OE. bowe boge, AS. boga, fr. AS. būgan to bend; akin to D. boog, G. bogen, Icel. bogi. See Bow v. t.

sn.def: Anything bent, or in the form of a curve, as the rainbow.
sn.q: I do set my bow in the cloud.

sn.def: A weapon made of a strip of wood, or other elastic material, with a cord connecting the two ends, by means of which an arrow is propelled.
An ornamental knot, with projecting loops, formed by doubling a ribbon or string.
The U-shaped piece which embraces the neck of an ox and fastens it to the yoke.
An appliance consisting of an elastic rod, with a number of horse hairs stretched from end to end of it, used in playing on a stringed instrument.
An arcograph.
Any instrument consisting of an elastic rod, with ends connected by a string, employed for giving reciprocating motion to a drill, or for preparing and arranging the hair, fur, etc., used by hatters.
A rude sort of quadrant formerly used for taking the sun's altitude at sea.
Two pieces of wood which form the arched forward part of a saddletree.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bowing
entry.def: To play (music) with a bow.

def2.def: To manage the bow.

cs.cd: a gun in the bow for firing while chasing another vessel.
a piece of ordnance carried at the bow of a ship.
on that part of the horizon within 45° on either side of the line ahead.

entry.ety: Icel. bōgr shoulder, bow of a ship. See Bough

sn.def: The bending or rounded part of a ship forward; the stream or prow.
One who rows in the forward part of a boat; the bow oar.

entry.def: Capable of being bowed or bent; flexible; easily influenced; yielding.
One born within hearing distance of Bow-bells; a cockney.
The bells of Bow Church in London; cockneydom.
entry.q: People born within the sound of Bow-bells are usually called cockneys.

entry.def: Bent, like a bow.

entries.entry:
Bow"-com`pass n.; pl.Bow-compasses.
An arcograph.
A small pair of compasses, one leg of which carries a pencil, or a pen, for drawing circles. Its legs are often connected by a bow-shaped spring, instead of by a joint.
A pair of compasses, with a bow or arched plate riveted to one of the legs, and passing through the other.

entry.def: the deletion of all passages considered to be indecent.
same as bowdlerize.
the deletion of all passages considered to be indecent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bowdlerized; p. pr. & vb. n. Bowdlerizing
entry.ety: After Dr. Thomas Bowdler, an English physician, who published an expurgated edition of Shakespeare in 1818
entry.def: To expurgate, as a book, by omitting or modifying the parts considered offensive; to remove morally objectionable parts; -- said of literary texts.
entry.q: It is a grave defect in the splendid tale of Tom Jones . . . that a Bowdlerized version of it would be hardly intelligible as a tale.

sn.def: bent over; -- used of back or head.
sounded by stroking with a bow; -- of a stringed musical instrument; as, bowed instruments. Contrasted with plucked.
resembling an arch.
same as bow-legged.
submitting to the authority of another.

entry.ety: OE. bouel bouele, OF. boel boele, F. boyau, fr. L. botellus a small sausage, in LL. also intestine, dim. of L. botulus sausage

sn.def: One of the intestines of an animal; an entrail, especially of man; a gut; -- generally used in the plural.
sn.q: He burst asunder in the midst, and all his bowels gushed out.

sn.def: Hence, figuratively: The interior part of anything; as, the bowels of the earth.
sn.q: His soldiers . . . cried out amain, And rushed into the bowels of the battle.

sn.def: The seat of pity or kindness. Hence: Tenderness; compassion.
sn.q: Thou thing of nobowels.
Bloody Bonner, that corpulent tyrant, full (as one said) of guts, and empty of bowels.

sn.def: Offspring.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Boweled or Bowelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Boweling or Bowelling
entry.def: To take out the bowels of; to eviscerate; to disembowel.
Having bowels; hollow.
entry.q: Theboweledcavern.

entry.def: Without pity.

entry.ety: From G.T. Bowen, who analyzed it in 1822
entry.def: A hard, compact variety of serpentine found in Rhode Island. It is of a light green color and resembles jade.

entry.cs: Best bower Small bower . See the Note under Anchor.
entry.ety: From Bow v. & n.

sn.def: One who bows or bends.
An anchor carried at the bow of a ship.
A muscle that bends a limb, esp. the arm.
sn.q: His rawbone arms, whose mighty brawned bowers Were wont to rive steel plates and helmets hew.

cs.cd: the knave of the trump suit, the highest card (except the “Joker”) in the game.
the knave of the other suit of the same color as the trump, being the next to the right bower in value.
in some forms of euchre and some other games, an extra card sometimes added to the pack, which takes precedence of all others as the highest card.

entry.ety: G. bauer a peasant. So called from the figure sometimes used for the knave in cards. See Boor
entry.def: One of the two highest cards in the pack commonly used in the game of euchre.

entry.ety: OE. bour bur, room, dwelling, AS. būr, fr. the root of AS. būan to dwell; akin to Icel. būr chamber, storehouse, Sw. būr cage, Dan. buur, OHG. pūr room, G. bauer cage, bauer a peasant. √97] Cf.Boor Byre

sn.def: Anciently, a chamber; a lodging room; esp., a lady's private apartment.
sn.q: Give me my lute in bed now as I lie, And lock the doors of mine unlucky bower.

sn.def: A rustic cottage or abode; poetically, an attractive abode or retreat.
A shelter or covered place in a garden, made with boughs of trees or vines, etc., twined together; an arbor; a shady recess.

entry.def: To embower; to inclose.
To lodge.

entry.ety: From Bough, cf. Brancher
entry.def: A young hawk, when it begins to leave the nest.

entries.entry: Bow"er-Barff" proc`ess . Metal A certain process for producing upon articles of iron or steel an adherent coating of the magnetic oxide of iron (which is not liable to corrosion by air, moisture, or ordinary acids). This is accomplished by producing, by oxidation at about 1600° F. in a closed space, a coating containing more or less of the ferric oxide (Fe2O3) and the subsequent change of this in a reduced atmosphere to the magnetic oxide (Fe2O4).

Bow"er bird` ☞ The name is also applied to other related birds of the same region, having similar habits; as, the spotted bower bird Chalmydodera maculata), and the regent bird (Sericulus melinus).. Zoöl An Australian bird (Ptilonorhynchus violaceusorPtilonorhynchus holosericeus), allied to the starling. The male constructs singular bowers or playhouses of twigs and decorates them with bright-colored objects to attract females; the satin bird.

entry.def: Shading, like a bower; full of bowers.
entry.q: A bowery maze that shades the purple streams.

entries.entry:
Bow"er*y n.; pl.Boweries. D. bouwerij
A farm or plantation with its buildings. U. S. Hist The emigrants [in New York] were scattered on boweries or plantations; and seeing the evils of this mode of living widely apart, they were advised, in 1643 and 1646, by the Dutch authorities, to gather into “villages, towns, and hamlets, as the English were in the habit of doing.”

entry.def: Characteristic of the street called the Bowery, in New York city; swaggering; flashy.
Same as Bower.
A voracious ganoid fish (Amia calva) found in the fresh waters of the United States; the mudfish; -- called also Johnny Grindle, and dogfish.
To swell out. See Bouge.
To cause to leak.
A frame or fender of rope or junk, laid out at the sides or bows of a vessel to secure it from injury by floating ice.

entries.entry:
Bow" hand`. Archery The hand that holds the bow, i. e., the left hand. Surely he shoots wide on the bow hand.
Mus The hand that draws the bow, i. e., the right hand.

entry.def: The great Arctic or Greenland whale. (Balæna mysticetus). See Baleen, and Whale.
a small genus of tropical African perennial bulbous herbs with deciduous twining stems; sometimes placed in family Hyacinthaceae.

entries.entry: Bow"ie knife`. A knife with a strong blade from ten to fifteen inches long, and double-edged near the point; -- used as a hunting knife, and formerly as a weapon in the southwestern part of the United States. It was named from its inventor, Colonel James Bowie . Also, by extension, any large sheath knife.

sn.def: The act or art of managing the bow in playing on stringed instruments.
sn.q: Bowing constitutes a principal part of the art of the violinist, the violist, etc.

sn.def: In hatmaking, the act or process of separating and distributing the fur or hair by means of a bow, to prepare it for felting.

entry.def: In a bending manner.
A knot in which a portion of the string is drawn through in the form of a loop or bow, so as to be readily untied.

entry.ety: OE. bolle, AS. bolla; akin to Icel. bolli, Dan. bolle, G. bolle, and perh. to E. boil a tumor. Cf. Boll

sn.def: A concave vessel of various forms (often approximately hemispherical), to hold liquids, etc.
sn.q: Brought them food in bowls of basswood.

sn.def: Specifically, a drinking vessel for wine or other spirituous liquors; hence, convivial drinking.
The contents of a full bowl; what a bowl will hold.
The hollow part of a thing; as, the bowl of a spoon.

entry.ety: F. boule, fr. L. bulla bubble, stud. Cf. Bull an edict, Bill a writing

sn.def: A ball of wood or other material used for rolling on a level surface in play; a ball of hard wood having one side heavier than the other, so as to give it a bias when rolled.
An ancient game, popular in Great Britain, played with biased balls on a level plat of greensward.
sn.q: Like an uninstructed bowler, . . . who thinks to attain the jack by delivering his bowl straightforward upon it.

entry.sn: pl. The game of tenpins or bowling. U.S

cs.cd: in cricket, to put out a striker by knocking down a bail or a stump in bowling.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bowled; p. pr. & vb. n. Bowling

sn.def: To roll, as a bowl or cricket ball.
sn.q: Break all the spokes and fellies from her wheel, And bowl the round nave down the hill of heaven.

sn.def: To roll or carry smoothly on, or as on, wheels; as, we were bowled rapidly along the road.
To pelt or strike with anything rolled.
sn.q: Alas, I had rather be set quick i' the earth, And bowled to death with turnips�

sn.def: To play with bowls.
To roll a ball on a plane, as at cricket, bowls, etc.
To move rapidly, smoothly, and like a ball; as, the carriage bowled along.

cs.cd: the unstratified clay deposit of the Glacial or Drift epoch, often containing large numbers of bowlders.
a wall constructed of large stones or bowlders.

entry.ety: Cf. Sw. bullra to roar, rattle, Dan. buldre, dial. Sw. bullersteen larger kind of pebbles; perh. akin to E. bellow

sn.def: A large stone, worn smooth or rounded by the action of water; a large pebble.
A mass of any rock, whether rounded or not, that has been transported by natural agencies from its native bed. See Drift.

entry.def: Characterized by bowlders.
A crooked leg.
Having crooked legs, esp. with the knees bent outward.
One who plays at bowls, or who rolls the ball in cricket or any other game.

entry.ety: From 2d Bowl
entry.def: A derby hat.
Destitute of a bow.
the quantity contained in a bowl.

entry.cs: Bowline bridles the ropes by which the bowline is fastened to the leech of the sail. Bowline knot. See Illust. under Knot. On a bowline close-hauled or sailing close to the wind; -- said of a ship.
entry.ety: Cf. D. boelijn, Icel. böglïna�, Dan. bovline; properly the line attached to the shoulder or side of the sail. See Bowof a ship), and Line
entry.def: A rope fastened near the middle of the leech or perpendicular edge of the square sails, by subordinate ropes, called bridles, and used to keep the weather edge of the sail tight forward, when the ship is closehauled.

cs.cd: a covered place for playing at bowls or tenpins.
a level piece of greensward or smooth ground for bowling, as the small park in lower Broadway, New York, where the Dutch of New Amsterdam played this game.

entry.def: The act of playing at or rolling bowls, or of rolling the ball at cricket; the game of bowls or of tenpins.
See Bowl, a ball, a game.

entries.entry:
Bow"man
Bowman's root. Bot See Indian physic, under Indian.
n.; pl.Bowmen. A man who uses a bow; an archer. The whole city shall flee for the noise of the horsemen and bowmen.

entry.def: The man who rows the foremost oar in a boat; the bow oar.

entry.ety: See Boun
entry.def: To make ready; to prepare; to dress.
entry.q: We will all bowne ourselves for the banquet.

entries.entry:
Bow" net`. A trap for lobsters, being a wickerwork cylinder with a funnel-shaped entrance at one end.
A net for catching birds.

Bow" oar`. The oar used by the bowman.
One who rows at the bow of a boat.

entry.def: Bow-compasses carrying a drawing pen. See Bow-compass.
Bow-compasses, one leg of which carries a pencil.
A saw with a thin or narrow blade set in a strong frame.

entry.ety: See Booze, and Bouse

sn.def: To carouse; to bouse; to booze.
To pull or haul; as, to bowse upon a tack; to bowse away, i. e., to pull all together.

entry.def: A carouse; a drinking bout; a booze.
The distance traversed by an arrow shot from a bow.

entry.ety: Bow + sprit; akin to D. boegspriet; boeg bow of a ship + spriet, E. sprit, also Sw. bogspröt, G. bugspriet
entry.def: A large boom or spar, which projects over the stem of a ship or other vessel, to carry sail forward.
To drench; to soak; especially, to immerse (in water believed to have curative properties).
entry.q: There were many bowssening places, for curing of mad men. . . . If there appeared small amendment he was bowssened again and again.

cs.cd: a bridge formed of an arch of timber or iron, often braced, the thrust of which is resisted by a tie forming a chord of the arch.
an arched beam strengthened by a tie connecting its two ends.
the tenacious fiber of the Sanseviera Zeylanica, growing in India and Africa, from which bowstrings are made.

sn.def: The string of a bow.
A string used by the Turks for strangling offenders.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bowstringed or Bowstrung; p. pr. & vb. n. Bowstringing
entry.def: To strangle with a bowstring.

sn.def: Furnished with bowstring.
Put to death with a bowstring; strangled.

entry.def: See Boultel.
An onomatopoetic name for a dog or its bark.

def2.def: Onomatopoetic; as, the bowwow theory of language; a bowwow word.

entry.ety: From Bow, like lawyer from law

sn.def: An archer; one who uses bow.
One who makes or sells bows.

cs.cd: the ash-leaved maple (Negundo aceroides), of North America.
the butcher's broom (Russus aculeatus).
a shrub (Lycium barbarum).
the tree variety of the common box.

entry.ety: As. box, L. buxus, fr. Gr. �. See Box a case
entry.def: A tree or shrub, flourishing in different parts of the world. The common box (Buxus sempervirens) has two varieties, one of which, the dwarf box (Buxus suffruticosa), is much used for borders in gardens. The wood of the tree varieties, being very hard and smooth, is extensively used in the arts, as by turners, engravers, mathematical instrument makers, etc.

entries.entry:
Box ☞ Box is much used adjectively or in composition; as box lid, box maker, box circle, etc.; also with modifying substantives; as money box, letter box, bandbox, hatbox or hat box, snuff box or snuffbox.
Box beam Arch a beam made of metal plates so as to have the form of a long box. Box car Railroads a freight car covered with a roof and inclosed on the sides to protect its contents. Box chronometer a ship's chronometer, mounted in gimbals, to preserve its proper position. Box coat a thick overcoat for driving; sometimes with a heavy cape to carry off the rain. Box coupling a metal collar uniting the ends of shafts or other parts in machinery. Box crab Zoöl a crab of the genus Calappa, which, when at rest with the legs retracted, resembles a box. Box drain Arch a drain constructed with upright sides, and with flat top and bottom. Box girder Arch a box beam. Box groove Metal Working a closed groove between two rolls, formed by a collar on one roll fitting between collars on another. R. W. Raymond. Box metal, an alloy of copper and tin, or of zinc, lead, and antimony, for the bearings of journals, etc.Box plait a plait that doubles both to the right and the left. Box turtleorBox tortoise Zoöl a land tortoise or turtle of the genera Cistudo and Emys; -- so named because it can withdraw entirely within its shell, which can be closed by hinged joints in the lower shell. Also, humorously, an exceedingly reticent person. Emerson. In a box in a perplexity or an embarrassing position; in difficulty. Colloq In the wrong box out of one's place; out of one's element; awkwardly situated. Colloq Ridley (1554
n.; pl.Boxes
As. box a small case or vessel with a cover; akin to OHG. buhsa box, G. büchse; fr. L. buxus boxwood, anything made of boxwood. See Pyx, and cf. Box a tree, Bushel
A receptacle or case of any firm material and of various shapes.
The quantity that a box contain.
A space with a few seats partitioned off in a theater, or other place of public amusement. Laughed at by the pit, box, galleries, nay, stage. The boxes and the pit are sovereign judges.
A chest or any receptacle for the deposit of money; as, a poor box; a contribution box . Yet since his neighbors give, the churl unlocks, Damning the poor, his tripple-bolted box.
A small country house. A shootingbox. Tight boxes neatly sashed.
A boxlike shed for shelter; as, a sentry box .
Mach
An axle box, journal box, journal bearing, or bushing.
A chamber or section of tube in which a valve works; the bucket of a lifting pump.
The driver's seat on a carriage or coach.
A present in a box; a present; esp. a Christmas box or gift. A Christmasbox.
Baseball The square in which the pitcher stands.
Zoöl A Mediterranean food fish; the bogue.

entry.cs: To box a tree to make an incision or hole in a tree for the purpose of procuring the sap. To box off to divide into tight compartments. To box up. To put into a box in order to save; as, he had boxed up twelve score pounds. To confine; as, to be boxed up in narrow quarters.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Boxed�); p. pr. & vb. n. Boxing

sn.def: To inclose in a box.
To furnish with boxes, as a wheel.
To inclose with boarding, lathing, etc., so as to bring to a required form.

entry.ety: Cf.Dan. baske to slap, bask slap, blow. Cf. Pash
entry.def: A blow on the head or ear with the hand.
entry.q: A good-humored box on the ear.

entry.def: To fight with the fist; to combat with, or as with, the hand or fist; to spar.
To strike with the hand or fist, especially to strike on the ear, or on the side of the head.

cs.cd: to turn the head of a vessel either way by bracing the headyards aback.
to name the thirty-two points of the compass in their order.

entry.ety: Cf.Sp. boxar, now spelt bojar
entry.def: To boxhaul.

sn.def: enclosed in or set off by a border or box; as, boxed sections of the report; boxed announcements in the newspaper.
enclosed in a box.

entry.q: The faded hue of sapless boxen leaves.

One who boxes; a pugilist.
A breed of dog.
The trunkfish.
To put (a vessel) on the other tack by veering her short round on her heel; -- so called from the circumstance of bracing the head yards abox (i. e., sharp aback, on the wind).
A method of going from one tack to another. See Boxhaul.

sn.def: The act of inclosing (anything) in a box, as for storage or transportation.
Material used in making boxes or casings.
Any boxlike inclosure or recess; a casing.
The external case of thin material used to bring any member to a required form.

cs.cd: a large padded mitten or glove used in sparring for exercise or amusement.

entry.def: The act of fighting with the fist; a combat with the fist; sparring; pugilism.

entries.entry: Box"ing day`. The first week day after Christmas, a legal holiday on which Christmas boxes are given to postmen, errand boys, employees, etc. The night of this day is boxing night. Eng

entry.def: A hollow smoothing iron containing a heater within.
An attendant at a theater who has charge of the boxes.

entries.entry: Box kite. A kite, invented by Lawrence Hargrave, of Sydney, Australia, which consist of two light rectangular boxes, or cells open on two sides, and fastened together horizontally. Called also Hargrave kite, or cellular kite.

entry.def: resembling a box in rectangularity.
the mailing address to which answers to a newspaper ad can be sent.

entries.entry: Box tail. Aëronautics In a flying machine, a tail or rudder, usually fixed, resembling a box kite.

entry.def: A plant of the genus Lycium, esp. Lycium barbarum.
The wood of the box (Buxus).

entry.note: ☞ Boy is often used as a term of comradeship, as in college, or in the army or navy. In the plural used colloquially of members of an associaton, fraternity, or party.

cs.cd: a boy (usually a chorister) elected bishop, in old Christian sports, and invested with robes and other insignia. He practiced a kind of mimicry of the ceremonies in which the bishop usually officiated.
the Devil.
guineas.
a popular English name of Southernwood (Artemisia abrotonum); -- called also lad's love.
childish amusements; anything trifling.

entry.ety: Cf. D. boef, Fries. boi boy; akin to G. bube, Icel. bofi rouge

sn.def: A male child, from birth to the age of puberty; a lad; hence, a son.
sn.q: My only boy fell by the side of great Dundee.

sn.def: In various countries, a male servant, laborer, or slave of a native or inferior race; also, any man of such a race; -- considered derogatory by those so called, and now seldom used.
sn.q: He reverted again and again to the labor difficulty, and spoke of importing boys from Capetown.

entry.def: To act as a boy; -- in allusion to the former practice of boys acting women's parts on the stage.
entry.q: I shall see Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness.

entry.note: ☞ English writers sometimes call Russian landed proprietors boyars.
entry.ety: Russ. boiárin'
entry.def: A member of a Russian aristocratic order abolished by Peter the Great. Also, one of a privileged class in Roumania.

entries.entry:
Boy"au Boy"au n.; pl.Boyaux or Boyaus. F. boyau gut, a long and narrow place, and (of trenches) a branch. See Bowel
Fort A winding or zigzag trench forming a path or communication from one siegework to another, to a magazine, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Boycotted; p. pr. & vb. n. Boycotting
entry.ety: From Captain Boycott, a land agent in Mayo, Ireland, so treated in 1880
entry.def: To combine against (a landlord, tradesman, employer, or other person), to withhold social or business relations from him, and to deter others from holding such relations; to subject to a boycott.

The process, fact, or pressure of boycotting; a combining to withhold or prevent dealing or social intercourse with a tradesman, employer, etc.; social and business interdiction for the purpose of coercion.
A participant in boycotting.
Methods of boycotters.
A dagger; a bodkin.

entry.ety: D. boeijer; -- so called because these vessels were employed for laying the boeijen, or buoys: cf. F. boyer. See Buoy
entry.def: A Flemish sloop with a castle at each end.

entry.ety: Boy + -hood
entry.def: The state of being a boy; the time during which one is a boy.
Resembling a boy in a manners or opinions; belonging to a boy; childish; trifling; puerile.
entry.q: A boyish, odd conceit.

entry.def: In a boyish manner; like a boy.
The manners or behavior of a boy.

sn.def: Boyhood.
The nature of a boy; childishness.

entries.entry: Boyle's" law`. See under Law.

entry.def: same as boyish.
a battle in the War of the Grand Alliance in Ireland in 1690, where William III of England defeated the deposed James II and so ended Stuart Catholicism in England.
entry.syn: battle of Boyne, battle of the Boyne.

entry.def: a Eurafrican annual (Mercurialis annua) naturalized in America as a weed; formerly dried for use as a purgative, diuretic or antisyphilitic.

entries.entry: Boy scout. Orig., a member of the “Boy Scouts,” an organization of boys founded in 1908, by Sir R. S. S. Baden-Powell, to promote good citizenship by creating in them a spirit of civic duty and of usefulness to others, by stimulating their interest in wholesome mental, moral, industrial, and physical activities, etc. Hence, a member of any of the other similar organizations, which are now worldwide. In “The Boy Scouts of America” the local councils are generally under a scout commissioner, under whose supervision are scout masters, each in charge of a troop of two or more patrols of eight scouts each, who are of three classes, tenderfoot second-class scout, and first-class scout.

sn.def: a cultivated hybrid bramble of California having large dark wine-red fruit with a raspberrylike flavor.
a large raspberry-flavored bramble fruit; a cross between blackberries and raspberries.

entry.ety: See Bosa
entry.def: An acidulated fermented drink of the Arabs and Egyptians, made from millet seed and various astringent substances; also, an intoxicating beverage made from hemp seed, darnel meal, and water.
same as brassiere.
Pertaining to Brabant, an ancient province of the Netherlands.

entry.ety: D. brabbelen to talk confusedly. √95. Cf. Blab Babble
entry.def: To clamor; to contest noisily.
A broil; a noisy contest; a wrangle.
entry.q: This petty brabble will undo us all.

entry.def: A brabble.
A clamorous, quarrelsome, noisy fellow; a wrangler.

entry.ety: L. bracatus wearing breeches, fr. bracae breeches
entry.def: Furnished with feathers which conceal the feet.

entry.cs: Angle brace. See under Angle.
entry.ety: OF. brace brasse, the two arms, embrace, fathom, F. brasse fathom, fr. L. bracchia the arms (stretched out), pl. of bracchium arm; cf. Gr. �

sn.def: That which holds anything tightly or supports it firmly; a bandage or a prop.
A cord, ligament, or rod, for producing or maintaining tension, as a cord on the side of a drum.
sn.q: The little bones of the ear drum do in straining and relaxing it as the braces of the war drum do in that.

sn.def: The state of being braced or tight; tension.
sn.q: The laxness of the tympanum, when it has lost its brace or tension.

sn.def: A piece of material used to transmit, or change the direction of, weight or pressure; any one of the pieces, in a frame or truss, which divide the structure into triangular parts. It may act as a tie, or as a strut, and serves to prevent distortion of the structure, and transverse strains in its members. A boiler brace is a diagonal stay, connecting the head with the shell.
A vertical curved line connecting two or more words or lines, which are to be taken together; thus, boll bowl; or, in music, used to connect staves.
A rope reeved through a block at the end of a yard, by which the yard is moved horizontally; also, a rudder gudgeon.
A curved instrument or handle of iron or wood, for holding and turning bits, etc.; a bitstock.
A pair; a couple; as, a brace of ducks; now rarely applied to persons, except familiarly or with some contempt.
sn.q: Abraceof greyhounds.
He is said to have shot . . . fifty brace of pheasants.
A brace of brethren, both bishops, both eminent for learning and religion, now appeared in the church.
But you, my brace of lords.

sn.def: Straps or bands to sustain trousers; suspenders.
sn.q: I embroidered for you a beautiful pair of braces.

sn.def: Harness; warlike preparation.
sn.q: For that it stands not in such warlike brace.

sn.def: Armor for the arm; vantbrace.
The mouth of a shaft.

entry.cs: To brace about Naut to turn (a yard) round for the contrary tack. To brace a yard Naut to move it horizontally by means of a brace. To brace in Naut to turn (a yard) by hauling in the weather brace. To brace one's self to call up one's energies. “He braced himself for an effort which he was little able to make.” J. D. Forbes. To brace to Naut to turn (a yard) by checking or easing off the lee brace, and hauling in the weather one, to assist in tacking. To brace up Naut to bring (a yard) nearer the direction of the keel by hauling in the lee brace. To brace up sharp Naut to turn (a yard) as far forward as the rigging will permit.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Braced; p. pr. & vb. n. Bracing

sn.def: To furnish with braces; to support; to prop; as, to brace a beam in a building.
To draw tight; to tighten; to put in a state of tension; to strain; to strengthen; as, to brace the nerves.
sn.q: And welcome war to brace her drums.

sn.def: To bind or tie closely; to fasten tightly.
sn.q: The women of China, by bracing and binding them from their infancy, have very little feet.
Some who spurs had first braced on.

sn.def: To place in a position for resisting pressure; to hold firmly; as, he braced himself against the crowd.
sn.q: A sturdy lance in his right hand he braced.

sn.def: To move around by means of braces; as, to brace the yards.

entry.def: To get tone or vigor; to rouse one's energies; -- with up.
held up by braces or buttresses.

entry.ety: F. bracelet, dim. of OF. bracel armlet, prop. little arm, dim. of bras arm, fr. L. bracchium. See Brace,n.

sn.def: An ornamental band or ring, for the wrist or the arm; in modern times, an ornament encircling the wrist, worn by women or girls.
A piece of defensive armor for the arm.
That which braces, binds, or makes firm; a band or bandage.
A covering to protect the arm of the bowman from the vibration of the string; also, a brassart.
A medicine, as an astringent or a tonic, which gives tension or tone to any part of the body.

entry.ety: OE. brache a kind of scenting hound or setting dog, OF. brache, F. braque, fr. OHG. braccho, G. bracke; possibly akin to E. fragrant, fr. L. fragrare to smell
entry.def: A bitch of the hound kind.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. (�) short + � a covering
entry.def: A group of beetles having short elytra, as the rove beetles.

entry.ety: OE. brache a kind of scenting hound or setting dog, OF. brache, F. braque, fr. OHG. braccho, G. bracke; related to Sw. brack a dog that hunts by scent; possibly akin to E. fragrant, fr. L. fragrare to smell
entry.def: A bitch of the hound kind. See also bratchet.
entry.q: A sow pig by chance sucked a brach, and when she was grown would miraculously hunt all manner of deer.

entry.def: same as bratchet.
See Brachium.

entries.entry:
Brach"i*al or a. L. brachialis bracch-), from bracchium bracch-) arm: cf. F. brachial
Anat Pertaining or belonging to the arm; as, the brachial artery; the brachial nerve.
Of the nature of an arm; resembling an arm.

entry.ety: See Brachiate
entry.def: A division of the Crinoidea, including those furnished with long jointed arms. See Crinoidea.

entry.ety: L. brachiatus bracch-) with boughs or branches like arms, from brackium bracch-) arm
entry.def: Having branches in pairs, decussated, all nearly horizontal, and each pair at right angles with the next, as in the maple and lilac.
One of the Brachioganoidei.

entry.ety: NL., from L. brachium bracch-) arm + NL. ganoidei
entry.def: An order of ganoid fishes of which the bichir of Africa is a living example. See Crossopterygii.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. brachiolum bracch-), dim. of brachium bracch-) arm
entry.def: A peculiar early larval stage of certain starfishes, having a bilateral structure, and swimming by means of bands of vibrating cilia.

entry.ety: Cf.F. brachiopode
entry.def: One of the Brachiopoda, or its shell.

entry.note: ☞ Within the shell is a pair of “arms,” often long and spirally coiled, bearing rows of ciliated tentacles by which a current of water is made to flow into the mantle cavity, bringing the microscopic food to the mouth between the bases of the arms. The shell is both opened and closed by special muscles. They form two orders; Lyopoma, in which the shell is thin, and without a distinct hinge, as in Lingula; and Arthropoma, in which the firm calcareous shell has a regular hinge, as in Rhynchonella. See Arthropomata.
entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � arm + -poda
entry.def: A class of Molluscoidea having a symmetrical bivalve shell, often attached by a fleshy peduncle.

entries.entry: Brach"i*um Brach"i*um n.; pl.Bracchia. L. brachium or bracchium, arm Anat The upper arm; the segment of the fore limb between the shoulder and the elbow.

entry.ety: L. Brachmanae, pl., Gr. �
entry.def: See Brahman.

entry.ety: Gr. �; brachy`s short + � to leave off; cf. � incomplete
entry.def: A verse wanting two syllables at its termination.

entry.ety: Gr. brachy`s short + � head
entry.def: Having the skull short in proportion to its breadth; shortheaded; -- in distinction from dolichocephalic.

entries.entry:
Brach`y*ceph"a*ly Brach`y*ceph"a*lism
n. Cf. F. Brachycéphalie . Anat The state or condition of being brachycephalic; shortness of head.

entry.ety: Gr. brachy`s short + ke`ras horn
entry.def: Having short antennæ, as certain insects.

cs.cd: the shorter lateral axis of an orthorhombic crystal.

entry.ety: Gr. brachy`s short + E. diagonal
entry.def: Pertaining to the shorter diagonal, as of a rhombic prism.
The shorter of the diagonals in a rhombic prism.

entry.ety: Gr. brachy`s short + E. dome
entry.def: A dome parallel to the shorter lateral axis. See Dome.
A writer in short hand; a stenographer.
entry.q: He asked the brachygrapher whether he wrote the notes of the sermon.

entry.ety: Gr. brachy`s short + -graphy: cf. F. brachygraphie
entry.def: Stenography.

entry.ety: Gr. � : brachy`s short + � discourse: cf. F. brachylogie
entry.def: Conciseness of expression; brevity.

entry.ety: Gr. brachy`s short + E. pinacoid
entry.def: A plane of an orthorhombic crystal which is parallel both to the vertical axis and to the shorter lateral (brachydiagonal) axis.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � short-winged; brachy`s short + � feather, wing
entry.def: A group of Coleoptera having short wings; the rove beetles.

entry.ety: NL. See Brachyptera.
entry.def: A group of birds, including auks, divers, and penguins.

entry.ety: Gr. � : cf. F. brachyptère
entry.def: Having short wings.

entry.ety: Incorrect for brachistochrone, fr. Gr. bra`chistos shortest (superl. of brachy`s short) + � time : cf. F. brachistochrone.
entry.def: A curve, in which a body, starting from a given point, and descending solely by the force of gravity, will reach another given point in a shorter time than it could by any other path. This curve of quickest descent, as it is sometimes called, is, in a vacuum, the same as the cycloid.
abnormal shortness of fingers and toes.

entry.ety: Gr. brachy`s short + � stamp, form
entry.def: Of a short form.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. brachy`s short + o'yra` tail
entry.def: A group of decapod Crustacea, including the common crabs, characterized by a small and short abdomen, which is bent up beneath the large cephalo-thorax. Brachyoura See Crab, and Illustration in Appendix.

entry.ety: Cf. F. brachyure
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or belonging to the Brachyura.
One of the Brachyura.
Imparting strength or tone; strengthening; invigorating; as, a bracing north wind.

sn.def: The act of strengthening, supporting, or propping, with a brace or braces; the state of being braced.
Any system of braces; braces, collectively; as, the bracing of a truss.

entry.ety: Cf.D. braak, Dan. bræk, a breaking, Sw. & Icel. brak a crackling, creaking. Cf. Breach
entry.def: An opening caused by the parting of any solid body; a crack or breach; a flaw.
entry.q: Stain or brack in her sweet reputation.

entry.ety: D. brak, adj., salt; cf. LG. wrak refuse, G. brack
entry.def: Salt or brackish water.

entry.ety: OE. braken, AS. bracce. See 2d Brake n.
entry.def: A brake or fern.

entry.note: ☞ This is the more general word. See Brace Cantalever Console Corbel Strut.

cs.cd: a gas fixture or a lamp attached to a wall, column, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. braguette codpiece, F. brayette, Sp. bragueta, also a projecting mold in architecture; dim. fr. L. bracae breeches; cf. also, OF. bracon beam, prop, support; of unknown origin. Cf. Breeches

sn.def: An architectural member, plain or ornamental, projecting from a wall or pier, to support weight falling outside of the same; also, a decorative feature seeming to discharge such an office.
A piece or combination of pieces, usually triangular in general shape, projecting from, or fastened to, a wall, or other surface, to support heavy bodies or to strengthen angles.
A shot, crooked timber, resembling a knee, used as a support.
The cheek or side of an ordnance carriage.

One of two characters [], used to inclose a reference, explanation, or note, or a part to be excluded from a sentence, to indicate an interpolation, to rectify a mistake, or to supply an omission, and for certain other purposes; -- called also crotchet.
A gas fixture or lamp holder projecting from the face of a wall, column, or the like.

A figure determined by firing a projectile beyond a target and another short of it, as a basis for ascertaining the proper elevation of the piece; -- only used in the phrase, to establish a bracket. After the bracket is established shots are fired with intermediate elevations until the exact range is obtained. In the United States navy it is called fork.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bracketed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bracketing

sn.def: To place within brackets; to connect by brackets; to furnish with brackets.
To shoot so as to establish a bracket for (an object).

entry.def: A series or group of brackets; brackets, collectively.

entry.ety: See Brack salt water
entry.def: Saltish, or salt in a moderate degree, as water in saline soil.
entry.q: Springs in deserts found seem sweet, all brackish though they be.

entry.def: The quality or state of being brackish, or somewhat salt.
Brackish.

entry.note: ☞ Bracts are often inconspicuous, but sometimes large and showy, or highly colored, as in many cactaceous plants. The spathes of aroid plants are conspicuous forms of bracts.
entry.ety: See Bractea
entry.def: A leaf, usually smaller than the true leaves of a plant, from the axil of which a flower stalk arises.
Any modified leaf, or scale, on a flower stalk or at the base of a flower.

entry.ety: L., a thin plate of metal or wood, gold foil
entry.def: A bract.

entry.ety: Cf.F. bractéal
entry.def: Having the nature or appearance of a bract.

entry.ety: Cf. L. bracteatus covered with gold plate
entry.def: Having a bract or bracts.
Furnished with bracts.
Furnished with bracteoles or bractlets.

entry.ety: L. bracteola, dim. of bractea. See Bractea
entry.def: Same as Bractlet.
Destitute of bracts.

entry.ety: Bract + -let
entry.def: A bract on the stalk of a single flower, which is itself on a main stalk that support several flowers.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. brod, Dan. braad prick, sting, brodde ice spur, frost nail, Sw. brodd frost nail, Icel. broddr any pointed piece of iron or stell; akin to AS. brord point, spire of grass, and perh. to E. bristle. See Bristle n.
entry.def: A thin nail, usually small, with a slight projection at the top on one side instead of a head; also, a small wire nail, with a flat circular head; sometimes, a small, tapering, square-bodied finishing nail, with a countersunk head.

entries.entry: Brad" awl`. A straight awl with chisel edge, used to make holes for brads, etc.

entry.def: Same as Bridoon.

a hypotensive tissue hormone (C50H73N15O11) which acts on smooth muscle, dilates peripheral vessels and increases capillary permeability. It is formed locally in injured tissue and is believed to play a role in the inflammatory process. It is a nonapeptide with the sequence: Arg-Pro-Pro-Gly-Phe-Ser-Pro-Phe-Arg.
a natural family comprising the true sloths.
type genus of the Bradypodidae, comprising the three-toed sloths.

entry.ety: See Bray a hill
entry.def: A hillside; a slope; a bank; a hill.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bragged; p. pr. & vb. n. Bragging
entry.ety: OE. braggen to resound, blow, boast (cf. F. braguer to lead a merry life, flaunt, boast, OF. brague merriment), from Icel. braka to creak, brak noise, fr. the same root as E. break; properly then, to make a noise, boast. �95
entry.def: To talk about one's self, or things pertaining to one's self, in a manner intended to excite admiration, envy, or wonder; to talk boastfully; to boast; -- often followed by of; as, to brag of one's exploits, courage, or money, or of the great things one intends to do.
entry.q: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words,Brags of his substance, not of ornament.
entry.syn: To swagger; boast; vapor; bluster; vaunt; flourish; talk big.

entry.def: To boast of.

sn.def: A boast or boasting; bragging; ostentatious pretense or self glorification.
sn.q: Cæsar . . . made not here his brag Of “came,” and “saw,” and “overcame.”

sn.def: The thing which is boasted of.
sn.q: Beauty is Nature's brag.

sn.def: A game at cards similar to bluff.

entry.ety: See Brag v. i.
entry.def: Brisk; full of spirits; boasting; pretentious; conceited.
entry.q: A brag young fellow.

entry.def: Proudly; boastfully.
the Norse god of poetry and music; a son of Odin.

entry.ety: From Braggadocchio, a boastful character in Spenser's “Faërie Queene.”

sn.def: A braggart; a boaster; a swaggerer.
Empty boasting; mere brag; pretension.

entry.ety: See Braggart
entry.def: Boastfulness; act of bragging.

entry.ety: OF. bragard flaunting, vain, bragging. See Brag v. i.
entry.def: A boaster.
entry.q: O, I could play the woman with mine eyes, And braggart with my tongue.

entry.def: Boastful.
One who brags; a boaster.

entry.ety: OE. braket bragot, fr. W. bragawd bragod, fr. brag malt
entry.def: A liquor made of ale and honey fermented, with spices, etc.
Boastingly.
the Norse god of poetry and music; a son of Odin.
Without bragging.
In a manner to be bragged of; finely; proudly.

entry.note: ☞ According to the Hindu religious books, Brahmawith the final a short), or Brahm, is the Divine Essence, the One First Cause, the All in All, while the personal gods, Brahmáwith the final a long), Vishnu, and Siva, are emanations or manifestations of Brahma the Divine Essence.
entry.ety: See Brahman

sn.def: The One First Cause; also, one of the triad of Hindu gods. The triad consists of Brahma, the Creator, Vishnu, the Preserver, and Siva, the Destroyer.

A valuable variety of large, domestic fowl, peculiar in having the comb divided lengthwise into three parts, and the legs well feathered. There are two breeds, the dark or penciled, and the light; -- called also Brahmapootra.

entries.entry:
Brah"man Brah"min,
Brahman bull Zoöl the male of a variety of the zebu, or Indian ox, considered sacred by the Hindus.
n.; pl.Brahmans Brahmins. Skr. Brāhmanacf. Brahman worship, holiness; the God Brahma, also Brahman): cf. F. Brahmane Brachmane Bramine, L. Brachmanae -manes -mani, pl., Gr. �, pl
A person of the highest or sacerdotal caste among the Hindus.
a person from an old, respected, and usually wealthy family who has considerable social or political influence; -- a term used especially in New England; as, a Boston brahmin .

entry.def: A Brahmani.

entry.ety: Fem. of Brahman
entry.def: Any Brahman woman.
Of or pertaining to the Brahmans or to their doctrines and worship.
The religion or system of doctrines of the Brahmans; the religion of Brahma.
An adherent of the religion of the Brahmans.
The religious system of Brahmo-somaj.

entry.ety: Bengalese, a worshiping assembly
entry.def: A modern reforming theistic sect among the Hindus.

sn.def: a famous German composer, b. 1833, d. 1897.
the music composed by Brahms; as, the program consisted mostly of Brahms .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Braided; p. pr. & vb. n. Braiding
entry.ety: OE. braiden breiden, to pull, reach, braid, AS. bregdan to move to and fro, to weave; akin. to Icel. bregða, D. breiden to knit, OS. bregdan to weave, OHG. brettan to brandish. Cf. Broid

sn.def: To weave, interlace, or entwine together, as three or more strands or threads; to form into a braid; to plait.
sn.q: Braid your locks with rosy twine.

sn.def: To mingle, or to bring to a uniformly soft consistence, by beating, rubbing, or straining, as in some culinary operations.
To reproach. Obs See Upbraid.
A plait, band, or narrow fabric formed by intertwining or weaving together different strands.
sn.q: A braid of hair composed of two different colors twined together.

sn.def: A narrow fabric, as of wool, silk, or linen, used for binding, trimming, or ornamenting dresses, etc.

entry.ety: Cf.Icel. breg�a to move quickly

sn.def: A quick motion; a start.
A fancy; freak; caprice.

entry.def: To start; to awake.

entry.ety: AS. bræd bred, deceit; akin to Icel. bragð trick, AS. bredan bregdan, to braid, knit, (hence) to knit a net, to draw into a net, i. e., to deceive. See Braid v. t.
entry.def: Deceitful.
entry.q: Since Frenchmen are so braid, Marry that will, I live and die a maid.

sn.def: adorned with braid; as, his braided collar.
formed into a braid or braids; as, braided hair.
The act of making or using braids.
Braids, collectively; trimming.
sn.q: A gentleman enveloped in mustachios, whiskers, fur collars, and braiding.

entry.ety: OE. brayle furling rope, OF. braiol a band placed around the breeches, fr.F. braies, pl., breeches, fr. L. braca bracae, breeches, a Gallic word; cf. Arm. bragez. Cf. Breeches

sn.def: A thong of soft leather to bind up a hawk's wing.
Ropes passing through pulleys, and used to haul in or up the leeches, bottoms, or corners of sails, preparatory to furling.
A stock at each end of a seine to keep it stretched.

entry.def: To haul up by the brails; -- used with up; as, to brail up a sail.

A system of printing or writing for the blind in which the characters and numerals are represented by patterns of raised tangible points or dots. It was invented by Louis Braille , a French teacher of the blind.

sn.def: to transcribe in Braille.

entry.note: ☞ In the brain of man the cerebral lobes, or largest part of the forebrain, are enormously developed so as to overhang the cerebellum, the great lobe of the hindbrain, and completely cover the lobes of the midbrain. The surface of the cerebrum is divided into irregular ridges, or convolutions, separated by grooves (the so-called fissures and sulci), and the two hemispheres are connected at the bottom of the longitudinal fissure by a great transverse band of nervous matter, the corpus callosum, while the two halves of the cerebellum are connected on the under side of the brain by the bridge, or pons Varolii.
☞ In this sense, often used in the plural.

cs.cd: to have constantly in one's thoughts, as a sort of monomania.
a decision requiring little or no thought; an obvious choice.
the bony or cartilaginous case inclosing the brain.
a massive reef-building coral having the surface covered by ridges separated by furrows so as to resemble somewhat the surface of the brain, esp. such corals of the genera Mæandrina and Diploria.
brain weariness. See Cerebropathy.
fever in which the brain is specially affected; any acute cerebral affection attended by fever.
calcareous matter found in the pineal gland.

entry.ety: OE. brain brein, AS. bragen brægen; akin to LG. brägen bregen, D. brein, and perh. to Gr. bre`gma brechmo`s, the upper part of head, if β = φ. √95

sn.def: The whitish mass of soft matter (the center of the nervous system, and the seat of consciousness and volition) which is inclosed in the cartilaginous or bony cranium of vertebrate animals. It is simply the anterior termination of the spinal cord, and is developed from three embryonic vesicles, whose cavities are connected with the central canal of the cord; the cavities of the vesicles become the central cavities, or ventricles, and the walls thicken unequally and become the three segments, the fore-, mid-, and hind-brain.
The anterior or cephalic ganglion in insects and other invertebrates.
The organ or seat of intellect; hence, the understanding; as, use your brains .
sn.q: Mybrainis too dull.

sn.def: The affections; fancy; imagination.
a very intelligent person.
the controlling electronic mechanism for a robot, guided missile, computer, or other device exhibiting some degree of self-regulation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brained brānd; p. pr. & vb. n. Braining

sn.def: To dash out the brains of; to kill by beating out the brains.
To destroy; to put an end to; to defeat.
sn.q: There thou mayst brain him.
It was the swift celerity of the death . . . That brained my purpose.

sn.def: To conceive; to understand.
sn.q: 'T is still a dream, or else such stuff as madmen Tongue, and brain not.

entry.def: the part of the skull that encloses the brain.
a product of one's creative thinking and work; as, the project was the brainchild of the director.
Supplied with brains.
entry.q: If th' other two be brained like us.

entry.def: Hot-headed; furious.
Without understanding; silly; thoughtless; witless.

entry.ety: Brain + pan
entry.def: The bones which inclose the brain; the skull; the cranium.
mental ability; intellectual acuity.
entry.syn: brain, learning ability, mental capacity, mentality, wit.

entry.def: Disordered in the understanding; giddy; thoughtless.
In a brainsick manner.
the clear (and often sudden) understanding of a complex situation; a sudden brilliant insight.
to try to solve a problem by discussing it exhaustively in an intense group meeting encouraging uninhibited and spontaneous contributions from all members.
a difficult problem.

entry.wordforms: imp. & p. p. brainwashed; p. pr. & vb. n. brainwashing

sn.def: to persuade completely; as, the propaganda brainwashed many people.
to to indoctrinate forcibly or by means of torture, or by constant psychological pressure.

entries.entry:
brainwashed adj. subjected to intensive forced indoctrination resulting in the rejection of old beliefs and acceptance of new ones.
brainwashed prisoners of war; captive audiences for TV commercials can become brainwashed consumers unbrainwashed

entry.def: the process of forcible indoctrination into a new set of attitudes and beliefs.

sn.def: rapid fluctuations of voltage between parts of the brain.
the clear (and often sudden) understanding of a complex situation.
Having an active or vigorous mind.
highly intelligent.

entry.ety: So called from its iridescent colors
entry.def: A European marine fish (Pagrus vulgaris) allied to the American scup; the becker. The name is sometimes applied to the related species.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: Charcoal powder; breeze.
Braised meat.

entry.ety: F. braiser, fr. braise coals
entry.def: To stew or broil in a covered kettle or pan.
