entry.def: A kettle or pan for braising.

entry.ety: Cf.W. braith variegated, Ir. breath breagh, fine, comely
entry.def: A rough diamond.
See Braise.
imp. of Break.

cs.cd: a thicket of canes. See Canebrake.

entry.ety: OE. brake fern; cf. AS. bracce fern, LG. brake willow bush, Da. bregne fern, G. brach fallow; prob. orig. the growth on rough, broken ground, fr. the root of E. break. See Break v. t., cf. Bracken, and 2d Brake n.

sn.def: A fern of the genus Pteris, esp. the Pteris aquilina, common in almost all countries. It has solitary stems dividing into three principal branches. Less properly: Any fern.
A thicket; a place overgrown with shrubs and brambles, with undergrowth and ferns, or with canes.
sn.q: Rounds rising hillocks, brakes obscure and rough, To shelter thee from tempest and from rain.
He stayed not for brake and he stopped not for stone.

entry.cs:
Air brake. See Air brake, in the Vocabulary.
Brake beamorBrake bar
the beam that connects the brake blocks of opposite wheels. Brake block. The part of a brake holding the brake shoe. A brake shoe.
Brake shoe or Brake rubber
the part of a brake against which the wheel rubs. Brake wheel a wheel on the platform or top of a car by which brakes are operated. Continuous brake . See under Continuous.
entry.ety: OE. brake; cf. LG. brake an instrument for breaking flax, G. breche, fr. the root of E. break. See Break v. t., and cf. Breach

sn.def: An instrument or machine to break or bruise the woody part of flax or hemp so that it may be separated from the fiber.
An extended handle by means of which a number of men can unite in working a pump, as in a fire engine.
A baker's kneading though.
A sharp bit or snaffle.
sn.q: Pampered jades . . . which need nor break nor bit.

sn.def: A frame for confining a refractory horse while the smith is shoeing him; also, an inclosure to restrain cattle, horses, etc.
sn.q: A horse . . . which Philip had bought . . . and because of his fierceness kept him within a brake of iron bars.

sn.def: That part of a carriage, as of a movable battery, or engine, which enables it to turn.
An ancient engine of war analogous to the crossbow and ballista.
A large, heavy harrow for breaking clods after plowing; a drag.

A piece of mechanism for retarding or stopping motion by friction, as of a carriage or railway car, by the pressure of rubbers against the wheels, or of clogs or ratchets against the track or roadway, or of a pivoted lever against a wheel or drum in a machine.
An apparatus for testing the power of a steam engine, or other motor, by weighing the amount of friction that the motor will overcome; a friction brake.
A cart or carriage without a body, used in breaking in horses.
An ancient instrument of torture.

entries.entry:
Brake"man brāk"m�n n.; pl.Brakemen brāk"m�n.
Railroads A man in charge of a brake or brakes.
Mining The man in charge of the winding (or hoisting) engine for a mine.

entry.def: the combination of interacting parts that work to slow a moving vehicle.
Full of brakes; abounding with brambles, shrubs, or ferns; rough; thorny.
entry.q: In the woods and braky glens.

entry.def: wearing no brassiere.
See Brahma.

entries.entry: Bra"mah press`. A hydrostatic press of immense power, invented by Joseph Bramah of London. See under Hydrostatic.

entry.ety: OE. brembil, AS. brēmel brēmbel brǣmbelakin to OHG. brāmal), fr. the same root as E. broom, As. brōm. See Broom

sn.def: Any plant of the genus Rubus, including the raspberry and blackberry. Hence: Any rough, prickly shrub.
sn.q: The thorny brambles, and embracing bushes.

sn.def: The brambling or bramble finch.

entries.entry: Bram"ble bush` bụsh`. Bot The bramble, or a collection of brambles growing together. He jumped into a bramble bush And scratched out both his eyes.

entry.def: Overgrown with brambles.
entry.q: Forlorn she sits upon the brambled floor.

entries.entry: Bram"ble net`. A net to catch birds.

entry.ety: OE. bramline. See Bramble n.
entry.def: The European mountain finch (Fringilla montifringilla); -- called also bramble finch and bramble.
Pertaining to, resembling, or full of, brambles.
entry.q: Inbramblywildernesses.

entry.ety: Cf. Breme
entry.def: Sharp passion; vexation.
entry.q: Heart-burning brame.

entry.def: See Brahman Brachmanic, etc.

entry.ety: OE. bren bran, OF. bren, F. bran, from Celtic; cf. Armor. brenn, Ir. bran, bran, chaff

sn.def: The broken coat of the seed of wheat, rye, or other cereal grain, separated from the flour or meal by sifting or bolting; the coarse, chaffy part of ground grain.
The European carrion crow.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A litter on which a person may be carried.

entries.entry:
Branch
Branches of a bridle two pieces of bent iron, which bear the bit, the cross chains, and the curb. Branch herring. See Alewife. Root and branch , totally, wholly.
n.; pl.Branches. OE. braunche, F. branche, fr. LL. branca claw of a bird or beast of prey; cf. Armor. brank branch, bough
Bot A shoot or secondary stem growing from the main stem, or from a principal limb or bough of a tree or other plant.
Any division extending like a branch; any arm or part connected with the main body of thing; ramification; as, the branch of an antler; the branch of a chandelier; a branch of a river; a branch of a railway. Most of the branches , or streams, were dried up.
Any member or part of a body or system; a distinct article; a section or subdivision; a department.
Branchesof knowledge. It is a branch and parcel of mine oath.
Geom One of the portions of a curve that extends outwards to an indefinitely great distance; as, the branches of an hyperbola.
A line of family descent, in distinction from some other line or lines from the same stock; any descendant in such a line; as, the English branch of a family. His father, a younger branch of the ancient stock.
Naut A warrant or commission given to a pilot, authorizing him to pilot vessels in certain waters. Bough; limb; shoot; offshoot; twig; sprig.

entry.def: Diverging from, or tributary to, a main stock, line, way, theme, etc.; as, a branch vein; a branch road or line; a branch topic; a branch store.

cs.cd: to form a branch or a separate part; to diverge.
to speak diffusively; to extend one's discourse to other topics than the main one; also, to enlarge the scope of one's business, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Branched; p. pr. & vb. n. Branching

sn.def: To shoot or spread in branches; to separate into branches; to ramify.
To divide into separate parts or subdivision.
sn.q: To branch out into a long disputation.

sn.def: To divide as into branches; to make subordinate division in.
To adorn with needlework representing branches, flowers, or twigs.
sn.q: The train whereof loose far behind her strayed,Branched with gold and pearl, most richly wrought.

sn.def: resembling a fork; divided or separated into two branches; as, long branched hairs on its legs, on which pollen collects.
same as branching a..
That which shoots forth branches; one who shows growth in various directions.
A young hawk when it begins to leave the nest and take to the branches.

entry.def: A system of branches.

entries.entry: Bran"chi*a Bran"chi*a n.; pl.Branchiæ. L., fr. Gr. �, pl. of � Anat A gill; a respiratory organ for breathing the air contained in water, such as many aquatic and semiaquatic animals have.

cs.cd: the bony or cartilaginous arches which support the gills on each side of the throat of fishes and amphibians. See Illustration in Appendix.
the openings between the branchial arches through which water passes.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to branchiæ or gills.
Furnished with branchiæ; as, branchiate segments.
Having gills; branchiate; as, branchiferous gastropods.
Fullness of branches.
Furnished with branches; shooting our branches; extending in a branch or branches.
entry.q: Shaded with branching palm.

entry.def: The act or state of separation into branches; division into branches; a division or branch.
entry.q: The sciences, with their numerous branchings.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � gill + E. gastropoda
entry.def: Those Gastropoda that breathe by branchiæ, including the Prosobranchiata and Opisthobranchiata.

entry.ety: Gr. � gill + -mere
entry.def: The state of being made up of branchiate segments.
One of the Branchiopoda.

entry.ety: Gr. � gill + -poda: cf. F. branchiopode
entry.def: An order of Entomostraca; -- so named from the feet of branchiopods having been supposed to perform the function of gills. It includes the fresh-water genera Branchipus Apus, and Limnadia, and the genus Artemia found in salt lakes. It is also called Phyllopoda . See Phyllopoda Cladocera. It is sometimes used in a broader sense.

entry.note: ☞ This term was formerly applied to a group of fishes having boneless branchiæ. But the arrangement was artificial, and has been rejected.
entry.ety: Gr. � gill + � to cover: cf. F. branchiostège
entry.def: Pertaining to the membrane covering the gills of fishes.

def2.def: A branchiostegal ray. See Illustration of Branchial arches in Appendix.

entry.def: The branchiostegal membrane. See Illustration in Appendix.
Branchiostegal.

entry.ety: NL., fr., Gr. � gill + � mouth
entry.def: The lancelet. See Amphioxus.

entry.ety: NL., fr., Gr. � gill + o'yra` tail
entry.def: A group of Entomostraca, with suctorial mouths, including species parasitic on fishes, as the carp lice (Argulus).
Destitute of branches or shoots; without any valuable product; barren; naked.

entry.ety: Branch + -let
entry.def: A little branch; a twig.

entries.entry: Branch" pi`lot. A pilot who has a branch or commission, as from Trinity House, England, for special navigation.

entry.def: Full of branches; having wide-spreading branches; consisting of branches.
entry.q: Beneath thy branchy bowers of thickest gloom.

entry.ety: OE. brand brond, AS. brand brond brand, sword, from byrnan beornan, to burn; akin to D., Dan., Sw., & G. brand brand, Icel. brandr a brand, blade of a sword. √32. See Burn v. t., and cf. Brandish

sn.def: A burning piece of wood; or a stick or piece of wood partly burnt, whether burning or after the fire is extinct.
sn.q: Snatching a live brand from a wigwam, Mason threw it on a matted roof.

sn.def: A sword, so called from its glittering or flashing brightness.
sn.q: Paradise, so late their happy seat, Waved over by that flaming brand.

sn.def: A mark made by burning with a hot iron, as upon a cask, to designate the quality, manufacturer, etc., of the contents, or upon an animal, to designate ownership; -- also, a mark for a similar purpose made in any other way, as with a stencil. Hence, figurately: Quality; kind; grade; as, a good brand of flour.
A mark put upon criminals with a hot iron. Hence: Any mark of infamy or vice; a stigma.
sn.q: The brand of private vice.

sn.def: An instrument to brand with; a branding iron.
Any minute fungus which produces a burnt appearance in plants. The brands are of many species and several genera of the order Pucciniæi.

entries.entry:
Brand v. t.
imp. & p. p. Branded; p. pr. & vb. n. Branding . To burn a distinctive mark into or upon with a hot iron, to indicate quality, ownership, etc., or to mark as infamous (as a convict).
To put an actual distinctive mark upon in any other way, as with a stencil, to show quality of contents, name of manufacture, etc.
Fig.: To fix a mark of infamy, or a stigma, upon. The Inquisition branded its victims with infamy. There were the enormities, branded and condemned by the first and most natural verdict of common humanity.
To mark or impress indelibly, as with a hot iron. As if it were branded on my mind.

entry.ety: So named after Brandenburg, a province and a town of Prussia
entry.def: A kind of decoration for the breast of a coat, sometimes only a frog with a loop, but in some military uniforms enlarged into a broad horizontal stripe.
entry.q: He wore a coat . . . trimmed with Brandenburgs.

sn.def: One who, or that which, brands; a branding iron.
A gridiron.

entries.entry:
Brand" goose`. Prob. fr. 1st brand + goose: cf. Sw. brandgås. Cf. Brant
Zoöl A species of wild goose (Branta bernicla) usually called in America brant. See Brant.

entry.def: Mingled with brandy; made stronger by the addition of brandy; flavored or treated with brandy; as, brandied peaches.

entries.entry: Brand"ing i`*ron. An iron to brand with.

Brand" i`ron. A branding iron.
A trivet to set a pot on.
The horizontal bar of an andiron.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brandished; p. pr. & vb. n. Brandishing
entry.ety: OE. braundisen, F. brandir, fr. brand a sword, fr. OHG. brant brand. See Brand n.

sn.def: To move or wave, as a weapon; to raise and move in various directions; to shake or flourish.
sn.q: The quivering lance which he brandished bright.

sn.def: To play with; to flourish; as, to brandish syllogisms.

entry.def: A flourish, as with a weapon, whip, etc.
entry.q: Brandishesof the fan.

entry.def: One who brandishes.

entry.ety: F. brandiller
entry.def: To shake; to totter.
Same as Branlin, fish and worm.

entry.ety: See Brand, and cf. Brannew
entry.def: Quite new; bright as if fresh from the forge.

entries.entry: Brand" spore`. Bot One of several spores growing in a series or chain, and produced by one of the fungi called brand.

Bran"dy
Brandy fruit fruit preserved in brandy and sugar.
n.; pl.Brandies. From older brandywine brandwine, fr. D. brandewijn, fr. p. p. of branden to burn, distill + wijn wine, akin to G. branntwein. See Brand
A strong alcoholic liquor distilled from wine. The name is also given to spirit distilled from other liquors, and in the United States to that distilled from cider and peaches. In northern Europe, it is also applied to a spirit obtained from grain.

entry.def: Brandy.

entry.ety: Prov. E. brangled confused, entangled, Scot. brangle to shake, menace; probably a variant of wrangle, confused with brawl. √95.>
entry.def: A wrangle; a squabble; a noisy contest or dispute.
entry.q: A brangle between him and his neighbor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brangled; p. pr. & vb. n. Brangling
entry.def: To wrangle; to dispute contentiously; to squabble.
Wrangle; brangle.
A quarrelsome person.
A quarrel.

entry.ety: Prov. of Celtic origin; cf. L. brance brace, the Gallic name of a particularly white kind of corn
entry.def: Buckwheat.

entry.ety: Cf. Gael. brangus brangas, a sort of pillory, Ir. brancas halter, or D. pranger fetter

sn.def: A sort of bridle with wooden side pieces.
A scolding bridle, an instrument formerly used for correcting scolding women. It was an iron frame surrounding the head and having a triangular piece entering the mouth of the scold.
To hold up and toss the head; -- applied to horses as spurning the bit.
To prance; to caper.

entry.ety: F. branc-ursine branch-ursine, fr. LL. branca claw + L. ursinus belonging to a bear (fr. ursus bear), i. e., bear's claw, because its leaves resemble the claws of a bear. Cf. Branch
entry.def: Bear's-breech, or Acanthus.

entry.ety: Scot. branlie fr. brand
entry.def: A young salmon or parr, in the stage in which it has transverse black bands, as if burned by a gridiron.

entry.ety: See Brand
entry.def: A small red worm or larva, used as bait for small fresh-water fish; -- so called from its red color.
See Brand-new.
Having the appearance of bran; consisting of or containing bran.

entry.ety: See Brawl a dance
entry.def: A brawl or dance.

entry.ety: Cf.Brand goose Brent Brenicle
entry.def: A species of wild goose (Branta bernicla) -- called also brent and brand goose. The name is also applied to other related species.

entry.ety: See Brent
entry.def: Steep.
The European redstart; -- so called from the red color of its tail.

entry.ety: For brand-fox; cf. G. brandfuchs, Sw. bradräf. So called from its yellowish brown and somewhat black color. See Brand
entry.def: A kind of fox found in Sweden (Vulpes alopex), smaller than the common fox (Vulpes vulgaris), but probably a variety of it.
Relating to the brain; cerebral.
Same as Brazen.
a magnoliid genus; a genus of dicotyledonous flowering plants regarded as the most primitive of extant angiosperms; alternatively, a member of the family Nymphaeaceae.

entry.ety: Cf. Gael. bras or G. barsch harsh, sharp, tart, impetuous, D. barsch, Sw. & Dan. barsk
entry.def: Hasty in temper; impetuous.

entry.ety: Cf. Amer. bresk brusk, fragile, brittle
entry.def: Brittle, as wood or vegetables.

cs.cd: an affection characterized by a spasmodic pain or hot sensation in the stomach with a rising of watery liquid into the mouth; pyrosis.
a severe form of diarrhea which sometimes attacks children just weaned.

entry.ety: See Brash brittle

sn.def: A rash or eruption; a sudden or transient fit of sickness.
Refuse boughs of trees; also, the clippings of hedges.
Broken and angular fragments of rocks underlying alluvial deposits.
Broken fragments of ice.
Resembling, or of the nature of, brash, or broken fragments; broken; crumbly.
sn.q: Our progress was not at all impeded by the few soft, brashy floes that we encountered.

sn.def: Showery; characterized by brashes, or showers.

entry.ety: OE. brasiere, F. braise live coals. See Brass
entry.def: An artificer who works in brass.

entry.ety: F. brasier braisíer, fr. braise live coals. See Brass
entry.def: A large metal pan for holding burning coals or charcoal; it is used to warm people who must stay outside for long times.
the capital city of Brazil, built on the central plateau.

entry.ety: Cf. F. brésiline. See 2d Brazil
entry.def: A substance, C16H14O5, extracted from brazilwood as a yellow crystalline powder which is white when pure. It is colored intensely red by alkalies on exposure to the air, being oxidized to bra*sil"e*in C16H12O5, to which brazilwood owes its dyeing properties.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A paste made by mixing powdered charcoal, coal, or coke with clay, molasses, tar, or other suitable substance. It is used for lining hearths, crucibles, etc. Called also steep.

entries.entry:
Brass ☞ The word brass as used in Sculpture language is a translation for copper or some kind of bronze. ☞ Brass is often used adjectively or in self-explaining compounds; as, brass button, brass kettle, brass founder, brass foundry or brassfoundry.
Brass band Mus a band of musicians who play upon wind instruments made of brass, as trumpets, cornets, etc.
Brass foil Brass leaf
brass made into very thin sheets; -- called also Dutch gold.
n.; pl.Brasses. OE. bras bres, AS. bræs; akin to Icel. bras cement, solder, brasa to harden by fire, and to E. braze brazen. Cf. 1st & 2d Braze
An alloy (usually yellow) of copper and zinc, in variable proportion, but often containing two parts of copper to one part of zinc. It sometimes contains tin, and rarely other metals.
Mach A journal bearing, so called because frequently made of brass. A brass is often lined with a softer metal, when the latter is generally called a white metal lining. See Axle box Journal Box, and Bearing.
Coin made of copper, brass, or bronze. Obs Provide neither gold, nor silver, nor brass in your purses, nor scrip for your journey.
Impudence; a brazen face. Colloq
pl. Utensils, ornaments, or other articles of brass. The very scullion who cleans the brasses.
A brass plate engraved with a figure or device. Specifically, one used as a memorial to the dead, and generally having the portrait, coat of arms, etc.
pl. Mining Lumps of pyrites or sulphuret of iron, the color of which is near to that of brass.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A sum formerly levied to pay the expense of coinage; -- now called seigniorage.
an armor plate that protects the arm.

entry.ety: F. brassard, fr. bras arm. See Brace n.
entry.def: Armor for the arm; -- generally used for the whole arm from the shoulder to the wrist, and consisting, in the 15th and 16th centuries, of many parts.
any of various tropical American orchids with usually solitary fleshy leaves and showy white to green nocturnally fragrant blossoms solitary or in racemes of up to 7.

sn.def: inflexibly entrenched; as, brassbound traditions.
having trim or fittings of brass; as, a brassbound campaign chest; the heavy brass-bound door.

entry.ety: Perh. a transposition of barse; but cf. LG. brasse the bream, G. brassen Cf. Bream
entry.def: A spotted European fish of the genus Lucioperca, resembling a perch.
a small restaurant serving beer and wine as well as food; usually cheap.
See Brassart.
a genus of tropical American epiphytic orchids having striking axillary racemes of yellow to green spiderlike flowers with long slender sepals and warty lips; the spider orchids.

entry.ety: L., cabbage
entry.def: A genus of plants embracing several species and varieties differing much in appearance and qualities: such as the common cabbage (Brassica oleracea), broccoli, cauliflowers, etc.; the wild turnip (Brassica campestris); the common turnip (Brassica rapa); the rape or coleseed (Brassica napus), etc.
a natural family of plants with four-petaled flowers.
entry.syn: Cruciferae, family Cruciferae, family Brassicaceae, mustard family.

entry.ety: L. brassica cabbage
entry.def: Related to, or resembling, the cabbage, or plants of the Cabbage family.
formerly a golfing wood with a face more elevated that a driver but less than a spoon.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A form of woman's undergarment, often stiffened with wire or whalebones, or the like, and worn to cover and support the breasts; -- also called bra. It usually has straps which support it from the shoulders, but strapless variants are also made.
The state, condition, or quality of being brassy.

sn.def: resembling the sound of a brass instrument.
having an appearance resembling that of brass.

entry.def: Impudent; bold.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to brass; having the nature, appearance, or hardness, of brass.
Impudent; impudently bold.

entry.def: A wooden club soled with brass.

entry.ety: See Burst
entry.def: To burst.
entry.q: And both his yën braste out of his face.
Dreadfull furies which their chains have brast.

entry.ety: OE. bratt coarse garnment, AS. bratt cloak, fr. the Celtic; cf. W. brat clout, rag, Gael. brat cloak, apron, rag, Ir. brat cloak; properly then, a child's bib or clout; hence, a child

sn.def: A coarse garment or cloak; also, coarse clothing, in general.
A coarse kind of apron for keeping the clothes clean; a bib.
A child; an offspring; -- formerly used in a good sense, but now usually in a contemptuous sense.
sn.q: Thisbratis none of mine.
A beggar'sbrat.
O Israel! O household of the Lord! O Abraham's brats! O brood of blessed seed!

sn.def: The young of an animal.

entry.def: A thin bed of coal mixed with pyrites or carbonate of lime.

entry.ety: Sc. also bratchart; fr. ME. brachet, fr. OF. brachet; ML. brachetus, dim. of brache a hound. See brach
entry.def: a kind of hound; a brach; -- applied contemptuously to a child. See also brach.
entry.q: The bratchet's bay From the dark covert drove the prey.
To be plagued with a bratchet whelp -- Whence came ye, my fair-favoured little gossip? .

entry.ety: G., fr. It. viola da braccio viola held on the arm
entry.def: The tenor viola, or viola.

entry.ety: See Brettice
entry.def: A wall of separation in a shaft or gallery used for ventilation.
Planking to support a roof or wall.

sn.def: See Brattice n.
Carved openwork, as of a shrine, battlement, or parapet.

entry.pr: brăt"wûrst; brăt"w�rst; brăt"vûrst; brät"wûrst; G. brăt"v�rsht
entry.ety: German
entry.def: a small pork sausage seasoned with spices and herbs, and usually served broiled or sauteed.
A native oxide of manganese, of dark brownish black color. It was named from a Mr. Braun of Gotha.
Bravado.

entry.ety: Sp. bravada bravata, boast, brag: cf. F. bravade. See Brave
entry.def: Boastful and threatening behavior; a boastful menace.
entry.q: In spite of our host's bravado.

entry.ety: F. brave, It. or Sp. bravo, (orig.) fierce, wild, savage, prob. from. L. barbarus. See Barbarous, and cf. Bravo

sn.def: Bold; courageous; daring; intrepid; -- opposed to cowardly; as, a brave man; a brave act.
Having any sort of superiority or excellence; -- especially such as in conspicuous.
sn.mark: Obs. or Archaic as applied to material things
sn.q: Iron is a brave commodity where wood aboundeth.
It being a brave day, I walked to Whitehall.

sn.def: Making a fine show or display.
sn.q: Wear my dagger with the braver grace.
For I have gold, and therefore will be brave. In silks I'll rattle it of every color.
Frog and lizard in holiday coats And turtle brave in his golden spots.
sn.syn: Courageous; gallant; daring; valiant; valorous; bold; heroic; intrepid; fearless; dauntless; magnanimous; high-spirited; stout-hearted. See Gallant.

sn.def: A brave person; one who is daring.
sn.q: The star-spangled banner, O,long may it wave O'er the land of the free and the home of the brave.

sn.def: Specifically, an Indian warrior.
A man daring beyond discretion; a bully.
sn.q: Hot braves like thee may fight.

sn.def: A challenge; a defiance; bravado.
sn.q: Demetrius, thou dost overween in all; And so in this, to bear me down with braves.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Braved; p. pr. & vb. n. Braving

sn.def: To encounter with courage and fortitude; to set at defiance; to defy; to dare.
sn.q: These I can brave, but those I can not bear.

sn.def: To adorn; to make fine or showy.
sn.q: Thou [a tailor whom Grunio was browbeating] hast braved meny men; brave not me; I'll neither be faced or braved.

sn.def: In a brave manner; courageously; gallantly; valiantly; splendidly; nobly.
Finely; gaudily; gayly; showily.
sn.q: And [she] decked herself bravely to allure the eyes of all men that should see her.

sn.def: Well; thrivingly; prosperously.

entry.def: The quality of state or being brave.

entry.ety: Cf. F. braverie

sn.def: The quality of being brave; fearless; intrepidity.
sn.q: Remember, sir, my liege, . . . The natural bravery of your isle.

sn.def: The act of braving; defiance; bravado.
sn.q: Reform, then, without bravery or scandal of former times and persons.

sn.def: Splendor; magnificence; showy appearance; ostentation; fine dress.
sn.q: With scarfs and fans and double change of bravery.
Like a stately ship . . . With all her bravery on, and tackle trim.

sn.def: A showy person; a fine gentleman; a beau.
sn.q: A man that is the bravery of his age.
sn.syn: Courage; heroism; interpidity; gallantry; valor; fearlessness; dauntlessness; hardihood; manfulness. See Courage, and Heroism.

entry.def: A bravado; a boast.
entry.q: With so proud a strain Of threats and bravings.

entry.def: In a defiant manner.

entries.entry:
Bra"vo n.; pl.Bravoes. I. See Brave a.
A daring villain; a bandit; one who sets law at defiance; a professional assassin or murderer. Safe from detection, seize the unwary prey. And stab, like bravoes, all who come this way.

entry.ety: It. See Brave
entry.def: Well done! excellent! an exclamation expressive of applause.

cs.cd: a florid air demanding brilliant execution.

entry.ety: It., (properly) bravery, spirit, from bravo. See Brave
entry.def: A florid, brilliant style of music, written for effect, to show the range and flexibility of a singer's voice, or the technical force and skill of a performer; virtuoso music.

entry.ety: See Brave a.

sn.def: Well-dressed; handsome; smart; brave; -- used of persons or their clothing, etc.; as, a braw lad.
sn.q: Abrawnew gown.

sn.def: Good; fine.
sn.q: Abrawnight.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brawled; p. pr. & vb. n. Brawling
entry.ety: OE. braulen to quarrel, boast, brallen to cry, make a noise; cf. LG. brallen to brag, MHG. pr�ulen, G. prahlen, F. brailler to cry, shout, Pr. brailar braillar, W. bragal to vociferate, brag, Armor. bragal to romp, to strut, W. broliaw to brag, brawl boast. �95

sn.def: To quarrel noisily and outrageously.
sn.q: Let a man that is a man consider that he is a fool that brawleth openly with his wife.

sn.def: To complain loudly; to scold.
To make a loud confused noise, as the water of a rapid stream running over stones.
sn.q: Where the brook brawls along the painful road.

entry.def: A noisy quarrel; loud, angry contention; a wrangle; a tumult; as, a drunken brawl .
entry.q: His sports were hindered by the brawls.

cs.cd: one who disturbs a neighborhood by brawling (and is therefore indictable at common law as a nuisance).

entry.def: One that brawls; wrangler.

sn.def: Quarreling; quarrelsome; noisy.
sn.q: She is an irksome brawling scold.

sn.def: Making a loud confused noise. See Brawl v. i., 3.
sn.q: A brawling stream.

entry.def: In a brawling manner.

entry.ety: OF. braon fleshy part, muscle, fr. HG. br�to flesh, G. braten roast meat; akin to Icel. br�� flesh, food of beasts, AS. br�de roast meat, br�dan to roast, G. braten, and possibly to E. breed

sn.def: A muscle; flesh.
sn.q: Formed well of brawns and of bones.

sn.def: Full, strong muscles, esp. of the arm or leg, muscular strength; a protuberant muscular part of the body; sometimes, the arm.
sn.q: Brawn without brains is thine.
It was ordained that murderers should be brent on the brawn of the left hand.
And in my vantbrace put this withered brawn.

sn.def: The flesh of a boar; also, the salted and prepared flesh of a boar.
sn.q: The best age for the boar is from two to five years, at which time it is best to geld him, or sell him for brawn.

sn.def: A boar.

entry.def: Brawny; strong; muscular.
A boor killed for the table.
The quality or state of being brawny.
Having large, strong muscles; muscular; fleshy; strong.
entry.q: Brawnylimbs.
entry.syn: Muscular; fleshy; strong; bulky; sinewy; athletic; stalwart; powerful; robust.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. breac rheum, broc sickness, Ir. bracha corruption. Jamieson

sn.def: A disease of sheep. The term is variously applied in different localities.
A diseased sheep, or its mutton.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brayed brād; p. pr. & vb. n. Braying
entry.ety: OE. brayen, OF. breier, F. broyer to pound, grind, fr. OHG. brehhan to break. See Break
entry.def: To pound, beat, rub, or grind small or fine.
entry.q: Though thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar, . . . yet will not his foolishness depart from him.

entry.ety: OE brayen, F. braire to bray, OF. braire to cry, fr. LL. bragire to whinny; perh. fr. the Celtic and akin to E. break; or perh. of imitative origin

sn.def: To utter a loud, harsh cry, as an ass.
sn.q: Laugh, and they Return it louder than an ass can bray.

sn.def: To make a harsh, grating, or discordant noise.
sn.q: Heard ye the din of battle bray?

entry.def: To make or utter with a loud, discordant, or harsh and grating sound.
entry.q: Arms on armor clashing, brayed Horrible discord.
And varying notes the war pipes brayed.

entry.def: The harsh cry of an ass; also, any harsh, grating, or discordant sound.
entry.q: The bray and roar of multitudinous London.

entry.ety: OE. braye brey brew, eyebrow, brow of a hill, hill, bank, Scot. bra brae bray, fr. AS. brǣw eyebrow, influenced by the allied Icel. brā eyebrow, bank, also akin to AS. brū eyebrow. See Brow
entry.def: A bank; the slope of a hill; a hill. See Brae, which is now the usual spelling.
An implement for braying and spreading ink in hand printing.
One that brays like an ass.
Making a harsh noise; blaring.
entry.q: Brayingtrumpets.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brazed; p. pr. & vb. n. Brazing
entry.ety: F. braser to solder, fr. Icel. brasa to harden by fire. Cf. Brass

sn.def: To solder with hard solder, esp. with an alloy of copper and zinc; as, to braze the seams of a copper pipe.
To harden.
sn.q: Now I ambrazesto it.

entry.ety: AS. bræsian, fr. bræs brass. See Brass
entry.def: To cover or ornament with brass.

entry.cs: Brazen age. Myth The age of war and lawlessness which succeeded the silver age. Archæol See under Bronze. Brazen sea Jewish Antiq a large laver of brass, placed in Solomon's temple for the use of the priests.
entry.ety: OE. brasen, AS. bræsen. See Brass

sn.def: Pertaining to, made of, or resembling, brass.
Sounding harsh and loud, like resounding brass.
Impudent; immodest; shameless; having a front like brass; as, a brazen countenance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brazened; p. pr. & vb. n. Brazening
entry.def: To carry through impudently or shamelessly; as, to brazen the matter through.
entry.q: Sabina brazened it out before Mrs. Wygram, but inwardly she was resolved to be a good deal more circumspect.

entry.def: Shamelessly impudent.
An impudent or shameless person.
entry.q: Well said,brazenface;hold it out.

entry.def: Impudent; shameless.
In a bold, impudent manner.
The quality or state of being brazen.
Same as Brasier.

entry.ety: Cf. Pg. & Sp. brasilete, It. brasiletto
entry.def: See Brazil wood.

entry.cs: Brazilian pebble. See Pebble n., 2.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Brazil.

def2.def: A native or an inhabitant of Brazil.

entry.ety: Cf. F. brésiline. See Brazil
entry.def: A substance contained in both Brazil wood and Sapan wood, from which it is extracted as a yellow crystalline substance which is white when pure. It is colored intensely red by alkalies.

entries.entry: Bra*zil" nut` ☞ From eighteen to twenty-four of the seeds or “nuts” grow in a hard and nearly globular shell. brȧ*zĭl" nŭt`. Bot An oily, three-sided nut, the seed of the Bertholletia excelsa; the cream nut.

Bra*zil" wood` Bra*zil"wood`
brȧ*zĭl" w�d`. OE. brasil, LL. brasilecf. Pg. & Sp. brasil, Pr. bresil, Pr. bresil); perh. from Sp. or Pg. brasa a live coal (cf. Braze Brasier); or Ar. vars plant for dyeing red or yellow. This name was given to the wood from its color; and it is said that King Emanuel, of Portugal, gave the name Brazil to the country in South America on account of its producing this wood
The wood of the oriental Cæsalpinia Sapan; -- so called before the discovery of America.
A very heavy wood of a reddish color, imported from Brazil and other tropical countries, for cabinet-work, and for dyeing. The best is the heartwood of Caesalpinia echinata, a leguminous tree; but other trees also yield it. An inferior sort comes from Jamaica, the timber of Caesalpinia Braziliensis and Caesalpinia crista. This is often distinguished as Braziletto , but the better kind is also frequently so named. The wood is also used for violin bows.
a tropical tree (Caesalpinia echinata) with a prickly trunk; its heavy red heartwood (also called brazilwood) yields a red dye and is used for cabinetry. peachwood, pernambuco wood.

entry.def: a North American river, flowing into the Gulf of Mexico.

entries.entry:
Breach
A clear breach implies that the waves roll over the vessel without breaking. A clean breach implies that everything on deck is swept away. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
Breach of falth a breaking, or a failure to keep, an expressed or implied promise; a betrayal of confidence or trust. Breach of peace disorderly conduct, disturbing the public peace. Breach of privilege an act or default in violation of the privilege or either house of Parliament, of Congress, or of a State legislature, as, for instance, by false swearing before a committee. Mozley. Abbott.
- Breach of promise violation of one's plighted word, esp. of a promise to marry. Breach of trust violation of one's duty or faith in a matter entrusted to one.
brēch n. OE. breke breche, AS. brice gebrice gebrecein comp.), fr. brecan to break; akin to Dan. bræk, MHG. breche, gap, breach. See Break, and cf. Brakethe instrument), Brack a break . The act of breaking, in a figurative sense.
Specifically: A breaking or infraction of a law, or of any obligation or tie; violation; non-fulfillment; as, a breach of contract; a breach of promise.
A gap or opening made made by breaking or battering, as in a wall or fortification; the space between the parts of a solid body rent by violence; a break; a rupture. Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more; Or close the wall up with our English dead.
A breaking of waters, as over a vessel; the waters themselves; surge; surf. The Lord hath broken forth upon mine enemies before me, as the breach of waters.
A breaking up of amicable relations; rupture. There's fallen between him and my lord An unkind breach.
A bruise; a wound.
Breach for breach, eye for eye.
Med A hernia; a rupture.
A breaking out upon; an assault. The Lord had made a breach upon Uzza. Rent; cleft; chasm; rift; aperture; gap; break; disruption; fracture; rupture; infraction; infringement; violation; quarrel; dispute; contention; difference; misunderstanding.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Breached ; p. pr. & vb. n. Breaching
entry.def: To make a breach or opening in; as, to breach the walls of a city.
To break the water, as by leaping out; -- said of a whale.
Apt to break fences or to break out of pasture; unruly; as, breachy cattle.

entry.ety: AS. brædan to make broad, to spread. See Broad a.
entry.def: To spread.

entry.note: ☞ Raised bread is made with yeast, salt, and sometimes a little butter or lard, and is mixed with warm milk or water to form the dough, which, after kneading, is given time to rise before baking.Cream of tartar bread is raised by the action of an alkaline carbonate or bicarbonate (as saleratus or ammonium bicarbonate) and cream of tartar (acid tartrate of potassium) or some acid.Unleavened bread is usually mixed with water and salt only.
entry.cs:
Aërated bread. See under Aërated. Bread and butter fig means of living.
Brown bread Indian bread Graham bread Rye and Indian bread . See Brown bread, under Brown. Bread tree. See Breadfruit.
entry.ety: AS. breád; akin to OFries. brād, OS. brōd, D. brood, G. brod brot, Icel. brauð, Sw. & Dan. bröd. The root is probably that of E. brew. √93. See Brew

sn.def: An article of food made from flour or meal by moistening, kneading, and baking.
Food; sustenance; support of life, in general.
sn.q: Give us this day our daily bread.

entry.def: To cover with bread crumbs, preparatory to cooking; as, breaded cutlets.
The stomach.
a container used to store breads or cake, to keep them fresh.
a container used to store breads or cake, to keep them fresh.
a queue of people waiting for free food.

entries.entry: Bread"corn`. Corn of grain of which bread is made, as wheat, rye, etc.

entry.def: Braided
Made of bread.

sn.def: The fruit of a tree (Artocarpus incisa) found in the islands of the Pacific, esp. the South Sea islands. It is of a roundish form, from four to six or seven inches in diameter, and, when baked, somewhat resembles bread, and is eaten as food, whence the name.
The tree itself, which is one of considerable size, with large, lobed leaves. Cloth is made from the bark, and the timber is used for many purposes. Called also breadfruit tree and bread tree.

entry.def: Without bread; destitute of food.
entry.q: Plump peers and breadless bards alike are dull.

entry.note: ☞ It is the Pomme blanche of Canadian voyageurs.
entry.def: The root of a leguminous plant (Psoralea esculenta), found near the Rocky Mountains. It is usually oval in form, and abounds in farinaceous matter, affording sweet and palatable food.
Grain, flour, or meal of which bread is made.

entry.ety: OE. brede breede, whence later bredette, AS. brǣdu, fr. brād broad. See Broad a.

sn.def: Distance from side to side of any surface or thing; measure across, or at right angles to the length; width.

entry.sn: Fine Arts The quality of having the colors and shadows broad and massive, and the arrangement of objects such as to avoid to great multiplicity of details, producing an impression of largeness and simple grandeur; -- called also breadth of effect. Breadth of coloring is a prominent character in the painting of all great masters.

entry.def: Without breadth.
Breadthwise.
In the direction of the breadth.
The member of a family whose labor supplies the food of the family; one who works for his living.

entry.note: With prepositions or adverbs:
entry.cs:
To break down. To crush; to overwhelm; as, to break down one's strength; to break down opposition. To remove, or open a way through, by breaking; as, to break down a door or wall. To break in. To force in; as, to break in a door. To train; to discipline; as, a horse well broken in . To break of to rid of; to cause to abandon; as, to break one of a habit. To break off. To separate by breaking; as, to break off a twig. To stop suddenly; to abandon. “Break off thy sins by righteousness.” Dan. iv. 27. To break open to open by breaking. “Open the door, or I will break it open.” Shak. To break out to take or force out by breaking; as, to break out a pane of glass. To break out a cargo to unstow a cargo, so as to unload it easily. To break through. To make an opening through, as, as by violence or the force of gravity; to pass violently through; as, to break through the enemy's lines; to break through the ice. To disregard; as, to break through the ceremony. To break up. To separate into parts; to plow (new or fallow ground). “Break up this capon.” Shak. “Break up your fallow ground.” Jer. iv. 3. To dissolve; to put an end to. “Break up the court.” Shak.
To breakoneall up
to unsettle or disconcert completely; to upset. Colloq
entry.note: With an immediate object:
entry.cs:
To break the back. To dislocate the backbone; hence, to disable totally. To get through the worst part of; as, to break the back of a difficult undertaking. To break bulk to destroy the entirety of a load by removing a portion of it; to begin to unload; also, to transfer in detail, as from boats to cars. To break a code to discover a method to convert coded messages into the original understandable text. To break cover to burst forth from a protecting concealment, as game when hunted.
To break a deerorTo break a stag
to cut it up and apportion the parts among those entitled to a share. To break fast to partake of food after abstinence. See Breakfast. To break ground. To open the earth as for planting; to commence excavation, as for building, siege operations, and the like; as, to break ground for a foundation, a canal, or a railroad. Fig.: To begin to execute any plan. Naut To release the anchor from the bottom. To break the heart to crush or overwhelm (one) with grief. To break a house Law to remove or set aside with violence and a felonious intent any part of a house or of the fastenings provided to secure it. To break the ice to get through first difficulties; to overcome obstacles and make a beginning; to introduce a subject. To break jail to escape from confinement in jail, usually by forcible means. To break a jest to utter a jest. “Patroclus . . . the livelong day breaks scurril jests.” Shak. To break joints to lay or arrange bricks, shingles, etc., so that the joints in one course shall not coincide with those in the preceding course. To break a lance to engage in a tilt or contest. To break the neck to dislocate the joints of the neck. To break no squares to create no trouble. Obs
To break a path road, etc., to open a way through obstacles by force or labor. To break upon a wheel to execute or torture, as a criminal by stretching him upon a wheel, and breaking his limbs with an iron bar; -- a mode of punishment formerly employed in some countries. To break wind to give vent to wind from the anus.
entry.vmorph: imp. broke brōk, (Obs. Brake); p. p. Broken brō"k'n, (Obs. Broke); p. pr. & vb. n. Breaking
entry.ety: OE. breken, AS. brecan; akin to OS. brekan, D. breken, OHG. brehhan, G. brechen, Icel. braka to creak, Sw. braka bräkka to crack, Dan. brække to break, Goth. brikan to break, L. frangere. Cf. Bray to pound, Breach Fragile

sn.def: To strain apart; to sever by fracture; to divide with violence; as, to break a rope or chain; to break a seal; to break an axle; to break rocks or coal; to break a lock.
To lay open as by breaking; to divide; as, to break a package of goods.
To lay open, as a purpose; to disclose, divulge, or communicate.
sn.q: Katharine, break thy mind to me.

sn.def: To infringe or violate, as an obligation, law, or promise.
sn.q: Out, out, hyena! these are thy wonted arts . . . To break all faith, all vows, deceive, betray.

sn.def: To interrupt; to destroy the continuity of; to dissolve or terminate; as, to break silence; to break one's sleep; to break one's journey.
sn.q: Go, release them, Ariel; My charms I'll break, their senses I'll restore.

sn.def: To destroy the completeness of; to remove a part from; as, to break a set.
To destroy the arrangement of; to throw into disorder; to pierce; as, the cavalry were not able to break the British squares.
To shatter to pieces; to reduce to fragments.
sn.q: The victim broke in pieces the musical instruments with which he had solaced the hours of captivity.

sn.def: To exchange for other money or currency of smaller denomination; as, to break a five dollar bill.
To destroy the strength, firmness, or consistency of; as, to break flax.
To weaken or impair, as health, spirit, or mind.
sn.q: An old man, broken with the storms of state.

sn.def: To diminish the force of; to lessen the shock of, as a fall or blow.
sn.q: I'll rather leap down first, and break your fall.

sn.def: To impart, as news or information; to broach; -- with to, and often with a modified word implying some reserve; as, to break the news gently to the widow; to break a purpose cautiously to a friend.
To tame; to reduce to subjection; to make tractable; to discipline; as, to break a horse to the harness or saddle.
sn.q: Tobreaka colt.
Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?

sn.def: To destroy the financial credit of; to make bankrupt; to ruin.
sn.q: With arts like these rich Matho, when he speaks, Attracts all fees, and little lawyers breaks.

sn.def: To destroy the official character and standing of; to cashier; to dismiss.
sn.q: I see a great officer broken.
sn.syn: To dispart; rend; tear; shatter; batter; violate; infringe; demolish; destroy; burst; dislocate.

entry.note: With prepositions or adverbs: -

cs.cd: to disengage one's self abruptly; to come or go away against resistance.

entry.cs:
To break down. To come down by breaking; as, the coach broke down . To fail in any undertaking; to halt before successful completion; as, the negotiations broke down due to irreconcilable demands. To cease functioning or to malfunction; as, the car broke down in the middle of the highway. He had broken down almost at the outset. Thackeray. To break forth to issue; to come out suddenly, as sound, light, etc. “Then shall thy light break forth as the morning.” Isa. lviii. 8; often with into in expressing or giving vent to one's feelings. “Break forth into singing, ye mountains.” Isa. xliv. 23.
To break from to go away from abruptly. This radiant from the circling crowd he broke. Dryden. To break into to enter by breaking; as, to break into a house. To break in upon to enter or approach violently or unexpectedly. “This, this is he; softly awhile; let us not break in upon him.” Milton. To break loose. To extricate one's self forcibly. “Who would not, finding way, break loose from hell?” Milton. To cast off restraint, as of morals or propriety. To break off. To become separated by rupture, or with suddenness and violence. To desist or cease suddenly. “Nay, forward, old man; do not break off so.” Shak. To break off from to desist from; to abandon, as a habit. To break out. To burst forth; to escape from restraint; to appear suddenly, as a fire or an epidemic. “For in the wilderness shall waters break out, and stream in the desert.” Isa. xxxv. 6 To show itself in cutaneous eruptions; -- said of a disease. To have a rash or eruption on the akin; -- said of a patient. To break over to overflow; to go beyond limits. To break up. To become separated into parts or fragments; as, the ice break up in the rivers; the wreck will break up in the next storm. To disperse. “The company breaks up.” I. Watts. To break upon to discover itself suddenly to; to dawn upon. To break with. To fall out; to sever one's relations with; to part friendship. “It can not be the Volsces dare break with us.” Shak. “If she did not intend to marry Clive, she should have broken with him altogether.” Thackeray. To come to an explanation; to enter into conference; to speak. Obs “I will break with her and with her father.” Shak.

sn.def: To come apart or divide into two or more pieces, usually with suddenness and violence; to part; to burst asunder.
To open spontaneously, or by pressure from within, as a bubble, a tumor, a seed vessel, a bag.
sn.q: Else the bottle break, and the wine runneth out.

sn.def: To burst forth; to make its way; to come to view; to appear; to dawn.
sn.q: The day begins to break, and night is fled.
And from the turf a fountain broke, and gurgled at our feet.

sn.def: To burst forth violently, as a storm.
sn.q: The clouds are still above; and, while I speak, A second deluge o'er our head may break.

sn.def: To open up; to be scattered; to be dissipated; as, the clouds are breaking .
sn.q: At length the darkness begins to break.

sn.def: To become weakened in constitution or faculties; to lose health or strength.
sn.q: See how the dean begins to break; Poor gentleman! he droops apace.

sn.def: To be crushed, or overwhelmed with sorrow or grief; as, my heart is breaking .
To fall in business; to become bankrupt.
sn.q: He that puts all upon adventures doth oftentimes break, and come to poverty.

sn.def: To make an abrupt or sudden change; to change the gait; as, to break into a run or gallop.

To fail in musical quality; as, a singer's voice breaks when it is strained beyond its compass and a tone or note is not completed, but degenerates into an unmusical sound instead. Also, to change in tone, as a boy's voice at puberty.
To fall out; to terminate friendship.
sn.q: To break upon the score of danger or expense is to be mean and narrow-spirited.
Fear me not, man; I will not break away.

entry.ety: See Break v. t., and cf. Brakethe instrument), Breach Brack a crack

sn.def: An opening made by fracture or disruption.
An interruption of continuity; change of direction; as, a break in a wall; a break in the deck of a ship.

sd.def: A projection or recess from the face of a building.
An opening or displacement in the circuit, interrupting the electrical current.

sn.def: An interruption; a pause; as, a break in friendship; a break in the conversation.
An interruption in continuity in writing or printing, as where there is an omission, an unfilled line, etc.
sn.q: All modern trash is Set forth with numerous breaks and dashes.

sn.def: The first appearing, as of light in the morning; the dawn; as, the break of day; the break of dawn.
A large four-wheeled carriage, having a straight body and calash top, with the driver's seat in front and the footman's behind.
A device for checking motion, or for measuring friction. See Brake n. 9 & 10.
See Commutator.

entry.def: the quality of being easily damaged or destroyed.
Capable of being broken.

sn.def: The act of breaking; a break; a breaking; also, articles broken.
An allowance or compensation for things broken accidentally, as in transportation or use.

entry.ety: Break + away

sn.def: A wild rush of sheep, cattle, horses, or camels (especially at the smell or the sight of water); a stampede.
An animal that breaks away from a herd.
an object designed to break off or shatter under impact, as a safety measure.
the sudden emergence of one or more players or contestants from a clustered group, rushing toward a goal, as bicyclists in a race, or baketball players after a rebound has been caught.

entry.def: a West Indian timber tree (Sloanea jamaicensis) having very hard wood.

entries.entry: Break"bone` fe`ver. Med See Dengue.

entry.def: A key or other device for breaking an electrical circuit.

a type of solo dancing in which the dancer performs elaborate footwork, pantomime, and various acrobatic movements, such as spinning head stands or spinning on the back, and usually containing much improvization. It was first performed by male teenagers in the 1970's, in small informal groups on the streets, and is often performed to the accompaniment of rap music or other rock music with a rapid, strong beat.

sn.def: The act or result of breaking down, as of a carriage; downfall.

sd.def: A noisy, rapid, shuffling dance engaged in competitively by a number of persons or pairs in succession, as among the colored people of the Southern United States, and so called, perhaps, because the exercise is continued until most of those who take part in it break down.
Any rude, noisy dance performed by shuffling the feet, usually by one person at a time.
sd.q: Don't clear out when the quadrilles are over, for we are going to have a breakdown to wind up with.

sn.def: One who, or that which, breaks.
sn.q: I'll be no breaker of the law.

sn.def: Specifically: A machine for breaking rocks, or for breaking coal at the mines; also, the building in which such a machine is placed.
A small water cask.
A wave breaking into foam against the shore, or against a sand bank, or a rock or reef near the surface.
sn.q: The breakers were right beneath her bows.

sn.def: a quarry worker who splits off blocks of stone.

entry.ety: Break + fast

sn.def: The first meal in the day, or that which is eaten at the first meal.
sn.q: A sorry breakfast for my lord protector.

sn.def: A meal after fasting, or food in general.
sn.q: The wolves will get a breakfast by my death.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. breakfasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Breakfasting
entry.def: To break one's fast in the morning; too eat the first meal in the day.
entry.q: First, sir, I read, and then I breakfast.

entry.def: To furnish with breakfast.
an act of trespassing into a closed structure such as a house or place of busineess for an unlawful purpose, usually as part of a burglary.

sn.def: p. pr. & vb. n. of break v. i.
Still happening or becoming known at the present time; -- used of news reports; as, breaking news; a breaking story.

entry.def: The act of breaking something.
See Brakeman.

sn.def: A fall that breaks the neck.
A steep place endangering the neck.

entry.def: Producing danger of a broken neck; as, breakneck speed.

sn.def: Any of various plants of the genus Saxifraga.
a productive insight.
a sudden change of situation, such as making an important discovery, that permits further rapid advances toward a goal.
a penetration of an enemy's defense in depth and strength.

entry.def: Disruption; coming apart; a separation and dispersion of the parts or members; as, a break-up of a meeting, assembly, or dinner party; the break-up of a spacecraft on re-entry into the atmosphere.

sn.def: the termination of a relationship; a break-up of the government; the break-up of a marriage; the break-up of a business partnership; the break-up of a comedy team.

entry.def: Any structure or contrivance, as a mole, or a wall at the mouth of a harbor, to break the force of waves, and afford protection from their violence.

entry.ety: OE. breme brem, F. brême, OF. bresme, of German origin; cf. OHG. brahsema brahsina, OLG. bressemo, G. brassen. Cf. Brasse

sn.def: A European fresh-water cyprinoid fish of the genus Abramis, little valued as food. Several species are known.
An American fresh-water fish, of various species of Pomotis and allied genera, which are also called sunfishes and pondfishes. See Pondfish.
A marine sparoid fish of the genus Pagellus, and allied genera. See Sea Bream.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Breamed; p. pr. & vb. n. Breaming
entry.ety: Cf. Broom, and G. ein schiff brennen
entry.def: To clean, as a ship's bottom of adherent shells, seaweed, etc., by the application of fire and scraping.

entry.cs: Breast drill a portable drilling machine, provided with a breastplate, for forcing the drill against the work. Breast pang. See Angina pectoris, under Angina. To make a clean breast to disclose the secrets which weigh upon one; to make full confession.
entry.ety: OE. brest breost, As. breóst; akin to Icel. brjōst, Sw. bröst, Dan. bryst, Goth. brusts, OS. briost, D. borst, G. brust

sn.def: The fore part of the body, between the neck and the belly; the chest; as, the breast of a man or of a horse.

Either one of the protuberant glands, situated on the front of the chest or thorax in the female of man and of some other mammalia, in which milk is secreted for the nourishment of the young; a mamma; a teat.
sn.q: My brother, that sucked the breasts of my mother.

sn.def: Anything resembling the human breast, or bosom; the front or forward part of anything; as, a chimney breast; a plow breast; the breast of a hill.
sn.q: Mountains on whose barren breast The laboring clouds do often rest.

sd.def: The face of a coal working.
The front of a furnace.

sn.def: The seat of consciousness; the repository of thought and self-consciousness, or of secrets; the seat of the affections and passions; the heart.
sn.q: He has a loyal breast.

sn.def: The power of singing; a musical voice; -- so called, probably, from the connection of the voice with the lungs, which lie within the breast.
sn.q: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast.

cs.cd: to cut the face of it on one side so as to lay bare the principal upright stems of the plants.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Breasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Breasting
entry.def: To meet, with the breast; to struggle with or oppose manfully; as, to breast the storm or waves.
entry.q: The court breasted the popular current by sustaining the demurrer.

entry.def: A band for the breast. Specifically: Naut A band of canvas, or a rope, fastened at both ends to the rigging, to support the man who heaves the lead in sounding.
The front transverse beam of a locomotive.
The bone of the breast; the sternum.
Deep as from the breast to the feet; as high as the breast.
entry.q: Set him breast-deep in earth, and famish him.

entry.def: Having a breast; -- used in composition with qualifying words, in either a literal or a metaphorical sense; as, a single-breasted coat.
entry.q: The close minister is buttoned up, and the brave officer open-breasted, on these occasions.

entry.def: A large rope to fasten the midship part of a ship to a wharf, or to another vessel.
The interior slope of a fortification, against which the garrison lean in firing.
High as the breast.
A thick piece of timber in the form of a knee, placed across the stem of a ship to strengthen the fore part and unite the bows on each side.

The curved channel in which a breast wheel turns. It is closely adapted to the curve of the wheel through about a quarter of its circumference, and prevents the escape of the water until it has spent its force upon the wheel. See Breast wheel.
A knot of ribbons worn on the breast.
A pin worn on the breast for a fastening, or for ornament; a brooch.

sn.def: A plate of metal covering the breast as defensive armor.
sn.q: Before his old rusty breastplate could be scoured, and his cracked headpiece mended.

sn.def: A piece against which the workman presses his breast in operating a breast drill, or other similar tool.
A strap that runs across a horse's breast.

A part of the vestment of the high priest, worn upon the front of the ephod. It was a double piece of richly embroidered stuff, a span square, set with twelve precious stones, on which were engraved the names of the twelve tribes of Israel. See Ephod.

entry.def: A kind of plow, driven by the breast of the workman; -- used to cut or pare turf.
The upper rail of any parapet of ordinary height, as of a balcony; the railing of a quarter-deck, etc.
See Breastband.
A summer or girder extending across a building flush with, and supporting, the upper part of a front or external wall; a long lintel; a girder; -- used principally above shop windows.

A water wheel, on which the stream of water strikes neither so high as in the overshot wheel, nor so low as in the undershot, but generally at about half the height of the wheel, being kept in contact with it by the breasting. The water acts on the float boards partly by impulse, partly by its weight.

sn.def: A defensive work of moderate height, hastily thrown up, of earth or other material.
A railing on the quarter-deck and forecastle.

cs.cd: breathless, exhausted; breathing with difficulty.
in low tones.

entry.ety: OE. breth breeth, AS. brǣð odor, scent, breath; cf. OHG. brādam steam, vapor, breath, G. brodem, and possibly E. Brawn, and Breed

sn.def: The air inhaled and exhaled in respiration; air which, in the process of respiration, has parted with oxygen and has received carbonic acid, aqueous vapor, warmth, etc.
sn.q: Melted as breath into the wind.

sn.def: The act of breathing naturally or freely; the power or capacity to breathe freely; as, I am out of breath .
The power of respiration, and hence, life.
sn.q: Thou takest away their breath, they die.

sn.def: Time to breathe; respite; pause.
sn.q: Give me some breath, some little pause.

sn.def: A single respiration, or the time of making it; a single act; an instant.
sn.q: He smiles and he frowns in a breath.

sn.def: Fig.: That which gives or strengthens life.
sn.q: The earthquake voice of victory, To thee the breath of life.

sn.def: A single word; the slightest effort; a trifle.
sn.q: A breath can make them, as a breath has made.

sn.def: A very slight breeze; air in gentle motion.
sn.q: Calm and unruffled as a summer's sea, when not a breath of wind flies o'er its surface.

sn.def: Fragrance; exhalation; odor; perfume.
sn.q: The breath of flowers.

sn.def: Gentle exercise, causing a quicker respiration.
sn.q: An after dinner's breath.

entry.def: Such as can be breathed.
State of being breathable.
to test the alcohol content of someone's blood by means of a breathalyzer.

entry.ety: a Trademark
entry.def: a device that measures alcohol content of a person's breath.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Breathed brē�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Breathing
entry.ety: From Breath

sn.def: To respire; to inhale and exhale air; hence;, to live.
sn.q: I am in health, Ibreathe.

q.au: Sir W. Scott [The Lay of the Last Minstrel].

sn.q: Breathes there a man with soul so dead Who never to himself hath said, This is my own, my native land!

sn.def: To take breath; to rest from action.
sn.q: Well! breathe awhile, and then to it again!

sn.def: To pass like breath; noiselessly or gently; to exhale; to emanate; to blow gently.
sn.q: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
There breathes a living fragrance from the shore.

cs.cd: to take breath; to feel a sense of relief, as from danger, responsibility, or press of business.
to die; to expire.
to open a vein; to let blood.

sn.def: To inhale and exhale in the process of respiration; to respire.
sn.q: To view the light of heaven, and breathe the vital air.

sn.def: To inject by breathing; to infuse; -- with into.
sn.q: Able to breathe life into a stone.
And the Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life.

sn.def: To emit or utter by the breath; to utter softly; to whisper; as, to breathe a vow.
sn.q: He softly breathed thy name.
Or let the church, our mother, breathe her curse, A mother's curse, on her revolting son.

sn.def: To exhale; to emit, as breath; as, the flowers breathe odors or perfumes.
To express; to manifest; to give forth.
sn.q: Others articles breathe the same severe spirit.

sn.def: To act upon by the breath; to cause to sound by breathing.
sn.q: Theybreathethe flute.

sn.def: To promote free respiration in; to exercise.
sn.q: And every man should beat thee. I think thou wast created for men to breathe themselves upon thee.

sn.def: To suffer to take breath, or recover the natural breathing; to rest; as, to breathe a horse.
sn.q: A moment breathed his panting steed.

sn.def: To put out of breath; to exhaust.
sn.q: Mr. Tulkinghorn arrives in his turret room, a little breathed by the journey up.

sn.def: To utter without vocality, as the nonvocal consonants.
sn.q: The same sound may be pronounces either breathed, voiced, or whispered.
Breathed elements, being already voiceless, remain unchanged in whispering.

entry.def: having breath or breath as specified; usually used in combination; as, sweet-breathed .
uttered without voice.

sn.def: One who breathes.

sd.def: One who lives.
One who utters.
One who animates or inspires.

sn.def: That which puts one out of breath, as violent exercise.
a pause to catch one's breath, or for some other form of rest or refreshment; -- often used in the phrase to take a breather, i.e. to pause for refreshment.
a vent in a container to allow equalization of internal and external pressure.
an air intake pipe to provide air to machinery or people submerged or otherwise sealed off from the outside.

entry.def: Full of breath; full of odor; fragrant.

entry.cs:
Breathing place. A pause. “That cæsura, or breathing place, in the midst of the verse.” Sir P. Sidney. A vent. Breathing time pause; relaxation. Bp. Hall. Breathing while time sufficient for drawing breath; a short time. Shak. Rough breathing spiritus asper) (ʽ). See 2d Asper n.
Smooth breathing spiritus lenis), a mark (') indicating the absence of the sound of h, as in 'ie`naiienai).

sn.def: Respiration; the act of inhaling and exhaling air.
sn.q: Subject to a difficulty of breathing.

sn.def: Air in gentle motion.
Any gentle influence or operation; inspiration; as, the breathings of the Spirit.
Aspiration; secret prayer.
sn.q: Earnest desires andbreathingsafter that blessed state.

sn.def: Exercising; promotion of respiration.
Utterance; communication or publicity by words.
sn.q: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose.

sn.def: Breathing place; vent.
Stop; pause; delay.
sn.q: You shake the head at so long a breathing.

sn.def: Also, in a wider sense, the sound caused by the friction of the outgoing breath in the throat, mouth, etc., when the glottis is wide open; aspiration; the sound expressed by the letter h.
A mark to indicate aspiration or its absence. See Rough breathing Smooth breathing, below.
Spent with labor or violent action; out of breath.
Not breathing; holding the breath, on account of fear, expectation, or intense interest; attended with a holding of the breath; as, breathless attention.
sn.q: But breathless, as we grow when feeling most.

sn.def: Dead; as, a breathless body.

entry.def: In a breathless manner.
The state of being breathless or out of breath.

cs.cd: a breccia containing bones, usually fragmentary.
a breccia containing coins.

entry.ety: It., breach, pebble, fragments of stone, fr. F. brèche; of German origin. See Breach
entry.def: A rock composed of angular fragments either of the same mineral or of different minerals, etc., united by a cement, and commonly presenting a variety of colors.
Consisting of angular fragments cemented together; resembling breccia in appearance.
entry.q: The brecciated appearance of many specimens [of meteorites].

entry.cs: Bred out degenerated. “The strain of man's bred out into baboon and monkey.” Shak. Bred to arms. See under Arms. Well bred. Of a good family; having a good pedigree. “A gentleman well bred and of good name.” Shak. Obs., except as applied to domestic animals Well brought up, as shown in having good manners; cultivated; refined; polite.
entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Breed.
Breadth.

entry.ety: See Braid woven cord
entry.def: A braid.
entry.q: Half lapped in glowing gauze and golden brede.

entry.ety: See Breeches

sn.def: The lower part of the body behind; the buttocks.
Breeches.
The hinder part of anything; esp., the part of a cannon, or other firearm, behind the chamber.
The external angle of knee timber, the inside of which is called the throat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Breeched; p. pr. & vb. n. Breeching

sn.def: To put into, or clothe with, breeches.
sn.q: A great man . . . anxious to know whether the blacksmith's youngest boy was breeched.

sn.def: To cover as with breeches.
sn.q: Their daggers unmannerly breeched with gore.

sn.def: To fit or furnish with a breech; as, to breech a gun.
To whip on the breech.
sn.q: Had not a courteous serving man conveyed me away, whilst he went to fetch whips, I think, in my conscience, he would have breeched me.

sn.def: To fasten with breeching.

entries.entry: Breech action. The breech mechanism in breech-loading small arms and certain special guns, as automatic and machine guns; -- used frequently in referring to the method by which the movable barrels of breech-loading shotguns are locked, unlocked, or rotated to loading position.

entry.def: The movable piece which closes the breech of a breech-loading firearm, and resists the backward force of the discharge. It is withdrawn for the insertion of a cartridge, and closed again before the gun is fired.
A cloth worn around the breech.
covering for the loins.
dressed in trousers.

cs.cd: in the life-saving service, a pair of canvas breeches depending from an annular or beltlike life buoy which is usually of cork. This contrivance, inclosing the person to be rescued, is hung by short ropes from a block which runs upon the hawser stretched from the ship to the shore, and is drawn to land by hauling lines.
a forked pipe forming two branches united at one end.
breeches coming to the knee, and buckled or fastened there; smallclothes.
to usurp the authority of the husband; -- said of a wife.

entry.ety: OE. brech brek, AS. brēk, pl. of brōc breech, breeches; akin to Icel. brōk breeches, ODan. brog, D. broek, G. bruch; cf. L. bracae braccae, which is of Celtic origin. Cf. Brail

sn.def: A garment worn by men, covering the hips and thighs; smallclothes.
sn.q: His jacket was red, and his breeches were blue.

sn.def: Trousers; pantaloons.
A whipping on the breech, or the act of whipping on the breech.
sn.q: I view the prince with Aristarchus' eyes, Whose looks were as a breeching to a boy.

sn.def: That part of a harness which passes round the breech of a horse, enabling him to hold back a vehicle.
A strong rope rove through the cascabel of a cannon and secured to ringbolts in the ship's side, to limit the recoil of the gun when it is discharged.
The sheet iron casing at the end of boilers to convey the smoke from the flues to the smokestack.

entry.def: A firearm which receives its load at the breech.
entry.q: For cavalry, the revolver and breechloader will supersede the saber.

entry.def: Receiving the charge at the breech instead of at the muzzle.

entries.entry: Breech" pin` Breech" screw` . A strong iron or steel plug screwed into the breech of a musket or other firearm, to close the bottom of the bore.
Breech" sight`. A device attached to the breech of a firearm, to guide the eye, in conjunction with the front sight, in taking aim.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bred; p. pr. & vb. n. Breeding
entry.ety: OE. breden, AS. brēdan to nourish, cherish, keep warm, from brōd brood; akin to D. broeden to brood, OHG. bruoten, G. brüten. See Brood

sn.def: To produce as offspring; to bring forth; to bear; to procreate; to generate; to beget; to hatch.
sn.q: Yet every mother breeds not sons alike.
If the sun breed maggots in a dead dog.

sn.def: To take care of in infancy, and through the age of youth; to bring up; to nurse and foster.
sn.q: To bring thee forth with pain, with care to breed.
Born and bred on the verge of the wilderness.

sn.def: To educate; to instruct; to form by education; to train; -- sometimes followed by up.
sn.q: But no care was taken to breed him a Protestant.
His farm may not remove his children too far from him, or the trade he breeds them up in.

sn.def: To engender; to cause; to occasion; to originate; to produce; as, to breed a storm; to breed disease.
sn.q: Lest the place And my quaint habits breed astonishment.

sn.def: To give birth to; to be the native place of; as, a pond breeds fish; a northern country breeds stout men.
To raise, as any kind of stock.
To produce or obtain by any natural process.
sn.q: Children would breed their teeth with less danger.
sn.syn: To engender; generate; beget; produce; hatch; originate; bring up; nourish; train; instruct.

cs.cd: to breed from animals of the same stock that are closely related.

sn.def: To bear and nourish young; to reproduce or multiply itself; to be pregnant.
sn.q: That they breed abundantly in the earth.
The mother had never bred before.
Ant. Is your gold and silver ewes and rams?Shy. I can not tell. I make it breed as fast.

sn.def: To be formed in the parent or dam; to be generated, or to grow, as young before birth.
To have birth; to be produced or multiplied.
sn.q: Heavens rain grace On that which breeds between them.

sn.def: To raise a breed; to get progeny.
sn.q: The kind of animal which you wish to breed from.

entry.note: ☞ Breed is usually applied to domestic animals; species or variety to wild animals and to plants; and race to men.

sn.def: A race or variety of men or other animals (or of plants), perpetuating its special or distinctive characteristics by inheritance.
sn.q: Twice fifteen thousand hearts of England's breed.
Greyhounds of the best breed.

sn.def: Class; sort; kind; -- of men, things, or qualities.
sn.q: Are these the breed of wits so wondered at?
This courtesy is not of the right breed.

sn.def: A number produced at once; a brood.

entry.def: One who breeds or originates quarrels.
entry.q: No telltale nor nobreedbate.

sn.def: One who, or that which, breeds, produces, brings up, etc.
sn.q: She was a great breeder.
Italy and Rome have been the best breeders of worthy men.

sn.def: A cause.
sn.q: Thebreederof my sorrow.

cs.cd: breeding from a male and female from the same parentage.
breeding from a male and female of different lineage.
politeness; genteel deportment.

sn.def: The act or process of generating or bearing.
The raising or improving of any kind of domestic animals; as, farmers should pay attention to breeding .
Nurture; education; formation of manners.
sn.q: She had her breeding at my father's charge.

sn.def: Deportment or behavior in the external offices and decorums of social life; manners; knowledge of, or training in, the ceremonies, or polite observances of society.
sn.q: Delicacy of breeding, or that polite deference and respect which civility obliges us either to express or counterfeit towards the persons with whom we converse.

sn.def: Descent; pedigree; extraction.
sn.q: Honest gentlemen, I know not your breeding.
sn.syn: Education; instruction; nurture; training; manners. See Education.

entry.ety: OE. brese, AS. briósa; perh. akin to OHG. brimissa, G. breme bremse, D. brems, which are akin to G. brummen to growl, buzz, grumble, L. fremere to murmur; cf. G. brausen, Sw. brusa, Dan. bruse, to roar, rush
entry.def: A fly of various species, of the family Tabanidæ, noted for buzzing about animals, and tormenting them by sucking their blood; -- called also horsefly, and gadfly. They are among the largest of two-winged or dipterous insects. The name is also given to different species of botflies.

cs.cd: a wind blowing from the land, generally at night.
a breeze or wind blowing, generally in the daytime, from the sea.

entry.ety: F. brise; akin to It. brezza breeze, Sp. briza brisa, a breeze from northeast, Pg. briza northeast wind; of uncertain origin; cf. F. bise, Pr. bisa, OHG. bisa, north wind, Arm. biz northeast wind

sn.def: A light, gentle wind; a fresh, soft-blowing wind.
sn.q: Into a gradual calm the breezes sink.

sn.def: An excited or ruffed state of feeling; a flurry of excitement; a disturbance; a quarrel; as, the discovery produced a breeze .

entry.ety: F. braise cinders, live coals. See Brasier

sn.def: Refuse left in the process of making coke or burning charcoal.
Refuse coal, coal ashes, and cinders, used in the burning of bricks.

cs.cd: to blow with increasing freshness.

entry.def: To blow gently.
Motionless; destitute of breezes.
entry.q: A stagnant, breezeless air becalms my soul.

entry.def: State of being breezy.

sn.def: Characterized by, or having, breezes; airy.
sn.q: Abreezyday in May.
'Mid lawns and shades by breezy rivulets fanned.

sn.def: Fresh; brisk; full of life.

entry.ety: Gr. � the front part of the head: cf. F. bregma
entry.def: The point of junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures of the skull.
Pertaining to the bregma.

cs.cd: the ancient Irish laws, -- unwritten, like the common law of England. They were abolished by statute of Edward III.

entry.ety: Ir. breitheamh judge
entry.def: An ancient Irish or Scotch judge.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A French gambling game somewhat like poker.
In French games, a pair royal, or triplet.

entries.entry: Bre*lan" car`re" Bre*lan" car`re". F. carré square Card Playing In French games, a double pair royal.
Bre*lan" fa`vo`ri" Bre*lan" fa`vo`ri". F. favori favorite Card Playing In French games, a pair royal composed of 2 cards in the hand and the card turned.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A seal or charm for a watch chain.
entry.q: His chains andbreloques.

entry.ety: OE. breme brime, fierce, impetuous, glorious, AS. brēme brȳme, famous. Cf. Brim a.

sn.def: Fierce; sharp; severe; cruel.
sn.q: From the septentrion cold, in the breme freezing air.

sn.def: Famous; renowned; well known.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brent�); p. pr. & vb. n. Brenning
entry.ety: See Burn
entry.def: To burn.
entry.q: Consuming fire brent his shearing house or stall.

entry.def: Bran.

entry.ety: OF. brenage; cf. LL. brennagium brenagium. See Bran
entry.def: A tribute which tenants paid to their lord, in lieu of bran, which they were obliged to furnish for his hounds.
Burningly; ardently.

entry.ety: German: end of burning
entry.def: the time at which the engines of a rocket stop firing; the termination of the firing of the rocket engines, whether due to intentional shutdown of the engines or exhaustion of the fuel. This term was used mostly in the early days of rocketry when only one firing sequence occurred for rockets, which were used as ballistic missiles or for experiments in rocketry or atmospheric science.

entry.ety: AS. brant; akin to Dan. brat, Icel. brattr, steep

sn.def: Steep; high.
sn.q: Grapes grow on the brant rocks so wonderfully that ye will marvel how any man dare climb up to them.

sn.def: Smooth; unwrinkled.
sn.q: Your bonnie brow was brent.

entry.def: Burnt.

entry.ety: Cf. Brant
entry.def: A brant. See Brant.

entries.entry: Breq"uet chain`. A watch-guard.

entry.def: A brier.
for Bursteth.
A torus.

entry.vmorph: imp. Brast; p. p. Brusten Borsten Bursten
