See Breastsummer.
See Birt.

entry.ety: OE. also brerdful, fr. brerd top, brim, AS. brerd
entry.def: Brimful.

entries.entry: Breth"ren ☞ This form of the plural is used, for the most part, in solemn address, and in speaking of religious sects or fraternities, or their members. n.; pl. of Brother.

entry.ety: F. breton
entry.def: Of or relating to Brittany, or Bretagne, in France.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Brittany, or Bretagne, in France; also, the ancient language of Brittany; Armorican.

entry.def: Same as Britzska.

entries.entry:
Bret"tice n.; pl.Brettices. OE. bretasce bretage, parapet, OF. bretesche wooden tower, F. bretèche, LL. breteschia bertresca, prob. fr. OHG. bret, G. brett board; akin to E. board. See Board n., and cf. Bartizan
The wooden boarding used in supporting the roofs and walls of coal mines. See Brattice.

entry.ety: AS. Bretwalda br�ten walda, a powerful ruler
entry.def: The official title applied to that one of the Anglo-Saxon chieftains who was chosen by the other chiefs to lead them in their warfare against the British tribes.

entry.ety: G
entry.def: See Pretzel.

entry.ety: It. & (in sense 2) LL. breve, fr. L. brevis short. See Brief

sn.def: A note or character of time, equivalent to two semibreves or four minims. When dotted, it is equal to three semibreves. It was formerly of a square figure (as thus: � ), but is now made oval, with a line perpendicular to the staff on each of its sides; -- formerly much used for choir service.
Any writ or precept under seal, issued out of any court.
A curved mark [˘] used commonly to indicate the short quantity of a vowel.
The great ant thrush of Sumatra (Pitta gigas), which has a very short tail.

entry.note: ☞ In the United States army, rank by brevet is conferred, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, for “gallant actions or meritorious services.” A brevet rank gives no right of command in the particular corps to which the officer brevetted belongs, and can be exercised only by special assignment of the President, or on court martial, and detachments composed of different corps, with pay of the brevet rank when on such duty.
entry.ety: F. brevet, LL. brevetum, fr. L. brevis short. See Brief

sn.def: A warrant from the government, granting a privilege, title, or dignity. French usage.
A commission giving an officer higher rank than that for which he receives pay; an honorary promotion of an officer.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brevetted; p. pr. & vb. n. Brevetting
entry.def: To confer rank upon by brevet.
Taking or conferring rank by brevet; as, a brevet colonel; a brevet commission.

entries.entry: Bre*vet"cy br�*vĕt"s� n.; pl.Brevetcies -sĭz. Mil The rank or condition of a brevet officer.

Bre"vi*a*ry n.; pl.Breviaries. F. bréviarie, L. breviarium summary, abridgment, neut. noun fr. breviarius abridged, fr. brevis short. See Brief, and cf. Brevier
An abridgment; a compend; an epitome; a brief account or summary. A book entitled the abridgment or breviary of those roots that are to be cut up or gathered.
A book containing the daily public or canonical prayers of the Roman Catholic or of the Greek Church for the seven canonical hours, namely, matins and lauds, the first, third, sixth, and ninth hours, vespers, and compline; -- distinguished from the missal.

entry.ety: L. breviatus, p. p. of breviare to shorten, brevis short

sn.def: A short compend; a summary; a brief statement.
sn.q: I omit in this breviate to rehearse.
The same little breviates of infidelity have . . . been published and dispersed with great activity.

sn.def: A lawyer's brief.

entry.def: To abbreviate.
An abbreviature; an abbreviation.

entry.note: ☞ This line is printed in brevier type.
entry.ety: Prob. from being originally used in printing a breviary. See Breviary
entry.def: A size of type between bourgeois and minion.

entry.ety: L. breviloquentia
entry.def: A brief and pertinent mode of speaking.

entry.ety: L. brevis short + pes pedis, foot: cf. F. brévipède
entry.def: Having short legs.

def2.def: A breviped bird.

entry.ety: L. brevis short + penna wing: cf. F. brévipenne
entry.def: A brevipennate bird.

entry.ety: L. brevis short + E. pennate
entry.def: Short-winged; -- applied to birds which can not fly, owing to their short wings, as the ostrich, cassowary, and emu.

entry.ety: L. brevis short + E. rostral rostrate
entry.def: Short-billed; having a short beak.

entries.entry:
Brev"i*ty n.; pl.Brevities. L. brevitas, fr. brevis short: cf. F. brièvité. See Brief
Shortness of duration; briefness of time; as, the brevity of human life.
Contraction into few words; conciseness.
Brevity is the soul of wit. This argument is stated by St. John with his usual elegant brevity and simplicity. Shortness; conciseness; succinctness; terseness.

entry.def: a genus of fishes consisting of the menhaden.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brewed brṳd; p. pr. & vb. n. Brewing
entry.ety: OE. brewen, AS. breówan; akin to D. brouwen, OHG. priuwan, MHG. briuwen brūwen, G. brauen, Icel. brugga, Sw. brygga, Dan. brygge, and perh. to L. defrutum must boiled down, Gr. bry^tonfor fry^ton?) a kind of beer. The original meaning seems to have been to prepare by heat. √93. Cf. Broth Bread

sn.def: To boil or seethe; to cook.
To prepare, as beer or other liquor, from malt and hops, or from other materials, by steeping, boiling, and fermentation.
sn.q: Shebrewsgood ale.

sn.def: To prepare by steeping and mingling; to concoct.
sn.q: Go, brew me a pottle of sack finely.

sn.def: To foment or prepare, as by brewing; to contrive; to plot; to concoct; to hatch; as, to brew mischief.
sn.q: Hence with thy brewed enchantments, foul deceiver!

sn.def: To attend to the business, or go through the processes, of brewing or making beer.
sn.q: I wash, wring, brew, bake, scour.

sn.def: To be in a state of preparation; to be mixing, forming, or gathering; as, a storm brews in the west.
sn.q: There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest.

entry.def: The mixture formed by brewing; that which is brewed.
Malt liquor; drink brewed.
entry.q: Some well-spicedbrewage.
A rich brewage, made of the best Spanish wine.

entry.def: One who brews; one whose occupation is to prepare malt liquors.
A brewhouse; the building and apparatus where brewing is carried on.
A house or building appropriated to brewing; a brewery.

sn.def: The act or process of preparing liquors which are brewed, as beer and ale.
The quantity brewed at once.
sn.q: A brewing of new beer, set by old beer.

sn.def: A mixing together.
sn.q: I am not able to avouch anything for certainty, such a brewing and sophistication of them they make.

sn.def: A gathering or forming of a storm or squall, indicated by thick, dark clouds.

entry.ety: OE. brewis brouwys browesse brewet, OF. brouet -s being the OF. ending of the nom. sing. and acc. pl.; dim. of OHG. brod. √93. See Broth, and cf. Brose

sn.def: Broth or pottage.
sn.q: Let them of their Bonner's “beef” and “broth” make what brewis they please for their credulous guests.

sn.def: Bread soaked in broth, drippings of roast meat, milk, or water and butter.

entry.ety: Named after Sir David Brewster
entry.def: A rare zeolitic mineral occurring in white monoclinic crystals with pearly luster. It is a hydrous silicate of aluminia, baryta, and strontia.
See Brazilin.
Same as Brier.
an old French breed of large strong usually black dogs having a long tail and long wavy and slightly stiff coat.

entry.ety: L. Briareius, fr. Briareus a mythological hundred-handed giant, Gr. �, fr. � strong
entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, Briareus, a giant fabled to have a hundred hands; hence, hundred-handed or many-handed.
the hard woody root of the briar Erica arborea.
wood from the hard woody root of the briar Erica arborea; used to make tobacco pipes.

sn.def: having or covered with protective barbs or quills or spines or thorns etc.; -- of plants or animals.
sn.syn: barbed, barbellate, briery, bristly, burred, burry, prickly, spiny, thorny.

entry.def: Capable of being bribed.
entry.q: A more bribable class of electors.

entry.ety: F. bribe a lump of bread, scraps, leavings of meals (that are generally given to a beggar), LL. briba scrap of bread; cf. OF. briber brifer, to eat gluttonously, to beg, and OHG. bilibi food

sn.def: A gift begged; a present.
A price, reward, gift, or favor bestowed or promised with a view to prevent the judgment or corrupt the conduct of a judge, witness, voter, or other person in a position of trust.
sn.q: Undue reward for anything against justice is a bribe.

sn.def: That which seduces; seduction; allurement.
sn.q: Not the bribes of sordid wealth can seduce to leave these ever�blooming sweets.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bribed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bribing

sn.def: To rob or steal.

To give or promise a reward or consideration to (a judge, juror, legislator, voter, or other person in a position of trust) with a view to prevent the judgment or corrupt the conduct; to induce or influence by a bribe; to give a bribe to.
sn.q: Neither is he worthy who bribes a man to vote against his conscience.

sn.def: To gain by a bribe; of induce as by a bribe.
To commit robbery or theft.
To give a bribe to a person; to pervert the judgment or corrupt the action of a person in a position of trust, by some gift or promise.
sn.q: An attempt to bribe, though unsuccessful, has been holden to be criminal, and the offender may be indicted.
The bard may supplicate, but cannot bribe.

entry.def: Incapable of being bribed; free from bribes.
entry.q: From thence to heaven's bribeless hall.

sn.def: A thief.
One who bribes, or pays for corrupt practices.
That which bribes; a bribe.
sn.q: His service . . . were a sufficient briber for his life.

entries.entry:
Brib"er*y
Bribery oath an oath taken by a person that he has not been bribed as to voting. Eng
n.; pl.Briberies. OE. brybery rascality, OF. briberie. See Bribe n.
Robbery; extortion. Obs
The act or practice of giving or taking bribes; the act of influencing the official or political action of another by corrupt inducements.

cs.cd: any curious or antique article of virtu, as a piece of antiquated furniture or metal work, or an odd knickknack.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Miscellaneous curiosities and works of decorative art, considered collectively.

cs.col: To have a brick in one's hat
cs.cd: to be drunk.

entry.note: ☞ Brick is used adjectively or in combination; as, brick wall; brick clay; brick color; brick red.
entry.cs: Brick clay clay suitable for, or used in making, bricks. Brick dust dust of pounded or broken bricks. Brick earth clay or earth suitable for, or used in making, bricks. Brick loaf a loaf of bread somewhat resembling a brick in shape. Brick nogging Arch rough brickwork used to fill in the spaces between the uprights of a wooden partition; brick filling. Brick tea tea leaves and young shoots, or refuse tea, steamed or mixed with fat, etc., and pressed into the form of bricks. It is used in Northern and Central Asia. S. W. Williams. Brick trimmer Arch a brick arch under a hearth, usually within the thickness of a wooden floor, to guard against accidents by fire. Brick trowel. See Trowel. Brick works a place where bricks are made. Bath brick. See under Bath, a city. Pressed brick bricks which, before burning, have been subjected to pressure, to free them from the imperfections of shape and texture which are common in molded bricks.
entry.ety: OE. brik, F. brique; of Ger. origin; cf. AS. brice a breaking, fragment, Prov. E. brique piece, brique de pain, equiv. to AS. hlāfes brice, fr. the root of E. break. See Break

sn.def: A block or clay tempered with water, sand, etc., molded into a regular form, usually rectangular, and sun-dried, or burnt in a kiln, or in a heap or stack called a clamp.
sn.q: The Assyrians appear to have made much less use of bricks baked in the furnace than the Babylonians.

sn.def: Bricks, collectively, as designating that kind of material; as, a load of brick; a thousand of brick .
sn.q: Some of Palladio's finest examples are of brick.

sn.def: Any oblong rectangular mass; as, a brick of maple sugar; a penny brickof bread.
A good fellow; a merry person; as, you 're a brick .
sn.q: He 's a dear littlebrick.

cs.cd: to fill up, inclose, or line, with brick.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bricked; p. pr. & vb. n. Bricking

sn.def: To lay or pave with bricks; to surround, line, or construct with bricks.
To imitate or counterfeit a brick wall on, as by smearing plaster with red ocher, making the joints with an edge tool, and pointing them.

entry.def: A piece or fragment of a brick. See 1st Bat n. 4.
genus of herbs of SW America having usually creamy florets followed by one-seeded fruits in a prominent bristly sheath.
a place where bricks are made and sold.

sn.def: Orig., at Sydney, a cold and violent south or southwest wind, rising suddenly, and regularly preceded by a hot wind from the north; -- now usually called southerly buster. It blew across the Brickfields, formerly so called, a district of Sydney, and carried clouds of dust into the city.
By confusion, a midsummer hot wind from the north.

entry.def: A kiln, or furnace, in which bricks are baked or burnt; or a pile of green bricks, laid loose, with arches underneath to receive the wood or fuel for burning them.

entry.cs: Bricklayer's itch. See under Itch.
entry.ety: Brick + lay
entry.def: One whose occupation is to build with bricks.
The art of building with bricks, or of uniting them by cement or mortar into various forms; the act or occupation of laying bricks.

entry.ety: OE. brekil brokel bruchel, fr. AS. brecan, E. break. Cf. Brittle
entry.def: Brittle; easily broken.
entry.q: As stubborn steel excels the brickle glass.

entry.def: Brittleness.
One whose occupation is to make bricks.

sn.def: Anything made of bricks.
sn.q: Niches in brickwork form the most difficult part of the bricklayer's art.

sn.def: The act of building with or laying bricks.

entry.def: Full of bricks; formed of bricks; resembling bricks or brick dust.
A place where bricks are made, especially an inclosed place.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A kind of traces with hooks and rings, with which men drag and maneuver guns where horses can not be used.

sn.def: An ancient kind of military catapult.
In court tennis, the rebound of a ball from a wall of the court; also, the side stroke or play by which the ball is driven against the wall; hence, fig., indirect action or stroke.
A shot in which the cue ball is driven first against the cushion.

entry.def: A bird.

entry.ety: From Bride. Cf. Bridal n.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a bride, or to wedding; nuptial; as, bridal ornaments; a bridal outfit; a bridal chamber.

entry.ety: OE. bridale brudale, AS. brȳdealo brideale, bridal feast. See Bride, and Ale, 2
entry.def: A nuptial festival or ceremony; a marriage.
entry.q: Sweet day, so cool, so calm, so bright, The bridal of the earth and sky.

entry.def: Celebration of the nuptial feast.
entry.q: In honor of thisbridalty.

entry.def: a shrub (Spiraea prunifolia) having copious small white flowers in spring.
entry.syn: bridal wreath, Saint Peter's wreath, St. Peter's wreath.

cs.cd: the city of Venice.

entry.ety: OE. bride brid brude brud burd, AS. brȳd; akin to OFries. breid, OSax. brūd, D. bruid, OHG. prūt brūt, G. braut, Icel. brūðr, Sw. & Dan. brud, Goth. brūþs; cf. Armor. pried spouse, W. priawd a married person

sn.def: A woman newly married, or about to be married.
sn.q: Has by his own experience tried How much the wife is dearer than the bride.
I will show thee the bride, the Lamb's wife.

sn.def: Fig.: An object ardently loved.

entry.def: To make a bride of.

entry.ety: See Bridal
entry.def: A rustic wedding feast; a bridal. See Ale.
entry.q: The man that 's bid to bride-ale, if he ha' cake, And drink enough, he need not fear his stake.

entry.def: The marriage bed.
Rich or highly ornamented cake, to be distributed to the guests at a wedding, or sent to friends after the wedding.
The nuptial apartment.

entry.ety: OE. bridegome brudgume, AS. brȳdgumaakin to OS. brūdigumo, D. bruidegom bruigom, OHG. prūtigomo, MHG. briutegome, G. bräutigam); AS. brȳd bride + guma man, akin to Goth. guma, Icel. gumi, OHG. gomo, L. homo; the insertion of r being caused by confusion with groom. See Bride, and cf. Groom Homage
entry.def: A man newly married, or just about to be married.
A knot of ribbons worn by a guest at a wedding; a wedding favor.
See Bridesmaid Bridesman.
A female friend who attends on a bride at her wedding.

entries.entry: Brides"man n.; pl.Bridesmen. A male friend who attends upon a bridegroom and bride at their marriage; the “best man.”

entry.def: A stake or post set in the ground, for guests at a wedding to dance round.
entry.q: Divide the broad bridecake Round about the bridestake.

entry.def: A house of correction for the confinement of disorderly persons; -- so called from a hospital built in 1553 near St. Bride's (or Bridget's) well, in London, which was subsequently a penal workhouse.

entry.cs:
Aqueduct bridge. See Aqueduct.
Asses' bridge Bascule bridge Bateau bridge . See under Ass Bascule Bateau. Bridge of a steamer Naut a narrow platform across the deck, above the rail, for the convenience of the officer in charge of the ship; in paddlewheel vessels it connects the paddle boxes. Bridge of the nose the upper, bony part of the nose. Cantalever bridge. See under Cantalever. Draw bridge. See Drawbridge. Flying bridge a temporary bridge suspended or floating, as for the passage of armies; also, a floating structure connected by a cable with an anchor or pier up stream, and made to pass from bank to bank by the action of the current or other means.
Girder bridgeorTruss bridge
a bridge formed by girders, or by trusses resting upon abutments or piers. Lattice bridge a bridge formed by lattice girders.
Pontoon bridge Ponton bridge . See under Pontoon. Skew bridge a bridge built obliquely from bank to bank, as sometimes required in railway engineering. Suspension bridge. See under Suspension. Trestle bridge a bridge formed of a series of short, simple girders resting on trestles. Tubular bridge a bridge in the form of a hollow trunk or rectangular tube, with cellular walls made of iron plates riveted together, as the Britannia bridge over the Menai Strait, and the Victoria bridge at Montreal. Wheatstone's bridge Elec a device for the measurement of resistances, so called because the balance between the resistances to be measured is indicated by the absence of a current in a certain wire forming a bridge or connection between two points of the apparatus; -- invented by Sir Charles Wheatstone.
entry.ety: OE. brig brigge brug brugge, AS. brycg bricg; akin to Fries. bregge, D. brug, OHG. brucca, G. brücke, Icel. bryggja pier, bridge, Sw. brygga, Dan. brygge, and prob. Icel. brū bridge, Sw. & Dan. bro bridge, pavement, and possibly to E. brow

sn.def: A structure, usually of wood, stone, brick, or iron, erected over a river or other water course, or over a chasm, railroad, etc., to make a passageway from one bank to the other.

Anything supported at the ends, which serves to keep some other thing from resting upon the object spanned, as in engraving, watchmaking, etc., or which forms a platform or staging over which something passes or is conveyed.
The small arch or bar at right angles to the strings of a violin, guitar, etc., serving of raise them and transmit their vibrations to the body of the instrument.
A device to measure the resistance of a wire or other conductor forming part of an electric circuit.
A low wall or vertical partition in the fire chamber of a furnace, for deflecting flame, etc.; -- usually called a bridge wall.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bridged brĭjd; p. pr. & vb. n. Bridging

sn.def: To build a bridge or bridges on or over; as, to bridge a river.
sn.q: Their simple engineering bridged with felled trees the streams which could not be forded.

sn.def: To open or make a passage, as by a bridge.
sn.q: Xerxes . . . over HellespontBridging his way, Europe with Asia joined.

sn.def: To find a way of getting over, as a difficulty; -- generally with over.

entry.note: The trump, if any, is determined by the dealer or his partner, the value of each trick taken over six being: for “no trumps” 12, hearts 8, diamonds 6, clubs 4, spades 2. The opponents of the dealer can, after the trump is declared, double the value of the tricks, in which case the dealer or his partner can redouble, and so on. The dealer plays his partner's hand as a dummy. The side which first reaches or exceeds 30 points scored for tricks wins a game; the side which first wins two games wins a rubber. The total score for any side is the sum of the points scored for tricks, for rubbers (each of which counts 100), for honors (which follow a special schedule of value), and for slam little slam, and chicane.

☞ For contract bridge, the scoring system has adopted different values, with 100 points required for a game. The penalties for failing to make a contract also vary with the score thus far achieved by the playing team, and with the degree, if any, of doubling during the auction.
entry.def: A card game resembling whist.
capable of being connected by a bridge or as if by a bridge.

sn.def: A notched board to which the treads and risers of the steps of wooden stairs are fastened.
A board or plank used as a bridge.

entry.def: a circuit consisting of a T-network with an additional arm bridging the two series arms.
A fortification commanding the extremity of a bridge nearest the enemy, to insure the preservation and usefulness of the bridge, and prevent the enemy from crossing; a tête-de-pont.
Having no bridge; not bridged.
The adjustable socket, or step, of a millstone spindle.

entry.ety: Bridge + tree a beam
entry.def: The beam which supports the spindle socket of the runner in a grinding mill.

sn.def: A bridge keeper; a warden or a guard for a bridge.
The principal ward of a key.

entry.cs: Bridging joist. Same as Binding joist.
entry.def: The system of bracing used between floor or other timbers to distribute the weight.
Full of bridges.

entry.cs:
Bowline bridle. See under Bowline. Branches of a bridle. See under Branch. Bridle cable Naut a cable which is bent to a bridle. See 4, above. Bridle hand the hand which holds the bridle in riding; the left hand.
Bridle path Bridle way
a path or way for saddle horses and pack horses, as distinguished from a road for vehicles. Bridle port Naut a porthole or opening in the bow through which hawsers, mooring or bridle cables, etc., are passed. Bridle rein a rein attached to the bit. Bridle road. Same as Bridle path. Lowell. A road in a pleasure park reserved for horseback exercise. Bridle track a bridle path. Scolding bridle. See Branks, 2.
entry.ety: OE. bridel, AS. bridel; akin to OHG. britil brittil, D. breidel, and possibly to E. braid. Cf. Bridoon

sn.def: The head gear with which a horse is governed and restrained, consisting of a headstall, a bit, and reins, with other appendages.
A restraint; a curb; a check.
The piece in the interior of a gun lock, which holds in place the tumbler, sear, etc.

sd.def: A span of rope, line, or chain made fast as both ends, so that another rope, line, or chain may be attached to its middle.
A mooring hawser.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bridled; p. pr. & vb. n. Bridling

sn.def: To put a bridle upon; to equip with a bridle; as, to bridle a horse.
sn.q: He bridled her mouth with a silkweed twist.

sn.def: To restrain, guide, or govern, with, or as with, a bridle; to check, curb, or control; as, to bridle the passions; to bridle a muse.
sn.q: Savoy and Nice, the keys of Italy, and the citadel in her hands to bridle Switzerland, are in that consolidation.
sn.syn: To check; restrain; curb; govern; control; repress; master; subdue.

entry.def: To hold up the head, and draw in the chin, as an expression of pride, scorn, or resentment; to assume a lofty manner; -- usually with up.
entry.q: Hisbridlingneck.
By her bridling up I perceived she expected to be treated hereafter not as Jenny Distaff, but Mrs. Tranquillus.

entries.entry: Bri"dle i`ron. Arch A strong flat bar of iron, so bent as to support, as in a stirrup, one end of a floor timber, etc., where no sufficient bearing can be had; -- called also stirrup and hanger.

entry.def: One who bridles; one who restrains and governs, as with a bridle.

entry.ety: F. bridon, from bride; of German origin. See Bridle n.
entry.def: The snaffle and rein of a military bridle, which acts independently of the bit, at the pleasure of the rider. It is used in connection with a curb bit, which has its own rein.
same as Brie cheese.

entries.entry: Brie" cheese` brē" chēz`. A kind of soft French cream cheese; -- so called from the district in France where it is made; it is milder than Camembert; -- called also fromage de Brie Brie and brieuncapitalized).

entry.cs: In brief. See under Brief n.
entry.ety: OE. bref, F. brief bref, fr. L. brevis; akin to Gr. brachy`s short, and perh. to Skr. barh to tear. Cf. Breve

sn.def: Short in duration.
sn.q: How brief the life of man.

sn.def: Concise; terse; succinct.
sn.q: The brief style is that which expresseth much in little.

sn.def: Rife; common; prevalent.
sn.syn: Short; concise; succinct; summary; compendious; condensed; terse; curt; transitory; short-lived.

sn.def: Briefly.
sn.q: Adam, faltering long, thus answered brief.

sn.def: Soon; quickly.

entry.note: ☞ In England, the brief is prepared by the attorney; in the United States, counsel generally make up their own briefs.
entry.cs: Apostolical brief a letter of the pope written on fine parchment in modern characters, subscribed by the secretary of briefs, dated “a die Nativitatis,” i. e., “from the day of the Nativity,” and sealed with the ring of the fisherman. It differs from a bull, in its parchment, written character, date, and seal. See Bull. Brief of title an abstract or abridgment of all the deeds and other papers constituting the chain of title to any real estate. In brief in a few words; in short; briefly. “Open the matter in brief.” Shak.
entry.ety: See Brief a., and cf. Breve

sn.def: A short concise writing or letter; a statement in few words.
sn.q: Bear this sealed brief, With winged hastle, to the lord marshal.
And she told me In a sweet, verbal brief.

sn.def: An epitome.
sn.q: Each woman is a brief of womankind.

sn.def: An abridgment or concise statement of a client's case, made out for the instruction of counsel in a trial at law. This word is applied also to a statement of the heads or points of a law argument.
sn.q: It was not without some reference to it that I perused many a brief.

sn.def: A writ; a breve. See Breve n., 2.
A writ issuing from the chancery, directed to any judge ordinary, commanding and authorizing that judge to call a jury to inquire into the case, and upon their verdict to pronounce sentence.
A letter patent, from proper authority, authorizing a collection or charitable contribution of money in churches, for any public or private purpose.
a type of men's underpants without legs, fitting tightly and held by an elastic waistband; also called Jockey shorts.

entry.def: To make an abstract or abridgment of; to shorten; as, to brief pleadings.
a small suitcase with a handle; it is used for carrying papers or files or books.

sn.def: giving detailed instructions, as for a military operation.
a detailed set of instructions before an operation, given to those who are to execute it.
a summary report of an operation or event after it has occurred, by a participant or observer.

entry.def: Having no brief; without clients; as, a briefless barrister.
Concisely; in few words.

sn.def: One who makes a brief.
A copier of a manuscript.

entry.def: The quality of being brief; brevity; conciseness in discourse or writing.

entry.cs:
Brier root the root of the southern Smilax laurifolia and Smilax Walteri; -- used for tobacco pipes. See also 2nd brier.
Cat brier Green brier
several species of Smilax (Smilax rotundifolia, etc Sweet brier Rosa rubiginosa). See Sweetbrier. Yellow brier the Rosa Eglantina.
entry.ety: OE. brere brer, AS. brēr brær; cf. Ir. briar prickle, thorn, brier, pin, Gael. preas bush, brier, W. prys prysg

sn.def: A plant with a slender woody stem bearing stout prickles; especially, species of Rosa Rubus, and Smilax.
Fig.: Anything sharp or unpleasant to the feelings.
sn.q: The thorns and briers of reproof.

entry.note: Brierroot seems to have been used formerly as a term meaning root of the Smilax laurifolia and is now defined as root of the Erica arborea. Not clear when this changed. -- PJC.

sn.def: the white heath Erica arborea.
a smoking pipe made of the root of the brier{1}.

entry.def: Set with briers.

sn.def: wood from the hard woody root of the briar Erica arborea; it is used to make tobacco pipes. See also 2nd brier and brier root.

entry.def: Full of briers; thorny.
A place where briers grow.
A bridge.

cs.cd: a two-masted vessel square-rigged forward and schooner-rigged aft. See Illustration in Appendix.

entry.ety: Shortened from Brigantine
entry.def: A two-masted, square-rigged vessel.

entry.ety: Origin unknown
entry.def: On a United States man-of-war, the prison or place of confinement for offenders.

entry.note: ☞ Two or more brigades constitute a division, commanded by a major general; two or more divisions constitute an army corps, or corps d'armée. U.S

cs.cd: an officer whose duty is to inspect troops in companies before they are mustered into service.
an officer who may be attached to a brigade to assist the brigadier in his duties.

entry.ety: F. brigade, fr. It. brigata troop, crew, brigade, originally, a contending troop, fr. briga trouble, quarrel. See Brigand

sn.def: A body of troops, whether cavalry, artillery, infantry, or mixed, consisting of two or more regiments, under the command of a brigadier general.
Any body of persons organized for acting or marching together under authority; as, a fire brigade .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brigaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Brigading
entry.def: To form into a brigade, or into brigades.

entries.entry:
Brig`a*dier" gen"er*al. F. brigadier, fr. brigade
Mil An officer in rank next above a colonel, and below a major general. He commands a brigade, and is sometimes called, by a shortening of his title, simple a brigadier.

entry.ety: F. brigand, OF. brigant light-armed soldier, fr. LL. brigans light-armed soldier (cf. It. brigante.) fr. brigare to strive, contend, fr. briga quarrel; prob. of German origin, and akin to E. break; cf. Goth. brikan to break, brakja strife. Cf. Brigue

sn.def: A light-armed, irregular foot soldier.
A lawless fellow who lives by plunder; one of a band of robbers; especially, one of a gang living in mountain retreats; a highwayman; a freebooter.
sn.q: Giving them not a little the air of brigands or banditti.

entry.ety: F. brigandage
entry.def: Life and practice of brigands; highway robbery; plunder.

entry.ety: F. brigandinecf. It. brigantina), fr. OF. brigant. See Brigand
entry.def: A coast of armor for the body, consisting of scales or plates, sometimes overlapping each other, generally of metal, and sewed to linen or other material. It was worn in the Middle Ages.
entry.q: Then put on all thy gorgeous arms, thy helmet, And brigandine of brass.

entry.def: Like a brigand or freebooter; robberlike.
Brigandage.

entry.ety: F. brigantin, fr. It. brigantino, originally, a practical vessel. See Brigand, and cf. Brig

sn.def: A practical vessel.
A two-masted, square-rigged vessel, differing from a brig in that she does not carry a square mainsail.
See Brigandine.

entry.def: A bridge.
See Brite v. i.

entry.note: ☞ Bright is used in composition in the sense of brilliant, clear, sunny, etc.; as, bright-eyed, bright-haired, bright-hued.

cs.cd: the positive or favorable aspects of a situation.
cs.col: to look on the bright side
cs.cd: to focus the attention on favorable aspects of a situation; to minimize attention to possible negative or unfavorable factors in a situation.

entry.ety: OE. briht, AS. beorht briht; akin to OS. berht, OHG. beraht, Icel. bjartr, Goth. baírhts. √94

sn.def: Radiating or reflecting light; shedding or having much light; shining; luminous; not dark.
sn.q: The sun was bright o'erhead.
The earth was dark, but the heavens were bright.
The public places were as bright as at noonday.

sn.def: Transmitting light; clear; transparent.
sn.q: From the brightest wines He 'd turn abhorrent.

sn.def: Having qualities that render conspicuous or attractive, or that affect the mind as light does the eye; resplendent with charms; as, bright beauty.
sn.q: Bright as an angel new-dropped from the sky.

sn.def: Having a clear, quick intellect; intelligent.
Sparkling with wit; lively; vivacious; shedding cheerfulness and joy around; cheerful; cheery.
sn.q: Be bright and jovial among your guests.

sn.def: Illustrious; glorious.
sn.q: In the brightest annals of a female reign.

sn.def: Manifest to the mind, as light is to the eyes; clear; evident; plain.
sn.q: That he may with more ease, with brighter evidence, and with surer success, draw the bearner on.

sn.def: Of brilliant color; of lively hue or appearance.
sn.q: Here the bright crocus and blue violet grew.
sn.syn: Shining; splending; luminous; lustrous; brilliant; resplendent; effulgent; refulgent; radiant; sparkling; glittering; lucid; beamy; clear; transparent; illustrious; witty; clear; vivacious; sunny.

entry.def: Splendor; brightness.
entry.q: Dark with excessive bright thy skirts appear.

entry.def: Brightly.
entry.q: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.

entry.note: From Bright a.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brightened; p. pr. & vb. n. Brightening

sn.def: To make bright or brighter; to make to shine; to increase the luster of; to give a brighter hue to.
To make illustrious, or more distinguished; to add luster or splendor to.
sn.q: The present queen would brighten her character, if she would exert her authority to instill virtues into her people.

sn.def: To improve or relieve by dispelling gloom or removing that which obscures and darkens; to shed light upon; to make cheerful; as, to brighten one's prospects.
sn.q: An ecstasy, which mothers only feel, Plays round my heart and brightens all my sorrow.

sn.def: To make acute or witty; to enliven.

entry.ety: AS. beorhtan
entry.def: To grow bright, or more bright; to become less dark or gloomy; to clear up; to become bright or cheerful.
entry.q: And night shall brighten into day.
And, all his prospects brightening to the last, His heaven commences ere world be past.

entry.def: Having glittering armor.

sn.def: Brilliantly; splendidly; with luster; as, brightly shining armor.
With lively intelligence; intelligently.
sn.q: Looking brightly into the mother's face.

entry.ety: AS. beorhines. See Bright

sn.def: The quality or state of being bright; splendor; luster; brilliancy; clearness.
sn.q: A sudden brightness in his face appear.

sn.def: Acuteness (of the faculties); sharpness 9wit.
sn.q: The brightness of his parts . . . distinguished him.
sn.syn: Splendor; luster; radiance; resplendence; brilliancy; effulgence; glory; clearness.

entries.entry: Bright's" dis*ease". From Dr. Bright of London, who first described it Med An affection of the kidneys, usually inflammatory in character, and distinguished by the occurrence of albumin and renal casts in the urine. Several varieties of Bright's disease are now recognized, differing in the part of the kidney involved, and in the intensity and course of the morbid process.

entry.def: Bright; clear; luminous; brilliant.

entry.ety: LL. brigosus, It. brigoso. See Brigue n.
entry.def: Contentious; quarrelsome.

entry.ety: F. brigue, fr. LL. briga quarrel. See Brigand
entry.def: A cabal, intrigue, faction, contention, strife, or quarrel.

entry.ety: F. briguer. See Brigue n.
entry.def: To contend for; to canvass; to solicit.

entry.ety: AS. brice
entry.def: A breach; ruin; downfall; peril.

entry.ety: Cf. Corn. brilli mackerel, fr. brith streaked, speckled
entry.def: A fish allied to the turbot (Rhombus levis), much esteemed in England for food; -- called also bret pearl prill. See Bret.

entry.ety: It. See Brilliant a.
entry.def: In a gay, showy, and sparkling style.
Brilliancy.

entry.ety: See Brilliant
entry.def: The quality of being brilliant; splendor; glitter; great brightness, whether in a literal or figurative sense.
entry.q: With many readers brilliancy of style passes for affluence of thought.

entry.ety: F. brillant p. pr. of briller to shine or sparkle (cf. Pr. & Sp. brillar, It. brillare), fr. L. beryllus a precious stone of sea-green color, Prov. It. brill. See Beryl

sn.def: Sparkling with luster; glittering; very bright; as, a brilliant star.
Distinguished by qualities which excite admiration; splendid; shining; as, brilliant talents.
sn.q: Washington was more solicitous to avoid fatal mistakes than to perform brilliant exploits.

sn.def: Exceedingly intelligent, or of distinguished accomplishment in a field;as, a brilliant chemist.

entry.note: ☞ This line is printed in the type called Brilliant.
entry.ety: F. brillant. See Brilliant a.

sn.def: A diamond or other gem of the finest cut, formed into faces and facets, so as to reflect and refract the light, by which it is rendered more brilliant. It has at the middle, or top, a principal face, called the table, which is surrounded by a number of sloping facets forming a bizet; below, it has a small face or collet, parallel to the table, connected with the girdle by a pavilion of elongated facets. It is thus distinguished from the rose diamond, which is entirely covered with facets on the surface, and is flat below.
sn.q: This snuffbox -- on the hinge see brilliants shine.

sn.def: The smallest size of type used in England printing.
A kind of cotton goods, figured on the weaving.

entry.ety: F. brillantine. See lst Brilliant

sn.def: An oily composition used to make the hair manageable and glossy.
A dress fabric having a glossy finish on both sides, resembling alpaca but of superior quality.

entry.def: In a brilliant manner.
Brilliancy; splendor; glitter.

entry.ety: CF. G. brille spectacles, D. bril, fr. L. berillus. See Brilliant
entry.def: The hair on the eyelids of a horse.

entry.ety: OE. brim brimme, AS. brymme edge, border; akin to Icel. barmr, Sw. bräm, Dan. bræmme, G. brame bräme. Possibly the same word as AS. brim surge, sea, and properly meaning, the line of surf at the border of the sea, and akin to L. fremere to roar, murmur. Cf. Breeze a fly

sn.def: The rim, border, or upper edge of a cup, dish, or any hollow vessel used for holding anything.
sn.q: Saw I that insect on this goblet's brim I would remove it with an anxious pity.

sn.def: The edge or margin, as of a fountain, or of the water contained in it; the brink; border.
sn.q: The feet of the priests that bare the ark were dipped in the brim of the water.

sn.def: The rim of a hat.

cs.cd: to be so full that some of the contents flows over the brim; as, a cup brimming over with wine; a man brimming over with fun.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brimmed; p. pr. & vb. n. Brimming
entry.def: To be full to the brim.
entry.q: Thebrimmingstream.

entry.def: To fill to the brim, upper edge, or top.
entry.q: Arrange the board and brim the glass.

entry.def: Fierce; sharp; cold. See Breme.
Full to the brim; completely full; ready to overflow.
entry.q: Herbrimfuleyes.

entry.def: Having no brim; as, brimless caps.

sn.def: Having a brim; -- usually in composition.
sn.q: Broad-brimmedhat.

sn.def: Full to, or level with, the brim.

entry.def: A brimful bowl; a bumper.
Full to the brim; overflowing.

entry.ety: OE. brimston bremston bernston brenston; cf. Icel. brennistein. See Burn v. t., and Stone
entry.def: Sulphur; See Sulphur.
Made of, or pertaining to, brimstone; as, brimstone matches.
entry.q: From his brimstone bed at break of day A-walking the devil has gone.

entry.def: Containing or resembling brimstone; sulphurous.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: One of the radiating sticks of a fan. The outermost are larger and longer, and are called panaches.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. bröndōttr brindled, fr. brandr brand; and OE. bernen brinnen, to burn. See Brand Burn
entry.def: Of a gray or tawny color with streaks of darker hue; streaked; brindled.
entry.q: Threebrindedcows,
Thebrindedcat.

entry.ety: See Brindled

sn.def: The state of being brindled.
A brindled color; also, that which is brindled.

entry.def: Brindled.

entry.ety: A dim. form of brinded
entry.def: Having dark streaks or spots on a gray or tawny ground; brinded.
entry.q: With abrindledlion played.

cs.cd: a fly of the genus Ephydra, the larvæ of which live in artificial brines and in salt lakes.
an instrument for measuring the saltness of a liquid.
a pit or pan of salt water, where salt is formed by cristallization.
a salt spring or well, from which water is taken to be boiled or evaporated for making salt.
a pump for changing the water in the boilers, so as to clear them of the brine which collects at the bottom.
a phyllopod crustacean of the genus Artemia, inhabiting the strong brines of salt works and natural salt lakes. See Artemia.
a spring of salt water.
brine which drops from granulated salt in drying, and is preserved to be boiled again.

entry.ety: AS. bryne a burning, salt liquor, brine, fr. brinnan brynnan, to burn. See Burn

sn.def: Water saturated or strongly impregnated with salt; pickle; hence, any strong saline solution; also, the saline residue or strong mother liquor resulting from the evaporation of natural or artificial waters.
The ocean; the water of an ocean, sea, or salt lake.
sn.q: Not long beneath the whelming brine . . . he lay.

sn.def: Tears; -- so called from their saltness.
sn.q: What a deal of brine Hath washed thy sallow cheecks for Rosaline!

sn.def: To steep or saturate in brine.
To sprinkle with salt or brine; as, to brine hay.

entry.cs:
To bring about to bring to pass; to effect; to accomplish. To bring back. To recall. To restore, as something borrowed, to its owner. To bring by the lee Naut to incline so rapidly to leeward of the course, when a ship sails large, as to bring the lee side suddenly to the windward, any by laying the sails aback, expose her to danger of upsetting. To bring down. To cause to come down. To humble or abase; as, to bring down high looks. To bring down the house to cause tremendous applause. Colloq To bring forth. To produce, as young fruit. To bring to light; to make manifest. To bring forward To exhibit; to introduce; to produce to view. To hasten; to promote; to forward. To propose; to adduce; as, to bring forward arguments. To bring home. To bring to one's house. To prove conclusively; as, to bring home a charge of treason. To cause one to feel or appreciate by personal experience. Naut To lift of its place, as an anchor. To bring in. To fetch from without; to import. To introduce, as a bill in a deliberative assembly. To return or repot to, or lay before, a court or other body; to render; as, to bring in a verdict or a report. To take to an appointed place of deposit or collection; as, to bring in provisions or money for a specified object. To produce, as income. To induce to join. To bring off to bear or convey away; to clear from condemnation; to cause to escape. To bring on. To cause to begin. To originate or cause to exist; as, to bring on a disease. To bring one on one's way to accompany, guide, or attend one. To bring out to expose; to detect; to bring to light from concealment. To bring over. To fetch or bear across. To convert by persuasion or other means; to cause to change sides or an opinion. To bring to. To resuscitate; to bring back to consciousness or life, as a fainting person. Naut To check the course of, as of a ship, by dropping the anchor, or by counterbracing the sails so as to keep her nearly stationary (she is then said to lie to). To cause (a vessel) to lie to, as by firing across her course. To apply a rope to the capstan. To bring to light to disclose; to discover; to make clear; to reveal. To bring a sail to Naut to bend it to the yard. To bring to pass to accomplish to effect. “Trust also in Him; and He shall bring it to pass.” Ps. xxxvii. 5. To bring under to subdue; to restrain; to reduce to obedience. To bring up. To carry upward; to nurse; to rear; to educate. To cause to stop suddenly.
v. i. by dropping the reflexive pronoun To stop suddenly; to come to a standstill. Colloq To bring up (any one) with a round turn to cause (any one) to stop abruptly. Colloq To be brought to bed. See under Bed.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brought; p. pr. & vb. n. Bringing
entry.ety: OE. bringen, AS. bringan; akin to OS. brengian, D. brengen, Fries. brenga, OHG. bringan, G. bringen, Goth. briggan

sn.def: To convey to the place where the speaker is or is to be; to bear from a more distant to a nearer place; to fetch.
sn.q: And as she was going to fetch it, he called to her, and said, Bring me, I pray thee, a morsel of bread.
To France shall we convey you safe, And bring you back.

sn.def: To cause the accession or obtaining of; to procure; to make to come; to produce; to draw to.
sn.q: There is nothing will bring you more honor . . . than to do what right in justice you may.

sn.def: To convey; to move; to carry or conduct.
sn.q: In distillation, the water . . . brings over with it some part of the oil of vitriol.

sn.def: To persuade; to induce; to draw; to lead; to guide.
sn.q: It seems so preposterous a thing . . . that they do not easily bring themselves to it.
The nature of the things . . . would not suffer him to think otherwise, how, or whensoever, he is brought to reflect on them.

sn.def: To produce in exchange; to sell for; to fetch; as, what does coal bring per ton?
sn.syn: To fetch; bear; carry; convey; transport; import; procure; produce; cause; adduce; induce.

cs.cd: one who, or that which, introduces.

entry.def: One who brings.
entry.q: Yet the first bringer of unwelcome news Hath but a losing office.

entry.def: The state or quality of being briny; saltness; brinishness.
Like brine; somewhat salt; saltish.
entry.q: Brinishtears.

entry.def: State or quality of being brinish.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A rough-haired East Indian variety of the greyhound.

entry.ety: Dan. brink edge, verge; akin to Sw. brink declivity, hill, Icel. brekka; cf. LG. brink a grassy hill, W. bryn hill, bryncyn hillock
entry.def: The edge, margin, or border of a steep place, as of a precipice; a bank or edge, as of a river or pit; a verge; a border; as, the brink of a chasm. Also Fig.
entry.q: Thebrinkof vice.
Thebrinkof ruin.
The plashy brink of weedy lake.

entry.ety: brink + -manship. (1956)
entry.def: the policy or practise of pushing a dangerous situation to the brink of disaster (to the limits of safety), in order to achieve the most advantageous outcome; -- used especially of diplomatic maneuvers in crisis situations, and originally applied to the policies of John Foster Dulles under President Eisenhower.

entry.ety: From Brine
entry.def: Of or pertaining to brine, or to the sea; partaking of the nature of brine; salt; as, a briny taste; the briny flood.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: A light sweet pastry (cake, bun or roll) made with flour, butter, yeast, and eggs.
A knitted foot cushion.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: An oval or pearshaped diamond having its entire surface cut in triangular facets.
See Bryony.

entry.ety: trademark
entry.def: a type of antacid sold over-the-counter.

entry.ety: F., dim. of brique brick

sn.def: A block of compacted charcoal, coal dust, or peat, etc., used as a fuel. Charcoal briquettes are a common fuel used for the outdoor barbecue grill.
A block of artificial stone in the form of a brick, used for paving; also, a molded sample of solidified cement or mortar for use as a test piece for showing the strength of the material.

entry.def: the Jewish rite of circumcision.
the shattering or crushing effect of a sudden release of energy as in an explosion; -- used especially as a measure of such a shattering power, applied to high explosives.

entry.note: the more brisant explosives, such as dynamite, will shatter rock into smaller fragments than the less brisant, such as gunpowder.

sn.def: of or pertaining to brisance.
having the ability to shatter, as contrasted with merely fracturing; -- of explosives.

entry.ety: Cf. W. brysg, fr. brys haste, Gael. briosg quick, lively, Ir. broisg a start, leap, jerk

sn.def: Full of liveliness and activity; characterized by quickness of motion or action; lively; spirited; quick.
sn.q: Cheerily, boys; be brick awhile.
Brisk toil alternating with ready ease.

sn.def: Full of spirit of life; effervesc�ng, as liquors; sparkling; as, brick cider.
sn.syn: Active; lively; agile; alert; nimble; quick; sprightly; vivacious; gay; spirited; animated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bricked; p. pr. & vb. n. Bricking
entry.def: To make or become lively; to enliven; to animate; to take, or cause to take, an erect or bold attitude; -- usually with up.
to become brisk.

entry.note: See Illust. of Beef
entry.ety: OE. bruskette, OF. bruschet, F. bréchet brichet; prob. of Celtic origin; cf. W. brysced the breast of a slain animal, brisket, Corn. vrys breast, Armor. brusk bruched, the front of the chest, Gael. brisgein the cartilaginous part of a bone
entry.def: That part of the breast of an animal which extends from the fore legs back beneath the ribs; also applied to the fore part of a horse, from the shoulders to the bottom of the chest.
In a brisk manner; nimbly.
Liveliness; vigor in action; quickness; gayety; vivacity; effervescence.

sn.def: a small fatty European fish; usually smoked or canned.
a small herring (Clupea sprattus) processed like a sardine.

entry.ety: OE. bristel brustel, AS. bristl byrst; akin to D. borstel, OHG. burst, G. borste, Icel. burst, Sw. borst, and to Skr. bhṛshti edge, point, and prob, L. fastigium extremity, Gr. 'a`flaston stern of a ship, and E. brush burr, perh. to brad. √96

sn.def: A short, stiff, coarse hair, as on the back of swine.
A stiff, sharp, roundish hair.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bristled; p. pr. & vb. n. Bristling

sn.def: To erect the bristles of; to cause to stand up, as the bristles of an angry hog; -- sometimes with up.
sn.q: Now for the bare-picked bone of majesty Doth dogged war bristle his angry crest.
Boy, bristle thy courage up.

cs.cd: to show anger or defiance.

sn.def: To rise or stand erect, like bristles.

sn.def: To appear as if covered with bristles; to have standing, thick and erect, like bristles.
sn.q: The hill of La Haye Sainte bristling with ten thousand bayonets.
Ports bristling with thousands of masts.

sn.def: To show defiance or indignation.

entry.def: grasses of grasslands and woodlands having large gracefully arching spikes with long bristles beneath each spikelet.
resembling a bristle in stiffness.
Terminating in a very fine, sharp point, as some leaves.
Resembling a bristle in form; as, a bristle-shaped leaf.

The quality or state of having bristles.
Thick set with bristles, or with hairs resembling bristles; rough.

a brick of siliceous matter used for polishing cultery; -- originally manufactured at Bristol.
rock crystal, or brilliant crystals of quartz, found in the mountain limestone near Bristol, and used in making ornaments, vases, etc. When polished, it is called Bristol diamond.

entry.def: A seaport city in the west of England.

A mark of cadency or difference.

entry.ety: From L. Britannia Great Britain
entry.def: A white-metal alloy of tin, antimony, bismuth, copper, etc. It somewhat resembles silver, and is used for table ware. Called also Britannia metal.

entry.ety: L. Britannicus, fr. Britannia Great Britain

To be or become overripe, as wheat, barley, or hops.

entry.def: A word, phrase, or idiom peculiar to Great Britain; any manner of using a word or words that is peculiar to Great Britain.

the four seas which surround Great Britain.

a custom that is peculiar to England or its citizens.

Easily broken; apt to break; fragile; not tough or tenacious

entry.ety: OE. broche, F. broche, fr. LL. brocca; prob. of Celtic origin; cf. W. proc thrust, stab, Gael. brog awl. Cf. Brooch

sn.def: An awl; a bodkin; also, a wooden rod or pin, sharpened at each end, used by thatchers.

sd.def: A tool of steel, generally tapering, and of a polygonal form, with from four to eight cutting edges, for smoothing or enlarging holes in metal; sometimes made smooth or without edges, as for burnishing pivot holes in watches; a reamer. The broach for gun barrels is commonly square and without taper.
A straight tool with file teeth, made of steel, to be pressed through irregular holes in metal that cannot be dressed by revolving tools; a drift.

sn.def: A broad chisel for stonecutting.
A spire rising from a tower.
A clasp for fastening a garment. See Brooch.
A spitlike start, on the head of a young stag.
The stick from which candle wicks are suspended for dipping.
The pin in a lock which enters the barrel of the key.

cs.cd: to incline suddenly to windward, so as to lay the sails aback, and expose the vessel to the danger of oversetting.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Broached; p. pr. & vb. n. Broaching
entry.ety: F. brocher, fr. broche. See Broach n.

sn.def: To spit; to pierce as with a spit.
sn.q: I'll broach the tadpole on my rapier's point.

sn.def: To tap; to pierce, as a cask, in order to draw the liquor. Hence: To let out; to shed, as blood.
sn.q: Whereat with blade, with bloody blameful blade, He bravely broached his boiling bloody breast.

sn.def: To open for the first time, as stores.
sn.q: You shall want neither weapons, victuals, nor aid; I will open the old armories, I will broach my store, and will bring forth my stores.

sn.def: To make public; to utter; to publish first; to put forth; to introduce as a topic of conversation.
sn.q: Those very opinions themselves had broached.

sn.def: To cause to begin or break out.
To shape roughly, as a block of stone, by chiseling with a coarse tool.
To enlarge or dress (a hole), by using a broach.
A spit; a broach.
sn.q: On five sharp broachers ranked, the roast they turned.

sn.def: One who broaches, opens, or utters; a first publisher or promoter.
sn.q: Some such broacher of heresy.

entry.note: Hence: -
☞ Broad is often used in compounds to signify wide large, etc.; as, broad-chested, broad-shouldered, broad-spreading, broad-winged.
entry.cs: Broad acres. See under Acre. Broad arrow originally a pheon. See Pheon, and Broad arrow under Arrow. As broad as long having the length equal to the breadth; hence, the same one way as another; coming to the same result by different ways or processes.
Broad pennant. See under Pennant.
entry.ety: OE. brod brad, AS. brād; akin to OS. brēd, D. breed, G. breit, Icel. breiðr, Sw. & Dan. bred, Goth. braids. Cf. Breadth

sn.def: Wide; extend in breadth, or from side to side; -- opposed to narrow; as, a broad street, a broad table; an inch broad .
Extending far and wide; extensive; vast; as, the broad expanse of ocean.
Extended, in the sense of diffused; open; clear; full.
sn.q: Broadand open day.

sn.def: Fig.: Having a large measure of any thing or quality; not limited; not restrained; -- applied to any subject, and retaining the literal idea more or less clearly, the precise meaning depending largely on the substantive.
sn.q: A broad mixture of falsehood.

sn.def: Comprehensive; liberal; enlarged.
sn.q: The words in the Constitution are broad enough to include the case.
In a broad, statesmanlike, and masterly way.

sn.def: Plain; evident; as, a broad hint.
Free; unrestrained; unconfined.
sn.q: As broad and general as the casing air.

sn.def: Characterized by breadth. See Breadth.
Cross; coarse; indelicate; as, a broad compliment; a broad joke; broad humor.
Strongly marked; as, a broad Scotch accent.
sn.q: It is as broad as long, whether they rise to others, or bring others down to them.
sn.syn: Wide; large; ample; expanded; spacious; roomy; extensive; vast; comprehensive; liberal.

sn.def: The broad part of anything; as, the broad of an oar.
The spread of a river into a sheet of water; a flooded fen.
A lathe tool for turning down the insides and bottoms of cylinders.
A woman, especially one who is sexually promiscuous; -- usually considered offensive.
An ancient military weapon; a battle-ax.
An ax with a broad edge, for hewing timber.

entry.def: an Old World upright plant grown esp. for its large flat edible seeds but also as fodder.
entry.syn: broad bean, broad-bean plant, English bean, European bean, field bean, Vicia faba.

sn.def: A wild duck (Aythya marilaorFuligula marila), which appears in large numbers on the eastern coast of the United States, in autumn; -- called also bluebill blackhead raft duck, and scaup duck. See Scaup duck.
The shoveler. See Shoveler.
A hat with a very broad brim, like those worn by men of the society of Friends.
A member of the society of Friends; a Quaker.

entry.def: Having a broad brim.
entry.q: A broad-brimmed flat silver plate.

sn.def: A casting or throwing seed in all directions, as from the hand in sowing.

an act of broadcasting; specifically, a program in which sounds or images are transmitted in all directions from a radio or television station; -- usually referring to a scheduled program on a commercial or public service radio or television station, using the normal radio frequencies for those media, in contrast to a radiotelephone conversation, which may also be transmitted in all directions, but is intended for receipt by a base station in the telephone network.
Cast or dispersed in all directions, as seed from the hand in sowing; widely diffused.
Scattering in all directions (as a method of sowing); -- opposed to planting in hills, or rows.

entry.def: So as to scatter or be scattered in all directions; so as to spread widely, as seed from the hand in sowing, or news from the press.

sn.def: to cast or disperse in all directions, as seed from the hand in sowing; to diffuse widely.
to transmit (sounds, images, or other signals) in all directions from a radio or television station.
to disseminate (information, a speech, an advertisement, etc.) from a radio or television station.
to spread (information, news, gossip) widely by any means.
someone who broadcasts on radio or television.
a mechanical device for scattering something (seed, fertilizer, sand, salt, etc.) in all directions.

entry.def: the medium that disseminates via telecommunications; radio and television.

sn.def: taking part in a radio or tv program.

entries.entry: Broad" Church`. Eccl A portion of the Church of England, consisting of persons who claim to hold a position, in respect to doctrine and fellowship, intermediate between the High Church party and the Low Church, or evangelical, party. The term has been applied to other bodies of men holding liberal or comprehensive views of Christian doctrine and fellowship. Side by side with these various shades of High and Low Church, another party of a different character has always existed in the Church of England. It is called by different names: Moderate, Catholic, or Broad Church, by its friends; Latitudinarian or Indifferent, by its enemies. Its distinctive character is the desire of comprehension. Its watch words are charity and toleration.

entry.def: A fine smooth-faced woolen cloth for men's garments, usually of double width (i.e., a yard and a half); -- so called in distinction from woolens three quarters of a yard wide.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Broadened; p. pr. & vb. n. Broadening
entry.ety: From Broad a.
entry.def: To grow broad; to become broader or wider.
entry.q: The broadening sun appears.

entry.def: To make broad or broader; to render more broad or comprehensive.

entries.entry: Broad" gauge`. Railroad A wider distance between the rails than the “standard” gauge of four feet eight inches and a half. See Gauge.
broad-headed adj. having a broad head.Narrower terms: brachycephalic (vs. dolichocephalic), brachycranal, brachycranic roundheaded, short-headed.

entry.def: Having horns spreading widely.
Rather broad; moderately broad.
A tree (Terminalia latifolia) of Jamaica, the wood of which is used for boards, scantling, shingles, etc; -- sometimes called the almond tree, from the shape of its fruit.

Broad"-leaved` Broad"-leafed`
a. Having broad, or relatively broad, leaves, in contrast to needlelike or scalelike leaves.Narrower terms: deciduous (vs. evergreen

entry.sn: inclined to respect views and beliefs that differ from one's own. Opposite of narrow-minded.Narrower terms: free-thinking, latitudinarian, undogmatic, undogmatical broadminded, broad, liberal, tolerant, open-minded, open.

entry.ety: AS. brādnes

An old English gold coin, broader than a guinea, as a Carolus or Jacobus.

entries.entry: Broad" seal`. The great seal of England; the public seal of a country or state.

entry.def: To stamp with the broad seal; to make sure; to guarantee or warrant.

entry.def: same as big-shouldered.

Spreading widely.

a hardy coarse-haired sheep of central Asia; the lambs are valued for their soft curly black fur.

a street in Manhattan famous for its restaurants and its theaters in the Times Square area. At its intersection with Seventh Avenue, it forms Times Square, an area with impressive displays of bright lights, particularly advertising; it is considered by some to be the cultural center of New York City.
the theater district of Manhattan, located near Times Square.

entry.def: Breadthwise.

entry.ety: Cf. Gael. brog, E. brog, n

entry.def: Colossal; of extraordinary height; gigantic.

entry.q: The legal brocard, “Falsus in uno, falsus in omnibus,” is a rule not more applicable to other witness than to consciousness.

entry.note: ☞ In the Highlands of Scotland, the ancient brogue was made of horsehide or deerskin, untanned or tenned with the hair on, gathered round the ankle with a thong. The name was afterward given to any shoe worn as a part of the Highland costume.

entry.def: Breeches.

entry.ety: F. brouiller to disorder, from LL. brogilus broilus brolium, thicket, wood, park; of uncertain origin; cf. W. brog a swelling out, OHG. prōil marsh, G. brühl, MHG. brogen to rise. The meaning tumult confusion, comes apparently from tangled undergrowth thicket, and this possibly from the meaning to grow rise sprout
entry.def: A tumult; a noisy quarrel; a disturbance; a brawl; contention; discord, either between individuals or in the state.
entry.q: I will own that there is a haughtiness and fierceness in human nature which will which will cause innumerable broils, place men in what situation you please.
entry.syn: Contention; fray; affray; tumult; altercation; dissension; discord; contest; conflict; brawl; uproar.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Broiled; p. pr. & vb. n. Broiling

sn.def: To cook by direct exposure to heat over a fire, esp. upon a gridiron over coals.
To subject to great (commonly direct) heat.

entry.def: To be subjected to the action of heat, as meat over the fire; to be greatly heated, or to be made uncomfortable with heat.
entry.q: The planets and comets had been broiling in the sun.

entry.def: cooked by direct exposure to radiant heat.
One who excites broils; one who engages in or promotes noisy quarrels.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Break.

entry.cs: Broken ground. Mil Rough or uneven ground; as, the troops were retarded in their advance by broken ground . Ground recently opened with the plow. Broken line Geom the straight lines which join a number of given points taken in some specified order. Broken meat fragments of meat or other food. Broken number a fraction. Broken weather unsettled weather.
entry.ety: From Break v. t.

sn.def: Separated into parts or pieces by violence; divided into fragments; as, a broken chain or rope; a broken dish.
Disconnected; not continuous; also, rough; uneven; as, a broken surface.
Fractured; cracked; disunited; sundered; strained; apart; as, a broken reed; broken friendship.
Made infirm or weak, by disease, age, or hardships.
sn.q: The one being who remembered him as he been before his mind was broken.
The broken soldier, kindly bade to stay, Sat by his fire, and talked the night away.

sn.def: Subdued; humbled; contrite.
sn.q: The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit.

sn.def: Subjugated; trained for use, as a horse.
Crushed and ruined as by something that destroys hope; blighted.

sn.def: Not carried into effect; not adhered to; violated; as, a broken promise, vow, or contract; a broken law.
Ruined financially; incapable of redeeming promises made, or of paying debts incurred; as, a broken bank; a broken tradesman.
Imperfectly spoken, as by a foreigner; as, broken English; imperfectly spoken on account of emotion; as, to say a few broken words at parting.
sn.q: Amidst the broken words and loud weeping of those grave senators.

sn.def: Having a broken back; as, a broken-backed chair.
Hogged; so weakened in the frame as to droop at each end; -- said of a ship.

entry.def: In a broken, interrupted manner; in a broken state; in broken language.
