sn.def: The state or quality of being broken; unevenness.
Contrition; as, brokenness of heart.

entries.entry: Bro"ken wind`. Far The heaves.

entry.def: Having short breath or disordered respiration, as a horse.

entry.cs:
Bill broker one who buys and sells notes and bills of exchange.
Curbstone broker or Street broker
an operator in stocks (not a member of the Stock Exchange) who executes orders by running from office to office, or by transactions on the street. U.S Exchange broker one who buys and sells uncurrent money, and deals in exchanges relating to money. Insurance broker one who is agent in procuring insurance on vessels, or against fire. Pawn broker. See Pawnbroker. Real estate broker one who buys and sells lands, and negotiates loans, etc., upon mortgage. Ship broker one who acts as agent in buying and selling ships, procuring freight, etc. Stock broker. See Stockbroker.
entry.ety: OE. brocour, from a word akin to broken bruken, to use, enjoy, possess, digest, fr. AS. brūcan to use, enjoy; cf. Fries. broker, F. brocanteur. See Brook v. t.

sn.def: One who transacts business for another; an agent.

An agent employed to effect bargains and contracts, as a middleman or negotiator, between other persons, for a compensation commonly called brokerage. He takes no possession, as broker, of the subject matter of the negotiation. He generally contracts in the names of those who employ him, and not in his own.
A dealer in money, notes, bills of exchange, etc.
A dealer in secondhand goods.
A pimp or procurer.
The business or employment of a broker.
The fee, reward, or commission, given or changed for transacting business as a broker.

entry.def: a financial specialist who trades for his own account and so acts both as a broker and principal.
Mean; servile.
The business of a broker.
entry.q: And with extorting, cozening, forfeiting, And tricks belonging unto brokery.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a broker or brokers, or to brokerage.
entry.q: Redeem from broking pawn the blemished crown.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. brw^ma food, bibrw`skein to eat

sn.def: Aliment; food.
A light form of prepared cocoa (or cacao), or the drink made from it.

entry.ety: Bromine + aldehyde
entry.def: An oily, colorless fluid, CBr3.COH, related to bromoform, as chloral is to chloroform, and obtained by the action of bromine on alcohol.

entry.ety: From Bromine
entry.def: A colorless or white crystalline compound, CH2)6N4C2H5Br, used as a sedative in epilepsy.

entry.ety: Bromine + aniline
entry.def: A substance analogous to chloranil but containing bromine in place of chlorine.
A salt of bromic acid.
To combine or impregnate with bromine; as, bromated camphor.
One versed in the science of foods.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, food + -logy
entry.def: The science of aliments.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: See Bromine.

entries.entry: Brome" grass`. L. bromos a kind of oats, Gr. � Bot A genus Bromus of grasses, one species of which is the chess or cheat.

entry.ety: Named after Olaf Bromel, a Swedish botanist
entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, a family of endogenous and mostly epiphytic or saxicolous plants of which the genera Tillandsia and Billbergia are examples. The pineapple, though terrestrial, is also of this family.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, bromine; -- said of those compounds of bromine in which this element has a valence of five, or the next to its highest; as, bromic acid.

sn.def: A compound of bromine with a positive radical.
A person who is conventional and commonplace in his habits of thought and conversation.
sn.q: The bromide conforms to everything sanctioned by the majority, and may be depended upon to be trite, banal, and arbitrary.

sn.def: a conventional or trite saying; -- often used in the phrase “old bromide”.

entries.entry: Bromide paperorBromid paper . Photog A sensitized paper coated with gelatin impregnated with bromide of silver, used in contact printing and in enlarging.

sn.def: of or pertaining to bromide (definition 2).
conventional or trite; repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse -- of sayings, assertions, or discourses; as, bromidic sermons.
sn.syn: commonplace, hackneyed, shopworn, threadbare, timeworn, tired, trite, well-worn.

entry.ety: Bromide + idiom
entry.def: A conventional comment or saying, such as those characteristic of bromides{2}; a bromide{3}.
See Bromate v. t.

entry.ety: Gr. � bad smell, stink. Cf. Brome
entry.def: One of the halogen elements, related in its chemical qualities to chlorine and iodine. Atomic weight 79.8. Symbol Br. It is a deep reddish brown liquid of a very disagreeable odor, emitting a brownish vapor at the ordinary temperature. In combination it is found in minute quantities in sea water, and in many saline springs. It occurs also in the mineral bromyrite.
A diseased condition produced by the excessive use of bromine or one of its compounds. It is characterized by mental dullness and muscular weakness.
To prepare or treat with bromine; as, to bromize a silvered plate.

entry.ety: From Bromley Hill, near Alston, Cumberland, England
entry.def: A carbonate of baryta and lime, intermediate between witherite and strontianite; -- called also alstonite.

entry.ety: Bromine + formyl
entry.def: A colorless liquid, CHBr3, having an agreeable odor and sweetish taste. It is produced by the simultaneous action of bromine and caustic potash upon wood spirit, alcohol, or acetone, as also by certain other reactions. In composition it is the same as chloroform, with the substitution of bromine for chlorine. It is somewhat similar to chloroform in its effects.

entry.ety: Bromine + gelatin
entry.def: Designating or pertaining to, a process of preparing dry plates with an emulsion of bromides and silver nitrate in gelatin.

entry.ety: Bromine + iodine + -ism
entry.def: Poisoning induced by large doses of bromine and iodine or of their compounds.
Treated with bromides and iodides.

entry.ety: Abbr. fr. tribromophenol
entry.def: A crystalline substance (chemically, tribromophenol, C6H2Br3OH), used as an antiseptic and disinfectant.

entry.ety: G. brompikrin; brom bromine + pikrinsäure picric acid
entry.def: A pungent colorless explosive liquid, CNO2Br3, analogous to and resembling chlorpicrin.

entry.ety: from Brompton Hospital, London
entry.def: A mixture containing morphine and cocaine, and sometimes other narcotic substances, such as heroin, in an alcoholic solution, administered mostly to terminally ill patients, especially cancer patients, to relieve severe pain. Its use is not universally accepted as good medical practice.
See Bromide.

entry.ety: Bromine + Gr. � silver
entry.def: Silver bromide, a rare mineral; -- called also bromargyrite.
an unbroken or imperfectly broken mustang.
See Bronchus.

entry.ety: L. , pl. Cf. Bronchus
entry.def: The bronchial tubes which arise from the branching of the trachea, esp. the subdivision of the bronchi.

cs.cd: branches of the descending aorta, accompanying the bronchia in all their ramifications.
the air cells terminating the bronchia.
glands whose functions are unknown, seated along the bronchia.
the mucous membrane lining the bronchia.
the bronchi, or the bronchia.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bronchial. See Bronchia
entry.def: Belonging to the bronchi and their ramifications in the lungs.
Bronchial.
of or pertaining to a bronchiole.
A minute bronchial tube.
inflammation of the membranes lining the bronchioles.
Of or pertaining to bronchitis; as, bronchitic inflammation.

entry.ety: Bronchus + -itis
entry.def: Inflammation, acute or chronic, of the bronchial tubes or any part of them.

entry.ety: Sp. bronco rough, wild
entry.def: A native or a Mexican horse of small size.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � windpipe + � tumor
entry.def: See Goiter.

entry.ety: Gr. � windpipe + � sound
entry.def: A modification of the voice sounds, by which they are intensified and heightened in pitch; -- observed in auscultation of the chest in certain cases of intro-thoracic disease.

entry.ety: Bronchus + pneumonia
entry.def: Inflammation of the bronchi and lungs; catarrhal pneumonia.

entry.ety: Gr. � windpipe + � to cut
entry.def: An instrument for cutting into the bronchial tubes.
An incision into the windpipe or larynx, including the operations of tracheotomy and laryngotomy.

entries.entry:
Bron"chus Bron"chus n.; pl.Bronchi. NL., fr. Gr. � windpipe. Cf. Bronchia
Anat One of the subdivisions of the trachea or windpipe; esp. one of the two primary divisions.

entry.def: Same as Broncho.

entry.ety: See Brand
entry.def: A sword.

entry.ety: Gr. � thunder + -graph
entry.def: A tracing or chart showing the phenomena attendant on thunderstorms.
An instrument for making such tracings, as a recording brontometer.

entry.ety: Gr. � + -lite -lith
entry.def: An aërolite.

entry.ety: Gr. � thunder + -logy
entry.def: A treatise upon thunder.

entry.ety: Gr. � thunder + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for noting or recording phenomena attendant on thunderstorms.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. bronth` thunder + say^ros lizard
entry.def: a dinosaur of the genus Brontosaurus; an individual may also be called a brontosaurus or an apatosaurus.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. bronth` thunder + say^ros lizard
entry.def: A genus of large sauropod American dinosaurs of the jurassic era, or an individual of that genus. A length of sixty feet is believed to have been attained by these reptiles. The genus is also called Apatosaurus, and individuals of the genus are also called brontosaurs.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � thunder + � beast
entry.def: A genus of large extinct mammals from the miocene strata of western North America. They were allied to the rhinoceros, but the skull bears a pair of powerful horn cores in front of the orbits, and the fore feet were four-toed. See Illustration in Appendix.

entry.note: ☞ The tracks made by these reptiles are found eighteen inches in length, and were formerly referred to gigantic birds; but the discovery of large bipedal three-toed dinosaurs has suggested that they were made by those reptiles.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � thunder + � animal
entry.def: An extinct animal of large size, known from its three-toed footprints in Mesozoic sandstone.

entry.cs:
Aluminium bronze. See under Aluminium. Bronze age an age of the world which followed the stone age, and was characterized by the use of implements and ornaments of copper or bronze. Bronze powder a metallic powder, used with size or in combination with painting, to give the appearance of bronze, gold, or other metal, to any surface.
Phosphor bronzeandSilicious bronzeorSilicium bronze
are made by adding phosphorus and silicon respectively to ordinary bronze, and are characterized by great tenacity.
entry.ety: F. bronze, fr. It. bronzo brown, fr. OHG. br�n, G. braun. See Brown a.

sn.def: An alloy of copper and tin, to which small proportions of other metals, especially zinc, are sometimes added. It is hard and sonorous, and is used for statues, bells, cannon, etc., the proportions of the ingredients being varied to suit the particular purposes. The varieties containing the higher proportions of tin are brittle, as in bell metal and speculum metal.
A statue, bust, etc., cast in bronze.
sn.q: A print, a bronze, a flower, a root.

sn.def: A yellowish or reddish brown, the color of bronze; also, a pigment or powder for imitating bronze.
Boldness; impudence; “brass.”
sn.q: Imbrowned with native bronze, lo! Henley stands.

entry.cs: Bronzed skin disease. Pathol See Addison's disease.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bronzed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bronzing
entry.ety: Cf. F. bronzer. See Bronze n.

sn.def: To give an appearance of bronze to, by a coating of bronze powder, or by other means; to make of the color of bronze; as, to bronze plaster casts; to bronze coins or medals.
sn.q: The tall bronzed black-eyed stranger.

sn.def: To make hard or unfeeling; to brazen.
sn.q: The lawer who bronzes his bosom instead of his forehead.

entries.entry: Bronze steel. A hard tough alloy of tin, copper, and iron, which can be used for guns.

entry.def: An Australian pigeon of the genus Phaps, of several species; -- so called from its bronze plumage.
A metal so prepared as to have the appearance of bronze.

def2.def: Made of bronzine; resembling bronze; bronzelike.

sn.def: The act or art of communicating to articles in metal, wood, clay, plaster, etc., the appearance of bronze by means of bronze powders, or imitative painting, or by chemical processes.
A material for bronzing.

entry.def: One who makes, imitates, collects, or deals in, bronzes.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bronzite
entry.def: A variety of enstatite, often having a bronzelike luster. It is a silicate of magnesia and iron, of the pyroxene family.
Like bronze.

entry.ety: See Broach n.

sn.def: An ornament, in various forms, with a tongue, pin, or loop for attaching it to a garment; now worn at the breast by women; a breastpin. Formerly worn by men on the hat.
sn.q: Honor 's a good brooch to wear in a man's hat.

sn.def: A painting all of one color, as a sepia painting, or an India painting.

entry.def: To adorn as with a brooch.

cs.cd: to ponder.

entry.ety: OE. brod, AS. brōd; akin to D. broed, OHG. bruot, G. brut, and also to G. brühe broth, MHG. brüeje, and perh. to E. brawn breath. Cf. Breed v. t.

sn.def: The young birds hatched at one time; a hatch; as, a brood of chickens.
sn.q: As a hen doth gather her brood under her wings.
A hen followed by a brood of ducks.

sn.def: The young from the same dam, whether produced at the same time or not; young children of the same mother, especially if nearly of the same age; offspring; progeny; as, a woman with a brood of children.
sn.q: The lion roars and gluts his tawny brood.

sn.def: That which is bred or produced; breed; species.
sn.q: Flocks of the airy brood,Cranes, geese or long-necked swans).

sn.def: Heavy waste in tin and copper ores.
Sitting or inclined to sit on eggs.
Kept for breeding from; as, a brood mare; brood stock; having young; as, a brood sow.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brooded; p. pr. & vb. n. Brooding

sn.def: To sit on and cover eggs, as a fowl, for the purpose of warming them and hatching the young; or to sit over and cover young, as a hen her chickens, in order to warm and protect them; hence, to sit quietly, as if brooding.
sn.q: Birds of calm sir brooding on the charmed wave.

sn.def: To have the mind dwell continuously or moodily on a subject; to think long and anxiously; to be in a state of gloomy, serious thought; -- usually followed by over or on; as, to brood over misfortunes.
sn.q: Brooding on unprofitable gold.
Brooding over all these matters, the mother felt like one who has evoked a spirit.
When with downcast eyes we muse and brood.

sn.def: To sit over, cover, and cherish; as, a hen broods her chickens.
To cherish with care.
To think anxiously or moodily upon.
sn.q: You'll sit and brood your sorrows on a throne.

entry.def: a box designed to maintain a constant temperature by the use of a thermostat; used for chicks or premature infants.

sn.def: worried and thinking long and intensely, especially about a particular problem.
sn.syn: broody, contemplative, meditative, musing, pensive, pondering, reflective, ruminative, gloomy, morose.

entry.def: good at incubating eggs, especially of a fowl kept for that purpose; as, a brooding hen.
the process of sitting on eggs so as to hatch them by the warmth of the body; -- mostly used of birds.
a female horse used for breeding.
Inclined to brood.

entry.ety: OE. brok broke brook, AS. brōc; akin to D. broek, LG. brōk, marshy ground, OHG. pruoh, G. bruch marsh; prob. fr. the root of E. break, so as that it signifies water breaking through the earth, a spring or brook, as well as a marsh. See Break v. t.
entry.def: A natural stream of water smaller than a river or creek.
entry.q: The Lord thy God bringeth thee into a good land, a land of brooks of water.
Empires itself, as doth an inland brook Into the main of waters.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brooked; p. pr. & vb. n. Brooking
entry.ety: OE. broken bruken, to use, enjoy, digest, AS. br�can; akin to D. gebruiken to use, OHG. pr�hhan, G. brauchen gebrauchen, Icel. br�ka, Goth. br�kjan, and L. frui, to enjoy. Cf. Fruit Broker

sn.def: To use; to enjoy.
To bear; to endure; to put up with; to tolerate; as, young men can not brook restraint.
sn.q: Shall we, who could not brook one lord, Crouch to the wicked ten?

sn.def: To deserve; to earn.

entry.ety: Named from the English mineralogist, H. J. Brooke
entry.def: A mineral consisting of titanic oxide, and hence identical with rutile and octahedrite in composition, but crystallizing in the orthorhombic system.
A small brook.
A plant (Veronica Beccabunga), with flowers, usually blue, in axillary racemes. The American species is Veronica Americana.

entries.entry: Brook" mint`. Bot See Water mint.

entry.def: The bank of a brook.
A small white-flowered herb (Samolus Valerandi) found usually in wet places; water pimpernel.

entry.cs: Butcher's broom a plant (Ruscus aculeatus) of the Smilax family, used by butchers for brooms to sweep their blocks; -- called also knee holly. See Cladophyll. Dyer's broom a species of mignonette (Reseda luteola), used for dyeing yellow; dyer's weed; dyer's rocket. Spanish broom. See under Spanish.
entry.ety: OE. brom brome, AS. brōm; akin to LG. bram, D. brem, OHG. brāmo broom, thorn�bush, G. brombeere blackberry. Cf. Bramble n.

sn.def: A plant having twigs suitable for making brooms to sweep with when bound together; esp., the Cytisus scoparius of Western Europe, which is a low shrub with long, straight, green, angular branches, minute leaves, and large yellow flowers.
sn.q: No gypsy cowered o'er fires of furze and broom.

sn.def: An implement for sweeping floors, etc., commonly made of the panicles or tops of broom corn, bound together or attached to a long wooden handle; -- so called because originally made of the twigs of the broom.

entry.def: See Bream.

entries.entry: broom"corn broom" corn` . Bot A tall variety of grass (Sorghum vulgare technicum), having a joined stem, like maize, rising to the height of eight or ten feet, and bearing its seeds on a panicle with long stiff branches, of which brooms are made.

Broom" rape`. Bot A genus (Orobanche) of parasitic plants of Europe and Asia. They are destitute of chlorophyll, have scales instead of leaves, and spiked flowers, and grow attached to the roots of other plants, as furze, clover, flax, wild carrot, etc. The name is sometimes applied to other plants related to this genus, as Aphyllon uniflorumand Aphyllon Ludovicianum.

entry.def: A broomstick.
A stick used as a handle of a broom.
Of or pertaining to broom; overgrowing with broom; resembling broom or a broom.
entry.q: If land grow mossy or broomy.

entry.ety: CF. Gael. brothas. Cf. Brewis Broth
entry.def: Pottage made by pouring some boiling liquid on meal (esp. oatmeal), and stirring it. It is called beef brose, water brose, etc., according to the name of the liquid (beef broth, hot water, etc.) used.
Brittle.
Brittleness.

entry.ety: AS. broð; akin to OHG. brod brot; cf. Ir. broth, Gael. brot. √93. Cf. Brewis Brew
entry.def: Liquid in which flesh (and sometimes other substances, as barley or rice) has been boiled; thin or simple soup.
entry.q: I am sure by your unprejudiced discourses that you love broth better than soup.

entry.ety: OE. brothel brodel brethel, a prostitute, a worthless fellow, fr. AS. beróðan to ruin, destroy; cf. AS. breótan to break, and E. brittle. The term brothel house was confused with bordel brothel. CF. Bordel
entry.def: A house of lewdness or ill fame; a house frequented by prostitutes; a bawdyhouse.
One who frequents brothels.
Lewdness; obscenity; a brothel.

entries.entry:
Broth"er A brother having the same mother but different fathers is called a uterine brother, and one having the same father but a different mother is called an agnate brother, or in Law a consanguine brother. A brother having the same father and mother is called a brother-german or full brother. The same modifying terms are applied to sister or sibling. ☞ In Scripture, the term brother is applied to a kinsman by blood more remote than a son of the same parents, as in the case of Abraham and Lot, Jacob and Laban. In a more general sense, brother or brethren is used for fellow-man or fellow-men.
Brother Jonathan a humorous designation for the people of the United States collectively. The phrase is said to have originated from Washington's referring to the patriotic Jonathan Trumbull, governor of Connecticut, as “Brother Jonathan.” Blood brother. See under Blood.
brŭ�"ẽr n.; pl.Brothers brŭ�"ẽrz or Brethren brĕ�"rĕn. See Brethren. OE. brother, AS. brōðor; akin to OS. brothar, D. broeder, OHG. pruodar, G. bruder, Icel. brōðir, Sw. & Dan. broder, Goth. brōþar, Ir. brathair, W. brawd, pl. brodyr, Lith. brolis, Lett. brahlis, Russ. brat', Pol. & Serv. brat, OSlav. bratrŭ, L. frater, Skr. bhrātṛ, Zend bratar brother, Gr. fra`thr fra`twr, a clansman. The common plural is Brothers; in the solemn style, Brethren, OE. pl. brether bretheren, AS. dative sing. brēðer, nom. pl. brōðor brōðru. √258. Cf. Friar Fraternal
A male person who has the same father and mother with another person, or who has one of them only. In the latter case he is more definitely called a half brother, or brother of the half blood. Two of us in the churchyard lie, My sister and my brother.
One related or closely united to another by some common tie or interest, as of rank, profession, membership in a society, toil, suffering, etc.; -- used among judges, clergymen, monks, physicians, lawyers, professors of religion, etc. Abrotherof your order. We few, we happy few, we band of brothers, For he to-day that sheds his blood with me Shall be my brother.
One who, or that which, resembles another in distinctive qualities or traits of character. He also that is slothful in his work is brother to him that is a great waster. That April morn Of this the very brother. For of whom such massacre Make they but of their brethren, men of men?

entry.def: To make a brother of; to call or treat as a brother; to admit to a brotherhood.

entries.entry: Broth"er ger"man. Law A brother by both the father's and mother's side, in contradistinction to a uterine brother, one by the mother only.

entry.ety: Brother + -hood

sn.def: The state of being brothers or a brother.
An association for any purpose, as a society of monks; a fraternity.
The whole body of persons engaged in the same business, -- especially those of the same profession; as, the legal or medical brotherhood .
Persons, and, poetically, things, of a like kind.
sn.q: A brotherhood of venerable trees.

entries.entry: Broth"er-in-law` n.; pl.Brothers-in-law. The brother of one's husband or wife; also, the husband of one's sister; sometimes, the husband of one's wife's sister.

entry.def: The state or quality of being brotherly.
Of or pertaining to brothers; such as is natural for brothers; becoming to brothers; kind; affectionate; as, brotherly love.
Like a brother; affectionately; kindly.
entry.q: I speak butbrotherlyof him.

entry.def: any fish of the family Brotulidae.
a natural family of chiefly deep-sea fishes related to the Ophidiidae.
Braided; broidered.
entry.q: Alle his clothes brouded up and down.

entry.def: A light, enclosed carriage, with seats inside for two or four, and the fore wheels so arranged as to turn short.

sn.def: the confused noise of many voices.
a confused disturbance far greater than its cause merits.

entry.def: a genus of shade trees including the paper mulberry Broussonetia papyrifera) of East Asia.

cs.cd: to frown; to scowl.

entry.ety: OE. browe bruwe, AS. brū; akin to AS. brǣw breáw, eyelid, OFries. brē, D. braauw, Icel. brā brūn, OHG. prāwa, G. braue, OSlav. brŭvĭ, Russ. brove, Ir. brai, Ir. & Gael. abhra, Armor. abrant, Gr. 'ofry`s, Skr. bhrū. Cf. Bray a bank, Bridge

sn.def: The prominent ridge over the eye, with the hair that covers it, forming an arch above the orbit.
sn.q: And his arched brow, pulled o'er his eyes, With solemn proof proclaims him wise.

sn.def: The hair that covers the brow (ridge over the eyes); the eyebrow.
sn.q: 'T is not your inky brows, your brack silk hair.

sn.def: The forehead; as, a feverish brow .
sn.q: Beads of sweat have stood upon thy brow.

sn.def: The general air of the countenance.
sn.q: To whom thus Satan with contemptuous brow.
He told them with a masterly brow.

sn.def: The edge or projecting upper part of a steep place; as, the brow of a precipice; the brow of a hill.

entry.def: To bound to limit; to be at, or form, the edge of.
entry.q: Tending my flocks hard by i' the hilly crofts That brow this bottom glade.

entry.def: any of several herbs of the genus Browallia cultivated for their blue or violet or white flowers.

entry.vmorph: imp. Browbeat; p. p. Browbeaten; p. pr. & vb. n. Browbeating
entry.def: To depress or bear down with haughty, stern looks, or with arrogant speech and dogmatic assertions; to abash or disconcert by impudent or abusive words or looks; to bully; as, to browbeat witnesses.
entry.q: My grandfather was not a man to be browbeaten.

entry.def: The act of bearing down, abashing, or disconcerting, with stern looks, supercilious manners, or confident assertions.
entry.q: The imperious browbeatings and scorn of great men.

entry.def: Crowned; having the head encircled as with a diadem.
Embroidery.
entry.q: Of goldsmithrye, of browdyng, and of steel.

entry.def: Having (such) a brow; -- used in composition; as, dark-browed, stern-browed .
Without shame.

entry.cs:
Brown Bess the old regulation flintlock smoothbore musket, with bronzed barrel, formerly used in the British army. Brown bread Dark colored bread; esp. a kind made of unbolted wheat flour, sometimes called in the United States Graham bread. “He would mouth with a beggar though she smelt brown bread and garlic.” Shak. Dark colored bread made of rye meal and Indian meal, or of wheat and rye or Indian; rye and Indian bread. U.S Brown coal wood coal. See Lignite.
Brown hematite or Brown iron ore
Min the hydrous iron oxide, limonite, which has a brown streak. See Limonite. Brown holland. See under Holland. Brown paper dark colored paper, esp. coarse wrapping paper, made of unbleached materials. Brown spar Min a ferruginous variety of dolomite, in part identical with ankerite. Brown stone. See Brownstone. Brown stout a strong kind of porter or malt liquor. Brown study a state of mental abstraction or serious reverie. W. Irving.
entry.ety: OE. brun broun, AS. br�n; akin to D. bruin, OHG. br�n, Icel. br�nn, Sw. brun, Dan. bruun, G. braun, Lith. brunas, Skr. babhru. √93, 253. Cf. Bruin Beaver Burnish Brunette
entry.def: Of a dark color, of various shades between black and red or yellow.
entry.q: Cheeks brown as the oak leaves.

entry.def: A dark color inclining to red or yellow, resulting from the mixture of red and black, or of red, black, and yellow; a tawny, dusky hue.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Browned; p. pr. & vb. n. Browning

sn.def: To make brown or dusky.
sn.q: A trembling twilight o'er welkin moves,Browns the dim void and darkens deep the groves.

sn.def: To make brown by scorching slightly; as, to brown meat or flour.
To give a bright brown color to, as to gun barrels, by forming a thin coat of oxide on their surface.

entry.def: To become brown.
The dowitcher or red-breasted snipe. See Dowitcher.

entries.entry: Brown" bill` ☞ The black, or as it is sometimes called, the brown bill, was a kind of halberd, the cutting part hooked like a woodman's bill, from the back of which projected a spike, and another from the head.. Brown + bill cutting tool A bill or halberd of the 16th and 17th centuries. See 4th Bill. Many time, but for a sallet, my brainpan had been cleft with a brown bill.

entry.def: having a tan color from exposure to the sun; -- of skin color.

cs.cd: the peculiar, rapid, vibratory movement exhibited by the microscopic particles of substances when suspended in water or other fluids.

entry.def: Pertaining to Dr. Robert Brown , who first demonstrated (about 1827) the commonness of the motion described below.

entry.ety: So called from its supposed tawny or swarthy color
entry.def: An imaginary good-natured spirit, who was supposed often to perform important services around the house by night, such as thrashing, churning, sweeping.

sn.def: The act or operation of giving a brown color, as to gun barrels, etc.
A smooth coat of brown mortar, usually the second coat, and the preparation for the finishing coat of plaster.

entry.def: Somewhat brown.
The views or teachings of Robert Brown of the Brownists.
The doctrines of the Brunonian system of medicine. See Brunonian.

A follower of Robert Brown, of England, in the 16th century, who taught that every church is complete and independent in itself when organized, and consists of members meeting in one place, having full power to elect and depose its officers.
One who advocates the Brunonian system of medicine.

sn.def: darkness resulting from the extinction of lights (as in a city invisible to enemy aircraft).

a partial reduction in the amount of electric power available to customers in a region, such as by reduction of voltage or selective cutoff of certain customers; -- it occurs for example in summer when the demand for electricity for air-conditioning exceeds the supply, or when power to certain customers is cut off by a severe storm. It is contrasted with blackout, which is the total loss of electrical power in a region.

entry.def: The quality or state of being brown.
entry.q: Now like I brown (O lovely brown thy hair); Only in brownness beauty dwelleth there.

entries.entry: Brown race. The Malay or Polynesian race; -- loosely so called.

sn.def: A dark variety of sandstone, much used for building purposes.
a building, especially a dwelling, faced with brownstone{1}.

entries.entry: Brown" thrush". Zoöl A common American singing bird (Harporhynchus rufus), allied to the mocking bird; -- also called brown thrasher.

entry.def: A species of figwort or Scrophularia Scrophularia vernalis), and other species of the same genus, mostly perennials with inconspicuous coarse flowers.
Brown or, somewhat brown.
entry.q: Brownylocks.

entry.def: A beam that goes across a building.

entry.ety: OF. brost broust, sprout, shoot, F. brout browse, browsewood, prob. fr. OHG. burst, G. borste, bristle; cf. also Armor. brousta to browse. See Bristle n. Brush n.
entry.def: The tender branches or twigs of trees and shrubs, fit for the food of cattle and other animals; green food.
entry.q: Sheep, goats, and oxen, and the nobler steed, On browse, and corn, and flowery meadows feed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Browsed brouzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Browsing
entry.ety: For broust, OF. brouster bruster, F. brouter. See Browse n., and cf. Brut

sn.def: To eat or nibble off, as the tender branches of trees, shrubs, etc.; -- said of cattle, sheep, deer, and some other animals.
sn.q: Yes, like the stag, when snow the plasture sheets, The barks of trees thou browsedst.

sn.def: To feed on, as pasture; to pasture on; to graze.
sn.q: Fields . . . browsed by deep-uddered kine.

sn.def: To look casually through (a book, books, or a set of documents), reading those parts which arouse one's interest. Contrasted with scan, in which one typically is searching for something specific.
To look at a series of electronic documents on a computer screen by means of a browser{2.
To feed on the tender branches or shoots of shrubs or trees, as do cattle, sheep, and deer.
To pasture; to feed; to nibble; to graze.
To look casually through a book, books, or a set of documents, reading those parts which arouse one's interest.
To search through a group of items to find something, not previously specified, which may be of interest.
An animal that browses.

a computer program that permits the user to view multiple electronic documents in a flexible sequence by the process of activating hypertext “buttons” within one document, which serves as a reference to the location of related document. The term is currently (late 1990's) used mostly for programs which allow traversing hypertext paths in documents on the internet. A typical browser will permit the user to easily reverse direction, and view again documents previously accessed.

entry.def: Shrubs and bushes upon which animals browse.
Browse; also, a place abounding with shrubs where animals may browse.
entry.q: Browsings for the deer.

entry.def: A rounded organ between the eyes of the frog; the interocular gland.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: The Malayan sun bear.

entry.ety: Cf. F. brucine, fr. James Bruce, a Scottish traveler
entry.def: A powerful vegetable alkaloid, found, associated with strychnine, in the seeds of different species of Strychnos, especially in the Nux vomica. It is less powerful than strychnine. Called also brucia and brucina.

entry.ety: Named after Dr. A. Bruce of New York
entry.def: A white, pearly mineral, occurring thin and foliated, like talc, and also fibrous; a native magnesium hydrate.
The mineral chondrodite.
Wet and dirty; begrimed.
a genus of plants of the nightshade family, including some plants often placed in the genus Datura, such as the angel's trumpets.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: The rhesus monkey. See Rhesus.

entry.ety: D. bruin brown. In the epic poem of “Reynard the Fox” the bear is so called from his color. See Brown a.
entry.def: A bear; -- so called in popular tales and fables.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bruised; p. pr. & vb. n. Bruising
entry.ety: OE. brusen brisen brosen bresen, AS. br�san or fr. OF. bruiser bruisier bruser, to break, shiver, perh. from OHG. brochisōn. Cf. Break v. t.

sn.def: To injure, as by a blow or collision, without laceration; to contuse; as, to bruise one's finger with a hammer; to bruise the bark of a tree with a stone; to bruise an apple by letting it fall.
To break; as in a mortar; to bray, as minerals, roots, etc.; to crush.
sn.q: Nor bruise her flowerets with the armed hoofs.
sn.syn: To pulverize; bray; triturate; pound; contuse.

entry.def: To fight with the fists; to box.
entry.q: Bruising was considered a fine, manly, old English custom.

entry.def: An injury to the flesh of animals, or to plants, fruit, etc., with a blunt or heavy instrument, or by collision with some other body; a contusion; as, a bruise on the head; bruises on fruit.
entry.q: From the sole of the foot even unto the head there is no soundness in it; but wounds, and bruises.

entry.def: suffering from emotional injury; as, a bruised ego.

sn.def: injured without breaking the skin; as, a cut forehead and bruised cheek.
One who, or that which, bruises.
A boxer; a pugilist; hence, a strong, tough person; -- often used in the phrase big bruiser.
sn.q: Like a new bruiser on Broughtonic sand, Amid the lists our hero takes his stand.

sn.def: A concave tool used in grinding lenses or the speculums of telescopes.

entry.def: A plant supposed to heal bruises, as the true daisy, the soapwort, and the comfrey.

entry.ety: OE. bruit brut, noise, bruit, F. bruit, fr. LL. brugitus; cf. L. rugire to roar; perh. influenced by the source of E. bray to make a harsh noise, Armor. brud bruit

sn.def: Report; rumor; fame.
sn.q: The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.

sn.def: An abnormal sound of several kinds, heard on auscultation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bruited; p. pr. & vb. n. Bruiting
entry.def: To report; to noise abroad.
entry.q: I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. bruma winter
entry.def: The second month of the calendar adopted by the first French republic. It began thirty days after the autumnal equinox. See Vendemiaire.

entry.ety: L. brumalis, fr. bruma winter: cf. F. brumal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to winter.
entry.q: Thebrumalsolstice.

entry.ety: F. brume winter season, mist, L. bruma winter
entry.def: Mist; fog; vapors.
entry.q: The driftingbrume.

entry.ety: Birminghamformerly Bromwycham), Eng., “the great mart and manufactory of gilt toys, cheap jewelry,” etc
entry.def: Counterfeit; gaudy but worthless; sham.
entry.q: TheseBrummagemgentry.

entry.def: Foggy; misty.

entry.ety: See Broun a brook
entry.def: Same as Brun, a brook.

sn.def: a late breakfast or an early lunch.

entry.def: a sultanate in Northwestern Borneo.

sn.def: of or pertaining to Brunei; as, Bruneian oil production.
a native or inhabitant of Brunei.

entry.sn: being or having dark-colored skin and hair; contrasted with blond.Narrower terms: adust, sunburned burned brown by the sun; black, brown; black-haired, dark-haired; browned, suntanned, tanned; grizzled, roan; nutbrown

entry.ety: F. brunet brunette, brownish, dim. of brun brune, brown, fr. OHG. br�n. See Brown a.
entry.def: A girl or woman with a somewhat brown or dark complexion.

def2.def: Having a dark tint.

entry.ety: F. brugnoncf. It. brugna prugna), fr. L. prunum. See Prune n.
entry.def: A nectarine.

Pertaining to, or invented by, Brown; -- a term applied to a system of medicine promulgated in the 18th century by John Brown, of Scotland, the fundamental doctrine of which was, that life is a state of excitation produced by the normal action of external agents upon the body, and that disease consists in excess or deficiency of excitation.

entries.entry: Bruns"wick black`. See Japan black.
Bruns"wick green`. G. Braunschweiger grün, first made at Brunswick, in Germany An oxychloride of copper, used as a green pigment; also, a carbonate of copper similarly employed.

entry.ety: OE. brunt bront, fr. Icel. bruna to rush; cf. Icel. brenna to burn. Cf. Burn v. t.

sn.def: The heat, or utmost violence, of an onset; the strength or greatest fury of any contention; as, the brunt of a battle.
The force of a blow; shock; collision.
sn.q: And heavybruntof cannon ball.
It is instantly and irrecoverably scattered by our first brunt with some real affair of common life.

cs.cd: a form of the electric discharge characterized by a brushlike appearance of luminous rays diverging from an electrified body.

entry.ety: OE. brusche, OF. broche broce brosse, brushwood, F. brosse brush, LL. brustia bruscia, fr. OHG. brusta brust, bristle, G. borste bristle, bürste brush. See Bristle n., and cf. Browse

sn.def: An instrument composed of bristles, or other like material, set in a suitable back or handle, as of wood, bone, or ivory, and used for various purposes, as in removing dust from clothes, laying on colors, etc. Brushes have different shapes and names according to their use; as, clothes brush, paint brush, tooth brush, etc.
The bushy tail of a fox.
A tuft of hair on the mandibles.
Branches of trees lopped off; brushwood.
A thicket of shrubs or small trees; the shrubs and small trees in a wood; underbrush.
land covered with brush{5}; in Australia, a dense growth of vegetation in good soil, including shrubs and trees, mostly small.
A bundle of flexible wires or thin plates of metal, used to conduct an electrical current to or from the commutator of a dynamo, electric motor, or similar apparatus.
The act of brushing; as, to give one's clothes a brush ; a rubbing or grazing with a quick motion; a light touch; as, we got a brush from the wheel as it passed.
sn.q: As leaves] have with one winter's brush Fell from their boughts.

sn.def: A skirmish; a slight encounter; a shock or collision; as, to have a brush with an enemy; a brush with the law.
sn.q: Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong, And tempt not yet the brushes of the war.

sn.def: A short contest, or trial, of speed.
sn.q: Let us enjoy a brush across the country.

cs.cd: to remove from one's way, as with a brush.
to remove, as with a brush or brushing motion.
to paint, or make clean or bright with a brush; to cleanse or improve; to renew.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brushed brŭsht; p. pr. & vb. n. Brushing
entry.ety: OE. bruschen; cf. F. brosser. See Brush n.

sn.def: To apply a brush to, according to its particular use; to rub, smooth, clean, paint, etc., with a brush.
sn.q: A'brusheshis hat o' mornings.

sn.def: To touch in passing, or to pass lightly over, as with a brush.
sn.q: Some spread their sailes, some with strong oars sweep The waters smooth, and brush the buxom wave.
Brushed with the kiss of rustling wings.

sn.def: To remove or gather by brushing, or by an act like that of brushing, or by passing lightly over, as wind; -- commonly with off.
sn.q: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brushed With raven's feather from unwholesome fen.
And from the boughts brush off the evil dew.
You have commissioned me to paint your shop, and I have done my best to brush you up like your neighbors.

entry.def: To move nimbly in haste; to move so lightly as scarcely to be perceived; as, to brush by.
entry.q: Snatching his hat, he brushed off like the wind.

sn.def: p. p. of brush.
having a soft nap produced by brushing; as, a dress of brushed cotton.

entry.def: an artist's distinctive technique of applying paint with a brush.
One who, or that which, brushes.
The quality of resembling a brush; brushlike condition; shagginess.

sn.def: Constructed or used to brush with; as a brushing machine.
Brisk; light; as, a brushing gallop.

entry.ety: From George J. Brush, an American mineralogist
entry.def: A white or gray crystalline mineral consisting of the acid phosphate of calcium.

entries.entry: Brush" tur`key ☞ The brush turkeys live in the “brush,” and construct a common nest by collecting a large heap of decaying vegetable matter, which generates heat sufficient to hatch the numerous eggs (sometimes half a bushel) deposited in it by the females of the flock.. Zoöl A large, edible, gregarious bird of Australia (Talegalla Lathami) of the family Megapodidæ. Also applied to several allied species of New Guinea.

Brush" wheel`. A wheel without teeth, used to turn a similar one by the friction of bristles or something brushlike or soft attached to the circumference.
A circular revolving brush used by turners, lapidaries, silversmiths, etc., for polishing.

sn.def: Brush; a thicket or coppice of small trees and shrubs.
Small branches of trees cut off.

entry.def: Resembling a brush; shaggy; rough.
Same as Brusque.

entry.ety: F. brusque, from It. brusco brusque, tart, sour, perh. fr. L. (vitis labrusca wild (vine); or cf. OHG. bruttisc grim, fr. brutti terror
entry.def: Rough and prompt in manner; blunt; abrupt; bluff; as, a brusque man; a brusque style.
Quality of being brusque; roughness joined with promptness; bluntness.

entry.cs: Brussels carpet a kind of carpet made of worsted yarn fixed in a foundation web of strong linen thread. The worsted, which alone shows on the upper surface in drawn up in loops to form the pattern. Brussels ground a name given to the handmade ground of real Brussels lace. It is very costly because of the extreme fineness of the threads. Brussels lace an expensive kind of lace of several varieties, originally made in Brussels; as, Brussels point, Brussels ground, Brussels wire ground. Brussels net an imitation of Brussels ground, made by machinery. Brussels point. See Point lace. Brussels sprouts Bot a plant of the Cabbage family, which produces, in the axils of the upright stem, numerous small green heads, or “sprouts,” each a cabbage in miniature, of one or two inches in diameter; the thousand-headed cabbage. Brussels wire ground a ground for lace, made of silk, with meshes partly straight and partly arched.
entry.def: A city of Belgium, giving its name to a kind of carpet, a kind of lace, etc.

cs.cd: to bristle up.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brustled; p. pr. & vb. n. Brustling
entry.ety: OE. brustlien and brastlien, AS. brastlian, fr. berstan to burst, akin to G. prasseln to crackle. See Burst v. i.

sn.def: To crackle; to rustle, as a silk garment.
To make a show of fierceness or defiance; to bristle.

entry.def: A bristle.

entry.ety: F. brouter, OF. brouster. See Browse n.
entry.def: To browse.
See Birt.

entry.ety: Fr. lit. rough
entry.def: very dry; -- used of wine or champagne.

entry.ety: NL., neuter pl., fr. L. brutus heavy, stupid
entry.def: See Edentata.

entry.ety: Cf. F. brutal. See Brute a.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a brute; as, brutal nature.
sn.q: Above the rest ofbrutalkind.

sn.def: Like a brute; savage; cruel; inhuman; brutish; unfeeling; merciless; gross; as, brutal manners.
sn.q: Brutalintemperance.

sn.def: to treat brutally.
to cause to become like a brute; as, life in the concentration camp had brutalised him.

entry.def: to become brutal.
Brutish quality; brutality.

entries.entry:
Bru*tal"i*ty n.; pl.Brutalities. Cf. F. brutalité
The quality of being brutal; inhumanity; savageness; pitilessness.
An inhuman act. The . . . brutalities exercised in war.

entry.def: The act or process of making brutal; state of being brutalized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brutalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Brutalizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. brutaliser
entry.def: To make brutal; beasty; unfeeling; or inhuman.
To become brutal, inhuman, barbarous, or coarse and beasty.
entry.q: He mixed . . . with his countrymen, brutalized with them in their habits and manners.

entry.def: In a brutal manner; cruelly.

cs.cd: The application of predominantly physical effort to achieve a goal that could be accomplished with less effort if more carefully considered. Figuratively, repetitive or strenuous application of an obvious or simple tactic, as contrasted with a more clever stratagem achieving the same goal with less effort;as, the first prime numbers were discovered by the brute force repetition of the Sieve of Eratosthenes .

entry.ety: F. brut, nasc., brute, fem., raw, rough, rude, brutish, L. brutus stupid, irrational: cf. It. & Sp. bruto

sn.def: Not having sensation; senseless; inanimate; unconscious; without intelligence or volition; as, the brute earth; the brute powers of nature.
Not possessing reason, irrational; unthinking; as, a brute beast; the brute creation.
sn.q: A creature . . . not prone And brute as other creatures, but endued With sanctity of reason.

sn.def: Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of, a brute beast. Hence: Brutal; cruel; fierce; ferocious; savage; pitiless; as, brute violence.
sn.q: The influence of capital and mere brute labor.

sn.def: Having the physical powers predominating over the mental; coarse; unpolished; unintelligent.
sn.q: A great brute farmer from Liddesdale.

sn.def: Rough; uncivilized; unfeeling.
An animal destitute of human reason; any animal not human; esp. a quadruped; a beast.
sn.q: Brutes may be considered as either aërial, terrestrial, aquatic, or amphibious.

sn.def: A brutal person; a savage in heart or manners; as unfeeling or coarse person.

sn.def: Brutality.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Brutified; p. pr. & vb. n. Brutifying

entry.def: To make like a brute; to make senseless, stupid, or unfeeling; to brutalize.
entry.q: Any man not quite brutified and void of sense.

Man may . . . render himself brutish, but it is in vain that he would seek to take the rank and density of the brute.
entry.syn: Insensible; stupid; unfeeling; savage; cruel; brutal; barbarous; inhuman; ferocious; gross; carnal; sensual; bestial.

entry.def: The nature or characteristic qualities or actions of a brute; extreme stupidity, or beastly vulgarity.
Browsing.
Relating to bryology; as, bryological studies.
One versed in bryology.

entry.ety: Gr. � moss + -logy
entry.def: That part of botany which relates to mosses.
A bitter principle obtained from the root of the bryony (Bryonia alba and Bryonia dioica). It is a white, or slightly colored, substance, and is emetic and cathartic.

cs.cd: a plant (Tamus communis) so named from its dark glossy leaves and black root; black bindweed.

entry.ety: L. bryonia, Gr. brywni`a, fr. bry`ein to swell, esp. of plants
entry.def: The common name of several cucurbitaceous plants of the genus Bryonia. The root of Bryonia alba rough bryony or white bryony) and of Bryonia dioica is a strong, irritating cathartic.
See Cryptogamia.
any of numerous plants of the division Bryophyta.
of or pertaining to bryophytes.
the class of plants comprising the true mosses, having leafy rather than thalloid gametophytes; it comprises the orders Andreaeales; Bryales; Dicranales; Eubryales; and Sphagnales.

entry.note:
☞ They are often coralike in form and appearance, each small cell containing an individual zooid. Other species grow in delicate, flexible, branched forms, resembling moss, whence the name. Some are found in fresh water, but most are marine. The three principal divisions are Ectoprocta
Entoprocta , and Pterobranchia . See Cyclostoma Chilostoma, and Phylactolema.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � moss + � animal
entry.def: A class of Molluscoidea, including minute animals which by budding form compound colonies; -- called also Polyzoa.
Of or pertaining to the Bryozoa.

def2.def: One of the Bryozoa.

entry.ety: NL. See Bryozoa
entry.def: An individual zooid of a bryozoan coralline, of which there may be two or more kinds in a single colony. The zoœcia usually have a wreath of tentacles around the mouth, and a well developed stomach and intestinal canal; but these parts are lacking in the other zooids (Avicularia Oœcia, etc.).

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: The wild dog of northern India (Cuon primævus), supposed by some to be an ancestral species of the domestic dog.

entry.ety: Scot., of uncertain origin
entry.def: A lantern; also, the moon.
Strong malt liquor.

entry.ety: Cf. 2d Bubby
entry.def: A young brother; a little boy; -- a familiar term of address of a small boy.

entry.ety: Abbrev. from Bubble
entry.def: To throw out in bubbles; to bubble.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bubale. See Buffalo n.
entry.def: A large antelope (Alcelaphus bubalis) of Egypt and the Desert of Sahara, supposed by some to be the fallow deer of the Bible.

cs.cd: the bubale.

entry.def: Resembling a buffalo.
a genus of ruminants which in some classification systems is included in the genus Bos; the water buffaloes.

entry.ety: Cf. D. bobbel, Dan. boble, Sw. bubbla. Cf. Blob n.

sn.def: A thin film of liquid inflated with air or gas; as, a soap bubble; bubbles on the surface of a river.
sn.q: Beads of sweat have stood upon thy brow, Like bubbles in a late disturbed stream.

sn.def: A small quantity of air or gas within a liquid body; as, bubbles rising in champagne or aërated waters.
A globule of air, or globular vacuum, in a transparent solid; as, bubbles in window glass, or in a lens.
A small, hollow, floating bead or globe, formerly used for testing the strength of spirits.
The globule of air in the spirit tube of a level.

Anything that wants firmness or solidity; that which is more specious than real; a false show; a cheat or fraud; a delusive scheme; an empty project; a dishonest speculation; as, the South Sea bubble .
sn.q: Then a soldier . . . Seeking the bubble reputation Even in the cannon's mouth.

sn.def: A person deceived by an empty project; a gull.
sn.q: Ganny's a cheat, and I'm abubble.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bubbled; p. pr. & vb. n. Bubbling
entry.ety: Cf. D. bobbelen, Dan. boble. See Bubble n.

sn.def: To rise in bubbles, as liquids when boiling or agitated; to contain bubbles.
sn.q: The milk that bubbled in the pail.

sn.def: To run with a gurgling noise, as if forming bubbles; as, a bubbling stream.
To sing with a gurgling or warbling sound.
sn.q: At mine earBubbled the nightingale and heeded not.

The great Locke, who was seldom outwitted by false sounds, was nevertheless bubbled here.

sn.def: One who cheats.

sn.def: A fish of the Ohio river; -- so called from the noise it makes.

entries.entry: Bub"ble shell`. Zoöl A marine univalve shell of the genus Bulla and allied genera, belonging to the Tectibranchiata.

entry.sn: giving off bubbles; -- of a liquid.Narrower terms: foaming, frothing; effervescent; boiling

sn.def: stimulatingly lively, witty, and entertaining; -- of people.

Abounding in bubbles; bubbling.

entry.def: A woman's breast.

entry.ety: A corruption of brother
entry.def: Bub; -- a term of familiar or affectionate address to a small boy.

entries.entry:
Bu"bo bū"b� n.; pl.Buboes -b�z. LL. bubo the groin, a swelling in the groin, Gr. boubw`n
Med An inflammation, with enlargement, of a lymphatic gland, esp. in the groin, as in syphilis.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a bubo or buboes; characterized by buboes.

entries.entry: Bubonic plague. Med a severe and often fatal disease caused by infection with the bacterium Yersinia pestisformerly Pasteurella pestis), transmitted to man by the bite of fleas, themselves usually infected by biting infected rodents. It is characterized by the formation of buboes, most notably on the groin and armpits, and accompanied by weakness and high fever. The disease was known as the black death, and was responsible for several devastating plagues throughout the middle ages. When lungs became infected, the disease was called the pneumonic plague. It is still found occasionally in poor areas of undeveloped countries but is rare in developed countries.

entry.ety: Gr. boubw`n groin + � tumor: cf. F. bubonocèle
entry.def: An inguinal hernia; esp. that incomplete variety in which the hernial pouch descends only as far as the groin, forming a swelling there like a bubo.
A red pimple.

entry.ety: L. bucca cheek: cf. F. buccal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the mouth or cheeks.

entry.ety: F. boucan. See Buccaneer

sn.def: A wooden frame or grid for roasting, smoking, or drying meat over fire.
A place where meat is smoked.
Buccaned meat.

entry.ety: F. boucaner. See Buccaneer
entry.def: To expose (meat) in strips to fire and smoke upon a buccan.

entry.note: ☞ Primarily, one who dries and smokes flesh or fish after the manner of the Indians. The name was first given to the French settlers in Haiti or Hispaniola, whose business was to hunt wild cattle and swine.
entry.ety: F. boucanier, fr. boucaner to smoke or broil meat and fish, to hunt wild beasts for their skins, boucan a smoking place for meat or fish, gridiron for smoking: a word of American origin
entry.def: A robber upon the sea; a pirate; -- a term applied especially to the piratical adventurers who made depredations on the Spaniards in America in the 17th and 18th centuries.
To act the part of a buccaneer; to live as a piratical adventurer or sea robber.
Like a buccaneer; piratical.

entry.ety: L. bucina a crooked horn or trumpet
entry.def: Shaped or sounding like a trumpet; trumpetlike.

entry.ety: L., a trumpeter, fr. bucinare to sound the trumpet
entry.def: A muscle of the cheek; -- so called from its use in blowing wind instruments.

entry.ety: Buccinum + -oid
entry.def: Resembling the genus Buccinum, or pertaining to the Buccinidæ, a family of marine univalve shells. See Whelk, and Prosobranchiata.

entry.ety: L., a trumpet, a trumpet shell
entry.def: A genus of large univalve mollusks abundant in the arctic seas. It includes the common whelk (Buccinum undatum).

entry.ety: Gr. boy^s ox + ke`ntayros centaur

sn.def: A fabulous monster, half ox, half man.
The state barge of Venice, used by the doge in the ceremony of espousing the Adriatic.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, lit., ox-headed; � ox + � head

a genus of grasses comprising buffalo grass.

entry.ety: So called from Bucholz, a German chemist
entry.def: Same as Fibrolite.

A South African shrub (Barosma) with small leaves that are dotted with oil glands; also, the leaves themselves, which are used in medicine for diseases of the urinary organs, etc. Several species furnish the leaves.

entry.ety: Akin to LG. büke, Dan. byg, Sw. byk, G. bauche: cf. It. bucato, Prov. Sp. bugada, F. buée

sn.def: Lye or suds in which cloth is soaked in the operation of bleaching, or in which clothes are washed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bucked bŭkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Bucking
entry.ety: OE. bouken; akin to LG. büken, Dan. byge, Sw. byka, G. bauchen beuchen; cf. OF. buer. Cf. the preceding noun

entry.note: ☞ A male fallow deer is called a fawn in his first year; a pricket in his second; a sorel in his third; a sore in his fourth; a buck of the first head in his fifth; and a great buck in his sixth. The female of the fallow deer is termed a doe. The male of the red deer is termed a stag or hart and not a buck, and the female is called a hind.
☞ The word buck is much used in composition for the names of antelopes; as, bush buck, spring buck.
entry.cs: Blue buck. See under Blue. Water buck a South African variety of antelope (Kobus ellipsiprymnus). See Illust. of Antelope.
entry.ety: OE. buk bucke, AS. bucca bua, he-goat; akin to D. bok, OHG. pocch, G. bock, Ir. boc, W. bwch, Corn. byk; cf. Zend būza, Skr. bukka. √256. Cf. Butcher n.

a fellow; a guy.

entries.entry:
buckbean Buck" bean`
bēn`. Bot A perennial plant (Menyanthes trifoliata) of Europe and America which grows in moist and boggy places, having racemes of white, reddish, or purplish flowers and intensely bitter trifoliate leaves, sometimes used in medicine; marsh trefoil; -- called also bog bean. It often roots at the water margin and spreads across the surface. water shamrock, bogbean, bog myrtle, marsh trefoil, Menyanthes trifoliata.

to die.

entry.ety: OE. budde; cf. D. bot, G. butze butz, the core of a fruit, bud, LG. butte in hagebutte, hainbutte, a hip of the dog-rose, or OF. boton, F. bouton, bud, button, OF. boter to bud, push; all akin to E. beat. See Button

sn.def: A small protuberance on the stem or branches of a plant, containing the rudiments of future leaves, flowers, or stems; an undeveloped branch or flower.
A small protuberance on certain low forms of animals and vegetables which develops into a new organism, either free or attached. See Hydra.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Budded; p. pr. & vb. n. Budding

sn.def: To put forth or produce buds, as a plant; to grow, as a bud does, into a flower or shoot.

entry.def: To graft, as a plant with another or into another, by inserting a bud from the one into an opening in the bark of the other, in order to raise, upon the budded stock, fruit different from that which it would naturally bear.
entry.q: The apricot and the nectarine may be, and usually are, budded upon the peach; the plum and the peach are budded on each other.

entry.ety: Skr. buddha wise, sage, 'the enlightened' fr. budh to know

sn.def: The title of an incarnation of self-abnegation, virtue, and wisdom.

The title of Siddhartha or Gautama, a deified religious teacher of the Buddhists and the founder of Buddhism; called also Gautama Siddartha or Sakya Sinha (or Muni). From three newly discovered inscriptions of the emperor Asoka it follows that the 37th year of his reign was reckoned as the 257th from the death of Buddha. Hence it is inferred that Buddha died between 482 and 472 B. C. It being agreed that he lived to be eighty, he was born between 562 and 552 B. C. The Buddhist narratives of his life are overgrown with legend and myth. Senart seeks to trace in them the history of the sun-hero. Oldenberg finds in the most ancient traditions -- those of Ceylon -- at least definite historical outlines. Siddhartha, as Buddha was called before entering upon his great mission, was born in the country and tribe of the Sakhyas, at the foot of the Nepalese Himalayas. His father, Suddhodana, was rather a great and wealthy landowner than a king. He passed his youth in opulence at Kapila-vastu, the Sakhya capital. He was married and had a son Rahula, who became a member of his order. At the age of twenty-nine he left parents, wife, and only son for the spiritual struggle of a recluse. After seven years he believed himself possessed of perfect truth, and assumed the title of Buddha, 'the enlightened.' He is represented as having received a sudden illumination as he sat under the Bo-tree, or ' tree of knowledge,' at Bodhgaya or Buddha-Gaya. For twenty-eight or, as later narratives give it, forty-nine days he was variously tempted by Mara. One of his doubts was whether to keep for himself the knowledge won, or to share it. Love triumphed, and he began to preach, at first at Benares. For forty-four years he preached in the region of Benares and Behar. Primitive Buddhism is only to be gathered by inference from the literature of a later time. Buddha did not array himself against the old religion. The doctrines were rather the outgrowth of those of certain Brahmanical schools. His especial concern was salvation from sorrow, and so from existence. There are "four noble truths": (1) existence is suffering; (2) the cause of pain is desire, (3) cessation of pain is possible through the suppression of desire; (4) the way to this is the knowledge and observance of the "good law " of Buddha. The end is Nirvana, the cessation of existence. Buddhism was preached in the vulgar tongue, and had a popular literature and an elaborately organized monastic and missionary system. It made its way into Afghanistan, Bactriana., Tibet, and China. It passed away in India not from Brahman persecution, but rather from internal causes, such as its too abstract nature, too morbid view of life, relaxed discipline, and overgrowth of monasticism, and also because Shivaism and Vishnuism employed many of its own weapons more effectively. The system has been variously modified in dogma and rites in the many countries to which it has spread. It is supposed to number about 850,000,000 of adherents, who are principally in Ceylon, Tibet, China, and Japan.

entry.def: The religion based upon the doctrine originally taught by the Hindu sage Gautama Siddartha, surnamed Buddha, “the awakened or enlightened,” in the sixth century b. c., and adopted as a religion by the greater part of the inhabitants of Central and Eastern Asia and the Indian Islands. Buddha's teaching is believed to have been atheistic; yet it was characterized by elevated humanity and morality. It presents release from existence (a beatific enfranchisement, Nirvâna) as the greatest good. Buddhists believe in transmigration of souls through all phases and forms of life. Their number was estimated in 1881 at 470,000,000.
One who accepts the teachings of Buddhism.
Of or pertaining to Buddha, Buddhism, or the Buddhists.
Same as Buddhist a.

sn.def: The act or process of producing buds.

A process of asexual reproduction, in which a new organism or cell is formed by a protrusion of a portion of the animal or vegetable organism, the bud thus formed sometimes remaining attached to the parent stalk or cell, at other times becoming free; gemmation. See Hydroidea.
The act or process of ingrafting one kind of plant upon another stock by inserting a bud under the bark.

A burner consisting of two or more concentric Argand burners (the inner rising above the outer) and a central tube by which oxygen gas or common air is supplied.

It comprehends a general view of the finances of the country, with the proposed plan of taxation for the ensuing year. The term is sometimes applied to a similar statement in other countries.

entries.entry:
Buf"fa*lo
Buffalo berry Bot a shrub of the Upper Missouri (Sherherdia argentea) with acid edible red berries. Buffalo bird Zoöl an African bird of the genus Buphaga, of two species. These birds perch upon buffaloes and cattle, in search of parasites. Buffalo bug the carpet beetle. See under Carpet. Buffalo chips dry dung of the buffalo, or bison, used for fuel. U.S Buffalo clover Bot a kind of clover (Trifolium reflexum and Trifoliumsoloniferum) found in the ancient grazing grounds of the American bison. Buffalo cod Zoöl a large, edible, marine fish (Ophiodon elongatus) of the northern Pacific coast; -- called also blue cod, and cultus cod.
Buffalo flyorBuffalo gnat
Zoöl a small dipterous insect of the genus Simulium, allied to the black fly of the North. It is often extremely abundant in the lower part of the Mississippi valley and does great injury to domestic animals, often killing large numbers of cattle and horses. In Europe the Columbatz fly is a species with similar habits. Buffalo grass Bot a species of short, sweet grass (Buchloë dactyloides), from two to four inches high, covering the prairies on which the buffaloes, or bisons, feed. U.S Buffalo nut Bot the oily and drupelike fruit of an American shrub (Pyrularia oleifera); also, the shrub itself; oilnut. Buffalo robe the skin of the bison of North America, prepared with the hair on; -- much used as a lap robe in sleighs.
n.; pl.Buffaloes. Sp. bufalocf. It. bufalo, F. buffle), fr. L. bubalus bufalus, a kind of African stag or gazelle; also, the buffalo or wild ox, fr. Gr. � buffalo, prob. fr. � ox. See Cow the animal, and cf. Buff the color, and Bubale
Zoöl A species of the genus Bos or Bubalus Bubalus bubalus), originally from India, but now found in most of the warmer countries of the eastern continent. It is larger and less docile than the common ox, and is fond of marshy places and rivers.
Zoöl A very large and savage species of the same genus (Syncerus Caffer syn. Bubalus Caffer) found in South Africa; -- called also Cape buffalo.
Zoöl Any species of wild ox.
Zoöl The bison of North America.
A buffalo robe. See Buffalo robe, below.
Zoöl The buffalo fish. See Buffalofish, below.

sn.def: any of several large carplike North American fish.

Any of several large fresh-water fishes of the family Catostomidæalso called suckers see Sucker family), of the Mississippi valley. The red-mouthed or brown (Ictiobus bubalus), the big-mouthed buffalofish Ictiobus cyrinellus, formerly called Bubalichthys urus), the black buffalofish Ictiobus niger), and the small-mouthed buffalofish Ictiobus bubalus, formerly called Bubalichthys altus), are among the more important species used as food.

entry.def: A United States five-cent coin minted from 1913 to 1937 having an image of an American bison (“buffalo”) on its reverse, and an American Indian on the obverse.

A black soldier of the United States army who served in the American west in the late 1800's, often as an indian fighter, and usually as part of an all-black troop; -- the name was given by the indians due to their their kinky hair, and the name was believed also to be a compliment on their courage.

entries.entry:
Buf"fel duck bŭf"fĕl dŭk`. See Buffalo
Zoöl A small duck (Charitonetta albeola); the spirit duck, or butterball. The head of the male is covered with numerous elongated feathers, and thus appears large. Called also bufflehead.

entry.ety: Prop a striker. See Buffet a blow

sd.def: An elastic apparatus or fender, for deadening the jar caused by the collision of bodies; as, a buffer at the end of a railroad car.
A pad or cushion forming the end of a fender, which receives the blow; -- sometimes called buffing apparatus.

sn.def: One who polishes with a buff.
A wheel for buffing; a buff.
A good-humored, slow-witted fellow; -- usually said of an elderly man.

a substance or mixture of substances which can absorb or neutralize a certain quantity of acid or base and thus keep the degree of acidity or alkalinity of a solution (as measured by pH) relatively stable. Sometimes the term is used in a medical context to mean antacid.
a data storage device or portion of memory used to temporarily store input or output data until the receiving device is ready to process it.
any object or person that shields another object or person from harm, shock, or annoyance; as, the President's staff is his buffer from constant interruptions of his work.

entry.def: to add a buffer{5} to (a solution), so as to reduce unwanted fluctuation of acidity.
containing a buffer{5}; -- of solutions, usually aqueous solutions.
The head of a buffer, which recieves the concussion, in railroad carriages.

entry.ety: trademark
entry.def: a brand of aspirin tablets coated with a substance capable of neutralizing acid (a “buffer”); -- sometimes applied generically to any buffered aspirin preparation.

entry.ety: F. buffet, LL. bufetum; of uncertain origin; perh. fr. the same source as E. buffet a blow, the root meaning to puff, hence (cf. puffed up) the idea of ostentation or display

sn.def: A cupboard or set of shelves, either movable or fixed at one side of a room, for the display of plate, china, etc., a sideboard.
sn.q: Not when a gilt buffet's reflected pride Turns you from sound philosophy aside.

sn.def: A counter for food or refreshments.
A restaurant containing such a counter, as at a railroad station, or place of public gathering.

A meal set out on a buffet[2], arranged so that guests may serve themselves and choose those items that they desire; as, a buffet dinner. Diners usually take a plate provided and move in a line past the items on the buffet[2], placing those items they desire on the plate, to be eaten at some convenient place.

entry.ety: OE. buffet boffet, OF. buffet a slap in the face, a pair of bellows, fr. buffe blow, cf. F. bouffer to blow, puff; prob. akin to E. puff. For the meaning slap blow, cf. F. soufflet a slap, souffler to blow. See Puff v. i., and cf. Buffet sidebroad, Buffoon

sn.def: A blow with the hand; a slap on the face; a cuff.
sn.q: When on his cheek a buffet fell.

sn.def: A blow from any source, or that which affects like a blow, as the violence of winds or waves; a stroke; an adverse action; an affliction; a trial; adversity.
sn.q: Those planks of tough and hardy oak that used for yeas to brave the buffets of the Bay of Biscay.
Fortune's buffets and rewards.

sn.def: A small stool; a stool for a buffet or counter.
sn.q: Go fetch us a light buffet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Buffeted; p. pr. & vb. n. Buffeting
entry.ety: OE. buffeten, OF. buffeter. See the preceding noun

sn.def: To strike with the hand or fist; to box; to beat; to cuff; to slap.
sn.q: They spit in his face and buffeted him.

sn.def: To affect as with blows; to strike repeatedly; to strive with or contend against; as, to buffet the billows.
sn.q: The sudden hurricane in thunder roars,Buffets the bark, and whirls it from the shores.
You are lucky fellows who can live in a dreamland of your own, instead of being buffeted about the world.

sn.def: To deaden the sound of (bells) by muffling the clapper.
To exercise or play at boxing; to strike; to smite; to strive; to contend.
sn.q: If I might buffet for my love, or bound my horse for her favors, I could lay on like a butcher.

sn.def: To make one's way by blows or struggling.
sn.q: Strove to buffet to land in vain.

entry.def: struck repeatedly; -- used especially of impact from winds, and sometimes metaphorically; as, buffeted by criticism.
One who buffets; a boxer.

sn.def: A striking with the hand.
A succession of blows; continued violence, as of winds or waves; afflictions; adversity.
sn.q: He seems to have been a plant of slow growth, but . . . fitted to endure the buffeting on the rudest storm.

entry.ety: So called from resembling buff �eather
entry.def: A sort of coarse stuff; as, buffin gowns.

entries.entry: Buff"ing ap`pa*ra"tus. See Buffer, 1.

entry.ety: OE., from F. buffle. See Buffalo
entry.def: The buffalo.
To puzzle; to be at a loss.

entry.ety: Buffle + head

sn.def: One who has a large head; a heavy, stupid fellow.
sn.q: What makes you stare so, bufflehead?

sn.def: The buffel duck. See Buffel duck.

entry.def: Having a large head, like a buffalo; dull; stupid; blundering.
entry.q: So fell this buffle-headed giant.

entry.ety: It. See Buffoon
entry.def: The comic actor in an opera.

entry.ety: F. bouffoncf. It. buffone buffo buffa, puff of wind, vanity, nonsense, trick), fr. bouffer to puff out, because the buffoons puffed out their cheeks for the amusement of the spectators. See Buffet a blow
entry.def: A man who makes a practice of amusing others by low tricks, antic gestures, etc.; a droll; a mimic; a harlequin; a clown; a merry-andrew.
Characteristic of, or like, a buffoon.
entry.q: Buffoonstories.
To divert the audience with buffoon postures and antic dances.

entry.def: To act the part of a buffoon.
To treat with buffoonery.

entries.entry:
Buf*foon"er*y n.; pl.Buffooneries. F. bouffonnerie
The arts and practices of a buffoon, as low jests, ridiculous pranks, vulgar tricks and postures. Nor that it will ever constitute a wit to conclude a tart piece of buffoonery with a “What makes you blush?”

entry.def: Like a buffoon; consisting in low jests or gestures.
The practices of a buffoon; buffoonery.
Low; vulgar.
entry.q: Apish tricks and buffoonly discourse.

cs.cd: the coagulated plasma of blood when the red corpuscles have so settled out that the coagulum appears nearly colorless. This is common in diseased conditions where the corpuscles run together more rapidly and in denser masses than usual.

entry.def: Resembling, or characterized by, buff.

entry.ety: L. bufo a toad
entry.def: A genus of Amphibia including various species of toads.
a natural family comprising the true toads.

entry.ety: L. bufo toad: cf. F. bufonite
entry.def: An old name for a fossil consisting of the petrified teeth and palatal bones of fishes belonging to the family of Pycnodonts (thick teeth), whose remains occur in the oölite and chalk formations; toadstone; -- so named from a notion that it was originally formed in the head of a toad.

entry.note: ☞ According to popular usage in England and among housekeepers in America around 1900, bug, when not joined with some qualifying word, was used specifically for bedbug. As a general term it is now used very loosely in America as a colloquial term to mean any small crawling thing, such as an insect or arachnid, and was formerly used still more loosely in England. “God's rare workmanship in the ant, the poorest bug that creeps.” Rogers Naaman). “This bug with gilded wings.” Pope.
In some communities in the 1990's, the incidence of AIDS is high and AIDS is referred to colloquially as “the bug”.
entry.cs: Bait bug. See under Bait. Bug word swaggering or threatening language. Obs Beau. & Fl.
entry.ety: OE. bugge, fr. W. bwg bwgan, hobgoblin, scarecrow, bugbear. Cf. Bogey Boggle

sn.def: A bugbear; anything which terrifies.
sn.q: Sir, spare your threats: The bug which you would fright me with I seek.

sn.def: A general name applied to various insects belonging to the Hemiptera; as, the squash bug; the chinch bug, etc.
An insect of the genus Cimex, especially the bedbug (Cimex lectularius). See Bedbug.
One of various species of Coleoptera; as, the ladybug; potato bug, etc.; loosely, any beetle.
One of certain kinds of Crustacea; as, the sow bug; pill bug; bait bug; salve bug, etc.
An error in the coding of a computer program, especially one causing the program to malfunction or fail. See, for example, year 2000 bug.
sn.q: That's not abug, it's a feature!

sn.def: Any unexpected defect or flaw, such as in a machine or a plan.
A hidden electronic listening device, used to hear or record conversations surreptitiously.
An infectious microorganism; a germ{4}.
An undiagnosed illness, usually mild, believed to be caused by an infectious organism.
An enthusiast; -- used mostly in combination, as a camera bug .

entry.def: to annoy; to bother or pester.

entry.ety: See Bug
entry.def: Something frightful, as a specter; anything imaginary that causes needless fright; something used to excite needless fear; also, something really dangerous, or an imaginary monster, used to frighten children, etc.
entry.q: Bugaboosto fright ye.
But, to the world no bugbear is so great As want of figure and a small estate.
The bugaboo of the liberals is the church pray.
The great bugaboo of the birds is the owl.

sn.def: a source of concern; as, the old bugaboo of inflation still bothers them.
sn.syn: Hobgoblin; goblin; specter; ogre; scarecrow; bogeyman; boogeyman; booger.

entry.def: A perennial white-flowered herb of the order Ranunculaceæ and genus Cimiciguga; bugwort. There are several species.
Same as Bugaboo.

def2.def: Causing needless fright.

entry.def: To alarm with idle phantoms.
The menhaden.

entry.ety: F. bougre, fr. LL. Bulgarus, a Bulgarian, and also a heretic; because the inhabitants of Bulgaria were infected with heresy. Those guilty of the crime of buggery were called heretics, because in the eyes of their adversaries there was nothing more heinous than heresy, and it was therefore thought that the origin of such a vice could only be owing to heretics

sn.def: One guilty of buggery or unnatural vice; a sodomite.
A wretch; -- sometimes used humorously or in playful disparagement.

entry.ety: OF. bougrerie bogrerie, heresy. See Bugger
entry.def: Unnatural sexual intercourse; sodomy.

entry.ety: From Buggy a.
entry.def: The state of being infested with bugs.

entry.ety: From Bug
entry.def: Infested or abounding with bugs.

entries.entry:
Bug"gy
Buggy cultivator a cultivator with a seat for the driver. Buggy plow a plow, or set of plows, having a seat for the driver; -- called also sulky plow.
n.; pl.Buggies.
A light one horse two-wheeled vehicle. Eng Villebeck prevailed upon Flora to drive with him to the race in a buggy.
A light, four-wheeled vehicle, usually with one seat, and with or without a calash top. U.S

entry.ety: OE. bugle buffalo, buffalo's horn, OF. bugle, fr. L. buculus a young bullock, steer, dim. of bos ox. See Cow the animal
entry.def: A sort of wild ox; a buffalo.

entry.ety: See Bugle a wild ox

sn.def: A horn used by hunters.

A copper instrument of the horn quality of tone, shorter and more conical that the trumpet, sometimes keyed; formerly much used in military bands, very rarely in the orchestra; now superseded by the cornet; -- called also the Kent bugle.

entry.ety: LL. bugulus a woman's ornament: cf. G. bügel a bent piece of metal or wood, fr. the same root as G. biegen to bend, E. bow to bend
entry.def: An elongated glass bead, of various colors, though commonly black.

entry.ety: From Bugle a bead
entry.def: Jet black.
entry.q: Bugleeyeballs.

cs.cd: the Ajuga chamæpitys.

entry.ety: F. bugle; cf. It. bugola, L. bugillo
entry.def: A plant of the genus Ajuga of the Mint family, a native of the Old World.
Ornamented with bugles.

entries.entry:
Bu"gle horn`. A bugle. One blast upon his bugle horn Were worth a thousand men.
A drinking vessel made of horn. Obs And drinketh of his bugle horn the wine.

entry.def: One who plays on a bugle.
A plant of the Mint family and genus Lycopus; esp. Lycopus Virginicus, which has mild narcotic and astringent properties, and is sometimes used as a remedy for hemorrhage.

entries.entry:
Bu"gloss
Small wild bugloss the Asperugo procumbens and the Lycopsis arvensis. Viper's bugloss a species of Echium.
n.; pl.Buglosses. F. buglosse, L. buglossa buglossus, fr. Gr. � oxtongue � ox + � tongue Bot A plant of the genus Anchusa, and especially the Anchusa officinalis, sometimes called alkanet; oxtongue.

entry.def: Bugbane.

entry.ety: From A. Ch. Boule, a French carver in wood
entry.def: Decorative woodwork in which tortoise shell, yellow metal, white metal, etc., are inlaid, forming scrolls, cartouches, etc.
See Bulbul.

entry.ety: OE. bur a whetstone for scythes
entry.def: A cellular, flinty rock, used for mill stones.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Built bĭlt; p. pr. & vb. n. Building. The regular imp. & p. p. Builded is antiquated
entry.ety: OE. bulden bilden, AS. byldan to build, fr. bold house; cf. Icel. bōl farm, abode, Dan. bol small farm, OSw. bol böle, house, dwelling, fr. root of Icel. būa to dwell; akin to E. be bower boor. √97

sn.def: To erect or construct, as an edifice or fabric of any kind; to form by uniting materials into a regular structure; to fabricate; to make; to raise.
sn.q: Nor aught availed him now To have built in heaven high towers.

sn.def: To raise or place on a foundation; to form, establish, or produce by using appropriate means.
sn.q: Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks.

sn.def: To increase and strengthen; to increase the power and stability of; to settle, or establish, and preserve; -- frequently with up; as, to build up one's constitution.
