sn.q: I commend you to God, and to the word of his grace, which is able to build you up.
sn.syn: To erect; construct; raise; found; frame.

sn.def: To exercise the art, or practice the business, of building.
To rest or depend, as on a foundation; to ground one's self or one's hopes or opinions upon something deemed reliable; to rely; as, to build on the opinions or advice of others.

entry.def: Form or mode of construction; general figure; make; as, the build of a ship; a great build on a man.
One who builds; one whose occupation is to build, as a carpenter, a shipwright, or a mason.
entry.q: In the practice of civil architecture, the builder comes between the architect who designs the work and the artisans who execute it.

sn.def: The act of constructing, erecting, or establishing.
sn.q: Hence it is that the building of our Sion rises no faster.

sn.def: The art of constructing edifices, or the practice of civil architecture.
sn.q: The execution of works of architecture necessarily includes building; but building is frequently employed when the result is not architectural.

sn.def: That which is built; a fabric or edifice constructed, as a house, a church, etc.
sn.q: Thy sumptuous buildings and thy wife's attire Have cost a mass of public treasury.

sn.def: the act of building up an accumulation.
the events, such as advertising or publicity, causing increased interest in some coming event.
sn.illu: The buildup to Superbowl XXIV was the most intense of the series.

entry.def: Shape; build; form of structure; as, the built of a ship.
Formed; shaped; constructed; made; -- often used in composition and preceded by the word denoting the form; as, frigate-built, clipper-built, etc.
entry.q: Like the generality of Genoese countrywomen, strongly built.

entry.def: strong and heavily built; -- of people.
entry.syn: beefy, burly, husky, strapping, strong, vigorous.

entries.entry: Buke" mus"lin. See Book muslin.

entry.def: See Backsheesh.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: An East Indian insectivorous mammal (Gymnura Rafflesii), somewhat like a rat in appearance, but allied to the hedgehog.

cs.cd: the eyeball.
the “root,” or part whence the hair originates.
the medulla oblongata, often called simply bulb.
the vascular and nervous papilla contained in the cavity of the tooth.

entry.ety: L. bulbus, Gr. bolbo`s: cf. F. bulbe

sn.def: A spheroidal body growing from a plant either above or below the ground (usually below), which is strictly a bud, consisting of a cluster of partially developed leaves, and producing, as it grows, a stem above, and roots below, as in the onion, tulip, etc. It differs from a corm in not being solid.
A name given to some parts that resemble in shape certain bulbous roots; as, the bulb of the aorta.
An expansion or protuberance on a stem or tube, as the bulb of a thermometer, which may be of any form, as spherical, cylindrical, curved, etc.
a light bulb.

entry.def: To take the shape of a bulb; to swell.

entry.ety: L. bulbaceus. See Bulb n.
entry.def: Bulbous.
Of or pertaining to bulb; especially, in medicine, pertaining to the bulb of the spinal cord, or medulla oblongata; as, bulbar paralysis.
Having a bulb; round-headed.

entry.ety: Dim., fr. bulb, n
entry.def: A separable bulb formed on some flowering plants.

entry.ety: Bulb,n.+ -ferous: cf. F. bulbifère
entry.def: Producing bulbs.

entry.ety: Dim. fr. bulb

sn.def: A small or secondary bulb; hence, now almost exclusively: An aërial bulb or deciduous bud, produced in the leaf axils, as in the tiger lily, or relpacing the flowers, as in some onions, and capable, when separated, of propagating the plant; -- called also bulblet and brood bud.
A small hollow bulb, such as an enlargement in a small vessel or tube.

entry.ety: Bulb,n.+ -let
entry.def: A small bulb, either produced on a larger bulb, or on some aërial part of a plant, as in the axils of leaves in the tiger lily, or replacing the flowers in some kinds of onion.
Bulbous.

entry.ety: Bulb,n.+ tuber
entry.def: A corm.

entry.ety: L. bulbosus: cf. F. bulbeux. See Bulb n.
entry.def: Having or containing bulbs, or a bulb; growing from bulbs; bulblike in shape or structure.

entry.ety: Per
entry.def: The Persian nightingale (Pycnonotus jocosus). The name is also applied to several other Asiatic singing birds, of the family Timaliidæ. The green bulbuls belong to the Chloropsis and allied genera.

entry.ety: L. bulbulus, dim. of bulbus. See Bulb n.
entry.def: A small bulb; a bulblet.

entry.ety: Dim. of bull
entry.def: A little bull.

entry.cs: Bulge ways. Naut See Bilge ways.
entry.ety: OE. bulge a swelling; cf. AS. belgan to swell, OSw. bulgja, Icel. bōlginn swollen, OHG. belgan to swell, G. bulge leathern sack, Skr. bṛh to be large, strong; the root meaning to swell. Cf. Bilge Belly Billow Bouge n.

sn.def: The bilge or protuberant part of a cask.
A swelling, protuberant part; a bending outward, esp. when caused by pressure; as, a bulge in a wall.
The bilge of a vessel. See Bilge, 2.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bulged; p. pr. & vb. n. Bulging

sn.def: To swell or jut out; to bend outward, as a wall when it yields to pressure; to be protuberant; as, the wall bulges .
To bilge, as a ship; to founder.
sn.q: And scattered navies bulge on distant shores.

entry.ety: From Bulge
entry.def: A driver or a brassy with a convex face.

entry.sn: curving or bulging outward. Opposite of concave.Narrower terms: biconvex, convexo-convex, lenticular, lentiform; broken-backed, hogged; convexo-concave; gibbous, gibbose; planoconvex Also See: protrusive. convex.

sn.def: curving outward.

entry.ety: Turkish
entry.def: parched crushed wheat.
Bulged; bulging; bending, or tending to bend, outward.

entry.ety: NL. bulimia, fr. Gr. boylimi`a, lit., ox-hunger; boy^s ox + limo`s hunger: cf. F. boulimie

sn.def: A disease in which there is a perpetual and insatiable appetite for food; a diseased and voracious appetite.

a disordered eating habit characterized by occasional episodes of excessive eating, followed by self-induced vomiting or abuse of laxatives, to avoid gaining weight; it is often accompanied by feelings of guilt; -- called also bulimia nervosa and binge-purge syndrome. It is observed mainly in young women of normal weight.
of or pertaining to bulimia.
suffering from bulimia.

entry.ety: L. bulimus hunger. See Bulimy
entry.def: A genus of land snails having an elongated spiral shell, often of large size. The species are numerous and abundant in tropical America.

entry.cs:
Barrel bulk. See under Barrel. To break bulk Naut to begin to unload or more the cargo. In bulk in a mass; loose; not inclosed in separate packages or divided into separate parts; in such shape that any desired quantity may be taken or sold.
Laden in bulk Stowed in bulk
having the cargo loose in the hold or not inclosed in boxes, bales, or casks. Sale by bulk a sale of goods as they are, without weight or measure.
entry.ety: OE. bulke bolke, heap; cf. Dan. bulk lump, clod, OSw. bolk crowd, mass, Icel. b�lkast to be bulky. Cf. Boll n. Bile a boil, Bulge n.

sn.def: Magnitude of material substance; dimensions; mass; size; as, an ox or ship of great bulk .
sn.q: Against these forces there were prepared near one hundred ships; not so great of bulk indeed, but of a more nimble motion, and more serviceable.

sn.def: The main mass or body; the largest or principal portion; the majority; as, the bulk of a debt.
sn.q: The bulk of the people must labor, Burke told them, “to obtain what by labor can be obtained.”

sn.def: The cargo of a vessel when stowed.
The body.
sn.q: My liver leaped within my bulk.
sn.syn: Size; magnitude; dimension; volume; bigness; largeness; massiveness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bulked; p. pr. & vb. n. Bulking
entry.def: To appear or seem to be, as to bulk or extent; to swell.
entry.q: The fame of Warburton possibly bulked larger for the moment.

entry.ety: Icel. bālkr a beam, partition. Cf. Balk n. & v.
entry.def: A projecting part of a building.
entry.q: Here, stand behind this bulk.

entry.def: A person employed to ascertain the bulk or size of goods, in order to fix the amount of freight or dues payable on them.

cs.cd: a line beyond which a wharf must not project; -- usually, the harbor line.

entry.ety: See Bulk part of a building

sn.def: A partition in a vessel, to separate apartments on the same deck.
A structure of wood or stone, to resist the pressure of earth or water; a partition wall or structure, as in a mine; the limiting wall along a water front.

entry.def: Greatness in bulk; size.
Of great bulk or dimensions; of great size; large; thick; massive; as, bulky volumes.
entry.q: A bulky digest of the revenue laws.

entry.note: ☞ The wild bull of the Old Testament is thought to be the oryx, a large species of antelope.
entry.cs: Bull baiting the practice of baiting bulls, or rendering them furious, as by setting dogs to attack them. John Bull a humorous name for the English, collectively; also, an Englishman. “Good-looking young John Bull.” W. D.Howells. To take the bull by the horns to grapple with a difficulty instead of avoiding it.
entry.ety: OE. bule bul bole; akin to D. bul, G. bulle, Icel. boli, Lith. bullus, Lett. bollis, Russ. vol'; prob. fr. the root of AS. bellan, E. bellow

sn.def: The male of any species of cattle (Bovidæ); hence, the male of any large quadruped, as the elephant; also, the male of the whale.
One who, or that which, resembles a bull in character or action.

sd.def: Taurus, the second of the twelve signs of the zodiac.
A constellation of the zodiac between Aries and Gemini. It contains the Pleiades.
sd.q: At last from Aries rolls the bounteous sun, And the bright Bull receives him.

sn.def: One who operates in expectation of a rise in the price of stocks, or in order to effect such a rise. See 4th Bear n., 5.
a ludicrously false statement; nonsense. Also used as an expletive.
sn.syn: bullshit, Irish bull, horseshit, shit, crap, crapola, bunk, bunkum, buncombe, guff, nonsense, rot, tommyrot, balderdash, hogwash, dogshit.

entry.cs: Bull bat Zoöl the night hawk; -- so called from the loud noise it makes while feeding on the wing, in the evening. Bull calf. A stupid fellow. Bull mackerel Zoöl the chub mackerel. Bull pump Mining a direct single-acting pumping engine, in which the steam cylinder is placed above the pump. Bull snake Zoöl the pine snake of the United States. Bull stag a castrated bull. See Stag. Bull wheel a wheel, or drum, on which a rope is wound for lifting heavy articles, as logs, the tools in well boring, etc.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a bull; resembling a bull; male; large; fierce.
To be in heat; to manifest sexual desire as cows do.
To endeavor to raise the market price of; as, to bull railroad bonds; to bull stocks; to bull Lake Shore; to endeavor to raise prices in; as, to bull the market. See 1st Bull n., 4.

cs.cd: an edict or imperial constitution made by the emperor Charles IV. (1356), containing what became the fundamental law of the German empire; -- so called from its golden seal.

entry.ety: OE. bulle, fr. L. bulla bubble, stud, knob, LL., a seal or stamp: cf. F. bulle. Cf. Bull a writing, Bowl a ball, Boil v. i.

sn.def: A seal. See Bulla.

A letter, edict, or respect, of the pope, written in Gothic characters on rough parchment, sealed with a bulla, and dated “a die Incarnationis,” i. e., “from the day of the Incarnation.” See Apostolical brief, under Brief.
sn.q: A fresh bull of Leo's had declared how inflexible the court of Rome was in the point of abuses.

sn.def: A grotesque blunder in language; an apparent congruity, but real incongruity, of ideas, contained in a form of expression; so called, perhaps, from the apparent incongruity between the dictatorial nature of the pope's bulls and his professions of humility.
sn.q: And whereas the papist boasts himself to be a Roman Catholic, it is a mere contradiction, one of the pope's bulls, as if he should say universal particular; a Catholic schimatic.

entries.entry:
Bul"la Bul"la n.; pl.Bullæ. L. bulla bubble. See Bull an edict
Med A bleb; a vesicle, or an elevation of the cuticle, containing a transparent watery fluid.
Anat The ovoid prominence below the opening of the ear in the skulls of many animals; as, the tympanic or auditory bulla .
A leaden seal for a document; esp. the round leaden seal attached to the papal bulls, which has on one side a representation of St. Peter and St. Paul, and on the other the name of the pope who uses it.
Zoöl A genus of marine shells. See Bubble shell.

entry.ety: OE. bolas bolace, OF. beloce; of Celtic origin; cf. Arm. bolos polos, Gael. bulaistear
entry.def: A small European plum (Prunus communis, var. insitita). See Plum.
The bully tree.

cs.cd: Gothic letters used in papal bulls.

entry.ety: See Bull an edict
entry.def: Pertaining to, or used in, papal bulls.

entry.ety: LL. bullarium: cf. F. bullairie. See Bull an edict
entry.def: A collection of papal bulls.

entries.entry:
Bul"la*ry n.; pl.Bullaries -rĭz. Cf. Boilary
A place for boiling or preparing salt; a boilery. And certain salt fats or bullaries.

cs.cd: a leaf, the membranous part of which rises between the veins puckered elevations convex on one side and concave on the other.

entry.ety: L. bullatus, fr. bulla bubble
entry.def: Appearing as if blistered; inflated; puckered.
Something used or suggested to produce terror, as in children or persons of weak mind; a bugbear.
entry.q: And being an ill-looked fellow, he has a pension from the church wardens for being bullbeggar to all the forward children in the parish.

entries.entry: Bull" bri`er. Bot A species of Smilax (Smilax Pseudo-China) growing from New Jersey to the Gulf of Mexico, which has very large tuberous and farinaceous rootstocks, formerly used by the Indians for a sort of bread, and by the negroes as an ingredient in making beer; -- called also bamboo brier and China brier.

entry.def: A scaraboid beetle; esp. the Typhæus vulgaris of Europe.

sn.def: A variety of dog, of remarkable ferocity, courage, and tenacity of grip; -- so named, probably, from being formerly employed in baiting bulls.
A refractory material used as a furnace lining, obtained by calcining the cinder or slag from the puddling furnace of a rolling mill.

cs.cd: a bat of the genus Nyctinomus; -- so called from the shape of its face.

entry.def: Characteristic of, or like, a bulldog; stubborn; as, bulldog courage; bulldog tenacity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bulldozed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bulldozing
entry.def: To intimidate; to restrain or coerce by intimidation or violence; -- used originally of the intimidation of negro voters, in Louisiana.
One who bulldozes.

entry.ety: Cf. Boln
entry.def: Swollen.

entry.ety: Native Australian name, from its cry
entry.def: The lyre bird.

entry.ety: Bull large, having a large head + nail
entry.def: A nail with a round head and short shank, tinned and lacquered.

entry.note: See Illust. under Horse
entry.cs: Bullet tree. See Bully tree. Bullet wood the wood of the bullet tree.
entry.ety: F. boulet, dim. of boule ball. See Bull an edict, and cf. Boulet

sn.def: A small ball.
A missile, usually of lead, and round or elongated in form, to be discharged from a rifle, musket, pistol, or other small firearm.
A cannon ball.
sn.q: A ship before Greenwich . . . shot off her ordnance, one piece being charged with a bullet of stone.

sn.def: The fetlock of a horse.

entry.def: a head shaped like a bullet.

cs.cd: a board on which announcements are put, particularly at newsrooms, newspaper offices, etc.

entry.ety: F. bulletin, fr. It. bullettino, dim. of bulletta, dim. of bulla bolla, an edict of the pope, from L. bulla bubble. See Bull an edict

sn.def: A brief statement of facts respecting some passing event, as military operations or the health of some distinguished personage, issued by authority for the information of the public.
Any public notice or announcement, especially of news recently received.
A periodical publication, especially one containing the proceeding of a society.
Capable of resisting the force of a bullet; resistant to penetration by a bullet; armored; as, a bulletproof vest; a bulletproof window.
designed so as to be resistant to abuse or misuse and incapable of malfunction under normal use; as, a bulletproof computer program.
so well thought out as to be resistant to criticism or certain to succeed; as, a bulletproof plan.

entry.def: Having a large face.
See Bullfight.

a sport of great antiquity, in which men torment, and fight with, a bull or bulls in an arena, for public amusement, -- still popular in Spain, Portugal and Latin American. In the Spanish version a matador kills the bull with a sword after the bull has been weakened by wounds from small barbed rods, and after he has displayed courage and artistic skill in causing the bull to charge many times while he stands still or nearly still. In some versions the bull is not killed. Occasionally the matador is wounded or killed by the bull.
the activity at a bullfight.

entry.note: ☞ As a cage bird it is highly valued for its remarkable power of learning to whistle correctly various musical airs.
entry.cs: Crimson-fronted bullfinch. Zoöl See Burion. Pine bullfinch the pine finch.
entry.def: A bird of the genus Pyrrhula and other related genera, especially the Pyrrhula vulgarisorPyrrhula rubicilla, a bird of Europe allied to the grosbeak, having the breast, cheeks, and neck, red.

entry.ety: Cf. G. bofist, AS. wulfes fist puffball, E. fizz foist
entry.def: A kind of fungus. See Puffball.
Any large fly troublesome to cattle, as the gadflies and breeze flies.
A very large species of frog (Rana Catesbiana), found in North America; -- so named from its loud bellowing in spring.

cs.cd: the kingfish of Florida (Menticirrus alburnus).

sd.def: A fresh-water fish of many species, of the genus Uranidea, esp. Uranidea gobio of Europe, and Uranidea Richardsoni of the United States; -- called also miller's thumb.
In America, several species of Amiurus; -- called also catfish horned pout, and bullpout.
A marine fish of the genus Cottus; the sculpin.
The black-bellied plover (Squatarola helvetica); -- called also beetlehead.
The golden plover.

sn.def: A stupid fellow; a lubber.
A small black water insect.

entry.def: Having a head like that of a bull. Fig.: Headstrong; obstinate; dogged.
resolute adherence to one's own ideas or desires.
a portable loudspeaker with built-in microphone and amplifier.
frightened into submission or compliance.

entry.note: ☞ Properly, the precious metals are called bullion, when smelted and not perfectly refined, or when refined, but in bars, ingots or in any form uncoined, as in plate. The word is often often used to denote gold and silver, both coined and uncoined, when reckoned by weight and in mass, including especially foreign, or uncurrent, coin.
entry.ety: Cf. OE. bullyon a hook used for fastening the dress, a button, stud, an embossed ornament of various kinds, e. g., on the cover of a book, on bridles or poitrels, for purses, for breeches and doublets, LL. bullio the swelling of boiling water, a mass of gold or silver, fr. L. bulla boss, stud, bubble (see Bull an edict), or perh. corrupted fr. F. billon base coin, LL. billio bullion. Cf. Billon Billet a stick

sn.def: Uncoined gold or silver in the mass.
Base or uncurrent coin.
sn.q: And those which eld's strict doom did disallow, And damm for bullion, go for current now.

sn.def: Showy metallic ornament, as of gold, silver, or copper, on bridles, saddles, etc.
sn.q: The clasps and bullions were worth a thousand pound.

sn.def: Heavy twisted fringe, made of fine gold or silver wire and used for epaulets; also, any heavy twisted fringe whose cords are prominent.

entry.def: An advocate for a metallic currency, or a paper currency always convertible into gold.

entry.ety: Cf. bully,n. & v., and rag to scold, rail. Cf. Ballarag
entry.def: To intimidate by bullying; to rally contemptuously; to badger.
Partaking of the nature of a bull, or a blunder.
entry.q: Let me inform you, a toothless satire is as improper as a toothed sleek stone, and as bullish.

entry.ety: F. bulliste. See Bull an edict
entry.def: A writer or drawer up of papal bulls.

entry.ety: L. bullire bullitum, to boil. See Boil v. i.
entry.def: The action of boiling; boiling. Obs See Ebullition.

entries.entry:
Bull Moose
Bull Mooser. Cant . (U. S. Politics A follower of Theodore Roosevelt in the presidential campaign of 1912; -- a sense said to have originated from a remark made by Roosevelt on a certain occasion that he felt “like a bull moose.” Cant The figure of a bull moose used as the party symbol of the Progressive party in the presidential campaign of 1912.
bull"-necked` a. Having a short, thick and muscular neck like that of a bull.Narrower terms: mesomorphic

entry.ety: AS. bulluc a young bull. See Bull

sn.def: A young bull, or any male of the ox kind.
sn.q: Take thy father's young bullock, even the second bullock of seven years old.

sn.def: An ox, steer, or stag.

entry.def: To bully.
entry.q: She shan't think to bullock and domineer over me.

entry.def: See Bull's-eye, 3.
A West Indian fish (Scarus Croicensis).

sn.def: an open area in a baseball stadium, off the playing field, where pitchers may warm up by throwing a number of trial pitches before playing.
the relief pitchers on a baseball team. Contrasted with starters.

entry.def: See Bullhead, 1 .

A contrivance consisting of a slat of wood tied to the end of a thong or string, with which the slat is whirled so as to cause an intermittent roaring noise. It is used as a toy, and among some races in certain religious rites.

sn.def: A small circular or oval wooden block without sheaves, having a groove around it and a hole through it, used for connecting rigging.
A small round cloud, with a ruddy center, supposed by sailors to portend a storm.
A small thick disk of glass inserted in a deck, roof, floor, ship's side, etc., to let in light.
A circular or oval opening for air or light.
A lantern, with a thick glass lens on one side for concentrating the light on any object; also, the lens itself.
Aldebaran, a bright star in the eye of Taurus or the Bull.
The center of a target.
A thick knob or protuberance left on glass by the end of the pipe through which it was blown.
A small and thick old-fashioned watch.
something that exactly succeeds in achieving its goal; as, to score a bull's eye .

entry.def: a ludicrously false statement.
entry.syn: bull, Irish bull, horseshit, shit, crap, crapola, bunk, bunkum, buncombe, guff, rot, tommyrot, balderdash, hogwash, dogshit.

entry.def: to talk through one's hat.
vodka and beef bouillon or consomme.
any of several large harmless rodent-eating North American burrowing snakes of the genus Pituophis. They include the gopher snake and pine snake.
An external angle when obtuse or rounded.

sn.def: by crossing the bulldog with terriers.

entries.entry:
Bull" ter`ri*er bull"ter`rier
bụl" tĕr`rĭ*ẽr. Zoöl A breed of short-haired terrier dogs originated in England by crossing the bulldog and the terrier.

Bull" trout`. Zoöl In England, a large salmon trout of several species, as Salmo trutta and Salmo Cambricus, which ascend rivers; -- called also sea trout.
Salvelinus malma of California and Oregon; -- called also Dolly Varden trout and red-spotted trout. The huso or salmon of the Danube.

entry.ety: Bole a stem + weed
entry.def: Knapweed.
See Bishop's-weed.

entries.entry:
Bul"ly bụl"l� n.; pl.Bullies bŭl"lĭz. Cf. LG. bullerjaan bullerbäk bullerbrook, a blusterer, D. bulderaar a bluster, bulderen to bluster; prob. of imitative origin; or cf. MHG. buole lover, G. buhle
A noisy, blustering fellow, more insolent than courageous, who threatens, intimidates, or badgers people who are smaller or weaker than he is; an insolent, tyrannical fellow.
Bullies seldom execute the threats they deal in.
A brisk, dashing fellow. Slang Obs
Bul"ly bụl"l� n. Bul"ly beef` bụl"l� bēf` . F. bouilli boiled meat, fr. bouillir to boil. See Boil v. The word bouilli was formerly commonly used on the labels of canned beef Pickled or canned beef.

sn.def: Jovial and blustering; dashing.
sn.q: Bless thee,bullydoctor.

sn.def: Fine; excellent; as, a bully horse.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bullied bụl"lēd; p. pr. & vb. n. Bullying
entry.def: To intimidate or badger with threats and by an overbearing, swaggering demeanor; to act the part of a bully{1} toward.
entry.q: For the last fortnight there have been prodigious shoals of volunteers gone over to bully the French, upon hearing the peace was just signing.

entry.def: To act as a bully{1}.
Well done! Excellent!
Noisily domineering; tending to browbeat others.
An exceptionally advantageous position from which to extol one's ideas; -- applied especially to the presidency of the United States, which was described thus by President Theodore Rossevelt.
Same as Bullirag.
A bully.

entries.entry: Bul"ly tree` bụl"l� trē`. Bot The name of several West Indian trees of the order Sapotaceæ, as Dipholis nigra and species of Sapota and Mimusops. Most of them yield a substance closely resembling gutta-percha.

entry.note: ☞ The name bulrush is applied in England especially to the cat-tail (Typha latifolia and Typha angustifolia) and to the lake club-rush (Scirpus lacustris); in America, to the Juncus effusus, and also to species of Scirpus or club-rush.
entry.ety: OE. bulrysche bolroysche; of uncertain origin, perh. fr. bole stem + rush
entry.def: A kind of large rush, growing in wet land or in water.
A purse or bag in which to carry or measure diamonds, etc.

entry.ety: LL. bultellus. See Bolt to sift
entry.def: A bolter or bolting cloth; also, bran.
Same as Bolty.
Biltong.
A trawl; a boulter; the mode of fishing with a boulter or spiller.

entry.ety: Akin to D. bolwerk, G. bollwerk, Sw. bolwerk, Dan. bolvärk bulvärk, rampart; akin to G. bohle plank, and werk work, defense. See Bole stem, and Work n., and cf. Boulevard

sn.def: A rampart; a fortification; a bastion or outwork.
That which secures against an enemy, or defends from attack; any means of defense or protection.
sn.q: The royal navy of England hath ever been its greatest defense, . . . the floating bulwark of our island.

sn.def: The sides of a ship above the upper deck, usually a fencelike structure around the deck.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bulwarked; p. pr. & vb. n. Bulwarking
entry.def: To fortify with, or as with, a rampart or wall; to secure by fortification; to protect.
entry.q: Of some proud city, bulwarked round and armed With rising towers.

entry.ety: Contr. fr. bottom in this sense
entry.def: The buttock.

cs.cd: to wander about idly or aimlessly.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. bummed; p. pr. & vb. n. bumming�)
entry.ety: See Boom v. i., to roar
entry.def: To make murmuring or humming sound.
To borrow without intention of returning; to cadge; as, to bum a cigarette; to bum a cup of coffee; -- usually with inexpensive items as the object.
A humming noise.

entry.ety: A corruption of bound bailiff
entry.def: See Bound bailiff, under Bound a.

entries.entry: Bum"bard. See Bombard. Obs

entry.def: See Bumboat.

entries.entry: Bum"bast. See Bombast. Obs

Bum"be*lo n.; pl.Bumbeloes. It. bombola
A glass used in subliming camphor.
bombolo bumbolo

entry.ety: See Bump to boom
entry.def: The bittern.
To make a hollow or humming noise, like that of a bumblebee; to buzz; to cry as a bittern.
entry.q: As a bittern bumbleth in the mire.

entry.def: to act ineptly or without clear understanding of what one is doing; to blunder; to stumble about; -- sometimes used with around.
to bungle (a task).

entry.note: ☞ There are many species. All gather honey, and store it in the empty cocoons after the young have come out.
entry.ety: OE. bumblen to make a humming noise (dim. of bum, v. i.) + bee. Cf. Humblebee
entry.def: A large bee of the genus Bombus, sometimes called humblebee; -- so named from its sound.

entry.ety: Origin unknown; cf. Bumble n.

sn.def: The old game of nineholes.
Whist played in an unscientific way.

entry.def: not skillful in physical movement especially with the hands; as, a bumbling mechanic.
entry.syn: bungling, butterfingered, ham-fisted, ham-handed, handless, heavy-handed, left-handed.

entry.ety: From bum the buttocks, on account of its clumsy form; or fr. D. bun a box for holding fish in a boat
entry.def: A clumsy boat, used for conveying provisions, fruit, etc., for sale, to vessels lying in port or off shore.

entry.ety: Boom a beam + -kin. See Bumpkin
entry.def: A projecting beam or boom; as: One projecting from each bow of a vessel, to haul the fore tack to, called a tack bumpkin. One from each quarter, for the main-brace blocks, and called brace bumpkin. A small outrigger over the stern of a boat, to extend the mizzen.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A small marine Asiatic fish (Saurus ophidon) used in India as a relish; -- called also Bombay duck.

sn.def: An idle, worthless fellow, who is without any visible means of support; a loafer; a dissipated sponger; one who bums.
an unpleasant event, experience, or situation; as, getting caught in a cloudburst while wearing my best suit was a bummer .

entry.def: See Bottomery.
entry.q: There was a scivener of Wapping brought to hearing for relief against a bummery bond.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bumped bŭmpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Bumping
entry.ety: Cf. W. pwmp round mass, pwmpiaw to thump, bang, and E. bum, v. i., boom to roar
entry.def: To strike, as with or against anything large or solid; to thump; as, to bump the head against a wall.
To come in violent contact with something; to thump.
entry.q: Bumpingand jumping.

entry.ety: From Bump to strike, to thump

sn.def: A thump; a heavy blow.
A swelling or prominence, resulting from a bump or blow; a protuberance.
sn.q: It had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cockerel's stone.

sn.def: One of the protuberances on the cranium which are associated with distinct faculties or affections of the mind; as, the bump of “veneration;” the bump of “acquisitiveness.”
The act of striking the stern of the boat in advance with the prow of the boat following.

entry.ety: See Boom to roar
entry.def: To make a loud, heavy, or hollow noise, as the bittern; to boom.
entry.q: As a bittern bumps within a reed.

entry.def: The noise made by the bittern.

entry.ety: A corruption of bumbard bombard, a large drinking vessel

sn.def: A cup or glass filled to the brim, or till the liquor runs over, particularly in drinking a health or toast.
sn.q: He frothed his bumpers to the brim.

sn.def: A covered house at a theater, etc., in honor of some favorite performer.
That which bumps or causes a bump.
Anything which resists or deadens a bump or shock, such as a metal or rubber rim extending from an object; a buffer.

a protective guard device, usually of metal or rubber, attached horizontally to the front or rear of the frame of a vehicle, designed to resist or deaden a bump or shock, and to prevent damage to the main frame of the vehicle in low-velocity collisions.

entry.def: moving slowly with little space between; -- used of road traffic.

entry.ety: The same word as bumkin, which Cotgrave defines thus: “Bumkin, Fr. chicambault, the luffe-block, a long and thick piece of wood, whereunto the fore-sayle and sprit-sayle are fastened, when a ship goes by the winde.” Hence, a clumsy man may easily have been compared to such a block of wood; cf. OD. boomken a little tree. See Boom a pole
entry.def: An awkward, heavy country fellow; a clown; a country lout.
entry.q: Bashful countrybumpkins.

entry.def: unsophisticated in a manner resembling a lifelong resident of rural areas; as, bumpkinly country boys.
Self-conceited; forward; pushing.
Conceitedness.

entry.ety: Scot. bun bunn, OE. bunne bonne; fr. Celtic; cf. Ir. bunna, Gael. bonnach, or OF. bugne tumor, Prov. F. bugne a kind of pancake; akin to OHG. bungo bulb, MHG. bunge, Prov. E. bung heap, cluster, bunny a small swelling

sn.def: any of a variety of slightly sweetened or plain raised cakes or bisquits, often having a glazing of sugar and milk on the top crust; as, a hot cross bun .
a type of coiffure in which the hair is gathered into a coil or knot at the top of the head.
the buttocks.

entry.note: Blood usually contains 10 to 15 mg of nitrogen per 100 ml in the form of urea. Stedman.
entry.ety: acronym
entry.def: same as blood urea nitrogen; the concentration of nitrogen in blood present in the form of urea; -- used as a measure of kidney function.

entry.ety: trademark
entry.def: a synthetic rubber made by copolymerizing butadiene with another substance such as acrylonitrile or styrene.
a sudden unexpected piece of good fortune.

entry.ety: Akin to OSw. & Dan. bunke heap, Icel. bunki heap, pile, bunga tumor, protuberance; cf. W. pwng cluster. Cf. Bunk

sn.def: A protuberance; a hunch; a knob or lump; a hump.
sn.q: They will carry . . . their treasures upon the bunches of camels.

sn.def: A collection, cluster, or tuft, properly of things of the same kind, growing or fastened together; as, a bunch of grapes; a bunch of keys.
A small isolated mass of ore, as distinguished from a continuous vein.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bunched; p. pr. & vb. n. Bunching
entry.def: To swell out into a bunch or protuberance; to be protuberant or round.
entry.q: Bunching out into a large round knob at one end.

entry.def: To form into a bunch or bunches.
Having a bunch on the back; crooked.
entry.q: Bunch-backedtoad.

entry.def: The dwarf cornel (Cornus Canadensis), which bears a dense cluster of bright red, edible berries.

entries.entry: Bunch" grass`. Bot A grass growing in bunches and affording pasture. In California, Atropis tenuifolia Festuca scabrella, and several kinds of Stipa are favorite bunch grasses. In Utah, Eriocoma cuspidata is a good bunch grass.

entry.def: The quality or condition of being bunchy; knobbiness.

sn.def: Swelling out in bunches.
sn.q: An unshapen, bunchy spear, with bark unpiled.

sn.def: Growing in bunches, or resembling a bunch; having tufts; as, the bird's bunchy tail.
Yielding irregularly; sometimes rich, sometimes poor; as, a bunchy mine.

entry.def: see bunko.

cs.cd: to speak for mere show, or popularly.

entry.note: ☞ “The phrase originated near the close of the debate on the famous ‘Missouri Question,' in the 16th Congress. It was then used by Felix Walker -- a naïve old mountaineer, who resided at Waynesville, in Haywood, the most western country of North Carolina, near the border of the adjacent county of Buncombe, which formed part of his district. The old man rose to speak, while the house was impatiently calling for the ‘Question,' and several members gathered round him, begging him to desist. He preserved, however, for a while, declaring that the people of his district expected it, and that he was bound to ‘make a speech for Buncombe.'” W. Darlington.
entry.ety: Buncombe a county of North Carolina
entry.def: Speech-making for the gratification of constituents, or to gain public applause; flattering talk for a selfish purpose; anything said for mere show.
entry.q: All that flourish about right of search was bunkumall that brag about hanging your Canada sheriff was bunkum . . . slavery speeches are all bunkum.

entry.ety: G
entry.def: League; confederacy; esp. the confederation of German states.

entry.ety: Hindi band
entry.def: An embankment against inundation.

entry.ety: Pers. bandar a landing place, pier
entry.def: A boat or raft used in the East Indies in the landing of passengers and goods.

entry.note: ☞ The Bundesrath of the German empire is presided over by a chancellor, and is composed of sixty-two members, who represent the different states of the empire, being appointed for each session by their respective governments.
entry.ety: G., from bundakin to E. bond) confederacy + rath council, prob. akin to E. read
entry.def: Lit., a federal council, esp. of the German Empire. In the German Empire the legislative functions are vested in the Bundesrath and the Reichstag. The federal council of Switzerland is also so called.

q.au: J. P. Peters (Trans. Müller's Pol. Hist.).

entry.q: By this united congress, the highest tribunal of Switzerland, -- the Bundesrathis chosen, and the head of this is a president.

entry.ety: G.; bund confederacy + versammlung assembly
entry.def: See Legislature Switzerland.

cs.cd: a column or pier, with others of small dimensions attached to it.

entry.ety: OE. bundel, AS. byndel; akin to D. bondel bundel, G. bündel, dim. of bund bundle, fr. the root of E. bind. See Bind
entry.def: A number of things bound together, as by a cord or envelope, into a mass or package convenient for handling or conveyance; a loose package; a roll; as, a bundle of straw or of paper; a bundle of old clothes.
entry.q: The fable of the rods, which, when united in a bundle, no strength could bend.

cs.cd: to send off in a hurry, or without ceremony; as, the working mothers bundle their children off to school and then try to get themselves to work on time.
to wrap one's self up warmly or cumbrously.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bundled; p. pr. & vb. n. Bundling

sn.def: To tie or bind in a bundle or roll.
To send off abruptly or without ceremony.
sn.q: They unmercifully bundled me and my gallant second into our own hackney coach.

sn.def: to sell together as a single item at one inclusive price; -- usually done for related products which work or are used together.

cs.cd: to dress warmly, snugly, or cumbrously.

sn.def: To prepare for departure; to set off in a hurry or without ceremony.
To sleep on the same bed without undressing; -- applied to the custom of a man and woman, especially lovers, thus sleeping.
sn.q: Van Corlear stopped occasionally in the villages to eat pumpkin pies, dance at country frolics, and bundle with the Yankee lasses.

entry.def: sold together as a single item; -- usually done for related products which work or are used together.
dressed warmly; as, bundled-up sailors and soldiers.

sn.def: a former custom, especially in New England, in which unmarried couples occupied the same bed without undressing, especially during courtship. See bundle{2 v. i.
the act of binding something into a bundle.
the act of shoving hastily; as, she complained about bundling the children off to school.

entry.ety: Hind. & Per. bando-bast tying and binding
entry.def: System; discipline.
entry.q: He has more bundobust than most men.

entry.ety: Cf. W. bwng orfice, bunghole, Ir. buinne tap, spout, OGael. buine

sn.def: The large stopper of the orifice in the bilge of a cask.
The orifice in the bilge of a cask through which it is filled; bunghole.
A sharper or pickpocket.
sn.q: You filthy bung, away.

cs.cd: to use up, as by bruising or over exertion; to exhaust or incapacitate for action.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bunged; p. pr. & vb. n. Bunging
entry.def: To stop, as the orifice in the bilge of a cask, with a bung; to close; -- with up.
entry.q: He had bunged up his mouth that he should not have spoken these three years.

sn.def: of or pertaining to a bungalow; similar to a bungalow.
having many bungalows.

entry.ety: Bengalee bānglā
entry.def: A thatched or tiled house or cottage, of a single story, usually surrounded by a veranda.

entry.ety: Bungar, the native name
entry.def: A venomous snake of India, of the genus Bungarus, allied to the cobras, but without a hood.

sn.def: a spring or other elastic device, especially one attached to a control to facilitate its manipulation.
same as bungee cord.

entry.def: a strong elastic cord, usually with a hook at each end, used as a shock-absorbing device or to bind packages together, as on a dolly or handcart.

an act of derring-do in which a person jumps from a high platform, such as a bridge, attached (usually by the legs) to a bungee cord, which is set to a length that will halt the drop before the person reaches the surface of the earth or the water.
See Bung n., 2.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bungled; p. pr. & vb. n. Bungling
entry.ety: Prob. a diminutive from, akin to bang; cf. Prov. G. bungen to beat, bang, OSw. bunga. See Bang
entry.def: To act or work in a clumsy, awkward manner.
To make or mend clumsily; to manage awkwardly; to botch; -- sometimes with up.
entry.q: I always had an idea that it would be bungled.

entry.def: A clumsy or awkward performance; a botch; a gross blunder.
entry.q: Those errors and bungles which are committed.

entry.def: performed poorly or inadequately; as, a bungled job; the Watergate scandal started with a bungled burglary.
A clumsy, awkward workman; one who bungles.
entry.q: If to be a dunce or a bungler in any profession be shameful, how much more ignominious and infamous to a scholar to be such!

entry.def: awkward to move or use especially because of shape; as, a load of bunglesome paraphernalia.
Unskillful; awkward; clumsy; as, a bungling workman.
entry.q: They make but bungling work.

entry.def: Clumsily; awkwardly.
A kind of canoe used in Central and South America; also, a kind of boat used in the Southern United States.
Same as Bunyon.
an Australian timber tree (Flindersia schottiana) whose bark yields a poison.

entry.ety: Cf. OSw. bunke heap, also boaring, flooring. Cf. Bunch

sn.def: A wooden case or box, which serves for a seat in the daytime and for a bed at night.
One of a series of berths or bed places in tiers; as, to sleep in the top bunk .
A piece of wood placed on a lumberman's sled to sustain the end of heavy timbers.
a bed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bunked; p. pr. & vb. n. Bunking
entry.def: To go to bed in a bunk; -- sometimes with in.
A type of multiple bed in which the individual beds are arranged one above the other. It is used to save space in crowded quarters.

entry.ety: Scot. bunker bunkart, a bench, or low chest, serving for a seat. Cf. Bunk Bank Bench

sn.def: A sort of chest or box, as in a window, the lid of which serves for a seat.
A large bin or similar receptacle; as, a coal bunker .
A small sand hole or pit, as on a golf course.
Hence, any rough hazardous ground on the links; also, an artificial hazard with built-up faces.

A fortified position dug into the ground, especially one which is closed on top and has protective walls and roof, e. g. of reinforced concrete. For defending positions it usually has windows to view the surrounding terrain, but as a safe location for planning operations or storage, a bunker may be completely underground with no direct access to the surface.

entry.def: To drive (the ball) into a bunker.

sn.def: someone who occupies the same sleeping quarters as oneself.

entry.ety: Sf. Sp. banco bank, banca a sort of game at cards. Cf. Bankin the commercial sense)
entry.def: A kind of swindling game or scheme, originally by means of cards or by a sham lottery, but now used for any swindling tactic.

cs.cd: a person employed as a decoy in bunko.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bunkoed; p. pr. & vb. n. Bunkoing
entry.def: To swindle by a bunko game or scheme; to cheat or victimize in any similar way, as by a confidence game, passing a bad check, etc.
See Buncombe.
See Bun.
See Bunyon.
A great collection of ore without any vein coming into it or going out from it.
A pet name for a rabbit or a squirrel.

entry.ety: NL. bunodonta, fr. Gr. � hill, heap + �, �, a tooth
entry.def: A division of the herbivorous mammals including the hogs and hippopotami; -- so called because the teeth are tuberculated.
the buttocks.
entry.syn: buttocks, arse, butt, backside, bum, can, fundament, hindquarters, hind end, keister, posterior, prat, rear, rear end, rump, stern, seat, tail, tail end, tooshie, tush, bottom, behind, derriere, fanny, ass.

sn.def: same as bunsen burner; a gas burner used in laboratories; has an air valve to regulate the mixture of gas and air.

entry.def: a kind of burner, invented by Professor Bunsen of Heidelberg, consisting of a straight tube, four or five inches in length, having small holes for the entrance of air at the bottom. Illuminating gas being also admitted at the bottom, a mixture of gas and air is formed which burns at the top with a feebly luminous but intensely hot flame.

entries.entry: Bun"sen's bat"ter*y. See under Battery.

Bun"sen cell. Elec A zinc-carbon cell in which the zinc (amalgamated) is surrounded by dilute sulphuric acid, and the carbon by nitric acid or a chromic acid mixture, the two plates being separated by a porous cup.

entry.def: A fungus (Ustilago fœtida) which affects the ear of cereals, filling the grains with a fetid dust; -- also called pepperbrand.

entry.ety: Cf. Sw. bunt bundle, Dan. bundt, G. bund, E. bundle
entry.def: The middle part, cavity, or belly of a sail; the part of a furled sail which is at the center of the yard.
A push or shove; a butt;
the act of bunting the ball.
To swell out; as, the sail bunts .

sn.def: To strike or push with the horns or head; to butt; as, the ram bunted the boy.
To bat or tap (the ball) slowly within the infield by meeting it with the bat without swinging at it.

entry.def: a fine white Philippine fiber from the stalks of unopened leaves of talipot palms; used in making hats.

sn.def: A woman who picks up rags in the streets; hence, a low, vulgar woman.
sn.q: Her . . . daughters, like bunters in stuff gowns.

sn.def: a batter who bunts{2}.

entry.note: ☞ Among European species are the common or corn bunting (Emberiza miliaria); the ortolan (Emberiza hortulana); the cirl (Emberiza cirlus); and the black-headed (Granitivora melanocephala). American species are the bay-winged or grass (Poöcætes gramineus or Poœcetes gramineus); the black-throated (Spiza Americana); the towhee bunting or chewink (Pipilo); the snow bunting (Plectrophanax nivalis); the rice bunting or bobolink, and others. See Ortolan Chewick Snow bunting Lark bunting.
entry.ety: Scot. buntlin corn-buntlin, OE. bunting buntyle; of unknown origin
entry.def: A bird of the genus Emberiza, or of an allied genus, related to the finches and sparrows (family Fringillidæ).

entry.ety: Prov. E. bunting sifting flour, OE. bonten to sift, hence prob. the material used for that purpose
entry.def: A thin woolen stuff, used chiefly for flags, colors, and ships' signals.

entry.ety: 2d bunt + line
entry.def: One of the ropes toggled to the footrope of a sail, used to haul up to the yard the body of the sail when taking it in.

entry.ety: Cf. Prov. E. bunny a small swelling, fr. OF. bugne, It. bugna bugnone. See Bun
entry.def: An enlargement and inflammation of a small membranous sac (one of the bursæ muscosæ), usually occurring on the first joint of the great toe.

entry.cs:
Anchor buoy a buoy attached to, or marking the position of, an anchor. Bell buoy a large buoy on which a bell is mounted, to be rung by the motion of the waves. Breeches buoy. See under Breeches. Cable buoy an empty cask employed to buoy up the cable in rocky anchorage. Can buoy a hollow buoy made of sheet or boiler iron, usually conical or pear-shaped. Life buoy a float intended to support persons who have fallen into the water, until a boat can be dispatched to save them.
Nut buoyorNun buoy
a buoy large in the middle, and tapering nearly to a point at each end. To stream the buoy to let the anchor buoy fall by the ship's side into the water, before letting go the anchor. Whistling buoy a buoy fitted with a whistle that is blown by the action of the waves.
entry.ety: D. boei buoy, fetter, fr. OF. boie buie, chain, fetter, F. bouée a buoy, from L. boia. “Boiae genus vinculorum tam ferreae quam ligneae.” Festus. So called because chained to its place
entry.def: A float; esp. a floating object moored to the bottom, to mark a channel or to point out the position of something beneath the water, as an anchor, shoal, rock, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Buoyed; p. pr. & vb. n. Buoying

sn.def: To keep from sinking in a fluid, as in water or air; to keep afloat; -- with up.
To support or sustain; to preserve from sinking into ruin or despondency.
sn.q: Those old prejudices, which buoy up the ponderous mass of his nobility, wealth, and title.

sn.def: To fix buoys to; to mark by a buoy or by buoys; as, to buoy an anchor; to buoy or buoy off a channel.
sn.q: Not one rock near the surface was discovered which was not buoyed by this floating weed.

entry.def: To float; to rise like a buoy.
entry.q: Rising merit willbuoyup at last.

entry.def: Buoys, taken collectively; a series of buoys, as for the guidance of vessels into or out of port; the providing of buoys.
Buoyancy.

entries.entry:
Buoy"an*cy n.; pl.Buoyancies.
The property of floating on the surface of a liquid, or in a fluid, as in the atmosphere; specific lightness, which is inversely as the weight compared with that of an equal volume of water.
Physics The upward pressure exerted upon a floating body by a fluid, which is equal to the weight of the body; hence, also, the weight of a floating body, as measured by the volume of fluid displaced. Such are buoyancies or displacements of the different classes of her majesty's ships.
Cheerfulness; vivacity; liveliness; sprightliness; -- the opposite of heaviness; as, buoyancy of spirits.

entry.ety: From Buoy v. t. & i.

sn.def: Having the quality of rising or floating in a fluid; tending to rise or float; as, iron is buoyant in mercury.
sn.q: Buoyanton the flood.

sn.def: Bearing up, as a fluid; sustaining another body by being specifically heavier.
sn.q: The water under me was buoyant.

sn.def: Light-hearted; vivacious; cheerful; as, a buoyant disposition; buoyant spirits.

entry.ety: L. buprestis, Gr. �, a poisonous beetle, which, being eaten by cattle in the grass, caused them to swell up and and die; � ox, cow + � to blow up, swell out
entry.def: One of a tribe of beetles, of the genus Buprestis and allied genera, usually with brilliant metallic colors. The larvæ are usually borers in timber, or beneath bark, and are often very destructive to trees.

cs.cd: a useful and ornamental species of oak (Quercus macrocarpa) with ovoid acorns inclosed in deep cups imbricated with pointed scales. It grows in the Middle and Western United States, and its wood is tough, close-grained, and durable.
a plant of the genus Sparganium, having long ribbonlike leaves.

entry.ety: OE. burre burdock; cf. Dan. borre, OSw. borra, burdock, thistle; perh. akin to E. bristle burr- for burz-), or perh. to F. bourre hair, wool, stuff; also, according to Cotgrave, “the downe, or hairie coat, wherewith divers herbes, fruits, and flowers, are covered,” fr. L. burrae trifles, LL. reburrus rough

sn.def: Any rough or prickly envelope of the seeds of plants, whether a pericarp, a persistent calyx, or an involucre, as of the chestnut and burdock; a seed vessel having hooks or prickles. Also, any weed which bears burs.
sn.q: Amongst rude burs and thistles.
Bur and brake and brier.

sn.def: The thin ridge left by a tool in cutting or shaping metal. See Burr n., 2.
A ring of iron on a lance or spear. See Burr n., 4.
The lobe of the ear. See Burr n., 5.
The sweetbread.
A clinker; a partially vitrified brick.

sd.def: A small circular saw.
A triangular chisel.
A drill with a serrated head larger than the shank; -- especially a small drill bit used by dentists.

sn.ety: Cf. Gael. borr borra, a knob, bunch
sn.def: The round knob of an antler next to a deer's head.

entry.def: a light gabardine raincoat of the type made by Burberry's of London.
to to make a burbling sound; -- used of water, especially brooks.

sn.def: uttered with unrestrained enthusiasm; as, a novel told in burbly panting tones.
bubbling; -- of sounds, especially of water.

entry.def: A birdbolt.

entry.note: ☞ The fish is also called an eelpout or ling, and is allied to the codfish. The Lota vulgaris is a common European species. An American species (Lota maculosa) is found in New England, the Great Lakes, and farther north.
entry.ety: F. barbote, fr. barbe beard. See 1st Barb
entry.def: A fresh-water fish of the genus Lota, having on the nose two very small barbels, and a larger one on the chin.

entry.ety: F. bourdelais, prob. fr. bordelais. See Bordelais
entry.def: A sort of grape.

cs.cd: an animal employed in carrying burdens.
the duty of proving a particular position in a court of law, a failure in the performance of which duty calls for judgment against the party on whom the duty is imposed.

entry.usage: A burden is, in the literal sense, a weight to be borne; a load is something laid upon us to be carried. Hence, when used figuratively, there is usually a difference between the two words. Our burdens may be of such a nature that we feel bound to bear them cheerfully or without complaint. They may arise from the nature of our situation; they may be allotments of Providence; they may be the consequences of our errors. What is upon us, as a load, we commonly carry with greater reluctance or sense of oppression. Men often find the charge of their own families to be a burden; but if to this be added a load of care for others, the pressure is usually serve and irksome.
entry.ety: OE. burden burthen birthen birden, AS. byrðen; akin to Icel. byrði, Dan. byrde, Sw. börda, G. bürde, OHG. burdi, Goth. baúrþei, fr. the root of E. bear, AS. beran, Goth. bairan. √92. See 1st Bear

sn.def: That which is borne or carried; a load.
sn.q: Plants with goodly burden bowing.

sn.def: That which is borne with labor or difficulty; that which is grievous, wearisome, or oppressive.
sn.q: Deaf, giddy, helpless, left alone, To all my friends a burden grown.

sn.def: The capacity of a vessel, or the weight of cargo that she will carry; as, a ship of a hundred tons burden .
The tops or heads of stream-work which lie over the stream of tin.
The proportion of ore and flux to fuel, in the charge of a blast furnace.
A fixed quantity of certain commodities; as, a burden of gad steel, 120 pounds.
A birth.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burdened; p. pr. & vb. n. Burdening

sn.def: To encumber with weight (literal or figurative); to lay a heavy load upon; to load.
sn.q: I mean not that other men be eased, and ye burdened.

sn.def: To oppress with anything grievous or trying; to overload; as, to burden a nation with taxes.
sn.q: My burdened heart would break.

sn.def: To impose, as a load or burden; to lay or place as a burden (something heavy or objectionable).
sn.q: It is absurd to burden this act on Cromwell.

entry.ety: OE. burdoun the bass in music, F. bourdon; cf. LL. burdo drone, a long organ pipe, a staff, a mule. Prob. of imitative origin. Cf. Bourdon

sn.def: The verse repeated in a song, or the return of the theme at the end of each stanza; the chorus; refrain. Hence: That which is often repeated or which is dwelt upon; the main topic; as, the burden of a prayer.
sn.q: I would sing my song without a burden.

sn.def: The drone of a bagpipe.

entry.ety: See Burdon
entry.def: A club.
bearing a heavy load; as, a hiker burdened with a heavy backpack.
One who loads; an oppressor.
Burdensome.
entry.q: Burdenoustaxations.

entry.def: Grievous to be borne; causing uneasiness or fatigue; oppressive.
entry.q: The debt immense of endless gratitude So burdensome.
entry.syn: Heavy; weighty; cumbersome; onerous; grievous; oppressive; troublesome.

entry.note: ☞ The common burdock is the Lappa officinalis.
entry.ety: Bur + dock the plant
entry.def: A genus of coarse biennial herbs (Lappa), bearing small burs which adhere tenaciously to clothes, or to the fur or wool of animals.

entry.ety: See Bourdon
entry.def: A pilgrim's staff.

entries.entry:
Bu"reau ☞ On the continent of Europe, the highest departments, in most countries, have the name of bureaux; as, the Bureau of the Minister of Foreign Affairs. In England and America, the term is confined to inferior and subordinate departments; as, the “Pension Bureau,” a subdepartment of the Department of the Interior. Obs In Spanish, bureo denotes a court of justice for the trial of persons belonging to the king's household.
Bureau system. See Bureaucracy. Bureau Veritas an institution, in the interest of maritime underwriters, for the survey and rating of vessels all over the world. It was founded in Belgium in 1828, removed to Paris in 1830, and reëstablished in Brussels in 1870.
n.; pl. E. Bureaus, F. Bureaux. F. bureau a writing table, desk, office, OF., drugget, with which a writing table was often covered, equiv. to F. bure, and fr. OF. buire dark brown, the stuff being named from its color, fr. L. burrus red, fr. Gr. � flame-colored, prob. fr. � fire. See Fire n., and cf. Borel n.
Originally, a desk or writing table with drawers for papers.
The place where such a bureau is used; an office where business requiring writing is transacted.
Hence: A department of public business requiring a force of clerks; the body of officials in a department who labor under the direction of a chief.
A chest of drawers for clothes, especially when made as an ornamental piece of furniture. U.S

entry.ety: Bureau + Gr. � to be strong, to govern, � strength: cf. F. bureaucratie

sn.def: A system of carrying on the business of government by means of departments or bureaus, each under the control of a chief, in contradiction to a system in which the officers of government have an associated authority and responsibility; also, government conducted on this system.
Government officials, collectively; -- used especially of nonelected government officials.

entry.def: An official of a bureau; esp. an official confirmed in a narrow and arbitrary routine.
the formal and often obscure style of writing characteristic of some government officials; officialese; -- it is characterized by euphemisms, circumlocutions, vague abstractions, and circumlocutions.

entry.ety: Cf. F. bureaucratique
entry.def: Of, relating to, or resembling, a bureaucracy.
nonelective government officials; same as bureaucracy.
An advocate for, or supporter of, bureaucracy.
Same as Borrel.

entry.ety: F., can, cruet, dim. of buire flagon
entry.def: An apparatus for delivering measured quantities of liquid or for measuring the quantity of liquid or gas received or discharged. It consists essentially of a graduated glass tube, usually furnished with a small aperture and stopcock.

entries.entry: Bur" fish`. Zoöl A spinose, plectognath fish of the Allantic coast of the United States (esp. Chilo mycterus geometricus) having the power of distending its body with water or air, so as to resemble a chestnut bur; -- called also ball fish balloon fish, and swellfish.

entry.ety: AS. burh burg, cf. LL. burgus. See 1st Borough

sn.def: A fortified town.

entry.sn: A borough. Eng See 1st Borough.

entry.ety: From Burg: cf. F. bourgage, LL. burgagium
entry.def: A tenure by which houses or lands are held of the king or other lord of a borough or city; at a certain yearly rent, or by services relating to trade or handicraft.
A small marine fish; -- also called cunner.
See Bergamot.
See Burgonet.

sn.def: A kind of small coat.
A swallow-tailed flag; a distinguishing pennant, used by cutters, yachts, and merchant vessels.

entry.def: See 1st Bourgeois.
A burgess; a citizen. See 2d Bourgeois.
To bud. See Bourgeon.

entry.note: ☞ “A burgess of a borough corresponds with a citizen of a city.”
☞ Before the Revolution, the representatives in the popular branch of the legislature of Virginia were called burgesses; they are now called delegates.
entry.cs: Burgess oath. See Burgher, 2.
entry.ety: OE. burgeis, OF. burgeis, fr. burcfortified town, town, F. bourg village, fr. LL. burgus fort, city; from the German; cf. MHG. burc, G. burg. See 1st Borough, and cf. 2d Bourgeois

sn.def: An inhabitant of a borough or walled town, or one who possesses a tenement therein; a citizen or freeman of a borough.
One who represents a borough in Parliament.
A magistrate of a borough.
An inhabitant of a Scotch burgh qualified to vote for municipal officers.

entry.def: The state of privilege of a burgess.

entry.ety: G. burggraf; burg fortress + graf count: cf. D. burggraaf, F. burgrave. See Margrave
entry.def: Originally, one appointed to the command of a burgfortress or castle); but the title afterward became hereditary, with a domain attached.

entry.ety: OE. See Burg
entry.def: A borough or incorporated town, especially, one in Scotland. See Borough.
Belonging to a burgh.

entry.ety: Burgh + bote
entry.def: A contribution toward the building or repairing of castles or walls for the defense of a city or town.

entry.ety: Burgh + F. brèche, equiv. to E. breach
entry.def: The offense of violating the pledge given by every inhabitant of a tithing to keep the peace; breach of the peace.

entry.note: ☞ These parties arose among the Presbyterians of Scotland, in 1747, and in 1820 reunited under the name of the “United Associate Synod of the Secession Church.”
entry.ety: From burgh; akin to D. burger, G. bürger, Dan. borger, Sw. borgare. See Burgh

sn.def: A freeman of a burgh or borough, entitled to enjoy the privileges of the place; any inhabitant of a borough.

A member of that party, among the Scotch seceders, which asserted the lawfulness of the burgess oath (in which burgesses profess “the true religion professed within the realm”), the opposite party being called antiburghers.

entry.def: See Burgomaster.
The state or privileges of a burgher.

sn.def: A burgomaster.
An officer who directs and lays out the meres or boundaries for the workmen; -- called also bailiff, and barmaster.

entry.ety: Burgh + mote meeting
entry.def: A court or meeting of a burgh or borough; a borough court held three times yearly.

cs.cd: a device for giving alarm if a door or window is opened from without.

entry.ety: OE. burg town, F. bourg, fr. LL. burgusof German origin) + OF. lere thief, fr. L. latro. See Borough, and Larceny
entry.def: One guilty of the crime of burglary.
A burglar.
Pertaining to burglary; constituting the crime of burglary.
entry.q: To come down a chimney is held a burglarious entry.

entry.def: With an intent to commit burglary; in the manner of a burglar.
secure against burglary.

entries.entry:
Bur"gla*ry ☞ By statute law in some of the United States, burglary includes the breaking with felonious intent into a house by day as well as by night, and into other buildings than dwelling houses. Various degrees of the crime are established. n.; pl.Burglaries. Fr. Burglar; cf. LL. burglaria
Law Breaking and entering the dwelling house of another, in the nighttime, with intent to commit a felony therein, whether the felonious purpose be accomplished or not.

entry.ety: by back-formation from burglar
entry.def: to commit a burglary; to enter and rob a dwelling.

entry.ety: D. burgemeester; burg borough + meester master; akin to G. burgemeister bürgermeister. See 1st Borough, and Master

sn.def: A chief magistrate of a municipal town in Holland, Flanders, and Germany, corresponding to mayor in England and the United States; a burghmaster.
An aquatic bird, the glaucous gull (Larus glaucus), common in arctic regions.

entry.ety: F. bouruignotte, because the Burgundians, F. Bouruignons, first used it
entry.def: A kind of helmet.

entry.ety: Prov. E. burgood yeast, perh. fr. W. burym yeast + cawl cabbage, gruel
entry.def: A kind of oatmeal pudding, or thick gruel, used by seamen.
Grass of the genus Cenchrus, growing in sand, and having burs for fruit.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: See Burggrave.

cs.cd: a resinous substance prepared from the exudation of the Norway spruce (Abies excelsa) by melting in hot water and straining through cloth. The genuine Burgundy pitch, supposed to have been first prepared in Burgundy, is rare, but there are many imitations. It has a yellowish brown color, is translucent and hard, but viscous. It is used in medicinal plasters.

sn.def: An old province of France (in the eastern central part).
A richly flavored wine, mostly red, made in Burgundy, France.

entry.def: See Burg.
The wild Himalayan, or blue, sheep (Ovis burrhel).
a natural family of large wading birds resembling the plovers; the stone curlews.
type genus of the Burhinidae, comprising the stone curlews.

entry.cs: Burial case a form of coffin, usually of iron, made to close air-tight, for the preservation of a dead body. Burial ground a piece of ground selected and set apart for a place of burials, and consecrated to such use by religious ceremonies. Burial place any place where burials are made. Burial service. The religious service performed at the interment of the dead; a funeral service. That portion of a liturgy which is read at an interment; as, the English burial service .
entry.ety: OE. buriel buriels, grave, tomb, AS. byrgels, fr. byrgan to bury, and akin to OS. burgisli sepulcher

sn.def: A grave; a tomb; a place of sepulture.
sn.q: The erthe schook, and stoones weren cloven, and biriels weren opened.

sn.def: The act of burying; depositing a dead body in the earth, in a tomb or vault, or in the water, usually with attendant ceremonies; sepulture; interment.
sn.q: To give a publicburial.
Now to glorious burial slowly borne.

sn.def: covered from view; as, her face buriedor hidden) in her hands; buried in the smoke of many rifles.
placed in a grave; as, the hastily buried corpses. Opposite of unburied.

entry.def: One who, or that which, buries.
entry.q: Till the buriers have buried it.
And darkness be the burier of the dead.

entry.ety: F. burin, cf. It. burino bulino; prob. from OHG. bora borer, borōn to bore, G. bohren. See 1st Bore

sn.def: The cutting tool of an engraver on metal, used in line engraving. It is made of tempered steel, one end being ground off obliquely so as to produce a sharp point, and the other end inserted in a handle; a graver; also, the similarly shaped tool used by workers in marble.
The manner or style of execution of an engraver; as, a soft burin; a brilliant burin .

entry.def: One who works with the burin.
The red-breasted house sparrow of California (Carpodacus frontalis); -- called also crimson-fronted bullfinch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burked; p. pr. & vb. n. Burking
entry.ety: From one Burke of Edinburgh, who committed the crime in 1829

sn.def: To murder by suffocation, or so as to produce few marks of violence, for the purpose of obtaining a body to be sold for dissection.
To dispose of quietly or indirectly; to suppress; to smother; to shelve; as, to burke a parliamentary question.
sn.q: The court could not burke an inquiry, supported by such a mass of a affidavits.

entry.def: The practice of killing persons for the purpose of selling their bodies for dissection.

cs.cd: a peculiar kind of nippers or tweezers used in burling woolen cloth.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burled bûrld; p. pr. & vb. n. Burling
entry.ety: OE. burle stuffing, or a knot in cloth; cf. F. bourlet bourrelet, OF. bourel, a wreath or a roll of cloth, linen, or leather, stuffed with flocks, etc., dim. of bourre. √92. See Bur
entry.def: To dress or finish up (cloth); to pick knots, burs, loose threads, etc., from, as in finishing cloth.

sn.def: A knot or lump in thread or cloth.
An overgrown knot, or an excrescence, on a tree; also, veneer made from such excrescences.

entry.def: A coarse fabric, made of jute or hemp, used for bagging; also, a finer variety of similar material, used for curtains, etc.
having an irregular pattern from the grain of a tree burl{2}, or one resembling such a pattern, in contrast to the regular wood grain consisting of parallel or concentric lines; -- of wood.
One who burls or dresses cloth.

entry.ety: F. burlesque, fr. It. burlesco, fr. burla jest, mockery, perh. for burrula, dim. of L. burrae trifles. See Bur
entry.def: Tending to excite laughter or contempt by extravagant images, or by a contrast between the subject and the manner of treating it, as when a trifling subject is treated with mock gravity; jocular; ironical.
entry.q: It is a dispute among the critics, whether burlesque poetry runs best in heroic verse, like that of the Dispensary, or in doggerel, like that of Hudibras.

sn.def: Ludicrous representation; exaggerated parody; grotesque satire.
sn.q: Burlesque is therefore of two kinds; the first represents mean persons in the accouterments of heroes, the other describes great persons acting and speaking like the basest among the people.

sn.def: An ironical or satirical composition intended to excite laughter, or to ridicule anything.
sn.q: The dull burlesque appeared with impudence, And pleased by novelty in spite of sense.

sn.def: A ludicrous imitation; a caricature; a travesty; a gross perversion.
sn.q: Who is it that admires, and from the heart is attached to, national representative assemblies, but must turn with horror and disgust from such a profane burlesque and abominable perversion of that sacred institute?

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burlesqued; p. pr. & vb. n. Burlesquing
entry.def: To ridicule, or to make ludicrous by grotesque representation in action or in language.
entry.q: They burlesqued the prophet Jeremiah's words, and turned the expression he used into ridicule.

entry.def: To employ burlesque.
One who burlesques.

entry.ety: It., dim. of burla mockery. See Burlesque a.
entry.def: A comic operetta; a music farce.
Quality of being burly.

entry.ety: OE. burlich strong, excellent; perh. orig. fit for a lady's bower, hence handsome, manly, stout. Cf. Bower

sn.def: Having a large, strong, or gross body; stout; lusty; -- now used chiefly of human beings, but formerly of animals, in the sense of stately or beautiful, and of inanimate things that were huge and bulky.
sn.q: Burlysacks.
In his latter days, with overliberal diet, [he was] somewhat corpulent and burly.
Burly and big, and studious of his ease.

sn.def: Coarse and rough; boisterous.
sn.q: It was the orator's own burly way of nonsense.

entries.entry:
Bur"man Burma is now (1998) named Myanmar. n.; pl.Burmans. “The softened modern M'yan-ma M'yan-manative name] is the source of the European corruption Burma.” Balfour.
Ethnol A member of the Burman family, one of the four great families Burma; also, sometimes, any inhabitant of Burma; a Burmese.
a. Of or pertaining to the Burmans or to Burmah.

entry.def: the type genus of the Burmanniaceae; slender herbs of warm regions with leaves resembling scales and flowers with a 3-angled or 3-winged perianth.
a natural family of chiefly tropical herbs with basal or bractlike leaves and small flowers.

entries.entry: Bur" mar"i*gold. See Beggar's ticks.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Burmah, or its inhabitants.

def2.def: A native or the natives of Burma (Myanmar). Also (sing.), the language of the Burmans.

entry.def: a language spoken in Northern Burma and Yunnan.

entry.cs:
To burn To burn together, as two surfaces of metal Engin to fuse and unite them by pouring over them a quantity of the same metal in a liquid state. To burn a bowl Game of Bowls to displace it accidentally, the bowl so displaced being said to be burned. To burn daylight to light candles before it is dark; to waste time; to perform superfluous actions. Shak. To burn one's fingers to get one's self into unexpected trouble, as by interfering the concerns of others, speculation, etc. To burn out to destroy or obliterate by burning. “Must you with hot irons burn out mine eyes?” Shak. to force (people) to flee by burning their homes or places of business; as, the rioters burned out the Chinese businessmen.
To be burned out to suffer loss by fire, as the burning of one's house, store, or shop, with the contents.
To burn up To burn down
to burn entirely.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burnedbûrnd) or Burntbûrnt); p. pr. & vb. n. Burning
entry.ety: OE. bernen brennen, v. t., early confused with beornen birnen, v. i., AS. bærnan bernan, v. t., birnan, v. i.; akin to OS. brinnan, OFries. barna berna, OHG. brinnan brennan, G. brennen, OD. bernen, D. branden, Dan. brænde, Sw. bränna brinna, Icel. brenna, Goth. brinnan brannjanin comp.), and possibly to E. fervent

sn.def: To consume with fire; to reduce to ashes by the action of heat or fire; -- frequently intensified by up: as, to burn up wood.
sn.q: We'llburnhis body in the holy place.

sn.def: To injure by fire or heat; to change destructively some property or properties of, by undue exposure to fire or heat; to scorch; to scald; to blister; to singe; to char; to sear; as, to burn steel in forging; to burn one's face in the sun; the sun burns the grass.

To perfect or improve by fire or heat; to submit to the action of fire or heat for some economic purpose; to destroy or change some property or properties of, by exposure to fire or heat in due degree for obtaining a desired residuum, product, or effect; to bake; as, to burn clay in making bricks or pottery; to burn wood so as to produce charcoal; to burn limestone for the lime.
To make or produce, as an effect or result, by the application of fire or heat; as, to burn a hole; to burn charcoal; to burn letters into a block.
To consume, injure, or change the condition of, as if by action of fire or heat; to affect as fire or heat does; as, to burn the mouth with pepper.
sn.q: This tyrant fever burns me up.
This dry sorrow burns up all my tears.
When the cold north wind bloweth, . . . it devoureth the mountains, and burneth the wilderness, and consumeth the ��ass as fire.

sn.def: To apply a cautery to; to cauterize.
To cause to combine with oxygen or other active agent, with evolution of heat; to consume; to oxidize; as, a man burns a certain amount of carbon at each respiration; to burn iron in oxygen.

cs.cd: to be entirely consumed.

sn.def: To be of fire; to flame.
sn.q: The mountburnedwith fire.

sn.def: To suffer from, or be scorched by, an excess of heat.
sn.q: Your meat doth burn, quoth I.

sn.def: To have a condition, quality, appearance, sensation, or emotion, as if on fire or excessively heated; to act or rage with destructive violence; to be in a state of lively emotion or strong desire; as, the face burns; to burn with fever.
sn.q: Did not our heart burn within us, while he talked with us by the way?
The barge she sat in, like a burnished throne,Burned on the water.
Burning with high hope.
The groan still deepens, and the combat burns.
The parching airBurns frore, and cold performs the effect of fire.

sn.def: To combine energetically, with evolution of heat; as, copper burns in chlorine.
In certain games, to approach near to a concealed object which is sought.
A hurt, injury, or effect caused by fire or excessive or intense heat.
The operation or result of burning or baking, as in brickmaking; as, they have a good burn .
A disease in vegetables. See Brand n., 6.

entry.ety: See 1st Bourn
entry.def: A small stream.
Combustible.
See Burnt.
Burnished.

sn.def: drained of energy or effectiveness; driven to apathy by overwork or prolonged stress; -- of people.
sn.syn: burned out(predicate), burnt out(predicate), fagged, exhausted, fatigued, played-out(prenominal), played out(predicate), spent, washed-out(prenominal), washed out(predicate), worn-out(prenominal), worn out(predicate).

sn.def: damaged or destroyed by or as if by fire; as, barricaded the street with burned-out cars.

cs.cd: see Bunsen burner.
etc. See under Argand Rose, etc.

sn.def: One who, or that which, burns or sets fire to anything.
The part of a lamp, gas fixture, etc., where the flame is produced.

entry.cs:
Burnet moth Zoöl in England, a handsome moth (Zygæna filipendula), with crimson spots on the wings. Burnet saxifrage. Bot See Saxifrage. Canadian burnet a marsh plant (Poterium Canadensis).
Great burnet Wild burnet
Poterium oficinalisorSanguisorba oficinalis).
entry.ety: OE. burnet burnet; also, brownish (the plant perh. being named from its color), fr. F. brunet, dim. of brun brown; cf. OF. brunete a sort of flower. See Brunette
entry.def: A genus of perennial herbs (Poterium); especially, Poterium Sanguisorba, the common, or garden, burnet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burnettized; p. pr. & vb. n. Burnettizing
entry.def: To subject (wood, fabrics, etc.) to a process of saturation in a solution of chloride of zinc, to prevent decay; -- a process invented by Sir William Burnett .

entry.ety: See 4th Burn
entry.def: A small brook.
The ladybird.

cs.cd: an ornamental shrub (Euonymus atropurpureus), bearing a crimson berry.

sn.def: That burns; being on fire; excessively hot; fiery.
Consuming; intense; inflaming; exciting; vehement; powerful; as, burning zeal.
sn.q: Like a young hound upon a burning scent.

cs.cd: any volatile illuminating oil, as the lighter petroleums (naphtha, benzine), or oil of turpentine (camphine), but esp. a mixture of the latter with alcohol.
a convex lens of considerable size, used for producing an intense heat by converging the sun's rays to a focus.
the furnace in which tin ores are calcined, to sublime the sulphur and arsenic from the pyrites.
a concave mirror, or a combination of plane mirrors, used for the same purpose as a burning glass.

entry.def: The act of consuming by fire or heat, or of subjecting to the effect of fire or heat; the state of being on fire or excessively heated.

cs.cd: a machine for smoothing and polishing by compression, as in making paper collars.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burnished; p. pr. & vb. n. Burnishing
entry.ety: OE. burnischen burnissen burnen, OF. burnir brunir, to make brown, polish, F. brunir, fr. F. brun brown, fr. OHG. br�n; cf. MHG. briunen to make brown, polish. See Brown a.
entry.def: To cause to shine; to make smooth and bright; to polish; specifically, to polish by rubbing with something hard and smooth; as, to burnish brass or paper.
entry.q: The frame of burnished steel, that east a glare From far, and seemed to thaw the freezing air.
Now the village windows blaze,Burnished by the setting sun.

entry.def: To shine forth; to brighten; to become smooth and glossy, as from swelling or filling out; hence, to grow large.
entry.q: A slender poet must have time to grow, And spread and burnish as his brothers do.
My thoughts began to burnish, sprout, and swell.

entry.def: The effect of burnishing; gloss; brightness; luster.

sn.def: One who burnishes.
A tool with a hard, smooth, rounded end or surface, as of steel, ivory, or agate, used in smoothing or polishing by rubbing. It has a variety of forms adapted to special uses.

entry.ety: Ar. burnus a kind of high-crowned cap: cf. F. bournous burnous, Sp. al-bornoz, a sort of upper garment, with a hood attached

sn.def: A cloaklike garment and hood woven in one piece, worn by Arabs.
A combination cloak and hood worn by women.
To burn till the fuel is exhausted; as, when the candle burned out the room was totally dark; the firefighters couldn't control the oil tank fire and had to let it burn out by itself.
To stop functioning due to failure of some component caused by the heat of the electrical current used in its operation; -- of electrical devices.

To become apathetic or depressed, and cease to function effectively, due to the fatigue and frustration of prolonged stress and overwork; -- of people; as, the stress in the bond market is so great that many traders burn out after only ten years on the job.

entry.def: A stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus).

cs.cd: a black, powdery fungus which destroys grain. See Smut.

something offered and burnt on an altar, as an atonement for sin; a sacrifice. The offerings of the Jews were a clean animal, as an ox, a calf, a goat, or a sheep; or some vegetable substance, as bread, or ears of wheat or barley. Called also burnt sacrifice.

entry.def: Consumed with, or as with, fire; scorched or dried, as with fire or heat; baked or hardened in the fire or the sun.
a high-speed motorcycle race on a public road.
the amount of fuel used up (as in a nuclear reactor).
to same as belch; as, In China it is polite to burp at the table.
to cause to belch; -- used especially of actions parents take to relieve stomach gas in infants; as, mother fed and burped the baby, and put her to bed.
