a reflex that expels wind noisily from the stomach through the mouth.

entry.ety: See Bur

sn.def: A prickly seed vessel. See Bur, 1.
The thin edge or ridge left by a tool in cutting or shaping metal, as in turning, engraving, pressing, etc.; also, the rough neck left on a bullet in casting.
sn.q: The graver, in plowing furrows in the surface of the copper, raises corresponding ridges or burrs.

sn.def: A thin flat piece of metal, formed from a sheet by punching; a small washer put on the end of a rivet before it is swaged down.
A broad iron ring on a tilting lance just below the gripe, to prevent the hand from slipping.
The lobe or lap of the ear.

A guttural pronounciation of the letter r, produced by trilling the extremity of the soft palate against the back part of the tongue; rotacism; -- often called the Newcastle burr Northumberland burr, or Tweedside burr.
The knot at the bottom of an antler. See Bur n., 8.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burred; p. pr. & vb. n. Burring
entry.def: To speak with burr; to make a hoarse or guttural murmur.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. burel reddish (cf. Borel n.), or F. beurré butter pear, fr. beurre butter. Cf. Butter
entry.def: A sort of pear, called also the red butter pear, from its smooth, delicious, soft pulp.
Same as Borrel.

entries.entry:
Bur"rel fly`. From its reddish color. See 1st Burrel
Zoöl The botfly or gadfly of cattle (Hypoderma bovis). See Gadfly.

Bur"rel shot`. Either from annoying the enemy like a burrel fly, or, less probably, fr. F. bourreler to sting, torture Gun A mixture of shot, nails, stones, pieces of old iron, etc., fired from a cannon at short range, in an emergency. R

entry.def: any of several fishes having rigid flattened spines.

entries.entry: Burr"ing ma*chine". A machine for cleansing wool of burs, seeds, and other substances.

entry.def: a flour tortilla folded around a filling.

entries.entry: Burr" mill"stone`. See Buhrstone.

entry.ety: Sp., an ass
entry.def: A donkey.

entry.ety: Perh. from AS. burg burh, hill + -ock
entry.def: A small weir or dam in a river to direct the stream to gaps where fish traps are placed.

entry.ety: See 1st Borough

sn.def: An incorporated town. See 1st Borough.
A shelter; esp. a hole in the ground made by certain animals, as rabbits, for shelter and habitation.
A heap or heaps of rubbish or refuse.
A mound. See 3d Barrow, and Camp n., 5.

cs.cd: a small owl of the western part of North America (Speotyto cunicularia), which lives in holes, often in company with the prairie dog.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burrowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Burrowing

sn.def: To excavate a hole to lodge in, as in the earth; to lodge in a hole excavated in the earth, as conies or rabbits.
To lodge, or take refuge, in any deep or concealed place; to hide.
sn.q: Sir, this vermin of court reporters, when they are forced into day upon one point, are sure to burrow in another.

entry.def: One who, or that which, burrows; an animal that makes a hole under ground and lives in it.
See Buhrstone.
Abounding in burs, or containing burs; resembling burs; as, burry wool.

entries.entry:
Bur"sa Bur"sa n.; pl.Bursæ. L. See Burse
Anat Any sac or saclike cavity; especially, one of the synovial sacs, or small spaces, often lined with synovial membrane, interposed between tendons and bony prominences.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a bursa or to bursæ.

entry.ety: LL. bursarius, fr. bursa purse. See Burse, and cf. Purser

sn.def: A treasurer, or cash keeper; a purser; as, the bursar of a college, or of a monastery.
A student to whom a stipend or bursary is paid for his complete or partial support.

entry.def: The office of a bursar.

entries.entry:
Bur"sa*ry n.; pl.-ries. LL. bursaria. See Bursar
The treasury of a college or monastery.
A scholarship or charitable foundation in a university, as in Scotland; a sum given to enable a student to pursue his studies. No woman of rank or fortune but would have abursaryin her gift.

Bursch Bursch n.; pl.Burschen. G., ultimately fr. LL. bursa. See Burse
A youth; especially, a student in a german university.

Bur"schen*schaft` Bur"schen*schaft`
Bur"schen*schaft`ler # Bur"schen*schaf`ter # n.
n.; pl. -schaften # . G In Germany, any of various associations of university students formed (the original one at Jena in 1815) to support liberal ideas, or the organization formed by the affiliation of the local bodies. The organization was suppressed by the government in 1819, but was secretly revived, and is now openly maintained as a social organization, the restrictive laws having been repealed prior to 1849.

entry.ety: LL. bursa, or F. bourse. See Bourse, and cf. Bursch Purse

sn.def: A purse; also, a vesicle; a pod; a hull.
A fund or foundation for the maintenance of needy scholars in their studies; also, the sum given to the beneficiaries.
An ornamental case of hold the corporal when not in use.
An exchange, for merchants and bankers, in the cities of continental Europe. Same as Bourse.
A kind of bazaar.
sn.q: She says she went to the burse for patterns.

entry.def: a natural family of resinous or aromatic chiefly tropical shrubs or trees.

entry.ety: See Burse
entry.def: Bursiform.

entry.ety: LL. bursa purse + -form
entry.def: Shaped like a purse.

entry.ety: NL., fr. E. bursa + -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of a bursa.

entry.note: Often used figuratively, as of the heart, in reference to a surcharge of passion, grief, desire, etc.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Burst; p. pr. & vb. n. Bursting. The past participle bursten is obsolete
entry.ety: OE. bersten bresten, AS. berstanpers. sing. berste, imp. sing. bærst, imp. pl. burston, p. p. borsten); akin to D. bersten, G. bersten, OHG. brestan, OS. brestan, Icel. bresta, Sw. brista, Dan. briste. Cf. Brast Break

sn.def: To fly apart or in pieces; of break open; to yield to force or pressure, especially to a sudden and violent exertion of force, or to pressure from within; to explode; as, the boiler had burst; the buds will burst in spring.
sn.q: From the egg that soonBursting with kindly rupture, forth disclosed Their callow young.
No, no, my heart will burst, an if I speak: And I will speak, that so my heart may burst.

sn.def: To exert force or pressure by which something is made suddenly to give way; to break through obstacles or limitations; hence, to appear suddenly and unexpectedly or unaccountably, or to depart in such manner; -- usually with some qualifying adverb or preposition, as forth out away into upon through, etc.
sn.q: Tears, such as angels weep, burst forth.
And now you burstah cruel!) from my arms.
A resolved villain Whose bowels suddenly burst out.
We were the first that ever burst Into that silent sea.
To burst upon him like an earthquake.

entry.cs: Bursting charge. See under Charge.

sn.def: To break or rend by violence, as by an overcharge or by strain or pressure, esp. from within; to force open suddenly; as, to burst a cannon; to burst a blood vessel; to burst open the doors.
sn.q: My breast I'll burst with straining of my courage.

sn.def: To break.
sn.q: You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?
He burst his lance against the sand below.

sn.def: To produce as an effect of bursting; as, to burst a hole through the wall.
A sudden breaking forth; a violent rending; an explosion; as, a burst of thunder; a burst of applause; a burst of passion; a burst of inspiration.
sn.q: Bursts of fox-hunting melody.

sn.def: Any brief, violent exertion or effort; a spurt; as, a burst of speed.
A sudden opening, as of landscape; a stretch; an expanse.
sn.q: A fineburstof country.

sn.def: A rupture or hernia; a breach.

entry.def: p. p. of Burst v. i.
One that bursts.
A plant (Herniaria glabra) supposed to be valuable for the cure of hernia or rupture.
See Birt.
See Burden.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. & Prov. E. bort to press or indent anything
entry.def: A peculiar tackle, formed of two or more blocks, or pulleys, the weight being suspended to a hook block in the bight of the running part.

sn.def: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Burundi; as, the Burundi capital.
of, pertaining to, or characteristic of the Burundian people; as, the Burundian population.

entry.def: a native or inhabitant of Burundi.
a terrestrial Siberian squirrel (Eutamius asiaticus or Eutamius sibiricus).

entry.note: used as a termination of names of places; as, Canterbury, Shrewsbury .
entry.ety: See 1st Borough
entry.sn: A borough; a manor; as, the Bury of St. Edmond's ;

sn.def: A manor house; a castle.
sn.q: To this very day, the chief house of a manor, or the lord's seat, is called bury, in some parts of England.

cs.cd: the general name of many species of beetles, of the tribe Necrophaga; the sexton beetle; -- so called from their habit of burying small dead animals by digging away the earth beneath them. The larvæ feed upon decaying flesh, and are useful scavengers.
to lay aside the instruments of war, and make peace; -- a phrase used in allusion to the custom observed by the North American Indians, of burying a tomahawk when they conclude a peace.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Buried; p. pr. & vb. n. Burying
entry.ety: OE. burien birien berien, AS. byrgan; akin to beorgan to protect, OHG. bergan, G. bergen, Icel. bjarga, Sw. berga, Dan. bierge Goth. baírgan. √95. Cf. Burrow

sn.def: To cover out of sight, either by heaping something over, or by placing within something, as earth, etc.; to conceal by covering; to hide; as, to bury coals in ashes; to bury the face in the hands.
sn.q: And all their confidence Under the weight of mountains buried deep.

sn.def: Specifically: To cover out of sight, as the body of a deceased person, in a grave, a tomb, or the ocean; to deposit (a corpse) in its resting place, with funeral ceremonies; to inter; to inhume.
sn.q: Lord, suffer me first to go and bury my father.
I'll bury thee in a triumphant grave.

sn.def: To hide in oblivion; to put away finally; to abandon; as, to bury strife.
sn.q: Give me a bowl of wine In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.
sn.syn: To intomb; inter; inhume; inurn; hide; cover; conceal; overwhelm; repress.

entries.entry: Bur"y*ing ground` Bur"y*ing place . The ground or place for burying the dead; burial place.

entry.ety: Abbreviated from omnibus
entry.def: An omnibus.
an electrical conductor that makes a common connection between several circuits.

entries.entry: Bus"by bŭz"b� n.; pl.Busbies bĭz. Mil A military headdress or cap, used in the British army. It is of fur, with a bag, of the same color as the facings of the regiment, hanging from the top over the right shoulder.

entry.ety: Sp., a searcher, fr. buscar to search
entry.def: One who searches for ores; a prospector.

entry.note: ☞ This was the original sense of the word, as in the Dutch bosch, a wood, and was so used by Chaucer. In this sense it is extensively used in the British colonies, especially at the Cape of Good Hope, and also in Australia and Canada; as, to live or settle in the bush.
entry.cs:
To beat about the bush to approach anything in a round-about manner, instead of coming directly to it; -- a metaphor taken from hunting. Bush bean Bot a variety of bean which is low and requires no support (Phaseolus vulgaris, variety nanus). See Bean, 1.
Bush buckorBush goat
Zoöl a beautiful South African antelope (Tragelaphus sylvaticus); -- so called because found mainly in wooden localities. The name is also applied to other species. Bush cat Zoöl the serval. See Serval. Bush chat Zoöl a bird of the genus Pratincola, of the Thrush family. Bush dog. Zoöl See Potto. Bush hammer. See Bushhammer in the Vocabulary. Bush harrow Agric See under Harrow. Bush hog Zoöl a South African wild hog (Potamochœrus Africanus); -- called also bush pig, and water hog. Bush master Zoöl a venomous snake (Lachesis mutus) of Guinea; -- called also surucucu. Bush pea Bot a variety of pea that needs to be bushed. Bush shrike Zoöl a bird of the genus Thamnophilus, and allied genera; -- called also batarg. Many species inhabit tropical America. Bush tit Zoöl a small bird of the genus Psaltriparus, allied to the titmouse. Psaltriparus minimus inhabits California.
entry.ety: OE. bosch busch buysch bosk busk; akin to D. bosch, OHG. busc, G. busch, Icel. būskr būski, Dan. busk, Sw. buske, and also to LL. boscus buscus, Pr. bosc, It. bosco, Sp. & Pg. bosque, F. bois, OF. bos. Whether the LL. or G. form is the original is uncertain; if the LL., it is perh. from the same source as E. box a case. Cf. Ambush Boscage Bouquet Box a case

sn.def: A thicket, or place abounding in trees or shrubs; a wild forest.
A shrub; esp., a shrub with branches rising from or near the root; a thick shrub or a cluster of shrubs.
sn.q: To bind a bush of thorns among sweet-smelling flowers.

sn.def: A shrub cut off, or a shrublike branch of a tree; as, bushes to support pea vines.
A shrub or branch, properly, a branch of ivy (as sacred to Bacchus), hung out at vintners' doors, or as a tavern sign; hence, a tavern sign, and symbolically, the tavern itself.
sn.q: If it be true that good wine needs no bush, 't is true that a good play needs no epilogue.

sn.def: The tail, or brush, of a fox.

entry.def: To branch thickly in the manner of a bush.
entry.q: Thebushingalders.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bushedbụsht); p. pr. & vb. n. Bushing

sn.def: To set bushes for; to support with bushes; as, to bush peas.
To use a bush harrow on (land), for covering seeds sown; to harrow with a bush; as, to bush a piece of land; to bush seeds into the ground.

entry.note: ☞ In the larger machines, such a piece is called a box, particularly in the United States.
entry.ety: D. bus a box, akin to E. box; or F. boucher to plug

sn.def: A lining for a hole to make it smaller; a thimble or ring of metal or wood inserted in a plate or other part of machinery to receive the wear of a pivot or arbor.
A piece of copper, screwed into a gun, through which the venthole is bored.

entry.def: To furnish with a bush, or lining; as, to bush a pivot hole.

sn.def: any of several agile long-tailed nocturnal African lemurlike primates of the genus Galago with dense woolly fur and large eyes and ears; -- called also galago.
antelope with white harnesslike markings and twisted horns.

entry.def: See Bushman.
very tired from exertion.
entry.syn: all in(predicate), beat(predicate), dead(predicate), dead tired(predicate), knocked out(predicate).

entry.note: ☞ The Winchester bushel, formerly used in England, contained 2150.42 cubic inches, being the volume of a cylinder 181/2 inches in internal diameter and eight inches in depth. The standard bushel measures, prepared by the United States Government and distributed to the States, hold each 77.6274 pounds of distilled water, at 39.8° Fahr. and 30 inches atmospheric pressure, being the equivalent of the Winchester bushel. The imperial bushel now in use in England is larger than the Winchester bushel, containing 2218.2 cubic inches, or 80 pounds of water at 62° Fahr.

☞ In the United States a large number of articles, bought and sold by the bushel, are measured by weighing, the number of pounds that make a bushel being determined by State law or by local custom. For some articles, as apples, potatoes, etc., heaped measure is required in measuring a bushel.
entry.ety: OE. buschel boischel, OF. boissel bussel boistel, F. boisseau, LL. bustellus; dim. of bustia buxidaOF. boiste), fr. pyxida, acc. of L. pyxis box, Gr. pyxi`s. Cf. Box

sn.def: A dry measure, containing four pecks, eight gallons, or thirty-two quarts.
A vessel of the capacity of a bushel, used in measuring; a bushel measure.
sn.q: Is a candle brought to be put under a bushel, or under a bed, and not to be set on a candlestick?

sn.def: A quantity that fills a bushel measure; as, a heap containing ten bushels of apples.
A large indefinite quantity.
sn.q: The worthies of antiquity bought the rarest pictures with bushels of gold, without counting the weight or the number of the pieces.

sn.def: The iron lining in the nave of a wheel. Eng In the United States it is called a box. See 4th Bush.

entry.ety: Cf. G. bosseln
entry.def: To mend or repair, as men's garments; to repair garments.
A duty payable on commodities by the bushel.
A tailor's assistant for repairing garments; -- called also busheler.

entry.ety: See Bosket
entry.def: A small bush.
One accustomed to bushfighting.
Fighting in the bush, or from behind bushes, trees, or thickets.
A hammer with a head formed of a bundle of square bars, with pyramidal points, arranged in rows, or a solid head with a face cut into a number of rows of such points; -- used for dressing stone.
To dress with bushhammer; as, to bushhammer a block of granite.

entry.ety: Jap. bu military + shi knight + dō way, doctrine, principle
entry.def: The unwritten code of moral principles regulating the actions of the Japanese knighthood, or Samurai; the chivalry of Japan.
entry.q: Unformulated, Bushido was and still is the animating spirit, the motor force of our country.

entry.def: The condition or quality of being bushy.

entry.ety: See 4th Bush

sn.def: The operation of fitting bushes, or linings, into holes or places where wear is to be received, or friction diminished, as pivot holes, etc.
A bush or lining; -- sometimes called a thimble. See 4th Bush.

entry.def: Free from bushes; bare.
entry.q: O'er the long backs of the bushless downs.

entries.entry:
Bush"man n.; pl.Bushmen. Cf. D. boschman boschjesman. See 1st Bush
A woodsman; a settler in the bush.
Ethnol One of a race of South African nomads, living principally in the deserts, and not classified as allied in race or language to any other people.

entry.ety: OE. busshement ambush, fr. bush

sn.def: A thicket; a cluster of bushes.
An ambuscade.

entry.def: One who roams, or hides, among the bushes; especially, in Australia, an escaped criminal living in the bush.
to lie in ambush for, lie in wait for.
entry.syn: ambush, scupper, lie for, waylay, lurk, ambuscade.

sn.def: to live in the bush as a fugitive or as a guerilla.
to cut one's way through the woods or bush.
One accustomed to beat about, or travel through, bushes.
sn.q: They were gallant bushwhackers, and hunters of raccoons by moonlight.

sn.def: A guerrilla; a marauding assassin; one who pretends to be a peaceful citizen, but secretly harasses a hostile force or its sympathizers.
Traveling, or working a way, through bushes; pulling by the bushes, as in hauling a boat along the bushy margin of a stream.
The crimes or warfare of bushwhackers.

entry.ety: From 1st Bush

sn.def: Thick and spreading, like a bush.
sn.q: Bushyeyebrows.

sn.def: Full of bushes; overgrowing with shrubs.
sn.q: Dingle, or bushy dell, of this wild wood.

entry.def: In a busy manner.

entries.entry:
Busi"ness
To do one's business to ruin one. Colloq Wycherley. To make (a thing) one's business to occupy one's self with a thing as a special charge or duty. Colloq To mean business to be earnest. Colloq
bĭz"nĕs n.; pl.Businesses bĭz"nĕs*ĕz. From Busy
That which busies one, or that which engages the time, attention, or labor of any one, as his principal concern or interest, whether for a longer or shorter time; constant employment; regular occupation; as, the business of life; business before pleasure. Wist ye not that I must be about my Father's business?
Any particular occupation or employment engaged in for livelihood or gain, as agriculture, trade, art, or a profession. Thebusinessof instruction.
Financial dealings; buying and selling; traffic in general; mercantile transactions. It seldom happens that men of a studious turn acquire any degree of reputation for their knowledge of business.
That which one has to do or should do; special service, duty, or mission. The daughter of the King of France, On serious business, craving quick despatch, Importunes personal conference. What business has the tortoise among the clouds?
Affair; concern; matter; -- used in an indefinite sense, and modified by the connected words. It was a gentle business, and becoming The action of good women. Bestow Your needful counsel to our business.
Drama The position, distribution, and order of persons and properties on the stage of a theater, as determined by the stage manager in rehearsal.
Care; anxiety; diligence. Obs Affairs; concern; transaction; matter; engagement; employment; calling; occupation; trade; profession; vocation; office; duty.

entry.def: In the manner of one transacting business wisely and by right methods; practical and efficient.

sn.def: serious and purposeful.

entry.note: This term is seldom applied to technical specialists, unless they are part of upper management.
entry.def: a person employed in a business at a managerial level, especially an executive or proprietor.
a female businessman.

entry.ety: F. busc, perh. fr. the hypothetical older form of E. bois wood, because the first busks were made of wood. See Bush, and cf. OF. busche, F. bûche, a piece or log of wood, fr. the same root
entry.def: A thin, elastic strip of metal, whalebone, wood, or other material, worn in the front of a corset.
entry.q: Her long slit sleeves, stiff busk, puff verdingall, Is all that makes her thus angelical.

entry.def: Among the Creek Indians, a feast of first fruits celebrated when the corn is ripe enough to be eaten. The feast usually continues four days. On the first day the new fire is lighted, by friction of wood, and distributed to the various households, an offering of green corn, including an ear brought from each of the four quarters or directions, is consumed, and medicine is brewed from snakeroot. On the second and third days the men physic with the medicine, the women bathe, the two sexes are taboo to one another, and all fast. On the fourth day there are feasting, dancing, and games.

entry.ety: OE. busken, fr. Icel. būask to make one's self ready, rexlexive of būa to prepare, dwell. Cf. 8th Bound

sn.def: To prepare; to make ready; to array; to dress.
sn.q: Busk you, busk you, my bonny, bonny bride.

sn.def: To go; to direct one's course.
sn.q: Ye might have busked you to Huntly banks.

entry.def: Wearing a busk.
a person who entertains people for money in public places (as by singing or dancing).

entry.ety: See Bosket Bouquet

sn.def: A small bush; also, a sprig or bouquet.
A part of a garden devoted to shrubs.

entry.ety: Prob. from OF. brossequin, or D. broosken. See Brodekin

sn.def: A strong, protecting covering for the foot, coming some distance up the leg.
sn.q: The hunted red deer's undressed hide Their hairy buskins well supplied.

sn.def: A similar covering for the foot and leg, made with very thick soles, to give an appearance of elevation to the stature; -- worn by tragic actors in ancient Greece and Rome. Used as a symbol of tragedy, or the tragic drama, as distinguished from comedy.
sn.q: Great Fletcher never treads in buskins here, No greater Jonson dares in socks appear.

sn.def: Wearing buskins.
sn.q: Her buskined virgins traced the dewy lawn.

sn.def: Trodden by buskins; pertaining to tragedy.
sn.q: Thebuskinedstage.

entry.def: See Bosky, and 1st Bush n.

entry.ety: OE. basse, fr. L. basium; cf. G. bus Luther), Prov. G. busserl, dim. of bus kiss, bussen to kiss, Sw. puss kiss, pussa to kiss, W. & Gael. bus lip, mouth
entry.def: A kiss; a rude or playful kiss; a smack.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bussed bŭst; p. pr. & vb. n. Bussing
entry.def: To kiss; esp. to kiss with a smack, or rudely.
entry.q: Norbussedthe milking maid.
Kissing and bussing differ both in this, We buss our wantons, but our wives we kiss.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. busse, Pr. bus, LL. bussa busa, G. büse, D. buis
entry.def: A small strong vessel with two masts and two cabins; -- used in the herring fishery.
entry.q: The Dutch whalers and herring busses.

entry.ety: F. buste, fr. It. busto; cf. LL. busta bustula, box, of the same origin as E. box a case; cf., for the change of meaning, E. chest. See Bushel

sn.def: A piece of sculpture representing the upper part of the human figure, including the head, shoulders, and breast.
sn.q: Ambition sighed: she found it vain to trust The faithless column, and the crumbling bust.

sn.def: The portion of the human figure included between the head and waist, whether in statuary or in the person; the chest or thorax; the upper part of the trunk of the body.
A woman's bosom{2}.

entry.def: To arrest, for committing a crime; -- often used in the passive; as, the whole gang got busted .

cs.cd: to go bankrupt.
or collapse from the effort; -- used in phrases expressing determination to do something; as, Oregon or bust, meaning “We will get to Oregon or die trying.”

sn.def: To break or burst.
In blackjack, to draw a card that causes one's total to exceed twenty-one.
To go bankrupt.

entry.note: ☞ The great or bearded bustard Otis tarda) is the largest game bird in Europe. It inhabits the temperate regions of Europe and Asia, and was formerly common in Great Britain. The little bustard Otis tetrax) inhabits eastern Europe and Morocco. Many other species are known in Asia and Africa.
entry.ety: OF. & Prov. F. bistarde, F. outarde, from L. avis tarda, lit., slow bird. Plin. 10, 22; “proximæ iis sunt, quas Hispania aves tardas appellat, Græcia 'wti`das.”
entry.def: A bird of the genus Otis.

sn.def: Inoperable due to damage; broken; -- of a machine; as, the coke machine is busted .
Arrested for committing a crime; -- of a person; as, the rock star was busted for coke possession..
same as demoted; -- said especially of military rank, and often folowed by to; as, he was busted to corporal for being AWOL.
same as exhausted; -- of people.

entry.def: Something huge; a roistering blade; also, a spree.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bustled-s'ld); p. pr. & vb. n. Bustling-slĭng)
entry.ety: Cf. OE. buskle, perh. fr. AS. bysig busy, bysg-ian to busy + the verbal termination -le; or Icel. bustla to splash, bustle
entry.def: To move noisily; to be rudely active; to move in a way to cause agitation or disturbance; as, to bustle through a crowd.
entry.q: And leave the world for me to bustle in.

entry.def: Great stir; agitation; tumult from stirring or excitement.
entry.q: A strange bustle and disturbance in the world.

entry.def: A kind of pad or cushion worn on the back below the waist, by women, to give fullness to the skirts; -- called also bishop, and tournure.
An active, stirring person.
Agitated; noisy; tumultuous; characterized by confused activity; as, a bustling crowd.
entry.q: Abustlingwharf.

entries.entry: Bus"to Bus"to n.; pl.Bustoes. It A bust; a statue.

entry.def: a serious quarrel (especially one that ends a friendship).
entry.q: With some antick bustoes in the niches.

entry.ety: OE. busi bisi, AS. bysig; akin to D. bezig, LG. besig; cf. Skr. bhūsh to be active, busy

sn.def: Engaged in some business; hard at work (either habitually or only for the time being); occupied with serious affairs; not idle nor at leisure; as, a busy merchant.
sn.q: Sir, my mistress sends you word That she is busy, and she can not come.

sn.def: Constantly at work; diligent; active.
sn.q: Busy hammers closing rivets up.
Religious motives . . . are so busy in the heart.

sn.def: Crowded with business or activities; -- said of places and times; as, a busy street.
sn.q: To-morrow is a busy day.

sn.def: Officious; meddling; foolish active.
sn.q: On meddling monkey, or on busy ape.

sn.def: Careful; anxious.
sn.syn: Diligent; industrious; assiduous; active; occupied; engaged.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Busied bĭz"zĭd; p. pr. & vb. n. Busying
entry.ety: AS. bysgian
entry.def: To make or keep busy; to employ; to engage or keep engaged; to occupy; as, to busy one's self with books.
entry.q: Be it thy course to busy giddy minds With foreign quarrels.

entry.def: intruding unasked into the affairs of others.

entries.entry: Bus"y*bod`y -bŏd`� n.; pl.Busybodies -bŏd`ĭz. One who officiously concerns himself with the affairs of others; a meddling person. And not only idle, but tattlers also and busybodies, speaking things which they ought not.

entry.def: the state of being or appearing to be actively engaged in an activity; as, they manifested all the busyness of a pack of beavers.
active work of little value, performed merely to occupy time, avoid boredom, or to look busy; as, while he was waiting he filled the days with busywork .

entry.note: ☞ In this sense, but is often used with other particles; as, but for, without, had it not been for. “Uncreated but for love divine.” Young.
entry.cs: All but. See under All. But and if but if; an attempt on the part of King James's translators of the Bible to express the conjunctive and adversative force of the Greek �.

cs.cd: unless.
cs.q: But this I read, that but if remedy Thou her afford, full shortly I her dead shall see.

entry.usage: These conjunctions mark opposition in passing from one thought or topic to another. But marks the opposition with a medium degree of strength; as, this is not winter, but it is almost as cold; he requested my assistance, but I shall not aid him at present. However is weaker, and throws the opposition (as it were) into the background; as, this is not winter; it is, however, almost as cold; he required my assistance; at present, however, I shall not afford him aid. The plan, however, is still under consideration, and may yet be adopted. Still is stronger than but, and marks the opposition more emphatically; as, your arguments are weighty; still they do not convince me. See Except However.
entry.note: ☞ “The chief error with but is to use it where and is enough; an error springing from the tendency to use strong words without sufficient occasion.”
entry.ety: OE. bute buten, AS. būtan, without, on the outside, except, besides; pref. be- + ūtan outward, without, fr. ūt out. Primarily, būtan, as well as ūt, is an adverb. √198. See By Out; cf. About

sn.def: Except with; unless with; without.
sn.q: So insolent that he could not go but either spurning equals or trampling on his inferiors.
Touch not the cat but a glove.

sn.def: Except; besides; save.
sn.q: Who can it be, ye gods! but perjured Lycon?

sn.def: Excepting or excluding the fact that; save that; were it not that; unless; -- elliptical, for but that.
sn.q: And but my noble Moor is true of mind . . . it were enough to put him to ill thinking.

sn.def: Otherwise than that; that not; -- commonly, after a negative, with that.
sn.q: It cannot be but nature hath some director, of infinite power, to guide her in all her ways.
There is no question but the king of Spain will reform most of the abuses.

sn.def: Only; solely; merely.
sn.q: Observe but how their own principles combat one another.
If they kill us, we shall but die.
A formidable man but to his friends.

sn.def: On the contrary; on the other hand; only; yet; still; however; nevertheless; more; further; -- as connective of sentences or clauses of a sentence, in a sense more or less exceptive or adversative; as, the House of Representatives passed the bill, but the Senate dissented; our wants are many, but quite of another kind.
sn.q: Now abideth faith hope, charity, these three; but the greatest of these is charity.
When pride cometh, then cometh shame; but with the lowly is wisdom.
But and if that servant say in his heart, My lord delayeth his coming; . . . the lord of that servant will come in a day when he looketh not for him.

entry.ety: Cf. But prep., adv. & conj.
entry.def: The outer apartment or kitchen of a two-roomed house; -- opposed to ben, the inner room.

cs.cd: the larger or thicker end; as, the but end of a log; the but end of a musket. See Butt n.

entry.ety: See 1st But

sn.def: A limit; a boundary.
The end; esp. the larger or thicker end, or the blunt, in distinction from the sharp, end. Now disused in this sense, being replaced by butt2}. See 1st Butt.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Butted; p. pr. & vb. n. Butting
entry.def: See Butt v., and Abut v.

a white crystalline ester (C18H30N2O2) that is applied to mucous membranes as a topical anesthetic. Chemically it is 3-(di-n-butylamino)-1-propanol 4-aminobenzoate H2N.C6H4.CO.O.(CH2)3N(C4H9)2). It is usually used as the sulfate salt.
a gaseous hydrocarbon C4H6; -- it is used as a monomer unit in making synthetic rubbers.

entry.ety: L. butyrum butter. See Butter
entry.def: An inflammable gaseous saturated hydrocarbon, C4H10, of the marsh gas, or paraffin, series.
a flammable alcohol (C4H9.OH) derived from butane and used as a solvent.

sn.def: markedly masculine in appearance or manner; -- used of men.
same as lesbian.

entry.def: a lesbian who is noticeably masculine.

cs.cd: such flesh of animals slaughtered for food as is sold for that purpose by butchers, as beef, mutton, lamb, and pork.

entry.ety: OE. bochere bochier, OF. bochier, F. boucher, orig., slaughterer of buck goats, fr. OF. boc, F. bouc, a buck goat; of German or Celtic origin. See Buck the animal

sn.def: One who slaughters animals, or dresses their flesh for market; one whose occupation it is to kill animals for food.
A slaughterer; one who kills in large numbers, or with unusual cruelty; one who causes needless loss of life, as in battle.
sn.q: Butcherof an innocent child.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Butchered; p. pr. & vb. n. Butchering

sn.def: To kill or slaughter (animals) for food, or for market; as, to butcher hogs.
To murder, or kill, especially in an unusually bloody or barbarous manner.
sn.q: Ithocles] was murdered, rather butchered.

sn.def: to bungle badly; to botch; -- used also when an object is damaged (literally or figuratively) in an activity; as, the new choir butchered the hymn.

entry.note: ☞ The Lanius excubitor is the common butcher bird of Europe. In England, the bearded tit is sometimes called the lesser butcher bird. The American species are Lanius borealis, or northern butcher bird, and Lanius Ludovicianus or loggerhead shrike. The name butcher bird is derived from its habit of suspending its prey impaled upon thorns, after killing it.

sn.def: any species of shrike of the genus Lanius, so called because they impale their prey on thorns.
large carnivorous Australian bird with the shrikelike habit of impaling prey on thorns.
The business of a butcher.
The act of slaughtering; the act of killing cruelly and needlessly.
sn.q: That dreadful butchering of one another.

entry.def: Butchery quality.
Like a butcher; without compunction; savage; bloody; inhuman; fell.
entry.q: The victim of abutcherlymurder.
What stratagems, how fell, how butcherly, This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!

entries.entry: Butch"er's broom`. Bot A genus of plants (Ruscus); esp. Ruscus aculeatus, which has large red berries and leaflike branches. See Cladophyll.

entry.ety: OE. bocherie shambles, fr. F. boucherie. See Butcher n.

sn.def: The business of a butcher.
Murder or manslaughter, esp. when committed with unusual barbarity; great or cruel slaughter.
sn.q: The perpetration of human butchery.

sn.def: A slaughterhouse; the shambles; a place where blood is shed.
sn.q: Like as an ox is hanged in the butchery.

entry.def: a genus of East Indian trees or shrubs: dhak.
any of three isomeric singly unsaturated hydrocarbons C4H8; all are used in making synthetic rubbers; -- called also butylene.
a genus of broad-winged soaring hawks.
relating to or resembling a hawk of the genus Buteo.
any hawk of the genus Buteo.

entry.ety: OE. boteler, F. bouteillier a bottle-bearer, a cupbearer, fr. LL. buticularius, fr. buticula bottle. See Bottle a hollow vessel
entry.def: An officer in a king's or a nobleman's household, whose principal business it is to take charge of the liquors, plate, etc.; the head servant in a large house.
entry.q: The butler and the baker of the king of Egypt.
Your wine locked up, your butler strolled abroad.

entry.def: A duty of two shillings on every tun of wine imported into England by merchant strangers; -- so called because paid to the king's butler for the king.
The office of a butler.

cs.cd: the part of a mortised timber surrounding the mortise, and against which the shoulders of the tenon bear.

entry.ety: Abbreviation of Abutment

sn.def: A buttress of an arch; the supporter, or that part which joins it to the upright pier.
The mass of stone or solid work at the end of a bridge, by which the extreme arches are sustained, or by which the end of a bridge without arches is supported.

entry.note: ☞ As applied to land, the word is nearly synonymous with mete, and signifies properly the end line or boundary; the abuttal.
entry.cs: Butt chain Saddlery a short chain attached to the end of a tug. Butt end. The thicker end of anything. See But end, under 2d But.

A butt's length the ordinary distance from the place of shooting to the butt, or mark. Butts and bounds Conveyancing abuttals and boundaries. In lands of the ordinary rectangular shape, butts are the lines at the endsF. bouts), and bounds are those on the sides, or sidings, as they were formerly termed. Burrill. Bead and butt. See under Bead. Butt and butt joining end to end without overlapping, as planks. Butt weld Mech a butt joint, made by welding together the flat ends, or edges, of a piece of iron or steel, or of separate pieces, without having them overlap. See Weld. Full butt headfirst with full force. Colloq “The corporal . . . ran full butt at the lieutenant.” Marryat.
entry.ety: F. but butt, aim (cf. butte knoll), or bout, OF. bot, end, extremity, fr. boter buter, to push, butt, strike, F. bouter; of German origin; cf. OHG. bōzan, akin to E. beat. See Beat v. t.

sn.def: A limit; a bound; a goal; the extreme bound; the end.
sn.q: Here is my journey's end, here my butt And very sea mark of my utmost sail.

sn.def: The larger or thicker end of anything; the blunt end, in distinction from the sharp end; as, the butt of a rifle. Formerly also spelled but. See 2nd but n. sense 2.
A mark to be shot at; a target.
sn.q: The groom his fellow groom at butts defies, And bends his bow, and levels with his eyes.

sn.def: A person at whom ridicule, jest, or contempt is directed; as, the butt of the company.
sn.q: I played a sentence or two at my butt, which I thought very smart.

sn.def: A push, thrust, or sudden blow, given by the head of an animal; as, the butt of a ram.
A thrust in fencing.
sn.q: To prove who gave the fairer butt, John shows the chalk on Robert's coat.

sn.def: A piece of land left unplowed at the end of a field.
sn.q: The hay was growing upon headlands and butts in cornfields.

sd.def: A joint where the ends of two objects come squarely together without scarfing or chamfering; -- also called butt joint.
The end of a connecting rod or other like piece, to which the boxing is attached by the strap, cotter, and gib.
The portion of a half-coupling fastened to the end of a hose.

sn.def: The joint where two planks in a strake meet.

A kind of hinge used in hanging doors, etc.; -- so named because fastened on the edge of the door, which butts against the casing, instead of on its face, like the strap hinge; also called butt hinge.
The thickest and stoutest part of tanned oxhides, used for soles of boots, harness, trunks.
The hut or shelter of the person who attends to the targets in rifle practice.
The buttocks; as, get up off your butt and get to work; -- used as a euphemism, less objectionable than ass.
sn.syn: ass, rear end, derriere, behind, rump, heinie.
sn.q: Amen; and make me die a good old man! That's the butt end of a mother's blessing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Butted; p. pr. & vb. n. Butting
entry.ety: OE. butten, OF. boter to push, F. bouter. See Butt an end, and cf. Boutade

sn.def: To join at the butt, end, or outward extremity; to terminate; to be bounded; to abut.
sn.q: And Barnsdale there doth butt on Don's well-watered ground.

sn.def: To thrust the head forward; to strike by thrusting the head forward, as an ox or a ram. [See Butt n.
sn.q: A snow-white steer before thine altar led,Butts with his threatening brows.

entry.def: To strike by thrusting the head against; to strike with the head.
entry.q: Two harmless lambs are butting one the other.

entry.note: ☞ A wine butt contains 126 wine gallons (= 105 imperial gallons, nearly); a beer butt 108 ale gallons (= about 110 imperial gallons).
entry.ety: F. botte boute, LL. butta. Cf. Bottle a hollow vessel
entry.def: A large cask or vessel for wine or beer. It contains two hogsheads.
The common English flounder.

entry.ety: F. See Butt a bound
entry.def: A detached low mountain, or high rising abruptly from the general level of the surrounding plain; -- applied to peculiar elevations in the Rocky Mountain region.
entry.q: The creek . . . passes by two remarkable buttes of red conglomerate.

cs.cd: a small vessel for holding melted butter at table.
the buttercup, a yellow flower.
a piece of carved wood used to mark pats of butter; -- called also butter stamp.
either of the two middle incisors of the upper jaw.

a tree of the genus Bassia, the seeds of which yield a substance closely resembling butter. The butter tree of India is the Bassia butyracea; that of Africa is the Shea tree (Bassia Parkii). See Shea tree.
a tool used in sampling butter.
a woman who makes or sells butter; -- called also butter woman.

entry.ety: OE. botere butter, AS. butere, fr. L. butyrum, Gr. boy`turon; either fr. boy`s ox, cow + turo`s cheese; or, perhaps, of Scythian origin. Cf. Cow

sn.def: An oily, unctuous substance obtained from cream or milk by churning.

Any substance resembling butter in degree of consistence, or other qualities, especially, in old chemistry, the chlorides, as butter of antimony, sesquichloride of antimony; also, certain concrete fat oils remaining nearly solid at ordinary temperatures, as butter of cacao vegetable butter shea butter.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Buttered�); p. pr. & vb. n. Buttering

sn.def: To cover or spread with butter.
sn.q: I know what's what. I know on which side My bread is buttered.

sn.def: To increase, as stakes, at every throw or every game.

entry.def: One who, or that which, butts.

a name given to several perennial plants having showy flowers of two shades of yellow, or of yellow and orange, such as Narcissus incomparabilis in Europe, and the toadflax (Linaria vulgaris) in the United States; the latter is a naturalized weed in North America.
entry.syn: toadflax, wild snapdragon, devil's flax, Linaria vulgaris.

sn.def: The buffel duck.
a fat person or animal.
a lump of butter rounded into a ball.
a plump chicken or turkey prepared for cooking.

entry.def: The rice bunting or bobolink; -- so called in the island of Jamaica.

entry.ety: OE. buttur the bittern + 5th bump
entry.def: The European bittern.
A broad-leaved plant (Petasites vulgaris) of the Composite family, said to have been used in England for wrapping up pats of butter.
A plant of the genus Ranunculus, or crowfoot, particularly Ranunculus bulbosus, with bright yellow flowers; -- called also butterflower golden cup, and kingcup. It is the cuckoobud of Shakespeare.
the fatty substance of milk from which butter is made.
Apt to let things fall, or to let them slip away; not skillful in using the hands; slippery; careless.
entry.syn: bumbling, bungling, ham-fisted, ham-handed, handless, heavy-handed, left-handed.

entry.def: someone who drops things (especially one who cannot catch a ball); a person who is butter-fingered.

A name given to several different fishes, in allusion to their slippery coating of mucus, as the Stromateus triacanthus of the Atlantic coast, the Epinephelus punctatus of the southern coast, the rock eel, and the kelpfish of New Zealand.
any of various plants of the genus Ranunculus.

entries.entry:
But"ter*fly` See Illust. under Aphrodite
Asclepias butterfly. See under Asclepias. Butterfly fish Zoöl the ocellated blenny (Blennius ocellaris) of Europe. See Blenny. The term is also applied to the flying gurnard. Butterfly shell Zoöl a shell of the genus Voluta. Butterfly valve Mech a kind of double clack valve, consisting of two semicircular clappers or wings hinged to a cross rib in the pump bucket. When open it somewhat resembles a butterfly in shape.
n.; pl.Butterflies. Perh. from the color of a yellow species. AS. buter-flēge buttor-fleóge; cf. G. butterfliege, D. botervlieg. See Butter, and Fly
Zoöl A general name for the numerous species of diurnal Lepidoptera.

entry.def: tropical gurnardlike fish with huge fanlike pectoral fins for underwater gliding; unrelated to searobins.
A substance prepared from animal fat with some other ingredients intermixed, as an imitation of butter.
entry.q: The manufacturers ship large quantities of oleomargarine to England, Holland, and other countries, to be manufactured into butter, which is sold as butterine or suine.

entry.ety: The same word as buttress, noun, in a different application, F. bouter to push
entry.def: A steel cutting instrument, with a long bent shank set in a handle which rests against the shoulder of the operator. It is operated by a thrust movement, and used in paring the hoofs of horses.

entries.entry: But"ter*man` n.; pl.Buttermen. A man who makes or sells butter.

entry.def: The milk that remains after the butter is separated from the cream.

sn.def: An American tree (Juglans cinerea) of the Walnut family, and its edible fruit; -- so called from the oil contained in the latter. Sometimes called oil nut and white walnut.
The nut of the Caryocar butyrosum and Caryocar nuciferum, of S. America; -- called also Souari nut.

entry.def: tall annual herb or subshrub of tropical Asia having velvety leaves and yellow flowers and yielding a strong fiber; naturalized in SE Europe and US.
entry.syn: velvetleaf, velvetweed, Indian mallow, China jute, Abutilon theophrasti.

entry.def: A kind of candy, mainly composed of sugar and butter.
An annual composite plant of the Mississippi valley (Senecio lobatus).

entry.note: ☞ Formerly it was a custom to give 18 ounces of butter for a pound.
entry.def: Over weight.

A genus of low herbs (Pinguicula) having simple leaves which secrete from their glandular upper surface a viscid fluid, to which insects adhere, after which the margin infolds and the insects are digested by the plant. The species are found mostly in the North Temperate zone.
Having the qualities, consistence, or appearance, of butter.

entries.entry:
But"ter*y
Buttery hatch a half door between the buttery or kitchen and the hall, in old mansions, over which provisions were passed. Wright.
n.; pl.Butteries. OE. botery botry; cf. LL. botaria wine vessel; also OE. botelerie, fr. F. bouteillerie, fr. boutellie bottle. Not derived from butter. See Bottle a hollow vessel, Butt a cask
An apartment in a house where butter, milk and other provisions are kept. All that need a cool and fresh temper, as cellars, pantries, and butteries, to the north.
A room in some English colleges where liquors, fruit, and refreshments are kept for sale to the students. And the major Oxford kept the buttery bar.
A cellar in which butts of wine are kept.
Butt" hinge`. See 1st Butt, 10.

entry.def: The common European starfish (Asterias rubens).
An abuttal; a boundary.
entry.q: Without buttings or boundings on any side.

entries.entry: But"ting joint`. A joint between two pieces of timber or wood, at the end of one or both, and either at right angles or oblique to the grain, as the joints which the struts and braces form with the truss posts; -- sometimes called abutting joint.
Butt" joint`. A joint in which the edges or ends of the pieces united come squarely together instead of overlapping. See 1st Butt, 8.

entry.ety: From Butt an end

sn.def: The part at the back of the hip, which, in man, forms one of the rounded protuberances on which he sits; the rump. Often used in the plural -- see buttocks.
The convexity of a ship behind, under the stern.

entry.def: the fleshy part of the human body at the back of the hip, on which a person sits.
entry.syn: arse, butt, backside, bum, buns, can, fundament, hindquarters, hind end, keister, posterior, prat, rear, rear end, rump, stern, seat, tail, tail end, tooshie, tush, bottom, behind, derriere, fanny, ass.

entry.cs: Button hook a hook for catching a button and drawing it through a buttonhole, as in buttoning boots and gloves. Button shell Zoöl a small, univalve marine shell of the genus Rotella. Button snakeroot. Bot The American composite genus Liatris, having rounded buttonlike heads of flowers. An American umbelliferous plant with rigid, narrow leaves, and flowers in dense heads. Button tree Bot a genus of trees (Conocarpus), furnishing durable timber, mostly natives of the West Indies. To hold by the button to detain in conversation to weariness; to bore; to buttonhole.
entry.ety: OE. boton botoun, F. bouton button, bud, prop. something pushing out, fr. bouter to push. See Butt an end

sn.def: A knob; a small ball; a small, roundish mass.

A catch, of various forms and materials, used to fasten together the different parts of dress, by being attached to one part, and passing through a slit, called a buttonhole, in the other; -- used also for ornament.
A bud; a germ of a plant.
A piece of wood or metal, usually flat and elongated, turning on a nail or screw, to fasten something, as a door.
A globule of metal remaining on an assay cupel or in a crucible, after fusion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Buttoned; p. pr. & vb. n. Buttoning
entry.ety: OE. botonen, OF. botoner, F. boutonner. See Button n.

sn.def: To fasten with a button or buttons; to inclose or make secure with buttons; -- often followed by up.
sn.q: He was a tall, fat, long-bodied man, buttoned up to the throat in a tight green coat.

sn.def: To dress or clothe.

entry.def: To be fastened by a button or buttons; as, the coat will not button .
See Buttonwood.
A shrub (Cephalanthus occidentalis) growing by the waterside; -- so called from its globular head of flowers. See Capitulum.

entries.entry: buttoned adj. furnished with buttons or something buttonlike. Opposite of unbuttoned.Narrower terms: botonee, botonnee; button-down; closed

entry.def: conservatively formal and businesslike in dress and manner.
entry.q: a colorful character in the buttoned-down, dull-gray world of business.

sn.def: taciturn. Opposite of voluble.
conservative in professional manner; as, employers are looking for buttoned-up types.

entry.def: The hole or loop in which a button is caught.
To hold at the button or buttonhole; to detain in conversation to weariness; to bore; as, he buttonholed me a quarter of an hour.

cs.cd: joints of encrinites. See Encrinite.

entry.def: A disk of bone, wood, or other material, which is made into a button by covering it with cloth.
A boy servant, or page, -- in allusion to the buttons on his livery.
The name of several plants of the genera Spermacoce and Diodia, of the Madder family.

The Platanus occidentalis, or American plane tree, a large tree, producing rough balls, from which it is named; -- called also buttonball tree, and, in some parts of the United States, sycamore. The California buttonwood is Platanus racemosa.
Ornamented with a large number of buttons.
entry.q: Thebuttonyboy.
My coat so blue andbuttony.

entry.note: ☞ When an external projection is used merely to stiffen a wall, it is a pier.
entry.cs: Flying buttress. See Flying buttress.
entry.ety: OE. butrasse boterace, fr. F. bouter to push; cf. OF. bouteretnom. sing. and acc. pl. bouterez) buttress. See Butt an end, and cf. Butteris

sn.def: A projecting mass of masonry, used for resisting the thrust of an arch, or for ornament and symmetry.
Anything which supports or strengthens.
sn.q: The ground pillar andbuttressof the good old cause of nonconformity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Buttressed�); p. pr. & vb. n. Buttressing
entry.def: To support with a buttress; to prop; to brace firmly.
entry.q: To set it upright again, and to prop and buttress it up for duration.

entry.def: An arrow without a barb, for shooting at butts; an arrow.

entries.entry: Butt" weld`. See Butt weld, under Butt.

entry.def: To unite by a butt weld.
One who mines by contract, at so much per ton of coal or ore.

entry.ety: L. butyrum butter + -yl. See Butter
entry.def: A compound radical, regarded as butane, less one atom of hydrogen.

entry.ety: Butyric + -yl + amine
entry.def: A colorless liquid base, C4H9.NH2, of which there are four isomeric varieties.
to introduce the butyl group into (a chemical compound).

entry.ety: From Butyl

sn.def: Any one of three metameric hydrocarbons, C4H8, of the ethylene series. They are gaseous or easily liquefiable; -- called also butene.
the hypothetical divalent radical -(CH2)4-; -- used in combining forms; as, butylene diamine.

entry.def: A volatile liquid, C4H9.SH, having a strong odor like that of a skunk; also called butanethiol. All three isomers, normal, sec-, and tert-butanethiol possess the skunk odor.

entry.ety: L. butyrum butter. See Butter
entry.def: Having the qualities of butter; resembling butter.
A salt of butyric acid.

cs.cd: C3H7.CO2H, an acid found in butter; an oily, limpid fluid, having the smell of rancid butter, and an acrid taste, with a sweetish aftertaste, like that of ether. There are two metameric butyric acids, called in distinction the normal- and iso-butyric acid. The normal butyric acid is the one common in rancid butter.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, butter.
A butyrate of glycerin; a fat contained in small quantity in milk, which helps to give to butter its peculiar flavor.

entry.ety: L. butyrum butter + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for determining the amount of fatty matter or butter contained in a sample of milk.

entry.ety: Butyric + -one
entry.def: A liquid ketone obtained by heating calcium butyrate.
Butyraceous.

entry.ety: Butyric + -yl
entry.def: The radical (C3H7.CO-) of butyric acid.

entry.ety: L. buxeus, fr. buxus the box tree
entry.def: Belonging to the box tree.
An alkaloid obtained from the Buxus sempervirens, or common box tree. It is identical with bebeerine; -- called also buxina.

entry.ety: OE. buxum boxom buhsum, pliable, obedient, AS. bōcsum būhsumakin to D. buigzaam blexible, G. biegsam); būgan to bow, bend + -sum, E. -some. See Bow to bend, and -some

sn.def: Yielding; pliable or compliant; ready to obey; obedient; tractable; docile; meek; humble.
sn.q: So wild a beast, so tame ytaught to be, And buxom to his bands, is joy to see.
I submit myself unto this holy church of Christ, to be ever buxom and obedient to the ordinance of it.

sn.def: Having the characteristics of health, vigor, and comeliness, combined with a gay, lively manner; stout and rosy; jolly; frolicsome.
sn.q: A daughter fair, So buxom, blithe, and debonair.
A parcel of buxom bonny dames, that were laughing, singing, dancing, and as merry as the day was long.

sn.def: having a pronounced womanly shape.
sn.syn: bosomy, curvaceous, full-bosomed, sonsie, sonsy, voluptuous.

entry.def: the type genus of the Buxaceae.

entry.cs: To buy again. See Againbuy. Obs Chaucer. To buy off. To influence to compliance; to cause to bend or yield by some consideration; as, to buy off conscience. To detach by a consideration given; as, to buy off one from a party. To buy out To buy off, or detach from. Shak. To purchase the share or shares of in a stock, fund, or partnership, by which the seller is separated from the company, and the purchaser takes his place; as, A buys out B. To purchase the entire stock in trade and the good will of a business. To buy in to purchase stock in any fund or partnership. To buy on credit to purchase, on a promise, in fact or in law, to make payment at a future day. To buy the refusalof anything), to give a consideration for the right of purchasing, at a fixed price, at a future time.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Bought b�t; p. pr. & vb. n. Buying bī"ĭng
entry.ety: OE. buggen buggen bien, AS. bycgan, akin to OS. buggean, Goth. bugjan

sn.def: To acquire the ownership of (property) by giving an accepted price or consideration therefor, or by agreeing to do so; to acquire by the payment of a price or value; to purchase; -- opposed to sell.
sn.q: Buy what thou hast no need of, and ere long thou wilt sell thy necessaries.

sn.def: To acquire or procure by something given or done in exchange, literally or figuratively; to get, at a cost or sacrifice; to buy pleasure with pain.
sn.q: Buy the truth and sell it not; also wisdom, and instruction, and understanding.

entry.def: To negotiate or treat about a purchase.
entry.q: I will buy with you, sell with you.

entry.def: One who buys; a purchaser.
the act of buying; as, buying equipment for the trip took several hours.
the acquisition of ownership of a company by purchasing a controlling percentage of its stock.
to take over ownership of; -- of corporations and companies.
See Buzz.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Buzzed bŭzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Buzzing
entry.ety: An onomatopœia
entry.def: To make a low, continuous, humming or sibilant sound, like that made by bees with their wings. Hence: To utter a murmuring sound; to speak with a low, humming voice.
entry.q: Like a wasp is buzzed, and stung him.
However these disturbers of our peaceBuzz in the people's ears.

sn.def: To sound forth by buzzing.
To whisper; to communicate, as tales, in an under tone; to spread, as report, by whispers, or secretly.
sn.q: I will buzz abroad such prophecies That Edward shall be fearful of his life.

sn.def: To talk to incessantly or confidentially in a low humming voice.
To sound with a “buzz”.
A continuous, humming noise, as of bees; a confused murmur, as of general conversation in low tones, or of a general expression of surprise or approbation.
sn.q: The constantbuzzof a fly.
I found the whole room in a buzz of politics.
There is a buzz all around regarding the sermon.

sn.def: A whisper; a report spread secretly or cautiously.
sn.q: There's a certain buzz Of a stolen marriage.

sn.def: The audible friction of voice consonants.

entry.note: ☞ The Buteo vulgaris is the common buzzard of Europe. The American species (of which the most common are Buteo borealis Buteo Pennsylvanicus, and Buteo lineatus) are usually called hen hawks. -- The rough-legged buzzard, or bee hawk, of Europe (Pernis apivorus) feeds on bees and their larvæ, with other insects, and reptiles. -- The moor buzzard of Europe is Circus æruginosus. See Turkey buzzard, and Carrion buzzard.

cs.cd: the fishhawk or osprey. See Fishhawk.

entry.ety: O.E. busard bosard, F. busard, fr. buse, L. buteo, a kind of falcon or hawk

sn.def: A bird of prey of the Hawk family, belonging to the genus Buteo and related genera.
In the United States, a term used for the turkey vulture Cathartes aura), and sometimes indiscriminately to any vulture.
A blockhead; a dunce.
sn.q: It is common, to a proverb, to call one who can not be taught, or who continues obstinately ignorant, a buzzard.

entry.def: Senseless; stupid.
A hawk resembling the buzzard, but with legs relatively longer.
One who, or that which, buzzes; a whisperer; a talebearer.
entry.q: And wants not buzzers to infect his ear With pestilent speeches of his father's death.

entry.def: In a buzzing manner; with a buzzing sound.
A circular saw; -- so called from the buzzing it makes when running at full speed.

entry.ety: a Trademark
entry.def: men's underwear.
biological warfare; the use of bacteria or viruses or toxins to destroy men and animals or food.
a boiling water reactor; a type of nuclear reactor that uses water as a coolant and moderator; -- the steam produced can drive a steam turbine and produce electrical power.

entry.note: To the meaning of by, as denoting means or agency, belong, more or less closely, most of the following uses of the word: It points out the author and producer; as, “Waverley”, a novel by Sir W.Scott; a statue by Canova; a sonata by Beethoven. In an oath or adjuration, it indicates the being or thing appealed to as sanction; as, I affirm to you by all that is sacred; he swears by his faith as a Christian; no, by Heaven. According to; by direction, authority, or example of; after; -- in such phrases as, it appears by his account; ten o'clock by my watch; to live by rule; a model to build by. At the rate of; according to the ratio or proportion of; in the measure or quantity of; as, to sell cloth by the yard, milk by the quart, eggs by the dozen, meat by the pound; to board by the year. In comparison, it denotes the measure of excess or deficiency; when anything is increased or diminished, it indicates the measure of increase or diminution; as, larger by a half; older by five years; to lessen by a third. It expresses continuance or duration; during the course of; within the period of; as, by day, by night. As soon as; not later than; near or at; -- used in expressions of time; as, by this time the sun had risen; he will be here by two o'clock.

In boxing the compass, by indicates a pint nearer to, or towards, the next cardinal point; as, north by east, i.e., a point towards the east from the north; northeast by east, i.e., on point nearer the east than northeast is.

☞ With is used instead of by before the instrument with which anything is done; as, to beat one with a stick; the board was fastened by the carpenter with nails. But there are many words which may be regarded as means or processes, or, figuratively, as instruments; and whether with or by shall be used with them is a matter of arbitrary, and often, of unsettled usage; as, to a reduce a town by famine; to consume stubble with fire; he gained his purpose by flattery; he entertained them with a story; he distressed us with or by a recital of his sufferings. see With.
entry.cs: By all means most assuredly; without fail; certainly. By and by. Close together (of place). Obs “Two yonge knightes liggyng [lyingby and by.” Chaucer. Immediately; at once. Obs “When . . . persecution ariseth because of the word, by and by he is offended.” Matt. xiii. 21. Presently; pretty soon; before long. In this phrase, by seems to be used in the sense of nearness in time, and to be repeated for the sake of emphasis, and thus to be equivalent to “soon, and soon,” that is instantly; hence, -- less emphatically, -- pretty soon, presently. By one's self with only one's self near; alone; solitary.- By the bye. See under Bye. By the head Naut having the bows lower than the stern; -- said of a vessel when her head is lower in the water than her stern. If her stern is lower, she is by the stern. By the lee the situation of a vessel, going free, when she has fallen off so much as to bring the wind round her stern, and to take her sails aback on the other side. By the run to let go by the run, to let go altogether, instead of slacking off. By the way by the bye; -- used to introduce an incidental or secondary remark or subject. - Day by day One by one Piece by piece, etc. each day, each one, each piece, etc., by itself singly or separately; each severally. To come by to get possession of; to obtain. To do by to treat, to behave toward. To set by to value, to esteem. To stand by to aid, to support.
entry.note: ☞ The common phrase good-by is equivalent to farewell, and would be better written good-bye, as it is a corruption of God be with you b'w'ye).
entry.ety: OE. bi, AS. bī big, near to, by, of, from, after, according to; akin to OS. & OFries. bi be, D. bij, OHG. bī, G. bei, Goth. bi, and perh. Gr. 'amfi`. E. prefix be- is orig. the same word. √203. See pref. Be-

sn.def: In the neighborhood of; near or next to; not far from; close to; along with; as, come and sit by me.
sn.q: By foundation or by shady rivulet He sought them both.

sn.def: On; along; in traversing. Compare 5.
sn.q: Long labors both by sea and land he bore.
By land, by water, they renew the charge.

sn.def: Near to, while passing; hence, from one to the other side of; past; as, to go by a church.
Used in specifying adjacent dimensions; as, a cabin twenty feet by forty.
Against.
With, as means, way, process, etc.; through means of; with aid of; through; through the act or agency of; as, a city is destroyed by fire; profit is made by commerce; to take by force.
Near; in the neighborhood; present; as, there was no person by at the time.
Passing near; going past; past; beyond; as, the procession has gone by; a bird flew by .
Aside; as, to lay by; to put by .

entry.def: Out of the common path; aside; -- used in composition, giving the meaning of something aside, secondary, or incidental, or collateral matter, a thing private or avoiding notice; as, by-line, by-place, by-play, by-street. It was formerly more freely used in composition than it is now; as, by-business, by-concernment, by-design, by-interest, etc.
A piece of leather crossing the breast, used by the men who drag sledges in coal mines.
One who bids at an auction in behalf of the auctioneer or owner, for the purpose of running up the price of articles.

sn.def: A side or incidental blow; an accidental blow.
sn.q: With their by-blows they did split the very stones in pieces.

sn.def: An illegitimate child; a bastard.
sn.q: The Aga speedily . . . brought her [his disgraced slave] to court, together with her pretty by-blow, the present Padre Ottomano.

entry.def: A private corner.
entry.q: Britain being a by-corner, out of the road of the world.

entry.def: An appendage; that which depends on something else, or is distinct from the main dependence; an accessory.
A drinking between meals.

cs.cd: in passing; by way of digression; apropos to the matter in hand.

sn.def: A thing not directly aimed at; something which is a secondary object of regard; an object by the way, etc.; as in on or upon the byei. e., in passing; indirectly; by implication.
sn.mark: Obs. except in the phrase by the bye
sn.q: The Synod of Dort condemneth upon the bye even the discipline of the Church of England.

sn.def: A run made upon a missed ball; as, to steal a bye .

In various sports in which the contestants are drawn in pairs, the position or turn of one left with no opponent in consequence of an odd number being engaged; as, to draw a bye in a round of a tennis tournament.
The hole or holes of a stipulated course remaining unplayed at the end of a match.

entry.ety: AS. bȳ; cf. Icel. bygð dwelling, byggja būa, to dwell √97

sn.def: A dwelling.
In certain games, a station or place of an individual player.

entry.def: An election held by itself, not at the time of a general election.
a European country east of Poland, formerly a part of the Soviet Union. After the breakup of the Soviet Union the name was changed to Belarus.

sn.def: a native or inhabitant of Byelorussia.
the language spoken in Belarus.

entry.def: Private end or interest; secret purpose; selfish advantage.
entry.q: “Profit or some other by-end.”

entry.def: Past; gone by.
entry.q: Bygonefooleries.

cs.cd: let the past be forgotten.

entry.def: Something gone by or past; a past event.
entry.q: Let oldbygonesbe

entry.def: Self-interest; private advantage.
A peninsula.
See Bilander.
A private lane, or one opening out of the usual road.

entry.ety: Cf. Sw. bylag, D. bylov, Icel. bȳarlög, fr. Sw. & Dan. by town, Icel. bær byrfr. bûa to dwell) + the word for law; hence, a law for one town, a special law. Cf. Birlaw and see Law

sn.def: A local or subordinate law; a private law or regulation made by a corporation for its own government.
sn.q: There was likewise a law to restrain the by-laws, or ordinances of corporations.
The law or institution; to which are added two by-laws, as a comment upon the general law.

sn.def: A law that is less important than a general law or constitutional provision, and subsidiary to it; a rule relating to a matter of detail; as, civic societies often adopt a constitution and by-laws for the government of their members. In this sense the word has probably been influenced by by, meaning secondary or aside.

entry.def: A nickname.
To give a nickname to.
A by-passage, for a pipe, or other channel, to divert circulation from the usual course.
A passage different from the usual one; a byway.
Past; gone by.
entry.q: By-pastperils.

entries.entry: By"path` n.; pl.Bypaths. A private path; an obscure way; indirect means. God known, my son, By what bypaths, and indirect crooked ways, I met this crown.

entry.def: A retired or private place.
Action carried on aside, and commonly in dumb show, while the main action proceeds.
A secondary or additional product; something produced, as in the course of a manufacture, in addition to the principal product.

entry.ety: Cf, Icel. bür pantry, Sw. bur cage, Dan. buur, E. bower
entry.def: A cow house.
Private end or view; by-interest.
A private or obscure road.
entry.q: Through slipperybyroads

entry.def: Pertaining to, or in the style of, Lord Byron.
entry.q: With despair and Byronic misanthropy.

entry.def: A private room or apartment.
entry.q: Stand in someby-room

entry.ety: See Besmut
entry.def: Bespotted with mud or dirt.
An incidental or casual speech, not directly relating to the point.

entry.ety: From Byssus

entry.ety: Byssus + -ferous
entry.def: Bearing a byssus or tuft.
See Byssus n., 1.

entry.ety: L. byssinus made of byssus, Gr. by`ssinos See Byssus
entry.def: Made of silk; having a silky or flaxlike appearance.

entry.ety: Byssus + -oid
entry.def: Byssaceous.

entry.def: An olive-green fibrous variety of hornblende.

entries.entry:
Bys"sus Bys"sus n.; pl. E. Byssuses; L. Byssi. L. byssus fine flax, fine linen or cotton, Gr. by`ssos
A cloth of exceedingly fine texture, used by the ancients. It is disputed whether it was of cotton, linen, or silk.
byss byssin
Zoöl A tuft of long, tough filaments which are formed in a groove of the foot, and issue from between the valves of certain bivalve mollusks, as the Pinna and Mytilus, by which they attach themselves to rocks, etc.
Bot An obsolete name for certain fungi composed of slender threads.
Asbestus.

entry.ety: By + stander, equiv. to stander-by; cf. AS. big-standan to stand by or near
entry.def: One who stands near; a spectator; one who has no concern with the business transacting.
entry.q: He addressed the bystanders and scattered pamphlets among them.

entry.def: A separate, private, or obscure street; an out of the way or cross street.
entry.q: He seeks by-streets, and saves the expensive coach.

entry.def: An accidental or a slyly given stroke.
An obscure road; a way turning from the main road.
A private or selfish view; self-interested aim or purpose.
entry.q: No by-views of his own shall mislead him.

entry.def: A secluded or private walk.
entry.q: He moves afterward in by-walks.

entry.def: The outlet from a dam or reservoir; also, a cut to divert the flow of water.
A secluded, private, or obscure way; a path or road aside from the main one.
entry.q: Take nobyways.

entry.def: A secret or side stroke, as of raillery or sarcasm.

entry.ety: AS. bïword; bï, E. by + word

sn.def: A common saying; a proverb; a saying that has a general currency.
sn.q: I knew a wise man that had it for a byword.

sn.def: The object of a contemptuous saying.
sn.q: Thou makest us a byword among the heathen.

entry.def: Work aside from regular work; subordinate or secondary business.

entry.ety: OE. besant besaunt, F. besant, fr. LL. Byzantius Byzantinus, fr. Byzantium
entry.def: A gold coin, so called from being coined at Byzantium. See Bezant.
See Byzantine.

cs.cd: the Eastern or Greek church, as distinguished from the Western or Roman or Latin church. See under Greek.
the Eastern Roman or Greek empire from a. d. 364 or a. d. 395 to the capture of Constantinople by the Turks, a. d. 1453.
historians and writers (Zonaras, Procopius, etc.) who lived in the Byzantine empire.
a style of architecture developed in the Byzantine empire.
cs.note: Its leading forms are the round arch, the dome, the pillar, the circle, and the cross. The capitals of the pillars are of endless variety, and full of invention. The mosque of St. Sophia, Constantinople, and the church of St. Mark, Venice, are prominent examples of Byzantine architecture.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Byzantium.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Byzantium, now Constantinople; sometimes, applied to an inhabitant of the modern city of Constantinople.

entry.def: The doctrine that the state is supreme over the church in ecclesiastical matters.
An ancient city on the Bosporus founded by the Greeks. It was later renamed Constaninople in honor of the emperor Constantine, and renamed Istanbul by the Turks, which name it still retains.
